Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exiiibitions. A Multitude Of Exhibitions Open To The Public To-Day-The Loan Collection At Guildhall, The Socicty Of British Artists In Suffolk-Street, The Three Annual Displays At The Bottom Of The Haymarket, A Collection Of Fine Water-Colours At Mlessrs. Vokinss In Great Portland-Street, A Pleasant Little Gathlering Of Old English Pictures Shown By M.Essrs. Shepherd In Pall-Mall While A Display Of French Pictures Has Been Newly Opened By M.Bernheim In Piccadilly. Leaving The First And The Most Important Of These For A Future Article, We May Briefly Deal With The Others. The Suffolk-Street Galleries Are Once Niore Filled With The Pictures And Drawings Of The Members Of The Society Of British Artists And Of The Not Very Ambitioas Outsiders Wvho Care To Exhibit There. Since The Time Of Its Brief Whistlerian Interliide The Society Has Relapsed Into Something Like The Respectable Dulness Of Its Earlier Time, Though Here And There We Find Upon Its Walls Pictures That Command Attention, Like The Landscapes Cf M.R. Yeend King And Mr. W. S. Jay, The Scenes Of River And Sea Shown By Messrs. Nelson Dawson, Arnold Priestman, And Lifr. Llewellyn, Bits Of Colour By M.R. John Reid And F. Parker, A Few Striking Water-Colours By Mr. F. Davis, Genre Pictures By Mr. J. A. Lomax, And Portraits Or Lifesize Figure Subjects By Mir. Lubert Vos. Probably The Best Picture Bere, From The Painters Point Of Viewv, Is The Faith Of The Last-Named Artist, Who, Unfortunately, Cannot Be Claimed As British, Except By Residence. Ihe Is An Admirable Draughtsman-Witness The Hands In The John Otto Macqueen, Esq. 581 While The Face Of The Old Woman At Her Devotions 140 Is Full Of Expression And Is First-Rate In Painting. Mr. Yeend King Has More Than Once Made His Mark By Large And Elaborately-Painted Landscapes Shown At The Royal Academy, And, Although His Position In The Front Rank Has Not Yet Been Assured, There Are Great Hopes Of His Attaining To It. What He Seems To Want As Yet Is That Power Of Simplification Wvhidh Is Essential To Every Artist, And To The Landscape-Painter Most Of All. Mr. W. S. Jay For Once Deserts His Beech-Woods, Though Not His Wild Pigeons. In The Pea-Field 188 These Beautiful And Always Hungry Creatures Occupy The Foreground In A Wide Landscape, Painted With Much Intelligence. Mr. Dawson, Mr. Llewellyn, And Air. Alfred Hartley All Paint The Late Twilight For These Artists, Like So Many Others Of Their Generation, Are Fond Of Half Tones, And Seem To Avoid The Sunlight As Though It Zvere Almost Vulgar. Their Pictures Have An Undoubted Charm, And Mr. Llewellyns Sketch Of St. Ivos 329 Is Among The Most Artistic Of The Pictures Here. But Theso Artists Belong To A School, And There Are Many Like Them. Mr. Sheiwood Hunter, On The Other Hand, Is Entirely Individual, Though Certain Analogies With His Work Arc To Be Found In That Of Some Of The French Paintets Of The Day. It Is Hard And Over-Emphatic But In The Portraitstudy Of An Old Dutchwvoman Who Has Fallen Asleep Over Her Spinning 313 There Are Remarkable Qualities. If Mir. Hunter, Who Is Evidently A Great Lover Of Rembrandt, Could Add Something Of Rembrandts Atmosphere To Such Work As This, His Pictures Would Be Less Eccentric But More Valuable. Mlr. Yllean Shows Somewhat Fewer Pictures Than Usual, But In Four Cases At Least These Are Of Higher Quality Than Are Commonly To Be Seen In Private Exhibitions, Messrs. Van Haanen, Peter Graham, Henry Moore, And Leon Lliermite Being Represented By Quite First-Rate Examples. No Artist Worlks Mcre Capriciously Or Produces Less Than Mr. Van 3Aanen, Who Follows The Very Permissible Rule Of Only Painting When The Fancy Takes Him, And Whose Pictures Are Therefore As Rare As They Are Admirable. It Is Two Or Three Years At Jeast Since Any New Work From His Hand Was Seen In London, And Now That Be Has Sent An Important Picture Oue Recognizes Once More How Easilv, As Far As Sheer Power Of Painting Goes, He Distances All His Venetian Competitors. The Subject Which The Catalogue Christeds T Dark And Fair Is Simply A Couple Of Girls In The Venetian Dress Of The Present Daythat Is, With Abundance Of Brilliant Colour In Their Gowns And Shawls As Well As In Their Faces Van Haanen Revels In Colour, And The Red Shawl Of The Darl Girl Has Given Him A Splendid Oppcrtunity, Of Which He Has Taken Advantage In Such A Wvay As To Make Us Forget The Ecmparative Thiviality Of The Subject. A Great Contrast To This Maginificent Arrangement Of Reds And Greens And Many Other Colours Is Shown In The Delightful Little Haymaker Of Lhermite 40, A Study Of Cool Blues And Grays, Displaying Great Refinement Of Feeling And A Growing Mastery Of The Bruslh. As To Mlr. Henry Mioore, We Rejoice To Find Him At Work Again, Apparently None The Worse For His Accident, But, On The Other Hand, Able, As In His Summer-Time Off The Channel Islands 33. To Paint The Sea With All His Old Ability And Insight. Mr. Peter Graham Again Has Been Happy In The Subject Which He Calls Caledonia Stern And Wvild 16, And He Has Seldom Of Late Years Equalled These Three Cattle And The Fleecy Mist That Envelops The Hills. Other Painters Here Whose Work Should Be Noticed Are The Hungarian Vastagh, Who Sends A Strongly Painted Lions Head 12, His Countryman Peske, Who Evidently Has Artistic Knowledge As Well As Humour, And The Russian Painter Harlamioff, Whose Sewing-Lesson Is The Best Picture That We Have Seen From His Hand. But Mr. Godwvard, Whopaintslittle Cabinet Pictures Verydext R.Usly, Overrated His Powers When He Ventured On The Life-Size Fancy Portrait Here Called The Rose 30. Next Door, At Messrs. Tooths, Instead Of A Somewhat Ovetwhelming Numler Of Small Pictures, We Have In The Principal Room A Few Large Works Very Well Hung, And To Be Studied At Leisure. The Centres Are Occupied By Two Pictures Of Munkacsy And One By Bouguereau-The Two Former As Effective As Usual And, It Must Be Added, As Tricky In Execution And The Last A Cupid As Beautifully Drawn, As Sentimental, And As Academic As Are All The Performances Of This Still Popular Artist. Other Foreign Painters That We Generally Meet In This Gallery Arc Ml. Deutsch, Joanowitch, Benlliure, Meadrazo, And Jaccuet, And All Of These Have Representative Works In The Present Exhibition M. Joanowitch An Especially Gcod One In The Study Of A Montenegrin Warrior, Which Lie Calls The Leisure Hour 68, And M. Madrazo One That Is Daintier Than Ever, The Artist In Pastel 21. Brilliantly Drawvn, But Cold In Colour, Is M. Detailles En Tirailleur And The Little Rosa Bonheur That Hangs Niext To It Is Of Extreme Beauty. But It Cannot Be Said That British Painters In This Gallery Fall In Any Wvay Behind Their Foreign Rivals, For We Have Sir John Millaiss Grace, Much Improved Since We Saw It At The Royal Academy Wse Have Large And Representative Landscapes By Messrs. Vicat Cole, Leter Graham, Leader, And The Late Kegley Halswello Andwe Have, In A Break In The Stormi -Glen-Lyon 47, The Finest Landscape Yet Produced By That Clever Scotch Painter Mr. David Farquharson. At The French Gallery, Messrs. Wvallis Try With Success The Somewlhat Perilous Experiment F Hanging Three Of Their Walls With New Pictures, Andl The Fourth With Choice Examples Of The Socalled Barbizon Painters. The Place Of Holnour Among The Latter Is Rightly Given To One Of The Most Beautiful Examples Of Corot That Has Been Seen In London While On Either Side Hang Chlarming Cabinet Specimens Of Troyon,Rousseau, And The Rest. There Is Nothing New To Be Said About These Men R Their Works, And It Is Enough To Record Their Presence In The Exbibition. Above Hang Some Of The Charming Little Landscapes Which Puzzled Everybody Wvhen They Appeared At A Recent Sale, And Wvhich, Tllough For Some Reason Or Other They Are Signed M. Cazin, Are Universally Believed To Be The Work Of The Very Emiinent French Landscape Painter J. B. Cazin Himself, And Not Of His Wife. Tlle Puzzle Will Exercise Critics For A Long Tinme To Come, And Until It Is Solved We Imiust Be Content To Judge The Little Pictures On Their Mnerits Anld To Acnire The Feeling And The Colour-Sense Which They Reveal. F Newv Wvorks There Are Characteristic Pictures By Mbi. Seiler, Firle, Joanowvitch, And Many Others, With A Vast Pastoral Landscape By Fauvel From Last Years Salon. But By Far The Most Interesting Is The Ifeili,E Abend, The Cchristmas Eve, Of Fritz Von Ijuie, The German Artist Who, Almost Alone Among His Countrymen, Now Commands The Admniration Of Critics In Paris, London, And The United States. The Exhibition Of His Wvorks Which Messrs. Vwtallis Organized A Short Time Ago Is Still Fresh In The Memory Of Thoso Who Care For Originality And Sincerity In Art, Althoughl It Appeals That Few English Amnateurs Were Enterprising Enougn To Become Possessed Of The Pictures. This Time We Have One Of Those Bits Of What May Be Called Inverted Realism By Which He Tries To Interpret The Bible Story For Us. Just As In The Last Supper Ne Gave Us A Group Of German Peasants At Their Meal, So.Here We Have A German Winters Night, The Ground Deep In Snowr And A Poor German Woman Waiting And Shivering In The Cold, Vhile Her Husband, A Peasant St. Joseph, Trudges Across The Drifts To Seek Shelter For The Hapless Pair In The Village. Only A Faintly Indicated Aureolo Denotes The Sacred Character Of The Woman. Tho Pathos Of The Scene Is Great, However Far It Takes Us From Bethlehem, And The Snowv-Painting Is Masterly In The Extreme. Miessrs. Vokins Have Collected A Large Numbei Of The Choicest Examples Of Some Of Ourold English Water-Colour Artists, Especially William Fut, De Wint, And Copley Fielding, And Have Added Many Drawings By Living Painters, Such As 3R. There Waite,. .5R. Birlket Foster, And Mrs. Allingham. Perhaps It Will Be Felt That The Exhibition Lacks Novelty, Since Not Only Have We Had Two Other Retrospective Exhibitions Of Drawings In Private Galleries Duning The Last Two Months, But At Burlingtonhouse We Have Just Had A -Wall Covered With William Hunts Work. But To M-Y People The Idea That- There Can Be Too Much Of A Good Thing Is Inadmissible, And These May At Least Be Certain That The Best Possible Fare Has Been Provided For Them By Messrs. Vokins. Miessrs. Shepherd, Driven Out Of Their Rooms In King-Street By The Building Operations Which, None Too Soon, Are Transforming Williss Rooms, Have Secured A Well-Lighted Little Gallery At No. 48, Pall-Mall, Which They Have Hung With An Attractive Collection Of Old English Landscapes And Portraits. Some Works Of Lomney, Wilson, Cotman, And The Elder Shayer Are Especially Interesting. Nothing Is Moro In Fashion Just Now Than The Barbizon School And For This Reason It Would Appear That Ml!. Bernheim, The Wvell-Knowvn Dealer Of The Rue Laffitte, Has Opened A Branch In Piccadilly, Near Duke-Street, With A Good Display Of Pictures Of This Class. There Are Many Such Stores Already In London Time May Possibly Prove That There Is Room For Yet Another-

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Engravings And Etcbings. Separate Treatment Of Two Exhibitions Of Engravings And Etchings Opening Next Door To Each Other On The Eve Of The Academy-Is Not To Be Expected. To Define Them In Scope-The Fine Art Society, 14, New Bond-Street, Shows Engravings And Etchings By Cd Masters, From Mantegna To Canaletto, While The Group Of Fine Prints At Messrs Colnaghis, 144, New Bond-Street, Represents Both Old And Modern I Mters. As Regards. The Old Miaters, The Fine Art Society Has-The Advantage In Range-139 Priots By Most Of The Knownengravers In The Nearly Threecenturies Covered, While Messrs. Colnaghi Put The Emphasis Upon Quality Of Impression, Concentrating Upon Mantegna, Diirer, And Rembrandt, With Goya To Introduce Modern Etching, In An Exhibition Of 80 Prints. As It Actually.Fals Out, Not More Than A Dozen Subjects-Are Duplicated In The Two Exhibition, So That Each Should Have Iti. Appeal To The Student And Collector. Frbm An Educational Point Of View The Fine Ait Sbcietys Exhibition Is Something Of An Event And Nobody But A Print Expert Need Be Ashamed Of Finding Many Of The Examples In It Unfamiliar. It Leads Off With Mantegna In Two Bacchanalian Groups In His Characteristie Bas-Relief Style Of Composition, And There Is Also A Schol I Engraving After The Elephants In His Trimph Of Casar At Hampton Cour. Martin Schongaher, Who Died Before Dorer 50Uld Become His Pupil, Foluows, And Is Most Forcibly Represeuted In-A Very Early Impressgon Of St. Jacob At The Battle Of Coripostela, Interesting To Compare Mentaly Vith Uccellos Rout Of San Roniano, And Havinz The Advantage Of It In Movement. At This Time Of Day, And With First-Rate Exhibitio6S Of Their Works Fresh In Memory Dlrerwho Is Represented Lo Both Metal And Wood Egraving-And Reinbrandt Need Only Be Iinamed, Though The Impressions Of Jan Six And Rembrandts Mother Seated At A Table Deserve Comment,And Attention Lingets Rather Over Such Names As Israel Van Meckenem, Altdorfer, Hans Sebald Beham, Aldegrever, Augustin Hirschvogel And The Masters T. V. B.. L B., And F. 3. Impressions Of Special Quality Are St. Sebastian, By Lucas Van Leyden, 4Peasants Brawling, By Beham, Set Ofwedding Dances, By Aldegrever. And Mucius Scaveala, By The Mster F. G. Of The Later Works The Most Exciting Are Four Plates Of The Gip!Ies, By Callot. No Stiudent Mf- Engraving Can Afford To Neglect This Exhibition. - The Collector Rather Than The Student Is Considered At Messrs. Colnaghis, And A Large Proportion Of The Prints Are From Named Collections. Rantegnas The Entombment Is Here, Add The Array Of Dlrersis Broken By Birds Of The Apocalypse,- In A Very Full Composition, By J. Duvet. One Of The Finest Of The Rennbrandts Is A Secondstateof The Death Of Thei Virgin. Meryon, Who May Be Called The. Origin Of One Strain-And That The Most In Evidence At The Moment-In Modern Etcing Is Represented By Four Of His Most Famous Subjects, And Then The Standard Of Quality Is Kept- Up- Through Haden, Whistler, Zorn Camteron, Bone, Griggs, Mcbey, And Bro.Kurst

Title: Danish Art Exhibition At Brighton
Full_text: Danish Art Exhibition At Brighton. An Exhibition Of Modern Danish Art Was Opened At The Brighton Art Galleries On Saturday. Among The Guests Of The Mayor And Mayoress Aiderman And Mrs. Thomas-Stanford, Who Gave A Soiree, Were Mr. Faber, Consul-General For Denmark, Who Performed The Opening Ceremony, Mrs. And Miss Faber, And Professor Tuxen The Danish Court Artist, Two Of Whose Pictures Of The Coronation Of King Edward Have Been Lent By The King And Are Publicly Exhibited For The First Time And Mrs. Tuxen. Before The Opening, The Fine Arts Committee Entertained A Large Company Of Danish And English Guests At Dinner. Mr. Faber, In Declaring The Exhibition Open, Said That It Was The First Collection Of Danish Modern Works Ever Shown In England. Individually, Danish Painters And Sculptors Had Exhibited At The Guildhall, Mt The Works Then Shown Were Retrospectivemostly By Painters Who Had Long Since Passed Away. There Were Only A Few Of Their Artists Of The Present Day Who Had Had Their Pictures Hung On The Walls Of The Guildhall. One Of Them Was Professor Tuxen. The Majority Of The Artists Belonging To The Modern School Of Denmark Now Made Their Bow To The British Public For The First Time, And Not Only They But Danes As A Whole Felt Themselves Under A Deep Debt Of Gratitude To The Brighton Corporation For The Opportunity Of Exhibiting In Those Beautiful Galleries. Queen Alexandra Had Not Only Given Her Patronage But Had Announced Her Desire To Visit The Exhibition. Cheers. J

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art, Exhibitions. English Water-Colours. Whether For The Quality Of Its Major Works, The Eircumstantial Or Historical Interest Of Many-Of The Subjects Represented, Or The Unconventional Breadth Of Its Range, The Annual Exhibition Of Early English Water-Colours At Walkers Galleries, 118, New Bond-Street, Is Distinctly Anevent Of The Season. For Anybody Interested In The Subject It Is A Public Occasion-Particularly Since,, In The Course Of Making His Acquisitions, Mr. Augustus Walker Has Become A Recogmized Authority On The Early English School There Can Be No Doubt What Is The Score Of The Present Exhibition-The 25Th Of The Series. It Is The Group Of Four Drawings, Two Of Them Very Large, By Alexander Cozens Fl. 1746-86. They Are All In Monochrome-A Warm Sepia, Or Bistre-Though Bathing Scene Is Touched Here And There With Blue And A Resulting Green. The Most Completely Satisfying In Design Is Rocky Island, Extended Rather Like The Fish Called A Skate On The S Urface Of The Water. Except That It Is In Western Perspective, With Linear And Atmospheric Recession Perfectly Reconciled, It Strongly Recalls The Ink Paintings Of The Chinese, And This Lends Colour To The Story, Generally Believedthough It Has Been- Questioned-That Cozens Was A Natural Son Of Peter The Great, From Whom He May Be Supposed -To Have Inherited A Mongolian Strain. His Son, J. R. Cozens 1752-99, Of Whom Constable Said That He Was All Poetry, Is Represented By A Large And Noble View Of London From Greenwich-1791, With The Dome Of St. Pauls Answering The Two Of The Hospital In The Middle Of The Composition. There Are Two Girtins, Wooded Landscape With Church And House, Which Looks Rather Amateurish And May Excite Some Doubts, And ,Lincoln Cathedral1798, Showing The Western Spires Wlhich, Are No Longer There. This Drawing, With Minor Alterations, Was Engraved As The Frontispiece To Howletts Lincoln, Shown At The Gallery. The Only Example Of J. S. Cotman Is Unimportant, But There Is A Very Splendid De Wint, Country Lane With Cattle Drinking, Coming Near To Cotman In Style, And Richard Wilson Is Represented By An Original Design, In Chalk, For Ir. Grevilles Niobe, From Paul Sandbys Collection. Sandby Himself Has Four Drawings, The High Road, In Particular, Being An Epitome Of The Rural Scene At The Period. The Rest Of The Exhibition-Which Contains 172 Drawings, Including A Few By Foreign Artists-Is Made Up Of Less Famous Names In A Great Variety Of Interest. The Turnpike, Croydon, By James Bourne 1773-1854, Castle Ruins. By F. J. Manskirsch 1770-1827, And Wells Cathedral, By G. F. Robson 1788-1833 May Be Specially Mentioned. There Are Several Unattributed Drawings, Including A Set Of Four Amusing Incidents On The Paddington Canal, Something Between Rowlandson And The Illustration Of The Hunting Of The Snark In Style.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Abt Exhibitions. At Messrs. Agnews Gallery, In Old Bondstreet, There Opens This Morning An Exhibition That Has Both An Artistic And An Historical Interest. It Is That Of A Series Of Drawings Illustrative Of Characters And Scenery Associated With Mary Stuart, Queen Of Scots The Artists Are Sir James Linton And Mr. James Orroel-, Of Whom The Former Contributes A Dozen Figure-Subjects, And The Latter About A Hundred Landscapes, Mostly Of Small Size. From The Historical Point Of View, The Figure-Subjects Must Of Course Be The Less Satisfactory, For It Will Always Be More Or Less A Matter Of Guesswork To Attempt To Give The Features Of The Queens Marys, Or Of Hamilton Of Bothwellhaugh, Or Of George Douglas, Or Of Any Other Of The Queens Friends Or Foes.- Indeed, As Everybody Agreed Last Winter After A Visit To The Stuart Exhibition, None Of The Authentic Portlaits Of The Queen Herself Really Explain Heir Extraordinary Fascinations, And If Sir James Linton In Depicting Her Had Merely Copied The Wyi4Dsor Miniature Or The Likeness Knoown As The Deuil Blanc He Would Have Given. Us The Idea Of A Not Very Attractive Woman. So He Has Perforce Been Thrown Back Upon His Own Ideals And His Own Models, With The Result That His Drawings Are Not Very Different From The Figures That We Have Been Accustomed To See From His Hand At The Institute And Elsewhere. The Painting, As One Might Expect, Is Of Remarkable Quality, And In The Best Drawings, Such As The 1 Darnley 23, The Mary Livingstone 107, And The Eamilton 101, Sir James Lintons Sense Of Rich And Even Splendid Colour Anid His Power Of Obtaining Strong Effects While Using Methods That Are Almost Thoso Of The Miniaturist Are Very Conspicuous. In The Landscape Work Mr. Orrock Has Certainly Bettered All His Previous Performances. Not Only Has He Followed The Steps Of The Unhappy Queen With The Raost Scrupulous Fidelity, And Given Us Faithful Drawings Of Iolyrood, Of Stirling, Of St. Andrews, Of Lochleven, Of Bolton, Tutbury, Fotheringhay, And Peterborough, But He Has Drawn Everything With A Freshness And Truth That Are Charming. A S Is Well Kmnown, Mr. Orrock Is Frankly A Follower Of The Methods Of Those Great English Water-Colour Artists Who Were The Lights Of The Last Generation But This Does Not Prevent Him From Seeing With His Own Eyes And Impressing An Individuaflcharactcr Upon His Work. It Is Difficult To Pick Out The Best Out Of So Many Drawings, But One Might Specify As Particularly Good And Artistic Bolton Castle 12, Tutbury Castle 15, The Two Views Of Stirling 24 And 27, And Several Of The Smaller And Slighter Sketches At The End Of The Room. We May Add That The Catalogue Is Annotated With Much Learning And Discretion By Mr. Walter Armstrong, Who Shows Himself Quite As Well Qualified To Write History As He Is To Criticize Art. Mr. Mlendoza, Of King-Street, St. Jamess, Has Opened His Usual Winter Exhibition Of Drawings In Black And White, To Which Are Added A Few Pastels. Such A Collection Is Aproof,If Proof Were Needed,Of The Amount Of Good Work That Is Now Being Done In England By Artists Who Have Not Attained To Fame, And Especially By Ladies. A Pastel Head By Miss Gemmell, A Harbour Scene By Miss Webb, And A Little Group, In Caldecutts Manner, By Miss Pocock, Are Instances In Point. There Are Also Some More Highly-Finished Performances, Such As The Pastel Fancy-Subjects By The Roman Artist, .Giannetti.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition Mr. James Gunn Mr. James Gunns Small Versions Of Manv Of His Most Successful Portraits, At Agnews Galleries, 43, Old Bond Street. Are Called First Impressions, But They Bear No Resemblance To The Ordinary Sketch Which An Artist Makes For A Large Picture. There Is Nothing In The Very Least Tentative About Them A Photographic Likeness Is Obtained With Cold Precision And With What Appears To Be A Truly Astonishing Certainty, While, For The Rest Of The Picture, The Painter Might As Well Have Been Making A Map For All The Evidence There Is Of Anything But Methodical Calculation The One Or Two Landscapes In The Exhibition Show How Indifferent Mr. Gunn Is To Anything Except Making A Record Of The Relative Position Of Everything In The Scene. Once This Is Done, He Appears To Be Able To Proceed At Once And Without Making Any Significant Changes, By A Process Which Can Only Be Called Enlargement, To The Full-Size Portrait. If, Indeed, Thcsc Unhesitant And Impersonal Statements Really Are The Paintees Very First Impressions, One Can Only Be Amazed At This Revelation Of The Workings Of So Rare, So Unerring, And So Completely Specialized A Faculty, Which Allows Itself To Be Distracted By None Of The Usual Considerations Which Are Present In The Normal Painters Mind When He First Views His Subject.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions And The Shops Act
Full_text: Abt Exhibitions And The Shops Act. In Reply To Mr. Ferens, M.P., Who Asked The Home Secretary Whether Societies Of Artists Holding Annual Exhibitions At Which Works Of Art May Be Purchased By The Public Are Required Under The Last Section Of The Second Schedule To The Shops Act, 1912, To Apply To The Local Authority For A Certificate That They Are Entitled To Exemption, Mr. Mckenna States To Obtain Exemption From The Requirement Of A Weekly Half-Holiday A Certificate Under The Schedule Is Required Ik Retail Trade Is Being Carried On. The Question Whether In Such Cases The Society Would Bo Regarded As Carrying On Retail Trade Would Depend, I Think, To Some Extent On The Circumstances Of The Particular Case, But If A Society Holds An Exhibition Of Works Of Art Which Arc For Sale, And Whether By Commission Or Otherwise Makes A Profit In Connexion With The Sales, The Case Would Appear To Be One Falling Within The Schedule.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Mr. Watts, Though His Name Is A Household Word, Among Those Who Care For Art, Has Never Been A Painter Of Popular Pictures. His Grave And. Conscientious Work Has Won For Him Something Better Than Mere Popularity. He Takes His Place Among The Greatest Artists Of His Age, And Has A Position All His Own In Virtue Of His Portraits And His Allegories. No One Has Painted, Portraits With Greater Insight And Distinction No One Has Rendered Allegory More Profitably, Or More Impressively. Any Collection Of Works By Mr. Watts Must Command Attention But A Special Interest Attaches To The 30 Or 40 Examples That Are Now Shown At Leighton-House, Because They Represent Him At Various Periods Of His Career, From 1838 And 1840 To The Present Day. Some Men. Turner, For Instance, And Millais, Passed Through Definite Stages And Changes. This Is Hardly True Of Mr. Watts, Whose Methods Have Changed More Than, His Style Or His Aims. The Thinly Painted Pictures Of His Earlier Year?. Have Been Superseded By His Later And More Solid Technique. And He Professes Himself A Student Still, For Art Is Longer Than The 66 Years Spent In Its Pursuit, And Some Work Of Noble Note May Yet Be Done. Several Charming Small Pictures Take Us Back To The Year 1838 A Large Canvas Showing A Group Of Halfdraped Girls Seems To Be The Result Of His Italian Student Life Last Of All Comes Love Steering The Barque Of Humanity From Last Years New Gallery. Between These Widely Distant Dates, How Many Strong Portraits, How Much Magnificent Colour, Have We To Admire In His Continuous But Newer Superabundant Work I Most Of It Is Elsewhere, But Enough Is Here To Enable Us To Study The Growth And The Maturity Of The Artist And The Persistence Of Undiminished Power In Old Age. A Roomful Of Excellent Modern Pictures Is To Be Found At The Goupil Gallery, At The Bottom Of Regent-Street. The Collection Is Of An Agreeably Varied Character, For It Ranges From One Or Two Works Of. The Barbizon School To Those Of A French .Artist, M. Lebottrg, Who Has Not Hitherto Been Seen In London. His Crdpusctde Is Impressionist But He Does Not Carry His Principles To An Extreme, And The Result Is A Compromise Of Great Beauty And Elegance. Perhaps The Principal Landscapes Are The Two Companion Harpignies, Morning, And Evening, The One Cold And Touched With Chilly Silver, And The Other Glowing With The Warm Air Of Sunset. Moonlight Is Seldom Painted With Such Skill As Is Shown By Lupines River Scene.. It Is A Most Difficult Subject, But Hero All Seems In Absolute Keeping. Yet, For All That May Be Said For These End. Other Landscapes, Not All Of Them French, By The Way, The Gem Of The Gallery Is The Little Charles Jacque. Once More We Have His Frequent Subject, Sheep Near The Edge Of The Forest A Perfectly Simple Affair, But Invested With Extreme Dignity And Truth. Besides- These, And. Others That Are Worthy Of Their Company, There Are Examples Of Work That Is Not Only Modern, But As New As Possible, In The Shape Of Pictures In The New Solid Oil-Colours. Now And. Then, As With Mr. Peppercorns Breezy Weather, They Suggest Great Speed, Of Execution, Though Perhaps This Spirited Performance Would, Have Been None The Worse For A Little More Deliberation. It Is A Sketch, But Ordinary Oil Sketches Are Not Impossible. And Now And Then The New Colours Are Used In Such A Way As To Be Almost Indistinguishable From Brush Work But More Often They Resemble Pastel, It Is Believed With More Permanence And Less Liability To Injury. Time Will Show How Far That Claim Is Justified Meanwhile, The Specimens Here Add To The Interest Of The Exhibition. There Are Three Little Exhibitions At Messrs, Gravess Galleries In Fall-Mall. Mr. Haywards Lowers Are Painted With Much Feeling For Colour, And The Few Water-Colours By Mr, Hayward Which Hang Beside Them Are Accomplished And Wholly Unpretending. Mrs. Adrian Hopes Friends And Fancies In Another Room Are In Part Pastel Portraits Of Good Quality, And In Part Fanciful Water-Colour Drawings Of Children, Animals, And Fairies Slight Enough, But An Amusing Combination Of Stothard And Alice In Wonderland. In Yet Another Room Are A Few Of Mr. Ben Austrians Game Hen And Chick Pictures. If His Source Of Inspiration Is Unusual, His Drawing Is Quite Beyond, Reproach. He Is An American Artist, And. Has Made Subjects Of This Kind His Special Study. - - 1 , I I I R 1 I

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions In London
Full_text: Entertainments Art Exhibitions In London A Wide Range June Is A Favourite Month For Picture Exhibitions, And During The Past Few Days Several Have Opened In London Which Are Well Worth A Visit From Those Who Enjoy Exercising Their Own Taste And Judgment, Whether Approving Or The Reverse. Among These Are Two One-Man Shows By Painters Employing Advanced Modern Technique. At The Redfern Gallery Mr. Jankel Adler, An Expressionist Artist Born In Poland In 1895, And Now In This Country, Is Exhibiting A Group Of Paintings Which May Perhaps Be Best Suggested By Saying That They Contain A Mixture Of Human, Or Other Recogmizable, Forns With Geometrical Shapes, The Whole So Arranged As To Suggest A Mood. His Colour Is Generally Strong And Glowing, And His Work Has A Certain Force, Thought It Is Strongly Alien, Or Even Repellent, To Most English Minds. Occasionally, As In The Two Dancer Pictures, He Uses Softer Colour, And A Style Approximating More Nearly To Our Conception Of Caricature, Which Make For Easier Understanding And Acceptance. Mr. Robert Colquhoun, Whose Work Is On View At The Lefevre Galleries, Is A Young Scottish Painter Who Has Worked A Good Deal Abroad. His Paintings Show Many Contemporary Influences, And In Spite Of His Fondness For Strong Colours. Especally Reds, He Does Not Yet Seem To Have Found Himself As A Colourist Nor To Achieve The Full Richness At Which He Seems To Be Aiming. A Mixed Collection Of Pictures By Sir William Nicholson, Mr. John, And Others Is Also At This Gallery. Tunisia And Egypt It Is A Very Different World Into Which One Steps At The ,Walker Galleries, Where Mr. Walker Tyndale Is Showing Some 20 Watercolours Of Tunisia And Egypt. Mr. Tyndale Is Now A Very Old Hand At The Type Of Watercolour Which Is Essentially An Illustration Of Travel-A Type Which Must Always Have A Certain Value Though It Is Somewhat Unfashionable At The Moment. Many Of His Subjects, Such As A Laundry At Gabes, A Street In Sfax, And A Suk In Tunis, Have A Topical Interest Just Now, And They Are, Moreover, Very Skilfully Done-It Is Noticeable, For Instance, How Much Life There Is In His Figures, Which Are Never Merely Decorative Adjuncts Of The Scene. At The Institut Francais, South Kensington, Is A Loan Collection Of More Or Less Modem Pictures By Artists Of Many Nationalities. There Are Several Good Things-Two Drawings By Picasso, For Example, And An Admirably Gloomy House By James Pryde-But On The Whole The Show Is Rather A Jumble As Regards Both Style And Merit. Mr. Paul Larsen Is Once Again Holding His Annual Exhibition Of Old Master Paintings At 43, Duke Street, S.W. They Are Chiefly English And Duich Or Flemish. The English Pictures Include A Small Anonymous Portrait Of Edward Vl, And, Of Later Works, Examples Of Lawrence, Hoppner, And The Pastellist John Russell. There Are Several Decorative Dutch Flower Pieces, And Among The Flemish Pictures Are Two Extremely Entertaining Examples Of Jan Van Kessel 1626.79 Illustrating Two Of The Senses- Sound And Taste. These Are Full Of Amusing And Historically Interesting Detail.

Author: Null
Title: Minor Art Exhibitions
Full_text: 1Llno Art Bxeibitions. Mr. F. C. Goulds Political Cartoons Arc So Well Known That It Is Hardly Necessary To Do More Than Call Tteution To The Collection Of His Work For The Last Year Or So That Is Now To Bo Seen In The Continental Gauery In Bond-Street. Hii Drawings Are Generally Reprodueced In So Ephemeral A Manner That It Is Au The More Desirabl, To See Them In Their Original Form. Undoubtedly His Excellent Draughtsmanship, His Invention, And His Sense Of Hnmour Make Hiuo, We Will Not Say First In His Art Whilo Sir John Tenaiel Is Vwith Us, But A Good Secoud To Any Of The Masters Of Caricature. Ele Owes Something To Them, Of Course, But His Humour Und Hs Ingernuity Are All His Own. One Of His Most Charucteristie Drawings Represents Ir. Goschen As S Stork And Mr. Chamt Berlain As A Fox. The Fornmer Remarks, T Propios Of The Increased Navy Estimates, My Bill Is As Long As Your Spoon To Which The Fox Replies, Yes, And Now We Can Go And Have Supper With The Bear. Nothing Can Be Happier Than 31R Goulds Metbod Of Blending His Politicians With Judiciously Chosen Birds And Quadrupeds. Botb His Animal Forms And His Buman Likenesses Are Exceedingly Truthful And-Crowning Merit In A Caricaturist-There Is No Oralice In His Sharpest Joke. Messrs. Cassells Black And White Exhibition, Which Is Being Held This Year At Catlers Hall, Warwicklane, Newgate-Street, Is Again A Distinct Success. By The Expression Blaek And Mhite Almost Everything Is Meant Except Colour. A Wide Choice Of Metbod Remains, From The Primitive Pen And Ink To More Elaborate Processes And The Result Is An Exhibition Of Treat Interest As Regards Both Portraits And Landecapes. Mr. Fulleylove, Mr. Caton Woodville, Mr. Railton, And Mr. C. W. Wyllie Are Ameng The Principal Contributors. With These Drawings May Be Compared Or Contrasted The L,Lack And White Work Of Two Associated Artists, Nature And Sciewce, Which Is To Be Seen On Tuesdays And Fridays At The Rootms Of The Camera Club In Charing-Cross-Road. It Represents The Latest Advances In The Art Of Photography, Which Cannot In These Days Be Cbarged With Any Wsnt Of The Artistic Spirit. It Has, Indeed, Been The Constant Aim Of Photographers To Bring The Personal Element Into Their Vork. The Photographs Bere Are As Fine As Any That Have Been Exhibited, And Sbow Not Only The Highest Technical Excelleuce, But Also A Surprising Degree Of Individuslity. A Display Of Mr. George Woodalls Beautiful Sculptured Glass Is Now On View At Mlessrs Phillips In Mount-Street. It Is A Development Of The Art Of Cameo-Cuttidg, The Material Being, Xot The Minute Gems In Which The Ancient Altists Worked, Or The Shells Used By Their Modern Roman Snecessors, But Large Layers Of Differently Tinted And Semi-Opaque Glass, The Upper Layer White, And The Lower Dark Red, Dark Blue, Or Dark Green. These Are Amply Sufficient For Lr Woodalls Purpose. He Is At Onee The Artist And The Executant Workman. Ihe Classica Designs Are His, A Little After The Style Of Flxmkan. But Less Severe, And With Fuller Pictorial Effects Of Light Anid Shade And Transparent Drapery And Be Alone Has Carved Them. Patieutly And Slowly, Until These Glass Vases And Plaques Become Something That Is Half Picture Gnd Half Sculpture Here Is As True A Combination Of Art And Craft As Can Possibly Be Found. The Nature Of Thc Material Necessitates The Utmost Delicacy Of Hand, And The Work Cannot But Proceed Very Deliberately. It Is. Therefore, All The More Provoking Thatit Should Be Liable To Unforeseen Accidents In The Shape Of Flaws And Air-Bubbles That May Be Discovered, Perhaps After Weeks Of Work, In The Glass Itself. Ibi Szis Effuc S Labor. When This Bappens, The Cmmeo Cannot Be The Perfect Thing Intended By The Artist. It Is Hoped That A Preliminary Examination Of The Glass By The X Rays May Show The Existence Of All Latent Flawsr Before The Artist Begins His Work But It Ia.Nut Yet Certain Whether Tho Test Whin Be Cet4Aal

Author: Null
Title: Industrial Art
Full_text: Industrial Art Desirability Of Exhibitions Gorell Committees Recommendations The Report Of Lord Gorells Conmmittee On Alt And Industry Is Issued To-Day Stationery Office, Is.. The Comniittee Vas Appointed In July, 1931, As One Of The Last Official Acts Of The Late Mr. William Graham, Then President Of The Board Of Trade, To Consider The Desirability Of Forrming Exhibitions Of Articles Of Every-Day Use And Good Design Of Ctrrent Manufacture. Under The Chairmanslip Of Lord Gorell The Committee Held 13 Meetings, Taking Evidence From Govermnent Departments, Associations, And Individuals. The Following Are Its Principal Recoimnendations A Central Body Responsible For Exhibitions Of Industrial Art Should Be Established With Executive Powers, In Close Association With The Department- Of Overseas Trade. Ideally, There Should Be In London A Special Building For Exhibitions Of Industrial Art. As An Immediate Practical Step An Existing-Building Centrally Situated Should Be Utilized. There Should Be Organized In London At Regularly Recurring Intervals Exhibitions Of Articles Of High Qualitv And Modern Manufacture Allied In Category, To Remain Open To The Public For Approximately Six Weeks. The Organi7Ation Of A Standing Exhibition I.E., Continuously Open, Though Constantly Changing Should Be Left For The Consideration Of The Proposed New Body When Adequate Experience And Finance Have Been Secured. The Main Periodic Exhibition Should Be Supplemented Bv Occasional Exliibitions In London And Elsewvhere, Including Exhibitions For Special Trades Or Special Purposes. Later, Travelling Exhibitions Should Be Undertaken Froni Time To Time In This Country. Later, Again, Exhibitions Abroad, Including Travelling Exhibitions, Should Be Undertaken. Suitable Provision Should Be Made For Acquiring By Gift Or Purchase Some Of The Best Examples Showvn In The Periodic And Other Exhibitions, And For Their Display To The Public, Pending The Absorption Into The National Collections Of Such Of Them As Are Eventually Judged Worthy Of This Honour. The Object Of Exhibitions Should Be The Improvement Of The Taste Of Designers, Manufacturers, Distributors, And The General Public By The Display To The Best Advantage Of Beautiful Modern Manufactured Goods, Due Regard Being Paid To The Purchasing Power Of The Householder Of Moderate Means. The Activities Of The British Institute Of Industrial Art And Voluntary Associations, So Far As The Organization Of Exhibitions Of The Above Tvpes Is Concerned, Should Be Unified And Placed At The Disposal Of The New National Organization. Apart From Exhibitions, The Government Should Prosecute Concurrent Measures Aiminat Improved Status For The Best Inldustrial Artists, Increased Use Of First-Rate Artists By Manufacturers, Better Art Education, Research Into The Needs Of Particular Inidustries, And A Safeguarding Of Artistic Materials, And Should Make The Board Of Trade Specificallv Responsible For The Advancement Of Industrial I Art In This Country. Function Of Educaltion The Committee State That Their Purpose Has Been To Discover How Exhibitions Of Industrial Art Can, In Modern Conditions Of Education And Commerce, Best Be Harnessed To The Joint Servce Of Art And Industry And Assist Towards The Production And Distribution Of Goods Of High Quality And United Kingdom Manufacture. The View Is Expressed, However, That The Mere Organization Of Such Exhibitions Is Incapable By Itself Of Solving The Vital Problem How Best To Raise The Level Of Industrial Art In The United Kiingdom. There Must, In The Committees Judgment, Be A Concurrent National Effort To Improve The Design And Quality Of The Products Exhibited, But Such Measures As The Improvement Of The Training Of All Who Participate, Whether As Designers, Manufacturers, Craftsmen, Or Wvholesale Or Ietail Buyers And Sellers, In Creating And Distributing The Products Of Industrial Art. It Follows That The E4Ucation Provided In The Art And Trade Schools, And Also In Public, Secondary, And Elementary Schools, In The Directions Botlh Of Creative Artistic Work And Of Appreciation, Is Of Fundamental Importance. From The Historical Summary With W Hich The Report Begins Two Facts Emerge-The Extent To Whicl Past Efforts To Improve Industrial Art On The Trade Side Have Been Diffused Instead Of Concentrated, And The Absence Of Any Satisfactory Solution Of The Difficulties, In Spite Of The Attention Whichl Has Been Devoted To The Problem. After Drawving Attention To Thesc Points Thc Report Continues - The Change That Has Taken Place Within The Last Decade In The Character And Volume Of The Import And Export Trade Of This Country Renders It, In Our Opinion, Impossible To Allow The Matter To Remain Longer In Its Present State. Under The Traditional System Of Free Imports, Which Is Now Ended, Manufacturers Had At Any Rate Strong Incentives To Secure That The Products And Manufactures Of This Country Should Be So Designed As To Be Able To Compete On All Points Wvith The Products And Manufactures Of Our Great Industrial Competitors. As, However, The Element Of Competition Is Now To Be Reduced By The Creation Of Artificial Barriers Round The Home Market, It Becomes Imperative That The Nation Should Redouble Its Efforts To Improve Its Standards Of Taste And Quality, And. Should Not Be Lulled Into A False Sense Of Security By The Increased Control Ov Cr The Homc Market That Is Secured By Tariffs. The Duty Of Maintaining Standards Is In Direct Ratio To The Degree Of Protection Afforded To Manufacturers. Plowers Of Centhral Body It Is Considered Essential That Tho Central Body Responsible For Exhibitions Should Be I Entrusted With Executive Povcrs, And The Comnm Mittee Recommend L That The Members Should I Be Appointed By The President Of The Board Of Trade, Who Would Thus Be Responsible To Parliament For Its Activities. One Member Should Represent Tle Department Of Overseas Trade Or The Board Of Trade, One Should Be Appointed After Consultation With The President Of The Board Of Education, One After Consultation W Ith The Secretary Of State For Scotland, And A Few Members With Experience Of Manufacture, Wholesale Trade, And Retail Trade Should Be Included. The Members Of The Central Bodv Should, Howevver, Be Primarily Chosen Not As Representing Particular Sections Of The Community, But As Persons Of Taste And Cultural Standards, With An Up-Todate And, As Far As Possible, An International Outlook On Art. Discussing Finance, The Committee State That They Have Confined Themselves To Nroviding A Conservative Estimate For An Immediately Practicable Scheme. This Estimate Covering The Hire And Decoration Of Halls, Packing, Transport, And Insurance Of Exhibits, Lease Of Office Premises, Office Equipment, Heating, Lighting, Cleaning, General Maintenance Expenses, Honoraria For Chairman And Members Of The Central Body And Salaries Of Staffs, Gives The Cost Of Such A Scheme As Not Less Than 10,000 A Year. To Meet This Cedenditure Some Revenue Might Be Obtained From Sources That Might Be Described As Internal-By Charges For Space, The Formation Of A Body Of Subscribers, Trade Levy Charges For Admission, Commission O,U Sales, Sawe Of Catalogues, And So Forth. Mr. Roger Fry, A Member Of The Committee. Suggests In An Appendix To The Reuort A Scheme For The Establishment Of Workshops Of Decorative Design, Under A Controller Of Design Whose Status Would Be That Of A Governmient Official, Of A Class Akin To 11.I. Inspectors Of Schools. I I I I I I I Ii I I I

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Country Life. Ruraj Associations Plav Such A Large Part In The Exhibition Of Woiks By Lady Helena Gleichen, Mr. Maurice Chesterton, And Mr. Charles Simpson At The Alpine Club Gallery That Artistic Interest Seems An Unworthy Substitute For Cider. The Paintings Of Horses And Dogs By Ladv Gleichen Show Not Only An Intimate General Knowledge Of The Subjects But Also The Somewvhat Rarer Capacity To Distinguish An Individual Of The Species And To Paint A True Portrait Of The Animal Concerned. To This Is Added A Feeling For Characteristic Surroundings, With The Result That Lady Gleichen Is, Not Only Able To Present Luack Shire Hiorse, Wave On, A Hunter, And Chang, A Chow Dog, To The Life, But Also On Occasion To Depart From Her Models And Weave Animnals And Landscape Into A Decorative Eomposition, As Hunting Frieze, And The Designs For Bed-Backs And Overmantels. Some Vigorous Representations Of Incidents On The Itelian Front During The War Prove Her Grasp Of The Larger Requirements Of A Picture, And Among The Small Direct Sketches From Nature There Are Some Delightful Thingsi Pink Pigs, Crakenthorpe Hiall, Westmorland, And Winter, For Examples. Fr. Chesterton Shows Water-Colours And Architectural Models Of Buildings, And Since They Are Mostly Farm Buildings In Gloucestershire The Rurail Note Or The Exhibition Is Not Diisturbed. . E Has-Evidently Steeped Himself In The Cotswold Tradition And Then Devoted All His Energies To Meeting Practical Requirements With Simplicity And Economy And An Eye To Good Proportions, Using Grey Thatch As The Best Substitute For Roofing Stones. The Most Interesting Of His Models Is That Of Dairy Farm For 40 Cows, Now In Course Of Construction For Sir Walter Preston, At Tetburv. In This, Mr. Chesterton Has Adopted The Bold- Expedient Of A Circular Plan For The Administrative Offices, Avoiding The Weak Effect Of Curved Roof L?Ie By A Central Tower At The Junction With The Straight Range Of Cowsheds. All The Praetical Requirements In This, And In Dairy Farm, For Colonel E. F. Morrison-Bell, Seem To Have Been Carefully Considered And Ingeniously Worked Out From The Point Of View Of Convenience, And They And The Others, Including A Sheltered Water - Garden Designed For A Windy Site, With Their Landscape Backgrounds, Are Very Pretty Models. In Water-Colour Mr. Chesterton Is Clear, Simple, And Decorative, On The Cotswolds,. Tidal River, And Poetry And Prose, A Factory Subject In Twilight, Being Good Examnles Of His Work. Mr-. Simpson, Who Is The Most Accomplished Painter Of The Three, Takes Us To Cornwall, With Special Reference To Seabirds And Waterfowl. His Special Gifts Are A Natural Sense Of Composition And An Extraordinary Appreciation Of Tone Values. Always He Is At His Best When He Relies Most Explicitly On These Capacities, And Formality-Which Is Often A Help To An Artist With An Imperfect Eye For Tone-Is A Hindrance To Him. Creditable As They Are His Two Decorative Screens Are Not Really So Good As The Large Painting Of Curlew, Loosely Wreathed Upon The Pale Gold Water. Gulls In Hlarbour, Solitary Gull, And Wild Swans Are Other Excellent Paintings Of Birds. Mr. Simpson Also Shows A Number Of Pastel-Or Crayondrawings Of The Wilder Aspects Of Cornwall. An 1Eastbourne Collection. Eastbourne Corporation Is Showinig In Towner Gallery A. Collection Of Over 150 Etchings And Aquatints And Original Drawings Belonging To The Graphic Art 4Ssociation. A Prominent Exlbibit Is Rocca Di Papa, A Water-Colour Drawing In The Early English Topographical Spirit By Kenneth Hobson, A.R.E. The Coliseum, Rome, By W. Russell Flint, Shows Vigorous Handling In Pencil And Herbert G. Hampton Displays Delihcate Draughtsmanihip In The Elms At Haammersmith. Other Notable Drawings Are The Rialto, Venice, By L. R. Squirrell, R.E. Elm Trees, By A. D. Murray Smith, Ar.W.S. Watching, By E. M. Henderson The Tramp, By E. A. Hope, R.B.A. And Waiting For Scraps, By Mrs. Borough Johnson. Among The Etchings There Is Arco Safnta Teresa, Palermo, By S. Tushingham, A.R.E., Which Reveals Dramatic Arrangement Of Light And Shade. G. L. Brockhurst., R.E., Has Two Finished Portrait Studies And Other Skilful Works Are -The Dryad, Bv Harold Nelson Dawn Over The City, Bv Percy Robert Robertson, R.E. Durham, Bv 8. R. Jones. The National Gallery, Bv M. T. Robinson, A.R.E. And The Wnreham Road, By John C. Moody. Aquatints Are Sent By E.- S. Earthrawl, A.R.E., And W. Westle Manning, R.O.I., A.R.E. The Exhibition Will Be Open Until June 7. Water-Colours At Milan. An International Exhibition Of Water-Colours At Milan Was Recently Opened By The Duke Of Bergamo, And Includes Five Rooms Of Italian Work, And Sections By Belgium. Hungary, France, And Great Britain. The British Section, Which Includes Drawings Bv Ceorge Clausen, R. A.. Vw. Russell Flint, A.R.An.. Oliver Hall, R.A., W.-Lee-Hankey, R.I., Moffat Linidner, R.O.I., James Paterson, R.Sa., Sir Herbert Hughes-Stanton, R.A., And Others, Has Been Much Admired.

Author: FROM OUR ART CRITIC
Title: Walker Art Gallery
Full_text: Walker Art Gallery -.. . Special Autumn Exhibition From Our Art Critic Liverpool, Oct. 6 Irrespective Of Its Special Characterworks By Lancashire And Cheshire Artists Exclusively-The Autumn Exhibition At The Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool, Which Was Opened To-Day By Lord Crawford And Balcarres, Has A Special Significance This Year Because Its Limitations Were Decided By The Reconstruction Of The Gallery That Is Now Being Carried Out. By All The Signs Next Year Liverpool Will Have An Artistic Opportunity So Great As To Be Almost Frightening. Seven Galleries Are Being Added, One Of Them. At Least, Among The Largest In The Country-Something Like The Big Venetian Room At The National Gallery. It Is Too Early Yet To Speak Of The Architectural Character Of The Additions By Messrs. Briggs And Thornley, The Architects Of The New Parliament Buildings Of Northern Ireland, But, Particularly In Lighting,Thepromise Is High. Nor Is This The Place To Suggest An Artistic Programme For Liverpool, But The Opportunity To Lay Down A First-Rate Permanent Collectionworthy Of The Nucleus Provided By The Roscoe Primitives And The Half-Dozen Or So Of The Most Celebrated Works By The English Pre-Raphaelites-And To Arrange Really Representative Loan Exhibitions Will Deserve, And Need, The Highest Efforts Of Which The Libraries, Museums, And Arts Committee And The New Director, Mr. Frank Lambert, Are Capable. There Are Signs, Too, In The Present Exhibition That Liverpool Is At Last Waking Up Artistically. Nobody Who Prefers A Clear To A Confused Artistic Experience Will Regret The Absence Of The Usual Padding, From The Academy And Elsewvhere, Which Has Hitherto Made The Liverpool Autumn Exhibition Too Much Like A Lancashire High Tea. The Best Tribute To This Exhibition Is To Say That The Rank And File Of Local Artists Have Never Before Made Such A Respectable Impression. But The Advantages Of The Exhibition Do Not End With The Better Representation Of The Rank And File For The Scope Has Been Wisely Extended To Artists Who Have Associations With The Two Counties As Teachers Or- Students. This Means That, Besides Mr. P. Wilson Steer, O.M., Who Was Born At Birkenhead, The Exhibition Includes The Two Other Artists Who, In The Opinion Of Most People, Share With Him The Leading Place In Contemporary English Painting Mr. Augustus John, R.A., And Mr. W. R. Sickert, A.R.A. Galleries Well Arranged The Exhibition Is Very Well Arranged. Consisting Of 659 Works In All Mediums, It Is, Of Necessity, Rather Closely Hung In The Limited Space Of The Ground-Floor Galleries, But In Such Good Order That Everything Can Be Seen Properly. A Very Fine Group Is Made In The Entrance Hall By Mlr. Johns Portrait Of H. Chaloner Dowdall, Esqre., Lord Mayor Of Liverpool, 1908-1909, And Footman Smith, And Two Steers The Horseshoe Bend Of The Severn, In His Earlier Manner Of More Precise Definition, From Aberdeen, And The Lovely Music Room, From The Tate Gallery. At This Time Of Day It Is Difficult To See Why Mr. Johns Portrait Group Was Not Popular On Its First Appearance. The Lord Mavor Cuts A Dignified Figure, And The Inclusion Of The Footman, With Sword Of Office, Adds Greatly To The Effect Of Civic Splendour, ,Besides Helping The Composition. This Is The Only John, But The Selection Of Works By Mr. Steer Elsewhere In The Exhibition Shows The Full Range Of His Developnient. In The Present Exhibition There Are Four Works By Mr. Sickert The Early, And Very Touching, Mamma Mia Poveretta, A Study Of An Old Venetian Woman, From Manchester, The Little Mother. A Drawing Of Dieppe Harbour And Summer Lightning -One Of His Recent English Echoes. Mr. Sickert Is Represented In The Permanent Collection Only By An Etching. The Names Of Mr. Philip Connard, R.A., Professor Randolph Schwabe, Mr. Robert Anning Bell, R.A., Sir Charles 1. Holines, Mr. John Copley, The Late Mr. Christopher Wood, Mr. Bernard Meninsky, Miss Frances Hodgkins, Mr. Matthew Smith, Mr. Allan Walton, Mr. Terrick Williams, A.R.A., Mr. Adrian Stokes, R.A., Mr. Svdney Lee, R.A., Mr. Francis Dodd, A.R.A., And Mr. S J. Lamorna Birch, R.A., All Represented In This Exhibition By Characteristic Works, Will Suggest The Quality-And Range In Style-Of Some Of The Other Artists Wvho Have Been Associated With Lancashire Or Cheshire At Some Time In Their Career. Lesser-Known Artists Among The Excellent Works By Artists Who Are Less Familiar In London May Be Noted The Blue Boat, By Miss Jessie Pescod-Malcolm Professor Wilberforce, By Mr. Edward 1. Halliday And The Willow Tree, By Mr. Karl Hagedorn But Allowing For Variety Of Taste The Average Quality Is Good Throughout The Exhibition. There Is A Collection Of Prints And Drawings, And One Room Has Been Set Aside For Works Of A Modern Tendency, Which Does Not Appear To Mean Anything More Alarming Than Increased Attention To The Picture, As A Picture, Irrespective Of What It Happens To Represent. The Autumn Exhibition At The Walker Art Gallery Does Not Exhaisst The Artistic And Associated Interests Of Liverpool At The Moment. At The Public Museum There Is An Exhibition Of Shipping In The Exhibition Hall Of The Central Library There Are Photographs From The Times The Picton Reading Room Has A Special Exhibition Of Prints And At The Old Bluecoat Schools There Is The First Annual Exhibition Of Ship Models, Made By Members Of The Ship Model Society. Altogether The Impressions Of A Visit Are Most Encouraging.

Title: RAC art exhibition
Full_text: Rac Art Exhibition An Art Exhibition, On The Open Road, Was Opened At The Rac Clubhouse In Pall Mall Last Night By. Mr Norman Fowler, Secretary Of. State For Transport. The Exhibition, Staged By Tlle Rac In Conjunction With The Contemporary Art Society, Ivill Run Until March 11. It Wvill Later Be Staged At The Rac Cotuntry Club Near Epsom. Four Prizes Of 500 Each Have Been Awarded By A Judging Panel Comprising Miss Nancy Balfour, Chairman Of Tthe Contemporary Art Soclety Mr Ronald Gordon, Rac Clubhouse Director And Cas Miember Mr Edwvard Lucie-Smith, Art Critic And Author Mr Godfrey Pilkington, Director, Piccadilly Gallery Professor Carel Weight, Ra, Artist And Former Professor Of Painting, Royal College Of Art.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Tile Fine Art Society In Lookinig At The Sea Pictures In Oil And Wtcr.Colouir By Mr. Arthlir Briscoe At The Galleries Of The Fine Art Society, 1S, New Bondstreet, Alrtistic Morality Goes To The Wvall. Thought-As Is Often Tho Case When Morility Is Forgotten For Positive Reasons--It Comes Bitck Notne Tho Worse. That Is To Say, Mr. Briscoo Is A Better Composer Than The Acuto Subject Interest Of His Dictires Might Allow One To Iperceive At A- Giance. His Compositions Are Dominated By The Way Thinigs Happen At Sea, And This Gives Theni Al Miolmientuill Wvhich Is Oftent Lacking In The Fruits Of Artistic Calculation. Mr. Briscoe Is A Good Histani-E Of The Rttist Created By It Rulitng Passion Outside Art-- If Seamanship Can Be Calledt Anythiing Buit An Art. Hle Is A Practical Sitilor, Ttnd Most Of The Pictules In This Exhibition Are Fromi Sketches And Stuflies Mnide Wvlie Taking It Hand In The Affairs Of A Finnish Windjammer. Mr. Briscoes Attittido To The Sea Is Clearly That Of One Wlho Likes It In Working Dress.
