For, Thoughi It Is Triue Tlhat Clippers Are Fewaer,E, Tot Anvyodv With The Sea In His Heart The Aige Of Saii Surviives As Long As There Is A Stick N Poni The Chaninel. Basing His Desigins Upon The Rhivthms Of Weather Mr. Briscoe Showvs Lhow The Whole Fabric Of The Sailinig Ship, And The Menei Who Handle It, Respond To These Movements, So That Every Picture Tells A Eosniical Story--Though The Acttal Title Mily Be Nothinig More Ilhiilitiatilig Thanil - Fore Tgallatit Brace Or - Fromn The Main Yard. It Is Nloticeable That, Though. Mr. Briscete Lklowvs Every Fibre In The Anatouivy Of The Ship, And I Though--Froin Thet Neeessities Of Construction -The Anatomy Is Lecorative In Itself, His Imore J Diagrammatic Designs Are The Least Interesting. It Is The Ship In Ltetion, Ts In Silelce, Tha Drawinig Out Of Sjlils To No Sound Otther Than The Creak Of It Block, Sniugging Down, Against A. Lark Stinset Aind All Hands, That Gives Hlit His Opportinlity. Mtulh As Lie Loves Thle Sea His Work Is Completely Free From Inlported Romanticism, Relying For Its Effet- Uponl The Poetry Of The Essential Facts Of Seafarinig. At The Sanle Galleries There Is An Exhibition Of Engravinigs By Anis Sebald Behamn And Othier Cerman Yiattlo Masters Of The 16Th Centtur. Thele Are Fewv Forn S Of Art- In Which The Interests Of Tdesign And Workmaniship Are So Evenly Balanced Antl Closely Interdependent As This, Anid The Collection Of 106 Proofs Is A Feast Of Artistic Lieasures In Little. The Small Scale Of Most Of The P Roofs Creates A- Kindl Of Attetittioi Ill Wvhiet Great Art Is Forgotten, So T-Hat Thele Is Notlititg To Interfere With Positive Enjometicnt-. The Quality Of Siuchi Proofs As Run In Series, Such As Christ And The Twelve Apostles, The Seven Planets, Andl The Recognititin Of God Anwd The Seven Virtules, By B3Ehtam, And - The Small Wvedding-Dancers,F By Aldegrever, Is Retnarkably Eveni, Andl Theie Are Seline Verly Linc Ilimpressiolns Of Sitigle Subject. Early Enigltsh Porcelain At Tie Galleries Of Miessrs. Stoner And Evans, 3, Kinlg-Street. St. Jamess-Square,, There Is On View A Smnall But Chloice Collection Of Early English Porcelain, Lent Bv Lord And Lady Fisher. In Looking At Such Wvares It Is Necessary To Dismiss Front The Minid The Ideals Of The East With Whiwel We Are Noiwadavs More Familiar, And To Accent. The Conventions Of The Daintv Roguie In Porcelain. Aul Thie Famnous Kifus, Bowv, Chelsea. Lowestoft, Bristol, Ilymouth, Worcester. And Loughton Alal, Are Represented. Antd Some Of The Piecesaaostlv Ornamental Figures. Thoughi The Loavestoft Is In The Form Of Mugs Atid Jugs-Arv Very Rare. Tho Chelsea Group, - Datciting Rouni Tile Araypole, After Teniers, For Inistzntice, Is Lot Often Seen. Chelsea, Mostly Of The Red Tmchoi0 Period, Roiiund About 17 O. Is Int The Majoritv, And, Ivith Stich Iharoiing Thineis A,S Ceres, The Sportsimatil The Sportsmalls Wvife, Lat Nourrice, Andl - The Cook. Vill Nrobably Gain Ios,T Favour. But Wve Confess To A Thrill Of Surprise At The Dignity Of Three Plymouth Figures, Including A Diana. Tie Of The Lowestoft M1Nt1S Is Diecorated With Atm Ealsy Cricket Match. Grahal Gallery Vtnidoubtedlv The - Fabric Pictures By Miss Marv Ireland .Are The Inost Interestinig Thinggs In The Present Exhinitiions At- The Glraham Gallery, 2, New Bond-Street. Tlev Are Interestilng. Too, For Strictly Artistic Reasolns--Pat-Tern And Colour-And Not, Merelv Becauise They Relpresent. T New Minor Art. They Are Made On The Priniciple Of Ctut Paper Desiglis. Except That The Materials Are Fabrics Of Tifferent Textures. With Excellenit Tsste .Miss Ire Landt Employs The Pattern Of The Stuftf To Suggest, But Not To Imitate, Niaturalistic Detail, Adapting The Thickness Of Th-C Material To Different Plames 6F Distance With Great Skill. The Landscape Designis, Such Is Crest Of The Hill And Autiumn Exvenitig, Make The Best Inipression-Pertly Because Thev Rcly Most Complietely U1Pon Diesign -Btmt Pomona And Isolde Are Good Figure Subjects, The Other Exhibitors Are Imiiss L. Stuart Smithson And Liss E. B. Macdonald, Who Show Small Flower Painting4S Anid Lattdscane Sketches In Oil. - A Shady Spot And Marigolds, By Mliss Siulithson, And Summer And An.Enrones, By Miss Macdonald. Can Be Praised. Colour Prints At The Macrae Gallery, 16, Fiulhaum-Read, There Is An Exhihition Of 41 Colour Prints, Publishied By The Forest. Precss. Which Was Tounded By Mr. Hesketh Hlubibard Inl The Nei Forest A Fewv Years Ago. The Modest. Aim Is To Provide Decorations For The Small Home At Small Prices. Without Affording Anything Of Striking Originality Or Beauty In Desigil, The General Effect Is Pleasing, And Simpler Than Is Often The Ca Sc Inl This Kinid Of Work. Onie Is Rather Incitied To Helieve That Keeping The Price Downu Has A Good Influence Oil The Making Of Coour Prints From Wrood, Since It- Disc Ourages The Artist Frot Iattemlptilig Subtleties. After All, The History Of Tjhe Kind Is Small Profits And Quick Returins.. .Ludefordi, By Mr. Leslie M. Wnard, Wheelwrights, By Mar. Hesketh Hubbard, Breton Fishing Boats, Bh Miss Dorothy Woollard, Harbour Lights, By Iir, T. T. Blaylock. Andl Wutapping, By 31Iss Mlarjory Avhittingtoni, Are Some Of The Best Decorations. Beaux Ar-Ts Gallery Mr. A. Baker Clack, Who Shows Recent Pailltings Of Lrench Laiidscape Aud Still Life Subjects At. The Br3Aux Arts .Allery, Brutonplace, Gives Mlost Pleasure Wlhen He Reduaces The Picture To A Lecorative Pattet Itin Coinparatively Flat Colour, Trusting To Directiou Of Hrushwork Rather Thau Changes Of Tone To Give Interost And Varietv. The Iipressmien -Given Is That Lie Does Noi Yet Know Enough About Tho Construction Of Things To Panit Strongh, And Tile Big Still Life Subject Of Fiowers And F Ruit Is Incohereont In Effeci, Thoughl T,He Objects Themselves Are Wvell Arranged. But Some Of The Slighter Landscapes, Suicl As Le E3Dge Of Tle Wool. In Which Everything Is Set Dowii In Vertica-L Touches, Are Charming, And In Miost Of The Pictures The Etfectl Of Light Is Wvell Realized. Throuigii The Trees Is, Pictorially, A Very Aniusing Wvater-Colour, Being Worked Out In A- Series Of Square Touches Of The Scale Of Tite Roofs. 1R. Clack Appears To Have A Tatent For This Kind Of Dasiglling, Of Wvlhich There Are Traces Ilt Several Othtec Pictlures, Pink Peonies, In A. Grev Valse, With. An Answering Curl Of Decorationi, And Study In Blue Are Tvo Good Still Life Paintings. Mir. Austin Frederic1E In All His Work Mr. Auist-Lit Frederick, Who Shotvs Drawings, Etchings, And Line Engravings At The Twenlty One Gallery, 15, 3Iill-Street, Conduit-Street, Aias At A Large, Sinmple, Aind Solid Effect, For Which Lie Is To Be Commended, Andi His Work Is Excellent On The Technical Side. Yet., Somehow, The General Impression Made By His Exhibitioni Is Rather Ditill, And The Reason Is Probably That He Dloes Not Sufficiently Elaborate The Interest Of His Designs. This Is Always The Danger Of The Artist Iwho Is Primiarilv A Eraft,Snmam , Becalise It Is Difficiult For Hilm To Realize That Wvhat Excites Hin Does Not Neces- Sarily Excite Other People. To Make What Nmav Appear To Be A Nice Distinction, It Is Not Subiject Initerest That Mr. Frederick Lacks, For Ho Touches Life At Manlly Poilits, But Interest Of Patterin-The Way Things Hatppen On The Paper, Bltiiswork Has Dignity And A Feeling For Movement, As In Such Drawings As Rutiti Leataing, Pening Tie Lock Gates, Slielteriing, And The Tombstone Carver Amid Tile Etchitigs Of Pig Killers, The Wineshop, And The Chilrchi Door -One Of His Best Efforts.

Author: By a Staff Reporter
Title: Brewers double contribution to art exhibition
Full_text: Brewers Double Contribution To Art Exhiiition By A Staff Reporter A Second Tolly Cobbold Eastern Arts L Ational Art Competition And Exhibition Is Planned For Next Year. The Ipswiich Brewers Are Doubling Their Contributioii Towvards Casts From 3,000 To 6,000 And Eastern Arts Vill Increase Its Share From 4,000 To More Than 6,000. The Brewing Company And The Arts Association Are This Year Cooperating Over The Award Of Three Comtnissions Wvorth 1,000 To Photographers To Undertake Wvork On The Theme Of Watervays In The Region. The Pictures Uill Be Put On Exhibition At Colchester In October And Then At Seven Other Places In Thearea.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Besides The New English Art Club, Which Has Now Obtained A Quite Respectable Age, Two Other Clubs Or Societies O Artistshave Added Themselves To Thu Number Of Such Institutions, As Though There Were Not More Than Enough Already. When The Portrait Painters And The Twenty-Five Open In A Few Days, To Be Immediately Followed By The Old Water-Colour Society, There Will Be No Less Than Nine Of These Large Exhibitions On View In The West-End Of London, Not To Mention One Man And Onewoman Shows At Various Dealers Galleries. One Can Only Hope That All This Activity On The Part Of Modern English Artists Meets With Its Due Reward, Though It Is Hard To Say Where The Purchasers Of So Many New Pictures And Sketches Are To Come From. We Must Assume, However, That The Artists And. Their Men Of Business Know How To Keep Some Kind Of Balance Between Supply And Demand, Though It Is Difficult To Reconcile The Increasing Output With The Almost Universal Complaints That One Hears About Slack Trade. These Questions, However, Are Not Quite To The Point Just Now, When What Concerns Us Is The Merits And Demerits Of The New English And Other Exhibitions. The Small Gallery In Dering-Yard 67A, New Bond-Street Opens With A Fair Average Show, But One Altogether Less Interesting Than That Of Last May. The Chief Impression Made On The Visitor Is That The Tide Of Artistic Fashion At The Moment Must Have Set Towards Montreuil In Piccardy, Whose Marketplace, Church, Old Court-Yards, And Old Gardens Seem To Have Been The Summer Inspiration Of Mr. Wilson Steer, Mr. Hopwood, Professor Fred Brown, And Several Other Members. Is There To Be A Montreuil School As A Sequel And Rival Of The School Of Barbizon ? Hardly, For An Old Town, Charming Though It May Be, Cannot Supply The Infinite Variety Of Themes That Millet And Rousseau And Their Friends Found In The Forest Of Fontainebleau. But In At Least Two Of The Pictures Of This Little Place There Is Real Charm And Beauty In Mr. Steers Court-Yard And In Mr. Browns Market Day, Studies Of Brilliant Light Upon Old. Houses And, In The Latter Case, Upon A Crowd Of Moving Figures. One Of Mr. Steers Figures, However, Is A Puzzle What Is The Womans Black Head Doing In That Position ? Two Other Leading Members Of The Club Have Pictures That Will Attract Notice, Mr.-Tonks With His Bird-Cage 108 And Mr. Orpen With His Grace Orpen 59, And His Small, Seated Portrait Of Mr. Percy Wyndham In His Library 84. The Last Is Excellent A Good Likeness, Though A Little Stiffly Posed, And The Background Painted With What So Few Artists Can Combinea Right Sense Of Values And A Thorough Observation Of Detail. The . Portrait Of The Artists Wife Is Wholly Different, But Not Less Good Large In Design, And Full Of Movement. Mr. Tonkss Picture Is A Nearly Lifesize Portrait Of A Lady Tending A Bird-Cage, And Is, Like All The Artists Pictures, A Dexterous And Attractive Harmony Of Gay Colours, Among Which A Bunch Of Brilliant Flowers Strikes The Dominant Note. Mr. Sargent Is Again An Exhibitor, With Some Sketches Done In Switzerland And North Italy A Mountain Landscape, The Moraine, And Two Rapidly-Painted Groups, The Fountain, With Portraits Of A Brother Artist And His Wife, And The Brook, With Two Girls Lying By The Side Of A Tumbling River. Masterly, Of Course And The Faces Charming But The Hand Which A Touch Would Alter Seems To Have Been Painted So That Those Who Have Denounced, The Hands In Every Sargent Picture Might Find Themselves Justified. Lastly, Let Us Mention Honoris Causa The Admirable Plain Of York, By Mr. W. W. Bussell The Late Spring Of Mr. Mark Fisher The Imaginative Vue De Moret Of Mr. A. Jamieson And The Stall Of Miss Clare Atwood. The Drawings Are Remarkable For Some Fresh Successes Of That Excellent Artist Mr. Muirhead Bone And Some Distressing Failures By Mr. A. E. John, Who Seems To Be Trying How Much The Patience Of His Admirers Will Stand. One Of The New Gatherings Of Which We Spoke Is The Society Of Country Painters, Which Has An Exhibition At Messrs. Tooths, 175, New Bond-Street. Country Should Mean West Country, For Most Of The Artists Are The Familiar Denizens Of Newlyn And St. Ives. It Is Almost Enough To Mention Their Namesmessrs. Frank Bramley And Arnesby Brown, Mr. T. C. Gotch And Mr. Moffat Lindner, Mr. Adrian Stokes And Mr. Tuke, With Some Recruits From Other Regions, Such As Mr. Francis James And James Paterson. The Visitor May Be Confident, Therefore, That He Will See The Work Of Some Very Accomplished Men, And That The Gallery Is Worth Visiting. Of Course, Too, The Exhibition Consists Of Sketches, Studies, And Small Finished Pictures And Drawings, Indicating That The Society Exists To Satisfy The Wish Of These Prominent Painters To Show What Could Not Well, Be Sent To The Academy. Mr. Gotch Is, Perhaps, The Chief Exhibitor, While Mr. Tuke Sends A Dozen Studies But The Best Things Here Are Two Delightful Child-Pictures By Mr. Bramley, Who, Except For One Important Picture, Has Appeared In Public Too Little Of Late Years. A Word Should Be Added In Praise Of Mr. Hugh Norriss Pleasant Series Of Landscapes In Water-Colour And Of Mr. Ayerst Ingrams Vigorous Little Pictures Of The Sea. The Grafton Galleries Are Filled With A Vast Assemblage Of The Works Of The United Arts Club The Same Club Which Last Week Was The. Victim Of An Adverse Decision By The Court Of Appeal. We Are Not Here Concerned With That Judgment, Except To Express Our Sympathy With A Number Of Innocent Artists On Whom The Law Has Pressed Heavily. The Club Has Now Moved To The Grafton, Where Over 400 Pictures, Drawings, And Other Works Of Art Are On Exhibition. It Need Not Be Said That The Effect Would Be Far Better If The Number Had Been Half As Large But Those Who Can Pick And Choose Will Find Much To Admire In The Sketches Of Mr. .Lavery, The Pictures Of Messrs. Coutts Michie, Leslie Thomson, Hughes-Stanton, And Glyn Philpot, The Beautiful Calligraphy Of Mr. Graily Hewitt, And The Printing Of The Eragny Press. Among Many Minor Shows One That Claims A Word Of Notice Is That Of The Work Of Mr. Austin Spare, At The Bruton Gallery, Bruton-Street. Mr. Spare Is Very Young, And Therefore Has Time To Learn. What He Should Learn, First And Foremost, Is That Ugliness Is A Poor Sort Of Ideal, And Aubrey Beardsley A Poor Sort Of Model. Among All These 114 Pen Drawings There Is Scarcely One That Reveals Any Desire To See And Draw Beautiful Things. Moreover, The Work Is Often As Careless As It Is Clever But It Is Clever Enough To Promise Considerable Things If Mr. Spare Will Only Be Wise In Time.

Author: (By Our Art Critic)
Title: The Royal Academy
Full_text: The Royal Acadeivy I.-Pictures And The Public A Varied Exhibition Tlhe Annual Exhibition Of The Royal Academy Ioil Be Open To The Public On M1Londay. On Page 16 Is Given A First Se.Cction Of The Exhibits. By Our Art Critic Every Year It Is Necessary To Repeat That The Royal Academy Is An Institution With The Virtues And Defects Of The Kind. When Its Institutional Character Is Forgotteni, It Is An Open Question Wlhether The Royal Academy Suffers More Firom Its Friends Or Its Foes Frota Thlose Who Claim That It Adequately Represents Contemiiporary Art, Or From Those Who Deny That It Has Anything To Do Wvith Art Whatever. To Anybody. Who Regularly Frequents The Other Art Exhibitions Of The Year It Must Be Evident That The Claim Cannot Be Sustained That The Academy Has Very Little To Say To Contemporary Art In So Far As That Means The Ideas And Problems Which Are Exercising The Minds And The Talents Of The More Active Artists Of The Day But, To Anybody Whlo Goes Round Tile Academy Wvith An Unprejudiced Eye, It Is Equally Evident That A Good Deal Of Genuinie Art Finds Its Way Into Burlington House. A Moments Reflection Shows That In Wlhat It Does And Wlhat It Leaves Undone The Academy Does Not Differ From Any Other Institution. No Institution Keeps In Very Close Touch With Life In The Province That It Nominally Represents It Would Lose Its Character If It Did, Because An Institution Has A Life And Organization Of Its Own Irrespective Of Wvhat Is Going On In The World Outside. Nobody, For Instance, Would Atrgue That The Family Represents The Maximumn Of Available Friendship And Affection. On The Other Hand, No Institution Can Completely Ignore What It Nominally Represents, And Continue-And The Academy Goes On From Year To Year. As To The Gains And Losses To Art By The Continued Existence Of The Academy As An Institution There Is Much To Be Said On Both Sides. The Root Of The Question Is The Relatiotn Of The Acaderny To The Public. On That Point We Had Some Striking Evidence In The Popular Success Of The Italian Art Exhibition-For It Would Be Idle To Pretend That The Exhibition Attracted Half A Niillion People Entirely By Its Intrinsic Merits. Sometliing Wvas Due To The Fact That It Was Held At The Royal Academny. To A Certailn Oider Of Mind The Ideal Of An Unslhepherded Public In Close Contact Wvitlh Contemporary, Art Is Tempting, But Experience Shows That Thinlgs Do Not Happen That Way. When People Can Go To See Anything Anywhere They Dont. Thliv Need To Have It Given A Local Habitation And A Name. Academiy Art What It Amounts To, Then, Is That-Like Aiiy Other Institution-The Academy Makes Up As A Public Convenience For Wlhat It Neglects In Contemporary Art. There Is No Reason Whatever To Suppose Hat The General Public Would Get Inlto Closer Contact Witlh Contemporary Art If The Academy Wvere Abolished. Going To Churchl Is Not The Whole Of Religion-But We Knowv All About The Tman Who Goes To Chlurchl In Tle Greeon Lields. What The Academy Represents Is, Roughly, What The Great Majority Of People Niean By Art-Which Is Not Necessarily Nearer To The Hteart Of Thc Subject Than What They Nlican By Literature Or The Dralma. It, Wvouldl Not Be Safo To Call It Academic Art, Becaziso The Wvord Is In Dispute But Acadeniy Aiit, With Its Implicaitioni Of Alaptation To The Tastc Of The Majority Wvho Find Burlingilton House An Aniual Convenience, Is A Fair Enoughi Description. Some Such Preliminary Is Necessairy To A Just General Estiiiate Of The Present Exhibition. It Is Oven Less In Touch Withl Contemporary Art Than Have Been Those Of Recent Years, But It Is Rather Better Than Usual, And Much More Varied In Effect, On Its Own Lines. Taken As A Whole, It Emphasizes The Institutional Character Of The Academy And Cultivates Its Peculiar Resources. From Wahat Has Been Said It Almost Follows That There Are Rmore Oil Paintings Than Last Year65 To Be Precise-Or The Year Before, Because The Typical Academy Picture Is The Oil Painting. The Quotation In The Catalogue Is From The Late Poet Laureate With New Attainmnent New Orders Of Beauty Arise. Fromi Wlhat We See Around Us Tlhis Can Only Be Interpreted As Meaning That Newv Beauties Are Seei When Beautiful Subjects Or Objects Are More Perfeotly Represented Or Arranged In A New Order. With The Order Of Beauty Which Arises Fjoni The Play Of Forlmis Or Colours In Tho Abstract Tho Academiiy Has Little Concern. Distinguishing Fe.Xtur.Es As Last Year, Gallery Vi. Is Devroted To Drawvings, Engravings, And Etchings, In Wvlichl The Tehlnical Standard, At Least, Is Consistently Higl, And Water-Colour Overflows-Largely In The Form Of Tetupera, Whlich, If Nlemory Can Be Trusted, Is Officially Recognized For The First Time-Into The Smaller Of The South Rooms. The Maost Startling Incidert In The Exhibition Is A Watercolour By Mr. P. Wilson Steer-Not Sent In By The Artist But Bought By The President And Council Under The Terms Of The Chantry Bequest In One Of Their Excursions Inito Contemilporary Art. This Alone Xwould Distinguish Lll Academy Of 1930, But In Addition Tlhere Is An Cxhibit, Of Plate For Delhi, By The Goldsmitlhs Company, Which Is Surely Tho Thin End Of The Wedge Of Applied Art. Tho Placo Of Honour In The Big Roomii Is Held By A Landscape, The Valley Of The Var, France Sunrise, By Sir H. Hughesstanton, R.A., And The Problem Of Liow Best To Colour The Walls Of The Big Room Is Still Unresolved. At Present They Are Of Tho Samre Sullen Purplish Terra-Cotta Wvhicli Menaced The Florentines In The Italian Art Exhibition. Tlho Best Colour For All Purposes Is Admittedly Difficult To Decide, But Going By The Look Of The First Room One Wvould Say That Something Between Its Grey And The Biscuit Of The Frieze In The Big Room Should Serve. Except On A Small Scale, In Groups, There Is Only One Royal Portrait, Her Mlajesty The Queen, By Mr. David Jagger-Three-Quarter Length, Seated, In A White Satin Evening Dress And Fur-Collared Cloak Of Royal Blue-And It Is Interesting For Several Reasons. In The First Placo It Is Obviously An Unofficial Portrait, And So Suggests A Particular Graciousness, And In The Second Place It Presents A More Credible Likeness Than Almost Any Royal Portrait We Have Ever Seen. What It Suggests Is The Pictorial Record Of One Of Those Endearing And Unrehealrsed Contacts Between Sovereign And Subject That Wve Read About When The King Or The Queen Goes Visiting Among Their People. This Is Said With The Greater Satisfaction Becauso Mlr. Jaggers Style Of Painting, His Rather Slick Rendering Of Surfaces And Textures, Is Not Very Much To Our Liking. He Is Certainly To Be Congratulated On The Use He Has Made Of This Opportunity. There Are Several Pictures Of The Problem Kind, And The Happiest Is The Chess Playerstwo Little Girls On The Floor Of A Gaily Furniished Room, With Sunlight Striking Across-By Sir John Lavery, R.A. Particularly In Colour, It Leans Too Heavily Upon Assorted Facts To Bo Called A Great Work Of Art, But It Is A Very Ingenious Composition In Perspective, Andl, Taken Together With His Ecellent Poritrait Of Time Lord Mclchett, So Firmly Constructed And Solidly Realized As To Be Lot Iiiimiiediately Recognized As Hiis, It Himspires A New Interest In T He Artist. Twvo Of Tho Other Probleni Pictuires Afford A Useful Illtustration Of How This Kind Of Thing Ought To Be Done. Were Yott Theret Ihiea They Crucified My Lord ? By Mr. Mark Syiunns-A Sort Of Closely Packed Pre-Raphaelite Version Of A Pieter Brueghel The Elder Motive, Representing All Vypes And Orders Of Humanity At The Crucifixion-Dbes Not Really Set Out To Be A Painting, But A Picture To Be Read And Therefore It Is Accepted Xwith All Its Discrepancies. You Do Not Really See The Picture, But Through It To The Story. Destructive Allegory Ho-Mo Sapiens, By Mr. John Keating -Represcnting A Spectacled Rnan Bearing A Rifle, Gas Mask, Bishops Mitre, And Judges Iwig, Before A Background Of Skyscrapers And Aircraft, And, Presumably, Intended To Expose The Follies Of A Mechanical Civilization-On The Other Hand, Does Set Out To Be A Painting, Is, In Fact, By An Hrtist Wvho Can Paint Very Vell Realistically. Thle Result Is That You Do Not Accept The Allegory. The Realism Of The Representation Brings Out The Discrepancy Of The. Facts. Nor Is The Allegory True Man May Be A Fool, But Lie Does Not Build Skyscrapers So Close Together As That. The Moral Is That, Contrary To General Belief, You Cannot Both Paint A Picture And Tell A Story. Mlany Of The Academy Exlhibitors Do Not Try To Paint A Picture, But Before Coming To Their Works-Often Admirable On Their Own Lines-It May Be Wvell To Uiame A Few Things Of Outstanding Merit, For Artistic And Human Reasons Combined Sir Gerald Du Mlaurier, By Mir. A,Tigustus John, R.A., Is Probably The Firtlst Oil Painting In The Whole Exhibiticn. It Is Rather Grubby In Colour, But This, And An Effect Of -Worry In The Handling, Only Intensify The Impression That The Artist Has Completely Lost Himself In His Conception Of The Subject. The Head Being Placed Higah, The Clasped Hands Are Properly Left Unfinished. Othervise They Would Make A Second Focus. Altogether Mr. Jolins Work This Year Is Remarkable For The Way In Which It Puts Grip Of The Subject Before Facility. Portrait Of A Young Man -One Of The Several Diploma Works Which Lend Circunistantial Interest To The Exhibition, Is A Fine Head And Earl Spencer, Viscount Althorp, K.G., G.C.V.O.. Though, At A Glance And Near To, It Strikes One As Rather Comic, Is Seen At The Proper Distance To Be A Very Dashing Military Portrait, Naking Its Effect Bv Arrangement, And Having A Splendid Foil To Scarlet In The Dark Blue Background. The Work By Mr. John Wlhichl Is Niost Likely To Be Argued About Is His Portrait Of Miss Tallulah Bankhead In The First Room. In Form It Is A Narrowish Upright, With The Lady In Pink, Wvith Lightly Crossed Hands, Against A Grey-Blue Background. It Is Definitely Fantastic, With Suggetions Of Both Rossetti And Albert Moore, But It Springs Like A Flower Out Of An Intense Reaction To An Inter.-Sting Personality. Two Other P9,?Traits Claim Attention. The First Is Rthe Late Dame Miillicent Fas Cett.. U.B.E., Ll.D., By Mirs. Annie L. Swynnerton, A.R.A., Which Nmakes A Devastating Comparison With Milss H. M,. Wvhite, Ll.D., Principal, 4Lxander College, Dublin, By Sir Wivilliam Orpen, R.A. There Can Be No Question Whichl Is The Cleverer Of The Two, But Wvhereas Sir William Orpen Puts You Off With A Brilliant Rendering Of Externals, Mrs. Swynnerton Presents You To A Real Human Being. The Titles Of The Twvo Subjects Niake The Coniparison All The Morc Pointed. Tlhe Other Portrait Is 2Miss Lidgett, By Mr. Francis Dodd, A.R.A. It Is Chosen Because It Showvs Very Wvell The Kind Of Portraiture That English Artists-Since They Lost The Decorative Swving Of The Eighteenth Century-Attempt Most Successfully. As A Picture-Though The Colour Scheme Is Pleasing-It Has No Great Merit, The Figure Having No Depth, But From The Point Of View Of Character And Facial Expression, Particularly In The Eyes, The Painting Of The Bead Is A Wonder. To Be Continutd

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. St. Georges Gallery. Thlose Wvilo. Wvitliout Ally Selltimeiitil Prejudice. L1Nl A Difficulty Iu Appreciating Ail Jaeob Epsteiius Pallel In The Liideoli Memorial Miglit Well Go To The St. Eorges Gallery. George-Street, Ilanover-Iquare, Wl-E- They -Vill See A Plaster Cast Of The Scullptors Original Study, Presumably From The Living Model, For The Head Of Itima. To Describe It As N Upturined Head Is Merely To State Its Positioni It Is, In Effect, The Head Of An Ecstatic Creature Drinkinig In The Light. Seen Thus At Close Quarters, The Head Should Present No Difficulty To Anyboly, And The Modifications Made In The Panel Are Determined By Material And Tho Distance At Wvliici The Work Is To Be Seeni. A Bad Sculptor Would Lhave Reproduced The Moulded Head In Stone And Made It Insigiilleat Mr. Epstein, Kniowing His Business As A Carver, Bas Male A Transliationi Similar To Thlat Made In Adapting A Study From Niature To Stained Glass. Otherwise The Present Exhibition At The St. Georges Gallery Is Interesting And Unconventionial. Lt Contains 16 Of Mr. Franik Braugwyns Less Familiar Vater-Colour And Pastel Drawiings, Of Whicil Breaking Up The Britannia And Cannon Street May Be Nanied As Particularly Striking Examples, Sonie Vigorous Pastel Drauwings Of The Nude By Mr. Austini 0. Spare, Masterly Zis To The Facts, But Leaiving The Appreciation Of Form Open To Questiox And A Series Of Theatrical Designs By Mr. Ordon Craig. These Last, Particularly Design For Hamlet, Play Scene, Open Air Theatre, And The Beggars Opera, Act 1, Seeiie 1, Ale Wonderful Examples Of Emotional Effects Produced By Simple And, So Lfr As Caa Be Judged, Very Practical Means.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Entertainments Art Exhibitions The Von Auspitz Collection The Von Auspitz Collection Of Old Nasters, Exhibited At Agnews Galleries, 43, Old Bond Street, Is An Amusing, Ingenious, And Sophisticated Collection Which Admirably Reflects A Modern Taste In Old Masters. Where A Picture Is Not Precisely A Good One, It Is Usually Entertaining, And It Is Obvious That The Collector Has Not Been Oppressed By Great Names. Italian Paintings Predominate, Althouglh The Finest Works Of Art Are From Other Schools. Thus There Are A Small Sketch Of A Head By Rembrandt, A Large Landscape By Ruisdael In Which The Painter Has Frankly Accepted And Made A Most Interesting Harmony Of The Most Difficult Greens And Reds, A Goya Portrait Which Is That Rare Thing, A Solid Work With Exquisitely Pretty Colour, An Impressive Portrait Of An Old Lady By Memling, And An Interesting Portrait By El Greco, More Remarkable, Perhaps, In Its Colour Than In The Modelling, Among The Italian Paintings The Most Unexpected Is A Little Nativity By The Piedmontese Painter Defendente Ferrari. One Would Hardly Have Supposed From His Large Altarpieces, With An Awkward Mixture Of High Renaissance Chiaroscuro And More Primitive And Papery Forms, That This Painter Could Have Achieved So Elaborate A Definition Of Space And So Complete A System Of Romantic Lighting. It Is One Of Those Pictures Which Introduce One Into A Fantastic World Which Yet Appears To Have Its Own Consistency. Foppa, It May Be Remembered, Has Sometimes This Same Gift, But Here, In An Interesting Example Of His Work, A Saint Sebastian, He Has Rather Inconsistently Introduced A Leonardesque Figure Into A Romantic Landscape Composed In His More Usual Manner. It Must, Therefore, Be A Very Latc Work. There Are Several Curious Works Of The Ferrarese School, Of Which The Best Is A Remarkable Small Figure Of St. Anthony Abbot By Ercole Roberti, And The Oddest An Adoration Of Thc Magi, In Which The Virgin, It Is Interesting To Note. Must Have Been Copied Directly From A Flemish Picturc Or Drawing. It Is Not A Question Of The Usual Influence This Is A Complete Copy. The Attribution To Galasso Galassi Must Be Rather Speculative, Since Only One Work Doubtfully-By This Painter, Celebrated In His Time, Now Exists, And That Is Quite Different. Perhaps One Might Think Of Parentino As An Alternative. To Turn To More Imposing Works, There Are Two Largc Decorations By Tiepolo, A Very Sound Portrait By Moroni, And A Pleasing If Rather Hard Landscape By Canaletto S Nephew, Bellotto, Painted On His German Tour. A Small Deposition By Benozzo Gozzoli, With An Interesting Hint Of Castagno In The Landscape, A Pretty Prcdella By Matteo Di Giovanni, And Two Angels Making Music By The Maestro Del Bambino Vispo Should Also Be Noticed.

Author: Null
Title: The Persian Art Exhibition
Full_text: Ti-Ie Persian Art Exhibition Loa.Ns From South Kensington Seinoe 80 Objects Are Being Lent To The Persian Exhibition At Burlington House Bv Tlle Victoria And Albert Miuseum. The Department Of Textiles At Soutlh Kensington Is Believed To Contain A Collection Of Woven And Embroidered Persian Fabries Superior To Any Held Either In Public Or In Plrivate Owvnership Elsewhere In The Wvorld, And Between 30 And 40 Exaniples Of Miiaterial And Costumnes Lhave Been Provisionally Selected For Loan. They Will Include A Celebrated Sassanian Silk Damask Of The Sixth Or Seventh Century, Which Bears A Pattern Similar To That Represented On The Robe Of Chosroes Ii. In The Taq-I-Bostan Reliefs, As Well As A Silk Panel, Almost Equally Rare, Attributed To The Seljuk Period. Silk Bocades Of The Late Sixteenth Century, With Figure Subjects, And Robes And Coats Of Coloured Figure Brocade Of The Seventeenth And Early Eighteenth Centiuries Have Also Been Chosen. A Large Dark Blue Satin Portiere Of The Late Sixteenth Century, Brocaded With Palmettes, Butterflies, And Wisps Of Cloud,In Coloured Silks And Silver And Silver-Gilt Thread, Is To Be Temi. Porarily Transferred To The Academy. With It Will Go Numerous Types Of Embroidery Of The Sixteenth And Seventeenth Centuries, Traycovers For Presents Ranging Inito The Eighteenth Century, And At Least One Pair Of The Nakshe Or Womens Trouserings Of The Nineteenth Century. Two Silk Brocades Of The Mid-Sixteenth Century Whiclh Have Been Chosen Perhaps Deserve Special Mention-The Figure-Piece Of Prince Ehusrau Chosroes On Horseback, And A Repeated Garden Scene, In Which A Man Carrying A Wine-Flask And Cup Walks Across A Rocky Background Tenanted By Lions, Tigers, Gazelles, And Flying Birds. Seven Years Ago The National Art-Collections Fund Assisted The Museum To Purchase A Magnificent Panel Of Velvet On A Ground Of Cloth-Of-Gold The Design, Woven In Coloured -Silks And Silverthread, Shows A Cypress Garden And Figures Of Youths In The Rich Robes Of The Time Of Shah Abbas 1587-1028. This Will Be Seen At Burlington House, Together With The Single Carpet Which The Mluseum Is Sending, A Smau Silk-Pile And Silver-Threadd Lion Carpet Of The Seventeentlh Century Given To The Museum Shortly After The War. The Main Collection Of Loo Persian Carpets Wviu Remain At South Kensington. It Is Believed That Sufficient Examples Of Carpet-Veaving Are Coming To Burlington House From Elsewhere, Though There Are Half A Dozen In The M1Useums Vest Central Court, Ivich May Be Considered Still Incomparable-The Great Sixteenth-Century Ardebil Carpet, The Earlier Chelsea Cardet, A Vase Carpet, A Rare Garden Carpet, A Hunting Carpet Wvith Winged Figures, And The Woollenpile Carpet Which Belonged To William Bmorris. Tiles The Ceramic Collection At South Kensington Is Ahnost Equally Rich In Persian Work Of All Periods Apart From Dishes And Vessels The Museum Is Rich In Tiles, Esdeciauy Of The Early Lustre-And-Blue Mosque Or Mihrab Tvpe And In Tile-Pictures And Mosaics Of The Shah Abbas Period. In Pottery Qf This Period Other Contributors To Burlington Housd Are Weakest, And The -Museums Ceramic Loan Vill Accordingly Consist Of Vases, Bowls, And Dishes Of The Sixteenth-Seventeenth Centuries. Thirtyfive Pieces Have Been Chosen, Illustrating The Blue-And-Wllite Silicious Earthenware So Similar To Contemporary Chinese Porcelain In Its Designs, Anld The Blue, Turquoise, Green, Brown And Yellow Glazes And Incised Work. Specimens Of The Translucent White Ware Soine With- Wrinldow Glazing Associated Wvith Lipalian, And Of The Olive-Green And Red- Painted Kerman Ware Of The Same Age Are Being Dispatched To The General Exhibition Without Noticeably Decreasing The Museums Own Display. In General The Contributions From Southl Kiensington Are Intenided Only To Fiil Gaps Among Loans To Burlington House From Elsewhere. Onlv Two Examples Of Woodwvork-A Sixteenth Century Oblong Lacquered Box, And An Inlaid Medicine-Chest Of The Seventeenth Or Eighteenth Century-Have Been Selected. As Specimens Of Metal Work There Are Being Sent An Astronomical Instrument Of The Time Of Shah Abbas, Gilt And Damascened, And A Golden Achaemenid Armlet From The Oxus Treasure Complernentary To That In The British Mluseum. A Special Series Of Postcards Is Being Prepared, Illustrating Persian Art In The Miuseum, And Lantern Lectures Free To The Public Are To Be Given At 5.30 On Successive Thursday Evenings. Lr. Bernard Rnckham Will Begin This Course On Januarv 15 Witlh A Lecture On Persian Pottery. He Wvill Be Followved By Captain K. A. C. Cresswell On The Evolution Of The Dome, Lur. J. V. S. Wilkinson On Persian Book-Illustration, Imr. A. F. Kendrick On Persian Decorative Art, And Professor Upham Pope On Persian Carpets. Professor Tancred Borenius Will Conclude The Series By Discussing The Relations Betwreen Persian And European Painting.
