Title: United Artists' Exhibition
Full_text: Tnited Artists Exhibition Contemporary Art At Burlington House For The Third Time Since The Outbreak Of War The Royal Academy Is Housing In Its Rooms A Winter Exhibition Of Contemporary Art, In. Which It Has Cooperated With 26 Other Exhibiting Societies. Two Gbod Causes Are To Benefit From This United . Artists Exhibition. The Duke Of Gloucesters Red Cross And St. John Fund Is -To Receive The Surplus Of Gate Money Over Expenses. The Artists Are Giving One-Half Of All Money Received From Sales To Be Divided Between That Fund And The Artists General Behevolenit Institution. The Pivate View Is Being Held To-Day And The Exhibition Wiu Open To The General Public To-Morrow. Dn All Some 1,100 Exhibits Are On Viewv, And Rhey Include Oil-Paintings, Waler-Colours, Drawings, Engravings, Miniatures, And Sculp- Tire. Cerjain Popular Artists Have, Unfortunately Not. Contributed, But Others Have, Sent Good Examples Of Their Work. And Sirice She Exhibition Does Notexclude Work Which Has Been Shown Before It Affords A Very Welcome Chance Of Renewing Acquaintance With Several Pictures Which One Has Admired On Other Occasions.- In Particular There Is The Opportunity Of Confirming Ones Impression Of Mr. Lawrgrsce Gowings Remarkable Lady With Book, Seen Not Long Since At She Leicester Galleries.I Lt Stands The Test Of The Big Gallery Af Burlintton House Very Well-Indeed, In These More Spacious Surroundings She Balance Of The Picture, And The Recession Of The Room Behind The Sitter And Her Sofa, Are The More Readily Appreciated. The Big Gallery In The Same Gallery Is Miss Amy K. Brownings Country Pride, A Very Jolly Spontaneous Picture Of A Mother And Child, Painted In Agreeably Clean Colour, Chiefly Blues And Green. Another Pleasant, If A Trifle More Selfconscious, Painting Is Mr. T. C. Dugdales Old Gardener Leaning On His Spade Against A Translucent Background Of Shady Vetation. Mr. George Harcourts -Rhe Lute Shows With What Elegance This Artist Caid Handle Something That Is Almost A Costume Piece The Ladys Blue Coat Is Very Effective And Yet Give Il Life And A Sense Of Realty. -Other Pictures In The Big Gallery Which.Will Attract Attention Are Mrs. Elizabeth- Polunins Excellent Likeness Of Professor W. G. Constable Miss Sylvia Gosses Le Chateau, Dieppe, Somewhat Influenced By Sickert, But With An Individuality Of Its Own Mr. John. B. Souters Enlertaining Scherzo -An Only Half-Serious Back To Boucher Group Of Cupids Destroying A Numbr Of Musical Instruments And, In A Looser, More Modemn Technique, Mr. Ben Mathewss Quietly - Decorative Landscape Near S1. Mawes, Cornwall. These Things, However, By No Means Exhaust The List Of Accomplished, Or.Otherwise Interesting, Oil Paintings-Nor Even Of Those In The Big Gallery. There Are A Large Number Of Artists For Example, Who Show Their Skill In Still Life And Flower Painting. In Still Life There Are The Studio Table V-Rather Sand-,Papered In Style, If One May Put It So-Of Mr. James Gunn, And Other Good Things By Mr. Adrian Hill Mr. Cowan Dobson, Mr. Will C. Penn, And Mrs. Helen Bedford, While The Flower Paintings Include The Luscious, But-Yet Rather Cold, Virtuosity Of Mr. H. Davis Richter,F The Attractive Colour And Comparatively Loose Drawing Of Mr. Rowland Suddaby, The Soft But Rich Hues And Broad Touch Of Miss Irene Ryland, And Pleasant-Things By Mr. Francis Dodd, Mrs. Evelyni Clutton-Brock, And Miss Grace English-To Name Only A Few. ,Architectural Painting, -Which Is In A Way Allied. To Still Life, Is Represented By Several Examples Which Are Not Only Decorative But Of Much Topographical Interest. Among Them Are Mr. John Coles Admirable No. 70, Park Road, N.W. An Enlarged Version, If Memdry Is Not At Fault, Of A Subject He Has Previously Painted On A Smaller Scale, Mr. Harold Workmans The Arches, Villiers Street, And The Soho Corner Of- Mr. Edward Le Bas, Who Seems, In This Picture, To Be Going Back To The Tradition Of The Camden Town Group.- - Pleasant Landscapes Though Landscape Is Not The Strongest Feature Of This Exhibition, There Arc Nevertheless -As Iri Almost Every Collectioh Of English Pictures-Some Good Things Of The Kind. Many Of Them, However, Are Comparatively Small, Like Sir Walter Russells Altogether Charming Studland Deach, With Its Bright Bathing Tents Outlined Against A Darkl Green Line Of Trees Coming Down To The Shore. Mr. Lucien Pissarros Thistle-Grown Field In France Mr. Philip Connards Little Sutton Farm, Miss Constance Bradshaws A Welsh Estuary And Miss Elsie Fews Delicately Gay And Pretty Little Eywood House With. Things By Mr. Sydneylee Mr. P. H. Padwick, Miss Ethel Gabain, Mr. William Hoggatt, Mr. John Copley, And Others, Also Linger Pleasantly In The Memory. So, Too, In Other Kinds, Do Mr. Claude Rogerss Small Head Of A Woman, Very Solid And Full Of Character, In Spite Of Its Comparative Lack Of Definition And Of A Rather Disturbing Shadow On One Cheek Mr. C. Maresco Pearces Lively Little Conversation Piece. No. 13, Bedford Square Mr. Ethelbert Whites Peace In Kensington Gardens, A Picture Of Londoners Taking Tea Under Gaily Coloured Umbrellas Which Showvs A Change Of Style, Both In Subject And Colour, From His Usual Work Mr. A. K. Lawrences Large Nude Standing Among Rocks And, By Way Of Contrast To The Last, Mr. Ruskin Spears Sombre Little Nude Study. The English Standard Is So High In Watercolour That A Critic Isapt To Be Exacting In Considering It, And Certainly There Are A Good Many Essentially Trivial Things In The Watercolour Rooms At Burlington House. But There Are Some Good Things Too, Such As Mr. George Grahams Green And Grey Drawing Of Rain, Falling On To The Fells Out Of A Leaden Sky, Mr. E. Boye Udens. Excellent Architectural Burgate Street, Canterbury, And Mr. Martin Hardies Windy Sky With Birch Trees Bent Across It. Mr. E. A. Sallis Benneys Blue Monochrome Of Kings College Chapel, Cambridge, Is Also A Sound Work. Mr. Robin G.Uthries Pen And Wash Drawing Of A Girl, Dinette, Is Lively And Nervous And Mr. Tan Strangs Tree Group. Buckinghamshire Shows Once More With What Riclness As Well As Detail This Artist Drawvs Landscape In Black Chalk. Therc Are Convincing Portrait Drawings Of Miss Dorothy L. Sayers By Pigalle, And Of Dr. Malcolm Sargent By Mr. Russell Reeve. Engravings And Sculpture Of The Engravings It Is Here Possible To Say No More Than That They Include Dry-Points By Sir Muirhead Bone And Mr. Malcolm Osborne, And Wood Engravings By Mr. C. W. Taylor And Almost As Perfunctory Treatment Must Be Given To The Sculpture. A Special Word, However, Must Be Spared For Mr. Charles Wheelers Head-Grave And Slightly Stylized Syrinx, In Polished Lead, And To Another Heat In The Same Medium, Mr. George Ehlichs Restrainedly Tragic Dumb Girl. The Exhibition Does Not Cover The Whole Of Contemp6Rary Art. The More Advanced Schools Are Hardly Represented-Though There Are Contributions By Miss Eileen Agar And Mr.,Ceri Richards-And Such Painters As Mr. Ivon Hitchens, Though Present, Are Not Seen At Their Best. Even Amorig The Academic Painters Some Eminent Figures Are Absent. Yet There Is Much That Is Attractive Among The Exhibits And, Since The Walls Afe Not Overcrowded, They Arc Seen To Advantage. To The Royal Academy, And To The Exhibiting Artists The Thanks Or Thc Public Are Certainly Due And, As The Cause Which Has The Patronage Of The King And Quteen Is Excellent, It Is Greatly To Bc Hoped That Thc Exhibition Will Meet With An Encouraging Reception And Brisk Sales. . Illustrations On Daze 6.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Mr. Clifford Hat.. Mr. Clifford Halls Oil Paintings At Roland, Browse And Delbancos Gallery, 19, Cork Street, Include A Number Of The Small Paintings In Which He Always Seems Most At Ease, But Also Some Larger Works In Whih He Has Worked Very Methodically And With An Admirably Serious Approach. His Technique And Style Derive From Sickert But His Larger Designs Are Usually Stiffer And More Geometrical Than Those Of The Master He Uses His Medium With A Certain Austerity And Concentrates On Form Construction And A Strictly Calculated Design. Place De Lodeon Is Perhaps The Most Successful And The Most Completely Realized Of His Landscapes In Some Of His Other Works May Be Seen The Defects Of His Qualities, A Certain Aridity And The Absence Of Any Spontaneous Response To His Subject. In Mr. Leslie Hurrys Watercolour Drawings At The Same Gallery Modem Surreahsm Is Combined With An Imitation Of The More Preposterous Inventions Of English Painters Of The Romantic Revival. Perhaps The Strangest Mixture Is In Industrial Family, Where Mechanized Figures Appear Against A Background Of Strawberry Hill Gothic. His Theatre Designs For Kcing Lear And Medea Are Less Whimsical And More Portentous. Jankel Adler An Exhibition Of His Watercolours, Gouaches And Drawings In Various Mediums At Gimpel Fils Gallery, 50, South Molton Street, Makes A Good Introduction To The Art Of Jankel Adler. In Oil Painting His Touch Was Sometimes Heavy And He Had, Moreover, A Tendency To Use Overelaborate Concoctions Of Paint In His Effort To Enrich The Surface Of His Pictures. But In Watercolour There Are No Such Obstacles To Prevent Appreciation Of His Remarkable Fertility Of Invention, His Power Of Giving Vitality To The Most Extravagantly Distorted Forms, And The Natural Breadth Of His Design. His Art Was Based On That Of Picasso, And Adler Made No Very Radical Changes In The Idiom He Borrowed, But He Used It With Complete Freedom And As An Appropriate Expression Of His Own Quite Individual Imagination His People Are Never Picassos And Their Expressions Are Very Different Even When Their Bodies Are Constructed In Much The Same Way. It Was For This Reason, No Doubt, That He Had Such A Marked Influence On A Number Of English Artists Just After The War Through Adler The Young Painter Was Introduced, Not So Much To Picasso Himself, As To The Possibility Of Using What Was By Then A Familiar Mode Of Distortion, In Themes Of His -Own Choosing Rather Than In A Mere Variation On Picassos Own Themes. Marine Arnsts The Fifth Annual Exhibition Of The Society Of Marine Artists, At Guildhall, Is Largely Dominated By Paintings, Of Which The Shipyard By Mr. Norman Wilkinson And Glamorous Night By Mr. Charles Pears May Be Taken As Good And Characteristic Examples, In Which The Artists Style Has Clearly Been Affected By The Requirements Of Modem Methods Of Reproduction. As Firm Outlines And Sharp Contrasts Come Out Best, This Certainly Makes For Clarity Of Design, But Also, In The Attempt To Render The Multiplicity Of Waves And Ripples With A Perfectly Clear Definition Of Every Contour, For The Use Of Rather Rigid Formulas. Mr. Pearss Black And White Sea, With The Sparkle Of Reflected Light Indicated By A Multitude Of Neat Dots, Is An Extremely Ingenious Instance Of The Use Of A Device Which Would Be More Justifiable In A Poster, For Example, Than In A Painting. But There Are Also A Number Of Workswhich Are Painted With A Freer Finish And More Interest In The Actual Quality Of Oil Paint Among These May Be Noticed Mr. Leslie Kents The Foreshore And Mr. P. Maurice Hills Attractive Little Interior, Marine Only In The View Through The Door And Window, The Toll-Bar Cafd, Fowey. Among The Watercolours May Be Noticed Mr. John Worsleys Sensitive View Of Portsmouth Harbour, Mr. S. E. Becks Modest Little Study Making Smoke, And Some Accomplished Paintings By Mr. Martin Hardie.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions The Architect As Painter At The Marlborough Fine Art Gallery, 17-18, Old Bond Street, There Is The First One-Man Show In London Of Paintings And Drawings By Mr. F. M. Gross, An Austrian Artist Whose Work Has Often Been Shown On The Continent. He Is An Architect As Well As Painter, But There Is None Of The Usual Tight Construction Of The Architect In His Pictures On The Contrary, His Drawing Is Free And Rhythmical And His Paint Is Usually Varied And Opulent, Sometimes With A Jewelled Brilliance Of Colour. His Largest Painting, Girl With Fruitbowl, Has A Most Luxurious Appearance And With All Its Sparkle And Glitter There Is A Firm And Well Sustained Design, Though The Modeleng Of The Head Is Perhaps A Little Too Linear To Agree With The More Ornamental Passages Elsewhere In The Picture. His Smaller Compositions, In Oil On Paper, Pastel, Or Gouache, Are Agreeably Light And Delcate In Touch And Im Several, Particularly The Audience And Refugee Children, There Is Some Sharp Observation Of Character. Mr. Jim Wylies Paintings In Oil And Watercolour, Many Of Them Of Moroccan Landscapes, Vary Much In Quality, But At Their Best They Are Very Lively In Colour And With A Sharp Perception Of Values. His Watercolours Are Painted With Considerable Spirit, But Not Without Some Delcacy Of Handling.

Author: Null
Title: A Young Painter's Exhibition
Full_text: A Young Painters Exhibition Mr. Launce Gribbin Mr. Launce Gribbin, Now Holding A Small Exhibition At The Artists House, Manette Street, Is A Young. Painter Who Has Studied Under Mr. Ruskin Spear, Mr. Robin Guthrie, And The Late William Clause. He Is Showing Only 15 Paintings, Of Which Two Are Copies Of Old Masters, But From The Remaining 13 One Seems To Detect A Pleasant Talent For Topographical Painting In A Manner Of Restraited Impressionism. Urban Views, Whether In London Or His Native Town Of Bexley, Suit His Temperament Well. A Favourable Example Is Trafalgar Square From St. Martin-In-The-Fields, Where Thc Greys And Purple-Greys Of A Cloudy Sky And Of The Buildings Are Relieved By Tie Cheerful Green Of Thc Early Summer Trees And Grass And By The Red Of A Motor Omnibus. The Pictures Are To Remain On View Until August 28.

Author: Null
Title: Japanese Artist's Exhibition
Full_text: Japanese Artists Exhibition European Scenes And European Figures Seen Through Japanese Eyes Are The Theme Of An Exhibition Of Paintings By Miss Fumiko Matsuda At Mr. Arthur Jeffresss Gallery, 28, Davies Street. The Translation, However, Is Of The Gentlest Kind-Too Gentle, One Might Suppose For The Bias Is Towards Sentiment And Charm Without The Benefit Of Compensatory Crispness In The Style.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. If The Numbers Could, Be Reduced By About Onehalf, The Exhibition Of The Society Of Portrait Painters At The New Gallery Would Be A Very Good One Bub Ib Is Not Possible To Fill Three Large Rooms With Fine Portraits, Even Though A Few Should Not Be The Work Of The Present Year. Nearly All The Oil Pictures In The South Room Might Well Be Spared. But Not The Drawings, For These Include Some Of The Best Things Here, Especially Those Of Professor Legros, Mr. William Strang, And Mr. C, H. Shannon. For The Rest, All That Need Be Mentioned Are Mr. Richard Jacks Full-Length Portrait Of A Small Boy In Brown Clothes And A Red. Tam-O-Shanter Cap 122, Mr. Hugh Rivieres Lady Heygate, And .Mrs. Joplings Head Of A Gallant Young Corporal In The Imperial Yeomanry. We Come To A Higher Average Of Work When We Enter The West Room. Here Are Some Portraits Painted Many Years Ago, Such As The Well-Known Ford Madox Brown, By Himself, And A Small Half-Length Of A Frenchman, The Excellent Work Of Ribot Before He Fell Into His Disastrous Imitation Of The Black Masters. If Mr. Whistler Is To Keep His Hold, Even Of Those Who Sincerely Admire His Work, He Must Show Something Better Than Green And. Gold. 5 But, On The Other Hand, M. Blanche Cannot Fail To Conquer The Applause Of Those Who Until Now Have Known Only His Pastel Drawings By Such A Completely Successful Picture As His Arthur Symons, Esq. 9. Few Portraits Here Are So Completely Realized Few Are So Masterly In Technique. Mr. Hugh Glazebrcoks Miss Lilias Walker 17 Is A Success And Deserves Its Conspicuous Position Mr. John Colliers Joyce 26 Is A Charming And Evidently Truthful Portrait Of A Very Young Girl Mr. E. A. Waltons Dr. Dey Is A Powerful Picture, Which Will -Improve With Time And Mr. J. H. Lorimers Sir John Scott, K.C.M.G. 33, Is A Clever Likeness Of A Remarkable Man, Though We Confess To A Prejudice Against The Artists Fondness For Highly-Polished Surfaces. Child Portraits By Mr. Llewellyn 34 And Mr. George Henry 39 Lead Us On To Mr. Guthries Very Distinguished Picture Of The Late Alexander Osborne, D.L. 48, A Work Planned With Much Dignity, But Unfortunately Tending To Blackness In The Flesh Tints. Mr. Richard Jacks Mrs. Donald Smith 52 Shows Us This Painter Coming As Near To Mr. Sargent As Any Follower Is Likely To Come A Capital Picture In Every Way, Did It Not Suggest Somewhat Too Closely Another Painters Style. The Same Objection May Be Brought Against The Beautiful Work By Mr. C. H. Shannon, The Circular Group Called The Bunch Of Grapes 32. It Is A Fine Thing Both, In Design And In Colour, But It Inevitably Recalls The Pictures That Mr. Watts Used To Paint Some Thirty Or Forty Years Ago. In The North Room There Is Not So Much That Is Excellent. The Most Popular Picture Will He Mr. Heywood Hardys The Zetland Hunt, A Crowd Of Riders And Hounds With Aske For A Background But The Most Important Pictures From The Point Of View Of Art Are The Study By Mr. Watts 87 And The E. Davis, Esq., By Mr. Orchardson 83, Though The Latter Has Never Been Ranked Among The Best Of The Artists Pictures. Mr. A. Stuart Wortley, The President Of The Society, Shows A Carefully-Painted Portrait Of Lord Kinnoull 66, And The Contributions Of Mr. Collier, Mr. Blake Wirgman, And Mr. Lorimer Are Worthy Of Note. With The Portraits Are Shown The Works Of The Society Of Miniature Painters, Who For The Moment Have Migrated Here From Bond-Street. The Light Yesterday Was So Bad That We Could Not Prptend To Judge Them Properly, But It Seems To Be An Attractive Exhibition. Most Of The Wellknown Members, Such As Mr. Alyn Williams, Mr. And Mrs. Lee Hankey, Mr. Dudley Hardy, Mme. Debillemont-Chardon, And Many Other Ladies Are Well Represented. The Exhibition Of The New English Art Club At The Dudley Gallery Is Of Not More Than Average Interest Indeed, It Suggests Once More, And Rather Painfully, The Question Whether Anything Is To Come Of A Movement Which Has Promised For Ten Years And Has Not Come To Performance. The Best Thing Here Is Undoubtedly Mr. C. W. Purses Lord Roberts But This Is Avowedly A Sketch, And The Finished Picture Was Exhibited, Several Years Ago At The Academy. It Is A Brilliant Thing And. A Great Contrast To The Majority Of Equestrian Portraits, In Which Wooden Men Are Mounted On Immovable Horses. Mr. W. W. Russell, Mr. James Henry, And. Professor Fred. Brown Once More Show A Charming Gift For Landscape Mr. Conder Paints Rough First Sketches Of Watteaus, But Gives Us No Chance Of Judging Whether He Possesses Anything Of Watteaus Delicacy Of Hand. Mr. W. Orpen Has A Good Seated Portrait, Rather Too Black 119, And A Still Better Figure Subject Which He Calls The Mirror Close To This Latter Are Mr. Bernhard Sickerts Very Clever Chiswick Mall And. The Interesting Little Picture The Escaped. Bird, By Mr. Henry Tonks. The Water-Colours Include Characteristic Drawings By Mr. Brabazon, Mr. Francis James, Mr. V. 8. Mccoll, Mr. E. E. Fry, And Other Well-Known Exhibitors. Of Minor Exhibitions And. One-Man Shows There Are So Many That We Cannot Pretend Even To Name Them All. Bond-Street Teems With Them. Messrs. Forbes And. Paterson Have Yet Another Display Of The Colour-Dreams Of Monti.Cell!, Whom, I In Spite Of All Temptations, The Lovers Even Of The Most Modern Art Cannot Quite Bring Themselves To Regard, As A Great Man. Great Or Not, However, Tins Little Gallery Contains The Best He Could, Do. At Messrs. Dowdeswells, Mr. Oliver Hall Proves With The Brush, What He Has Often Proved, With The Etching Needle, That He Has A Real Gift For Landscape, Though We Are Not Sure That He Quite Realizes The Variety Of Colour Possessed By The Landscapes Of Southern England. Mr. Finn, At The Modern Gallery, Once More Shows Clever Drawings Of Cathedrals, This Time Choosing Lincoln, And Ely. It Is Impossible To Praise The Extremely Artificial Beauties In Mr. Herbert Schmaltzs Dream Of Fair Women At The Fine Art Societys Gallery But In The Adjoining Room Are A Number Of Those Beautiful Visions Jjof Mr. Albert Goodwins, Of Which It Is Scarcely Possible To Have Too Many. Lastly, If -We May Pass From Bond-Street To The Neighbourhood. Of Christies, And. From The New To The Older Art, We Find, A Number Of Interesting Pictures At Messrs. Shepherds, Who Still Strive Manfully To Present The Public With Good, Works Of This Class, In Spite Of The Increasing Difficulty Of Finding Them. A Portrait Of The Wife Of William Collins, I?. A., By Mrs. Carpenter, Shows That The Celebrity Which That Lady Enjoyed As A Portrait Painter Was Not Undeserved And. A Few Genuine Works By John Russell, Gainsborough, And Opie A Lamplight Scenetogether With Some Good Old. English Landscapes, Make Up A Pleasant Little Exhibition.

Author: Null
Title: Hampstead Art Exhibition.-On Saturday
Full_text: Hampstead Art Exhtmtion.On. Lcterday Afternoon Tbo Grand Duke Michael Of Russia And Tho Countess Torby Attended The Opening Of The Hampstead Art Societys 19Th Annual Summer Exhibition At Tho Town Hall, Haverstock-Hul. Over 230 Works Of Art Arc On View, Amongst The Contributors Being Sir Alfred East, Sir James D. Linton, Mrs. Allingham, Mr. Yccnd King, Mr. Iv. H. J. Boot, Mr. P. L. Forbes, Mr. G. Hillyard Swinstcad, And Mr. J. Shaw Crompton. Tho Grand Duke, In Declaring The Exhibition Open, Expressed His Delight At Finding In That Charming Part, Oi London So Many Artists Who Were Capable Of Producing Such Exceptionally Fine Works. His Wife And He Were Much Impressed, By What They Bad Seen, And Wished The Society Continued Success. A Vote Of Thanks Was Awarded To The Distinguished Visitors On The Motion Of Mr. J. S. Fletcher, M.P., And Afterwards The Grand Duko Purchased, A View Ot Tho Garden At Golders-Hill By Mr. Frederick Evans. Tho Exhibition Will Remain Open For A Fortnight.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: -Art-- Exhibitions. - Leagh Pottery. Mr. Bernard Leach, Of St. Ives, Cornwall, Who Is One Of Our Two Most Artistic Potteis-The Other Being Mr. W. Staite Hutray-Has Treds The Interestin G Extperient .Of Holdig Tio Miultaneous Exhibitions Of Bis Work In London- One,, Of His. More Personal Creations In. Expensive 8Stoneware, At The Paterson Gallery, 5, Old Bond-Street And--The Other, Of Sound Had-Made Pottery In The Slish Ewtradition, At The Three Bhields Elery, S Hdolland-Sireet, Kens-T Of Any Possible Advantage To Mr. Lsch, The Circumstance Has Value Because It.Suggests. The Kind. Of .Relation There Ought To Be Between Precious Potting And More Commercial Production -T.Hough Al Mr. Leachs Work Is Innocent Of The Machine. People Often Question The Utility Of The Cloistered Virtue I! Represented By The - Examples At The Paterson Galleiy The Sculptural Pieces, Expressing The Artist In Every-Line And In Their Sober Glazes Of Russet, Grey,And Olive. The Answer Is That The Utility Is That Which Cloistered Virtue Always Has--That Of Acounsel Of Perfection, No So Much To Be Imitated In Wo,Aday Conditions As To Radiate An Influence. In Relation To Industrial Potting -The Pieces At The Paterson Gallerystand For Pure Artistic Research-As Necessary In Its Way As Pure Scientific Reserh. The Examplesat The Three Shields Gallery, Mostly In Orange-Brown Glazes With A Friendly Relationship To The Little Brown Jug, Being Stiu Hand-Made, Do Not Aetually Descend To The Factory, But, Representing Shillings Instead Of Pounds, They Form A Most Valuable Link Between Studio And Factory Conditions. A Spanish Artist. A Large Proportion Of The Paintingsand Drawings By Mr. Mariano Andrea Who Was Born At Bareelona In 1888 At The Claridge Gallery, 52, Brook-Street, Are Of Musical Subjects, And There Is More In The Circumstance Than Sentimental Preference Would Explain. The Truth Is That Mr. Andreul Is Strongly Musical In His Pictorial Inclination, Putting The Emphasis Upon Melody Of Lne. He Is, Fineed, A Very Skilful Composer, Able To Bring Human And Inanimate Forns-As Of Cellos And Pianos-Into Relationship So That They Make A Unified Design, And Wvhat Waes The Skill Au The More Remarkable Is That The Forms Are Sharply Delineated And Modelled In Relief With A Good Deal Of Gradation. Groupe Musicale, Of Ladies With Various Instruments Round A Piano, And Matin, A Group -Of Figures, Also With A Musical Reference, In Landscape, Are Delightful Compositions From The Point Of View Of Entertaining The Eye. Beyond That Mr. Andreii Does Not Go Very Deep His Work Is Curiously Remote From Psychological Interest-Though Deux Femmes Jouant Aux Eartes, With The Ace Of Hearts In Play, Hss An Emotional Su Lestiveness But-He Is A Very Accomplishe Mrftran, Particularly In Pencil. Nos. 2, 7, 15, 20, 33S, And 51 Are Excellent Drawings, Incisive In Definition, But With The Delieawy, Of Silverpoint In Modelling. Mr. James Gunn. Mr. James Gunn, Who Exhibits Ortraits And Landscapes At The Qolnaghi Ries. 144, New Bond-Street, Wins Respect And Gives Pleasure By Considered Refinement Of Workmanship In A Vein Of Simphfied Realism. His Work Is Not Lacking In Colour, But It Is Primarily Concerned With Tone Relations, Which Are Worked Out With Great Subtlety, Though With A Decorative Breadth Of Statement. Self-Portrait Is Practically A Study In Greys, Running Through The Whole Scale From Almost Hiit Wsiifst-Hlackthefleslitins-Heing Subdued Into Harmony With Them And The Pater Naade By The Greys, Apart From Their Representative Function, Gives A Good Idea Of Mr. Gunns Talent As A Composer. In The Fullflength Seated Cortrait Of James Pryde, Esq., Lent By The Scottish Modern Arts Association, Nothing Could Exceed The Tactful Care With . Hich Everything Is Placed Upon The Canvas The General Disposition Of The Fure Ir The Chair, The Relative Positions Of The Hesd, Gloved Hands, And Feet, The Eyeglassin The Right Spqt And Reflecting The Right Amount Of Light, The Discreet Reply Of The Thin Red Line Of The Screen Behind To The Magenta Socks. It Is This Capacity For Making The Most Of Everythtng For Pictorial Purposes, Without Departing From- Realism And With An Extremely Simple Manner Of Execution, Wlidh Gives Distinction To The Work Of Mr. Ctunn. The Diving Board And St. Paul From The South Are Two Out Of A Series Of Admirable Landscapes.-

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Ex-Hibitions. The Late Mrs. Downe. The Late Mrs. Walter Downe Winifred Downe, Who Is The Subject Of A Memorial Exhibition At Walkers Galleries, 118, New Bond-Street, Undoubtedly Had A Streak Of Genius-With All The Inequality In Performance Implied. She Could, Apparently, Do Nothing By Rule, But Sho Had Imagination, Wit And Humour, Keen Sensibility, A Natural Instinct For Design, A Fine Sense Of Colour, .And, At Any Rate In Water-Colour, Full Confidence In The Medium. There Is Batdly A Picture Or Sketch In The Exhibition Of 179 Items Which Does Not Give The Impression Of Whole-Hearted Enjoyment. Mirs. Downes Portraits Are Comparatively Commonplace It Was In Decorative Flower Studies And Rapid Imptessions Of Landscape That Her Personality Found Free And Characteristic Expression. In Such Flower Paintings As White Flower Group And Flower Piece, Lent By Mrs. Asquith, And Ivory And Grey, Loosely Composed, But In Perfect Balance, Nith No Great Concern For Depth, The Natural Susceptibility To The Emotional Appeal Of Form, As Well As Of Colour, Is Unmistakable. They Get By A Sort Of Rhythmical Instinct What Many Others Attempt By Theory. Market Day, 3Iontreuil, And The Old Curiosity Hop, An -Interior, Show How The Same Instinct Rather Than Science Enabled Mrs. Downe To Bring Much Detail Into Unity It Is The Underlying Tone, So To Speak, Which Holds The Pictures Together. The Freakish Humour Which First Attracted Notice To Mrs. Dovne Is Shown In D For Donkey Having A Lark And Holding Up The Traffic And Amiong The Landscapes, From The Miorridge, North Staffordshire, And Stormelouds, Bosham, May Be Specially Noted. Apart From Individual Excellences, The Exhibition Of Drawvings By Contemporary French Artists At The 1Hdependent Gallery 7A, Grafton-Street, Makes An Interesting And Not X-Ery Comforting Comparison With Any Similar Collection Of English Worksay, At The R.W.S. Almost Without Exception The 53 Drawings, Mostly In Watercolour, By Nine Artists Are Concerned With Fornmal Relations. Representation Is Not Ivoided, But It Is Treated As The Raw Material Of Design. We May Justly Plead That The Best Engli3H Work Gives A Greater Interest And A More Obvi3Us Charm To The Represenltation Itself, But The Greater Masculiniity Here Is Not To Be Escaped. Paul Signac, Who Carries Forward Impiessionism Into A Sort Of Colour Calligraphy, Is Perhaps The Artist Who Comes Nearest To Hridging The Two Shools, And Be Is Very Well Represented In La Rochelle And Antibes. There Is, Too, An Affinity Witl The Work Of Mr. George Clausen In The Brretoni Dravings By Jean Fr6Lant. Such As The Old Manor Hlousc And The Gulf Of 3Iorbihan, But They Strike One As More Sinewy.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibnonm Less-Known Artists. Under The Title Of I Works By Some Unknown And Less-Known Artists, A Very Interesting Exhibition Bas Been Arranged At The Goupil Gallery. If Memories Of Art School Exhibitions Can Be Trusted, Most Of The Contributors Are Either In The Later Stages Of Recognized Studentship Or At The Beginning Of Tleiz Professional Careers-Times Of Great Importance To Both Artists And Possible Patrons. All The 271 Works Have Been Sent In Under Sponsorsbip, For The Artist, Of Some Art School Head Or Artist Of Established Ieputation. Probably For This Reason The Exhibition, With Variety In Kind, Is Quite Remarkably Even In Quality. There Is Little, If Anything, Which Gives Prf Of Genius, But There Is No Rubbish, Nor Is There Anything That Can Be Described As Cxtravagnnt In Tendency.. As Might Be Expected, Many, If Not Most, Of The Works Are Initative, And Quite A Long List Could Be Made Out Of Wtul-Knowau Artists, Past And Present, Who Are Thus Reilcentd But There Is No Harm-Rather The Reverse In So Highly Technical A Business-In This So Long As The Imitation Is Intelligent, As It Is In Most Cases. It Is Only Here And There That A Method Has Been Adopted Without Any Apparent Grasp Of What Its Originator Was Driving At. The Most Encouraging Thing About The Exhibition Is The General Effect Of Responsibility Which It Produces. Detailed Criticism Or Description Is Hardly Caued For, Particularly Since There Is Little That Can Be Built Upon Positively, But The Names Of Mr. John L. Howard, Mr. Peter Brooker, Imiss Sine Mackinnon, Mr. Percy Horton, Mr. Roland V. Pitchforth, Mtir. C. A. Morris, Miss Mabel Bowden, Mr. David M. Jones, Mr. Powys Evans, Mr. M. K. Bowles, Miss Barbara Cayley Robinson, And Mr. Maurice Lambert May Be Suggested As Giving Particular Promaise For The Future.

Author: Null
Title: Exhibition Of Art Treasures At Manchester
Full_text: Bxhibition Of Art Treasres A? Manohrst.R. I Cw The Gallery Of The Academy Of The Belle Arte At Florence Still Furnishes The Best Illustration Of The Growth Of Italian Art Through The 14Th And 15Th Centuriea The Collections At Berlin And Munich Remain Unrivalled For E.Amples Showing The Development Of Painting In Germany Up To The Time Of The Reformation. Those Who Wish To See Assembled The Greatest Number Of Masterpieces Ofthetuscaii School Mnst Still Seek The Uffizi And The Pitti Palaces Nor Can Thebellinis, Giorgiones, Titians, And Tintorets Be Yet Appreciated Uithout Study Of Their Works In The Churches, The Scuole, And The Gaueries Of Venice For Ornamental Work In Ivory, Jewels, Precious Atones, And Metals, The Kunbt-Kammern Of Berlin And Vienna And The Green Vaults Ot Dresden Still Remain The Richest Repositories. For Ilustration Of The History Of Enamelling The Louvre Must Still Be Visited Nor Will The Enthusiast In Arms And Armour Be Able To Dispense As Yet With Many A-Days Laborious Search In The Arsenals Of Madrid And Venice, And The Zwinger Gallery In The Capital Of Saxony. In Short, The Manchester Collection Of Art Treasures Is Not An Assemblage Of Worhs Of Art And Wonders Of Design Unequalled In Any One Of Its Many Component Parts It Cannot Even Be Said To Exhibit In Au Its Branches The Masterpieces Of Each Which May Be Found In The United Kingdom, But It Is Fairly Entitled To The Credit Of Presenting Compactly, And Within Compass Of Even Those Who Cam Give But Little Time To The Study Of Art, A More Complete Illustration Of The History Of Au The Great Eurodean Schools Of Painting, And Of Most Of The Prin. Cipal Branche3 Of Design In Which Art Has Been Applied To The Uses Of Daily Life, Than Can Anywhere Be Found Gathered Under The Same Roof And It Opens The Way To Practical Application Of The Lessons Which May Be Deduced From All Its Early Examples Of Art And Design By Placing In Juxtaposition With These What Modern English Art And Contemporaxy English Design Have Done, And Are Doing, To Decorate Our Own Walls And Minister To Our Own Household Uses. When The Projectors Of This Bold And Comprehensive Umdertaking First Communicated With Prince Albert On The Sabject Of Their Design The Prince Strongly Recommended That The Collection Of Pictures Should Be Limited To The Old Masters. He Thought, Probably, That The Educational Object Of The Design Would Best Be Served In This Way, And That The Public Had No Need Of Any Other Gathering Together Of Contemporary Pictures Than The Annual Exhibitions, Metropolitan And Provincial On This Point The Manchester Projectors Differed From His Royal Highness, And, We Venture To Think, Wisely. Neither Ancient Nor Modern Art Can Be Thoroughly Appreciated Apart. Enthusiastic Devotion To Either, And Il-Judged Contemptfor Either, May Readily Be Engendered By Exclusive Study Of One Or Ofthe Other But Appreciation Isonlypossible To Those Who, Holding In Check Their Own Tendencies, And Studiously Estimating The Objects, Advantages, Conditions, And Applications Under And For Which The Ancient And The Modern Painter Worled, Will Be Content To Study The Art Of Every Century, From The 13Th To The 19Th. Opportunities Of Doing This By Help Of Anything Like A Complete And Systematically Arranged Series Of Examples Are So Rare That We Rejoice That The Planners Of The Manchester Lxhibition Did Not Let Slip The Chance Of Adding This, The Best And Fullest, To The Number. There Is No Other Country In The World Where It Is So Possible To Gather Within The Countrys Own Borders The Means Of Effecting This Completely, And That, Too Without Trenching On Public Galeries And National Collections. With The Exception Of Some Examples Of The Ceramic Art From The British Museum And The Department Of Science And Art, And Of Some Arms And Armour From The Tower, Everything Here Exhibited Comes From The Galleries Of The Sovereign, Or From The Collections In Private Houses. British Individualism Is Impressed On This As On Every Other Manifestation Of British Mind, And Along With This That Feature Which, Individual As We Are, Links Us More Closely In Nationality Than Any Other People,-British Public Spirit. The Work Has Been Planned For Objects Nothing Less Than National. The Owners Of The Rarest Pictures And Miniatures, Of The Most Fragile Treasures In Glass, Porcelain, And Pottery, Of The Most Precious Works In Gems And Gold And Silver, Of The Most Curious Specimens Of Cabinetwork, Of Engravings And Etchings, Unique And Almost Priceless, Have Not Secrupled, For A National Object, To Expose Their Treasures To The Dangers Of Packing And Transport, The Rislk Of Thieves And Fire, And The Thousand Hazards Of A Crowded Exhibition-Room. For Works Of Which The Money-Value May Be Reckoned In Millions, The Owners Have Only Required The Protection Of In. Surance To The Amount Of Less Than 200,0001. Where Contributions Have Been Refused It Has Been In The Vast Majority Of Cases, Not From Indisposition To Contribute, But From The Strict Stipulations In Family Settlements Forbidding The Transfer Of Heirlooms From The Galleries Where They Are Hung. And Thus Many Of The Noblest Tributes To Devotion, Of The Most Gorgeous Appliances Of Wealth And Civilization And Of The Most Artistic Ministrations To The Refinements Of Life, Have Found Their Way To Smoky, Sooty, Steamy Manchester And For Its Toiling Crowds, Within Hearing Of Its Never-Ceasing Dia Andwhirl Of Wheels, Under The Canopy Of Its Black Cloud From Innumerable Chimneys, Arises A Temple Dedicated Tothe Beautiful. It Was A Noble Duke, And Not Amanchester Cottonspinner, -Who Asked The Question, When Applied To For Some Of His Pictures, What In The World Has Manchester To Do With Art I Manchester Has To Do With Art, If Only Because It Is Condemned To The Most Continuous And Unlovely Forms Of Labour. It Has To Do With Art Because Art Is A Potent Means Of Education And Refinement And Without These Manchester Cannot Continue To Prosper, Morally Or Materially. It Has To Do With Art, Finally, Because Mianchester Is The Great Centre Of The Manufacturing District Of The North, And Art Is The Foundation Of Design, And Design Is Of The Essence Of Successful Manufactures. Before Entering Upon A Detailed Consideration Of The Works Here Exhibited, We Would Offer A Few Suggestions To The Committee With Reference To The Means By Which Their Undertaking May Be Made Most Conducive To Its Best Objects. The Sooner Some Plan Is Devised For Admitting The Working Tbousands To Their Exhibition The Better. Manchester Is One Of The Few Seats Of In- Dustry In Which A Saturday Half-Holyday Is The Rule N All Establishments. Let The Exhibition, Then, Be Opened On Saturdays At The Lowest Possible Prlce Of Admission-If 2D. So Muchthebetter-Fortheworking Classes. But For These The Contents Of The Building Will Be A Chaos Unless A Cheap And Compendious Guide-Book, Not A Detailed Catalogue, Be Furnished. If Thecommittee Do Notfurnishone Themselves, Let Them Select The Best From The Many Which Are Likely To Be Produced By Independent Enterprlse, And Give Facilities For Its Sale In The Building. Would It Not Even Be Possible To Provide Guides, Competently Informed, Who At Stated Intervals Might Conduct Parties Through The Galleries, Explaining The Nature And Relations Of Their Contents T Tho Catalogue At Present Printed Is Marked Provisional. It Is Easy. To Understand How Incomplete The First List Of Contents Of Such A Collection Must Almost Inevitably Be. The Non-Arrival Of Some Works, The Late Arrival Of Ethers, The Heavy Labour Thrown On Those Charged With The Superintendence Of De. Partments At Tho Last Moment Are Quite Sufficient To Account For The Incompleteness And Disorder Which Make Little Better Than Printers Pie Of Some Portions Of Thle Pre2Ent Catalogue. No Time Abo, I E Lost In Setting This To Rights. In The-Cblffolo- T Ical List Of Old Masters Appended To The Catalogae Of The Ancient Pictures Figures Should Be Introduced Referring The Repder To The Examples Of Those Painters To Be Found Here. To The Works Of Some Of The Modem. Masters Whose Importance In The History Of Native Art Warrants This The Dates Of Production Should Be Appended Inthecatalogue. We May Instance Lawrence, Wilkie, Rnd Turner As Cases In Poin. This Is Particularly Required For The Watercolour Drawinga Of The Last Master, In Which The Exhibition Is So Peculiary Rich. All Visitors Who Are Desirous Of Profiting By The Exhibition Should, Of Course, Begin With The Old Masters, And Study Their Works As Much As Possible In The Chronological Order. The Works Of The Early Italian And German Schools Are Hung In Saloon A, And Should Botalh Be Exarmined Before Passing To The Later Productions Of The Two Countries In The Vestibules, Saloons B And C, And Saloon H, To The Left, Looking Towards The Orchestra, Which Contain The Flemish And Dutch Masters Of The 17Th Century And A Eelection Of The Choicest Ornaments Of The Hertford Gallery. When This Review Of Art To The Plose Of The 18Th Century Is Concluded The Visitor May Pass With Better Chance Of Profit To The Works Of Modem English Painters, From The Predecessors Of Reynolds Down To The Contributors To Last Years Exhibition Of The Royal Academy. The Collection Of Historical Portrai.Ts, The Watercolour Gallery, And The Unrivalled Series Illustrative Of The History Of Engrving In All Its Branches, Will Each Form A Separate Subject Of Study. We May Mention That It Is In The Part Devoted To This Last Department Of The Fahibition That The Provisional Catalogue Has Been Left In Most Hopeleas Confusion. It Is Not Till Thae Pictures Have Been Carefully Examined That The Illustrations Of Design In The Various Branches Of Glass, Porcelain, And Pottery, In The Ivories, The Enamels, The Bronzes, The Furniture, And The Arms And Armour Here Collected Can Be Examined With Something Like Appreciation, For These Will Be Found To Reflect In Theirrespectivedevelopements, In Their Beauties To Be Turned To Account, And In Their Faults And Deformities To Be Avoided, The Mutual Relation, Progress, And Decadence Of The Various Schools Of Painting And Architecture. We Are Writing Principally For Those Who Will Bring Ittle Previous Knowledge To The Consideration Of This Collection. We Must Therefore At Starting Put The Visitor On His Guard Against Contempt And Hasty Irreverence Towards The First Efforts Of Painting As He Will See Them Exemplified In The Works Of The Byzantine And Early Italian Schools Which Line The End Wall Of Saloon A, Beginning On His Right Hand As He Faces Them. He Must Bear In Mind That Modern Art Took Its Rise At A Time When Ancient Art Had Become Helplessly And Hopelessly Degenerate. What It Was In Its Later Forms Is Here Indicated By The Frgments Of Ancient Fresco Contributed By Mr. Dilke, Sir M. W. Ridley, And The Earl Of Pembroke. Ancient Art Had Been Devoted To The Service Of Paganism, And Many Of The Most Influeatial Among The Early Christian Teachers Condemned Art Altogether, And Would, If They Could Have Had Their Will, Have Banished It Entirely From The Service Of Religion. But The Nature Of Man Was Too Strong For Them. The Thought Would Find Expresdon In Form As Well As In Words. Admitting This Overmutering Necessity, The Church, Though It Could Not Stifle Art, Resolved To Fetter It. The Ravages Of Barbarian Horde3, And The Internecine Struggles Of Rude Chieftains, Had Driven The Arts To The More Peaceful Evast, And Byzantium Became The Fountain-Head Of The Theorles As Well As The Practice Of Painting. The Byzantine Church Imposed On The Artists Who Wrought In Itj Service, And Who Were Generally Monks Or Priests Of Its Communion, The Sternest Limitations Of Invention And Representation. To This Day The Greek Church Maintains These Limitations. The Picture In Greek Churches Are Still Executed In Precisely The Same Manner, Still Retain The Same Faces, Forms, Draperies, And Attitudes As They Did Undler Honorius And The Comneni The Chresmologia Or Manual Of Imago Painting Which To This Day Guides The Practice Of The Paintermonks Of Mount Athos-Still The Official Workshop Of Greek Religious Painting-Is The Same As Controlled The Painters Of The 9Th And 10Th Centuries, From The Time That The Partisan Of The Use Of Images In The Church Triumphed Over Leo The Isaurian. It Is True That After The Conquest Of Italy By The Lombards A Native School Of Art, Indepenadent Of The Byzantine, Began Feebly To Develope Itself. But It Was So Rude, So Inferior In Technical Dexterity To Its Eastern Rival, That It Had Succumbed To It Before The 11Th Century, And We Have To Seek In A Few Ivory Carvings And Some Scattered Missals For Evidences Even Of Its Existenee. The Sdent Will Find Such Evidences Among The Ivories In The Mayer And Douce Collections Exhibited In This Building. Thus Fettered By The Unyielding Rules Of Byzantine Iconography, Whieh Extended Not Merely To The Types Of Particular Saints Or Saered Personages, But To The Whole Anangement Of Every Story That Was Permitted To Be Told In Colour, It Was Only By Slow And Painful Steps That Art Emerged Into Something Like Free And Dramatic Representation. All This End Wall Contains Illustrations Of This Struggle From The Stiff And Meagre Forms, The Scanty Draperies, Rigid Attitudes, And Symmetrical Arrangement Of The Byzantine Chresmology, Towards The Comparatively Unfettered Eomposition And Correct Drawing Of The Early Tusean School Of Meacio. It Was Well Done To Hang Among These Early Works Some Modern Rusia Pictures, As Showing The Unyielding Grasp Of Byzantine Art Tradition. All Namnes Attached To Small Works Of This First Century Of Italian Art Must Be Taken With Hesitation. It Is Next To Imposible Here To Refer To Any Picture As An Undoubted Example Of Cimabue Or Giotto, The Two Masters Who Usually Stand At The Head Of The Italian Emancipators Of Art From Its Byzantine Swaddlingclothes. This Is Inevitable. The Larger And Wellidentified Pictures Of The Time Are Either Immoveable Mosaics, Half-Effaced Frescoes, Or Altar Pieces Too Highly Valued To Be Obtainable By Foreign Collectors. The Painting Of Small Detached Pictures At This Period Was Rarely Practized Art Worked Exclusively For The Church. The Smaller Works Of The Time, Exhibited In Galleries, Are Either Portions Of Larger Fixed Altar-Pieces Removed From Churches And Being The Miniatures Which Embelished The Predeaa, Or Base Of The Laiger Pictlure, Or Portable Triptycles Pictures With A Double Folding Shutter, Intendea To Be Carried About By Lords Or Pre. Iates In Warlike Expeditions, Or Religious Pil. Grimages And Peregrinations. But Already In The Pictures Bearing The Name Of Duccio Da Siena 11, And Ijgolino Da Siena 12, Which Are Undoubted Works Of The Siennese School, The Observer May See Indications Of Vitalily And Dramatic Intention. Let Him Note, Espeelally In The Former, The Feeling Of Maternal Tenderness In The Virgin Mother, Aud Of Infantina Affeion In The Chllds Pressure Of His Cheek To Hers Such Expressions Are The Foreshadowing Of That Employment Observable In Succeeding Schools Of The Virgin And Her Divine Son As A Type Of Motherly Love, Even Rmore Than A Symbol Of The Mysterious Relation Of Christ To The Human Family. The Work Whaich Has Been Ascribed To Fargharitone Darezzo A.D. 1236-1313, Representing The Virgin Crowned By The Saviour, Is Unquestionably Of Later Date, And Might Be Referred With More Probability To -Some Scholar Of Giotto. The Treatmen.T And Character Ara- Precisely The Ie Ma Mi.Y Be Seen I The Lar Qqtqation6 Thovi , U It Master, In The Centre Of The Space Between The Two Doord Which Haa Itself Obviously Been Subjected To Severe Procems Of Repainting. The Only Works Here, Which We Can With Confidence Ascribe To Giotto Are The Two Fragents 1.4 And-16, Which Formed Part Of The Frescoes By That Master In The Church Of The Carmtine At Florence, Now Destroyed By Fire. They Were Actually Sawn From The Wall By Patch, The Engraver, Who Published Complete Engravings Of The Series Before The Destruction Of The Churcl There Is Giottosintensity Of Tenderness In The Head Of The Woman Who Holds The Child, And Manifest Traces Of His Grace And Comparative Freedom Of Action In The Figure Representing The Daughter Of Eterodias. Again, The Picture Ascribed To Simon Memmi 20 Is An. Inscribed And Dated Work Of The Master, Apd There Is Nothing In The Work Itelf To Disprove The Inference From The Inscription. So The Small Altarpiece With Wings 23, Bearing The Name Of Taddeo Gaddi And The Date Of 1338, Is Probably A Genuine Work Of This The Most Distinguished Of Giottos.Pupila And The Figuires With Musical Instruments 2X5, Ascribed Here To The Same Master, Are Not Unworthy Of Him. They Have Grace And Naturalness Of Action Enough To Show The Great Stride Which The Art Had Already Made From Its Byzantine. Beginnings. These Pictures, Then, We Repeat, Must Be Regarded Only As Showing The General Eharacteristics Of Italian Art Before Its First Great Advance Into Naturalness Under Masaccio. But The Visitor Must Not Suppose That Anything Here Shown Can Give Him An Adequate Idea Of The Powers Of Giotto, The Master From Whom The Real Commencement Of Tuscan, As Distinct From Byzantine Art, Should Be Dated. Giotto Can Only Be Judged In Florence, In Padua, And In Naples. The Newlyuncovered Frecoesjiu The Church Of Santa Maxis Novella, The Painted Walls Of The Arena Chapel, And The Series Of The Sacraments In The Church Of The Incoronats, Must Be Seen Before We Can Appreciate The Singular Invention, Rare Power Of Telling A Storys And Profound Sentiment Of Beauty, Which Have Crowned Giotto, The Sovereign Of Italian Art, Before Masaccio. None Of His Pupils Carried Painting Beyond The Point At Which He Left It. Andrea Orcagna Had A Power Of Conception, Especially In The Terrible, Which Places Him Apart But In Technical Mastery, And In The General Conception Of Artistic Representation, He Cannot Claim A Distinctive Throne In The Hierarchy Of Painting. But Adequately To Estimate Him We Must Study His Ast Judgment, And His Triumph Of Death, On The Walls Of The Holy Fieid Of Pisa, That Impressive Burial-Place In Which Ancient And Modern Art Have United To Solenize Death And Enforce Its Lessons On The Living. With Masaccio The Visitor To The Manchester Exlhibition May Trace The Advance Of Art To A New Reach Of Power. As Has Always Been The Case, This Is Due To A New Infusion Of Naturalness,-An Effort At More Truthful Representawion Of Things As They Appear. A Hundred Years Separate Masaccio From Giotto, But The One Left Art Still Formal And Half Fettered, The Other Left It Consummate In The Power Of Representing The Human Face And Form. The Single Work By Which Masaccio Is Here Represented-Called His Own Portrait, And Sufficiently Resembling The Acknowledged Type Of His Faoeto Justify The Designatin-Though The Carnations Have Flown, Is As Solid And Simple A Rendering Of A Youthful Head As Raphael Or Titian Could Have Painted-Startling, Indeed, In Its Reality And Strong Expresaion Of Individual Character. Inadequate As It Is To Give The Untravelled Spectator A Conception Of Masccios Range And Grasp Of Power, Which Must Be Seen In That Brancseci Chapel, In The Church Of The Carmine At Mlorence, Which For So Many Years Was The Academy Of The Men We Reverence As First In Art-Of Leonardo, And Michael Angelo, And Raphael-Its Qualities Are Marked Enough To Enable Any One To Apprecate The Gap That Separates The Wchool Of Giottofrom The Tuscan School Of The 15Th Century, Which Begins With Masaccio. The Appearance Of Every Great Master In The History Of Art Is Marked Bysuch Wide And Sudden Intervals. One Such Divides Giotto From His Predecessoe R Masacclo Marks A Second. Raphael, Leonardo, And Michael Angelo Unite To Indicate A Third. And When We Turn To Germna Art We Shall Find The Same Law Exemplified In The Cases Of The Van Eycks, Mabuse, Quentin Matays, And Rubens. We Have Dwelt At Some Length On Thesa The Incunahula Of Painting, Because It Is Here That Just Appreciation Is Most Difficult For The Untrained And The Untravelled. Everyman Has A Difficulty In Conceiving How Art Could Ever Have Been So Barbarous As It Appears In The 14Th Century. It Seems As If Any Attempt At Representation Ought To Have Been More Like Life Than This. We Have Been Anxious To Point Out That Art Did Not Begin With The Attempt At Representing Things As They Are-That It Commenced In A Rigidly Defined Religious Symbolism, And That Every Deviation Into Naturalness From The Narrow Track Marked Out By The Laws Of Byzantine Orthodoxy Was A Rebellion From Which Reverent Spirits Would Naturally Shrink, And By The Consciousness Of Which They Must Often Have Been Haunted And Checked, Even In The Effort To Which Their Perceptions And Consciencoshadimnpelled Them. That Art Was To Be The Handmaid Of Religion Was Of Itself Enough To Deter Artists From Attempts At Natural Representation. The Saviour, The Virgin The Saints, And Mnrtyrs Were Glorified Beings. The Church, Which Was The Witness Of Their Lives And The Depository Of Their Doctrines, Might Be Supposedto Be Authorized To Prescribe How They Should Be Represented To The Faithful Considerations Of Earthly Beauty And Symmetry Had No Place In Such A Matter. That Art Should Be Unlike Nature Ws No Reproach While Art Owned Only. A Supernatural Fnontion And It Is A Testimony Tothesoundecclesiastical Sensewhicb Governed The Byzantine Churchinitsstern Repression Of Private Judgment In Art, That, From The Time Naturalness Of Representation Was Introduced As An Aim In Art, Thepainter, Generationbygeneration, Grew Less And Less An Effective Aid To The Priestthat Art Gradualy Divorced Itself From The Exclusive Service Of The Altar And That Ita Nominal Dedication To Relgion Proved Altogether Insufficient To Keep It, A It Had Been, A Mere Aiceasary To The Church. Nve Hope To Trace The Progrse Of This Change By Help Of This Gallery In Future Articles. Anctester, Mv 9. The Prevalence Of A Raw Easterly Wind Produced A Hlisht Diminution In Tbe Number Of Visitors To The Exhibition On Friday. On The Other Hand, The Sale Of Season Tickets Was As Great As Ever, So That The Receipts Amounted To Much The Same As During The Preious Days-Viz., Nearly 8001. The Confidence In The Financial Sucecess Of The Undertaking Therefore Remains Unabated. During Saturday The Weather Though Enlivenedwith Occaional Gleamsof Sunshine, Was Severe, Even For An English May Yet, On The Whole, The Attendance Was Apparently Rather Better 1Han On Friday. While The East Wind Blows The Interior Of.The Building Is Cold To An Extreme, And, What Is Worse, No Means Can Be Applied To Warm It. The Very Perishable Nature And Enormous Vlue Of Its Contents Upwards Of 6,000,0001. Have Led To The Moat Stringent Precautions Being Taken Against The Possibility Of Accident From Fire No Light Or Fire Of Any Description, Or Under Any Pretence Whatsoever, Is Allowed Within The Walls, And So Rigidly Is This Law Carried Into Effect That Even The Official Letters On The Business Of The Exhibition Are Tealed At A Detached Office Far Removed. Thus When The Weather Is Cold The Building Is Cold In Proportion, And Cold It Must Remain Till Eollus Is More Propitious. As A Matter Of Course, Thisinifaences The Attendance, For The Pictures And Rare Works Of Art Can Only Be Studied By Visitors When Standing Still, And Who Therefore Feel The Low State Of The Thermometer A Most Unpleasant Adjunct To Tbh Entertainment Of The Day. The Sale Of The Provisional Catalogue Has Been So Rapid That A New One, On A Greatly Improved Plan, Will Be Issied In A Few Days. With Re-Gard To This We Would Beg To Suggest That, Among Other Improvements, It Should Contain, As Well As The Tames Of The Old Masters, Their Place Of Birth Andathe School To Which Each Belonged. Two Additional Words Would Effect This, And The Latter At Loat Would Much Facilitate General Visitors In Atudying Practicaly The O.Mparative Merits Of The P Lapte, Roma And Yenex Styles.

Author: Taylor, John Russell
Title: Homage unmasks the myth
Full_text: Galleries John Russell Taylor In Venice On A Show That Celebrates But Also Exposes Marcel Duchamp Homage Unmasks The Mvth Like It Or Not, There Is No Doubt That With Todays Conceptual Avant-Garde The Focus Has Decisively Shifted From The Artist As Maker To The Artist As Star. If Any One Person Was Responsible For This, It Was Marcel Duchamp, Now Being Anatomised In This Years Major Show At Fiats Venice Arts Centre, The Palazzo Grassi. Duchamp Was The Man Who Put A Ready-Made Bottle Stand, A Ready-Made Urinal, Into Art Exhibitions, In 1914 And 1917 Respectively, As Original Sculptures. Possibly, Some Said, As An Attempt To Open Our Eyes To The Plastic Beauty That Lies Around Us In The Least Regarded Everyday Objects Possibly, Others Suggested, As A Satire On And Send-Up Of The Whole Concept Of Fine Art In Any Case, It Was Exactly The Period Of Dada In Switzerland And The Beginnings Of Surrealism In France, So This Kind Of More Or Less Seri - Ous Prank Was Very Much In The Spirit Of The Times. Duchamps Great Strength Was That He Never Really Elu - Cidated His Inten - Tions , But Left That For Others To Do. He Was The 20Th Centu - Ry S First Artistic Guru. His Own Pro - Nouncemen T S Were Either Gnomically Duchampi Was The 2 I Century S First Artistic Guru Obscure Or Childishly Simple, So There Were Ample Opportunities For Disciples To Gather Up And Explicate Every Last Fragment From The Work - Bench . In Other Words, He Had All The Makings Of A Myth. He Clearly Wished To Be A Myth, And Duly Became One To Such An Extent That 405 Unnumbered Pages Of The Telephone Directory-Sized Catalogue Are Taken Up With Ephemerides , Telling What He Was Doing Missing A Train, Having A Telephone Conversation On Each Day Of The Year In Arbitrarily Selected Years Between 1900 And His Death In 1967. Hagiolatry Could Hardly Go Further. Compared With All This Battery Of Incidental Information, One Might Expect The Work Itself To Look Rather Puny. And Sure Enough It Does. It Seems Sad That All That Remain To Bear Witness To 81 Years Of A Life In. Art Are 20-Odd Paintings, A Number Of Objects Like Spades And Bicycle Wheels, Not To Mention Urinals And Bottle Racks, And Thousands Of Little Pieces Of Paper Bearing Faint Scrib - Bles Or Sometimes Not Even That. . Ae Of This Is Reverently Displayed, Though The Objects Are Seldom Even The Originals, Touched At Least By The Hand Of The. Master , But Replicas And Reconstructions Made After His Death, While Much Of The Material Seemingly Rescued , From Du - Cham P S Wastepaper Basket Is Shown As Reproduced Infacsimile In Some Of Thesigned Limited Editions Of His Later Years. Of Course One Can Say. That That Is The Whole Point, That Ideas Of Original Materi - Al , The Hand Of The Artist And So On, Are Shown To Be Deeply Irrelevant To Duchamp In Particular And 20Th Century Art In General. One Can, But Perhaps Not Every - Bod Y Will. The Show Itself Is Exemplary In Lay - Out And Execution. Fears Of Cuteness Set Off By The Bicycle Wheel Hear The Be - Ginning Being Pro - V Ided With A Win - Dow - Dresser S Painted Shadow Are Not Subsequently Realised. And While The Systematically Minded May Be Disturbed By The Deliberate Rejection Of Chronolog I - Cal Order, This Programmed Arbi - Trariness Is Very Much In The Spirit Of Duchamp Himself. At Any Rate, It Introduces A Teasing Element Which Seems To Have Played An Important Part In Duchamps Psychological Make-Up . The Paintings Begin With Some Charming But Conventional Land - Scapes From Around 1902 And End, In Effect, With His Famous Nu Descendant Un Espalier, A Som E - What Futurist-Looking Attempt To Re - Create The Movement As In Stop - Motion Photography, Which Caused A Sensation At The Epoch-Making New York Armory Show In 1912. Remembering That Duchamp Had Two Talented Older Artist-Brothers With Whom He Must Have Com - Pared Himself, One Has To Wonder If He Was Not Like The Would-Be Concert Pianist Who Realises He Is Just Not Good Enough To Reach First Rank And Decides To Settle Instead For Being Liberace. Whether Or Not Such A Feeling Was Responsible For His Change Of Direction, And Especially His Forsak - Ing Of Painting, He Was Clearly Not Lacking In Application Of A Sort. He Was Constantly On The Move, Con - Stantly Attracting Publicity To Him - Self , Constantly Doing Something, Usually Within A Self-Destroying Dada Convention. His Life , As Has Been Said Of So Many Who Followed In His Tracks, Became His Art, And The Trickle Of Tangible Work In The Show Is Mainly The Incidental Record Of That One All - Consuming Artwork. It Is Significant That His Most Public Years And His Major Publicity Stunts Were All In New York, Then As Now The Place Where Charisma, Whether Or Not Backed Up With Talent, Will Get You Furthest . He Was .. In New York Primarily From 1915 To 1923, And Again From 1942 Until His Death, Spending Most Of The Intervening Period In Paris, Where He Tended To Be Seen As Just One Of Many Jokey Characters Of The Avant-Garde . In A Sense He Was Certainly The Great Precursor Of Much That Is Highly Fashionable In Art Today. If There Were Any Doubt Of That, This Exhibition Would Dispel It. What Is Still Far From Dear, However, Is The Value Of Any Specific Thing He Did. It Is Tempting To Say That Seeing So Much Of It So Scrupulously , Res Pect - Fully Displayed Explodes The Reput - Ation , Which Has Always Thrived On Mystery And Myth. On The Other Hand, Duchamp Himself Would Probably Have Loved It, As The Biggest Duchampian Joke Of All.
