Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Up To The Moment When The Academy Opens, The Series Of One Man Exhibitions Seems To Continue Without A Break. There Are Three New Ones In Bond-Street Alone, And Another At The Goupil Gallery, Lately Transferred To The Lower End Of Regent-Street. At The Fine Art Societys Rooms, To Mr. Wetherbees Collection Of Pleasant Pictures Of English Pastoral Life Have Been Added A Large Series Illustrating Marinjon And Rokeby, The Figure Subjects By Sir James Linton And The Landscapes By Dkr. Orrock. To Name These Painters Is To Describe Their Work. Sir James Linton Supplies A Dozen Groups Or Single Figures, Finished Like Enamel, Rich In Colour, And Remarkable In The Quality Of Their Textures. These Characteristics Must Strike Every One But It Is Not Easy To Find In The Drawings Any Particular Reference To Scotts Poetry. This Painters Fault-Or Shall We Say Merit ?-Is That Al His Works Are Studies In Cclour And Texture Alone There Is Notaing Dramatic In Them They Are Artistic, And In No Sense Literary. Mr. Orrocks Landscapes Are All Studied On The Spot, And Most Of Them Painted In The Open Air, And Thus Far They Have An Element Of Truth In Them Which Is Recognizable At A Glance. The Personal Element, However, Is Strong The Artist Has His Decided Preferences In The Matter Of Colours,And Is Apt To See Scotland, Yorkshire, Even Essex And Surrey, With The Same Eyes. But The Dexterity Of His Brushwork And The Beauty Of His Atmospheric Effects Are Not To Ba Questioned. Opposite, At The Japanese Gallery, Are A Group Of Drawings Of Indiza And Ceylon By Mr. John Rarley, A Grandson Of The Eminent Contemporary Of Turner And Girtin, And Friend Of Blake. Mir. Varleys Work Is Fairly Well Known His Eastern Drawings Are Competent, Though Not Hlighly Interesting. A Much More Noteworthy Artist, And One Who Has Never Yet Received Quite The Recognition He Desorves, Is Mr. C. E. Holloway, Whose Recent Work Has Been Brought Together By Arr. Van Wisselingh In His Little Gallery At The Bond-Street End Of Brook-Street. Mr. Tholloways Sketches Of The Sea Are Quite Equal To Anything Of 3Iesdags Perhaps Some Day It Will Be The Fashion To Think Them So. The Small Show At The Gonpil Gallery Would Have Attracted More Attention If It Had Not Followed So Closely Upon The Similar And More Important Display Of T The Late Edward Calverts Work At Burlingtonhouse. But Some People Are So Keenly Interested In That Inspired Amateur, And In ,The Beautiful Dreams Of An Areadian World Which His Brush Transferred To Canvas Or Paper, That They Will Be Glad To See This Fresh Collection Of His Rare Sketches. At Messrs. Vokinss,In Great Portland-Street, There Is A Large Collection Of The Recent Drawings Of An Artist Who Is Much Admired By The Lovers Of The Infiuitely Pretty In Art, Mr. E. Wake Cook. They Are Views Of The Italian Lakes, Of E.W Zealand,And Of Other Regions, And They May Be Described As Echoes Of Turner, Crossed By Birket Foster. Extremely Conscientious, Crowded With Minute Detail, And As Full Of Colour As The Rainbow, These Drawings Are The Very Antithesis Of The Art Now Most In Vogue. Perhaps For That Very Reason They Are Worth Seeing. The Society Of Lady Artists Have Left The Egyptian-Hall And Found A Roomy And Welltlighted Gallery In Maddox-Street. Their Exhibition Is One Of The Best That We Remember To Have Seen Under Their Auspices. There Is, As Of Old, A Good Deal Of Slight And Rather Too Elementary Work, But There Is Also Much That Deserves Other Epitbets. Miss E. M. Osborns Portrait 184, Mliss Oharas Sea-Pieces, The Flowers Of Miss Helen Thornycroft, Mliss M1. S. Grose, And Miss Grace Hastie, And Miss R. Solomons Emmanuel Hospital Would Do Credit To Any Exhibition Of Water-Colours. There Is Less That Is Good Among The Oil Pictures, Where Much Of The Work Is Crude And Unformed But Here Xiss Newcombes Woodland Landscape, Miss Florence Pashs Interior Which She Calls Fairy Tales 15, Mrs. Wrights Minerals-In Emulation Of Miss Kate Wvhitleys Marvellous Productions Of The Same Kind-Aadmiss Donaldemiths Landscapes Are All Of Considerable Excellence. Lnthe Smaller Gallery Some Portraits In Pastel Should Be Remarked-Especially Those Of Miss Donald-Smith And Miss Janet Archer And Mliss C. 31. Beresfords Series Of Water-Colour Sketches, Painted In Many Different Lands, Are The Work Of A Clever Artist.

Author: Null
Title: Slade Students' Part In Young Painters' Exhibition
Full_text: Slade Students Part In Young Painters Exhibition The New Exhibition At The Institute Of Contemporary Arts, 17-18, Dover Street, Consists Of 36 Works By Eight Painters, All Of Them British, All Of Them Born Between 1916 And 1932, And Five Of Them Recent Or Present Students At The Slade School. This Emphasis On The Slade Is Of Particular Interest At A Time When A Remarkable Amount Of Public Attention Is Being Given To A Group Of Young Painters Au Of Whom Are Products Of The Royal Couege Of Art, Our Other Senior Art School. It Is No Accident That The Kensington Neophytes Have Been More In The Public Eye Than Their Bloomsbury Counterparts The College Nowadays Excels In Turning Out Young Artists Who Are Impressively Adept At Making The Most Of Their Gifts And Whose Work Is As Brashly Vivid And Appealing As It Is Precocious, Whereas The Slade Graduates And Undergraduates Of The Present Generation Are Altogether Less Sure Of Thiemselves, More Halting, More Questioning, And Therefore Much Less Prolific. Indeed, One Rather Suspects That For Every Picture Completed By A Slade Student A College Student Completes An Exhibition. This Would Certainly Seem To Be No Exaggetation In The Case Of Mr. Michael Andrews, Who Left The Slade In 1953 With The Rome Prize For Painting. Mr. Andrews Perhaps The Most Imaginative And Serious Young Painter We Have, Characteristically Contributes Just One Picture To The I.C.A. Exhibition-A Composition Of Sunbathers In A Garden Who, As He Puts It In The Catalogue, Were Supposed To Have Plumped Themselves Down Unceremoniously-But Formally With Respect To Their Surroundings. If Mr. Andrews So Rarely Has Any Tangible Record Of His Progress To Offer His Admirers That He Is In Danger Of Being Taken For A Rumour Rather Than A Person, His Low Productivity Has The Compensatory Advantage Of Precluding Repetitiousness And Making Every Picture He Completes A New Experience, For Us And For Himself. As A Consequence, A Visitor To The I.Ca. Who Happens To Be Unaware That The Appearance Of A New Painting By Mr. Andrews Is Something Of An Event Will Still Surely Feet, On Internal Evidence, That This Group Of Sunbathers Is The Outcome Of Profoundly Thoughtful Painting Which Has Had No Traffic Whatsoever With The Well-Tried Formula. The Picture, For All The Care That Has Evidently Gone Into It, Is Very Imperfect, Full Of Gaucheries And Inconsistencies, But The Drawing Of The Figures And Their Disposition In Space Have A Tautness And A Freshnessvand An Insight Which Render It Unusually Moving And Memorable. If, However, We Are Looking For A Happier Balance Between Vision And Accomplishment, We Have To Turn To Another Ex-Slade Student, Mr. Peter Snow, Who, Hardly Known As A Painter, Has Gained A Certain Reputation For His Work In The Theatre, Which Includes The -Not Very Satisfactory-Decor For Waiting For Godot. Mr. Snows Three Conservatory Still Lifes At The I.C.A. Show Him To Be A Painter In The Tradition Of Matisse With A Mastery Of Colour Worthy Of That Tradition. Mr. Snow Reveals An Ability To Reconcile Gaiety Of Mood With Seriousness Of Approach That Seems To Be The Prerogative Of The French And Is Certainly Rare Among English Painters. On The Other Hand, There Is Something Deeply English About The Suggestion Of A Kinship With Mr. Stanley Spencer That Manages To Percolate Through Mr. Snows Matisse-Ish Style. Incidental Y, It Is Interesting To Observe That Mr. Andrews Likewise Has Inherited Something From Spencer. Mr. Eric Finlay, Still A Student At The Slade, Shares Neither These Painters Link Vwith Spencer Nor, Their Seriousness. Mr. Finlay Is Evidently A Fan Of The Great Marcel Duchamp. The Note On Himself That He Contributes To The Catalogue- Wears Dark Glasses And Runs A Bawdy-House In Marrakesh -Is In Imitation Of The Dadaists One Of His Two Paintings Is Clearly Inspired By M. Duchamps Nude Descending A Staircase The Other Is Presented Behind Deliber. Ately Splintered Glass, Presumably In Recognition Of The Fact That M. Duchamps Famous Paintings On Glass Have Been Splintered In The Course Of Time. It Reflects No Credit On The I.Ca. That They Should Give A Showing To Such Meretricious Nonsense, Or, For That Matter, To The Academic Action-Paintings Of Mr. Duncan And Mfr. Kit Barker. The Other Exhibitors Are Miss Janet Barrett, Mr. Barry Daniels, And Mr. W. G. Poode.

Author: From Our Special Correspondent-PARIS
Title: France Shows its Best Sixteenth-century Paintings at Paris Exhibition
Full_text: France Shows Laintings Its Best Sixteenth-Century At Paris Exhibition Portrait Of A Young Woman Attributed To Raphael. From Our Special Correspondent-Paris A Richly Rewarding Exhibition Of Sixteenth-Century European Painting Is At Present To Be Seen At The Petit Palais, Paris. It Consists Of More Than 360 Items -From High Renaissance To Early Baroque-Lent From Public Collections In All Parts Of France. Many Of The Pictures Are Little Known Even To Specialists And Have Left Provincial Museums For The First Time. Beginning With A Madonna Of 1511 By Fra Bartolommeo, From Besancon Cathedral, The First Two Rooms Represent The High Renaissance In Italy. The Exhibits Include Bellinis Drunkenness Of Noah From Besancons Museum, Correggios Virgin And Child From Orleans, And Carianis Delightful Lute Player From Strasbourg. Great Interest Has Been Aroused By The Raphael Portrait Of A Woman In A Gown With Gold Lame Sleeves, Set Against A Background Of Pale Yellowish Green, Known, Probably Erroneously As La Fornarina, After Raphaels Mistress. Previously Owned By Lord Acton, It Was Bought In 1890 By Strasbourg Museum As An Undisputed Raphael. Later, The Artists Hand Was Questioned And The Picture Attributed Instead To Giulio Romano. Todav T.He Experts Are Once Again In Doubt. Seeing It After Cleaning In Readiness For The Present Exhibition, They Feel That Perhaps The Original Attribution Was Correct. Raphaels Afterthought Professor John Pope-Hennessy, Keeper Of The Department Of Architecture And Sculpture At The Victoria And Albert Nluseum, Who Has Made A Visit To France To See The Picture And To Study X-Ray Photographs, Is Satisfied That It Is A Raphael. Tests In The Louvre Laboratory Reveal That Someone At A Later Stage-Possibly Raphael Himself--Filled In The Neckline With A White Muslim Guimpe. It Has Not Been Removed. Recent Cleaning Has Produced Similar Surprises In A Number Of Other Pictures, Though In Most Cases The Additions Have Been Taken Out. Infrangoiscloucts Baindediane For Instance In The Room Devoted To The E?Cole De Fontainebleau, Heavy Drapery No Longer Swathes The Limbs Of The Chief Attendant. The Bain De Diane Which Once Belonged To Cardinal Fesch, Napoleons Uncle, Has In The Past Been Attributed To Primaticcio And N Iccolo Dell Abbate, But Restoration Has Enhanced Its Beauty And Confirmed The Delicate Touch Of Clouet. It Will Return To Rouen Museum Considerably Increased In Value. Speculation Surrounds The Identity Of The Principal Character. Is She Diane De Poitiers With Henri Ll Wearing Striped Satin Approaching On Horseback ? Is She The Temptation Of St. Anthony , By Veronese. Gabrielle Destres With Henri Iv ? The Same Question Is Asked Of Dame A Sa Toilette From Dijon Mluseum, A Fascinating Portrait By An Unknown Artist, Probably Clouet. The Lady At The Dressing Table Wears A Choker Collar Of Gilt Lace, A Cross Or Medallion On A Long Jewelled Chain, And A Transparent Stole. Her Face Is Seen Again In A Pearl-Trimmed Looking-Glass A Wall Mirror Reflects The Figure Of A Kneeling Servant Searching In A Drawer. Under The Moral Stimulus Of The Reformation, A Very Different Mental Outlook Characterizes The Work Of The German Artists. Instead Of The Frank And Sensuous Enjoyment Of The French There Is An Emotional Intensity That Is Almost Visionary. One Sees It In The Work Of Diirer, Altdorfer, Baldung Grien, And Holbein, And In The Set Of Cranach Portraits From Reims. Yet In La Courtisane Et Le Vieillard . For All Its Apparent Condemnation, Cranach Dwells Lovingly Upon The Young Womans Gorgeous Russet Pink Costume With The Padded Slashed Sleeves And The Boa Of Looped Ribbons. Underlying Unity Moving From Room To Room, It Is Interesting To Discover Affinities And Common Tendencies In The Various Countries, Resulting From The Rapid Spread Northwards Of New Artistic Ideas From Italy And To Note The Underlying Unity Of Pictorial Art, Due In No Small Measure To The Enforced Migrations Of Artists In A Europe Torn By Religious Conflict. The Popularity Of The Portrait, The Cult Of The Nude. The Attraction Of Eroticism, The Preoccupation With Heroic Themes Drawn From Greek And Roman Mythology Are Each Exemplified. The Vigour And Realism Of The Flemish Masters. The Daring Gallantry Of The School Of Prague, The Creative Imagination Of Michelangelo And Of The Italian Mannerists In Florence. Parma And Rome, As Shown In The Work Of Bronzino And Correggio, The Flamboyante And Splendour Of The Venetians. Expressed By The Three Giants. Titian. Tintoretto. And Veronese, Are All Represented. Ten Superb Canvases By Vevonese Include A Portrait Of An Unidentified Voung Woman Uith Crimped Bronze-Gold Hair But The Most Imipressive Picture Is The Temptation Of St. Anthony . His First Masterpiece, Painted At The Age Of 24, And A Design For The Dome Of Mantua. Tine Pale Glowing Skin Of The Temptress Contrasts Dramatically With The Deep Reddish-Brown Shadows. The Martyrdom Of St. Stephen From Lille Museum Is Among The Best Of The Titians. It Is A Late Work, A Final Triumph Of The Artist In His Extreme Old Age. Ttians Virgin. Child And St. John The Baptist With Either Saint Agnes Or Saint Catherine Comes From Dijon Musce Des Beaux Arts. It Was Sold To Liouis Xiv By The Banker Jabach. Who No Doubt Obtained It From England When Charles Is Art Collection Was Dispersed During The Commonwealth. Earlier, It May Have Belonged To Thomas Howard, Earl Of Arundel Tarquin And Lucretia , Very Similar To The Titian In The Fitzwilliaam Museum, Cambridge, Has Recently Been Authenticated By Radiographic Examination At The Louvre. It Is Known Ro Have Belonged To Thomas Howard, Charles 1, Jabach, And Louis Xiv Before Being Sent To The Musee De Bordeaux When The French Royal Collections Were Dispersed. This Vast Exhibition In Which Nearly 200 Painters Are Represented, Covering The Artistic Development Of A Stupendous Century, Is Not Easy To Assimilate. It Begins In A Blaze Of Glory And Ends On A Note Of Bitterness And Tragetdy. It Ranges From Durerrs Study For A Madonna - Portrait Of A Woman With Flowing Hair And Downcast Eyes, To El Grecos Mystic Blue-Hooded Virgin, Lent By Strasbourg Museum. It Spans 100 Years Of Changing Intellectual Values. From Bellegambes Gothic Altarpieces To Rubenss Crown Of Thorns Brought From The Obscurity Of The Hospice De Grasse In The South Of France. It Comes To A Close With Two Flagellations Hy Carracci And Caravaggio, Violent, Emotional, Theatrical, In Which European Art Moves Forward Into A New Phase. The Flagellation , By Caravaggio.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Streatham Art Society. No Indulgence Is Needed To Notice The Sixth Exhibition Of The Streatham Art Society, At The Streatham Hall, For It Compares Favourably With The Average Of Minor Exhibitions In Bondstreet. Indeed, If It Has A General Defect It Is That It Shows Very Little Of That Stammering Of The Talented Amateur Which Often Makes A Visit To Exhibitions Off The Beaten Track A Grateful Experience. The Majority Of The Cxhibitors Are, Apparently, More Or Less Professional-Several Of Them Are Familiar In London Exhibitions-And The Prevailing Virtues Are Of The Kind We Call Academic. That The Society Serves A Useful Purpose Cannot Be Doubted. Not Only Does It Bring Pictures Into A Suburb, But It Links Up Any Artistic Interests That May Exist There. A Feature Of The Exhibition, Which Consists Of 172 Works In Oil, Water-Colour, Black-Andwhite, And Sculpture, Is. The Number Of Highly Accomplished Still Life Paintings. Several Of The Most Elaborate In Composition Are Contributed By Mr. E. J. Gead,, Who Devotes Himself To Such Exercises With A Thoroughness Not Often Seen Nowadays, Working Low Down In The Scale Of Colour, As In Wallrlowers And A Full Bag -A Game Subject. Mimosa, By Mrs. 0. Welch, Poppies, By Mr. Harry Dixon, The Stone Bottle, By Mr. Leonard Ashford, Scallops, By Mr. Owen Dexter, And Pottery And Bronze, By Mt. J. Van Abbe, Are Other Excellent Still Life Paintings In Oil Full-Dress Landscape In The Same Medium Is Represented By Light Beyond, By Mr. Arthur W..Tend H. Bromhead, Esq., And F. H. Wagstaff, Esq., Are Two Scholarly Portraits By Mr. S. Van Abbe And .Montreuil, By Miss Alice Beach, A Mountain Tarn, By Miss B. Ghristian, The Gardeners Fboy, By Miss Alice Beach, And Venetian Children, By Miss Vera Down, Are All Oil Paintings Of High Quality-The Work Of Miss Beach Being Particularly Refined In Colour. By An Edrror-Due To The Absenec Af A Catalogue On Press Day-The. Name Of The Artist Responsible For The Water-Colours Of Canada In The Palace Of Arts At The Ntortheast Coast Exhibition, Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, Wev Gienin Thte Times Of Way 14 As Mliss S.A Dknson It Should Have Been Mo Ophia Atkinson. Who Spent Nearly Four Yasi Making Water-Colouirs Of Western Life And Scenery.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Xzhibitions. I Mr. Dunthorne, Of Vigo-Street, Has Just Opened To The Public What Can Hardly Fail To Be Ono Of The Most Interesting Among The Minor Exhibitions Of The Day. Be Has Brought Together A Loan Collection Of The Water-Colour Drawidgs Of The Late Frederick Walker, A.R.A., And Has Secured Many Of The Most Famous Examples, Such As The Harbour Of Refuge, The Lishmongers Shop, The Ferry, The Old Gate, And Two Of Mr. Grahams Exquisite Garden Scenes, Stobhall Gardens And Lilies. Altcgether There Are 46 Drawings And Two Important Sketches In Oil, One Of The Latter Being The Plough, A Finished Study For The Large Picture. The Character Of Walkers Genius Is So Well Known, And So Much Has Been Said And Vwritten About It Both In His Lifetime And After His Premature Death, That There Is No Need To Discuss It At Any Great Length Here. Enough To Say That Those Who Did Not See Mr. Desehamnps Exbibition In 1876 Will Do Well To Repair That Omission Now While Those Who Studied Walker Then Will Be All The More Glad Of A Fresh Opportunit Of Enroying His Admirable Art They Will See It Herefin All Its Phases, From The Very Early Blackberrying, A Drawing Made In 1860 And Showin The Strongest Tiaces Of The Influence Of Mr. Birket Moster, Down To The Last Exhibited Drawing, The Old Gate, And The Still Later Sketch, The Unfinished Work Cn Which Walker Was Engaged Just Before His Death, And Which He Prophetically Called The Unknown Land. The Excellent Essay Of M1Ra. Comyrs Carr, Which Is Reprinted As A Preface To-The Catalogue, Contains All That Is Known Or That Need Be Told Of The Story Of Walker Life, From His Birth In 1840 To His Death In Scotland In 1875. Be Was A London Lad, Who Early Showed A Strong Taste For Drawing. Be Entered An Architects Office And Soon Left It, And Was Then Apprenticed To Mr. J. W. Whymper, The Wood Engraver. In 1859 We Find Him Engaged In Illustiatna Once A Week, And Thus Becoming Associated With Such Leading Artists As Mr. Millais, Mlr. Tenniel, And Others. Then He Wvas Introduced To Thackeray, And At Oneand-Twenty Was Honoured With A Request For Anillustration To One Of The Roundabout Papers, Which Is Of Especial Interest, Being Given In The Catalogue Of This Exhibition Togetber With A Facsimile Of Thackerays Own Pen-And-Ink Hint Which Walker Developed. From This Time Forward He Became A Regular Illustrator Of The Corxhill Magazine, In Which Many Of His Best Subjects Appeared. Mieanwhile, He Began To Exhibit At The Royal Academy, Coming Rapidly To The Front Until In 1867 He Produced What Is Commonly. Thought To Be His Masterpiece, The Bathers, A Picture Which Placed Him At Once In The Foremost Rank Of Living Artists. The Reputation Then Obtained Has- Gone On Steadily Growing, And It Is Difficult To Believe That Walker Will Ever Decline From The High Position Which He Now Holds In The Estimation Both Of Artists And Of The Educated Public-On A Level With Mason As An Artist Of Sentiment And Feeling, And Far Superior To Miason As A Master Of Technique. It Is Not Necessary To Describe Or Criticize In Detail The Works Exhibited In Vigo-Street. Those Of Them That We Bave Named Are Suffieiently Well Known As It Is, And Need Neither Introduction Nor Guarantee. We Would Only Call Attention To The Very Beautiful Drawing Of The Ferry, Lent By Mr. Lehrnanu, And This Because Of The Lovely Etching That Has Just Been Executed Of It By Mr. R. Wv. Macbeth, A.R.A. Nwo Better Tribute To Walkers Genius Has Ever Been Paid Than This Of His Admirer And Brother Artist, Who Has Succeeded In A Truly Remarkable Way In Transferringfl To His Plate The Spirit, The Tone, And The Minutest Details Of The Original Drawing. Of The Rest, Some Of The Most Interesting Examples Are Those That Are Smallest In Scale, Such As The Old Gate, Which We Have Already Mentioned, The Rainv Day, And A Delicious Little Drawing Called The Chaplains Daughter 44, An Illustration Of One Of 3Iss Thackerays Stories. There Is To Be Seen At The Bcrlington Gallery, In Old Bond-Street, A Rather Notable Collection Of Sketches Of Highland Scenery By Mr. A.W.Weedon, A Well-Known Member Of The Institute. On The Whole These Drawings Seem To Us The Best, The Most Accurate, And The Most Spirited Performances That Have Ever,Come From Mir. Weedons Hand. The Large Central Work, A Spate On The Logan, Is A Very Vigorgus And Ratber Remark-Able Transcript Of A Striking Scene. M1R. Weedon Has Evidently Studied The Older Masters, Especially David Cox, To Considerable Advantage. At Another Galery, Mr. Koekkoeks, In Piccadilly, There Is Now Besides Munkacsys Picture Condemned To Death, Already Described By Us, A Large And Noteworthy Historical Work By A Rising Belgian Artist, M. Van Der Ouderaa. The Subject Is Taken From That Inexhaustible Field, The Spanish Rule In The Netherlands. The Picture Represents The Moment Before The Execution Of A Beautiful Girl, Condemned To Death For The Assassination Of A Spaniard Who Had Insulted Her. The Story Is One Of The Best Known In The Annals Of The Netherlands, And The Artist Has Portrayed It With No Little Mastery. Be Paints In The Well-Known Manner Of The Strict Antwerp School, Which Is One Of The Few Schools In Europe That Encourage These Serious Historical Paintings.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition Mrs. Alec-Tweedie Uniusual Interest Is Lent To The Exhibition Of Mrs. Alec-Tweedies Pictures, Which Opens To-.Day. At The Coolinrg Galleries, 92, New Bond Street, By Reason Of The Artists Insatiable Curiosity Which Has Led Her Into Manv Strange Corners Of The World, Where I She Has Painted What She Found With An Enthusiastic Brush. Whether She Is Depicting London Or China, Or Any Place In Bctween, Her Work Bears The Stamp Of An Energetic Mind, Fired To Quick Enthusiasm By Fleeting Impressions. Her Pictures Are The Expression Of Her Personality, And, Whereas A Close Examintation Would Pronounce The Drawing Weak And The Colour In Many Instances Rather Crude, They Are All They Pretend To Be-Vivid Impressions-And As Such They Can Be Enjoyed. F Two Pictures Of Barnet Fair 78 And 79 Illustrate This Very Well. Thieves Den In Paris 124 Is Made More Interesting By The Paragraph In The Catalogue. A Number Of Flower-Paintings Are Pleasant But Not Outstanding Green Chrysanthemums On Silver Chinese Temple Papcr 31 Being By Far The Best In Composition And The Delightful Tones Of The High Key In Which It Is Painted. At The Samc Gallery There Is An Exhibition Of Paintings By Miss Eileen Robey. This Artist Has Found Some Very Charming Sitters For Heportraits, But The Painting Which Shows Most Vitality Is The Green Singihg Cherub 17 Miss Robey Has Not Felt So Restrained While Painting His Portrait As In Some Of The Others And The Result Is Charming.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Pictitres Of Irish Life. In The Pictures Of Irish Life, By Mr. Jack B. Yeats, At The Galleries Of Messrs. Arthur Tooth And Sons, 155, New Bondstreet, The Imaginative, Poetical, And General Artistic Qualities Are So Much Ahead Of Technical Accomplishment That It Is Difficult To Place Them Fairly. Not That Mr. Yeats Falters In Execution For Better Or Worse, He Carries The Thing Through With A Remarkable Effect Of Unity But That Lie Hardly Begins To Organize His Brushwork. He Paints As The Bird Sings. His Strong Points As An Artist Are His Feeling For Form As An Emotional Weapon, And His Instinct For Tone And Colour. Althouh The Subjects Of The Pictures Belong To Maturity, The Point Of View Expressed In Them Is Pretty Much That Of Stevensons Childs Garden Of Verses. They Are Romantic About Quite Ordinary Things- Mail Coach Eoad, The Hackney Car, Coming Up Sligo River, Early Morning, And Dublin News Boys. Mr. Yeats, In Short, Has The Gift Of Wonder-Nowhere Better Expressed Than In Graftonstreet, Dublin, A Delicate Scheme Of Rose And Grey, In Vhich The Source Of Wonder Is A Dummy In A Shoev Window. The Haute Ecole Act, Again, Besides Being A Remarkably Good Composition, Has All The Romance Of The Subject In A Boys Imagination, And All That Is Meant By The Spanish Main Is Sumnred Up In The Figure Of A Man Leaning Against A Shed In A Uestern Quay. The Mystery Of Donkeyhood Is The Real Subject Of By The Canal, Dublin, The Trotter Was Dreamt The Night Before The Race, And The Delicate Young Woman At The Bar Recalls Henleys Dove Among The Pots. Undouxbtedly, M1R. Yeats Is The Playboy I Of Painting. Photography. Those Who Like A Reasonable Amount Of Freedom In The Pictorial Application Of Photography Will Find Much To Please Them At The Bouse Of The Royal Photographic Society, 35, Russell-Square, Where There Are Two Exhibitions -Prints, Alt Of Landscape, By Mr. Charles Job And Prints By Members Of Societies Affliated To The Royal Photographic Societv. Mir. Job, Whose Prints Are Arranged Chronologically From 1894 And According To Processplatinum, Carbon, And Direct Oil-Shows Great Skill And Taste N Avoiding The Protests Of The Camera And Chemicals Against Control, And Low Wvater, Bosham, .. Buirning Leaves, Kensington Gardens, And In The Gardens Of The Villa Deste, Italy May Be Named As Three Of His Best Compositions. In The Mixed Collection Upstairs The Most Pleasing Pictures Come From Mr. H. Felton, 3R. M. 0. Dell, Mr. George Brown, Mr. R. Chalmers, Mir. S. Walton, Mr. L. V. Jessop, And Miss Edith L. Willis, Whose Cat Is A Great Success. At The Camera Club, 17, John-Street, Adelphi, There Are Portraits Of Legal Celebrities By 31R. Walter Thomas. They Are Straightfo.- W Ard Enlargements, Gaining Something From The Decorative Accessories Of Wigs And Robes, And The Culmulative Effect Of Wisdom Is Verv Impressive. Lwithout Presenting A Common Type, The Heads Do Seem To Possess Certain Common Characteristics, A Combination Of Firmness In The Eyes With Subtlety In The Modelling Round The Mouth-Justice Tempered With Mercyv Perhaps. The Right Lion. Lord Darling, . The Lon. 31R. Justice Avory, And Tliet Hon. Mr. Justice Clavell Salter Are Typical.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: I Art Exhibitions. The New Fngt.Tqt-L The Outstanding Picture At The Newi English Art Clubs Exhibition At 5A, Pall- I Mall-East, Is Mr. Tonkss Posthumous Portrait Of Mr. And Mrs. John Scott Oliver 78, Partly Because It Is The First Thing To Catch The Eye As You Enter The Gallery, Partly Because It Is So Comfortably Victorian In Subject, With The Whiskered Gentleman, The Full-Gowned, Gracious Lady, The Clock In A Glass-Ease On The Mantelpiece, And So Forth , But Chiefly Because Here Is So Much More Than Mere Cleverness And Accomplishment. The Picture Is Really Good One Comes Back To It Again And Again For Refreshment. And On Meeting, Much Later In The Longish Tour, A Little Pastel Of A Sleeping Child 149, By The Same Hand, One Realizes Anew That It Is The Hand Of A True Artist. There Is Something Quietly Big In These Things-The Bigness Being In The End, Perhaps, Only The Result Of A Kind Of Smiling Reverencewhich Sets Them Apart From A Great Deal In This Very Clever And Often Brilliant Exhibition. Miss Ethel Walker Has Some Of This Quality, Too, And Shows It In Her Portraits 58, 70, And, To Some Extent, In Her Sea-Piece 99. We Find .Some Of It Also In Mr. R. J. Burns, Appealing Por- I Trait Of A Girl, 72, And In Lr. Mcninskys Several Chalk-Drawings Of Mothers And Babies 139, 143, 154, And In Mirs. Robin Guthrics Study Of A Boy 113. In Many Other Cases We Feel No More Than That Thei Artist Found It Great Fun, And Was Rather Pleased With Himself For Pulling It Off. Such Things Are Great Fun To Look, At For A Little But It Is A Momentary Sensation. L For All That, -There Is, Indeed, Much Cleverness And Some Brilliance In The Exhibition, Within The Wide Limits Which The New English Allows -Its Exhibitors. One Of The First Tlings To Attract Is Mr. R. Ihlees Triumphant Little Nocturne, Biskra 9 And Then Mir. Edward Wadsworths Masterly Picture Of Boats At La Rochelle 12, One Of The Best Wadsvorths That Wve Have Seen. Miss Margaret Gere Got Quite A Lot Of Fun Out Of Painting Her Portrait Of Elsie I7, With Her Red Frock And Her Red Hair And Her Firm Flesh. Past Mr. F. H. S. Shepherds Un-L Usual And Rather Attractive Lady Into Tree 20, We Come To Mr. John Nashs Edge Of The Wood-Autumn 22, Which Is Very Good John Nash Indeed Gay And Strong And Suave. Mr. Walter Bayess Mediterranean 24 Is, For Him, A Little Loose Perhaps It Is Too Big But Mr. A. Tlhorntons Ollioules 27 Has Its Grandeur, Though It Is But A Small Picture. A Lively Little Nude By Margaret Fisher Prout 35 A Picture Of The Thames, Chelsea 43 By Mr. Fairlie Harmar, Which Proclaims Itself At A Glance And Gets Better The More One Looks At It Three Landscapes By Sir C. J. Holmes, Of Which Much The Best -Is The Magnificent Pendragon Castle 60 A Lovely Landscape, Les Amandiers, Le Lavandou 62 By Mr. Lucien Pissarro A Portrait Of Ikrassin By Mr. A. Neville Lewis 73, Very Direct And Masterful Pictures By Mr. Collins Baker, Miss Sine Mackinnon, Mr. Charles M. Gcre, Mr. Charles E. Cundall, Mr. Algernon Newton -In Going Round One Sees Many Things That Are Great Fun, And A Few That Are More Than That. And On And Behind The Screen Are Drawings And Water-Colours And Etchings Among Them A Street In Stbekholm 165 And A Big Water-Colour Of The French Presidents Arriva At Marseilles In 1921 186 By Mr. Muirhead Bone A Delicious Little Water-Colour By Mr. D. S. Maccoll 141 Three By Mr. Wilson Steer, Of Wvhich The Horse Pond 171 Is A Marvel Of Significant Touch And Drawings By Mr. Martin Hardie, Mr.- Ethelbert White, Mrs. Cheston, Mr. Henry Rushbury, Mr. Ambrose Meevoy,-And Many Others Show Various Aims And Various Levels Of Achievement.

Author: Null
Title: The International Exhibition
Full_text: T1E International Exhibition. The First Of A Series Of International Exhibition Of The Fine Arts And Of Industry Was Opened At Soulth Kensington Yesterday By The Prince Of Wales, On Beh0If Of The Queen, And Was Made The Occasion Of An Imposing State Pageant. To Most People Great Exhibitions Have Become Somewhat Trite And Even Tiresome. That Of 1851 Was New, Instructive, And Delightful. The Palace Of Crystal Which Sprang Up In Thos Days Seemed Almost Too Subtle And Delicate A Creation To Be Coupled By Builders, Contractors, Androughhandicrafts. It Wassuggestive Rather Of Firydon And The Genii, Of The Lamp, And Helped Powerfully To Arouse And Sustain Our Wonder And Admiration. When This Glittering Casket And The Treasures It Contained Passed Array One Or More Crystal Palaces Were Establiished Among Us M Permanence And Nine Years Ago There Arose Another Great Exhibition, Displaying Two Vast Domes Of Glass Each Larger Than The Dome Of St. Peters. That, Too, Was Successful But The Parent Exhibition Was Copied Without Being Improved I Upon Both At Home And Abroad, Until The Plan Which 20 Years Ago Was So Novel And Agreeable Seemed Work-Ed-Out And Wearisome. Other Causes Contributed To The Growing Unpopularity Of Great Exhibitions Fashioned After The First Model. Manufacturers And Inventors Found It Exceedingly Expensive To Exhibit, While, After In- Eurring The Expense, They Might Chance To Be Robbed I Of The Merit Due To Them By Some Accident Or Prejudice. Havingregard To These Conditions, The! Royal Commissioners Of 1851 By Whom The Present Exhibition Is Promoted, Wisely Determined To Alter Materially The Conditions On Which It, And Its Successors Should Be Based. To Begin, This Is Not A Great Exhibition In The Con- Ventional Sense. It Is Not A Noahs Ark Into Which All Industries, Products,And Inventions Are Admitted, Classified, And Hurriedly Placed Accordina To Their Supposed Merit. The Manufactures Now Shown Are Contined To Woollens, Worsteds, And Pottery. Next Year Two Or Tlhree Other Industries Will Have Their Turn. Every Year, However, The Fine Arts,Giving That Phrase A Liberal Interpretation, Will Be Represented So Will Works Of Scientific Invention And Horticultare. At A Time, Too, When A New Education Act Is Beingadministered, A Collection Of Educational Applianes Is Very Apt And Useful And These Will Be Found In The Buildings Yesterday Opened. Latstly, With A Viewv To Ease Both The Minds And Pcckets Of Exhibitors, The Royal Commissioncrs Have Discarded The System Of Medals, Certificates, And Prizes They Ap- Point In Each Department A Committee Of Taste,Who, I As At The Royal Academy, Decidce Whether, Having Re- I Gard To The Space At Their Command, The Objects Sent Are Wortly Of Admission And Every Object Admitted Then Stands On Its Own Merits, No Personal, Trade, Or! International Jealousy Beina Created By Awards Which May Be Just, But Which, Through Accident Or Bias, Have Often Hitherto Been Unsatisfactory. It Is Necessary To Explain At Starting How The New Exhibition Departs From Tradition, Not Aiming, Like Its Predecessors, To Contain A Little-Or, Rather, A Good Deal-Of Everything, And Being Therefore Much Less Bewildering. The Building Itself, Too, Is Utterly Unlike Those Of 1851 And 1862. Indeed, Visitors Who Came To South Kensington Yesterday Had To Ask, When Close By The Eixhibition, Where Is It ? There Is No Transept, Glowing In The Sun There Is No Nave, And There Arc No Domes, Large Or Small. Take The Gardens Of Theroyalhorticu,Ural Society For A Quadrangle,And They Make A Magnificent One Imagine Galleries Of One And Two Stories As Quadrants, Connected With The Albert Hall And Utilizing The Arcades Of The Horticultural Society With A Portion Of The Old Galleries Of The Exhibition Of 1862 Upon The South, And You Have A Rough Idea Of The International Exhibition Of 1871. The Galleries On The Garden Side Are Of Red Brick Faced With Terra Cotta They Are Meant To Be Permanent And Fulfil Admirably The Purpose For Which They Were Designed By Lieutenant-Colonel Scott But They Form No Architectu. Ral Landmlark In South Kensington, Which Has, Indeed, Plenty Of Such Distinctions Already. In Default Of The Necessary Spaca In The New Line Of Buildinos, The Chief Part Of Yesterdays Ceremonyi Was Appointed To Be Held In The Conservatory Of The Royal Horticutltural Society, A Very Graceful And Pretty Interior, But Too Smallfor A Pageant In Whichi So Many Took Part And Which So Manymora Vainly Wished To See. A Dais Covered With Scarlet Cloth Was Placed At The Southern Side Of The Conservatory For The Royal Party And Their Attendants. In Front Of This Dais Were Placed The Diplomatic Corps And Distinguished Visitors And On Either Side, Separated By A Slight Barrier, Seats Were Reserved For Those Who Had Acquired The Muchcoveted Right To Enter. Opposite The Dais Was The Southern End Of The Royal Albert Hau, Entered By A Graceful Gallery Connected With. The Conservatory By Two Flights Of Steps. Probably This Gaulery And The Conservatory Proper Will Together Hold 3,000 People, And Both Were Filled. By 11 Oclock Little Room Was Left For Later Comers, Except Those Who Had A Part To Play In The Pageant. There Were Those Who Predicted That,X This Being May-Day, The Weather Wotuld Be Wet, Cold, And All That Poets Ignore. The Rain, It Raineth Every Day Was, In Fact, True As To The Last Week Or Two Of April But There Was A Fortunate Change, And Yesterday, Save One Passing Shower, And A Suspicion Of Chiliness, Was As Bright And Genial A Day As Could Be Desired. The Conservatory, With Its Branching Pahns And Tropical Plants Would Have Been Dull Indeed Without Abundant Smnliaht. The Sun, However, Assisted At The Cere- Mony With Genial Warmth And Rays Which It Seemed Ungratefull To Vward Off By Awnings. Occasional Gleams Could Not Be Denied Entrance, And Then These, Gaining Strength In Their Passage Throug,H The Glazed Roof, Lit Upon A Scarlet Uniform Or Civic Robe The Wearer Seemed Ablaze. All The Visitors Passed Through The Albert Hall And Entered The Conservatory By One Or Other Of The Flights Of Steps Already Mentioned. The Diplomatists Mustered Early Their Uniforms Glittering Lace, Orders, And Crosses. The Turkish Fez Was There With Officers In White In Light Blue, And In Dark Blue Coats, Contrasting With The English Staff Officers In Scarlet And White Plumes, Through Whom They Passed Ton Their Way Towards The Dais. One Diplomatist, Distrustful Of The English Climate, Especially On May-Day, Wore A Loose Overcoat Of Dark Blue Velvet Trimmed With Costly Fur, And Loo.Ed Like Avenetian Doge Or Senator. Thenthere Wqs A Childofthe Sun,Elsao Diplomatist In Becoming Uniform And Presently Entered The Nawab Nazim Aud His Two Sons,In Lustrous Dresses Of Gold Stuff, And Turbans Glistening With Precious Stones. Lord Hough. Ton, As A Deputy-Lieutenant, Moved Here And, There. The Lord Mayor, Attended By Mace And Sword Bearers, Was Conspicuous In The Throng Scarlet Robes Of Aldermen, The Purple, Robes Or Robes Of Mazarin Blue Worn By Councillors And Deputies From The City Were Plentiful And Provincial Mayors, Wearing Their Robes And Gold Chains Of Office, Added To A Scene As Highly Coloured, Perhaps, As Has Been Often Witnessed Of Late In Our Undemonstrative Days. In This Gathering, As Time Passed, Were Mingled The More Sober Court Uniforms Of Dark Blue And Gold Lace, With Here And There The Still More Sober Uniform Of Our Volunteers. Lord Elcho Wore The Gray, More Useful Perhaps, Though Less Brilliant, Than The Scarlet Thie Bishop Of Winchester, Happily Recovered From His Sudden Illness, Was Present, But Not Robed. Soon After 12 Oclock The Royal Party Arrived At The! Northern Entrance To The Albert Hall, Where They Were Met By The Rcoyal Commissioners For Tne Exhibition Of 1851, And Were Escorted To The Conservatory. Thte Princess Christian, Wrho Wras Expected, Was Kept Aw Ay By Illness. The Prince Of Wales, Who Wore The Scarlet Uniform Of A General Ofiicer, Conducted The Countess Of Flanders, The Count Of Flanders Led The Princess Mary. Princeajohn Of Gllcksbu Rg Followed, With The Duke Of Camibridre. Princedward Of Saxe-W Eimar, Prince Teak, Tho Lords And Ladies In Waiting, And Tho Great Officers Of State-A Brilliant Thronor. The Home Secretary, Mr. Bruce, Mr. Goschen, Fr. Ayrton, And Mir. Forstewere The Ministers Present. Neither The Premier Nor Mr. Lowewasthere. Mr. Disraeli Appeared Amongthe Royalcommissioners. Whenthe Royalprocessioni Entered, A Military Band Stationed At The Foot Of The Staircase, Played The National Anthem, Which Was Followed By Metrical Version Of The 148Th Psal2 , Sung, And Played To The Austrian National Air. But The B And Overpowered The Chorus, Who Were Under The Disadvantage Of Being Stationed Much Further Off The Dais, And From That Distant Position Struggled Vainly Tobe Heard. Meanwhile The Prince Of Wales And The Rest Of The Royal Party Had Taken Their Position Upon The Dais, Standinm In Line, With The -Personages Of The Court And The Great Officers Of State Behind Them. The Prince Of Wales Had On His Right The Countess Of Flanders, Prince 3Oh-A Of Gliiek-Sberg, The Duke Of Camnbridge, And Prince Christian And Oni His.Left The Princess Mary, Tho Coiunt Of Flpanders, And The Prince Of Teak. Some Hunadreds Of Official Personages Wore Then Presented To The Prince Of Wales,. Approaching The Dais In Order, And Defiling In Front Of The Royal Party, The Prince Acknowledging The Saluitation Of Each Idy A Gracious Bow. Th Duke Of Camibridge Presented The Inspector-General Of Fortifications, The Deputy Adjutant-General Of The Royal Engineers, Andl The Military Officers Assisting In The Exhibition Prince Christian, As A Royal Commissionler, The Officers Of The Exhibition Staff, Andl Members Of Committees Engraged In The Fine Arts Division The Prince Of Teak, Also A Royal Commissioner, The Officers Of The Exhibition Staff And Members Of Commiittees Engaged In The Industrial Division Lord Granville, Tlle Foreign Comamissioners. Lord Henry Lennox Presented The Council Of The Society Of Arts Who Wore Mixsing For A Few Momenta When Called For The Bishop Of Winchester Performed The Same Office For The Council Of The Royal Horticultural Society, And Lord Houghton For The Official Reporters Of The Exhibition. Lf. Braice Next Preented Several High She-Riffs Of Counties, The Lord Mayor Of London, And The Provincial Mlayors Invited To Attendl The Ceremony Sir J3. Pakcington, The Musical Committee For The Exhibition Mfr. Chichester Forteacue, Several Chairmen Of Chambers Of Commerce, The Lord Mayor Closing This Long And Somewhat Tedious Part Of The Proceedings By Presenting Members Of Some Of The City Companies. Then Colonel Scott, The Secretar Of The Royal Commissioners, Banded Their Report T The Home Secretary, Who Presented It To The Prince, Who Received It On The Part Of Her Majesty. The Report, Whichi Was Taken As Read, Was As Follows To Trse Right Hox. Henrcy Austis Enrtce, Ml.P. Oncx Of Hert Majexstys Pncrczsal Secreaxris Of State. Sir,-I. Her Majestys Cemmissioners For The Exhibitionk Of 1851, Incorpotated By Royal Charter To Dispose Of The Surplus Arising From That Exhibition In The Promotion Of Objects Tending To Increase The Means Of Industrial Education Aind To Extend The Influience Of Science And Art Upon Prodctie Idusry,Hav Toreprt Hatin The Discharge Of The Rus Comited T Thm Tey Averesolved, Toestablih Aseres F Anul Iteratinalexhbiions Of The Fin Ars Nd F Idutry Th Frstof Hih Is Open This 2.Durngthe20Years Which Have Elapsed Since The Great Exhbto F15 Various Exhibitions Have Taken Place In Thi And Other Countries, And Her Majestys Coinniissieners Have Not Failed To Take Advantage Of The Informsation Which The Different Organizations Of Suich Exhibitions Have Afforded In Determaining The Principles On Which The Present Series Should Be Based, In Order As Far As Possible To Increase Their Practical Utility. 3. Her Majestys Commissioners Observed That The Tendencv Of Such Exhibitions Has Been To Enceurage Undue In Crease In Their Size, To Admit Objects In No Way Distinguishable For Any Peculiar Merit Beyond Those To Be Obtained In The Ordinary Way Of Trade, And To Throwv Upon Exhibitors Who Wore Influenced By Considerations Apart From The Actual Sale Which Might Be Made In The Exhibition Itself A Heavier Tax Than They Were Inclined To Bear. T4. It Had Also Forced Itself Upon The Attention Of Her Majestys Commissioners That The Systesa Of Pronouncing Definite Opinions On The Merits Of This Or That Production By Means Of Juries Led To Inconveniences. The Estimation Of The Merits Of The Goods Of Each Country Was Often Determined Very Much,In. The Proportion Of The Number Of The Jurors It Was Allowed To Name. It Was Impossible To Find Jurors With Sufficient Technical Kssowledgo Of All The Subdivisions Nteessarily Grouped Under One Heading To Pronounce Comprehensie And Correct Judmsats On The Comparative Excellencee Ovf The Objects Exhibited And Amid The Enormous Rmas Of Objects Which Such Immense Exhibitions Brought Togeother Maany Oversights Occurred Which. Did Injustice To Intdividuals. 5. In Settling The Principles For Placin- The Objects Inl The Exhibition Of 1851, It Was The Strong Wists Of The Prince Consort That The Arrangement Should Be By Classes And Not By Nationalities-A Wish Which It Was Impossible To Realize In Such A, Novel Anad Vast Undertaking-But Her Majestys Commissioners Feel Satisfaction In Having In The Present Year, In Great Measure, Carried Out The Wishes Of The Great Founder Of Interunational Exhibitions And In Futura Years They Intend To Carry The Principle Into Effect Without Exceptions. By This Means Greater Scora Will Be Given To The Publio For The Actual Comnparison Of The Works Of Different Countries, And The Educational And Practical Value Of Such Displays Will Be Much Increased. .6. Guiided By These Ideas,Ror Majestys Commissioners Arrived At The Following Conclusions, And Have Endeavourea To Oive Effect To Thiem In The Present Exhibition. A. To Comnflo The Exhibition Of Each Year To Two Or Three Industries Only, But To Admit Every Year Works Of Fine Art, Scientific Inventien, Aud Horticulture. I. To Admit Such Objects Only As Might Be Seleoted As Worthy Of Exhibition By A Competent Committee Of Selection. C. To Group These Objects By Classes And Not By Nation- Alities. In The Ease Of Fine Arts,Certaine Alight Modifications Of The Role Have, For Thlis Year Only, As Alreadly Intimated, Been Admitted. D. To Save To Exhibitors, So Far As Possible, The Cost And Trouzble Of Exhibiting, By Providing For Them Glass Cases, Stands, Steam Power, And Other Appliances For The Proper Exhibition Of Their Objects, And Also By Enploying Ageants Who Will Answer Inquiries Respecting The Objets And Generally Watch Oyer The Interests Of The Exhibitors. 7. With The View Of Increasin The Educational Value Of The Exhibition, Her Kajestys5Commisioners Have Also Made Arrangements For Issuing, Withint A Few Weekcs Of The Opening Of The Exhibition, Reports On The Various Classes Of Objects. In. These Reperts An Attempt Will Be Made To Inculcate Such Principles As Will Enable The Pablio To Arrive At A Stadrar Of Judgment, And Form Its Own Opinionsi Upon Them. S8. In Discardling The Jury System Her Majestys Commiissionkers Also Abandon That Of Giving Prizes, Which Had. Ro.Ved A Source Of Dissaltisfaction And Sometimes Of Sabse. H Admission To The Exhibition Itself, In The Opinion Of Hler Majestys Commissioners, Should He Viewed As Conferring A Distinction Worthy Of Competition. 19. Her Majestys Commissioners Desire To Acknowledge The Patience And Conscientiousness With Whichi The Ladies Alnd Gentlemen Eminent In The Spheres Of Art, Science, And Ndustry,Who Were Invitedto Act As Committees Of Selection, Save Carried Oat Their Arduoius And Reisponsible Duties. C10. In The Design Of The Royal Albert Hall, Erected To The Memory Of The Prince Consort, Considerable Provision Had Been Made For The Exhibition Of Objects In And Around The Miain Chamber Of The Structure. Her Majestys Comnssiasiooers Have Therefore Taken Advantage Of The Space Thus Afforded For This Years Exhibition, While For The Main Portions Of The Exhibsitions They Have Erected On Each Side Of 11. Theyvhavedevoted A Further Sum Of 25,0001. In Providianf Fittisgs, Furniture, And Cases For The Exhibition Kaleierse, For Certain Necessary Work In The Adjacent Buildings To Enable Them To Be Used Las A Part Of The Exhibition Space, And To Maeet The Preliminary Expenses Attending The Undertaking. The Total Cost, Therefore, Of Openingthie, The First Of The Series Of Exhibitions, Including The Permanent Gtructuires Which Wil Be Available For The Whole Series, Will Be 100,0001. Fc 22 The Representationx Of All Branchies Of The Fine Arts, Ofscientific Inventions, Andof Horticulture Takes P Lace This Year, As It Will Do In Sabsequent Years, And Hfer Mlajestys Commissioners Have Soeleted Woollen And Worsted, Pottery, And Educational Appliances As The Manufactures And Industries For The Exhibition Optned This Day. 13. Her Majestys Commissioners Have Also Decided That During The Exhibition Representations Of Music, As A Branch Of The Fine Arts Shall Take Place In The Royal Albert Hall, With A View To Tee Improvemient Of The Taste For Muisic, Which Has Aot Hitherto Met With That Attention In England As An Elevating And Educational Instrument Whiceh Has Been Bestowed Upon It In Other Civilized Countries. The Fouir Nationalities Of England, Franco, Germany, And Italy Will Be Spccially Represented By Musical Compositions On This Day. 114. To This Report Her Majesty Commissioners Append The Catalogue Of The Exhibitioa Of The Preseat Year, Euume. Ratiug Upwardsa Of 8 000 Objects Or Groups Of Objlects, And They Humbly Trust Tht Their Work This Year Will Receive Hfer Majestys Graoious Favoutr And Approval. De15. It Was Long Since Announcled To The World That This Exhibition Would Open On The Lat Of Way, For It Appearead To Her Majestys Commissioners That The Present Series Of Exhibitions Could Not He Opened More Appropriately Than On The Anniversary Of Tlhe Day On Which The First Great Inter. W Saslhonoen Wto The Sadmihrmatioeoftheswomrld,Siandteys Torus Thabyte Xbblesion Of Godib Thei Workeon Which Itheayo Maesys Sujct,Hu Il Sss In Romotinry The Friend-T Secretarv. The Prince Then, Advaucing To The Edge Of The Dais, Saidj In A Clear Foice, Distinctly Heard Even In The Gallery, On Behalf Of Her Miajesty The Queen I Proclaim The International Exhibition Now Open. His Royal Elighness, Passing At Once To The Balcony Overlooking The Horticultural Gardens, Made Proelamation To The Same Effect To The Crowd There Assembled, In Both Cases It Was Received With Cheer8, The State Trumpeters Blowing A Stirring Blast, While By Preconcerted Si-Anal The Artillery In The Park Fired A Salute. 1 Those Persons Who Had Been Presented To The Prince Had, Meanwhile, Retiring To The Galleries, Formed There In Procession. This Was The Order Of Their Going, And Wh1En. The Royal Permnit Had Been Given To Open The Building Thley Went At Once Heralds And State Trumpeters, The Contractor For The Bmldiun Mr. Lucas, The Fine Arts Staff And Committoo For The . Xhibition, The Industrial Staff And Committees Of The Exhibitions, The Military Staff Of The Exhibition, The Foreign Acting Cemmissioners, The Council Of The Royal Horticultural Society, The Counci Of The Society Of Arts, Oficial Reportcrs, The Chairen Of The Chambers Of Commerce, The Layors Of The United Kingdom, The City Companies,Tho Lord Mayor And Corporation Of Londou, The Hish Shetoffs, The General Lurposes Committe Forthe Ex- Hibition,Er Fajesto Oommissionersfortheehibitionn9 Royal Hichxess The Prince Of Wvales And Her Royal Nigh. Ness The Countess Of Flanders, The Royal Personage Presents The Lxdies And Genjtlemen In Waiting, And Offlicers Of State. The Routo Taken Lay First Through The East Gallery, Devoted To Fine Art, And Approached From The Conservatory By A Glazed Arcade. Beneath Is The Porcelain, And It Is Said, Probably With Truth, That Re Finer Show Of Modern Work In This Branch Of Artmanufacture Has Never Yet Been Brought Together In Any Country. But Yesterday The Porcelain Was Neglcoted, The Procession Passing Through The Gauery On The Upper Story. This Gallery, 600Ft. Long, Is Broken Up Mto Rooms, And Though The Separation Ia A Nominal One It Is Enough To Avoid Uniformity And Justify A Distinctive Name To Each Division. The Royal Pavty Could Not But Be Struck By The Extreme Merit Of The Pictures From Belgium, Which Stands Foremost Among The Foreign Contributories,And His Royal Highncs The Countof Flanders, Who Is A Commissioner For Belgium, Might Well Be Complimented On The Rich Display Of Art Sent Here Under His Auspices. In One Of These Rooms The Long Line Of Canvas Is Agreeably Broken By Reproductions Of Shields, Tazzas, And Plaster Casts Of Architectural Remains, Conspicuous Among- Which Is A Reproduction Of The Eastern Gateway Of The Great Buddhist Tope, At Sanchi, In Central India, In The Territory Of The Begum Of Bhopal. This Remarkable Cast, Taken With Immense Labour By Lieutenant Cole And His Assistants, Is Supposed To Date From The Commencement Of The Christian T Era And Its Primitive Carvings Of Elephants And Other Designs, Its Ungainly Form,- It Attracted Universal Attention. The French Court Has Naturally Been Lilled Under Difficulties, But It Represents Not Unworthily The Artistic Power Of France. Some Well-Remembered Paintings Were Pointed Out To The Royal Party As They Passed,Such As The Mlarie Antoinette Of Paul De La Roche And The Familiar Portrait Of Madame Rosa Bonheur. There Was One Dicture, By M. Regnault, Which Commanded Rather Than Attracted Observation Itis Called An Execution In The House Of A Moor. The Eye Turned With Relief To Auother Work By The Same Artist On The Opposite Wall-An Equestrian Portrait Of The Late General Prim, Among The Mob Of Madrid Lie Knew So Well How To Control. So The Cort4G Passed On, Often Inclined To Linger,But Forced To Move Forward In Order To Keep A Continuous Line. Here, As Throughout The Whole Of The Art Collection, Pieces Of Statuary Are Interspersed In The Centre Of The Gauleries,With Glass Cases In Which Goblets,Vases, Carvings In Wood And Ivory, Jewelry, And Line Metal Work Are Seen. At Intervals, Too, You Can Walk From The Courts Into The Open Air Upon The Flat Roof Of The Arcades, And Rest And Refresh The Eye Wvith The Tender Green Which Spring Has Caued Forth In The Gardens Enclosed. From The Eastern Galleries The Procession, Descending To The Ground Floor, Passed Through Corridors In Which Are Arranged The Meyrick Collection Of Armour From Goodrich Court. India Contributes Some Native Armour-Breast-Guards Of Rhinoceros Hide, Elbow Gauntlets Of Damascened Steel And The Like,Sometimes Bearing Invocations To Ali While In Silent Contrast To The Cross-Bows And Match-Locks, The Arquebus, And The Martel-De-Fer, The Men In Buff And The Knights In Armour, Are Ranged A Few Empty 9-Inch Shells Weiglhing 3021B.,With A Bursting Charge Of 181B. A Good Many Members Of The Procession Looked As Though They Would Like To Stop For A Few Minutes In The Refreshment-Rooms Which Were Skirted At This Part Of The Route Btut The Trumpeters Sounded At Each Stae, And Fate Was Inexorable. Passing More Rapidly Througlh The Southern Courts, Dedicated To Bricks And Terra-Cotta Ornaments, And Through The Interesting Fish Couection Arranged By Mfr. Frank Buckland, The Royal Party Found Themselves In The Fine Arts Courts On The Western Side, Where Modern British Art Has Clothed The Walls With Glowing Canvas, And You Pass From Room To Room Till The Eye Almost Refuses To Take In Either Form Or Colour. In One Of These Rooms Are Ranged The Prize Fans. The Rule That No Rewards Are To Be Given Is Broken In This Case Alone. The Queen Offered A Prize Of 401., The Competition Being Restricted To Ladies Under 25, But This Has Not Been Awarded. Among The Prize-Holders Is Plincess Louise, Who Contributes A Fan Painted Last February, And Giving A Very Lively, Vigorous Representation Of A Skating Scene. There Was, Of Course, Much Stopping To Identify This Sketch. The Decoratiyo Furniture, The Sculpture, Metal-Work, Indian Jewelry, Mosaics, Carvings, And Other Art Objects In The Western Galleries Were Eagerly Scrutinized, But Stragglers Were Soon Recaued, And Reminded That More Leisurely Inspection Must Be Reserved For Future Visits. So A Good Mile Of Galleries Was Traversed The Royal Party, Re- Turning To,The Point From Which They Had Set Out, Proceeded Through The Hall To Their Carriages At The North Entrance, Without Waiting For The International Concert That Was To Follow And The Exhibition Of 1871 Was Thrownn Opon Td Undistinguished As Well As Distinguished Visitors. The Vocal And Instrumental Concert, Or Exhi-! Bition Of Musical Art, As It Was Somewhat Pompously Described In The Printed Programme, Began With A Splendid Performance Of The Overture To Der Freisnhiito, Under The Direction Of Sir Michael Costa. The Hall Being Crammed Literally In Every Part, The Orchestral Effaect Was Much More Encouraging Thanat Either Of The Concerts Given By The Society Of Arts, Or Even At That Organized By The Sacred Hlarmonic Society, When Mendelssohns Oratorio, .Lfijalh, Was Essayed. A Crowded Audience Seems To Be One Of The Essential Conditions Of Musical Success At The Royal Albert Hall. After Der Freisc7Tz The Ner Pieces Written Expressly For The Opening Of The Exhibition Were Heard Insuccession,Conductedbytheirrespectivecomposers. On Such An Occasion Criticism Would Be Entirely Out Of Place, And We Shall, Therefore, Confine Ourselves To A Mere Description Of The Plan And Character Of Each Work, More Especially As We Feel Convinced That Other Opportunities Of Bearing And Estimating Theni At Their Value Will Speedily Be Forthcoming. To Begin From The Beginning-Italy Was Reprosented By Signor Ciro Pinsuti, A Gentleman Lono Resident Among Us, And Deservedly Held In High Esteem. Siganor Pinsutis Contribution Was A Fourpart Chorale, Set To The Subjoined Stanzas Of Lord Houghton- O, People Of This Favoured Land, Witbin This Peaceful Orbit Met, We Strike The Chords With Trembling Hand, The Voice Within Us Falters Yet While On This Point Of Time We Staud, Shall We Remember Or Forget? We Must Remember Those Good Days When First We Bid The Nations Flu The Fairy Halls We Dared To Raise, By Genius Wed To Earnest Will,- And All Was Pleasure, Power And Praises Tho Fair Reward Of Toil And Skill. So Let This Hapoy Memory Veil From Present Gheuhts The Later Woe- Now That The Blood-Red Clouds Grow Pale, Now That No More The Trumpets Blowno More Beneath The-Fiery Hail Ochildren In Terror Come Andgo. Be This A Feast Of Hope I The Flowers Of Spring The Waste Of War Repair- The Quiet Work Of Happier Hours Dispels The Load Of Human Care For Industry And Art Are Powers That Know No End And No Despair. The Clwrale, A Smooth And Scholarly Piece Of Vocal Harmony, In The Key Of A Lati Was Extremely Waell Sung, And Furthereonfimcd Us Mn An Opinion Alwready Advanced, That Choral Music I3 Hikely More Thlan Any Other To Test Decisively The Acoustic Capabilities Of Albert Hall. Me. Gounods Motett, Entitled Gallia, As In Direct And Strong Contrast With The Foregoing. Signor Pinsuti Sings A Song Full Of Gratulation And Hope While M. Gounod, Until His Very Last Mnovement, Is All Sadness And Despondency. The Words Of Gallia Are Taken From Tileo Lamentations Of Jeremiah Chapter 1, Verses 1, 2, 4, And 12. The Maotett Is Published Both With The Latin Text From The Roman Catholio Bible And An English Translation Adapted From It, So As To Meet The Requirements Of Musical Rhythm. It Comprises An Orchestral Introduction And Chorus- Qtumodo Sedet Sola Civias Solitary Lieth The City, In The Key Of E Minor A Soprano Solo, In A Minor- Vis Siol Lu. Genft Tie Ways Of Zion Do Mourn A Chores, With Soprano Solo, In C- 0 Sos Omnes Qui Transitis Perianm All Ye That Pass By, The Second Section Of Which, Vie, Ldotnine, Afflictinemr Meane 0, Lord, Behold My Affliction, Brings Us Back To The Minor Key Of The Opening, And A Solo, Leading To A Chorus- Jesusamen I Jerusalem I Coi Wertere Ad Dominum Duentn Tuinen Jerusalem ! Jerusalem I Be Converted To The Lord Thy God, Which Is In The Major Key, And With Wonderful Briphtness, Dispels The Gloom Of Afl That Precedes It. We Have Hinted That Criticism Would Be Just Nowoutof Place But This Neednot Deter Us From Saying How Deeply M. Gounod Has Felt The Theme, Of His Own Hoice, How Tenderly And Beauti- Fully He Has Treated It, And How Hiis Music Is Suxeto Excite The Sympathies Of All Who Desire To See The Great Country Of Which He Is One Of The Most Distinguished Sons Restored To Its Normal Condition Of Honour, Prosperity, And Peace. What Gallia Meant Must Have Been Plain To Every Englishman, As To Every Frenchman, Yesterday. We Have Merely To Add That The Solos In The Motett Were Undertaken By Madame Conneau, Known In Parisian Circles As An Amateur Of Remarkable Ability That The General Performance, Under M. Gounods Own Direction, Was Admirable And Tlat The Reception Accorded Both To The Composer And His Work Was Of The Heartiest Poseible Kind. France Was Worthily Represented. The Grand March By Dr. Ferdinand Eiifler, Wtho Was Invited As A Inatter Of Cotuse To Represent Germany, Is A Composition Of Appropriate Brilliancy.. The Themes Are Vigorous, Rhythmical, And To The Purpose. The March Is In The Key Of D Major, With A Trio In A And Another In B Flat. The Execution By Tho Orchestra, Under The Direction Of The Eminent Composer Himself, Was All That Could Be Wished. Last, Not Least, England Was Represented, And, We May Add, Worthily Represented, By Mr. Arthur Suuivan, Who Contributed A Dramatic Cantata, Entitled On Slwre Awd Sea, The Plan And Character Of Which May Bo Best Explained By The Argument Supplied For The Programme By Mr. Tomrtaylor, Author Of The Words- The Action Passes On Shore At Ono Of The Many Small Seaports Dependent On Genoa, Such As Cogoletto, Or Camog, Ruta, Or Porto-Ferio-In Which Gaueys Were Manned Ana Tted Out For Her Service-And At Sea, On Board, First Of A Geneeso And Afterwards Of A Moorish Galley. The Cantata Opens With The Fleet Weighing Auchor To Tho Joyons Sonr Of The Sailors As They Heave At The Windlass And Spread The Sail, And The Lament Of Wives And Moters, Sisters And Sweethearts, Left Sorrowing Onshore. Then The Scene Changes To The Sea. Aboard One Of Tho Galeys, In The Midnight Watch The Thoughts And Prayers Of The Ayarine Go Back To The Ioyed Ones Left Behind, And Invoke For Them The Protection Of Our Lady, Star Of Tho Sea. Months Pass. The Scene Changes Again To The Shore. The Fleet, So Long And Anxiously Looked For, Shows On The Horizon, Aud The Crowd Flocks To The Port To Greet Its Triumphant Entry, Headed By The Yonag Wife Orniaiden Whose Fortunes The Cantata Fouows. But The Price Of Triumph Must Be Paid. The Galley Aboard Which Her Sailor Served Is Missing It Has Been Taken By The Rovers. Her Beloved Is Captive Or Slain. She Gives Expression To The Desolation Amid The Sympathizisg Sorrow Of Her Companions. Herlover,However, Is Notslain, But A Slave, Toiling At The Oar Uuder The Lash Of His Moorish Captors. He Plans A Rising On The Rovers, And While They Are Celebratinogtheir Triumphs With Song And Feasting, Possesses Himself Of The Key Of The Chain To Whicb, As It Ran From Stem To Stern Of These Gaueys, Each Prisoner Was Secured, And Exhorts His Fellow-Prisoners To Strike For Their Liberty. The Galley Slaves, After Encouraging Each Other To The Enterprise While They Toil At The Oar, Rise On Their Captors, Master The Galley, And Steer Homewards. Re-Entering The Port They Are Welcomed By Their Beloved Ones Sorrow Is Turned To Rejoicing, And The Cantata Ends With A Chorus Expressing The Blessedness Of Peace. The Music Of Mr. Sullivan Is Full Of Interest, But The Work Is Of Too Great Importance To Be Dismissed In The Few Lines Which Just Now Are All Which Ve Can Possibly Devoteto It. It Comprises No Less Than Eight Choruses, Togethor Witlh Reoitatives And Airs For Soprano And Bass Voices, And More Than One Orchestral Interlude, As Atriking And Characteristic As The Rest. In Certain Parts Of The Cantata The Young Composer Has Employed The Strange Intervals Which Distinguish The Oriental, And Especiauy The Turkish And Egyptian, Styles Of Melody. He Has Done This Moreover, With Eminent Success, Because He Has Done Itin Such A Way That Genuino Music Is Never Kept Out Of Mind. From The Brief Orchestral Introduction, Which Usher3 In The Opening Chorus Of Sailors, To The End There Is Always Something To Invite Attention And, In Fact, Hardly One Of The Ten Numbers Into Which The Canttata Is Divided Can Be Set Aside As Unworthy Special Notice. Mr. Sullivan Himself Conducted The Performance, Whiceh Was Received With High Favour, And, What Is More, Thoroughly Deserved It. The Solos Were Allotted To Madame Lemmens-Sherrington And Mir. Winn. After The Cantata The Overture To Rossinis Semir Ramidc Was Played, Under Sir Michael Costas Direction, With The Same Perfection As At The Second Concert Given By The Society Of Arts, Though, Coming So Late In The Programme, It Scarcely Excited The Same Enthusiasm. The National Anthem, For Chorus And Orchestra, Brought The Concert To An End. It Should Be Addedthat The Whole Of Themusical Arrangements Were Confided To The Directors Of The Sacred Harmonic Sooiety, Whieh Alone Would Account For The Excellence Of The Chorus Just As The Presidence Of Sir Michael Costa Woula Account For The Excellence Of The Orchestra.
