Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Chinese Landscapes. What One Most Adrnires In The Chinese And Japanese Landscapes By Mr. Stewart Carstairs At Messrs. Knoedlers Galleries, 15, Old Bond-Street, Is The Taste And Tact With Which The Artist Has Applied His Comparatively Limited Powers Of Execution To Scenes And Subjects Which Have Interested Hini. 1Painted In Oil In A System Of Judiciously Modified Pointillism In Light Schemes Of Colour--With Grey, Lilac, Aid Lavender Predotninatingthe Pictures Are Most Successful In The Rendering Of Space And Atmosphere. They May Be Said To Make Space Decorative. Mr. Carstairss Limitations As A Draughtsman Come Out In His Treatment Of Trees, But So Long As He Is Dealing With Regular Shapes, Such As Houses And Bridges, He Does Not Betray Them, And The North Bridge, Ihushukwan And A Dye Shop, Euchow, With The Fabrics Hanging Like Nets From A Bamboo Framework, Are Two Of The Best Of His Chinese Pictures. The Japanese Pictures Are Mostly In A Series Representing Cherry Blossom In The Early Morning Mist, And In Them The Veiled Forms Of Wooded Hills Are Well Suggested, With Great Charm Of Colour. By Dint Of Careful Simplicity In Drawing And Wise Reliance On The Intrinsic Decoration Of Costume Mr. Carstairs Has Made A Good Portrait Of A Manchu Priicess In Wedding Dress. But What Really Makes His Exhibition Attractive Is The Intelligence With Which He Has Recognized And Adapted His Powers To Subject Matter Of A Special Kind. Drawings Of 1Taly. Without Being Imitative In Style Or Closely Topographical In Subject, The Water-Colours And Drawings Of Italy By Mr. Kenneth Hobson At The Cotswold Gallery, 59, Frith-Street, Soho-Square, Have A Simplicity, Gravity, And Restraint Which Remind One A Good Deal Of The Early Mnasters Of The British School, J. R. Cozens In Particular. The Impression Given Is Not That Mr. Hobson Has Deliberatelycomposed His Mind And Limited His Palette, But That He Is Naturally Serious And Reflective And Finds Simple Means The Best For Expressing His Deep Interest In The Subjects. One Proof Of His Freedom From Pose Is His Ability To Unbend Wvhen The Subject Suggests A Looser And More Atmospheric Treatment, As In The Delightfujl Drawing Of A Sunilit Wll, A Wayside Shrine, Fraseati. Most Of The Drawings Are Of Architecture Closely Associated With Rocky Formations Of Ground, And It Is In His Treatment Of The Relations Between The Twvo That Mr. Hobson Displays His Skill As A Draughtsman. Keepinig Pretty Close To The Facts, And Withouit Being Ostentatiously Structural, He Gets The Effect Of A Unified Mass By Consistency In The Style Of Draw- Ing And Tact In Placing The Waslhes. With L The Drawing Named, Rome From The Pincio, Rocca Di Papa And Monte Cavo, And Monte Compatri And The Roman Campagna May Be Picked Out As Illustrating His Range. The Victorians. Mr. Osbert Sitwells Remarks On The Etchings Of The Late Queen Victoria In The Exhibition Of Them And Other Victorian Pictures And Objets Dart At The Broolstreet Art Gallery Are To Be Read As Written, But It Is True That Her Majesty Had Not Only General Artistic Talent But A Personal Style. A Celestial Choir And H.R.H. Princess Alice And Her Nurse, To Name Two Of The Best Original Etchings, May Not Be Drawn Perfectly By Academic Standards, But They Are Definitely Drawnv, With Selection From The Facts According To The Nature Of The Medium, And Clear And Decisive Statement. In Artistic, As Distinct From Romantic, Interest They Are Far Superior To The Works Of The Prince Consort Or By Him And The Queen In Collaboration. They Are, In Fact, Distinctly Modernist In Flavour. Altogether This Is A Most Entertaining Exhibition. It Contains A Good Many Things Of Which The Interest Is Chiefly Historical Or Circumstantial, Such As The Glass And Mother-Of-Pearl Pictures, The Fragment Of H.M. Queen Victorias Wedding Cake And The Rare Purple Bristol Glass Vase -Technically Perfect, But In Shape And Colour Suggesting A Jelly Infused With A Cheap Port Wine But, On The Other Hand, There Are A Few First-Rate Works Of Art, Those Whose Ideas About W. P. Frith Are Based Exclusively On Engravings Of Paddington And Time Derby Day Will Learn Something Fresh About His Powers As A Painter From The Hungerford Bridge Omnibus, And As A Composer From English Merry-Making In The Olden Time And There Are Slcetches By Wilkie, Faed, Leech, And Millaisincluding A Pencil Drawing Of The Head Of Sir Isumbras. Nor Must The Graceful Statuette Group Of John Brown, With The Pony Flora And The Collie Sharp, By Princess Louise, Be Overlooked.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. A New Gallery To Judge From Its Opening Exhibitionpaintings By Renoir And Other Modern Artists-And Situation-3, Grosvenorsfreet-The New Paul Guillaume Gallery, Conducted By M. Paul Guillaume, The Wellknown Picture Dealer Of Paris, And Mr. F3Randon Davis, A Collector Who Makes His First Venture In Dealing, Intends To Pursiue A Definite Policy. Exhibitions Of Conteniporary English Art Are Promised, But All Tile Circumstances Combine To Suggest That The Emphasis Will Be Put Upon Works With Acquired As Well As Intrinsic Values. The Gallery Has Been Converted, By Mr. A. Lovell Knight, From A Private House, And The Rooms Are Well Lighted And Soberly Decorated In A Style Wliich Suggests An Atmosphere Conducive To Quiet Consideration Of The Works Displayed. There Are No Fewer Than 35 Paintings And 14 Drawings By Renoir, And In Range Of Period And Style It Appears To Be The Most Representative Exhibiition Of Him That We Have Had. By This Time Renoirs, Importance In The History Of French Tainting Is Beyond Question, Though We May Still Be Allowed To Comment Upon The Characters Whioh Make Us Contemplate -His Work With Mixed Feelings. He Began His Life As A Painter On Porcelain, And The Experience Haunted His Work To The End. Throughout His Work There Is Felt A Confliot Between Sensuous And Formal Quali,Ties-As If He Were Aiming At A More Intellectual Conduct Of The Pieture Than Really Suited His Instincts-And Again And Again In Looking At His Works One Is Reminded Of The Enlarged China Painting. At The Same Time It Is Clear That His Desire For A Monumental Treatment Of -Form Was Quite Genuine It Is Only That He Did Not Appear To Be Able To Make The Necessary Sacrifice Of What May Be Called Substantial Qualities-Colour, Texture, And Surface As Delights In Themselves, The Result Is Rather Like Having Peche Melba Served Up In A Dish Which Presupposes Carvingand Beyond A Certain Scale There Is Too Much Peche Melba. Renoirs Plastic Feeling Is Undeniable He Approaches Rubens In His Nioulding Of Rounded Forms Into A Unified Composition, But He Lacks The Bones That One Felt In Even The Most Billowy Picture By The Flemish Master And His Treatment Of Hands, With Their Sudderi Tapering From A Plump Wrist, Must Eyacite Painful, Memories In Anybody Who Siiffered From Chilblains In Youtil The Great Attraction In His Work Is Its Innocent Enjoyment Of Material Beauties -Of Woomen, Children, And Flowers-And One Of The Most Completely Satisfying Paintings In The Present Exhibition Is That Of A Little Boy, Portrait Of Jean. .The Most Important As A Composition Is Portrait Of Colonna Romano, Seated On A Sofa Against A Red Wall, With Picture Frames Playing A Part In The Rhythm Of The Design, And There Are Some Interesting Self-Portraits, Including One Of The Artist As A Young Man. The Drawings Are Particularly Welcome Because They Show Renoir Without His Material. Seduetions-Not That The Seductions Are To Be Regretted In Themselves On The Contrary, They Are.To Be Enjoyed But That, In The Paintings, They Are Too Often Felt To Be The Urong Context-S If You Were Offered Strawberries And Cream At A Solemn Occasion... You Curse The Occasion, Not The Strawberries And. Cream. In The Drawings Everything Is Consistent, And The Sacrifice Of Character To Mass Explains Itself. Mother And Children, At Any Rate, Would Bear Comparison With Rubens. The Paintings By Other Artists Inelude A Very, Fine - C6Zanne Landscape, Le Tholomnet, -A Middle-Period Corot, Landscapq Near Etampes, Both Firm And Atmospheric, A Lovey Snow Scene, By Sisley, And Several Eiarnples Of The Elegant Art Of Matisse. In A Place Of Honour There Is An Enchantig Picture Of The Wedding, By Henri Rousseau The Douanier,. Itshowwhat Happens When Yoducommiission A Portrait Group From A Genuine Awrtist. The Sporting Gallery. Being Illustrations, 3R. Ernest Il Shepards Original Drawings, Exhibited At The Sporting Gallery, 32, King-Street, Covent Garden, For The - House, At Pooh Corner And Mr. Punchs County Songs Are Chiefly Of Psychological Interest. In The Illustrations To Mer.. A. A. Milnes Stories Mr. Shnpardcchowa A Remarkable Aptitude In Giving A Human Expression To Animals, And His Pigs, Rabbits, And Other Animals Are, If Possible, Even More Expressive Than The Children Which Accompany Them. Mr. Shepards Children To Some Extent Remind One Of Fashion Plates-Though Of Course His Drawing Is Much More Competentin That They All Achieve The Same Sort Of Elegance, The Same Charm, And Even Appear To Be To Some Extent Aware Of The Social Position With Which This Kind Of Charm Atrees. Flow Mr. Shepard So Unfailingly Contrves To Suggest A Complete Social Milieu, And Even To Throw Light Upon Its Standards, In Drawings So Slight As These Is Indeed Mysterious. His Draw- Ings For Mr. Punchs County Songs, Are More Elaborate And Consequently Even Mnore Expressive Of The Aspirations Which Are So Ingeniously Aduinbrated In His Drawings Of Children. Hr. Cecil Aldins Coaching Pictures At The Same Gallery Evoke With Equal Ingenuityand As Satisfactorily A Different Kind Of Romance, One More Objective And Remote From Human Needs, To Which He Gives The Title The Romance Of The Road. Coaches And Inns, Clay-Pipes, Beer, Winking Coachmen, And Regency Architecture Are The Constituents Of This ,Kinid Of Rozance, But What Is Interesting About Mr. Aldins Drawings Is That He Uses So Exactly -The Particular Technique, The Rather Loose Method Of Drawing, Which Experience Has Shown To Be Necessary For His Purpose.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exrlitions. There Is Not Much That Is Distinctive In The Exhibition Of The Society Of British Artists In The Large Galleries In Suffolk-Street But Then One Hardly Expects It Nowadays In The Half-Yearlyidisplays In These Rooms. A Certain Novelty Is Lent By. The Eccenttic Productions Of Mr. J. W. T. Manuel, -Whose Work Tecalls The Curiosities That Were Common Here Under A Different Vrime A Few Years Ago But With This One Exception There Is Very Little That Compels Attention. A Certain Number Of Very Blue Sea-Pieces, A Grave Scotch Landscape By Mr. Tom Robertson 72, Pleasant In Colour Bat A Little Infirm In Handling, And One Chsracteristic Picture By Mr. Cayley Robinson Lre What Chiefly Remain In The Memory Of The Visitor After A Tour Of The Central Gallery. Mr. Cayley Robinson Is, As We Have Said More Than Once, An Interesting Painter, Who Combines With The Spirit Of The English Prm-Raphaelites A More Modem Feeling Derived Apparently From French Training. His Littlo Picture Of The Foundling, Were It Not For The Excessive Size Of The Childs Head, Would Be A Decided Success The Figure Of The Woman Who Is Making Ready The Bed Has A Curious Grace, And The Coloar Of The Whole Picture Is Charming After Its Quaint Fashion. But, As In All The Work Of The Men Upon Whom Mr. Robinson Seems To Model Himself-Madox Brown And Wir. Holman Hunt-There Is A Superfluity Of Detaii Which Is Perhaps Intended To Have A Mean- Ing, But Which Rather Hurts The General Effect. The Large Picturo Which Mr. R. U. W. Bunny Calls Ros 103 Is Decorative But Mysterious, And The Fisherman Who Is About To Throw His Net To Catch, Not The Fish, But, As It Would Seem, The Mnaiden Goddess Who Walks Scarcely Visible Upon The Water, Has A Co.Nic Effect, Which We Fear The Artist Never Intended. Mr. Simes Clever Portrait 185 Is Full Of The Newest And Least Attractive Of French Mannerisms Mr. J. E. Breuns 153 Is A Little Theatrical. There Is Excellent Intention Inthesymboliepicturewhich Hr. B.M Achell Calls Love, But The Painting Is Not So Good As The Design, And The Best Part Of The Picture Is Its General Decorative Conception And The Execution Of The Frame. The Large Room At The Fine Art Societys In New Bond-Street Is Now Filled With A Remarkable Collection Of Drawings Illustrating A Century And Sa Half Of English Rumorous Art From Hogarth To The Present Day, And To The Catalogue Of This Rather Ambitious Display An Historical Introduction Has Been Written By Mr. Joseph Grezo, A Gr3At Authority On The History Of The Grap-Hic Humourists. Of Course No More Than A Very Few Specimens Can Be Given Even Of The Chief Artists In So Long A Line, And We Can No More Judge Gillray And Rowlandson By A Few Sarnples Than We Can Judge Sir John Tenniel By The Cartoons Of Asingle Month. The Greatness Of A Humourist Often Lies In His Fertility What Made That Of Leech, For Example, Was His Wide Outlook Upon Life And His Power Of Going On Year After Year With Fresh Illustrations Of Its Follies And Its Foibles. Hcmour Is The Most Difficult Thing In The World To Sample Satisfactorily. Still, Space, At All Events In The Exhibition Room, Has Its Limits, And We Must Be Content Withwhat The Artists Themselves Would Have Thought And What The Living Ones Doubtless Think A Very Scanty Representation Of Their Talent. One Of The Old Caricaturists Who Comes Out Best From The Ordeal Is H. W. Bunbury, A Member Of The Well-Known Norfolk Family Which Will Always Bo Associated With The Names Of Reynolds, Goldsmith, And Their Circle. This Man Of Fashion, This Amateur Of Genius, Could Draw A Smart Crowd With A Charm Almost Equal To That Which Gainsborough Put Into His Picture Of The Mall, And A First-Rate And Well-Preserved Example Of His Talent Is Given Here In The Drawing Of The Garden Party At Carlton-House. Artistically This Is Perhaps The Most Important Drawing In The Rooni, But It Is Rather A Charming Picture Of Society Than A Satire Or A Caricature. We Pass From It To The Coarser And More Vigorous Art Of Rowlandson, To The Grim Satire Of The Cruikahanks, To The Interesting Set Of Original Illustrations For Pickwick Here Exhibited Together Upon A Screen, And Thence To The Men Of Our Own Day, The Men Who Week After Week Have Entertained Us In Punch. And Other Periodicals. Here Are A Few Exeulent Drawings By Du Maurier, To Remind Us Of A Loss We Shall All Feel For Many A Day Here Are Thinas By Mr. Linley Sambourne, Mr. F. C. Gould, Nr. B. T. Reed, Mir. Leslie Ward, And Many Another Favourite Of The Public. But Of These Men The Work Is So Familiar That No Description Of It Is Necessary It Is Enough To Say That The Selection Of It Is Interesting Both In Itself And As Affording A Means Of Comparison Between Styles And Points Of View. From The Genial Caricatures Of Well-Known Contemporarieswhich This Room Contains Itisa Curious Change To Pass To The Very Interesting Exhibition Of Paintings By Mr. Milure Ha Mlton At The Goupil Gallery, At The Bottom Of Resent-Street. Here, Too, Are Portraits Of Celebrities, Though Not Caricatures Lir. Gladstone In Several Aspects, Mr. Herbert Spencer, Professor Tyndall, Air G. F. Watts, Lord Leighton, Mr. Onslow Ford, And Several Other People, All Invested With Life In An Extraordinary Degree And With That Quality Of Instantaneousness In Which Scarcely Any Contemporary Artist Can Rival Mr. Hamilton. The Artist Has A Method All His Own He Paints So Thinly As Scarcely To Cover The Canvas, Andgzives, Except In Lord Leightons Portrait, Almost The Effect Of Monochrome. But This Slightness Is Only Apparent In Reality The Heads Are Most Carefully Modelled And The Likeness In Almost Every Case Is Singularly Vivid. The Largo P Icture Called In The Library At Hawarden . Is Really One Of The Most Veracious Of Existing Portraits Of 3Ir. Gladstone, And The Head Of Mir. Herbert Spencer Is Probably The Only Portrait Of That Philosopher That I At Al Satisfactory. Altogether This Little Exhibition Is Not One To Be Missed We Hope It Will Reveal To The Public At Large, What Has Long Been Known To The Painters, That Mr. Mlure Hamilton Is An Artist Of Very Unusual Talent In Portraiture. We Must Pass Over With A Single Word The Pleasant Exhibition, At The St. Georges Gallery In Grafton-Street, Of Landscapes By The Late M. Lipine, Who Is Described As The Pupil Of Corot And Who Certainly Was Greatly Influenced By Him And Also The Picture Exhibited With Much Parade And Mystery At Messrs. Dowdeswells Close By. This Is The Rabboni Of Mr. Herbert Schmalz . The Title Explains The Subject, And The Name Of The Artist Is A Sufficient Indication Of The Style In Which It Is Treated. Lastly, We May Direct Atteution To The Little Exhibition Of Old English Pictures To Be Seen In What Has Become Their Customary Home, Messrs. Shepherds Gallery In Kinc-Street, St. Jamess. Among A Number Of Small Cabinet Pictures-Genuine Sketches By Romney, Constable, David ,Ox, C.-There Stand Out Two Rather Remarkable Works Of Little-Known Painters, A Very Vigorous Portrait Of The Duke Of Wellington In Uniform By J. Simpson, A Pupil Of Sir Thomas Lawrence, And A Keminiscence Of The Last Montem At Eton By W. Parrott. This Picture, Which Was Exhibited At The Royal Academy In 1849, Is A Vivid Rendering Of A Scene Interesting To All Etonians And To All Readers Of Disraelis Novels. The Painter Is One Of Those Who Have Been Undeservedly Forgotten He Had A True Eye For English Landscape And For Sparkling Colour.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Parson Painters. A Society Of Parson Painters Is In Itself An Interesting Fact, And That, And The Possibilities Suggested Rather Than Present Performance Make Noteworthy The First Exhibition Of The Society At Holy Trinity Church House, 204A, Reat Portland-Street. The Dean Of York, Who Is President Of The Society, Contributes Some Excellent Water-Colours Of Coast-Scenes, In Which-In Sands, Walberswick, In Particular-The Feeling Of Space As Contained Between The Receding Planes Of Eartli And Sky Is Very Well Suggested, And There Are Oil Paintiigs, Charming In Colour And Atmosphere, Of Scenes Abroad By Bishop Hamilton Baynes. The Strongest Impression, However, Is Made By The Gro Up Of Water-Colours By Mr. Mi. F. Foxell Clear And Simple, And Showing A Real Grasp Of Structural Principles In Both Landscape And Architecture. Wootton, Oxon, And - Puddle Dock Are- Particularly Good. Mr. Claude Torrey, Who Is Not Unknown In The Exhibiton World, Is Well Represented By Near Avranches, And The Seascapes In Oils By Mr. L. G. Brown, The Study Of Roofs, Scarborough, By Canon H. Ward, And One At Least Of The Ftgure Paintings, Love Tangled With Roses, By Mr. A. B. Tremearne, Way Be Noted. Lastly, A Word Must Be Given To The Precise Little Landscapes, Two British Camps In Particular, By Mr. Hugh Mark. If It Should Lead Our Parish Priests Who Can Draw To Make Topographical Studies Of Their Localities, And Careful Copies Of Interesting Details-Glass, Carvings, Wall Paintings-In Their Churches, The Society Wil Deserve Every Encouragement, The Exhibition Is Open Until November 28 From 10 To 4 Daily, Closing On Wednesday At 1.30 And All Day On Saturday. A Russian Painter. Opened On Thursday By The Dowager Marehioness Of Milford Haven, The Exhibition Of Portrait Paintings By Countess Orloff-Davidoff At The American Womens Club, 46, Grosvenorstreet, Gives Evidence Of An Impulsive Talent Beyond The Present Technical Accomplishment Of The Artist. None Of The Portraits-Includmg A Drawing Of Hj.H. The Grand Duchess Xenia And Paintings Of Princess Nina Of Russia, Princess M. Galitzine, And Count A. Orloff-Davidoff -Fails Inthe Suggestion Of Character, And The Adaptation Of Treatment Totyshows Real Imagination. Petite Claire, Annita, A Basque Girl, And Negro Girl From Madagascar Are Sympathetic Studies Of Heads There Are Some Lively Drawings From Sketch-Books, And The Single Latndscape, Of A Scene In Normandy, Has All The Essentials Of Good Landscape Painting Under Its Tentative Execution. The Exhibition Is Open Until To-Day. Portrait Sculpture. By Kind Permission Of Mrs. Philip Snowden There Was Held On Thurslday, At 53, Carlisle-Mansions, A Private View Of Portrait And Other Sculpture By Mrs. Dorothy Dick M Stewart Dick. Without Any Great Pretensions To Formal Beauty The Work Of Mrs Llick Is Expressive In Modelling, And She Bas The Gift Of Being Able To Make A Lively And Sympathetic Likeness-As Iuustrated By The Bust Of Mrs. Plilip Snowden A1Nd The Series Of Six Reliefs Of Sybil Thorndike, Done Quickly In The Dressing-Room During The Run Of Saint Joan. Mrs. Dicks Decorative Abilities Are Shown, In A Mask Of Sybil Thorndike As Saint Joan And Some Translations Of The Old Masters In Coloured Relief, As Well As Studies, In The Same Form, Of Dancers And Volendam Fisherfolk.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Abt Exbibitions. The Antumn Exhibitions At The Two Galleriss In The Eaymarket, Mlessrs. Tooths And Mr. M.Leans, Are Thrown Open To The Public This Morning And Will Not, On The Whole, Disappoint Their Visitors. As Usual, The Strength Of Both Exhibitions Lies In The Work Of Foreign Artists, Though Certain Native Favourites Like Mr. Peter Graham, Mr. Leader, And Mr. W. L. Wyllie, Send Attractive Piectures,While At Mlessrs. Tooths A Central Place Is -Occupied By The Well-Known Besieged Of The Late Frank Holl. This Is One Of Those Somewhat Gloomiy Subjects In Which The Colebrated Painter Found So Much To Attract Him, And To Which, Strange To Say, He Was Always Regretting That His Incessant Engagements As A Portrait Painter Did Not Allow Him To Return. It Is Not On Them But On His Portraits That His Falme Will Rest, And Yet His Treatment Of These Subjects Allowed Him To Display That Skilful Use Of Strongly-Contrasted Light And Shade Which Was One Of The Distinguishing Marks Of His Painting. Other Pictures On Which The Strength Of The E-Hibition Depends Are Le Pardon-Bretagne, By Dagnan-Bouveret 56, And La Jeune Favorite, By That Extremely Skilful Painter Of Eastern Subjects, L. Deutsch, Both Of Them Works -Hich Made A Mark In-The Last Salon. The Latter Is A Sort Of Subject That G4Rome Used To Paint In His Best Days The Young Girl With Her Two Black-Robed Duennas Is Passing Into The Harem Before A Line Of Black Mutes In White Dresses Aird Wvhite Turbans, Drawn Up Against The Wvall. It Would Be Hard To Surpass The Technical Perfection Of This Work The Painting Of The Negroes Faces, Of The Purple-Blue Carpet And The Soft Matting, Of The Yellow Robe Of The Chief Eunuch, Is Just As Fine As It Can Be, And It Is Only Because G4R6Me And Charles Bargue And A Few Others Have Already Familiarized Us With The Style Of Painting That Such Work Does Not Make A Sdnsation. A Small Picture In The Ante-Room By M Weisse Is Equal In Quality To The Works Of Deutscli In Fact, There Are At The Present Time At Least Four Or Five Men Painting In Paris Who Can Achieve These Striking Effects Of Eombined Brieadth And Finish. -Mn. Daguan-Bouveret Is Of A Different Sort He Is Knowinfor Pictures Of Moaedern European Life, Serious In Tone And Strong In Treatmnent. This Time He Has Gone To The Land Which -Pierre Lotis Novels Have Made Familiar To So Many, And Has Painted A Few Figures Out Of A Breton Religious Procession. The Heads Are Wonderfully Modelled The Old White-Haired Man Who Looks As If He Might Have Fought With The Chouans, The Younger Man With Narrow Forehead And Pursed Lips, The. Typa Of The Peasant Bigot, The Happy-Looking Elder-Women And The Beautiful Girls-All These Areo Realized With Extraordinary Force And Haimonized. Into A Fino Picture. Another Work Which Ranks With These Two Is The Sunny Moments Of C. Bisschop, The Well-Known Dutch Painter An Altogether Charming Picture Of A Young Girl Standing Near A Window Through Which The Light Pours In Upon A Splendid Oriental Tablecloth Such As The Old Dutch Artists Loved To Paint. This Is By Far The Best Example Of Bisschops Work That Has Been Seen In London For Some Time. Last Among The Foreign Pictures We May Notice Le Veillee, By Lieerbaitte, An Agreeable Variation From His Usual Manner - The Stirrup Cup, A Very Clever And Attractive Example Of Rafaelle Sorbi, And The Cardplayers, A Work Of Bleissonier, Dated 1872. There Is A Certain Crudity Of Colour In The Contrast Between The Bright Red Brick-Work And The Blue A-Nd Green Coats Of The Players, But The Modelling Is As Masterly As Meissoniers Work Invariably Is, And T,He Picture Wvill Certainly Make A First-Rate Engraving. Of The Ienglish Pictures, As We Said, There Are Many That Are Wvell Up To The Painters Tsual Mark, But We Need Onl7 Call Special Attention To The Stratford Locki Of Mr. B. W. Leader, Not Because It Is A Particularly Good Picture, But Because It Has Been Beautifully Etched By Chauvel. The Etching Makes A Capital Companion To The Summer Showers Of Mr. Vicat Cole, A Picture Which Hung In This Very P Lace A Year Ago. The Landscapes Of Mr. Davidfarquharson And Some Small Flower Pieces By Miiss Ada N3Ell Are Also Noticeable. What Strikes One Flrst In Mr. Mleans Exhibition Is The Number Of Landscape And Cattlo Scenes That He Has Brought Together In Fact, Save For These And One Or Two Pictures Of Horses And Dogs There Would Be But Little In The Gallery. Rosa B3Onheur, Van Mareke, His Daughter Madame Dieterle, Charles Jacque, Schreyer, Yates Carrington, L. B. Hult, And The Spanish Paintel 31Anocal-All These Have Contributed Pietures Of Animal Life, So That The Gallery May Be Said To Contain An Epitome Of The Works Of Most Of The Best Animal Painters Now Living. The Gem Of The Collection Is Rosa Bonheurs Pasturage In The Pyrenees, Picture Fresh From Her Easel, And A Truly Marvellous Example Of Her Power. A Group ,Of Cattle Sutrounding A Magnificent Dun Lull Are Standing Or Lying About On The Top Of A Pyrenean Pass Amid The Bushes Of Alpenrose If That Name Is Appropriate When Thre Shrub Grows In The 0Pyrenees. Beyond, Throiigh Air Of Wonderful Clearness,Thedistant Peaks Are Visible, And Between Ithem And Us The Pastures Are Dotted With More Icattle, Smooth-Haired Cousins Of Our Own Fiercelooking Highland Breed. Miiademoiselle Bonheur S As Remalkable For Her Tact As For Her Painting Ishe Seldom Or Never Tries Effects In Which The Special Qualities Of Her Art Do Not Appear To Tadvartage. The Melancholy Of The Northern Tmarshes, Misty And Sombre, Is Not For Her Let Ivan Miarcke Find Poetry There ! The Beautiful Glades Of Fontainebleau, The Sunny Fallows Of The Nivernais, The Glowing Pyrenean Heights Are Twhat She Delights In. And Of All Her I-Yrenean Pictures This One Before Us Is Probably The Best, Lassuming That This Extraordinary Enamelled Work, This Jewel-Like Finish, Is A Legitimate Excellence Of Painting. The Other Animal Painters Are Fairly Represented Van Marcke Perhaps Least Satisfactorily. The Large Schreyer And Its Smaller Replica Are Brilliant, And Mr. Carringtons Pair Are Not Only Amusing, But They Are Painted Wvith A Strong Sense Of Colour. Senor 3Ranocal Like All The Other Spanish Painters Of The Day, Treads In The Stepa Of Fortuny The 2Ittle Sketch From His Hand Here Exhibited 26 Is Lfull Of Ability. Of The Other Pictures, Attention Is Claimed By A Pair Of Italian Lake Scenes By Mir. .Birket Foster, Who Seldom Paints In Oil And -Whose Conventionality Is Sadly Apparent In Them And By A Charming Work Of Poetzelberger, The Honeymoon 2,As Elegant A Little Tablcau De Genre As We Have Seen For Many A Day. Amateurs Who Prefer The Work Of Tho Old Tonglish School Will Find It Worth While To Look At Sthe Small Exhibition Now Arranged At Messrs. Shepherds, In King-Street. Some Little Pictures. By Constable, David Cox, Stark, Vincent, And .3!Orland Are Here, Mostly Of Excellent Quality, Zwith Cromes M1Ill On The Yare, A Brilliant ,Picture, Of Which An Etching Is Announced By Mr. Jole, A.R.S.A.2 Whose Renderings Of Corot Lately Iattracted Attenti-On. Baddeleys Book-Plates The Art Of 0. W. Sherborn May Be Not Unworthily Carried On. There Is, We Regret To See, Very Little Mezzotint, But What There Is Is Good. The Metal Work On The Whole Is Poor And Inclined To Be Fussy, But The Illumination Is Exceedingly Creditable, And The Art Of- Lettering Is Evidently Receiving The Attention It Deserves. --The National Competition. . Work Which Is Touched To-Life Either By ,The Intimate And Interested Acquaintance Of The Students With The Subject Or By The Hotiop Uf Purpose Which Underlies The Craftsmanship. And Enjoyed At First Hand By The Student, Or A Piece Of Metal-Work Or Wood-Work Made, As It Were, In The Course Ot The Daily Life X And The Liveliness And-F Dree Of-Such Exhibits Is Unmistakable.
