Title: The National Art Exhibition At Leeds
Full_text: The Ationyal Art Bxlftbi1Tioia At L Bmds. The Central Hall Of The Slew Infirmry, In Which The Great Coremony Of Inaugurating The Exhibition On Tuesday Next -I1 Be Held, Is Dow Actually Ready For The Purpose. It Hbs A Domned Roof Of Glass, And Is 15Dot. Lonag, 4Ft, Wide, And G0Ft. High. There Are 12 Columns Sup. Porting The Roof, Which Are Painted In Sombre Tints But The Tracery, Mouldings, C., Are Etched Io Blue Relieved With Gold. The Temporary Decorations Are Tnost Effective. Besides A Very Pictaresque Display Of Flags And Blazonry, There Aro Peudant Baskets Stored With The Loveliest And Sweetest Flowers, Aud In Recesses At The Sides Of The Hau Are Rockeries And Parterres Luxuriant Of Mosses, Creepers, Exotics, And Greenhouse Plants. At The East Extreafity Of Thehail, In Frout Of An Orcbestra In Which Mr. Charles Hlau6 Will Preside, Is A Dait On Which A Chair Of State Will Be Placed For The Prince Of Wales, And Bis Suite Wil Find Upon It The Accommoodation. Necessary For Their Close Attendance Upon Him. The Following Is The Progammra Of The Ceremoniatof Taesday -- Oa His Royal Highness Entering The Central Bau The Orchestra Nll Perform Thenationsial Nthem Instrumentally. His Royal Highness Having Taken His Seit On The Dais, The National Authem Wiu Be Given Vocauy. At The Conclusion Of The Inthem, The Mayor And Corpo. Ration Of Leeds Will Present Their Address To The Lprince, To Which His Royal Highness Will Reply. Chores, Thehravens Areteling-Hardn. Tbe Address Of The Executive Comrnittecof Theexhibition Wil Next Be Presentedi To His Royal Iligness By The Chairman, To Which The Prince Will Reply. The Lord Bishop Of Ripon Will Invoke A Blessing On The Undertaking, And, At The Termination Of The Prayer, Tho Orchestra, Will Perforns All Aen, Au Thing-S Praise The Lord, By Mendelssohn. The Prince Wiu Then Proceed To Inspect The Galleries, To Which His Royal Highness Will Be Conlucted By The Chief Comnmissioner, The Executive Committee, The Oiesident Of The London Committee, And The President Of The General Council And His Rtoyal Highness Wiu Be Accompanieda By The Adies An! Gentlemen, The Guests Of Mr. Meyselt Ingram, Of The Chairmau Of The Committee, And Of The Mayor Of Jleds. At The Entrance To Each Gallery The Respective Superintendents Will Be In Attendance. During The Progress Of His Royal Highness Througlh The Galeries A Selection Of Music And Chorases From Ataetie And From The Oratorio Of Solonon Wilt Be Performed. Having Concluded The Preliminary Inspection Of The Gal. Leries, The Princo Will Return To The Dais In The Central Hall, Aud His Royal Highness Will, In The Name Of Her Ma5Esty Thsequeen, Declare The Exhibition Open After Which Will Follow The S,Illelujal Chorus From Beethovens Mount Of Mfirec. His Royal Highness Will Then Retire From The Central All, Accompaniedt As On The Inspection Of The..-Gleries, And Will Proceed To Luncheon, After Which His Rloyal Llighness Will Make A Further Inspection Of The Galleries, Should He Desire To Do So. The Princa Will Then Take Biis Departure Form The Build. Ing, Escorted In The Same Manner As On His Royal Highneses Arrival Leeds Was Not More Busy Ten Years Ago, In Anticipation Of The Queeus Visit To Open The Town-Hall, Than It Is Now, In Its Desire To Do The Utmost Possible Honoar To The Prince Of Wales. Painters And Decorators Can Almosb Obtain Their Own Terms, And Bunting Is In Such Request That To Buy A Decent Dag Reqjuires A Startling Outlay. And To Hire One For A Day Or Two Is By Hr The More Extravagant Mode Of Procedure. Thie Workmen On The Triuraphal Arches To Be Erected By The Corporation Ply Their Avocation Us Though Not A Moment Was To He Lost, Ana The Streets Through Which The Procesrion Will Pass, Wvinding Through Tho Busiest, Though Some Of It May Not Be Thebeat,Partof Thetown, Appear To Have Been Entirely Taken Possession Of By An Army Of Carpenters, Who Are Either Erecting The Usual Barricades Or Constructing Temporary Platforms. Perhaps The -First Remarkable Sight Which Will Strike The Attention Of Thc Princo Wiu Be The Thousands Of Poor Clhildren Attending Church And Indastrial And Ragged Schools Who Will Be Assembled In That Part Of The Grave-Yard Which Liesin The East-Cud Of Thn Parish Church. Should The Weather Befavourable The Prince Will Be Sure Of The Joyous Greetings Of The Mightiest Multitude Of Yorkshiremen He Ever Saw. No Precise Information Can Be Gained As To The Sale Of The Five Guinea Tickets, Which Give Admission To The Opening Ceremony, And Coufer Other Privileges . Butit May Be Taken For Granted That The Revenue Anticipated From This Source Vill Be Fuuy Realized. The Guests Of Mr. Ueyneu Ingram, At Temple Newsum, Will Include -The Dake And Dachess Of St. Albans, The Dnke Of Devonshire, The Earl Of Chesterfield, The Countess Of Scarborougah Ana Two Ladies Lumley, The Earl And Countess Fitzwilliam And Two Iadies Eitzwvilliam, The Earl Ana Lady Constance Grosvenor, Lord And Lady Frederick Cavendi-H, Viscountandviscountea Lhalifax And The Hon. Misc Wood, Viscount Petersham, And Several Others. Mir. W. Beckett Denison Vill Entertain At Meanwood-Park,-Theearl And Countess Of Dudley, The Earl Of Eldon, Viscount And Viscountess Neville, Lord Feversham, Lord Boughton, Colonel The Hon. 0. Duncombe, Up., Lady Caroline And Two Miis3Sesdncombe. Mr. Rairbairn The Mayor Will Entertain At Woodsloy-House -Viscount Flans Os,Viscouot Rnd Visconutess Dlilton, Lorda C. Hantilton, Dir, And Dire. F. A. Millhanke And Twvo Misses Diiuhnke And We Hear Thlat Colonel Markhans, Of Beeca, And Mir. W. Gascoigne, Of Parlington, Vill Also Receive Huge Parties For The Ocecsion.

Author: BY OUR ART CRITIC
Title: The Chinese Art Exhibition
Full_text: Entertainments The Chinese Art Exhibition Rhythm Of Space By Our Art Critic Asked What Was The Most Striking Effect In Music, Beethoven Is Reported To Have Said No Music Meaning, It May Be Supposed, The Measured Rest Of So Many Beats Or So Many Bars Through Which The Rhythm Goes On Silently To Become Audible In The Next Chord. Translated Into Visual Terms, This, The Rhythm Of Eloquent Spaces, Is One Of The Characteristic Effects Of Chinese Painting, And It May Be Observed At The Royal Academy Not Only In The Sung Landscapes But Even In Such A Late Work As The Seventeenthcentury Screen 1,672 In The Big Room. The Spaces Betaveen The Cranes Are Not Empty But Filled With The Implication Of Their Movernent, And Even When Movement Itself Is Not Represented There Is The Same Effect, As Between A Group Of Trees And A Mountain Peak, And The Movement Of The Eye From One To The Other Is Part Of The Appreciation Intended. Before Looking At The Paintings It Might Be Well To Go Into The Smaller Of The South Rooms To See The Examples Of Calligraphy Displayed There, Such As Nos. 3,041 And 3,073, Because Chinese Painting Is A Brush-Writing Of The Mental Conceptions Of The Artist. It Might Be Incorrect To Say That Painting Was Derived Historicalty From Calligraphy, But Both Were Commonly Done By The Same Person-The Chinese Characters Themselves Being A Sort Of Shorthand Of Pictorial Ideas. As Good A Painting As Any To Begin Upon Is The Scroll Of The Hundred Geese 1,387, By Ma Fen Late Eleventh Century, Not Because It Is The Finest In Poetical Mood But Because It Shows To Perfection Both The Style Of Execution And The Eloquent Spaces Of The Chinese Artist. As Indicated By The General Direction Of The Geese, You Are Supposed To Begin On The Right, The Scroll Being Unrolled Gradually And Read Like A Poem. It Is Almost A Pity That The Scroll Could Not Be Shown That Way, To Provide The Succession Of Thrills As Each New Incident Came Into View. Nothing Is Represented But Geese, In An Infinite Variety Of Movement, And Bamboos, Standing Out Or Disappearing Into Misty Air, But There Is Never The Effect Of Empty Space. At One Point The Geese Are Shown Flying In File, As If To Sober Down The Excitement Caused By Their Actions, Diving, And So On. The Whole Thing Is A Masterpiece Of Impressionist Notation In Ink, In Nervous Touches, As If It Were Done At A Sitting In A Mood Of Intense Excitement. Scroll Paintings From This, And From The Other Scroll A Myriad Miles Of The Yangtze 1,127, By Hsia Kuei Active C. A.D. 1180-1230, Which Is More Placid In Mood, It Seems As If Unity In A Chinese Painting Were An Affair Of General Mood, And Images In Succession With Implied Links Between Them-Almost As If The Time Element Wvere Includedrather Than Of The Ordered, And Often Symmetrical, Composition With Which The Word Is Associated In European Art. Not All The Paintings Are Scroll Paintings, But Even In The Hanging Pictures A Sirnilar Kind Of Attention Seems To Be Asked For. You Stand Comparatively Close To The Picture, Give Yourself Up To Its Mood-Of A Serene Solemnity In Boating By Moonlight 1,163, And Of Something More Expectant In A Mountain After Rain 1,091, To Name Two Of The Finest Examples-While You Read The Subject. In Both These Paintings, In The Drop From The Mountain I To The Low-Rlaced Boat In The Former, And In The Ascent From The Trees To The Peak In The Latter, The Music Of Space Helps To Con- I Dition The Mood. Otherparticularly Fine Paintings Are Landscape With Palace Pavilions 1.000, More Architectural In Composition Than Is Usual The Kao Kao Pavilion 1,040, With Very Free Brushwork Two Horses 1,116, With The Soliditv Bv Contour Which Was Noticed In Th1E Tang Fragments And Mountain Landscape 1,207. Sculpture Disregarding History, Which Ought To Be Studied From Books, It Looks As If The Roots Bf Chinese Sculpture Were In The Early Bronzes, Jades, And Stone Carvings. The Chunky,, Buffalo 268,, Which Dates From The Shang-Yin Dynasty ? 1766-? 1122 B.C., Otherwise Nobody-Knows-When, Is A Good Starting Point. But In Most Of The Early Works The Forsrn, When They Are Not Df Abstract Pattcrns, Are Strongly Stylizedwith Tantalizing Hintsof Scythian, Pacific And Central American Affinities. -Gradually Mgore Nlaturalistic Animals And Figures Emerge, To Reach Perfection In The Tang Tomb Statuettes In The Lecture Room. Figure Sculpture Proper Comes With Buddhism, By What -Looks Like Greek Influence Via India, Absorbing The Riper Forms By The Wvay. What Strikes One At Once Is The Much Sharper Distinction Between Painting And Sculpture In China Than In Europe, As If The Solid Material Were The Raiso,T Dc,Re Of Sculpture. Reference To The Great Buddha, In The Central Hall, And Buddhist Priest, Holding Lotus 2,393, In The Lecture .Room,.Shows That The Figure Itself Is Conceived Very S6Lidly, While The Folds Of The Draperv Are Written Upon It, So To Speak, In More Stylized Lines And Curves Than-In Greek Sculpture, Recalling, Indeed, French Romanesque. There Is An Interesting Comparison Between No. 2,393 And The More Freely Modelled Temple Guardian 2,394 Beside It The Latter Seeming To Show The Native Chinese Movement Towards What We Should Call A Gothic Manner. In The Delightful Kuan-Vin 1,299. In Gallery Vi., It Has Reached The Full Baroque, And Throughout The Exhibi Tion There Seems To Be A Conflict Between Classical Rigidity -And Romantic Freedom. But In All The Buddhistic Sculpture, In The Exceedingly Beautiful Kuan-Yin 860, In Gallery Iv., For Example, One Cannot Fail To Be Struck By The Effect Of Calm Radiating From The Figures, Which Is Not Entirely Due To Tacial Expression..

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions I Civil Service Arts This Year The Annual Exhibition Of The Civil Service Arts Council-Founded In L924 To Include All Branches Of The Service-Is Held In The Imperial Gallery Of Art, Imperial Institute, Where It Makes A Very Orderly Appearance. A Little Too Orderly, Perhaps, For If Any Artists Can Afford Original Sin It Should Be Those Who Are Not Dependent On Their Art For A Living. Here And There Al One, Like 3Miss Florence J. Cogger In Violets, Kicks Over The Traces, Aen Dr. S. W. Wheaton Goes Resolutely His Own Way In The Welsh Matterhorn, But Most Of The Pictures Are On Bond-Street Behaviour. This Granted, There Is A Good Deal To Admire In Thle Exhibition. As Is Generally Known The Civil Service Includes Officials At Some Of The National Museums And Galleries, And One Or Two Of Them Exhibit Here. Mr. Mrartin Hiardie, For Instance, Whose - The Road To Croyland, A View Once Seen Never Forgotten, Lends Distinction To The Water-Colours. One Has The Feeling That Where Sober Virtues Are The Rule They Are Best Carried To Excess, And For That Reasoni A High Place Must Be Given To At Vid Greenwich Interior, Bv Mr. T. P. Clark, A Drawing In -Which The Pre-Raphaelite Treatment Of A Collection Of Junk Is Given Coherence By The Relative Positions Of The Skyliglht In The Shadowed Ceiling And The Door In Dark Silhouette Against Its Lighted Opening. From A Technical Point Of View The Most Accomplished Of The Water-Colourists Is Captain Guy Dol6Man, Whose Marine Studies, Suchl As After The Storm -One Of Two Pictures To Be Offered As Prizes For The Best Coulple In Fancy Dress At The Coming Civil Service Arts Ball-Are Models Of Broad And Fluent Execution. Other Water-Colours To Be Plraised For One Reason Or Another Arc Suburban Spring, By 3M1. Ernest Blaikley, Still Life, In The Japanese Manner, By 31R. J. Butcher, Farm Cart, Angmering-On-Sea, Bv 3Mr. J. R. Taylor, Flowers From The Hedge, By 11R. Charles Harvey, Spring Landscape, By Mr. E. M1. Jack, . The Mount Of Temptation, Jericho, By Sir Victor Wellesley, Blackcap Hill, Fieiar Luwes, By 3Mr. B. S. Long, And Winter Sunshine, By Mir. A. T. H. Stone. In Oil Painting The Honours Rest Between Mistra., Greece, A Rocky Landscape, By Sir Vtictor Wellesley, And The Idle Lamllp, A Careful Still Life, By 31R. Sauel H. Hancock, Though There Are Sev-Eral Other Cr Editable W Orks, Such As A Cotswold Fami, By Mr. William H. D. Hampton, August In Kensington Gardens, By Mr. A. E. Farmuer, Stiu Life, Japonica, By Mr. H. E. Mann, And Breamlll, By Mr. A. E. Wesley. There Is A Good Collection Of Etchings, Woodcuts, Linocuts, And Drawings-Anmong Wbich The Landscape Drawings By M1R. Ernest Blaikley Deserve Special Attention, And The Photographs Are At A Consistently High Jevel. Sculpture Is, At Any Rate, Neatly Handled By Miss Ethel Tewreley And Others, There Is Lively Invention In Applied Arts And Crafts, And Mr. John Bew And Mr. Rowland Koster Show Excellent Pottery.

Author: Null
Title: Christmas Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Christmas Art Exhibitions Attractive Displays Great Regret Will Be Felt At The Announcement On The Invitation Card That The Present Exhibition At The Little Gallery, 3, Ellis Street, Sloane Street, Is A Closing Sale Because The Little Gallery Has Become Familiar As A Convenient Centre For Some Of The Best Contemporary Handicrafts Weaving, Hand-Block Printed Textiles, Pottery, Glass, Jewelry, And So Forth. It Is To Be Hoped That The Closing Of This Gallery, Which Neverl Stocked Rubbish, Will Be Only Temporary. The Present Christmas Show Covers A Wide Range, Including Wall Papers By Mr. Edward Bawden, Pottery By Mr. Leach, Mr. Cardew. Miss Braden. And Mr. Liamada Tableware And Ivory Backed Brushes And Mirrors By Miss Catherine Cockerell English And Swedish Glass Finnish Wood Carving And Swedish Toys. The Names Given Above Will Suggest The Artistic Quality Of The Work. At Picture Hire, Limited. 56, Brook Street, There Is A Comprehensive Exhibition Of Cooured Reproductions In The Form Of Christmas Cards And Calendars. It Includes Some Unusual Designs, The Most Welcome, Perhaps, Being Reproductions Of Early Russian Miniatures From Sacred Books. Other Novelties In The Way Of Christmas Cards Are Eighteenth And Nincteenthcentury Persian Costumes, Englis-H Sporting Prints, Early American Views, And Spanish Old Masters. There Is A Wide Choice Of Contemporary English And French Paintings In Colour Reproduction. At Walkers Galleries, 118, Newv Bond Street, There Is A Very Attractive Display Of Jewelry By Miss Dorrie Nossiter. Wlho Follows The Good Rule Of Disregar-Dinig The Intrinsic Value Of Her Stones In Favour Of Their Values In Colour And Lustre. She Inclines To Close Setting, With Encrusted Elfects. And Each Piece Is A Littlc Study In Colour Gradation.

Author: Null
Title: The Art Treasures Exhibition
Full_text: Tee Art Treasures Exhibition. The Admissions On Wednesday Were -By Season Tickets, 1,961 On Payment, 7,8141 Total, 9,775. Of These 3,779 Arrived By Railway, Including 430 Students From The Halifax Working Mens College, 20 Teachers From The Haley-Hill Sunday School, And 60 Teachers From The Copley Sunday School, Near Halifax. The Entire Cost Of The Traiu From Haifax And Of A Dinner For The Teachers And Students, Which Was Given In Mr. Donalds Coffee Saloon, Was Defrayed By Mr. Akroyd, Xp., The Liberal Supporter Of The Halifax College. The President Of The College And The Committoe Of Management Were Also Present. Yesterday There Was A Good Attendance At The Exhibition, And In The Evening The Members Of The Institation Of Mecnanicalengine3Rs Dined At The Art Treasures Palace, In A Saloon Fitted Up For Their Accommodation By Mr. Donald. The Programme Of Ceremonial On Her Majestys Vsit Has Been Issued. The Royal Visitors And Suite Leave Woraley In Six Carraes-L, Containing The Tutors Of Prince Alfred Hpps And Two Equerries 3, The Marquis Of Bteadalbane, Sir G. Grey, And Baron Moltke 4, The Marchioness Of Ely And Miss Ldyard 5, Prince Of Wales, Prince Alfred, Princess Alice, And The Duchess Of Sutherland-. 6, The Queen, Prince Albert, The Prince Of Prussia, And The Princess Royal. The Coltjg Wil Be Escorted By The Lancashire Yeomanry, And Preceded By The Carriages Of The Earl Of Ellesmere, The Earl Of Burlington, And Mr. Charles Townley, The High Sheriff. On The Road They Will Be Joined By The 4Th Dragoons. At The Palace The Proceedings Will Be Very Brief. The Committee Will Present An Address, And Another Will Be Presented By The Corporation Of Manchester. After Her Mjestys Replies, The Coronation Anthem Will Be Eung While The Royal Party Go Through The Picture Galleries. Hier Miajesty Then Returns To Wole.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Modern Society Of Portrait Painters. - J . We Could Gladly Dispense With Half The Picture Exhibitions Now Open In The West-End Of London But The Modem Society Of Portrait Painters Is Not Among Those That Would Go. It Has Youth And Vitality And Abundance Of Talent. Moreover, It Is Not Only Progressive In Tendency, But, What Is Much More To The Point, Many Of Its Individual Members Are Making Progress. Among The 47 Portraits Many Of Them Full-Lengthsin The First Room Of The Royal Institute Galleries, And Among The 38 In The Second, There Are Several Failures, Several Freaks, And Several Clever Uglinesses But There Are A Dozen Original Works Which Prove That The Young English School Of Portrait Painting Is Very Much Alive. The Success Of The Year Is The Work Of Mr. Glyn Philpot, Who Passes In It From Promise To Performance Of A Remarkable Kind. His Manuelito, The Circus Boy, A Full-Length Of A Handsome Lad In Gay Spanish Costume, Is Quite The Most Striking Modern Picture Now Exhibiting In London, And Is Quite Worthy Of The Attention Of The Chantrey Trustees. Of Course, Every Young Painter Is Influenced By Somebody, And Mr. Philpot Has Been Influenced By Manet But This Picture Is As Strong As A Manet, And Far More Agreeable. There Is Much Ability Also In The Same Painters The Stage Box, Though Here The Two Figures Are Of A Decadent Type, And The General Effect Is Not Pleasing. Mr. Gerald Kelly, Another Painter Who Has Been Making Way, Must Look To His Colour Schemes And Backgrounds, Which This Year Are A Little Muddy. Much More Successful Is The Apache, By Mr. Oswald Birley, A Portrait In Character Of That Clever Actfress Miss Beatrice Collier. It Is Said That This Picture Was Rejected From The Academy Which Only Proves Once More That A Salon Des Refuses Would Often Contain Some Of The Best Things Of The Year. Mr. Louis Ginnetts Miss Eva Russell6 Young Girl With A Fishing Rod Mr. Ronaldsons Charming Portrait Of The Daughter Of Mr. R. H. Benson Mr. Crealocks Mrs. Aird And The Portraits Of Ladies By Mr. Lindhd And Mr. Sholto Douglas Are Excellent In Their Way And Mark An Advance On The Part Of Each Of The Artists. But The Vast Salomfi Of Mr. Ranken, Clever As It Is. Gives Little Pleasure. It Is Called S Portrait Of The Princesse X. A Strange Princess, To Wish Herself Painted In This Character, End On This Scale! In The Second Room The Portraits Of Ladies By Mr. Mark Mflbanke And Mr. Guy Wilthew, End Mr. Studds Whistlerian Two Children Ere Noteworthy, Es Are The Rather Extravagant Tours De Force Of Mr. Cadell But The Chief Picture In The Room Is His Majesty The King, By Mr. G. W. Lambert. This, Representing The King In Uniform, Standing By His Horse, Is The Largest And Most Ambitious Performance As Yet Attempted By This Very Clever Artist But He Has Kept The Tone Of The Face So Low That The Picture Cannot Be Called A Complete Success. The Drawings By Mr. Lambert, Mr. Ronald Gray, And Others, In The Next Room, Terminate In An Interesting Way An Exhibition Which Illustrates Very Fully The Tendencies Of The Time In Portraiture. The Ridley Art Club. . The 24Th. Exhibition Of This Club Is Being During This Week At The Grafton Gallery. We Held Fear That It Will Not Draw The Crowds Who Flocked To The Loan Collection, But It Is Large And Comprehensive, And Contains Among Its 263 Numbers A Fair Allowance Of Presentable Works, Not All Of Them New. Mr. And Mrs. Bedford, Miss Atkinson, Miss Beatrice Bland, Mr. E. H. Macandrew, Miss Emma Belloc, Mr. Dacres-Adams, And Mr. Richard Jack Are Among Tho Painters Whose Work Is Good And Often Impressive. But, Except For The Satisfaction Of The Members And Their Friends, It Is Not Easy To Discover Raison Tlre-Tar The Exhibition. There Are Too Many Such Already. ... ? Mr. William Shackleton. . It Is Otherwise With Tho Show Of Mt. Shackletons Pictures And Drawings At The Goupil Gallery. Here Is An Artist Of Very High Accomplishment, And, If The Phrase Be Allowed, Of Marked, But Partly Borrowed, Individuality. That Is To Say, Mr. Shackleton Has So Steeped Himself In Turner That He Often Allows His Own Originality To Be Obscured By That Of The Greater Man Though There Are Times When, Partly By Choice Of Subject And Partly By The Treatment, He Appears In An. Independent Light. There Is, For Instance, Nothing Of Turner In The Pencil Studies, And Very Little In The Sketches Of Figures Such As The Little Gleaner, Or In Certain Pictures Where The Figure Is The Dominating Element, Such As Children On The Sea-Shore, Painted Ten Years Ago. Indeed, If One Were To Be Content With The Interesting Preface To The Catalogue Written By The Artist, One Might Suppose That Turner Counted For Nothing He Is Never Mentioned, Mid Instead We Have The Outlines Of A Private Esthetic Philosophy, Vague, As Are The Words Of Nearly All Painters When They Try To Account For The Faith That Is In Them, But Quite Sincerely Felt, Mr. Shackleton Insists That Life Is What Interests Him But His Pictures Tell Us That It Is A Lose Transfigured By Blaring Sunlight, A Glowing Atmosphere, And Colours Scarcely Of This World. Often His Figures Are Of Little Account It Is The Landscape And The Atmosphere That Tell. But Turner, Too, Imagined That In His Radiant Visions Ho Was Philosophizing Upon Life. The Interpretation Never Counted For Much, But The Pictures Remain, A Joy For Ever. So We Will Not Follow Mr. Shackleton Into His Commentaries Upon His Phryne At Eleusis And Other Pictures But Enjoy Them, And Commend Them, As Really Brilliant Exercises Ot Imagination And Also Of Technique. Some Of The Water-Colour Sketches Are Lovely.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Mr. Moores Drawings For Sculpture There Can Be No Question That Mr. Henry Moore Has A Highly Developed Sense Of Form In The Abstract, And The Present Exhibition Of 31 Drawings For Sculpture By Him At The Mayor Gallery, 19, Cork Street, Is Well Worth Study From The Point Of View Of Formal Research. As A Rule Mr. Moore Gives Most Satisfaction At Extremes When He Conducts His Researches Fairly Close To Life, Or When He Carries Them Towards The Condition Of Architecture But In His Least Explicable Distortions His Forms Are Never Felt To Be Empty Of Life. His Use Of Colour To Reinforce Form Is So Apt That One Would Like To See Paintings By Him. Possibly The Most Interesting Works In This Exhibition Are The Sheets Of Studies Nos. 14, 15, 18, And 19. In Them His Preference For A Unit Of Form Which May Be Described As A Round Square Is Evident. It Is Similar To That Which Gives Masculine Energy To The Ornament On Ancient Chinese Bronzes, As Aiso To Chinese Calligraphy, And The Suggestion Of Depth By Tones Of Colour Is Admirable. Other Powerful Designs Are Drawing For Metal Sculpture 7 And Reclining Figures Red 28. There Is Much In The Work Of Mr. Mtloore That Seems To Fall Between The Two Arts Of Sculpture And Architecture, But Everything He Does Is So Full Of Meaning That One Is Well Content To Let Him Carry On.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Abt Eahtbttipns, M. Le Sidoner Is An Impressionist Of Peculiar Type, Ind His Technique Is All His Own. Seer From Close By, His Pictures Appear To Be Mere Collections Of Coarse, Square Brush-Marks, Thrown Together Anyhow But As One Recedes To The Proper Distance, All These Till Into Their Place, The Juxtaposed Colours Fuse Into Something Different From Any Of Them, Tone Is Relieved Against Tone, And The Total Offset Is The Beautiful Harmony Of Nature. It Is In The Squareness Of His Touch That The Artist Differs From Monet And The Rest In The Touch, And In The Daring Way In Which He Decomposes Colours Into Their Tiemerits. In The Little Exhibition Of Venice Intwilight And At Night, Winch Opens Tins Morning At The Goupil Gallery, There Are Many Examples Of This Latter Achievoxaent. Take For Example The Picture Called Vhorloge, Place Saint-Marc 4. From The Middle Of The Room The Wall Looks White, A Delightful Ivory White But As You Come Close You See That It Is Pink, Bine, Yellow. Again, Tire Posts In Le Grand Canal, Clair De Luns 1, Are, If One Smells The Picture In The Way That Sir Godfrey Kntiler Forbede, Blurred With The Buildings In The Background. Ten Feet Away, They Are As Sharply Defined As If A Pen Had Drawn Their Outlines. In His Management Of Colour, Indeed, M. Le Sidauer Is Highly Remarkable And It Would Not Be Too Much To Say That Hobodynowpainting Has A More Complete Mastery Of Delicate Twilight Effects. His Pictures Want Quiet Room And A Wall To Themselves. Garish Neighbours Ox Strong Sunlight Would Spoil Them. But Under Favonrabla Conditions The Best Of Them, Like This Clair De Lune, Are Lovely. Wo Should Add That The Exhibition Contains Only Seven Finished Pictures And A Few Studiestire Latter Not Very Remarkable, Forwithm. Le Sidaner Finish Is Everything. But It Is Finish In The Sense That The Modern Artists Give To The At The Modem Gallery, 61, New Bond-Street, There Is An Exhibition Of No Fewer Than 186 Water-Colour Drawings By Miss Edith Martineau, Ab.W.S, And Her Sister, Miss Gertrude Martineau. They Represent The Work Of Several Years, And In One Or Two Cases The Date Of A Drawing Goes Back To The Eighties. Varied As Is The Character Of The Exhibition, Comprising Figures, Landscapes, Gardens, And Special Studies Of Flowers, Its Title Rightly Indicates That The Highlands, And Especially Aviemore, Have Famished And Autumns Which They Spent There With Their Eminent Father, The Late Dr. Mhrtinean, Gave Him The Leisure To Write Philosophy And Them The Leisure To Practise, And The One Has Tried To Capture The Fleeting Effects Of Sunlight On The Moors And Of Tire Passage Of Tire Cloud-Shadowy Across The Mountains And The Other, With X Success To Which The Exhibitions Of Tire Royal Water Colour Society Have Often Borne Witness, Has Preferred The Wealth Of Flowers End Foliage Of A Scotch Garden In June Or Early, Autumn. Miss Edith Martincan Has A Real Talent For Flower Painting, Whether In Direct Studies Like The French Poppies 85 And Carnations 96, Or In Masses And Borders, Such As Those Shown In The Drawing Calledlavish June 32. Soma Of Her Figures, Especially Those Of Children 70, Are Also Very Accomplished Examples, Though Of A Careful And Minute Method Not Much Practised By The Painters Of The Day. Other Exhibitions Of Drawings Xhs Given By Mx. Frank Wasley Mendosa Gallery, Bond-Street, Mr. Dacres Adams Patersons, 5, Old Bondstreet, And The Barones H. Von Cramm Graves, Pall-Mall. The Lastnamed Artist, Who Seems To Have Travelled Everywhere, Is Happy In Her Renderings Of Soft Grey Lakes. Mr. Wasley Is Too Emphatic Ho Shonld Remember That Imagination Is Effective Only When The Expression Of It Is Kept Under Restraint. Mr. Adams Is In Many Ways A Charming Artist, With A Gift For The Illustration Of Fairy-Tiles And A Word Should Bo Said In Praise Of His Sisters Bookbindings, Which Are Shown In The Same Room. The Carfax Gallery In Buiy-Street Is Showing Some Drawings By The Very Modern German Artist L. Von Hofman, And Some Interesting Bronzes By Mr. Charles Ricketts. Everything Here Looks As If It Has Strayed Out Of A Room At The International. Mr. Ricketts Has So Marked And So Comprehensive A Talent That One Is A Little Impatient With Him For Not Achieving A Masterpiece. Fn Statuettes Are Full Of Ah Kinds Of Promise But For The Finished Work, The Achievement, We Still Have To Wait.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Tri-National Paintg And Sculpture. 0 England, France, And America. In Pursuance Of One Of Its Objects, To Promote International Good Feeling, The Tri-National Art Exhibition At The Chenil Galleries, Initiated By Mrs. F. H. Harriman, Of New York, Does Not So Much Afford Opportunity For Broad Comparisons Between The Nations Concerned As Bring Selections Of The Contemporary Art Of England, France, And America Together In Friendly Association. .Selections Advisedly, Because, To Judge From The Native Works, It Cannot Pretend To Be Fully Representative. There Are, For Instance, New English Exhibitors, But The Special Flavour Of The New English Art Club Would Be Hard To Find. No Doubt This Is As It Should Be, For Anything Like Sectarianism Was To Be Avoided But If The French And American Selections Have Been Made On The Same Principle This Must Be Looked Upon As An Occasionfor Sampling Rather Than Estimating The Contemporary Art Of Those Countries. Perhaps Mr. Roger Frys Happy Phrase, Something Like A Cross-Section Of The Whole Pictorial Or Sculptural Art Of Each Country, Allowing Full Value To Something Like, Is A Fair Description, And It May Be Agreed That The Exhibition Is Lively And Stimulating Throughout. If There Is A General Conclusion To Be Drawn It Is That Contemporary Artistic Effort, With Its National Flavours, Is Much Less Theoretical Than Appeared To Be The Case About 15 Years Ago. The Designers Have Staked Out Their Claims, And Now They Are Cultivating Them, Witlh, If Anything, An Over-Consciousness Of The Nature Of The Soil. Paint, Formerly Neglected, Is Now Very Much In Evidence. Partry For This Reason, The Definitely Old-Fashioned Things In The Exhibition Are The Jig-Saw Exercises Like Le Ueridon. By Picasso. They Have Something Of The Sentimental Appeal Of Old Numbers Of The Illustrate7I London News. For Once In A Way Sculpture Has Received Proper Attention And A Suitable Place For Its Display. In This Company One, Mr. Frank Dobson, Makes A Very Powerful Impression As A Sculptor Who Really Can Keep Some Relation Between His Forms And Their Filling. Most Of Our Young Men Who Try To Simplify, And To Insist On Planes, Decline Into The Effect Of The Newly Peeled Potato. Mr. Dobson May Not Have The Technical Mastery Displayed In Mr. Jacob Epsteins Head Of Fedora Rozelli, But He Promises To Have A Larger Grasp Of Composing In Sculptural Forms. His Cambria Is Probably The Most Dignified Monument Madle In This Country Since The Beginning Of The Century. The American Exhibits Are Graceful Torso Of Seated Woman, By The Late Mr. Paul Wayland Bartlett, And Victory, By Miss Janet Scudder, Being Typical Examples But, Except For The Animals By Mr. Herbert Heseltine, They Run To Line Rather Than Mass In Their Effect. Maillol Is Represented By A Torso Which Shows Wlhat A, So To Speak, Academic Subject May Becoma In The Hands Of A Real Sculptor There Are Some Charming Animals By Jeanne Poupelet And Three Very Interesting Exercises In Abstraction, Determined By The Materials Employed, By Brancusi. Sorcerer Is Really A Fulfilment In Sculpture Of The Natural Tendency Of A Branching Tree The Fish Is A Highly Polished Oval Of Brass And Torso Is An Ovoid Of Marble. Judged By Their Titles These Works May Not Be Intelligible, But They Have The Great Merit Of Giving Characteristic Form To Substance. It Cannot Be Said That The American Paintings Speak With A Very Certain Voice, And Perhaps The Most National Are The Elegant Figure Compositions, Such As The Galaxy, By Mr. Arthur B. Davies. Girl In Ihinese Costume, By Mir. William Glackens, Obviously Derives From Renoir, And Femnme Avec La Lime, By Paul Burlin, From Derain. Angelina Asleep, By Mr. Maurice Sterne, And Still Life, By Mr. Charles Sheeler, Are Other American Pictures Which Whet The Appetite For More. Of The French Pictures The Most Emphatic Is The Big Nude By Derain, A Splendidly Plastic Study Of Body And Limbs Declining Into Prettiness In The Head. This Work, With Its Discrepancy, Might Well Be Commended To The Hon. John Collier As An Instance Of What Happens When An Artist Allows His Formal Conception To Be Disturbed By The Attractions Of The Model. There Is A Mixture Of Two Kinds Of Beauty. Taking Into Account The Special Object Of This Exhibition, We May Be Content To Bless Its Friendliness And To Name A Few Works By English Artists Which Gave Particular Pleasure In A Round Of The Galleries Sucil As Tthe Slum Park, By Mr. W. P. Roberts Route Nationale, No. I, By Mr. Roger Fry Young London, By Mr. A. R. Thomson The Ardent Shore, By Mr. Nwalter Bayes Lilac, By Mr. F. J. Porter And Figures, By Mr. Dtucan Grant. Some Still Life Paintings By M1R. Augustus John Are A Special Feature. Air. E. Barnard Lintott. At The Same Galleries There Is An Exhibition Of 49 Landscapes In Water-Colour By Mr. E. Barnard Lintott. They Cover A Wide Range Of Country And Effect, And Are Uniformly Good In Feeling And Style, Reaching Their Best When The Conditions Put A Premium Upon Slightness And Directness-As In Rottingdean, The Path To The Old 31Ill, Cagnes, The Red Roof. Cagnes, And Knocke, Belgium. When It Is A Case Of Composing In Masses, Mr. Lintott Is Not So Successful, Though His Desires In This Direction Are Quite Easy To Understand. What He Seems To Need Is A Bolder Grasp Of The Larger Forms-Such As Mountains. The Mayor Gallery. If Only For His Courageous Belief In His Own Generation, Mr. P. Hoyland Mayor Deserves All Good Wishes In His New, Welllighted Gallery At 37, Sackville-Street, Which He Opens With An Exhibition Of Modern English Art. Almost Everything In It May Be Said To Be At The Apparent Growinig Point Of Contemporary Effort. Apparent Because, For Anything We Know, The Leading Shoot May Take Quite Another Direction, And These Buds May Date A Mnere Decade Or Two. Somebody May Discover That, When You Have Said All That There Is To Be Said About Relations In Form And Colour, The Root Of The Matter In Painting Is Relations In P,Aint. However. Grantinig The Aim Of Creating Relations In Form And Colour Which Shall Parallel The Infinite, Most Of These Works Fulfil It Engagingly, And Some Of Them Include The Substance Of Paint In The Scheme. Mr. Paul Nash, For Instance, Is At An Interesting Turn Beginning To Allow Paint To Play A Part In Determining The Relations He Would Establish. That He Should Be A Little Untidy In The Transition From A More Arbitrary Method Is Natural Enough. He Is In The Position Of A Man Who, Having Laid Down A Line Of Conduct, Suddenly Discovers That He Has A Body- Mr Lewisham, In Fact. Mr. Duncan Grant Has Got Over The Transition, And In Market Day, Form, Colour And Sub- Stance, Or Spirit, Soul And Body, As They Might Be Called, Sing Together. Miss Vanessa Bell, Mr. William Roberts, Mr. F. J. Porter, Miss Winifred Nicholson, And Mr. Elliott Seabrooke All Help In The Entertainment, And A Word Must Be Given To The Reticent Little Carving Of Grief, By Mr. Hilary Stratton. Mr. James Mcbeys Etchings. As An Etcher Mr. James Mcbey May Be Said To Have Romped Into The Favour Of Collectors, And The Present Exhibition Of 68 Proofs By Him, And A Few Water-Colours, At The Galleries Of The Fine Art Society, 148, New Bond-Street, Helps To Explain The Reason Why. He Is, First Of All, Immensely Full Of Spirits, And He Has An Easy Command Of Space, Atmosphere, And Movement. A Static Subject, In Which Solidity Is The Requirement, Betrays His Limitations. Perhaps There Is No Living Etcher Who Corresponds More Exactly To What One Feels To Be The Meaning Of Painter Etcher, But Though It Is Tonal Rather Than Linear Relations Which Excite Him, He Uses Line With Exemplary Purity. A Good Example Is Zaanstreek, In Which, Though The Relation Between The Near Boat And The Distant Mills Is Thc Motive, The Work Is Carried Out In A Simple Hatching Of Upright Lines. But It Is In The. More -Impulsive Subjects, Such As Sanuall At Kampen. Antwerp, With A Boat Turning, And Gale At Port Errol, That Mr. Mcbeys Personal Qualities Are Most Apparent. A Number Of His Palestine Subjects, Done In The War, Are In The Exhibition, Including The Never-To-Be-Forgotten Surrender Of Jerusalem To Two Dispassionate Tommies. Downstairs There Is A Large Collection Of Etchings By Various Artists, Including Rembrandt And Zorn. Most Of The Proofs Are Familiar, But There Is An Undescribed Cameron, A River In Flood, And Note May Be Made Of Head Of A Model, Bv That Accomplished Young Etcher Mr. E. Bouverie Hoyton. Landscapes And Flowers. Being Under The Same Roof, At 22, Old Bondstreet, The Gieves And Arlington Gatlleries May Be Treated As One. At The Former There Are Landscapes In Water-Colours, By Mr. Rupert Butler, Who Presents The Somewhat Unusual Character Of Being A Better Composer Than Executant. His Draving Is Weak And His Values Are Incoherent-See Nos. 14 And 15-But He Has A Good Notion Of Bow To Make A Picture Nnd Sonie Command Of Space As A Subject For Moulding. His Skies, For Example, Though Tending To Be Over-Dramatic, Do Give You Succeysive Depths Of Light, As In On Exmoor Ald On The Wiltshire Avon. On The Whole, However, One Would Be Inclined To Pick Out The Careful Studies Of Wiltshire Cottage And A Sussex Bani As His Best Efforts. Mliss Juliet Williams, On The Floor Above, Xvins Approval By Her Sympathetic Understanding Of What May Be Called The Psychology Of Flowers-That Is To Say. The Kind Of Temperamenit Tlhat. No Doubt Fallaciously, We Attribute To Theni. The Drawing, As Betrayed In Pots, Is Far From Sure, But Her Colour Is Pleasing, Anid She Has An Unfailing Instinct For The Right Kindl Of Arrangement For The Particular Bloom. The Best Of Her Studies Are On Grey Or Brown-Tinted Paper, Thus Avoiding The Complication Of Heavy Tones, And She Has Had The Good Sense To Make Manv Very Small Studies. Christmas Blooms Suffolk Blossoms, And Paigles Are Three Good Examples. Four Decorative Panels, In The Dutch Manner, In Oils, Are By No Means Unsuccessful.

Author: FROM OUR MUSEUMS CORRESPONDENT
Title: Exhibition Of Church Art
Full_text: Exhibmion Of Church Art I A Long-Continuling Tradiimon From Our Museums Correspondent Chelmsford, May 2 A Programne Of Events Arranged By The Friends Of Essex Churches Began To-Day In The Chapter House Of Chelmsford Cathedral, When Mr. Basil Spence, The Architect Of The New Coventry Cathedral, Opened An Exhibition Of Essex Church Art, Which Is To Continue Until The Evening Of May 13. In His Opening Speech Mr. Spence Said That In England Tbere Was A Long-Continuing Tradition In Church Arts And Crafts. This Must Be Maintained And Means Found To Keep Thz Craftsmen Employed In It. Art Could Rise To Its Greatest Heights As It Had At Times In The Past When The Church Was Its Patron. The Idea Of A Continuing Tradition Is Reflected In The Exhibition, Which Contairs A Section Of Modern Work. Tne Older Exhibits Are Most Fully Represented, And They Include Objects Of Art Or Craft Belonging To Essex Churches And A Smaller Number Of Works Of Religious Art From Private Collections In The County. Among These Last Is A Beautiful Softly Coloured Chelsea China Group Of 1750, Representing The Dead Christ In The Virgins Arms. A Design Derived From Michael Angelos Statue In St. Peters, Rome. It Has Been Lent By Mr. J. J. Tufnell, And Is The Only Known Coloured Example Of This Chelsea Group. Maplewood Maze-R The Most Numerous Class Of Exhibit Is The Church Plate, The Earliest Piece Being A Mnaplewood Mazer Of About 1480-90, With Silver-Gilt Band And Central Medallion, From Holy Trinity, Colchester. Essex Is Not Rich In Pre-Reformation Silver, Since It Lay Too Close To London To Escape The Attention Of Henry Viiis Commissioners. By Compensation, The County Is Rich In Elizabethan Church Plate, Most Of The Dated Pieces Being Of London Make, Though Some Of The Undated Ones Are Thought Possibly To Have Been Made Near Colchester. Of Mid-Seventeenth-Century Work Especially Attractive And Simply Designed Examples Are The Silver Flagon, Cup, And Paten Of 1634 From Messing And The Silver Cup, Paten, And Alms Dish Of 1641 From Netteswell, Which Are Remarkable As Examples Of Entirely Unornamented Puritan Design. Other Things Shown Are Furniture, Hangings, Vestments, Books, Pictures, And Drawings. Perhaps The Most Important Single Object Is The Great Thirteenth-Century Altar Chest From Newport With Five Oil Paintings, The Central One A Crucifixion, Inside The Lid. These Are Remarkably Early Examples Of Their Kind In England. A Crucifix By Benvenuto Cellini Has Been Lent By Mr. W. A. Foyle. Other Events This Week Are A Lecture By Mr. John Betjeman On Friday At Chelmsford And On Saturday And The Afternoon Of Sunday An Exhibition Of The Courtauld Family Siver, Arranged By Mr. Augustine Courtauld, At Spencers, Great Yeldham, Near Halstead.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions A Czechs Paintings In Addition To The Picture Exhibitions Noticed In Tlhe Times During The Last Week Or Two, A Number Of Others Are Now Open In London. At The Redfern Gallery, 20, Cork Street, There Arc Paintings By The Czechoslovak Artist, Mr. Geza Szobel, Whose Grim Drawings Of The War Have Already Been Seen. His Work In Oils Is Very Different. He Uses Chiefly Depp, Translucent, Glowing Blues, Greens, And Reds, Merging Often One Into Another, In The Depths Of Which Loom Fantastic, Partly Cubist Shapes. There Is No Question Of Mr. Szobels Ability, And Purely As Shapes Floating In Colour His Pictures Are Attractive To The Eye. What The .Ritic Feels Less Certain About Is The Intellectual Content. In Some Degree The Same Criticism Applies To Mr. David Bonibergs Exhibition, Consisting Largely Of Oil Studies Upon Paper, At The Leger Gallery, 13, Old Bond Street. Mr. Bomberg Calls These Pictures Imaginative Compositions, Though They Seem To Start, More Often Than In Mr. Szobels Case, With Something Actually Seen. Occasionally, As In Fishing Folk, That Something Is Pretty Clearly Defined But More Usually It Has Become Fused Into A Pattern Of Rather Quiet, Agreeable Colour-Browns And Greys And Purplish Redsso That Only A Hint Of It Remains. At Its Most Successful Say, Numbers 18 And 30 This Method Gives An Effect Which Can Perhaps Be Compared To Pot-Pourri To Which Somehow A Rhythm Has Been Given. But Again The Question Is-How Long Will The Mind Remain Satisfied ? French Pictures French Paintings Of The Present Century Are On View At The Lefevre Galleries, 1A, King Street, St. Jamess. They Include An Interesting Bonnard Of A Rainy Night In Paris, With The Lights Shining Through The Windows Into The Dusk, And A Pretty Little Vuillard Of A Woman Seated On A Sofa. Rouault Is Represented By A Good Small Head Of A Psnan, And By A Large Feinme Du Cirque And There Are Examples Of Modigliani, Utrillo, Picasso, And Others. A Word, Too, Must Be Said Of Mr. Thomas Carrws Water-Colours, Which Are On View At The Leicester Galleries, Leicester Square, Concurrently With The Portrait Exhibition Which Has Already Been Noticed. Mr. Carr Seems To Have Qualities Which May Well Make Him Art Extremely Popular Painter, For. He Has The Gift Of Prettiness Without Banality Or Vulgarity. On The Whole The Added Body Of Oil-Paint Suits Him Better Than Water-Colour, But There Are Some Charming Drawings In This Collection. Good Examples Are The Iron Bridge And Edenderry Locb, Which Are Tvpical Of His Pale, Rather Misty, Use Of Colour, And His Broad Grouping Ot Shapes, In This Medium. With Mr. Frank Galsworthys Highly Finished And Elaborate Water-Colours Of Flowers And Of Groups Of Porcelain Figures And Other Ornaments, Now At The Walker Galleries, 118, New Bond Street, The Visitor Moves Into Such A Different World That Scarcely A Point Of Contact Remains. The Flower Paintings Are Sometimes A Trifle Hard, But Mr. Galsworthy Has Considerable Skill Of Hand And Has Clearly Laboured Long Over These Pictures. Certainly Such A Thing As The Pedlar Doll And Friends, With -A Water-Colour Tecognizably By William Payne Hanging On The Wall Behind A Table Covered Wvjth Various Ornaments And Knick-Knacks, Is Sorething Of A Tour-De-Force.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Mr. R. 0. Dunlop Nvorking Chiefly-If Not Exclusivelywith The Palette Knife, Mr R. 0. Dunlop, Whose Recent Paintings Are Now On View At The Redfern Gallery, 27, Old Bond Street, Is Distinguished By Two Things In Particular The Soundness Of His Colourmostly In The Range Of Earth Pigments -And The Close Relation In His Work Between Form And Expression. His Pictures Give The Impression, No Doubt Erroneous, Of Having Been Designed In The Course Of Execution. The Danger That Lurks In This Close Relationship, With Its Reliance On The Expressive Capacitv Of Pigment, Might Be Compared To That Of An Emotional Speaker Who Trusts To The Tones Of Hisvoice Rather Than To The Arrangement Of His Words. Mr. Dunlops Paintings, Particularly His Figure Compositions, Are A Little Deficient On The Architectural Side. It Is True That The Architectural Aspect Of Painting Can Easily Be Ridden To Death As A Hobby, But It Is A Good Thing To Keep At The Back Of The Mind, And Mr. Dunlops Work Will Gain In Power With More Rigorous Mental Planning, Which Need Not Be At The Cost Of Direct Expression. Almost As A Consequence Of His Methiod, Except In The Case Of The Half-Length Of A Young Girl, In An Appropriate Scheme Of Green And Subdued Gold, Preference In This Exhibition Nearly Always Goes To The Landscapes To Such Pictures As Notre Dame, Paris, Street, St. Troper, Provenpal Farm, The Harbour, St. Troper, And Mistral Over St. Troper. It Is Not That Landscape Really Needs Less Construction Than The Figure, But That Construction In It Is-Owing To The Atmospheric Conditionsmore Dependent Upon The Right Placing Of Colour Values And Less Upon The Mental Grasp Of The Forms And In The Placing Of Colour Values Mr. Dunlop Is Seldom At Fault. Titles Do Nor Count For Very Much, But It Might Be Said That The Picture Called Contemplation, With Ail Its Merits, Thirows Light On Mr. Dunlops Present Weakness. It Is Too Much A Study Of Contemplation And Not Enough A Study Of A Young Woman Resting Her Arm On A Chair. But -With These Reservations About His Treatment Of The Figure, In The Landscapes Named And In Flowerpiece, Mr. Dunlop Is A Very Satisfying Artist. Mr. Reginald Hallward Among The Works By Mr. Reginald Hallward At The Arlington Gallery, 22, Old Bond Street, There Are A Good Many Designs For Stained Glass, And He Has Given A Personal Turn To That Medium, But To Speak Of Him As A Decorative Designer Would Be To Ignore Both The Poetical Sentiment And The Technical Virtuosity Which Distinguish His Paintings. He Is An Other-World Artist, Starting, No Doubt, From Some Actual Plan, But Relating It To A Consistent Landscape Of His Own Imagination. It Is A Landscape Of Rocky Terraces And Very Tall Trees, With An Atmosphere In Which Anything Might Happen. Mr. Hallward Is An Artist To Be Pored Over Rather Than To Be Taken In At A Glance, And This Must Limit The Circle Of His Appreciators At The Present Day. Miss Ruth Doggett In Her Exhibition Of Landscapes, With The Title August In England, At The Fine Art Societys Galleries, 148, New Bond Street, Miss Ruth Doggett Has Achieved An Admirable And Intelligent Balance Between Pure Impressionism, Which Follows All The Vagaries Of The Light And The Landscape, And A Method Of Sound, At Times Even Systematic, Construction. It Is A Difficult Balance, And It Is Hardly To Be Wondered At If In A Few Pictures Her Colour Suffers In The Process And In A Few Others Her Method Of Simplification Is Rather Harsh. But For The Most Part She Is Remarkably Successful She Knows When To Stop And Certainly Does Not Risk Spoiling Her Pictures For The Sake Of Any Subtlety Beyond Her Powers, But She Manages Her Talents Competently, Economically, And With Assurance.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Two One-Man Shows. An Exhibition Of Paintings, Drawings, And Etchings By M. Andre Dunoyer De Segonzac Will Be Opened To-Morrow At The Independent Gallery, 7A, Grafton-Street, W. Some Of This Artists Work Has Been Seen Here Before, But This Is, We Believe, The First One-Man Show That He Has Had In London. The Obvious Thing About His Landscapes Is A Massive And Noble Simplicity. Fields, Roads, Hills, And Trees Stand Together In A Grand And Plain Design. It Is Not At Once That One Sees How This Dignified Simplicity Of Mass And Contour Is Very Delicately Adjusted By Transitions From Plane To Plane. His More Complex Designs, Such As Nos. 4 And 7, Do Not Express Themselves So Beautifully As Simpler Things Like Nos. 1, 3, And 5 And It Is In Looking At The More Complex Paintings That One Understands Best M. De Segonzacs Practice Of Leading Up To These Final Works By Study After Study Of Details And Portions. The Drawing No. 19, Is A Late Study For The Picture No. 13. Each Has Points That Makc It Preferable To The Other And The Difference Rouses A Desire To See The Studies For The Superb Painting No. 16, Les Deux Ormes. The Fine Austerity Of The Paintings Is Matched By The Dignity And Direct Force Of The Drawings. And Then In Some Of The Etchings, Like Nos. 31 And 33, We Come Upon A Delicate Tenderness Of Touch And Mood Which Help To The Understanding Of What Lies Below The Power And Sweep Of The Paintings. M. De Segonzac Has Greatness In Him. Prof. H. B. Wieland. Snow, We All Know, Is White. Professor R. B. Wieland, A Swiss Artist, Is Concerned, At The Gieves Gallery, 22, Old Bond-Street, To Show, In Oils And Watercolour, That It Has All The Colours Of The Opal And The Rainbow. To Look At His Lovely Little Hoar Frost 4 Is To ., First, The Boughs Of Trees Weighed Down With Snow And. Rime, And Snow All Over The Ground. White, Of Course. The Next Glance Shows That It Is Mainly Blue. Hard By Hangs No. 5, The Village Of Fetan, Where The Snow Is All Opalescent. And So We Go On, Learning What Sunlight And Moonlight And Shadow Can Do With What We Call White. Professor Wieland Gets A Little Muddled Sometimes With Anything Like A Complex Design. Where His Design Is Simple, His Pictures Are Strong And Rich, And There Is A Fine Security Of Handling In His Two Portraits Of Guides. Hns Exhibition Will Fascinate Alpine Climbers But It Is Not For Alpine Climbers Only.

Author: Null
Title: Exhibition Of Belgian Art Of The 17th
Full_text: Exhibition Of Belgian Art Of The 17Th Century.This Exhibition, Organized By The Belgian Government, Has Just Been Opened In Brussels. It Comprises Over 600 Flemish Paintings, Including Works By Rubens, Van Dyck, Jordaens, Fyt, Snyders, And Teniers,And Over 200 Drawings, As Well As Examples Of Applied Art, Tapestries, Sculptures, Armour, Laces, C. The Exhibition Will Remain Open Until The End Of October. The Sailors Home.The Report Of The Sailors Home For The Year Ended April 30 States That During The Year 4,163 Seamen Stayed At The Well-Street Institution, Or Its .Offshoot At Gravesend, While Ashore, And 7,265 Seafarers Who Were Passing Through London Or Working On Coasting Vessels Took Rooms For One Night. During The Year 543 Shipwrecked Mariners Were Received And Maintained At The Expense Of The Shipwrecked Fishermens And Mariners Society, Those In Need Being Supplied With A Seagoing Outfit Seagoing Employment Was Found For 1,624 Seamen And Firemen, And The Destitute Sailors Fond Gave Assistance To 751 Sailors.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitionats. The New English Art Club Is In Danger. T Is Becoming Fashionable. The Private View On Saturday Was Crowded And We All Know How Difficult It Is To Maintain The Purity Of Ones Principles In The Face Of Popular Favour. In Point Of Fact There Is In Tho Present Exhibition At The Dudley Gallery A Good Deal Less Eccentricity Thala Of Old, And Much Less Preference Of Ugliness For The Sake Of Ngliness Nay,Eight Or Ten Of The Chief Pictures Might Find Their Place In An Ordinary Exhibition And Not Be Thought Impossibly Advanced. From Any Point Of View Several Of The Pictures And Nearly All The Drawings Are Very Good And Interesting, Though The Club Has Not On This Occasion Shown The Work Of Some Of Its Best Men-Yir. C. W. Furse, For Instanceflnd Though It Appears To Have Lost Mr. Sargent. Perhaps The Exhibitors Who Make The Strongest Impression Are Mir. C. H. Shannon, Mr. Hel-Ry Tonks, Mr. Freed Brown, Mr. Bertram Priestman, And Minr. W. Y. Macgregor, All Of -Whom Have Been Pretty Constant Exhibitors Here, But Who Have This Year Taken A Stride Forwavrd. Mr. Macgregors Largelandscape, The Quarry 98, Is The Sort Of Work That Appeals To Artists Rather Than To The Ordinary Eye But Those Who Can Take Pleasure In A Low-T6Ned Picture, And Who Are Not Repelled By The Rough-Ness Affected By This Whole School, Wiil Find Much To Admire In This Dignified Composition, Recalling, As It Does, Much Of The Wvork Of Professor Legros. Mr. Tonks Is Varied Alike In Subject Aucd In Method. We Are Not Sure Whether Tho Best Of All His Works Is Not Tho Delicate Draving Called The Barn 17, A Perfect Example Of Its Kind But His Most Ambitious Effort Is The Painting Called The Shadow Of The Cliff 106. This Charming Picture Of An English Watering Place Is At Once Gay And Harmonious In Colour, But It Is Nou Easy To See How One Is To Focus The Picture. Naturally One Dwells On The Figures In The Foreground, But These Are Relativelv Blurred Whereas The Houses On The Cliff-Top Are Clear And Distinct, As Though The Spectator Were Meant To Fix His Eye Upon Them And To Make Everything Else Secondary. Such An Inversion Of The Common Theory Of A Picture, Is, Even In These Days Of Experiments, A Little Surprising. Mslr. F. Brown, Professor At The Slade School, Is Among The Most Sincere Of The Eng,Lish Art,Ists V.Ho Incline To Impressionism If He Seeks After Broad Effects By Seemingly Simple Means It Is Not Because He Is Not The Master Of An Extremely Delicate Brush. Ris Striking Little Picture, A Coming Storm 75-Which We Believe Is A View Of Knaresborough-Is Really A Ve.-Y Fine Thig, And When Time Has Softened Its Slight Harshnesses Might Fairly Take Its Place By The Side Of A Landscape By Millet. Mir. Bertramu Priest,Man Has Stuldied Constable To Some Purpose In His Picture Of An Autumn Cloud 80 But, Like So Many Artists Who Paint For Exhibition, He Tends To Exaggerate. There Is An Excellent Aud Very Careful Woodland Landscape Called Through The Trees, By Mfr. Francis Bate 56 But Mir. Charles Conder, From Whom Much Has Been Expected, Is A Littre Disappointing In His Landscape In Alsace 53, While Mr. Buxton Kinight And Mr. Mark Fisher Have Not Seat Their Strongest Work. On The Other Hand, The Souvenir Of Vandyck 48, By Mtr. C. H. Shannon-The Interesting Draughtsman And Lithographer Who Has Already Made His Mark In Those Departments,And Appears Tq Be Capable Of Making It As A Painter-Is A Charming Study In Cool Tones Which Will Be Found By Many People The Most Attractive Picture In The Exhibition. We May I Add That Many Other Artists Whose Work One Is, Accustomed To See In This Room Are Characteristically Represented-Mr. H. B. Brabazon, For Example, Mr. Wilson Steer, Mr. Sickert, Mir. Arthur Tomson, And Fr. S. P. Mallet. There Are Many Smaller Exhibitions For Which The Briefest Possible Word Of Notice Must Suffice. At The Goupil Gallery The Managers Have Fallen Back Upon Jozef Israels, Who Is, Of Course, Always Well Worth Seeing, But Whese Work Is Probably Better Known In London Than That Of Any Other Living Painter, Certainly Any Foreign Painter. At 175, New Bond-Street, Mr. Herbert . Finn Shows Some Seventy Pictures And Drawings Of The Kentish Coast, Of Wales, Of Holland All Conscientous And Full Of Observation, And I Some Of Them Interesting Records Of Momentary Sfects Of Light. Mtiss Sosavvallis Shows A Few Unpretending But Attractive Drawfings Of Italy At Mr. Dunthornes Gallery In Vtigo-Street. Lastly, At The Dutch Gallery In Brook-Street, Is A Rather More Ambitious Exhibition-Some Fifty Works By Mxr. William Estall, An English Painter Who -Eems To See Nature With The Eyes Of The Modern Dutchmen Who Follow Israels And Mauve. There Is No Question About His Ability Or About The Charm Of His Work When He Is At His Best. As In The Beautiful Drawing Called Dawn-Yorkshire Moors 17 But The Whole Impression Made By This Collection Is An Impression Of Sunless Melancholy. Mr. Estall Does Justice Neither To His Own Talent Nor To The Beauty Of England.

Author: Young, Michael
Title: Galleries
Full_text: .I Lai Ff4Pmmmmwwam? L S L- S S - - I 0 Ciiiijemi The Judges View Of Triple Vision A Strange Sight Will Internittently Greet Visitors To The British Art Show In Birmingham From Friday Three Men Fixed Together Siamese-Style By Their Armis And Legs, Hopping And Jerking About The Courtyard, And From Time To Time Down New Street. It Is Not A New Form Of Breakdance Busking, But Serious Performance Art The Triptych Nan. Always Referred To Rather Pretentiously In The Third Person Singular, The Triptych Man Turns Out To Be A Suitable Symbol For The Show. Organized By The Arts Council, Its Aim - To Assess The Achievement, Of British Artists Over The Last Five Years - Is Ambitious. Its Methods - Tihree Selectors Sitting In Judgment Like A Three-Headed Deity Rewvarding Thc Good, Casting Out The Bad - Are Distinctly Questionable. T He Triptych Man And Triptych Judge Have Stuck All Six Of Their Necks Well And Truly Out. Jon Thompson, A Lecturer At Loldsmiths College, And One Of The Selectors, Sees His Function Ais Being To Spark Off Public Debate I Expect A Lot Of Flack, He Says. Unfortunately, He, Marjorie Alithorpe Guyton An Art Historian And Sandy Nioffat Painter And Art Tutor At The Glasgow School Of Art Seem To Haie Been Overwhelmed By The 1.000 V Isits To Artists Studios And The 18 Months Of Deliberation. For All The Editing Efforts Of Nicola Bennett, The Exhibition Organizer, A Read Through Their Catalogue Is As Illunuinating As A Trudge Through Treacle. In Conversation, Thompson Is More Succinct. The Whole Mniimalist Ethic Is Under Challenge. He Says, And Adds That The Arrival Of Abstract Work In This Country Was The Result Of An American Brain-Washing Programme After The Var More A Usurpation Titan A Fertilization. Only Now Nas Britain Shaking Off That Yoke. I Expect Letters Of Complaint Front Peolie Like Anthony Caro, Thompson Says.-In Fact Caro Has Less To Worry About Than Bridget Riley. Ic Has Been Selected. She Has Not. Gimpel Fils, 30 Davies Street, London Wl 493 2488. From Tues Until Nov 24, Mon-Fri 9.30Am5.3Opm, Sat 1Oam-Lpm. John Tunnard His Gouaches Were As Musical As Kandinskys, As -Delicate As Klees And As Gay As Miros. So Said Peggy Guggenheim In 1938 Of,The Painter Who Died In 1971 Aged 71. Sat I11Ar-S.30Pm, Sun 2-5.30Pm Definitive Exhibition For The Great Horse Paiiter, Although In Those Dayseveryone Know Their Place, Stubbs Has A Skilful Way Of Giving Aristocrats, Peasants And Creatures Equality Under The Sky. Modern Masters Royal Academy, Piccadilly, London.Wi 734 9052. Until Dec 19, Daily 10Am-Spmn More Than 1 Do Paintings. All The Isms Of The Twentieth Century Are Represented, Fromn Impressionism To Surrealism. Highlights Include. Gaugins Matua Mua And Five Harlequihpicturesrby Picasso. Work By The Chosen 82 Includes Painting, Sculpture, Performance Art And Video. First Come The Survivors Who Refused To Turn Abstract Vhen The Going Got Rough R. B. Kitaj, Francis Bacon And Lucien Freud. Then The Prodigal Sons Gilbert And George, And Stuart Brisley, Whio After Years Of Perforniing And Conceptualizing Are Now Back Making Images Gilbert And George In Huge Photographs Of Themselves, Brisley In A Sculpture Where Dozens Of Empty Gloves Dangle. New Themes Include A Journey Back To The Source In Neo-Cave Paintings From Jo Baer And Bruce Robbins, And A Journey Into The Future With Fantasy Subjects Inspired By Strr Wars And Other Futuristic Films. There Will Also Be A Massive Progranime Of Lectures, Seminirs And Workshops. Although Specific Schools Are Few, In The Last Five Years Sculpture Has Found A Focus In The Activities Of The Lisson Gallery, London. Ihe Exhibition Includes Work Bv Richard Wentsvorth And Bili Woodrow, Hut Not Hv ,Julian Opie Or David Nmlach. We Just Dont Think Theyre Very Good, Says The Allpowverful Jon T Hompson. Performance And Video Art Is Also Represented. As Is Often Tihe Case With Public-Funded Art, It Is Inclined To Hite The Hand That Feeds It, And To Run On Political Lines. The Judges Passed Sandra Goldbackers Video Dots And Moonbeams Which Uses Advertising Techniques To Discuss W Omens Issues, But Rejected Rose Garrard. The Dazzling Theatricality Of The Cibachrome Prints Seems To Add Nothing To Our Perception Or Understanding Of The People Portrayed In Dominica Or Elsewhere. Gruyaert Has An Intuitive Feel For Composition And Uses The Patterning Qualities Ot Colour In A Controlled Way, But I Find It Hard To Accept That The World Is As Saturated-With Colour As These Pictures Portray It. Also Yulla Lipchitz, Widow Of The Sculptor Jacques, Offers Some Curious Colour Views Of New York Which Are Decorative If Nothing Else. Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition Wood Engravings In Woodcuts And Some Words Lmr. Gordon Craig Gives The Right Reason At The Present Day For Cutting By Hand Designs That Mnight Be Drawn With The Pen. For The Explicit Reason That Wood Engraving, Being A Difficult Task, Lends The Hand Precision, Perhaps Some Style, Is A Tough Craft., And One To Grow Fond Of. . . . There Is Good Reason For An Imaginative Fellow Lhaving Some Tough Craft It Cools- His Ardour. It Is Very Unlikely That Any Of The Innumerable Contemporary Artists Who Are Wood Engraving Are Guided By This Reason, But That Does Not Matter They Have To Go Through With It. At A Time When The Tendency Is More And More To Shirk The Executive Side Of Things In Art Any Wood Engraving Is Better Than None. So Imany Contemporary English Artists Are Submitting Themselves To The Discipline Of Wood Engraving That They Have To Divide Themselves Into Two Societies-Tlie Society Of Wiood Engravers, Exhibiting At The Rediern Gallery, 27, Old Bond-Street And The English Wood Engraving Society, Exhibiting At The St. Georges Gallery, 32A, George-Street, Hanover-Square. Between The Two Societies There Does Not Appear To Be Any Distinction Of Aim Or Policy-Several Artists Belong To Bothbut It Does Happen That The Redfern Gallery Exhibition Runs More To The Illustrative And The St. Georges Gallery Exhibition More To The Constructive Kind Of Wood Engraving. There Is A Great Deal To Be Said For The Illustrative Kind Being Printed From A Design In Relief And With The Same Kind Of Ink The Wood Engraving Is Second Cousin To Typography, And Gains In Formal Respects From The Relationship, And Illustration Compels The Artist To Think About Sometlhing Wlhich Is Not Purely Artistic-Always An Advantage To His Purely Artistic Capacities But Since Constructors Are More Apt Than Illustrators To Shirk Manual Discipline, The Constructive Wood Engraving Is Perhaps The One To Be Most Encouraged At The Present Day On Grounds Of Artistic Hygiene. Both Kinds Of Wood Engraving, However, Must Be Judged By The Quality Of The Designs Produced In Them, And Here The Two Exhibitions Are Fairly Equal-With The Balance Slightly In Favour Of The One At The St. Georges Gallery. But There Are Some Very Good Things At The Redfern. Of All Contemporary Wood Engravers Mrs. Gwendolen Raverat Is Perhaps The One Who Owes Least To Fads And Fashions, And Her Set Of The Seasons Are A Delight. For Sheer Beauty Of Craftsmanship There Is Nobody To Equal Mir. Eric Gill. His Designs Here, Transiliens Colles, For A Good One, Are Not Ostensibly Illustrations, But The Discipline And Example Of Typography Are Always Implied In His Work. In The Matter Of Suggested Colour In Black And White The Finest Thing In The Exhibition Is The First Of The Decorations For Celeste No. 56, A Study Of Two Roses, By Ir. John Nash, Who Also Manages Better Than Most To Combine Construction With A Fairly Close Reference To Nature. As To The Proportion Of Black And White In A Wood Engraving Tastes Differ In His Book Mr. Gordon Craig Prints Two Amusingly Contradictory Notes On The Subject By John Ruskin And Odilon Redon But One Cannot Help Feeling That A Good Mnany Contemporary Artists Would Do Well To Cut More Wood Away. Miss Clare Leightons Forcible Designs For Wuthering Heights, For Instance, Are. Blacker Than The Emotions Of Even That Work Require. In Kensington Gardens, Figures Reclining On The Grass, By Mliss Althea Willoughby, Is An Excellent Design In A Rather Sophisticated Manner The Very Title Of Song Against Speed, By Miss Nora S. Unwin, Is Attractive And The Illustrations To The Scventh Man, By -Mr. Robert Gibbings, Coronilla, By Mr. Paul Nash, Elm Angel, By Mr. Eric Ravilious, Yellow Iris, By Mr. Eric Daglish, Uinicorn, By Mr. David Jones, A Corner Of The Forest, By Mr. Ethelbert White, Morning With Swiss Family Robinson, By Miss Pamela D. Nathan, And Holiday, By Air. E. Nicholson, Are All Prints Worth Looking Out. At The St. Georges Gallery, Where The Average Size Of Prints Is Larger And The Decorative Effect On The Wall More Pronounced, The Centre Of Interest Is In The Illustrations By Mr. Blair Hughes-Stgnton For Birds, Beasts, And Flowers, By The Late D. H. Lawrence. As Might Be Expected, Without The Text Their Illustrative-Or Symbolical-Meaning Is Not Very Clear, But They Are Extraordinarily Moving As Designs. Nobody Can Use The Direct Emotional Attack Of Black And White Better Than Imr. Blair Hughes-Stanton. Miss Gertrude Hermes Excels Him In The Handling Of Intermediate Tones, And Her Willows And Water-Lilies Is Possibly The Best Print In The Exhibition From A Technical Point Of View. For Some Reason, Perhaps Because The Medium Implies Occupation For The Hand, Abstract Designs Do Not Come Off Very Well In Wood Engraving, And The Examples By Mr. John Tandy-Though They Are Goodish Designs In Themselves-Are Among The Few Things In The Exhibition That Look As If They Had Been Better Produced By Some Other Means. Prints Of Special Interest, For One Reason Or Another, Are Landscape, By Ir. Claughton Pellew, Silent Noon, By Mr. John F. Greenwood, Riding On Dartmoor, By Mliss Mary E. Groom, Denizens Of Tbe Deep, By Miss Dorothy Hirst., Burnham Beeches, By Miss Marjory Firth, And The Hayrick, Autumn, By Mr. Sidney Rodgers.

Author: FROM OUR ART CRITIC
Title: French Art
Full_text: Entertainments French Art British Amuseum Exhibitions Fronm Our Art Crrric To Suggest The Relationship Between The Present Exhibitions Of Frenclh Art At The British Mluseum And The One At The Royal Acadeniy, The Museum Exhibitions Are Conicerned Exclusively With Frenclh Graphic Art, In Its Thuree Forms Of Illumtinated Manuscripts. Drawings, Engravings, While The Academy Exhibition Deals With Tlhe Frenchl Arts Generally. In Inanuscripts And Drawings The Two Institutions To Some Extent Cover The Salie Ground, But-Particularly At Certain Periods-The Representation At The Muscum1 Is Fuller And Inore Systematic, And In The Case Of Drawings It Comes Down To The Present Day. Frenclh Engravings Are To Be Seen Only At The Mluseumn, And Here, Again, Contemporary Artists Are Included. Apart Firom The Differences Noted, The Conditions At The Museum Are Specially Favourable For Leisurely And Ininterrupted Study. The Scope And Character Of The Exhibition Of Drawings And Engravings In The King Edward Vii. Galleries, And Of Illuminated Manuscripts In The Grenville Library, Were Fully Described In The Times Of January 5. For Present Purposes -After A Comment On The Extraordinary Richness Of The Miuseum Collections, Formed Largely By Private Generosity-It Will Be Enough To Giance At A Few Of The More Interesting Or Important Examples. The Absenee Of Catalogues Will Not Affect The Visitor, All The Works Bein- Labelled With Title Of Work. Namle Of Arti-St. Dates, And Description And T-He Arrangement In Each Section And Class Of Work Is Chronological So That The Exliibitioxis Are Very Easy To Follow But It Naturally Makes Detailed References Difficult, Withoutt The Tttking Of Elaborate Notes-Apt To Be Misleading Vhen Written In Haste. Drawings To Take The Drawings And Engravings First-Onl Tho First Slope Case In Tile King Edwvard Vii. Galleries There Are A Few Primitives, Anonymous, And Showing Thle Italian And Flemish Entanglements Of The Period, A Marriage Of The Virgin, Early Fifteenth Century, And A Visitation, Of About 1500, Being Particularly Beautiful, Wvitli A Distinctly French Flavour In Tlle Facial Types. A Drawing Of A Man In The Style Of Fran,Ois Clouet Has The Interest Of A Somewlhat Tentative Line, As If The Decided Character Familiar In Drawings Of The Class Caime After Prelininary Searc Hing. Thouglh The Slope Cases Contain Several Other Interesting Works-Such As A Very Fine Landscape, View Of Park And Fountain, By Nicolas Poussin, An Alleged Self-Portrait Of Poussin, Made, According To An Italian Inscription, At Rome In 1630, During Convalescence After A Severe Illness, A Sensitive Drawing Of The Nude, By Francois Lemnoine, 1688-1737, Formerly Attributed To Watteau, A Mnsterly Study Of A Child, By Philippe De Clampaigne, And An Architectural Design Bv Thotmas De Thomnion 1756-1814-It Will Be Convenient Here To Turn At Once To The Splendid Group Of Portrait Drawings By The Clouets And Their School, On The First Screen. These Inake It Clear Why The Clouets Are Often Spoken Of As French Holbeins, Though The Desciiption Ought To Be Reversed, Since It Is Likely That Holbein Was Influenced By Jean Clouet. It Will Be Observed That The Clouet Heads Are Inore Elaborately Modelled, And Rely Less Upon Inflection Of Line Than The Typical Holbein Portrait Drawing.-- It Is In Looking At The Cloucts, The Claudes, And The Watteaus That We Realize Time Wealth Of The Museum Collections, In The Case Of Watteau The Richest And Most Representative Public Collection In The World. To Discuss The Claude And Watteau Drawings Wvould Be Idle They Are To Be Enjoyed-Though Claudes Music Of Space Mimay Be Noted, -And Also Watteaus Preference For The Draped Over The Nude Figure. A Head Of A Child, By Greuze, Suggests That He Weas A More Virile Artist Than His Clharaqteristic Paintings Allowed Him To Appear, And There Is A Remarkably Fine Head Of A Man In A Hat, Attributed To David. Ingres Follows With A Group Of Drawings, Anid Then Gericaults Visit To England, Recalled By Recent Coirespondence In Ile Times, Is Documented In A Sheet Of Studies Of The Family Of The Bootmaker Witlh Wlhom He Lodged In London. Another London Record Is Construetion Of The Thames Eembankment, Showving Waterloo Bridge And The Shot Tower, Dated July, 1866, By Daubigny.. Thale Are Two Very Fine Drawings By Decamnp,S, Eastern Mlother And Child, And Soutliern-Landseape, And Then, Tluough Jongkind, The Gallicized Dutcllmani, We Pass To The Impressionists, Followed By -Rodin, Odillon Redon, Toulouse Lautrec-His Studies Of Liorses Ale Unexpected-Steinlen, Witlh His Cats, And So To The Present-Day As Represented By. Maillol, Signac, Segonzac, Vliaminck, Mkatissc, And Others. Engra?Viintgs The Engravings Mire Grouped According Tol Iedituma-Wood Engravinas, Line Engravings, And Etchings-Chronologically In Each Group. To The Wood Erlgraving Section-As Also To That Of-Cdntemaporary Illustration-Tle Department . Of- Printed Books Has Contributed. A Great Prize Is The Very Large Wood Engraving, Coloured By Hand, Of Christ On The Cross, Dating From About 1510, By A Toulouse Artist. This Was Found Folded Up Inside A Uorse -The Small Satchel Used At Alass. Only One Other Impression Is Known, End Tllat Is Uncoloured. Comparing This And The Other Early French Wood Engravings In Memory Witlh German Examples, One Fancies A Greater Ease Of Composition. Amilong The Books Is Lhistoire Du Chevalier Olsen, Of About 1480, One Of The Earliest Examples Of French Book Illustration, And There Are Several Books Of Hours And Dances Of Death Witl Wood Engravings. Duvet, 1495-1561, Known As Tie Master Of The Unicorn, And Jean De Gourimont I., 1506-1555, Are Well Represented, And Then Wve Pass To The Group Of Line Engraved Portraits, Including A Charlining One, In Open Line, By Chaules Mellan, 1598-1668, Of Louis Xiv. As A Boy. Mezzotinit In Black And White Does Not Seeim To Have Been Popular In France, Thlougli A Few Examples Are Shiown, But There Is A Fine Group Of Imezzotints Printed In Colour, By Caiitier Dagoty, 1716-1781, Including Twvo Beautiful Still Life Subjects, Together Witlh Aquatints In Colour By Janinet And Debucourt. Included Among Thle Etchings There Is The Only Known Etclhing By Ingres, A Portrait Of The Archbishop Of Besancon Andl There Are Fine Groups Of Lithographs By Daunnier And Etclings By Meryon. A Drypoint By Paul Helleu Of A Lady Looking At Wntteanu Drawvings In The Louv2E2 Shows The Saine Frames As Those Surroundin. The Watteau Drawings Lent By The Louvre To The Burlington House Exhibi Tion. The Contemporary Books Have Illulstrations By Lucien Pissarro, Herrnine David, Marie Laurenciti And Labrari?Eu1. Probably The Illumiinated. Manuscripts. In The Greniville Library, Do Not Excel Tho Finest At Burlington House-Certainly Not Whlell It Collies To Jeanl Fouquet-But Theil Niass Arrangemiienit In Chronological Order Continued At Foot Of Next Column Gives A More Consistent Impression Of This Torm Of French Art. The Earliest, Such As The Bible In Latin, Of The Niddle Of The Ninth Century, Aue Definitely Byzantine In Style, And Then There Is A Gradual Transition To Gothic, At Its Best As Regards Harmony Of The Page, One Would Say, In Tho Late Tlhirteentlh And Early Fourteenth Centuries. Examples Of Special Beauty In The Miniatures Are La Sainte Abbay 21 And The Breviary 37-Eatly Fifteenth Century-With An Exquisite Little Picture Of St. George And The Dragon. Breviary 26 Has Marginal Deeorations Of The Games Of Quintain And Hoodman Blind. Gradually The Style Of Tlhe Minintures Becomes Mlore Fully Pictorial-There Is One Leaf From The Etienne Chevalier 3Book Of Hours, Bv Jean I,Ouquetand Witli The Sixteentlh Cenftury The Artist Begins -To Feel The Pagta As A Hindrance Rather Than A Help To Lus Activities.
