Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Imipressions Of India. I No Slight Is Intended To The Impressions I Of India And Kashmir By Miss Nora Wright, At The Brook-Street Galleries, In Desciibing Them As Jig-Saw Patterns. Miss Wright Has The Pattern-Making Instinct Highly Developed, And She Had The Judgment To Record Her Pleased And Amused Impressions Of The Country By The Artistic Method Already At Her Command. In India-My Impressions, She Has Given Us Something Like A Childs Happy Memories Of The Pantomime Just Before Falling To Sleep Mountains, Water-Carriers, Cows, I Horses, And Elephants All Superimposed, With No Regard For Relative Size, But Care For A Decorative Composition. The Whole Is Dominated By The Shadowy Figures Of Polo-Players In Silhouette, Which May Or May Not Have A Symbolical Meaning. The Flowers Of Kashmir Shows That Miss Wrights Pattern-Making Is Something More Thlan Patchw,Ork In Colour, The Informal Arabesque Of Blooms Which Makes The Surface Of The Design Being Held Together By A Banded Arrangement Underneath. Here And There, In The Excellent Drawing Of White Bulls, For Example, There Are Hints That Miss Wright Has Been Influenced Unconsciously By The Native Traditional Style And Many Of Her Pictures Are Touched With Freakish Humour. Thus, In Unsettled, It Is The I Rabble Of Mountains Which Seems To ! Move, To The Discomfiture Of Cattle In The Foreground. For Harmony Of Colour Counting The Herds Is, Perhaps, The ! Choicest Of The Pictures. Five Artists. Of The Five Young Artists, All More Or Less Modern In Their Aims. Who Fill The Alpine Club Gallery. Mill-Street,! Conduit-Street, Wvith Paintings, Watercolours, And Drawings, Mr. Frank Potter Would Seem To Be The Least Dependent On Aims And The Most On Craftsmanship. His The Allotment, Woodland Scene, No. 2. And Surrey Landscape Are-L Really Excellent Works Nicely Simplified As To The Facts, Well Organized As Com- Positions, And Remarkably True In Atmo-I Spheric Quality. Next To Him One Would Place Mr. Jan Juta, Whose Intelligent Practice Of His Art Is Well Seen By Com- I Paring His Paintings From Life And Nature,! His Designs For Book Illustration, And His J Drawings. In Each Case There Is That Evidence Of Application To Purpose Which Is One Of The Most Encouraging Signs In The Young Artist. The Illustrations-To Cannes And The Hills, By Miss R,6N6! Juta, And Sea And Sardinia, By Mr. D. Hi. Lawrence-Are Extremely Good. The Subjects Are Reduced To The Simplest Terms, And Then Stated In Bold Colourpatterns With A Very Discriminating Use Of Black. Mr. Horace Brodzky Brings An Exotic Flavour Into The Exhibition. People And Buildings In New York Are The Subjects Of His Pictures, And In Them He Shows, A Power Of Massive Arrangement Andwhat May Be Called A Full Taste In Colour. Mr. Hyam Myer Leans Too Much To What Used To Be Called The Gorblimy Type Of Humanity, And He Should Paint Better When He Is Less The Devil Of A Fellow, But His Drawings Are Good, And - So Are Mir. Adrian Daintreys. Trish Scenery. At The Rooms Of The Irish Literary Society. Windsor House, Victoria-Street, There Are Sketches In Oils Of Irish Scenery And Other Subjects By Professor Peter J. Keelan And Mrs. Eve Keelan. What They Lack In Force They Make Up For In Sensibility, Being Fresh And Direct Impressions Of Changing Moods In The Wicklow Mountains And Elsewhere. In Addition To Their Sympathy With The Subjects Represented, Both Artists Have Sympatlhy With Their Medium, So That Their Intentions Come Through With A Persuasiveness Which Is Often Absent From Work Of More Obvious Accomplishment-With A Touch Of The Blarney, In Fact. On The Hill Of Howth. And Rushing Waters. Co. Galway, By Professor Keelan, And The Waterfall, Wicklow Mountains, By Mrs. Keelan, Are Good Examples. John Drawings. At The Beaux Arts Gallery, 1, Brutonplace, There Is Now To Be Seen A.Collection Of Early Drawings By Mr. Augustus John, A.R.A., Belonging To The Period Of His Transition From The Slade Student To The Professional Artist. Apart From Their Individual Merits They Show Clearly The Careful Study Of Human Form And Feature Which Preceded The Freedom Of His Later Manner, Before Accuracy Broadened Into Generalized Truth And They Might Well Appeal Strongly To People Who Are A Little Disturbed At The Departures From Strict Proportion Which Proceed Naturally From Drawing Which Aims At Expression Rather Than Representation. At The Same Time These Drawings Are Anything But Literal In The Imitative Sense Of The Word, Because Everything In Them Is Duly Translated Into Terms Of The Chalk Or Pencil. They Have, Moreover, Great Variety In Subject And Treatment, Ranging From Portraits To Studies Of The Figure In 18Th-Century Costume. From The Earliest Of The Series, The Bird In The Hat, A Half-Length Of A Girl In Pen-Cil Line, The Increasing Mastery Of The Draughtsman Can Be Studied In The Most Interesting Mainer. Nude Girl In Crouching Attitude 10, Mrs. John 13, And Study Of Mr. Ambrose Mcevoy Are Especially Beautiful. At The Chelsea Palace Theatre On Saturday, In Aid Of The East London Hospital For Children, There Will Be A Performance Of The Sleeping Beauty, By The Pupils Of The Mlayfair School Of Dancing. I

Author: Null
Title: Ethiopian Arts And Crafts Exhibition
Full_text: Ethiopian Arts And - Crafts Exhibition Tradmional Designs Opening An Exhibition Of Ancient And Modern Ethiopian Arts And Crafts At Foyles Art Gallery, In London Yesterday, Sir Patrice Ahercronibie Said The Exhibits Proved That The Ethiopians Intended To Develop Their Own Ideas Of- Design, And To Wontinue To Express Themselves Traditionatly, Although They Were Importing Machinery For Mass Production. He Hoped That The Exhibition Would Be The Beginning Of A Regular Exclhange Of Goods And Ideas Between Britain And Ethiopia. The Exhibition Includes Many Examples Of Fine Nietal Work, Pottery And Glass, Textiles, Firs, And Traditional Ceremonial Robes.. Perhaps The Most Interesting Items Are A Church Banner, With Virgin And Child, Attendant Angels And Kneeling Donors, Indicating A Strong Portuguese Influence Ard A Praying Staff With Gold Taw Cross, Sft. High, Used By Priests To Lean On During The Long Church Services. The Staff Was Recently ?Resented By The Head Of The Coptic Church In Ethiopia To The Rev. G. A. Ellison, Vicar Of St. Marks, Rortsmouth. The Exhibition Was Arranged By The Princess Tsahai Memorial Council, Which Was Formed To Establish A Memorial Hospital In Ethiopia. The Estimated Cost Of The Hiospital Is 100,000, Halt Of Which Has Been Already Subscribed By Ethiopians. The Exhibition Will Remain Open Until February 4.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Entertainments. Art Exhibitions. Goupil Gallery. Different As They Are In Subject And Style, There Is Yet A Certain Sympathy Between. Mr. A. S. Hartrick And Bfr. Sydney W. Carline At The Goupil Gallery, Becalise They Both Have That Setisibility To -Iature Whieh Is One Of The Charms Of English Art. It Is Extremely Imteresting To See This Charicteristio Quality Persistmg In Work Which Reflects The Artistic Ideals Of Two Generations Mr. Hartrick, Who Is Primarily A Draughtsman, Show,S Watercolours And Drawings With A Reed Pen And Rolour, Made. For The Most Part In The Neighbourhood Of Clevedon, Somerset. It Is A Part Of The Country Which Has Little To Offer To The Large-Scale Landscape Designer, But Yields A Good Deal Tosympathetic Pottering At Close Quarters. Not That Mr. Aartrick Is Pottering In Style He Appreciates Character, But He Is Economical In Statement, And He Is Remarkably Successful Im Keeping The Paper Filled With Light Even When He Is Working In Line. There Is A Peculiar Effect Of Light Reflected From The Channel In This Neighbourhood Which He Conveys Admirably In The Harbour, Old Clevedon, Where An Inlet Winds Through The Mud Isats Between The Church Of In Memoriam And Woodspring-Or Worspring-Priory. Most Of The Drawings Represent Small Things- On The Beach. Clevedon, The Magpie, The Beach Chairs -But They Are Small Things Recorded With A Selective Vision And A Feeling For Style. Morning On Cleeve Hill, One Of The Finest Views In England, Seen From A Window, With A Girl At Her Toilet, Is As Happy A Picture As One Could Wish Ta See. As Becomes A Younger Man, Mr. Carline, Who Shows Oil Paintings, Watercolours, And Drawings, Is More Guarded In His Response To Nature, And His Pictures Are More Obviously Orgamiized, Btit It Is The Response That Distinguishes Him From The More Cosmopolitan Artists Of His Generation. Delicate Colour In Subtle Relations Is For Him The Great Appeal, And It Is Confessed With Reserved Beauty Of Execution In Such Landseaipes As Capel Curig, Moel-Siabo D, Willow Tree In Frost, And Tree-Trunk. These Are Really His Best Paintings- Willow Tree In Frost Is The Best Of All-But There Are Others With Bolder Compositional Devices. Eiderdown, On An Iron Bedstead In A White Cottage Interior, Justifies Its Boldness By The Admirable Spacing Of Its Darker Details, But In Breakfast The Rainbow-Striped Tablecloth Has Got Out Of Hand-With Something Of The Effect Of A Joke In The Wrong Context.. In Resting, A Girls Head, The Intrinsic Appeal Of The Subject Has A Little Got The Better Of The Artist, But Gwen, Another Head, Is An Excellent Painting, Treated With Proper Detaclhment That Is Vet Sympathetic. Of The More Ambitious Landscapes In Oil St. Johns, Downshire Hill, In Snow, Is The Best-Balanced In Design, And There Are Some Excellent Water-Colours Of English And Arab Subjects. Included In The Exhibition Are Studies For Some Of The Aeroplane Pictures Painted By Mr. Carline For Tlle Imperial War Museum.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Flower Pictuifes. For Sheer Pleasure There Is Nothing In London Galleries At The Moment To Com Pare With The Exhibition Of Ffower Pictures, 1568 To 1027, At Messrs. Knoedlers, 15, Old Bond-Street. To The Chelsea Flower Show, With Which It Coincides, It Stands In The Relation Of Art To Nature, And Excursions Profitable To The Right Enjoyment Of Both Might Be Made Between The Two. In A Sense Flower-Painting Brings All Artists To A Level-But Only To Show The Differences Between Them. Some Paint Flowers Like Vegetables, Others Like Souls With Some Fortn Is The Principal Concern, With Others Colour--Whether Intrinsic Or As Conditioned By The Play Of Light With Others, Agai, Iragrance-.Or, Rather, That Aura In Form, Colour, Light, And Fragrance Are All Diffused, Which Is Helpfully Suggested By The Word Bouquet. This Gives Us A Lead To The Most Enchanting Pictures In The Present Exhibition. Flowers Lend Themselves More Or Less Well To Every Practice Of Painting, Imitative Or Abstract, Atmosphenc Or Decorative, But They Lend Themselves Best Of All To The Kind Of Ainting In Which Formal And Substantial Qualities Are Pretty Evenly Balanced. The Emphasis May Be A Little One Way Or A Little The Other, But The Artist Who Would Get The Most Out Of Flowers Must Be A Painter, In The Specific Meaning, As Well As A Designer. He Must Have The Capacity, Easier To Recognize Than To Describe, For Translating The Beauty Of One Substance Into The Beauty Of Another. Mere Imitation Of The Substance Of Flowers Will Not Do It, Nor Will The Merely Workmanlike Handling Of Pigment There Must Be A Process For Which Reincarnation, Though Inexact, Seems The Only Word. Consequently It Is Not Surprising To Find That The Most Enchanting Pictures In This Exhibition Correspond To The Phase Of French Impressionism-Using The Term Broadly Enough To Include Manet At One End And Cezanne, Vuillard, And Bonnard At The Other. Impressionism, We Might Almost Say, Was Made For Flower-Painting. This Is Not To Deny The Attractions Of The First Room, Containing Works By Velvet Breughel, Mary Moser, And The Dutchmen -Van Huysum In Particular. These Painters, With Their Massive Compositions, Crafty Colour Arrangements, And Solid Execution, Did Get The Qualities In Flowers Which Can Be Summed Up As Handsome. Ness, But They Missed The Qualities That Are Summed Up As Bouquet. Their Flowers Remain Beautiful Vegetables. Perhaps The Romantic Movement Was Necessary, But -And Not Forgetting The Small Brightness Of The Early Italian Flower-Painters, Charmingly Recalled Here By No. 62, By The Douanier Rousseau-It Really Does Seem As If We Had To Wait Until The Middle Of The 19Th Century For The Full Apprecia. Tion Of Flowers As Flowers In Painting. The Awakening To Light Had, Of Course, A Great Deal To Do With It-The Inclination To Paint The Visible World As A Many-Coloured Envelope In Which Form Is Felt Rather Than Perceived. Even Manet Came Down A Little On The Vegetable Side-Though No. 45, In Which Dull Red And Brown Flowers Are Compared With A Gilt Frame, And The Dark Stand Of The Bowl Strikes A Bass Note, Is A Magnificent Piece Of Decoration-And If We Had To Name The Floweriest Paintings In The Exhibition We Should Point To The Examples By Vuillard, Bonnard, Berthe Morisot, And Renoir And Among The Renoirs We Should Choose, Not The Noble Group Of Mixed Flowers In A Blue Bowl, But The More Diffused Nos. 57 And 60. That Is To Say, From The Point Of View Of Floweriness. But Here Less Than Anywhere Must Narrow Standards Be Adopted, And As Between The Great Rounded Mass Of Flowers Resembling Mallows, With The Light Behind Them, By Monet 48B The Serenely Observed Bouquet De Fleurs In An Even Light, By Camille Pissarro The Fantastic Vase Chinois, By Odilon Redon The Inlaid Pivoines, By Braque And The Ingenious Vase De Fleurs Sur Une Table, By Matisse, It Is Hard Indeed To Say How Flowvers Ought To Be Painted. Among The Englfsh Pictures There Is Nothing To Surpass The Mixed Bunch No. 67 By Bliss Ethel Walker. The Warren Gallery. The New Warren Gallery, At 39A, Maddox-Street, Opens Like A May Morning With Water-Colours By Mr. Paul Nash. We Do Not Remember To Have Received A Happier Impression Of This Admirable Artist. It Might Be Rash To Say That Mr. Nash Paints Better In Water-Colour Than In Oil, But There Can Be No Doubt That The Slighter Medium Is Peculiarly Well Suited To His Intentions As A Designer. He Conceives Of The Space Enclosed By The Frame Of The Picture As A Void In Three Dimensions, And Then Proceeds To Inform It With What Somebody Has Aptly Called Plastic Rhythm By The Deft Placing Of Tones, Sufficiently Representative Of Natural Forms For Intelligibility, Which Establish The Lateral Relations By Their Positions And The Relations In Depth By Their Values, Until The Whole Space Is, So To Speak, Modelled, The White Paper Playing A Considerable Part In The Forms Created. When The Process Is Completed The Picture Is Finished. Though Corroborative Detail May Be Added. The Reason Why Watercolour Seems More Suitable For This Process Than Oil Is That It Lends Itself To A Further Degree Of Abstraction. A Streak Of Oil Pigment 9N Canvas Needs More Explanation Thanl A Stain Of Water-Colour On Paper. And, Therefore, One Feels That Oil Painting Requires A More Imitative Treatment, To Lean More Heavily Upon The Facts Of Nature. But In These Water-Colours There Is Nothing To Disturb Our Pleasure In Following The Artist In His Rhythmical Evolutions Through Space. His Allusions To Nature, However Remnote, Are Perfectly Understood Through The Nature Of The Medium, And There Is No Unorganized Material To Be Explained Away. Canary, In A Darkly Framed Window, Shows How Strongly The Method Can Be Used Without The Need For Literalness In Representation, And There Are Several Pictures-Perhaps View Of Garden Goes Farthest-Which Display Its Possibihties In Considered Slightness. Steps Under Trees May Be Named For Its Musical Rhythm, And Avenuie By The Stream For Its Fullness Of Representation. Five Designs For Scenes From King Lear, Made For The Players Shakespeare, Published By Messrs. Benn, Are Included In The Exhibition. In The Other Rooms There Is The First Exhibition Of Ol Paintings By Mr. Adrian Daintrey. -His Gifts Are A Quick Grasp Of The Subject As A Whole, A Vigorous Method Of Brush Construction, And A Remarkably Truesense Of Values -Enabling Him To Get Lively -Effect. Without Incoberence. Vivacity Is, Indeed, The Prevailing Character In The Exhibition, The Works Include Portraits, Landscapes, And Stl-Life Subjects, And The Dachshiind, On A Sun-Splashed Road, The Railway Bridee, Moret-Sur-Loing, Lollingdoo, And Winter Scene May Be Picked Oub As Good Examples. At The Q Theatre The Mja Nepoht, By Ybn Wirsh, Will Be Produced On Ienday Night With A Company That Includes Mir. Lewin Anerin , Mhs 31Audie Dunha, 11. Eaddon Son, Rlola Duncan, Wasirene Rooke. Mrmatth Ew Boultozi, Ad Miss Kude Alexader. The Broacatig P Roasse Fortoa- Da Si4Bo.Csta Noto, Wil Bg Foun- N Ae. .-

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions The Goupil Gallery Mr. Hyam Myer, Whose Oil Paintings Are To Be Seen At The Goupil Gallery, 5, Regent-Street, Employs Rather Florid Curves Which He Obtains By Bold Distortions. Every Part Of His Pictures Is Connected By These Flowing Lines. But If The Structure Of His Pictures Is Almost Florid The Execution Of Them Is The Reverse. His Colours Are Often Harsh And Uncompromising, And In The Quality Of His Paint, Which Seldom Has A Soft Or Agreeable Surface, He Makes No Concessions. Catalan Woman Is Perhaps The Most Extreme Example Of These Two Apparently Contradictory Aims, Which Are Here More Or Less Reconciled. This Taste For Rude Vigour Which Comes Out In The Colouring Nnd Texture Of His Pictures Also Affects The Choice Of His Subjects. He Seems To Delight In Viewpoints And Positions Which Accentuate The Harshness Of Everything Which He Sees. But In Some Of His Landscapes, Where, Curiously Enough, He Does Not Indulge In Very Sweeping Curves, He Does Indulge In Delicate And Agreeable Colour. At The Same Gallery 3Miss Dora Crockett The Countess Eric Lewenhaupt Shows A Number Of Oil Paintings And Water-Colours. Many Of These Are Rather Bare And Strict Structures, And Often The Rough Surface Of The Canvas, Not Filled In With Paint, Accentuates Their Austerity. But This Austerity Is Often, And Especially In Some Mountainous Scenes, Turned To Dramatic Ends. At Other Times, As In Giverny, A More Subtle Feeling For Tones And Colour Changes The Whole Character Of The Picture. The Watercolours Are Also Much More Soft And Gentle. And The Paint Has Been Laid On Damp So As To Take A Pleasant Surface. Mr. Charles Tharp The Portraits In Mr. Charles Tharps Exhibition Of Portraits And Other Works At Coolings Galleries, 92, New Bond-Street, Are Greater In Number And Importance Than The Other Works. In Fact, Mr. Tharp Is Very Definitely A Portrait Painter. But He Has Made An Effort To Bring The Ordinary Portrait Of To-Day Into Line With More Traditional Kinds Of Painting, An Attempt Certainly Well Worth Making. In The Main Mr. Tharp Contents Himself With Painting, As Vasari Would Have Put It, In The Modern Manner, Though He Does Not Take This Very Far. But He Paints With Freedom, His Colours Are Often Bright, And There Is Some Considerable Difference Betwveen His Portrait Of The Late Viscount Cowdray, A Perfectlv Conventional If Competent Portrait, And Many Of His Other Works. Too Often His Search For Greater Freedom Has Led Him To Leave His Pictures Unfinished, And Even Where Every Part Of The Canvas Is Covered With Paint One Has The Impression That Had Mr. Tharp Put A Finer Polish Upon His Work And Included More Detail The Conventional Portrait Would Have Emerged. Nevertheless, In These Rougher Portraits The Colour Is Often Attractive, And In The Heads, If Not In The Rest Of The Picture, There Is Sometimes A Certain Grasp Of The Structure, As In The Portrait Of The Late Rev. A. V. 3Iagee. In His Other Works 3Mr. Tharps Sense Of Colour Is Allowed More Play, As In Siesta, While The Colour Of The Skv In Portland Place Is An Interesting Invention. Modern Japanese Prints At Yamanaka And Co.S Galleries, 127. New Bond-Street, Is An Interesting Exhibition Of Modern Japanese Colour Prints, Planned, As We Are Told In A Foreword To The Catalogue, As A Protest Against The Assumption That The Glory Of Japanese Colour Printing Has Faded Away. . . It Chiefly Consists Of The Work Of Kobayashi Kiyochika, Who Worked During The Period 1868-1912 And So Encountered The Influence Of The Yest. His Technique Remained For Long Almost Entirely Oriental, But Bis Subjects Were Changed. He Worked For His Countrymen And Depicted Steamships, European Houses, And So Forth. At The Same Time He Adventured With Thunderstorms, Fireworks, And Fires. His Representations Of Modern Objects Have A Curiously Naive And Childlike Effect, And I From This He Seems To Have Derived A Pleasant Decorative Method. His Drawing Is Often Naive Enough Even When He Is Not Depicting Unoriental Objects, Asin Mandai Bridge-Dawn. With All His Eastern Technique He Often Approaches Near To The Simpler And Less Sophisticated European Colour Prints Of The Same Period. But Later He Seems To Have Grown More Sophisticated And To Have Introduced More Important Realistic Effects Into His Prints. Thus Evening On The Sumida River No. 22 Still Appears Perfectly Japanese In Technique, Hut The Treatment Of Space Is Actuallv European In Feeling. Some Other Prints By More Modern Artists Are Included In The Exhibition. I

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Walkers Galleries. The Water-Coloru-S Of The Isle Of Skye And Western Highlands By Captain G. Drunmmondfish At Wvalkers Galleries, 118, New Bondstreet, Are Considerably Above The Average For The Subjects. They Are Free From Sentimcntality, Though They Are Not Afraid Of Drama, And They Observe The Fact That Hills Have Bulk As Weu As Ouitline. Captain Drummond-Fish, In Short, Has Perceived The Truth That The Real Pictorial Opportunities Of This Kind Of Scenery Lie In The Configuration Of The Ground In The Way Hills Rise And Recede, Rivers Wind, And Roads Take The Line Of Least Resistance. Physical Geographv Is, Of Course, Not Enough To Make A Picture, But It Is A Good Beginning, And In Several Of His Water-Colours Captain Drummnond-Fish Shows No Mean Ability As A Composer In Brig C Dee, Galloway, Loch Clair, Torridon, Looking Ltp The Glen, Sligachan, Skye, And Elgol Skye, For Examples. The Loch Clair Drawing Is Not The Only One, Which Shows Considerable Skll In The Management Of Differcrt Planes Of Light. In Its Sober Colouring, Miostlv Russet And Grey, In Comparatively Flat Tones, The Work Of This Artist Reminds One Of The Honest Efforts Of The Early Aquatinters.

Author: Null
Title: The Dudley Gallery
Full_text: The Dudley Gallery. I The 18Th General Exhibition Of Wvater-Colour Drawings At The Dudley Gallery Certainly Does Not Fall Below The Usual Level Of Excellence. In The Single Room Are Gathered Together Some 640 Drawings Of Au Sorts And Sizes, From Mr. Herkomers Minute Painting Ort Ivory To Mr. Joseph Knights Large Mountain Landscspe And If Among All Theso There Is Nothing Of The Very Highest Quality, At Least There Is Singularly Little Really Bad Workmanship. There Are Times, Indeed, When One Is Tempted To Echo The Complaint Of M. Claretie, The French Critic, Against The Enormous Fertility Of Modern Art. Sixty Thousand Pictures, Good And Bad, Produced Every Year In Paris Alone ! What Will Posterity Do With Them All ? Yet It Is Better To Trust Posterity To Solve Its Own Problems, Anl Meanwhile To Enjoy The Best Of What Our Painters Provide For Us. So Long As The Average Continues To Rise We May Be Content To Reflectthat This Means An Increased And Extended Interest In Art And Wider Facilities For Art Training. And That The Average Is Rising Is Eviaent To Any One Who Enters A Gaflerv Like This And Compares What He Sees In It With What He Would Have Seen If Ten, Twenty, Thirty Years Ago He Had Found Himself, Not In An Exhibition Of The Works Of A Few Picked Men, But In A General Exhibition Open To All Comers And Frequented For The Most Part By Young Painters. There Can Be No Question That The Improvement In Drawing, Colouring, And In Composition Has Been Steadyin Other Words, That Water-Colour Art Has Felt The General Intellectual Movement Of Which We Are Hardly Conscious, Because We Live In The Midst Of It. Southey, In 1818, Speaking Of The Many Volumes Of Poetry Which Were Then Appearing Without Bringmg Their Writers Either Notice Or Reward, Says,- There Is Not One Of The Whole Number Which Would Not Have Excited Attention And Secured A Remnuneration To The Author Had It Been Published 80 Yesrs Ago. Fortunately For The Painters, There Is A Better Market For Their Works Than There Was For Poetry In 1818 But The Tone In Which The Mass Of Them Are Sometimes Spoken Of Is Hardly Less Disparaging Than That In Which The Critics Then Spoke Of The Poetry Of The Day. They May Console Thomselves With Adapting Southeys Saying To Their Own Case. Judged By The Standard Of To-Day, There Is Nothing Exceptional In This Exhibition At The Dudley Gallery But None The Less, It Contains At Least Fifty Drawings Which, If They Had Appeared As The Work Of New Men In 1850,Would Have Arrested Everybodys Attention. At One Time The Exhibitions At The Dudley Gallery Showed The Prevailing Inflaence Of One School-In Fact, Inclined To Cliquishness. There Is No Sign Of This Now. The Direct Inheritors Of The Pre-Raphaelite Tradition Have Gone Elsewhere - And The Impressionist School, Which Triumphs In Some Foreign Galleries, Is Not Represented To Any Great Extent. There Are Exceptions, Such As Mr. R. W. Allan, Whose Views Of Seville And Venice Are Decidedly Interesting Mr. Melville, Whose 1 Turkish Bath Is A Fine Piece Of Colour, And Signor Cabianca, Of Whose Venetian Scene The Same May Be Said Mr. Edwin Ellis. Whosa Arawing Must Trankly Be Pronounced A Failure And Liss Macaulay, Who Should Take Warning In Time Aainst Caricaturing The Style Of Miss Montalba. Tbut The Mass Of The Best Work Here Belongs To A Different School-That Which Aims At Hitting The Mean Between The Neglect Of Detail And The Slavish Adherence To It-That, In Fact, Which Tries To Forget Neither The Whole Nor The Parts, Neither The Total Effect Nor The Details Which Go To Make It. Such Is The Work Of The Brothers Severn, Of Mr. F. Walton, In A Certain Degree Of Mr. Alfred Parsons, Of Mr. H. M. Marshall, And Of Many Others Of The More Remark-Able Exhibitors. In A Class By Themselves Stand The Two Drawings Of Mr. Ruskin, Which The Gallery Has Had The Good Fortune To Secure. Beginning With The Left-Hand Wall We Come Upon Mr. C. Earles Near The Lands End, Which, With The Penborth Cove 292 Of The Same Painter, May Be Profitably Compared With The Very Similar But Finer Work Of Mr. F. Walton No. 46, In Penborth Cove , Who Has Succeeded Better In His Rendering Of The Almost Mediterranean Blue Of The Western Sea. No. 22 Is Mr. Il W. Allans Seville, A Broadly-Treated And Almost Too Luminous Dravwing, But Not So Excessive In Brilliancy As The Fish-Stall In Venice Of The Same Painter, Where The Pavement Suggests Water Rather ,Than Sunlight. Not Far Off No. 31 Hangs What Is, Perhaps, The Best Of Mr. A.Parsonss Fourdrawins -A Delicious Study Of An Orchard In Spring. It Is Less Ambitious Than Either Of Those Opposite, But Is Certainly More Successful Than Either In Making The Spectator See What The Painter Saw -A Stretch Of May Grass, With Sheep Dotted About It, And Trees Loaded With Apple-Blossoms. Mr. Parsons Is One Of The Most Rising Of Our Landscape Painters, Whether He Uses Water Or Oil, And This Is For Its Size One Of His Most Charminlg Drawings. It Escapes, For Example, What Seems To Us The Fault Of The Neighbouring Sketch No. 48 Of Bablock Ythc, So Dear To Vjxiora Men, Wnere Ttie Heavy Cloud That Covers Half The Sky Has Not Been Allowed To Soften The ,Foo Great Brilliancy Of The Grass. Between These Two Hangs The Large Drawing Of Mr. Edwin Ellis. To Whioh We Have Already Referred, Sand Hills, North Wales -A View Of Scrub-Covered Bills, With A Shepherd And What May Be Supposed To Be His Flock Climbing Them. Mr. Ellis Has Unquestionable Talent, And Has Often Given Us Sketehes Of The Sea That Have Much Of Mr. Hooks Power And Colour In Them But There Is A Hasty Unfinished Look About All He Does Which Makes His Work Of Less Value Than It Ought To Be. These Sheep, For Exsmple, What Are They ? Turner, No Doubt Would Have Dashed Ttem In Rapidly, And Would Have Taken Little Pains With Their Proportions, And So Would David Cox But Those Painters Would Have Left It Certain That They Were Sheep, While In Mr. Elliss Hands They Might Very Well Be Insects. It Is A Pity To See So Much Ability Used To So Little Purpose As It Has Been In This Picture. Passing By Several Small And Pleasant Drawings 40, 0 Pleasant Eventide -A Town Scene, By F. Ihamilton Jackson 41, Men Were Deceivers Ever, By L. L. Pocock 47, Evening, By P. T Rrant We Come To Mr. Aspinalls Spring Scene, Ere A Leaf Is On A Bush 55. Mr. Aspinall Is A Now Exhibitor, Vwe Believe, And He Ought To Be Welcomed As One Who Uromises Extremely Well. This Small Drawing, Like No. 257 Opposite Paidington Farm, Dorking , Is One Of The Most Poetical, Refined, And Yet Perfectly True Studies To Be Found In The Gallery. Spring, With Her Rainy, Fleeting Charms, Her Promise, Her Illusions, Is Rendered In This Sketch Of The Brook Among The Hills In A Truly Delightful Manner, The Only Fault That Can Be Suggested Being, Perbaps, That The Style Is A Little Over-Laboured. Not Very Dissimilar Is The Park Gate 61, By Mr. W. F. Stocks, But This, Though Excelent In Drawing, Is Perhaps Too Artificial In Colour. No. 69, A Call Afternoon Z By E. J. Du Val, Is A Pleasant Summer Scene Of Rippling Sea With White Gulls Descending Upon It And No. 7T, Mr. F. E. Tboxs Walberwick Ferry, Is A Study Of Girla Dresses, Which In A Measure Recalls Tissot, Though Being Without That Distinguished Paintera Atmosphere. Next Jianas The Trout-Stream Of Hir. W. G. Addison, A Rich, Perhaps Over-Rich, Drawing Of A Stream With Its Bordering Of Lu.Sh Grasses, Reeds, And Yallow Iris. Like The Apple Blossom, Which Hangs Opposite, This Drawing Recaus The Style Of Alfred Parsons, But It Seems To Want The Reserve Which Is A Quality Of His Work, And Consequently To Reach A Less Degree Of Excellence. Mr. . Dillons 1 Blind Arched Gateway 73 Is A Pleasant Little Drawing Of Buildings And In Pglen Docbart 85, Mr. Fhenry Moore Leaves His Favourite Sea And Gives Us A Very Clever View Of A Highland Scene With Its Full Autumn Contrast Between The Rich Colour Of The Foreground And Tho Wnow-Covered Mountain Behind. Mr. John White Is Now A Ms Deszznis Yesr, None Of His Three Drawings Deing Equal To His Recent Work In Oils. Mr. Joseph Knights Breezy Day, And The Old Well Of His Namesake, J.W.B. Knight, Are Noticeable, And Beyond Tbem- Is One That Must Be Ranked Among The Most Remarkable Drawings In The Gallery, The Aumeris Of Mr. J. H. Hensball. It Isadrawing Of A Low-Browed-, Dark-Haired Woman, In A Richlyembroidered Dress, Who Stands On A. Marble Floor Before A Deep Purple Curtain In Feature And Expression She Is Repellent, Even Ugly, And Her Attitude Is.Poor. But In Point Both Of Painting And Colour The Drawing Stands Out As Something Quite Weitfnt From Most Of Its Neighbours. The Last Among The Drawings On This Wall Which Calls For Notice Isthat Of Mr. J. C.Dollman, Whose Humorous Gift Is Not Deserting Him. Les Misdrables Are The Master And His Dog-A Rough-Looking Master And A Villainous Dog-Turned Out Of Their Cottage, With All The Furniture, For The Weekly Cleaning. The Profound Wretchedness Of These Houseless Ones Is Admirably Rendered. The Place Of Honour At The End Of The Room Is Occupied By Mr. Josoph Knights Lingering Ligbt, A Large Drawing Of A Monntain Side, Fronted By A Dark Pool On Which The Sun Never Seems To Shine, And Itself Clotbed With Wood Till Near The Summit. On Vale And Wood The Shadow Of Night Has Fallen, But Above It The Rosy Light Of Sunset Still Lingers. The Great Solidity Of Treatment Which Mdr. Knight Has Adopted Is Unusual In Water-Colours Some Might Even Call It Illegitimate. Btit The Best Way To Discredit Bard And Fast Distinctions Between The Legitimate And The Illegitimate In Art Is To Paint A Successful Picture Which Confounds Them. M-R. Knights Drawing Is Flanked By Two, Matching In Size But A Singular Contrast In Subject, By The Brothers Arthur And Walter Severn-, Ice On The Tbames At Battersea And The Rising Tidesark. Both Of These Large And Powerful Drawings Are Well Worthy Of Their Conspicuous Position. Mr. Arthur Severns Is A Very Delicate Study Of The Misty,Waning Light Of An Evenin- Of Hard Frost Bis Brothers A View Of One Of The Nobie Promontories That Jut From The Wonderful Shore Of Sark, With The Sea Coming In So Fast And Steadily That The Spectator Almost Fears To Be Left In That Lonely Bav With All Escape Shut Off By The Rocks And The Waves. On Either Side Of These Two Drawings Are The Workx Nf Dir. Mvielville And Signor Cabianca, Of Which We Have Already Spoken. Close By Is A Charming Shore Scene, By Mr. J. 0. Long, The White Sands Of Iona And Below Mr. Knights Pictnre Is Miss M. S. Groses 1 Souvenir Of Algeria, A Very Clever Studyof Eastern Stilllife. Onthe Same Wall Are Three Small Drawings In One Frame Of The Lakce Country In Winter, By Mr. H. M. Marshall, Who Is Rapidly Earning The Position Of The Lake Painter Par Exceuence. No One Who Knowvs The Bend Of Fairfield, And Who Knows Also How Seldom Either Artist Or Photographer Succeeds In Rendering The True Proportion Of That Bend Or Of The Valley Beneath, Ought To Miss This Sketch. Wansfell Is Perbaps,A Shade Less True, But, Taken All In All, This Trio Cf Minute Drawinas Are Extremelv Successful Both As Pictures And As Renderings Of Actual Places. Lastly May Be Mentioned Mr. Talmage Whites Valley Of The Pines At Massa, Near Sorrento, A Refined And Tet Glowing Representation Of A Beautiful Italian Scene. On The Next Wall The First That Invites Attention Is Mr. A. B. Donaldsons Venetian Drawing M Murano And San Cristoforo, Very Brilliant And Faithful, In Spite Of The Depth Of Blue That To Those Wbo Do Not Know The Lagoon At Al Seasons Might Seem Exaggerated. The Same Painters View Of The Terrace Of The Pincio 368 Is Hardly So Succesful, And Provokes Inevitable Comparisons With M. Heilbuths Magnificent Drawings Of The Same Place Which Were Exhibited In London A Few Years Agc. Mr. Luther Hoopers Staple Inn, Holborn Is A Broadly-Treated And Clever Sketch Of A Part Of Old London Which Can Hardly Survive Another Genaration. Of Mr. Aspinalls Paddington Farm We Have Already Spoken. Close To It Is Oak Valley, Cannock Chase No. 259, H. Biirides. An Important Drawing With A Great Deal Of Pleasant Colour And Suiggestiveness, Though There Is An Impression Of Stippling About The Work Which Mars Its Value. The Infinite Detail Of Grass Is Not Really Attained By These Stippling Processes, And The Main Result Is A Kinl Of False Atmosphere Wbich Spoils The Picture. Mr. H. A. Harpers Larae Drawing Of Jerusalem-Sunrise 265 Is Bold And Spirited, Rendering The Character Of The Place Without Being Overladen With Detail, And Fine And Pure In Colour. Below Is Mr. H. Pilleaus Best Drawing 268, The Two Colossi, Thebesdluring The Inundation Of The Nile, Which Renders In A Singularly Successful Way The Tone Of The Egyptian Valley In Floodtime. Mr. Radcliffes Wanderers From The Flock 293 Is A Pleasant Study Of Tree Trunks, Red Leaves And Lichens, And Sheep Aud Mr. Hawksworths Small Sketch Of Limehouse 301 Is Full Of Promise. Bevond Is Iylr. .E. Watons Et And ,Ost Characteristic Lontribution, Excellently Described In The Line From Shelley Which Ho Takes For Its Title If Winter Comes, Can Spring Bo Far Behind 7- Amoug Many Other Venotian Sketches Is One Sent By Miss Leigh Smith 343, Across The Lagune And Among The Lake Drawings Is A Large And Laboured Picture Of Windermere By Mr. E. T. Compton, Who Has Succeeded Much Better With His Distanices Than With His Difficult Ferny Foreground. Mr. J. E. Graces Work Is Always Pleasant, And If Bis Veteran Of The Woods 365 Is Not One Of His Most Striking Efforts, It Is Not The Less A Clever And Attractive Sketch. Mr. Pococks Sympatby 408 Is An Attempt In The Direction Of Dramatic Painting That Cannot Be Called Altogether Successful. Mr. A. J. Watsons Mansion House 432 Is A Very Clever Study Of London Atmosphere In Rain And Miss E. Wveblings Eosalinrd May Pass For A Good Imitation Of An Early Florentine Head, Such As La Bella Simonetta, Or Some Other Imnaertal Fair One. We Have Scarcely Left Onrselves Space To Do Justico To The Many Excellent Little Wvorks That Hang On The Screens. On The First Are-To Take Uvv Lw 1L1Uullut3 01 D Yir. Jofln Efvanss Masterly Church Interiors Two Of Miss H. Thornycrofts Studies Of Orchids-Brilliant And Delicate Pieces Of Colour Which It Would Be Difficult To Surpass And Mr. B. W. Spierss Clever And Careful Bit Of Wardour-Street -A Corner In Which Are Gathered Together In Delightful Disarray An Ancient Sword, A Fiddle Perbaps This Is A Genuiie Carlo Bergonzi !, Old Engravings, Books With Fascinating Titles, Coral Beads, Coins, And China. Above It Hangs, What To Many Visitors Will Be The Most Interesting Drawing In The Gallery, Mr. Ruskins Wonderfully Elaborate In The Pass Of Killiecrankie-A Study Of Trees And Rocks, Seen With The Nicroscopic Eye Of The Great Critic. The Other Screen, Which Is Devoted To Drawings Of The Snrallest Size, Is Itself Sufficient To Occupy The Visitor Through A Pleasant Half-Hour. Mr. J. 0. Long Has Another Iona Sketch 536, Below Which Nangs A Clever And Amusing Drawing Called Conceit By Mr. J.A.Fitzgerald-A Negro Dressing Up In His Masters Finery, To His Own Intense Satisfacthon. Mr. E. Waterlows Shady Spot Miss P. Townsends Street In Scheveningen And Mr. Marshalls On The Medway Are Noticeable Among The Drawings On The One Side Of The Screen. The Other Side Is Richer, For There Are Two Gems Of Mr. Arthur Severns, A Tiny Drawing By Mr. Ruskin, Mr. Raerkomers Bread And Sunshine --A Miniature On Ivory Of A Bavarian Boy Enjoying His Middav Meal In Freedom-And Many Others Of High Quality. Of The Monaco And Monte Carlo Of Mr. Severn It May Be Truly Said-And No Higher Praise Could Be Given-That He Has Succeeded In Adequately Rendering What Is, Perhaps, The Most Beautiful Spot In Europe, Its Dazzling Sea, The Exquisite Lines And Colours Of Its Infinitely Varying Shore, And Its Heavonly Atmosphere. Mr. T. G. Linnells Scotch Firs Is A Brilliant Little Drawing, And Mr. J. Hardwicke Lewiss Man In Blue Is A Work Whicb, If We Cannot Say Of It, In The Phrase Of The French Irreconcilable, That It Is Encore Plu8 Mauvais Que Meissonier, Is Yet An Exceedingly Strong And Careful Bit Of Painting In The Style Of The French Figure Painters. To Conelude, We May Mention Mr. Houghs Basket Of Plums, Than Which-Assuming That Plums Are A Worthy Subject For Art-Nothing Could Be More Successful. Indeed, In Subjects Of This Kind The Gallery Is Rich, For, Besides Those We Have Mentioned Already, The Flower Pieces Of Mr. Mitchell, Mr. David Carr, Miss Kate Sadler, Miss Scott, Miss Maud Naftel, Miss L3. Parsons, Miss A. Moore, Miss V. Lindsay, And, Above All, Of Mrs. Martineau, Are Of Remarkable Excellence.

Author: Null
Title: Exhibition Of Norwegian Art
Full_text: Exhibition Of Norwegian Art. It Has Been Decided That The Exhibition Of Modern Norwegian Art Which Is To Be Held At The Brighton Corporation Art Galleries During April, May, And June Next Year Shall Afterwards Be Moved To Some Of The More Important Towns Of The United Kingdom. The Suggestion Was Made By The Director Of The Galleries Mr. Henry D. Roberts, Who Organized The Previous French, Swedish, And Danish Exhibitions, And Has The Approval Of The Norwegian Minister In London, Who Has Been Invited To Accept The Position Of President. Among Norwegians, Especially Those Interested In Art, The Proposal Has Aroused Considerable Interest, And A Committee Has Been Formed To Assist The Brighton Art Director In Selecting Paintings, Water-Colour Drawings, And Bronze And Sculpture Exhibits.

Author: Null
Title: Redfern Gallery Exhibition
Full_text: Entertainments Redfern Gallery Exhibition Paintings By Mr. T. Carr Mr. Thomas Carr, 30 Of Whose Paintings Are On View At The Redfern Gallery, 20, Cork Street, W.1, Is An Artist With A Pleasing Gift Of Bright, But Not Garish, Colour. He Has, Too, A Strongly Developed Sense Of Silhouette, Which Influences The Composition Of Many Of His Most Attractive Pictures. The Latter Characteristic Is Very Noticeable In Such Things As Marine Parade, Dover, Which Is An Arrangement Of Figures Silhouetted Against Houses, Which In Their Turn Are Outlined Against Cliffs And Pierrots, A Lively And Decorative View Of A Seaside Entertainment, With Both Performers And Audience Seen From The Side-An Approach Which May Possibly Have Been Suggested By A Well Known Picture By Mr. Sickert. Another Delightful Picture Of Mr. Carrs, In Somewhat The Same Manner, Is Children Paddling While A Fresh And Charming Nude, Girl In Bed, And An Agreeable Portrait, Sally, Illustrate Other Aspects Of His Work. In An Adjoining Room Is A Small Selection Of Paintngs And Drawings, Some Of Them Completely Abstract, By Nine English Painters-A Selection Which Is Shortly To Be Exhibited In America. The Abstractionists Include Mr. John Tunnard Not Quite At His Best Mr. Ben Nicholson, Showing Some Of His Painted Reliefs Made Up Chiefly Of Superimposed Rectangles Of White, Grey, Brown, And Red Miss Barbara Hepwortb, Whose Drawings For Sculpture Rather Suggest Infinitely Neat Geometrical Problems And Mr. Alastair Morton. Mr. Graham Sutherland And Mr. Henry Moore Are, As It Were, Only Semi-Abstract In Their Exhibits-And Perhaps Therefore Less Easy To Understand. Mr. Sigmund Pollitzer Contributes Some Surrealist Drawings Done With A Very Delicate Pencil Line. Mr. Paul Nashs Watercolours Show Once Again His Soft And Lovely Sense Of Colour And Include An Amusing Beetles Eye View, So To Speak, Of A Group Of Toadstools. Both Exhibitions Continue Until November 22.
