Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art E.Xhibition Miiniature Works For Several Reasons, Large Nutnber And Small Scale Of Avorks Auiong Tle Nuore Obvious Ones, It Is Not Easy To Deal Fairly Witlh E.Xh-Ibitionis Of Miniature Art, And Tlese Notes On The Tlhirty-Seventlh Annual Exhibition Of The Royal Society Of Miniature Painters, Sculptors, And Gravers At The Arlington Gallery, 22, Old Bund-Street. Iiust Bo Read In The Light Of The Circnwistances. B1Ut, Wiheti Every Allowance Is Made For The Possibility Of Overlooking Something First Rate, The General Mierits Of The Exhibition Do Not Appear To Rise Above Neat Woorkmanship In Little. There Is Variety Of Medium-I-Painting, Sculpture, Engraving, Pottery, Jewelry, And Mietalwork-But Very Few Of The Exhibitors Seem To Be Aware Of The Truthl Contained In Mir. Charles Jobnsons Recent Book On English Painting, That The Miniature Should Be Something Otlher Than Fullsized Portraituie Reduced In Scale. What Is Generally Wanting-In All Mediums-Is A Convention Adapted To The Scale, And, So Far As Painting Is Concerned, To Find A Good Miniature Convention It Is Not Necessary To Go Fartber Than Nicholas Hilliard, Who Laid It Down That The Lyne Without Shadowe Showeth All To Good Judgment, But The Shadowe Without Lyne Showoth Nothing. To Judge By This Exhibition Miniature Painting Began With Samuel Cooper, Though Cosway Is The Liore Favourite Model. One Of The Best Groups, That By The Late Mrs. A. E. Rosalie Emaslie, Recalls Lhim Strongly, And The Work Of Mirs. Emslie Certainly Has The Advantages Of Character And Pleasantly Cool Colour Schemes. Armiong The Few Artists Wlho Appreciate The Advantages Of Lyne In Miiniature Work -Tlhoughi Her Pictures Are Above The Average In Size Is Miss Joan Ayling, And Her Landscape, Vernonnet, And Figure Study, Elizabetlh, Are Refresling Things To Come Upon. For The Rest The Attractions Of The Paintings Are To Be Found Almost Exclusively In The Fact Of Smallness And In Virtuosity-Sometimiies Great Virtuosity-Of Execution. The Morning, Paper, By Mrs. C. B. Klitgaardmay, The Lady Anne Coventry, By Miiss Nellie M. Hepburn Edmunds, Edmund Wimperis, Esq., By Miss Alice Florence Uood, Patience, By Mr. Charles Spencelayh, Shirley, By Miss Miay B. Lee, A Game Of Skill, By Mrs. Winifred N. Zm. Brunton, And The Governor Of The Province, By Miss Violet Brunton, Iriay Be Quoted As Works Above The Average. Mr. S. Arthur Lindsey Has An Ingenious Portrait Of His Liajesty King George V. In Anarnorphosis -That Is To Say, A Distorted Representation, Which, Picked Up By A Curved Reflecting Surface, Appeais Regular And In Proper Proportion-The First To Be Made Since That Of Charles I. The Decorations By Major Sir Nevile Wilkinson Have Their Own Curious Clharnii - And Miniature Paintings Of Flowers-The Group By Miss Lorna Burgoyne, Apple And Pear In A Blue Jug, In Particular, Shows A Decorative Instinct-Landscapes, Birds, And Dogs Lend Variety Of Subject. Tlle Illuniinated Manuscripts By Mliss Jessie Bayes And Mi-. E. B. Crapper Are Pleasing, Miss Edith Linnell Has Some Good Jewvelry, And Among The Wrorks In Thle Round The Honours Go To Foal, In Glazed Earthenwvare, By Miss Jeanne Bell.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition Mr. Paul Nash Under Tlle General Title Of Page And Scene There Is At The Batsford Gallery, 15, North Audley-Street, A Most Interesting Exhibition Of Designs By Mr. Paul Nash. The Title Suggests Rather More Tha L Was Perhaps Intended, For There Can Be Little Doubt That The Work Of Such Artists As Mr. Nazsh Gains By Sonic Definite Application. It Is Worth Remarking, By The Way, That The Disadvantage Of Abstract Painting Is Not Unlikeness To Nature-A Mosaic Or A Stained Glass Window Is Unlikc Nature In That Sense-But Comparative Unlikeness To Drawing And Painting. In The Case Of The Mosaic Or The Window The Intractability Of The Materials, Easily Recognized By The Simplest Person, Explains The Abstraction, But In The Case Of The More Flexible Mediunm There Is Not The Same Explanation, And The Abstraction Seems Intellectually Rather Than Artistically Determined, At The Expense Of The Medium. But When Mr. Nasli Makes Wood Engravings Or Designs For The Stage Or For Book Decoration, The Circumstances Again Explain The Style, And There Is No Feeling Of A Deliberate Avoidance Of Naturalism. The Most Striking Things In This Exhibition Are The Four Sketch Designs For The Decoration Of Sir Thornas Browvnes Urn Burial And The Garden Of Cyrus. Here Not Only The Style But The Artistic Convention-Roughly That Of Surrealism, Or The Bringing Together Of Objects By Their Subconsciously Felt Association Ratlher Than By Their Consciously Observed Relationseems Exactly Right. These Are Most Excellent Designs.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Entertainments Art Exhibitions The French Gallery The Connecting Link Between The Nine Artists Exhibiting Paintings And Drawings At The French Gallery, 11, Berkeley Square, Is That They Are All More Or Less Recent Graduates Of The Royal College Of Art. Certainly The General Character And Quality Of Their Work Do Credit To That Institution. Graduates, On Reflection, Might Give The Wrong Impression, And The Stage Of Accomplishment Reached Is More Like That Of The Journeyman Painter Under The Good Old Guild System. That Is To Say, The Young Artists Are Out Of Their Apprenticeship But Are Not Yet Masters And This Description Will Suggest Very Conveniently The Kind Of Opportunity Presented To The Discriminating Buyer Or Commissioner Of Pictures. Mr. Barnet Freedman Is The Best Known Of The Nine, And He Appears Here As A Forcible And Accomplished Realistic Painter. His Two Sicilian Puppets Is A First-Rate Piece Of Stilllife Painting, With The Dramatic Effect In The Design Proper To The Subject. There -Is, As Is Common In This Kind Of Work-Based On Visual Rather Than Mental Grasp Of The Mnaterial-Some Uncertainty Of Relationship Between The Puppets And The Panelled Wall-Or Door-Against Which They Are Suspended, But It Is A Minor Defect, And In The Wood, By The Same Artist, With Sharp Lights Through The Trees Reflected In A Pond, Is A Very Good Landscane. Mlr. G. Ososki, Though He Also May Be Called A Realist, Is More Intellectual In His Treatment Of Form, And His Portrait Of The Artists Brothcr Has A Conscious Insistence On The Volumes To Which The Colour Aptly Contributes. It Is Evident That The Common Apprenticeship Has Not Destroyed Individuality, For Each Of The Artists Has His Own Way Of Doing Things. Mr. P. Horton Draws Carefully-His The Garden Path Is Worthi Looking Out Among The Drawings-And Paints, As In The Ironing Board, With Full Gradations While Mr. D. Towner. In Snow On Hampstead Heath And The Garden, 16, Church Row. Hampstead, Seems To Aim At The Values Of Open Tones. Eileen Glane. By Mr. H. Finney, Xwcst Wittering Church, By Mvr. G. Rhoades, Autumn, By Mr. C. Mahoney. Still Life, By Mr. A. Flouthuesen, And Figure Study 2, By Mir. Nf. Rothenstein, Well Represent The Other Exhibitors. Tie Combined Effect Of Young Artists Ready For Employment Makes It Difficult To Understand The Complaints One Hears Of Shirking In The Present Generation. If Anytliing Is Lacking Here It Is Certainly Not Grounding In The Craft. At The Same Gallery There Is An Exhibition Of Water-Colours And Sculpture By Mr. Trevor Tennant. Here, Again, The Imprcssion Is Not So Much Of Very Great Talent As Of General Capability, With An Intelligent Eye To Applications And A Sensible Preparation For Such Opportunities As May Arise. Mr. Tennant Is A Good Carver, Particularly In Wood, And His Work In That Material Appears To Gain In Proportion As It Accepts The Naturalistic Suggestion Of The Grain Rather Than When It Is Aimed At More Abstract Formal Effects. Male Torso, In Yew, And Madonna And Child, In Elm, May Be Quoted. Not That Torso, In Sycamore, Is Not An Exceedingly Graceful Piece Of Simplification-And There Is Good Work In All The Pieces-But That The Dislike Of Representational Interest, Which Seems To Be Constitutional With The Present Generation, Leaves Sculptire Somewhat At A Loose End. If The Aim Be Abstract Form, Why All That Solid Niaterial ? As In The Case Of Painting, The Logical Conclusion Is Architectural Application, Which Explains Away The Material, And Mr. Tennant Seems To Be Alive To This, For Several Of His Pieces, Capital And Panels For A Cottage Fireplace, For Example, Are Designed For An Architectural Setting. His Water-Colours Show The Sculptors Instinct In Their Effort To Define Space Relations By Means Of Colour-As In Harvest In Sussex And Road To Stopham. They Are Most Attractive, However, When This Worthy Aim Is Associated With The Free Calligraphy Which Water-Colour Asks For -As In River At Midhurst And The Rother.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Miss Flora Lion. Flexibility Is As Good A Word As Any To Describe The Eharacteristio Attraction In The Work Of Miss Flora Lion. Hitherto We Have Known Her Almost Exclusively As A Portrait Painter And Draughtswoman, But The Present Exhibition Of 53 Works By Her At Barbizon House, 9,Henrietta-Street, Cavendish-Square, Includes Landscape And Flower Paintings As Well, And They Pleasantly Enlarge The Impression Made By Her Talent. For Practical Purposes Miss Lion Is A Designer In Two Dimiensions, And This, While It May Indicate Some Weakness Of Grasp, Is A Positive Advantage To The Appearance Of Her Exhibition As A Whole. The Walls Are Alive With A Decorative Play Of Line And Colour, But Nothing Comes Forward Into The Room And, In Present Conditions Of Living, The Gain Iln Comfort-Particularly On The Usual Scale Of Portraiture-.More Than Makes Up For The Limitation. As A Portrait Painter We Like Miss Lion Bestwhen She Is Least Like Sir John Lavery, Ra. This, By The Way, Is Not A Backhander At That Eminent Artist, But Only To Suggest That Miss Lions Talent Is Of 3 Different Order, More Sensitive In Line, Mnore Varied In Colour-In A Word, More Feminine And Positive Femininity In Art Is Rare Enough To Be Welcomed With Both Hands. Her Paintings Of Women And Ehildren, In Particular, Fore Intensely Sym-. Pathetic, In Both Character And Arrangement-As If The Artist Painted Clothes And Personal Surroundings In The Spirit In Which They Were Chosen By The Owner. The Designs Are Not Very Complex, But Much Is Made Of Little, With Chief Reliance Upon Responses In Colour. The Most Attractive Portrait Here Is That Of Mrs. Frank Schwab, In White Against A Green Background, Very Well Judged In Tone. The Arms Hang Loosely, And Slightly Outwards, And The Green Of The Back. Ground Is Artfully Brought In By Concrary Movement In A Criss-Cross Of Green Trimming On The Full Skirt. Another Excellent Portrait Is That Of Lady Davis, In A Scale Of Greys, With Her Little Terrier, The Green Of A Spanish Comb Being Repeated In The Collar Of The Animal. In The Landscapes There Is More Penetration Into Depth, But The Attraction Is Still That Of Skilfully Related Colour Values. Isla Di Pescatori, Maggiore Is The Most Solid In Composition, But Evening, Lago Mag. Giore, Primarily A Study Of Space And Light, And Foscari Palace, Vrenice, A Study Of Reflection, Excel It In Charm. From The Flower Paintings Iceland Poppies And White Tulips May Be Picked Out, The Last Being A Little Overweighted By Its Brownish-Purple Background. Her Disinclination To Force Or Harden Her Style Is Not The Least Of Mliss Lions Merits As An Artist.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Corot And Delacroix An Illuminating Comparison Has Been Staged At The Wildenstein Galleries, 147, New Bond Street, Where Eight Paintings By Corot And Ten By Delacroix Are Hung On Opposite Walls. It Is Not A Mere Contrast But A True Comparison Of Two Different Impulses Within What Is Unmistakably The Same School Of Painting. In The One Case There Is An Advance To Colour Through Firm Planning In Tone. And In The Other The Colour Attack Is Direct, With The Drawing Loosened In Sympathy. The Comparison Is Most Pointed Between The Two Figure Subjects, Christine Nillson, With Guitar, By Corot, And Leducation De La Vierge, By Delacroix, Because In The Forwer, A Half-Length Recalling The Pearl In General Composition, Corot Comes As Near To Positive Colour As He Ever Did, And The Reds In The Two Pictures Are Somewhat Similar. In The Delacroix The Figures Are Placed Side By Side In Landscape, But There Is No Division Of Interest. Most Of The Pictures In The Exhibition Arc Unfamiliar, And Le Rtuisseau And La Couir Au Nuits, Normandie,- By Corot, And Junioni Et Eole And Lermite De Copmanhurst Et Le Chevalier - An Illustraltion To Scotts Ivanhoe -By Delacroix, May Be Picked Otit For Special Mention. The Exhibition Includes A Landscape Drawing By Corot And Five Water-Colours Of Arab Subjects By Delacroix. Mir. Philip Nesbirt It Wvould Be Difficult To Say Why The 41 Eccentric Watcr-Colours By Mlr. Philip Nesbitt At The Leicester Galleries Strike One As Character Istically American Except That They Seem Invented Rather Than Imagined, With Their Humorouis Point In Matter-Of-Fact Understatement. Otherwise Tiley Bespeak The Experienced Decorator, And Many Of Them Are Pleasingly Intense In Colour. Fan Ling People. Tahitian Scene. Tea In Ihe Jtiingle, Ald Conscience. Represented By A Green Lizard, Are Touir Good Examples. In Another Room There Is A Second Edition Of 65 Of Ihc Original Paintings On Ceilliloid By Walt Disney And His Collaborators For The Film Sijootn Tvhie Ind Thne Seteit Dwarfs. These Confirm The Impression Made By The Tilm Itself That, Apart From His Fertile And Noetical Invention. Mr. Disnevs Strength Is In Stylization, In Both Form And Colour. This, We Are Persuaded, Is The True Artistic Opportunity Of The Film Designed By Hand. Sir Rabindranath Tacore Apart Irom Illeii Cirtmnistandiai Inercst As The Woi K Of A P,Ct. Thc 44 Paintings By Sir Rabindranath Tagore At The Ca.Mann Gallery, 42, St. Jamess Pliace., Are Remarkable For Their Variety Of Effect. Though An Automatic Character Is Pretsent In These Paintings. They Do Not End With It But Respond To A Dozen Different Forma! Intentions Now Square. As In Sitting Man. Now Angular, As In A Ride, And Now Curved, As In Ttirkey. They Are Less Traditionai As We Tiiderstand The Word In Connexion With Indian Art Ihan Suwaecstive Of Aboriginal Hautintings. As If The Artist Had Access To The Very Soulrncs O The Native School. Fill Of Imagination, Vith A Richniess Of Colour That Is Enhanced Bv The Use Of Lark Tones- Cc Fantisy. Floeers. Anld Head 22 -And Seductive In Quality Of Substance, These Paintings Are Well Worth Seeing. In Complete Sympathy Therc Is Being Exhibited With Ithem A Mask In Silvered Bronze Of Mrs. Stelia Kramrisch, The Indian Archaeolo,Ist, By Mrs Else Fraenkel. Closed Eyes Give An Effect O Withdrawal. Imd The Actual Substance Of The Work Is Bcautiully In Accord With Its Subtlety Of Expressioln. Mr. Georges Loukoniski At The Batsford Gallery, 15, North Audley Street, Mr. Georges Loukomski, Who Established His Reptitationi With A Remarkable Series Of Diawings Of Old Synagogues In .Ost Of The Conintri- Of Eutope, Is Showing 60 Iccce Drawings In Colour Of Interesting London Buildings Of The Seventeenth, Eighteenth, And Early Nineteenthi Ceniuries. Having A Profound Knowledge Of Architecture, Mr. Loukomski Is Able To Combine Veracity With Freedom In His Representations, I.. Which Some Heaviness Of Tone, If Pictorially To Be Regretted. Is Felt To Be In Accord With Ihc Character Of The Subjects. It Is Clear That The Powers Of The Artist Rise In Proportion To The Quality Of The Architecture, And The Centre Of Interest In The Exhibition Is The Group Of Six Diraxings Of Somerset House. Miss Susan Palmer Freshness Of Outlook, Charm Of Colour, And Freedom Of Style Are Combined In The 40 Pastels By Miss Susan Palmer At The Storran Gallery, 5, Albany Court Yard. Miss Palmer Appears To Have A Natural Turn For The Baroque In Architecture. And Some Of Her Happiest Effects Are From Churches In Rome. Dome Of Saintandrea Al Quirinale. Seen In Perspective As A Gold Spiral, Comes First. But S. Maria Dellorto, St. Peters, Interior, Dome In Rome, And Apse Of The Gesu, Rome Are All Excellent Studies. It Is Not. Usual To Comment On Prices, But Miss Palmers Lyrical Freshness Is Equalled By The Modesty Of Her Expectations. At The Same Gallery There Are 17 Interesting Figure Compositions In Gotiache By A Young French Painter, M. Mablord. A Hint Of Manets Dejeuner Sur Therbe In One Of Them Leads Back To What Seems To Be The Common Inspiration Of Them All-That Is To Say, The Giorgione Type Of Picture, With The Figure Seated On The Ground To Decide Its Characteristic Movement. Nos. 3, 5, 7, And 9 May Be Quoted. Mr. Adrian Hill The Exhibition Of 44 Water-Colours By Mtr. Adrian I-Till At The Brook Street Galleries Gives The Impression Of Great Competency, Which However, So Far From Being Mcchanical, Responds To Each Subject Or Motive With A Change Of Stvle. The Change Of Treatment, As Between Cotswold Village And A Showery Day. For Instance. Is Indeed- Remarkable, Tlie Common Character In The Water-Colours Being Directness And Freedom Of Handling. Mir. A. S. C. Butler At The Adams Gallery, 2, Pall Mall Place, There Is An Exhibition Of 44 Water-Colour Drawings By Mr. A. S. G. Butler, Who Is Professionallv An Architect. Madc In Various Parts Of England And Europe, Bohemia In Particular, They Illustrate In The Most Interesting Manner The Problems That Arise In The Transference Of A Talent From One Art To Another. Some Of The Subjects Are Architectural, And In Them It Is Evident That The Artist Has Hesitated Between The Claims Of The Mistress Art And A Pictorial Impulse. Actually, With One Or Two. Exceptions, The Best Of The Water-Colours Are Those That Escape Into Terms Of Colour And Tone, In More Or Less Pure Landscape. Nicholson Gallery Under The General Title Of Pictures For The Grown-Up Child- There Is At The Nicholson Gallery, 45, St. Jamess Place, An Entertaining Exhibition Of 40 Paintings In Oil, Tempera And Water-Colour, Drawings, Collages And Small Pieces Of Sculpture. Few Of The Works Are Humorous- Joys Of Summer, Which Looks Like A Contemporary Jerome Bosch, By Mr. Walter Trier, And Baby Camel, In Terracotta, By Mr. Raoh Schorr. Might Come Into That Description-The Intention Being Rather To Encourage People To Come Off The Perch And Enjoy Their Art As Naturally As They Might Their Dinner. Point Is Given To The Intention By The Circunistance That One Of The Pictures, A Road Accident, By Mr. Tristram Hillier. Is Tragical In Subject. It Is Taken Seriously, And With Poignancy, But, As A Picture, It Lends Itself To The Same Kind Of Enjoyment As The Others. There Is Quite A Lot Of Artistic Philosophy N This Little Picture. To Make A Selection- The Estuary, By Mr. Morland Lewis. Portrait Of Mr. Dylan Thomas, Bymr.Augustus John, Autumn Hedge, By Miss Nicolette Macnamara, The Beach, Honfleur, By Mr. Anthony Devas, And Regatta, By Mr. John Armstrong, Are All Pictures To Make One Happy In The Right Way. The Exhibition Includes A Collection Of Trompe-Lmils Mostly Eighteenthi Century, Which Work Out Surprisingly Like Surrealist Designs Of An Abstract Persuasion.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Etchings. Mtixed Exhibitions Of Etchings Are All Much Alike, But There Gre Two At The Moment Which May Have A Few Words In Passing. At The Abbey Gallery, 2, Victoria-Street, The Note Is That Of Extreme Variety, From Zorn To Miss Eileen Soper In Date, And, In Quality, From Sir D. Y. Cameron And Mr. Muirhead Bone To Etchers. Of The Popular Kind. There Are 86 Etchings And Drypoints In All, And If We Name The Turkish Fort, Cairo, By Sir D. Y. Cameron, The Rt. Hion. Sir E. J. Clarke, By Alr. Malcolm Osborne, T-He Harvester8, By Mr.. L. F. Tunnicuffe, Strindberg, By Zorn, The Paint Room, Covent Garden, By Mtr. Ian Strang, An Archway, Chioggia, By Mir. Muirhead Bone, And The Studio Coat, By The Late Mr. Claude Shepperson, An Idea Will Be Formed Of. The More Serious Resources Of The Exhibition. At The Beaux Arts Gallery, 1, Bruton-Place, The Variety Is In Medium, Colour Etchings And Line Engravings Being Included, And There Are A Fewv Proofs By Good Artists Wvho Are Not Yet Familiar As Etchers. Reedbuck Feeding, By Mr. John Skeaping, The White Bull, By 3Mr. W. Staite Murray-The Potter-And A Lear Subject, Blow Winds, By Mr. Edmund J. Sullivan, Are Examples. The Line Engraver Is Mr. William E. C. Morgan, Who Has A Somewhat Richer Style Than Is Common In Modern Practice. Ohieto Roofs Is His Most Attractive Proof. Twenty One Gallery. Mrr. Ralph Fisher Skelton, Who Shows Paintings And Drawings At The Twenty One Galery, 15, Mill-Street, Stri ,Es Us As Being Intended For The More Deliberate Kind Of Portraiture. He Draws Well And Firmly, And Is Clearly Interested In Character, His Weakness Being In Tone Relations, Particularly As Between Figure And Background. All His Portraits Are Better Drawn Than They Look, Owing To Parts Being Pushed Out Of Plane By False Values, And They Are Nicely Placed On The Canvas From A Lnear Point Of View. Mnime. Georges Kopp, In Costume A Study In Compared Whites, Is The Most Pleasing. Holbeinesque Is The Convenient Description For Mr. Skeltons Kind Of Portraiture. Some Figure And Landscape Drawings By The Same Artist Confirm The Impression That His Instincts Are For Line Rather Than Mass. Tvwo Water-Colours Of Arctic Scenes, However, Show A Feeling For Space That The Figure Subjects Would Not Smiss Jean Clark, Who Shows Oil And Watercolour Paintings At The Eame Gallery, Seenis To Be Working From Careful Realism Towards Free Expression, With A Certain Amount Of Liberty In The. Treatment Of Form. Sussex Farm, In The Former, And The Checkered Cloth, In The Latter Manner, Are Her Two Best Efforts, The Second-With A Cut Pinenpple To Contrast With The Grey Cloth-Bemg Very Pleasing In Colour. Art At The Stores. -Ot To Be Regarded As An Oidiinary Art Exhibition, But Interesting In Its Bearings And Implications, There Is At The Army And Nvv Stores, Victoria-.Stteet, The Second Annual Arts And Crafts Exhibition Of The Victoria Athletic Association, Composed Exclusively Of The Employees Of The Stores. The Advantage Of Handicrafts To People Engaged Mainly In Clerical And Distributive Occupations Need Not Be Underlined, And By A Wise Provision Nobody Is Allowed To Send In Work Asociated With Their Professional Activities. It Is, Essentially, An Exhibition Of Hobbles. Thus, One Of The Best Of The Water-Colours, Chesil, Is By A Hairdresser, And The First Prze In All Sections, The Dr. Bennett Mremorial Bowl-In Memory Of The Late Medical Officerhas Gone To A Beautifully Designed And Finished Model Of A Motor-Car In Wood By An Assistant In The Seed Department. The Range Of Exhibits Is Extremely Wide, Firom Oil And Water-Colour Paintings To Cakes-And Even Poetry Is Incltided. Among The More Accom71Ished Tuings, Besides Those Mentioned, Are Somre Still Life Paintings In Oil, An Elaborate Crochet Tea-Cloth, And A Set Ofdrawings Of The Bigure And Drapery By. A Young Land,Y Wnb Sconfesses To A Taste For Sign-W Thei Man King Of Plans.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Marine Etchings Whatever May Be Said About Them From A Purely Artistic Point Of View, The Etchings By The Late Mlr. W. L. Wyllie, R.A., At The Rembrandt Gallery, 5, Vigostreet, Cannot Fail To Give Pleasure To Anybody Witli A Taste For Shipping-Or For Riverside London, For The Matter Of That. Perhaps What Most Distinguished Mlr. Wyllie Among Artists Dealing With Similar Subjects Was The Ease With Which He Wore His Knowledge And His Complete Freedom From The Airs Of A Discoverer. Nothing Marked Him More Surely Of His Generation Than This Habit, Comparable To That Of The Older Scholars, Of Taking For Granted What People Nowadays Are Apt To Plume Themselves Upon. In The Course Of Studying His Material For Pictorial Purposes He Must Have Had Inany Adventures And Seen Strange Sights, But There Is Never A Hint In His Wvork Of What Went To The Making Of The Picture. He Would, One Feels, Have Considered It Bad Manners To Hint At The Means In Presenting The End. As Will Be Remembered, Mr. Wyllie Made His Reputation With His Painting, Noxv In The Tate Gallery, Toil, Glitter, Grime, And Wealth. It Is Represented In The Present Exhibition By An Etching, Made After It, And, Though A Good Many Deep Sea Subjects Are Included, The Exhibition Does Resolve Itself Largely Into A Series Of Impressions Of London River. There Are Several General Views, Such As Westminster From St. Iauls And The City Of London, And There Are Studies Of Most Of The Bridges. Vaterloo Bridge Was Etched As Recently As Last Year. In These Impressions Mlr. Wylie Subordinated Everything To The General Conditions Of Light, Atmosphere, And Movement, But Every Detail Is Found On Examination To Be Based Upon Intimate Knowledge. There Is Very Little Suggestion That He Was Interested In The Craft Of Etching For Its Own Sake Be Found It Suitable For His Purposes, And The Rest Was A Matter Of Getting The Maximum Of Effect Out Of The Workmanship. Many Of Us Would Prefer A Style Of Greater Economy, But, Given What Mr. Wyllie Set Out To Do, It Is Difficult To See How He Could Have Spared The Needle. A Stiff Breeze, Homeward Bound Brig, Medway Barge Race. Rounding The Buoy, And Custom House May Be Named As Prints Of Special Interest.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Abt Bxhibitions. The Perilous Honour Of Painting The Jubilee Celebration In Westminster Abbey Vwas Conferred Upon Mr. W. E. Lockhart, A Member Of The Royal Scottish Academy And Of The Royal Water-Colour Society, And An Artist Whose Work Is Favourably Known Both In Edinburgh And In London. The Picture Is Now Finished, And Is On View In A Gallery In Pall-Mall East, Which Has Been Exteraporized Out Of A Portion Of The Building Which Used To Be Known As Waterloo-House-An Excellent Gallery, By The Way, In Which Pictures Look Their Est. There Is No Need To Dwell Upon The Diifflculties Of Mr. Lockharts Task, For Every One Knows How Thanukless, Generally Speaking, Is The Labour Employed Upon The Representation Of These State Pageants. We May Say At Once That The Painter As Succeeded Better Than Almost Any Of His Predecessors Who Have Undertaken Similar Works During The Queens Reign, And That His Picture Will Stand Out, Among The Series Of Royalweddings And The Like, As The Work Of A Very Clever Artist, Who Has Known How To Compose His Picture Ingeniously And To Paint Not Inexpressive Portraits. The Artist Is Supposed To Stand On The South Side I Of The Altar In The Immediate Foreground Are The Archbishops, The Dean Of Westminster, The Bishops, Canons, And Other Clergyj Just Beyond Are Two Lines Of Royal Personages, Jgs, Princes, And Princesses, European And Lndian Her Majesty In The Coronation Chair Is In The Centre Of The Picture. To Her Left, In The North Transept, Are A Certain Number Of Members Of The House Of Commons, Easily Recognizable, And In The Gallery Overlooking The Sacrarium Are Portraits Of Various Yell-Known People, Such As Thelate Mr.Browning, Eir Frederic Leighton, And Afr. Irving. The Artist Had To Paint Likenesses Without Sacrificing The General Effect Of His Picture, And Mr. Lockhart May Be Congratulated On Having Satisfied The Difficult Conditions Of His Problem To An Unhopedfor Degree. His Abilities Are Also Well Shown In The Series Of Studies From The Life Which Hang Round The Gallerywalls, And In The Loan Collectionof Certain Finished Pictures In Oil And Water Colours Which Represent His Artistic Performance During The Last 15 Or 20 Years. The Studies Are Specially Life-Like It Would Be Difficult To Beat, In This Sketchy Manner, The Portraits Of Mnr. Gladstone And Archdeacon Farrar. The Jubilee Picture Is To Be Reproducede In Photogravure By The Berlin Photographic Company, But We May Remark That The Charge Which It Is Proposed To Make For The So-Called Artists Proof S-20 Gumineas-Seems To Us To Be Altogether Unwarrantable. Photogravures Cost Very Little To Produce They Are, After All, Only Photographs Slightly Touched Up By An Artist, And Printed From A Plate, And -Thereisabsolutely No Difference In Artistic Quality Between What Is Called The Artists Proof And Any Other State Of The Plate. The Summer Exhibition Of The Hanover Gallery, In New Bond-Street, Which Has Lately Opened, Contains A Certain Number Of Good Pictures, Including La Charrue, An Excellent Little Example Of Rosa Bonheur, Some Small Works By Troyon, Corot, Courbet, And Other Deceased French Masters, A Few Battle Pieces By Bernebellecour, Boutigny, And Others, And Some Works Of A Very Clever Parisian Painter, Raffaeli, Including A Rather Vulgar Caricature Of A Salvation Army Meeting. Some Large Pictures Of The Nude By Professor Graef, Of Berlin, Are Also Included In The Exhibition. Among These Is One Called The Persecution Of Fantasy, Which He Painted As A Satire Upon Those Who Had Brought Certain Charges Against Him For Which He Was Put On His Trial. The Morals Of The Pictures May Pass, But The Art Is Heavy And Germanic. The Best Of Herr Graefs Pictuires, That Which He Calls Milbrchen 48, Represents An Entirely Unpaintable Subject, And Fails To Tell Its Own Story. One Turns From It With Relief To The Rosa Bonheur Of Which We Have Spoken, And To The Lovely Corot Opposite One Of Those Silvsry And Transparent Studies Of Moist Light In -Which The Oldl Painter Showed His Astonishing Mastery Of The Brush. At The Fine Art Societys Gallery, In New Bond-Street, The Large Room Is Now Siled With Pictures And Sketches Of Animal Life By The Wellknown Belgian Orbelgian-Dutchpainter, Madame Henriette Ronner. Individual-Pictures Of Hers Have Frequently Been Seen In The Loaddon Exhibitions, But This, Wve Believe, Is The First Time That A Collection Of Them Has Been Brought Together Here. She Has Few Rivals In The Painting Of Cats, Especially Those Soft Persian Cats And Kittens Which Look So Innocent In Their Drawing-Room Surroundings, And Which Yet Possess Such Infinite Possibilities Of Taischief And Worse. A Turbulent Family 65-Kittens Rolling Over And Around An Empty Cage, A Longing Look 70-A Persian Cat With All Her Tigerish Instincts Aroused By The Sight Of A Canary Whats Oclock ? 76-Kittens Wreaking Their Wicked Will Upon A Fine Old Timepiece In Pictures Like This Madame Ronner Is At Her Best. She Is A Trained Observer Of The Forms And Manners Of Animals, And As A Colourist Her Achievement Is Considerable. Some Pictures Of Dogs Are Portraits Painted For The Queen Of The Belgians And The Countess Of Flanders, And Are Goqd In Their Way, But They Hardly Show The Sympathetic Skill Which Wenotice In The Painters Cat Pictures. In This Latter Department She Is, As The Writer Of The Note To The Catalogue Says, A Rival Of Eugbne Lambert, Though In Delicacy And Lightness Of Touch The Water-Colours Of The Latter Painter Are Supreme. We Are Glad That London Should Have A Sight Of Mr. Miadox Browns New Fresco Before It Takes Its Place In The Series Which This Veteran Artist Has Now Nearly Comnpleted For The Manchester Townhall. It Is True That It Cannot Be So Well Judged In Messrs. Dowdeswells Gallery, Where It Is Now Exhibited, As It Nvill Be Gn Situ, With The Appropriate Surroundings Of The Building For Which It Is Intended, But This Composition, Representing The Incident In Old Manchester History Of John Kay At Work Upon His Loom, Is Still Very Interesting, Wherever One Sees It. The Characteristics Of Hitr. Madox Browns Art Are Well Known, And The Eact That He Represents A School Which Has Now Few Professors Among Us Ought Not To Lessen Our Appreciation Of The Picture. Mr. William Strang, To Whose Plates We Have Frequently Called Attention At The Society Of Painter-Etchers, Has Now Exhibited A Complete Series Of His Etchings At Mr. Dunthornes Gallery In Vigo-Street. No Fewer Than 150 Plates Bear Witness To The Industry As Well As To The Talent Of This Excellent Pupil Of Professor Legros, Who Seems Onlv To Want Self-Confidence And A Resolve To Proceed Independently To Place Him Very High Among The Etchers Of To-Dii.Y. Miessrs. Tooth Have Secured For Their Gallery In The Eaymarket The Most Important Rwater-Colour Drawing That M!Tdlle. Rosa Bcnheurhas Painted For A Long Time, Representing Her Favourite Eighland Cattle In Their Native Haunts. This Interesting Tvork Is Now On View.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Nothing Could, Form A Better Supplement To The? Exhibition At Burlington-House Than The Collection Of English Water-Colour Ait During The 19Th. Century, Which Is Being Shown By The Fine Art Society, In Their Rooms In New Bond-Street. It Has Been Formed On A Deliberate Plan, And, Atleast Bo Far As Deceased, Artists Are Concerned, No Pains Have Been Spared To Make It Really Representative, The First Room Is Hung With The Drawings Of The Early Painters, The Men Whose Glory It Is To Have Founded The English School Which Was Afterwards To Be Enriched And Strengthened Bythe Genius Of Turner And David Cox. It Would Not Be Easy To Find Better Examples Of Such Men As J. R. Cozens And Paul Sandby Than, We Can See In This Room, And If In Looking At Them We Cannot Quite Understand The Enthusiasm Which Led Constable To Speak Of Cozens As The Greatest Genius That Ever Touched Landscape, We Can At Least Admire The Simplicity And Purity Of The Talent Which Produced These Delicate Southern Drawings. His Palette Was Very Limited, But, As Mr. Roget And Other Historians Have Pointed Out, This Was A Necessity In Those Days, When The Manufacture Of Colours For The Water-Colour Artist Was Very Much Restricted. The Chief Beauty Of Cozenss Drawings, The Beauty Which So Greatly Commended Them To Turner That He Condescended To Copy A Great Number Of Them, Lies In Their Transparency And Atmospheric Depth. In This He Was Supreme Till Turner Came, Whereas Paul Sandby, Malton, And Others, By Whom There Are Excellent Works To Be Seen Here, Excelled In Their Drawings Of Buildings And In Placing Figures In Their Landscapes In A Manner Full Of Life And Character- Others Of The Early Men, Who Are Well Represented Here, Are John Varley, And, A Little Later, George Barret, Of Whose Luminous Skies And Somewhat Conventional Compositions There Are Several Fine Examples. By Girtin, Who Might Have Been So Great Had He Lived Longer, There Is Unfortunately Nothing Very Remarkable. J. M. Wright, The Genre Painter, Has One Very Clever Drawing But All These Are Preludes To The Great Period Represented In The Next Room, Where A Few Fine. Turners, Some Noble Works By Cox And De Wint, And Other Drawings By Their Contemporaries Lead On To The Last Generation, Where Thomas Collier And H. G. Hine Among The Landscape Painters, And G. J. Pinwell Among The Imaginative Figure Painters, Are Conspicuous. It Is Pleasant To See Again Pinwells Two Drawings In Illustration Of The Pied Piper, Drawings So Well-Known From The Etchings Had The Artist Been As Happily Inspired And As Thorough, In His Other Works As He Is In These Brilliant Performances, His Name Would Have Ranked Quite As High As That Of Frederick Walker. A Little Group Of Early Drawings By Rossetti And Burne-Jones Fitly Brings This Little Collection Of Deceased Masters Works To A Conclusion, And Leads To An Interesting Roomful Of Drawings By The Men Of To-Day. We Cross The Street And Find Ourselves, By Way Of An Extreme Contrast, Among The French Impressionists, Brought Together In The Hanover1 Gallery. It Is Curious Indeed That Both The English Water-Colour School And The French Impressionists Owe Much To The Same Mighty Genius,, That Of Turner. But They Read The Lesson Of Thorn Aster Very Differently. The Story Goesprobably There Is Not Much Truth In Itthat Claude Monet I Became An Impressionist After A Visit To The Turner Boom At The National Gallery Certainly His Effort From The Beginning Has Been To Grapple More And. More With The Same Problem Which Vexed The Mind Of Turner Throughout His Latter Years, The Problem Of Painting Light. It Is Said By One Of The Newest Of French Critics, M. Etienne Bricon, In His Recently-Published Psychologic Dajrt, That Monet Owed Much, To The Veteran Chemist Chevreul And His Researches Into The Laws Of Colour, And That The Efforts Of The Painter Have Been A Never-Ending Effort To Express In Art Some Of The Variety In Tones Which Chevreul Proved To Exist Even In What Seem To Be Uniformly-Coloured Natural Objects. Whether His Efforts Will Ever Commend Themselves To The London Public, As, Thanks To The Guidance Of Some Clever Writers And The Enthusiasm Of Some Young Painters, They Have Done To The Public Of Paris And New York, May Well Be Doubted. But In Such Work As Geltie Blanche, Giverny 19, In The Quiet And. Beautifully Composed Landscapes Of Sisley, And In The Charming Portraits Of M. Renoir, Even Those Whose Eye Has Been Trained To Admire De Wint And Constable And Millais May Find An Art That Is Interesting And Undoubtedly Sincere. Two Small Shows In Bond-Street Claim A Visit And A Few Words. At Messrs. Dowdeswells, Mr. C. J. Collings Has Some Landscape Drawings Of A Kind That Is At Once Individual And Charming, Deriving Not A Little From Modern Impressionist Methods, But Evidently The Work Of A Trained Draughtsman. At No. 118, Mr. J. B. Yeats Shows A Few Sketches Of Life In The West Of Ireland. Very Modern Also And Very Clever, Especially The Horses And The Men Who Are Watching Them. In The Haymarket, At Messrs. Tooths, M. Georges Scott, A French Artist Who Has Been To South Africa, Has Three Well-Painted War Pictures, Representing Elandslaagte.The Surrender Of Cronje, And The Final Crossing Of The Tngela, Like All Pictures Which Aim At Representing The Clear Southern Atmosphere, These Are A Little Raw In Colour But As Pictures Of Events They Are Spirited And Impressive.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. The Fine Art Society. Woodouts And Lithographs, Though There Are Some Good Etchings, Provide The Chief Interest In The Exhibition Of The Graphic Society Of Holland At The Galleries Of The Fine Art Society, 148, New Bond. Street. Most Of The Wood-Engravers Incline To Effects In Sheer Black And White, Rather Than To The Tone Gradations Of Our Own Contemporary Workers, As If They Designed For The Wall Rather Than For The Printed Page. The Exhibition Opens With A Very Entertaining Group Of Works By 3Mr. Peter Ahna, In Which The Subjects Are, So To Speak, Disintegrated And Their More Characteristic Elements Re-Assembled In A Decorative Pattern. Two Of The Most Distinguished Designs-Reflecting Japanese Influence-Are Fish And Diving Fish, By Mr. J. G. Veldlieer, And There Is An Excellent Group Of Animals By Mr. S. Jessurin De Mesquita. In The Landscapes By Mr. B. Essers- Harvest For A Good Example-There Is A Careful Translation Of Detail Into Terms Of Engraving, Together With A Fine Feeling For Solidity In The Composition As A Whole. The Etching Aunt, By Mr. J. Dykstra, Confirms The Belief That An Aunt Is A Type Rather Than A Relative, And Other Proofs Of Special Interest Are May, By Mr. J. Franken, Virgin Downs, By Mr. J. Mn. Graadt V. Roggen, October, By Mir. Edz. Koning, Trafalgar-Square, By Mir. Jan Poortenaar, And Pieta, By Mr. K. Van Veen. There Is A Group Of Characteristic Etchings By Mr. Marius Bauer, Whose Work Is Well Known In This Country. The Specimens Of Ty,Pography Designed By Mr. S. H. De Roos, On The Table, Should Not Be Overlooked. The Page Of Grotius Is Extremely Beautiful. With Its Fieedom From Portentousness And Air Of Experiment, The Whole Exhibition Is Very Pleasing. The Water-Colours Of Sun, Rocks And Flowers In Dalmatia, Istria, And The Dolomites, By Mr. Giorgio De Wolff, A Dalmatian Artist, In Another Room, Are More Remarkable For Technical Than Artistic Qualities, Being Rather Photographic In Vision, Though Broad Enough In Execution. They Are Not, To Speak The Truth, Very Sunny, A Peculiar Sallowness Of Colour Prevailing In The Landscapes. But They Show An Astonishing Command Of The Medium In Elaborate Drawings On A Large Scale. The Best Of Them Are Of Full Subjects, With A Good Deal Of Variety In Colour, Such As A Peasant Garden, Colfosco And A Rockery In Istria.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Miniature Art To Judge By The Thirty-Eighth Annual Exhibition Of The Royal Society Of Miniature Painters,Sculptots, And Gravets At The Arlington Gallery, 22, Old Bond Street, To Ask For Something On The Hilliard Model Is To Be A Voice Crying In The Wilderness. Except A Fewv Of The Flower Studies, Such As The Group By Miss Lorna Burgoyne, Which Exploit The Resources Of Line And Colour Pattern, Everything Is ,Nodelled In Light And Shade, And The Attempts To Escape Frohi This Convention By Means Of A Free Aiid Sketchy Style, As In The Work Of Mir. Chris Adams, Do Not Excite Much Enthusiasm. There Is Still The Avoidance Of A Decorative Flatness, With The Emrphasis Upon Line Drawing, Which See-Lms To Us The Ideal In Miniature Wvork. The Portrait Which Comes Nearest To The Ideal Is That Of A Boy, John Scobell Armstrong, By Miss Joan Ayling. It E Would Have Gained By A More Definitely Linear Treatnient, But With Its Colour Scheme Of Beige-Or Buff-On Green And Free Gilt Lettering On The Background, It Is A Very Charming Piece Of Work. Otherwise The Modelled Convention Has To Be Accepted, The Difference Between One Work And Another Being Mainly In Certainty Of Drawing And Comparative Looseness, Or Tightness, Of Execution. If The Work Is To Be Modelled, Or Shaded, We Do Not See Any Particular Gain In Avoiding The Peculiar Virtuosity Of The Miniature Painter, And Pi-Eference Generally Goes To Work In Which It Is Carried Pretty Far. Examples Are An Orphan, The Diploma Work Of Mviss Mabel Buchanan, Shirley, By Ntiss May B. Lee, Retta, By Miss Enid Marjorie Vale, Billie, By Nliss N. Hepburh Edmunds, And The Groups By Mr. Percy Buckman, Nirs. Violet Bruntonaugless-Wvho Pleases Bv Her Restraint In Colour-And Mrs. Nitnifred M. N. Brunton, Who Has The Interest Of Her Egyptian Subjects. Miniature Landscapes, Flowers, And Imiscellaneous Subjects Afford Welcome Relief, And Among Them Blue Amazon Parrot, By Mrs. Frances E. Young, Dicentra, By Miss Enid M1. Vale, Cottages At Hythe, By Mr. S. Dominic F. Tringpearce, Arid We Two, By Miss M. Grace Mead, May Be Mentioned. The Miniature Sculptures Do Not Amount To Very Much, The Most Successftil Pieces Being Grazing Foal, By Miss Jeanne Bell, Tapits, By Mliss Stella R. Crofts, Both In Glazed Pottery, Ahd Sea Fantasv, In Bronze, By Miss Doris Le-Cocq. Major Sir Nevile R. Wilkinson Is Represented Bv Design For Titanias Palace, And There Are Illurninated Manuscripits By Miss Edith B. Crapper And Miss Jessie Bayes. M Mr. And Mrs. Blakeney Ward Not Often Is The Work Of Husband And Wife So Clearly Contrasted As It Is In The Exhibition Of Pictures By Mir. And Mrs. C. Iliakeney Ward At The Palser Gallery, 27, King Street, St. Jamess. It Is Riot Only That Mrs. Ward Shows Exclusively Portraits In Pastel, Wvhile Mr. Ward Is Represented By Andscapes And Flowver Studies In Oil, But That The Whole Character Of The Work Is Different. As Is Often The Case, The Immediate Effect Of Efficiency Is On The Ferinine Side, While Mr. Wvard Has The Advantage In Taste And Subtlety. Mrs. Ward Is, Indzed, An Extrenmely Efficient Portrait Artist. She Does Not Go Very Deep Into Character, Nor Has She Any Great Originality In Design, But She Drawvs And Constructs Well, Her Figures Are Generally Wc Planted In The Picture Space, And Her Broad Celfcts Of Colour, If Superficial, Are Generally Harmonious. H-Cr Use Of Pastel, Too, Though We Prefer Slighter E-Lects In This Medium, Is Direct And Unworried. On Its Own Lines Mrs. Tyiden, Ih Red Against A Dark Blue Background, Is An Immensely Competent Portrait, And As Examples Of Grcater Freedohl, With More Research In Colour, The Half-Lengths Of Miss Helena Perrott And Miss Peggy Black May Be Named. That Mrs. Ward Herself Would Prefer A Slighter Use Of Pastel Is Suggested B The Delightful Head Of The Spanish Baby. To Turn To The Work Of Mr. Ward Is To Exchange Evident Skill For A Sensitive Taste In Colour And An Appreciation Of Subtle Rhythims In Design. Spring Garden, In Wvhich The Movement Of The Paths Is Accepted As A Theme And Continued In The Play Of Branches, Is An Almost Perfect Little Picture Of Its Kind Rotten Row 30 Years Ago Has, Besides Its Documentary Interest, Rich Qualities Of Tone, And I Plum Blossom, Sparliing In Front Of A Cottage, And Spring In Wales Are Both Excellent Smail Landscapes. The Still-Life Paintings, Too, Such As Chinese Pagoda, Screened By A Branch Of Winter Jasmine, And Flowcr Studs, In Whici Scarlet Martagon Lilies Are Patterned Upon A Silvery Arabesque, Give Every Evidencc Of Artistic Intention. The London Artists Association At A First Glance And In Thc Mass The Paintings Of Mr. Claude Rogers, Who, Together With Mr. John Dodgson, Has An Exhibition At The London Artists Association, 92, New Bond Street, Seem Very Serious, But Rather Bleak. He Has A Preference For Cold, Dark Colours, And In Particular For Those Disquieting Greens And Purples Which Were Popular With The Upholsterers Of Tihe Last Century. And His Designs, Though Thorough, Arc Often Strict And Academic. But All This Is What One Would Expect Of A Serious Iainter At The Beginning Of His Career, And It I. Best To Ignore The Obvious Asperity Of Many O. These Works And To Look For The Signs Of A Frecr Sensibility Woich Will No Doubt Have More Play When The Artist Has Worket Through His Necessary Exerciscs. It Is Clear That Mr. Rogers Has A Delicate Sense Of Colour When He Allows Himsclf To Use It. Thouzh The Prevailing Impression Or His Still Life No. I May Be Sombre. It Cantains Many Deicate Passages. His Self Portrait Seems To Bc An Essay In The Manner Of Cezanne. And Thc Range Of Colour Is Extraordinarily 19! C4Zannes. But It Is A Sound And Original Imitation, Very Solid In Its Modelling, And It Is Clear That Mr. Rogers Has Really Understood The Colours Which He Has Borrowed. His Cssays In The Manner Of Mr. Sickert, Of .,Hich Pechaps The Best Is Chocolates-Cigatettes ! Are By No Ma.,S Superficial. In His Water-Colours, And Cspe2Nily In An Interior Of A Theatre, Mr. Rogers Shows That He Can Draw Agreeably And Elegantly. Mr. Dodgson Is Equally Serious, But There Is A More Obvious Contrast Betwecn His Sensibility And The Organiz.. Ion, The Framework, Which He Finds For It. In A Small Landscape, Le. Salettes, He Has Observed The Scene With Grcat Delicacy, But In Many Of His Larger Piintings He Has Imposed, As If From Without, A Hard And Geometrical Design On The Sensitive Gradation1S Of Colour And The Gentle Modelling Which Scems To Con.C Naturally To Him. At The Cooling Galleries, In The Same Building, Is An Exhibition Of The Work Of Five Artists. Miss Ccelia Bedford Draws With Considerable Accuricy And Includes A Good Deal Of Detail. Btit Cvcrything Is Set Down With So Much Refinement That She Is Often Able To Substitute For The False Emphasis Of Descriptive Drawing A Subdued And Agrieable Rhythm. Betty With A Broom Is Ah Excellent Etampic Of Her Figure Subjects, And Daffbdil Fields, Holland, Of Her Landscapes. Miss Htlebtfgbfdon Duff, Thoutgh Her Works Arc Unequal, Has A Very Pleasant Sense Of Colour And Is Atble To Use With Real Originality Both Bright And Gay Colours, As In Katinka, And More Gloomy Colours, As In Orchids. Miss Mabel Doylcy. Seldom Has Anything Original To Say In Her Still-Lifc -Ubjectsbut Her Lahdscape Ebury Sqiuare Is Very Plcasant In Colour And The Space Is Well Organized. Miss Ethel Deane Burdetts Landscapes And Still-Life Subjects Arc Painted With Vigour And Freedom, But They Arc Somewhat Harsh In Colour. Miss Mary Mcneile Seems To Be A Grnibine And Natural Impressionist. Not Only Is She Something Of A Pbintillist And Can Catch An Cffect Of Light Very Well, But She Scems To Like Taking Hcr Subjects From An Odd And Accidental View-Point.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Portrait Drawings. Remarkable For Firmness Rather Than Sensibility, The Portrait And Other Drawings By Professor William Rothenstein At The Redfern Gallery, 27, Old Bond-Street, Bear Witness Against Woolly Thinking And Slipshod Execution. They Are So Bracing. Occasionally, It Must Be Admitted, They Are Bracing At Some Expense To What One Feels To Be The Character Of The Subject. Thus, E. M. Forster, In A Half-Length, Has A Little The Look Of Refusing To Declare Himself With No Uncercain Voice To Professor Rothensteins Informed Leading -Questions About A Passage To India Laurence Binyon Shows The Official Rather Than The Poetical Side Of His Temperament And The Engaging Helplessness Of R. Vaughan Williams Has Been Hardened Out Of Recognition. But This Is Only To Say That The Most Definite Expression Of A Man Is Not Necessarily His Most Characteristic,. And When The Character Resides In Structure Rather Than In Expressidn, As In William Simmonds, Eric Gill, Sir Walter Parratt. And Andr6 Gide, The Man Is Put Before Us With Force And Brevity. Is It Because Professor Rothenstein Is More Tolerant Of Philosophical Than Poetical Abstraction That Prof. F. Einstein Is The Best Of The Lot ? Some Early Drawings, Of Between 1890 And 1897, Are Included, Mierediths Phoebus Apollo Turned Fasting Friar Being Perfectly Realized In Sir Leslie Stephen. Towards Landscape Professor Rothensteins Attitude. Is. Ever A Little Schoolmasterly, But V-Iew Of Leysin .And. Chalet Near Leysin Prove The Advantage Of Restraint And Econonly Over Sentimentality In Dealing With -The Landscape Of Switzerland. Arlington Gallery. The Memorial Exhibition Of Works By The Late Miss Hlenrietta Irvine-An Artist Of Irish Birth, Trained Iu Paris And Domiciled In Australia, Who Died Three Or Four Yeanrs Agosuggests A Sensibility That Would Have Found Its Proper Exppression In The Mastcry Of Oil Painting. The Mastery Vas Not Attained, But It Is Very Interesting To See How The Resistance Of The Thicker Medium Gave Emotional Value To Moods Wlhieh Declined Into Sentimentality In Water-Colour. There Is No Mistaking The Intensity Of Feeling In The Sefngees, A Mother Clasping Her Child, The Portraits-Notably L-Ussian Student Andl Madam B., Lent By Sir Wnilliam Irvine, K.C.M.G.-Show An Appreciation Of Temperament As Wvell As Of Charactcr. And There Is Tuhl Good Xw Ork In The Study Of A Baby, Just Awake, Ill The Two Laundry Studies. And In Some Of The Landscapes. Whiat Is Lacking Is The Articulateness Of Handling Which Would Have Done Justice To The Dept.H And Quickness Of Feeling, The Response To Light, And The Good Taste In Colour. Chester Gallery. The Steady Improvement In The Quality Of The Exhibition At This Gauerv, At 2. Chester. Terrace, Deserves A Word Of Recognition. Of The Two Present Exhibitors, Mr. Arthur Jenkins And Mr. C. N. Knight. It Cannot Be Said That They Provide Mnore Thani Pleasaut Pictures, But They Are Content With Their Owvn Interests And Do Not Affect The Manners Of Better Painters Than They Happen To Be. Mr. Jenkins Is, On The Whole, Happiest In Oils Anid In Subjects Made Up Of Small Features, Such As Crab Apple Trees, In Which A Conisiderable Variety Of Tone Is Nicely Held Together But His Water-Colours Of Algeria And Tunis, Pepper Trees, Kairoun, And Algiers Bay In Particular, Have Good Qualities. The Best Of Mr. Knights Landscapes Are Li Co. Tyrone And Southwold. And Lie Shows Some Carefully Studied Interiors With Figures.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition. Theodore Roussel. Almost Forgotten Pleasures In Art Are Revived At The Memorial Exhibition Of Works By The Late Ir. Theodore Roussel 1847-1926 At The Goupil Gallery. Mir. Roussel Was The Kind Of Artist That We Call, Tautologically And With More Convenience Than Accuracy, Very Artistic Not So Much In The Sense Of Perfectly Adapting Means To End, W Hich Is Probably The Most Respectable Meaning Of The Word Artistic, But In That Of Cultivating The Means Themselves With Extreme Virtuosity. In This Direction He Went Even Farther Than Wlhistler, With Whom He Was At One Time Closely Associated. Nowadays, Our Attentioi. Is Directed So Exclusively To The Constructive Use Of The Means In Art That Virtuosity Is Not Only A Relief To Our Enjoyment But A Corrective To Our Ideas. We See That, Let Form Be Never So Significant, There Is Something To Be Said For Exquisite Manners. The Immediate Effect Of The Exhibition Of 11 2 Works. Itn Oil, Water-Colour, Etching, And Lithography, Is To Surprise Us At The Range Of The Artist Our Recent Acquaintance With His Worik Beingf Limited To Occasional Prints In The Exhibitions Of The Society Of Graver Printers In Colour, Of Wvhich He Was First President, And One Or Two Small Exhibitions Of His Watercolours. We See Here That Mr. Roussel Was Capable Of Constructing A Large Oil Picture, Such As The Night, September, Chelsea And Perseplione, Though It Will Be Generally Agreed That His More Personal Qualities Are Less Evident In Them Than In Smaller Paintings, In Which The Function Of The Design Might Be Compared To The Rounding Of A Sentence Rather Than To The Building-Up Of A Paragraph. Creen Brocade, Kensington Gardens, A Study Of Horse Chestnuts, With A Sickle-Shaped Curve Of Subdued Simlight Upon The Grass, Is A Good Example. Mr. Roussel Composed A Picture, One Would Say, As A Man Might Compose His Mind, The Better To Dwell Upon His More Intimate Concerns. The Astonishingly Good Preservation Of Portrait Of Mrs. Glray Robinson, A Bust Portrait With The Dark Head Relieved Upon A Pink Ground, Painted About 1886, Or 41 Years Ago, Showvs That His Oil Painting Was As Technically Sound As It Was Artistically Considered. This Portrait, A Sheffield Vase-Grey And Silver, With Appleblossom For Relief, The Lovely Opal, An Evening In June, Apparently On The Thames, And The Tiny A Rose In The Evening, A Single Flower Shining Out Of A Green Gloom Of Shrubs And Clipped Hedges, Are The Oil Paintings Which Suggest The Greatest Enjoyment In Execution. The Temperament Reflected In These Works And In The Water-Colours And Etchings Is Extremely Attractive Fastidious And Taetful, And Enriched With A Refined Sensuiousness. Sedulous As Mir. Roussel Was In. His Meshods, Printing State After State Of His More Elaborate Etchings, His Work Never Looks Laboured. It Is Clear That He Spent As Much Time And Thought Over Leaving Out As Putting In, And His Instinct For Particular Mediurns Was Remarkable. Examples Of. This Are The Water-Colours Sunshine After Shower, A Bathing Subject, And Trees, Water And Clouds, Evening, The Drypoint Head Of A Child, Portrait Of Miss Marion Melville, The Etching Little Girls And Perambulators, Chelsea Embankment, And The Preparatory Study In Aquatint For The Well-Known Lagonie Des Flemus. For His Etchings Mr. Roussel Designed His Own Frames, Printing Upon Them Etched Designs In Sympathy With The Subjects. This Is An Exhibition To Be Taken In A Leisurely Manner-Like A Well-Ordered Meal.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Mr. E1Ati Woolf 1R. Hal Woolf, Who Shows Oil And Watercolour Paintings At The Redfern Gallery, 27, Old Bond-Street, Has A V,Ide Range In Subject8Portrait Heads, Fogure Ctmposltions, Landscapes, And Still-Life Studies-But He Appeals To Have A Special Turn For Street Scenes. These He Knows How To Arrange In A Comfortable Manner And With A View To Bringing Out Local Character And Atmosphere, But It Is Not Easy To See Otherwise What He Is After. His Artistic Interest, As Distinct From His Skmll In Representation Would Seem To Be Colour, And In Looking At His Work One Has The Feeling That He Is At Present Allowing It To Be Swamped By What Are For Him Irrelevant Considerations. Rn Several Of The Street Scenes The Colour-As Represented By Painted House Fronts, Posters, And Tbe Garments Of Passs-By-Appears To Be Playing A Game Of Its Own, Irrespective Of The Task The Artist Has Set Himself, And It Is By No Means Unlikely That The Colour Is In The Right That Mr. Woolfs Instincts Are Better Than His Opinions. At Any Rate, His Most Successful Pictures Are Those That Depend Almost Entirely Upon Colour Comparison, Such As -Everlasting Plower, Tarascon, And San Gimignano, With Buildings Bumped Against An Evening Sky. Place St. .Andr4 Des Arts And Wardour Street Are Two Of The Best Of The Townscapes. Mr. Woolf Will Paint Better When He Simplifies His Motives.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Water-Colours In Royal Exchange Some 170 Topographical Water-Colours Done Under The Recording Britain Scheme Are Now Hung In The Royal Exchange And Are Ort View There From Monday To Friday Each Week During The Afternoons. They Are Selected From About 1,000 Which The Scheme Has So Far Produced, And Which The Pilgrim Trust Has Lent To C.E.M.A. For Exhibition. In This Selection One Notices Many Of The Best Things From The Two Recording Britain Exhibitions At The National Gallery. In Addition There Is A Small Loan Section Consisting Of About A Dozen Examples By Earlier Topographical Water-Colourists From The Seventeenth To The Nineteenth Century. This Serves As A Brief Introduction To The Contemporary Drawings. It Includes Notably Fine Examples Of Paul Sandby And Francis Towne. Other Current Exhibitions Include One Of Living French Artists At The Beaux Arts Gallery. Bruton Place. W.I. Most Of The Painters Represented, Might Be Described As Late Impressionists, None Of Them Of Very Extreme Kind. Chief Prominence Is Given To The Work Of Paul-Elie Gernez. Who Is Especially Remarkable For His Pastels. In Which Medium, Used Very Firmly On Rough Paper, He Obtains Effects Somewhat Like Those Of Body Colours. Some Of His Best Pastels Are Of Seashore Scenes, With Groups Of People In Gay Bathing Costumes. And He Also Renders Subjects Of This Kind Effectively In Water-Colours. Other Artists At This Gallery Are Lucien Adrion, Emile Othon Friesz, And M. De Vlaminck. At The Czechoslovak Institute. 18, Grosvenor Place, S.W.1. A Selection Of Works By Hannah Gabert Is On View Until October 12. This Artist, Who Is Nowv Working In England, Paints Both In Oils And Water-Colours, And Also Does Linocuts And. Tapestries -These Last Being Decorative Hangings Made By Cutting Out And Sewing Together Cloth Of Various Colours. She Is Best In Vigorous Pen Work Strongly Coloured, Such As Study For A Portrait. The Berkeley Galleries, 20, Davies Street, W.L, Is At Present Chiefly Occupied With Native Art From Africa And Also From The Pacific. The Exhibits Include Bronzes From Benin, A Remarkable Stylized Head Of A King In Wood From Ashanti, And Other Things Of The Kind.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Leicester Galleries With Sculpture, Paintings, Drawings, And Engravings By Mr. Leon Underwood, Water-Colours By Mr. Anthony Slade, And A Collection Of 83 French Drawings And Water-Colours, The Leicester Galleries Cannot Be Accused Of Short Commons About Mr. Underwood Mr. R. H. Wilenski Is Probably Right When He Says, In His Appreciative Introduction To The Catalogue, His Exhibition, To Be Properly Assessed, Must Be Assessed As A Whole, As A Complex Gesture Representing The Aesthetic, Imaginative, And Spiritual Experiences Of A Complex And Adventurous Personality. At Any Rate, The Effect Of The Exhibition Is That Of An Eager, Stimulating, And Suggestive Talker, Who Jumps From One Subject To Another And Does Not Finish His Sentences. It Is An Effect Of Great Versatility, But-Except In The Matter Of Mediums-We Are Not So Sure That It Is Artistic Versatility, And We Should Say That Mr. Underwood Deals In Notions Rather Than In Ideas. His Determination To Keep His Art In Close Touch With His Intuition And Imagination As A Man Is All To The Good, But He Seems To Lack The Patience To Find The Right Form For What He Has To Say, And Too Often He Illustrates The Ideaor The Notion-Instead Of Expressing It In Terms Of His Materials. To Get Over The Worst And Be Done With It, The Cathedral, In The Form Of A Colossal Figure, With Symbols Of The Senses Over The Entrance, Is, Artistically, A Bad Break. Cathedrals Cannot Be Invented, They Grow Out Of A Creed In A Form Determined By The Organization Of Society At A Particular Time, According To The Capacities Of A Particular Method Of Building Construction. By Far The Most Satisfying Of The Works In Sculpture Is Totem To The Artist, A Carving In Yew, Consisting Of Three Figures One Above The Other, The Topmost Standing On Its Head. This Has All The Character Of Something Conceived In And Not Merely Imposed Upon The Material For The Purposes Of Illustration, And It Is Very Rich In Colour. Clod Of Clay Book Of Thel, Blake, In Bronze, Has A Blockly Impressiveness, And There Is Lively Movement In Herald Of New Day, In Chased Brass, But We Cannot Help Feeling That Mr. Underwoods Talents As A Sculptor Find More Characteristic Expression In Such Comparatively Realistic Works As The Torso, Also In Chased Brass, Flux, And The Portrait Head Of Eric Kennington. Except In Totem To The Artist And Watercarrier, In Veined Marble, He Seems To Jump Away From Realism Instead Of Translating It Into Something More Sculptural. Most Of The Paintings Reflect Mr. Underwoods Visit To Mexico, But It Is Questionable If The Most Successful Is Not The Emigrant, A Full Length Of A Seated Woman, With Large Hands In Her Lap, Which Has Both Pathos And Dignity. Cooling Galleries At The Cooling Galleries, 92, New Bond Street, There Is Good Entertainment For Half An Hour In An Exhibition Of 103 Decorative Paintings Of Bird, Flower, And Sporting Subjects, English And Foreign, And Mostly Of The Eighteenth And Nineteenth Centuries. It Is Probable That Some Of The Attributions Are Sanguine, But That Will Not Worry Anybody Who Takes The Exhibition In The Right Spirit-That Is To Say. As An Opportunity To Find Something Which, While Providing Subject Interest, Will Take Its Place As Part Of The Furniture Of A Room. There Are Several Handsome Flower And Other Still-Life Paintings, Such As Flowers And Insects In A Vase, By Nicolas Van Veerendael, And Still Life, By Edward Ladell-Not To Speak Of Several Works By Fantin Latour-And Among The Bird Subjects Poultry In A Landscape And A Happy Family, By C. Van Leemputten, Are Remembered With Special Affection But The Real Entertainment Is In The Collection Of Sporting Subjects By English Artists. In This Field Names Hardly Matter, And The Obscure Artist Will Often Give You A More Racy Representation Of The Scene Or Incident Than A Famous One. There Are Two Lively Little Pictures, A Hawking Party And The Horse Race, Attributed To John Wootton, And The Hunting Party, By D. Wolstenholme, Junior, Holding Up The Coach, By J. C. Maggs, Southampton And London Coach, By J. Cordery, And An Irish Horse Fair, By W. H. M. Turner, All Give Some Characteristic Aspect Of English Country Lifc.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitiona. Late In The Season Though It Be, There Are To-Day Fresh. Succession Of Private Views To Tempt The Amateur Of Other Things Than The Academy Has To Show. The French Gallery In Pall-Mall, Mr. Obacbs In Cockspur-Street, The Fine Art Society And Messrs. Dowdeswell In New Bond-Street, Have Pictures And Drawings Of Some Importance, While At The Rooms Of The Berlin Photographic Conipany, A Fewv Doors Off, There Are On View The First Portions Of The Splendid Wvork Which They Are Devoting To The Hermitage Gallery At St. Petersburg. No Fewer Than 84 Of The Finest Pictures In That Gallery, The Least Known Of All The Great National Collections Of Hurope, Are Being Reproduced In Photogravure, And Are Ultimately To Be Accompanied By A Description By Dr. Tschudi, Of Berlin, An Interesting Preface Being Contributed By Sir Martin Conway. Among The Pictures As Yet Reproduced Are Three Great Titians-The Danae, The Magdalen, And The Toilet Of Venus -Several Rembrandts, Three 3Murillos Of The Highest Quality, The Exquisite Madonna Attributed To Leonardo, And Some Choice Dutch Genre Pictures. For Those Who Prefer Originals To Photographs, However Fine, There Are Some Good Things At Messrs. Dowdeswells, And Notably One Of The Most Periect Works Of Jacob Ruysdael That Exist Anywhere. This Is The Upright Landscape No. 243 In Smiths Catalogue Which Belonged To Baron Verstolk, And, Unlike Most Of His Collections, It Has Remained In The Low Countries Till Recently. The Foreground Has Darkened A Little, But In Subject And In Handling This Admirable Scene Of Woodland And Sun-Lit Cottages Must Fairly Be Called A Masterpiece. Two Portraits By The Rare Pupil Of Hals, Jan Verspronck, Show The School Of Haarlem At Its Great Moment, And Some Conversation Pieces By Dirk Hals, Simon Kick, And Others Are. Of Interest. There Are Also Some Good Early Portraits There Are English Works Of Some Importance, Including A Fine New Of Lincoln By De Wint And One Of The Best Of The Haskett-Smith Morlands-A Work Of Exceptional Quality. At The Fine Art Eocietys, Besides The Burnejones Sketches Which Have Been Having A Prodigious Success There Are A Few Pauels Of Oil And Water-Colour Sketches By Suchwell.Known Artists As Messrs. Boilghton, Wimperis, And Orrock, Mime. Renriette Ronuer, Mr. Elgood, And Mr. Thorburn, The Painter Of Game Birds. More Novel, At Least To English People, Are The Brilliant Society Sketches Of The American Artist, Charles Dana Gibson, The Most Celebrated Of All The Pictorial Satirists Of New York. The Drawings Here Shown Form A Part Of Those Which Were Issued In A Volume Last Year, But It Is Natural That The Originals Should Be Far Saperior To The Engravings. Large In Size, To Give Scope To Mr. Gibsons Sweeping Strength Of Line, They Are Surprisingly Alive And If The Humour Is Not Always Equally Good, Nothing Could Surpass The Delightful Picture Of Oupid And The Young Widow, A Gem Ia Every Way. Mr. Obach Has Now On View Some Of These Choice Barbizon Pictures Which Come To Him Periodically, Including L La Mare Aux Vipbres Of 1Iaz While Messrs. Wallis, At The French Gallery, Combine The Old And The New, The Hone-Grown And The Foreign,. In A Very Comprehensive Way. A Romney, A Richard Wilson, A Little Gainsborough Landscape A Celebrated Wilkie, Which- We Ramember At The Old Masters Some Years Ago And Works Of Corot, Charles Jacque, And The Now Toofashionable -Mauve, - Jostle With -Bouguereaus, Lhermnittes, And Heffners In A Pleasant Confusion Which Should At Least Provide Something For Every Taste. Few Romneys Are More Charming Than This Sketch Of Lady Melville, One Of Those Rapidly Painted Pictures Which The Artist Left In -Their Beautiful Incompleteness. Nor Did Charles Jacque, The Best French Pastoralist Since Troyon, Ever Paint Better Than In The Picture Hera Called F Lomewards.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Miss Elsie Henderson. Best Known By Her Lithographs And Bronzes Of Wild Aninaals, Miss Elsie Henderson Is Now Exhibiting At The Redlern Gallery.. 27, Old Bond-Street, The Whole Range Of Her Art, Which Includes Oil Painting. Apart From The Good Taste In Colour Which They Reveal, A Taste At The Same Time Happy And Reserved, The Oil Paintings Make Evident A Feeling For Rhythm Which Has Not Yet Been Indulged As Far As It Might Be In Mlss Hencdersons More Familiar Work. Always In Looking At Her Animalschiefly The Larger Cats-One Has Felt That The Intimate Knowledge Of The Artist Has To A Certain Extent Conflicted With Her Command Of General Form, Particularly In Her Bronzes. The Painting Of A Leopard On A Bough, Entitled C9Amoufage, Makes It Clear That Miss Henderson Can Well Afford To Let Herself Go In A Decorative Direction, As Illustrwted Here And In Flower Gfirls And Contemplation, A Composition Of Three Women And Flowers. Too Easy Stylizatlon Is, Of Course, To Be Avoided, But With Miss Hendersons Knowledge Of Animna Anatomy And Characteristic Movement She Is Not Likely To Go Astray, And We Welcome The Bolder Treatment In These Paintings And In Such Drawings As Panther And Snarling Tiger.Anter Dnd Sarin Ger. Diference Of Medium And Method Piays Its Part In Au Generalizations Of Nature, And Thereis An Interesting Difference, Creditable To The Artist, To Be Observed Between The Carvings In Artificial Stone Of Nilgai Doe And Gazelle, And The Bronzes-Produced By Modelling. It Is Likely That The Lithogramhssuch As Leopard Watching, D Ilgai Doe, And Squirrels -Will Remain The Best Appreciated Of Ariss Hendersons Productions, But The Whole Exhibition Behpeaks The Inteligent Artist, Working Slowly From A More To A Less Naturalistic Treatment Of Form With A Sensi- Tive Appreciation Of The Claims And Possibilities Of Her Materials. The Excellent Oil Painti Wimter Sea Should Not Be Over-

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Barbizon House As Is Usual At This Address, The Sunmer Exhibition At Barbizon House, 9, Henrietta-Street, Cavendish-Square, Has A Consistency Which Goes A Long Way To Meet Any Criticism That Might Be Made Of Its Limitation In Kind. Poetical Naturalism, As Indicated By Thle Names Of Sir George Clausen, Sir D. Y. Cameron, Mlr. Wilson Steer, And Mir. Arnesbv Brown, Witlh Their Differences In Style Understood, Is A Fair Description Of The Prevailing Attitude, But The Range Is Wide Enough To Include Mr. Walter Richard Sickert And Mr. C. R. W. Nevinson. It Is Not A Collection Of Masterpieces, And It Has Not Much To Sav To Contemporary Artistic Ideas, But It Represents A Good Sound Body Of Vork In Oil And Water-Colour-60 Examples In All. The Most Complete Summary Of Sir Cecrge Clausens Characteristics-His Controlled Love Of Nature, Sympathy With 3-Outh -And Labour, And Discriminating Appreciation Of Conditions Of Light-Is To Be Found In The Shepherd Boy, Sunrise, Decidedly A Picture To Live With. Sir D. Y. Cameron Has The Strongest Appeal In His Water-Colours, Such As Stirling And Arras, Though Ben Vrenue, Under Snow,V With Its Linear Treatment Of The Foregrowund, Is A Good Exarnple Of His Work In Oil. Mr. Steer, With His Methods Of Distillation, Conveying The Moods Rather Than The Facts Of Nature, Allowvs A Wider Range Of Choice, And Preference Hesitates Between A Golden Afternoon, In The Heart Of A Wood, In Oil, And A Grove, Bridgenorth, In Water-Colotir. In Bamsbury Mr. Sickert Reduces A Shop-Front To Its Aesthetic Values In Colour And Tone M Mr. Arnesby Brown Captures The Spirit Of An October Evening In The Picture W Ith That Title And Theatreland, By Mir. Nevinson, Murton Fell, By Sir Charles Holmes, Yoredale, By Mr. J. Wthitelaw Hamilton, Florence, Bv 31R. Henry Rushbury, And Aprils Opening, Loch Eam, Bv Mr. W. Russell Flint, Are All Pictures That Become Their Authors. This Is An Exhibition Of Mild Pleasures, But They Are Genuine If Taken In The Spirit In Which They Are Offered.
