Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition. Picturies At The Redfern Gallery. All Three Of The Present Exhibitors At The Redfern Gallery, 27, Old Bond-Street, Have Something To Commend Them. In The Case Of Mr. Adrian Allinson, Who Shows Mostly Landscapes In Oil, Watercolour, Black And White, And Coloured Chalks, It Is - Detachment. He Happens To Have- Painted Several Of His Pictures In Provence, But, With An Intelligent Applicatiorn Of The Principles Of C6Zanne To His Own Purposes, He Has Avoided That Effect Of Fawmng Upon The Subject-Matter Which Is Beginning To Make Provence As Unwelcome In Our Exliibitions As Cornwaau Used To Be And Sussex Now Is In Our Novels. Mr. Allinsons Talent Is Explorative, And You Would Say That He Walked About With A Cool Head, Perhaps Whistling, In Order To See How The Landscape Would Go In His Pictures. His General Aim Is To Bring Three Dimensions Fnto A Decorative Arrangement, And He Does It Mainly By Observing Directions And Relations-The Mnlination Of Walls And Furrows And The Relative Positions Of Trees On Plan. Provencal Apple Orchard And The Plane Trees Of Avignon Are Two Very Good Compositions On This Basis. Proven9Al Spring, In Oil, Is Perhaps A Little Over-Calculated, But Venetian Fugue, In The Same Medium, Justifies Its Title By The Contrapuntal Interest Derived From Curved Bridge And Straight Houses. Mr. Allinsos Work May Lack Magic, But It Is Eminently Reasonable In Form And Plesi In Colour. The Obvious Affinity Between Mr. Tom Nash And Mlr. Stanley Spencer Is Interesting Rather Than Derogatory To The Former, Because It Seems To Show That, Given A Keen Interest In The Subjectmatter Of Scriptural Themes And, At The Same Time, A Talent For Formal Design, Things Work Out Pretty Much Alike. We Are Inclined To Think, Too, That-Possibly Because He Is Attempting Less Complicated Problems-Mr. Nesh Has More Command Of His Material Than Mlr. Spencer, At- Any Rate When He Is Wvorking On A Small Scale, And His Colour Is Certainly Better Regulated. We Are Too Familiar With Purely Illustrative Painting And Also With The Painting That Runs Away From Illustration In A Sort Of Panic, So That It Is Rather A Relief To Come Upon An Artist Like A-R. Nash, Who Does Not, In The Classic Phrase, Empty Out The Baby With The Bath. His Largest Painting, The Cruciflbion, Though Intense In Feeling, Is Not Very Well Organized, But Healing The Sick, The Fall Of Jericho, Christ Anid The Mroney Chlangers, And The Small Crucifixion Are Excellent Pictures, Interesting To The Eye And At The Same Time Interesting In Their Subjects. Mr. Nash Is To Be Encouraged In The Double Task That He Is Attempting-To Organize Both His Religious And His Pictorial Interests. The Third Exhibitor, Mr. George Butler, Has Slighter Aims-Indeed, He Might Be Said To He Engaged In Slight Plasics, His Evident Desire Being To Suggest Full Relief With Colour Only. Apples, Mauve Tulips, Form In Colour, And Stiu Life Are All Charming Exercises On These Lines, Sensitive In Feeling And Decorative In Arrangement.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Among Tho Interesting Exhibitions Of The Moment Is On That Opens To-Day At The Goupil Gallery, In Memory Of The Late J. Buxton-Knight, To Be Supplemented Some Weeks Hence By A Display Of The Same Artists Watercolours At The Leicester Galleries. Mr. Buxton-Knight? Who Died Last January At The Age Of 66, After A Long Period Of Ill-Health, Was A Very Sincere And Genuine Painter, And One Of The Few Landscape Artists Of The Day Who Had Any Claim To Bo Called A Colourist. Richness Rather Than Subtlety Was The Characteristic Of His Pictures And While He Never Impressed The Royal Academy Sufficiently To Obtain Th Associateship, He Appealed To Lovers Of Advanced Art As One Of Th Ablest Of Our Landscape Painters. He Obtained His Effects By Massing His Colours And To A Certain Extent By Loading His Paint. He Loved To Render The English Sky With Masses Of Cloud At Rest Or In Slow Motion He Loved Also Heavy Trees, Beginning To Grow Golden Under The Touch Of Autumn And Now And Then, With Much Understanding Of Th Fora And Movement Of Waves, He Painted The Seo. Examples Are To Be Found In This Gallery. Abundant A Fine Sea Piece, Painted In 1893, Gives Us White Walkr Near Dover Another, Smaller In Az And Less Stormy In Subject, Shows Shecmess Harbour, With Boats Moving In And Out. Others Take Us To Richly Wooded Inland Landscapes, Such As The White Lodge, Richmond, Richmond From Below Th Star And Garter, And Th Very Recent Thorn Tree In Flower. A Pathetic Interest Attaches To The Very Beautiful English Cottage Homes 38, For, When Paralysis Had Disabled The Painters Right Hand, He Painted This Entirely With His Left. This Exhibition Will Bring Home To Many Minds The Fact That In Buxton-Knight We Have Lost An Artist Of Distinguished Merit, Who Was Not Properly Appreciated While He Was Alive. At The Leicester Galleries, The Place Lately Held By The Late H. G. Moon And Mr. Rackham Is Being Filled By Two Very Well Known Artists In Water-Colour, Mr. Herbert Marshall And Mr. James Aumonier. The Former, Whose Views Of Misty London Have Been A Feature Of The Old Water-Colour Society For A Generation, Has Left The Mists Behind Him In Three Or Four Visits To France-, The Result Of Which Is Here In 68 Drawings Of Cathedral Cities. The Tours Have Reached From Abbeville To Poitiers, From Bourges To Laon And, Though The Cathedrals Are A Feature Of Mast Of The Drawings, Mr. Marshall Has Often Devoted Himself To Some Old Historic Castle, Or To Some Medieval Street. For Instance, Amboise And Its Matchless Chateau, Rising Straight From The River Bank, Gives Him Scope For Some Of His Finest Drawings, And So Does The Seldom Visited Sxumnr. But We Have Tho Cathedrals Of Amiens, Rouen, Evreux, Chartres, Meaux, And A Score Of Other Places, All Exquisitely Drawn, And Glowing With Sunny Colour. There Is No Cure For Incipient Mannerism Like A Change Of Venue. France Has Quite Shaken Off Th Slight Monotony Of Habit Which Was Threatening To Injure This Excellent Artists Work.Mr. Aumorder More Often Appears Before The Public As A Painter In Oils, But His Water-Colours Ar Most Charming And Accomplished, As These Rooms Will Show. His Trees Are A Little Faulty, And Are Sometimes Generalized Rather Carelessly Seo No. 12, But In Tho Rendering Of English Pastoral Landscape, As In Th Sheep-Washing, The Rough Pasturage, And The Afternoon Sunshine 60, There Are Few Painters Who Can Surpass Him. These Drawings Imply On The Part Of The Artist Years Of Patient Observation And A Life Steeped In Tho Associations Of The Country. Very Different, But Quite As Remarkable, Are The Drawings Of Tho Boman Campagna By Signor A. Sartorio At The Fine Art Societys In New Bond-Street. The Painter Is Well Known In Italy And In Germany He Has Worked For The King, And Has Been Professor At Weimar And He Admits The Influence Of Men So Different As Gerome And D. G. Rossetti. What His Large, Ambitious Pictures May Be Like We Cannot Say, But These Small Water-Colours And Pastels Are Of Great Interest To All Who Love Italy And To All Who Admire A Hand That Draws Nature As The Eye Sees It. We Are Told That It Is To Signor Carlandis Recommendation That This Exhibition Is Duo But Certainly There Could Not Be Two Painters More Dissimilar. For Our Part W Infinitely Prefer These Accurate Transcripts By Ths Younger Man To Th Conventionalities Of The Elder. In Another Gallery In Bond-Street, Messrs. Connells, There Is On View A Large Collection Of M. Boots Etchings Of Paris. They Are Mdryonesque, Without Being Imitated From Meryon. M. Bjot Is An Admirable Draughtsman, And His Buildings And Bridges Have Substance And Solidity. He Has Been For Some Time Accepted By The Parisian Critics As On Of The Best Town-Etchers Of The Day.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art - E Xhibii I Arlt Exa-Ibition. I -.5 , The New English. Virtuosity Rather Than Origiriality Prevails At The 76Th Exhibition Of The New English Art Club At The Spring Gardens Gallery, And It Could Only Be Described In Detail. Exoept For A Greater Freedom I Than Usiual From Immature Exercises In Composition Of The Slade School Tybpe It Has No Distiative Eharacter. Possibly On A6Count Of Bletter Lighting, The Oil, Paintings In The First Room Make A Livelier Impression Than Those In The Big Centre Gallery, But It Is Questionable If The Best Entertainment Is Not To Be Found Ambng The Water-Colours, Drawihgs, And En- Gravings. I To Take Oil Paintings First, Two In I Particular Claim Attention The River Sarela, By Mr. Stephen Bone, And Cloud Over Helvellyn, By Sir C. J. Holmes. The First Is Not More Than A Scholars Exercise, Saying Little About The Personal Feelings Of The Olung Artist, But It Deserves Great Praise For The Way In Which The Material-A Hilly Landscape With Architecture, Women Washing Clothes, And Lounging Soldiers-Is Kept Together And For The Clean, Articulate Touch With Which It Is Painted. Though Different In Subject, It Reminds One Rather Of Some Of The Newlyn And Penzance Views Of Mr. Stanlhope Forbes. There Is The Same Lack Of Emphasis, Almost As If-Though The Treatment Is Not Uhghgrahru A Gotograph Had Been Takenas Aguide. Oud Over Helvellyn Is The Most Consistent Landscape In Oil By-The Artist That One Can Remember, Chiefly On Account Of The Better Relation Between Clouds And Mountains, Obtained By Getting More Architecture Into The Former And Departing From A Linear Character In The Latrter. With Its Downipour Of Light, Revealing A Hollow In The Hills, And One Emp Atic - Peak, It Is A Very Uplifting Canvas. Other Goad Oil Paintings In The First Room Are The Rather Obviously Composed -Winter, By Mr. John G. Nicholls Honesty, Relieved With The Red Capsules Of Cape Gooseberries, By Mr. Malcolm Milne The Soaring, Green And Blue 3Huttered Facade Of Mentone, By Mr. Mar-Esco Pearce Misty Morning On The Wye, By Miss Tthel Leigh Chessel, By Mr. C. H. Collins Baker And Forest, With Monkeys, Painted As If By Flashlight, By Mr. Keith Henderson. In The Centre Gallery A Place Of Honour Has Been, Iven To The Half-Length Of The Lady Gwendoline Churchill, By The Late Mr. Ambrose Mcevoy. Essentialy A Study Of A Transitory Effect Of Light, Colour, And Movement-It Might Alrnost Be Called She Passes - It Serves Very Well To Recall Ihe Characteristic Powers Of The Artist, But It Leaves A Doubt Whether Charm Is Enough To Ifil A Canvas Of That Size For Permnanent Isatisfaction. In View Of It, The Rea,Tion Of Our Younger Painters In The Direction Of The Solid Constrtction Indicated Here By The Brown Young Philosopher Of Mr. Gerald Ososky Is Understandable. Stolid Rather Thapi Solid, But Imnaensely Capable, Is The Full-Lenkth Of A Seated Guardsman, By Mr. William L. Clause, Painted As If In Defiance Of Scarlet. Excepting Margaret Forbes, In Green, Seated, In A Mountain Landscape By Miss Ethel Walker, And The Dead Christ, A Not More Than Praiseworthy Old-Masterish Composition By Mr. Peter Brooler, Most Of The More Interesting Paintings In This-Room Are Small Among Them Being, Wvinter Landscape, By Miss Sine Miackinnoji Putney Common, By Mr. Charles Cundall Chulch At Rieder Alp, By Mr. Charles M. Gere And Spring Morning, By Mr. Allan Gwvnne-Jones. Among The Water-Colours The Highest Pitch Of Intensity Is Easily Found In The Pine, By Mr. Piaul Na4Sh, A Truly Thrilling Gesture With The Brush In A Degree Of Abstraction Which Seeins Inevitable From The Means. The Hunter Prince, By Otbvkia, With Its Genuinely Oriental Inspiration, Strikes One As The Most Completely Organized Large-Scale Decoration This Gifted Young Artist Has Painted Mr. Rex J. Whistlers Study For Decoration, In Thorodghly Amusing Eighteenth. Century Chinese, Whets The Appetite For The Fruits Of His Labours In The Refreshment Room At The Tate Gaucry And With The Choice, Of Drinks, By Mr. Munlhead Bone The Birdcage, By Miss Mary Adshead Tiger, By Miss Vere Tenajae Gnd Tlle Copse, By Mr. P.Hei.Jowett, There Is Great Variety Of Accomplishment. T1He Small Gallery, With Its Water-Cololurs By Mr. Vwilson Steer And Mr. David Muirhead, Pastel And Pencil Studies By Professor Henry Tonks, Figure Drawings By Miss Ethel Walkernot To Speak Of The Delightful Outline Drawing Of Snows Hill, Glkucestershire, Bymr. Ian Strangcan Be Recommended As A Whole. For, Indeed, With Its High Level Of Accomplishment And Lack Of Outstanding Features, This Is An Exceedinglydifficult Exhibition To Describe, But, Taken Picture By Picture, It Leaves A Better Impression Than Is Promised In A Preliminary Saunter Through The Galleries.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Poster Designs. The Exhibition Of Posters And Advertisiig Art By The British Society Of Patter Designers At The Royal Institute Galleries, 195, Piccadilly, Quite Bears Ont Mr. Joseph Thbrps Claim In His Foreword To The Catalogue That It Rests With Advertisers To Rrmake Our Hoardings The Best In The World. If They Are Not It Is Onlv Because The Average Of Quality Showvn Here Is Lowered In Practice By The Taste Of A Majotity Of Patroni For What Malr. Thorp Aptly Calls The Technique Of Sentimental Realism. The Notion That This Technique Represents A Proved Efficacy With The Public Mav Be Dismissed. Tihe Average Quality Of This Exhibition Is All The More Remarkable Wlhen It Is Noted That Two Of Our Best And Most Active Poster Designers, Mr. Gregory 1Brown And Mr.-Horace Taylor, Are Not Representecl. A Word Is Due To The Excellent Arrangement Of The Exhibition, The Posters Being Displayed On A Background Of Grey Paper, With Black Borders And Divisions To Set Them Off. We Have Seldom Seen The Size Of The Royal Institute Galleries So Completely Justified By Their Contents. Most Of The Posters, Which Are Hung In Groups According To Artist, Arc Familiar, So That Only General Observations Are Needed Here. Having Regard To Psychological Differences In The Puiblic It Would Be Rash To Say What, Excluding Sentimental Realism, Is The Most Effective Poster Style, But There Is An Interesting Comparison To Be Made Between Two Groups At One End Of The Large Gallery Those By Mr. Tom Pcirvis And Mr. E. Mcknight Kauffer. On Their Owvn Lines Both Are Consistently Good, Mr. Puiviss L.N.E.R. East Coast Poster, Of A Child Wading Out With Water-Wings, Being As Good As The Style Of Simplified Realism Permits. We Cannot Help Feeling, Hox-Ever, That Mr. Kauffers Posters Have The Advantage In Concentration Of Design, And The Artistic Lesson We Would Deduce From Tbe Comparison-A Lesson That The Heraldic Artists Of The Past Followed By Instinct-Is That Simplification Without Distortion, Using The Word In A Broad Sense To Include All Modifications Of Outline, Always Results In A Certain Emptiness Of Effect. In Proportion As You Leave Out You Have To Modify Or Reinforce The Remainder. A Good Many Of The Posters In The Exhibition Suffer Somewhat From The Effect Of Emptiness, Of Something Left Out, That We Observe In Those By Mr. Purvis, And We Would Urge A Study Of Mr. Kauffers To See How The Effect Can Be Overcome. Mr. Kauffers Modernity Has Not Much To Do With The Matter. The Accent, Or Idiom, May Be New, But The Principle Is Not. As Anybody May See Who Studies A Good Sign-Board Or The Royal Standard. For An Effect Of Completeness, Simplification Implies A Decorative Convention.

Author: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT)
Title: Northern Photographic Exhibition
Full_text: Northern Photographic Exhibition Fine D1Splay At Maniiester From1 Ovri Own Correspondent Manchester, Dec. 2 The Northern Photographie Exhibition, Open Fror Six Weeks In The City Art Gallery Here, Is The Twelfth Of A Series Arranged Bv The Liverpool, Leeds, Bradford, And Manchester Photogiaphic Societies, And Is Designed To Provide A Representative Display Of Modern Camera Work Of As High A Standard As Anythliing Shown In London. Althoughl The Largest Part Of The Britishi Work Exhibited Is By Northern Photographers, And Northern Subjects Of All Kinds Are Boldlv Tackled. With All The Disadvantages Of The Northern Lack Of Sunshine, It Would Seem That Local Difficulties Are Only A Spur To Miore Intensive Effort. They Perhaps Account For A Notable Predominance Of Portraiture, But The Landscape, Architectural, Shipping, And Seashore Work In The Pictorial I Section Display Some Very Beautiful Effects Of Natural Lighting. The Manchester Society Has Beeu Fortunate Enough To Receive A Large Nnimber Of Imzperial And Foreign Entries. These Have Come From The Utnited States And Canada. From Cermany, France, Italv, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Polaind. Denmark, Belgium, Greece, Malta, And South Africa. The Prints Submitted In The Pictorial And Natural History And Scientific Sections Number 1,793, And In Addition There Are Over 1,000 Entries Of Transparencies And Colour Photographs. In The Opinion Of Specialists The Collection Of Transparencies Is One Of The. Finest Ever Got Together. Mr. John Macsymon, Who Was Judge Of The Pictorial Section, Had To Levote -Two Whole Daye To His Duties, And States That Much Line Vork Had To Be Rejected Merely Owing To Space Restrictions. Durni January, 151 Of The Principal Personalities In Amateur Photographic Circles, Including Mr. J. Dudley Joluiston, President, And Twvo Otheri Memiibers Of The Royal Photographic Society, Will Deliver Lectures On A Wide Range Of Topics. Notices Of Forthcoming Marriages And Other Societu Announcements On This Page Are Inserted At The Following Rates Three Guineas For Fice Lines Or Lcss. And Twelve Shillings And Sixpence For Each Additional Line. A Line Consists Of About Six Words. Announcements, Which Are Subject To Editorial Revision, Should Be Addressed To The Mlanager, Private Announcement Depariment, The Times, London, E.C.4. Block Letters Should Be Used For Names And Addrcsses.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. The Exhibitions Which Open This Week Are Not Among The Most Interesting. The Largest Is That Of Ths Society Women, Artists But Among Ths Pictures, Drawings, Rts And Crafts Which Fill The Large Rooms In Suffolk-Strcirt There Are But Sow That Rise Above A Moder- 4Te Standard. It Sounds Ungallant, But It Isnone The Less Iruc, To Say Tiiat Few Women Can, Point Really Well And Those That Can Preferto Show Their Works At The Academy Or The New Gallery Or In One Of The Water-Colour Oxhihi- Tions. Still There Are A Few Good Pictures And Drawings Dore, 2Nd, As Usual, The Rooms Of Applied Arts Contain A Certain Number Of Jewels, Embroideries, Bookbindings, C., Which Deserve Praise. Perhaps The Best Of The Pictures Is One Sent By An Exhibitor Whose Name Unfamiliar, Mrs. Blakeney Word. It Is A View On The Quantock Hills 307,Quietly Classical Infeeling, Exceliel.T In Drawing And Good In Its Tranquil, Restful Colour. Such Work Is Much Better Worth Doing Than The Rather Lond Id Vehement Landscapes That Abound On The Neigh- Souring Walls. In Portraiture, Miss M. L. Lucas Shows A Cleverly Painted Miss Etlinger 404, Which Appears To Have Met With Approval At One Of The French Salons Miss Beatrice Bright Shows Once More Her Academy Picture Of An Amateur Actor-Cvidently Very Much An Amateurporing As Richelieu And Miss M. E. Luxmo Ore Has A Satisfactory Half Length Of A Girl, Under A , .... Zx E At. It , - Fancy Title 863. One Or Two Of The Small Subject Pictures, Such As Those By Miss Hilda Fairbairn 303 And Miss Townsend Johnson 202, Are Above The Average. Of The Water-Colour Drawings, Those By Miss Ohara, Miss Macchesney, Miss M. A. Sloane, And Miss Wood- Head, Demandaword Of Notice. So Do Several Of The Chalk And Pen Drawings In The Further Room Notably A Wolfs Head By Miss Winifred Austen And Some Amusing Sketches By Miss Fannie Moody And Miss Farmilob. The Mrs. Dick 659, Mrs. Palmers Needle- Work, And Miss Parks Leaiherfirescreen On A Steel Frame, Are Noticeable Examples Of Industrial Art. Two Small Exhibitions Of Oil Landscapes, At The Goupr And Dowdeswell Galleries, Are Agreeable, If Not Much More. At The Former, Mr. G. Leon Little Has Some Fifty Pictures Of Cabinet Size, Mostly, It Would Seem, Painted In Surrey. He Has A True Eye For Twilight Effects, But His Details, Especially In Regard To The Forms Of Trees, Are Not Always Well Realized. Mr. Grosvenor Thomas, At Messrs Jlowdeswells, Paints In She Sweeping Fashion Now In Vogue Bnthissmallpictnresof Shaded Pools And Of The Sea Have A Certain Charm. A Delicate Contrast To This Rather Emphatic Art Is To Be Found In. The Etchings By The Late Charles Jacque At Mr. R. Gutekunsvs Gallery, 16, King-Street. In These Small Rooms One Always Finds Choice Impressions Of Beautiful Prints, And The Jacque Exhibition Is As Choice As Any Of Its Predecessors. The Rare Dry Pointe, Of Which Only Some Fifteen Prints Were Ever Taken, Make A Special Appeal To Collectors. 1

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. L.M.S. Photographic Society Amateur Photography Of More Than Ordinary Merit Is To Be Seen In The Third Annual Exhibition Of The London Midland And Scottish London Photographic Society, Afliated To The Royal Photographic Society Of Great Britain, In The Shareholders Meeting Room At Euston Station. There Is, For One Thing, A General Inclination To Compose Pictures Out Of Very Simple Material, Suggesting That A Truly Artistic Spirit Is Abroad In The Society. Instances Of What We Meau Are Luss, Loch Lomond, By Mr. T. H. Lismer, In Which The Name Board. Gangways, And Bollards Of A Steamer Landing Place Are Made Sufficient Chenies, A Sunlit Road, By Mr. F. J. Hole Beached, An Affair Of Boats And A Slipway, By Mr. J. L. White Parisiana, A Striking Composition Of Urns, The Kerbs Of Basins, A Sculptured Horse, And The Distant Eiffel Tower By Mr. B. S. Beck And Nearing Sundowvn, A Very Poetical Study Of Ploughing, By Mr. H. B. T. Stanton. Many More Pictures Might Be Named, But These Are Enough To Suggest The Serious Regard For Picture Making-As Distinct From Mere Snap-Shotting-Which Is Characteristic Of The Whole Exhibition. The Works Are Divided Into A Beginners And An Advanced Section, And Betwveen The Two There Is An Evident Increase In Experience. A Cup Is Awarded For The Best Print In Each Section, The Award Being By Popular Vote-For Which A Slip Is Provided In The Catalogue. The Exhibition, Which Is Open To The Public Daily Until 7 P.M, Closing On Saturday, Is Easily Reached By The Staircase From The Great Flail Of Euston Station. Chester Gallery. Though They Are Amateurish In Execution, Particularly When The Subject Makes Demands Upon Drawing, The Water-Colours Of Places In Scotland, Including The Outer Hebrides, By The Countess Of Norbury At The Chester Gallery, 2, Chester-Terrace, Are Distinguished By A True Feeling For Space And Light. It Almost Follows That The Studies Of The Islands Are Generally The Best, And Nos. 7, 8, 13, 14, And 15 Have Qualities Of The Kind Indicated Which Atone For Much Wealness In The Arrangement And Representation Of Solid Facts. Actually The Best Picture, However, Is A Pearly Study Entitled 9 Am.N -The Second Of A Series Of Three Representing 4 Artists Day On Cromarty Firth. Quite Clearly Lady Norburys Talents Are For The Rendering Of Atmospheric Conditions. At The Same Gallery There Are Prettily Illuminated Book-Covers On Vellum, By Mrs. Burton Fanning, And Ornamental Pottery By Mr. J. 0, Peters. The Tivoli Picture Palace, The First Cinema Theatre Built In Sheffield, Was Destroyed By Lre Yesterday Mornimg.

Author: FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT
Title: Exhibition Painting Defaced
Full_text: Exhibmon Painting Defaced Thumb Marks On Canvas From Our Correspondent Oxford, Nov. 16 When An Exhibition At Lincoln College, Oxford, In Aid Of World Refugee Year, Was Opened To-Day It Was Found That Thumb Marks Had Been Make All Over The Canvas Of A Large Oil Painting, Trees, The Work Of Jean Cartier, A French Painter Living In Oxford. Mr. Cartier, Who Had Offered To Give A Fifth Of The Price Of Each Of His Paintings Sold To World Refugee Year Funds, Had Been Working On Trees For Six Weeks And Had Vriced It At 150. The Culprit Evidently Pressed His Thumb In A Thick Patch Of Paint Which Was Still Wet Underneath And Then Dabbed At Random All Over The Painting. Mr. Cartier Said To-Day If Someone Had Put A Knife Through The Painting At Least I Could Have Repaired It. But To Do Anything To Get Rid Of This Mess Will Take Weeks Of Patient Work And Will Be Simply Patchwork. The President Of Lincoln College Junior Common Room, Mr. Julian Hartlandswann. Said Last Year We Bought A Painting For The Common Room And This Also Was Defaced. It Must Be Someone In The College Who Is The Culprit.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. The Immense Collection Formed By The Late Mr. Stoats Fortes Is Being Gradually Dispersed But Toe Process Is Of Necessity Slow. First The Great Dealers Of Europe And America Had Their Pick, And The Most Important Corots And Millets Were Sold By Private Arrangement. Then Came The Exhibition At The Grafton Galleries And Latterly Messrs. Brown And Phillips Have Been Shewing Different Sectionswater-Colours By Harpignies, Chalk Drawings By Millet, And Now Some50 Pictures, Chiefly By Corot, The Exhibition Of These Opens This Morning At The Leicester Galleries. The Pictures Are For The Most Part Either Early Works Or Slight Productions, Some Of Which Were Probably First Thoughts For Larger Canvases. As Such They Are Interesting, Though There Is Not A Picture Here That Could Ire Called A First-Rate Or Representative Corot. The Auvergne 18 Was Painted So Far Back As 1833, In The Precise And Careful Manner Practised By Corot While Under The Influence Of His Master Michahon But Most Of The Others Are Of The Later Period, In The Masters Characteristic Manner. Nos. 12 Laue Leading To Ville Davray , 13 Sunset, With Figures , And 40 He Two Hrtrw 1 Sea Man. Tha Hact Nf Theca There Are Oots0S V Ms Among Ths Best Ot Tocso. J. Here Are Also Some Good Small Examples Of Diaz,. Troyon, And Jules Dupre, Larger Sketch By Daubigny 15, And An Exceptionally Good Monti Celli. Mr. Mcleans Exhibition In The Haymarket Is Rather Better Than Usual, Because The French And Dutch Pictures Have Been Chosen With More Regard To Art Andless Regard To Anecdote. Three Fine Works By Harpignies, Painted In 1896,1897, And 1902, Show That Excellent Master Of Landscape In His Later Phase, When He Seems To Have Set Himself Deliberately To Carry On The Barbizon Tradition. There Is A Good Interior By Albert Neuhuys, Whose Art, Now So Much In Favour, Seems To Have Passed Through Precisely The Same Stages As That Of Josef Israels, The Chief Of The School Of Other Foreign Painters We Notice A Charming Gazin And A Small Work By An Italian, F. Scattola, Who Paints In A Manner Not Unlike That Of The Eminent Frenchman. Mr. Oxchardson Has An Important Single Figure, Jessica, Which Does Not Seem To Have Been Exhibited Before There Is A Pleasant Example Of The Delicate Art Of Mr. Stott 36, And One Of Mr. J. W. Godwards Classical Figures, Drawn And Painted With The Accuracy Of A Leighton, But Too Artificial For The Realistic Spirit, Of To-Day. Among Other Small Exhibitions Now Open Or Just Opening We May Mention The Drawings By Mr. Sutton Palmer At The Leicester Galleries, Messrs. Connells Show Of The Fine Landscapes Of The Late Alexander Fraser At Their Rooms In Old Bond-Street, And The Small Collection Of New Pictures By Mr. Bysin Shaw At The Dowdssweu Galleries. Mr. Shaw Is A Serious Aspirant For Fame, And In Some Respects He Is Undoubtedly An Artist To He Taken Note Of. He Draws Well, Is Not Afraid Of Brilliant Colour, Aud Paints Textures With Curious Felicity. But Bis Symbolism Is Too Elaborate To Be Always Happyas, For Instance, In The Central Picture Here, Which Comes Perilously Near To The Grotesque And He Is Far Too Fond Of Great Gold Frames Wherein The Gilder Outdoes Himself And Almost Kins The Picture. None The Less, Mr. Byam Shaw Is Not A Negligible Quantity Just Nowwhich Is More Than Can Be Said Of A Good Many Of His Brethren.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Entertairnments. Art Exhibitions. Goupil Gallery. In The Summer Exhibition Of Modem Art-Consisting Of 85 Paintings And Drawings And Twvo Pieces Pf Sculpture-At The Goupil Gallery There Are Several Things Of Uncommon-Interest. Modern, By The Way, Is To Be Understood In A Liberal Spirit, Since Fantin-Latour, Ribot, And, Charles Conder Are Among The Artists Represented And The General Tone Is Rather Before That Of The Moment. First Place Among The Uncommonly- Interesting Things Mist Be Given To The Extremely Beautiful Watercolour Of The Farm Pond, By Mr. John Nash. Without Being Obviously Designed . It Is Full Of Subtle Rhythmns Obtained Without Violence To The Facts, And We Do Not Reriiember A Recent Water-Colour Either Carried So Far Without Loss Of The First Impulse Or So Successful In Combining Natural Poetry With Pictorial Music. Then There Are Some Drawings Of Architecture By Mr. Eric Gill. Except One Wood Engraving, We Do Not Remember Any Work By Him Of Such Subjects-For Which He Is Obviously Suited By Temperament. Technically These Drawings Are Superb. Firm And At The Same Time Nervous And They Are All The Better For Subordinating The Design On The Paper To The Design Of The Architecture Itself.-Uite A Different Considerition. There Are Many. Other Good Water-Colour And Other Drawings Martindale And High Street, By Sir Charles Holmes, The Ferry, By Mr. Walter W. Russell, Tie Adam And Eve, Old Chelsea, By Messrs. H. And- W. Greaves, And Nude Study, By Mr. Augustus John, For Examples But They Are More Familiar In Kind Than Those Noted Above. Technical Accomplishment Rather Than Originality In Design Is The Note Among The Oil Paintings. A Place Of Honour Is Given To A Very Good Portrait Of Iris, By Mr. Villiam Nicholson, A Work Which Combines To A Remarkable Degree Full Representation With Plastic Feeling. This Is The Kind Of Painting-That-Makes One Ask Whether All The Sacrifices In The Interests Of Design .Vhich Are Now Common Are Really Necessary. The Same Question Is Excited By The Grey Painting Of The Cooks, By Th. Ribot. On The Other Hand Rest Camp, St. Valery-Sur-Somnire, By Sir William Orpen, Accomplished As It Is, Does Make You Feel That More Would Have Been Said With A Muore Suminary Treatment. There Is A Good Group Of Three Works By Air. Bernard Meninsky, Energetic In Design And Sharp In Colour, And Mr. Mark-Gertler Has Seldom Shown To Better Advantage Than In His Painting Of The Nude, Meditation. It Is Felt To Be On Exactly The Right Scale For Him, And It Is Very Choice In Colour. The Stove, By Mr. Sickert, Tannhiuser, By Fantin-Latour, Seapiece, By Sidney Starr, Brother And Sister, By Mr. Neville Lewis, And Hertfordshire Lane, By Mr. Gilbert Spencer, Are Other Specially Attractive Works In An Exhibition Which-And It Is Intended As A Compliment-Is To Be Enjoyed Rather Than Written About.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. The Exhibition At The Hanover Gallery, In New Bond-Street, Has For Its Principal Attraction A Vast Picture Which Made A Good Deal Of Talk In Paris In 1890. This Is The 1 Christ Aux Outrages Of M. Henri De Groux, A Young Eelgian Painter Who Has Succeeded In Exciting Much Enthusiasm And Many Protests In His Own Country, And Whom Excitable Young Writers In The Newspapers Of Ghent Arid Brussels Hava Freely Compared With Rembrandt, Delacroix, And Many Other Of The Sitrnite. A More Reasonablte Eyo Sees In This Younz Tnan An Artist Of No Little Talent, Who Is Formed Under Two Influences-The Commaon Contemporary Loio Of Action, Movement, Vehemence, And The Special Flemish Tradition, Established Long Before Rubens By Quentin Mlatsys And The Glass. Painters. If This Tempestuous Crowd, Surging And Raging Arouid The Dim Figure Of Tlhe Clist, Suggests Anything At All, It Sug-Ests Seine Oi The Flemish Glass Of The 15Th Century Even The Coarse Outlines Of The Figures Seem To Be Copied From The Leads In A Painted Window. It May Be Judged Whether This Borrowing From What Is A Necessary Evil In Glass-Painting Is Any Help To An Art In Which It Is Not Necessary. Briefly, Wve May Say That 3I. De Groux Shows Considerable Power Of Invention, And Can Sketch A Strong Composition But His Colour Is Ndfi True, And His Picture Is Without Atmosphere. The Gallery Contains A Number Of Other Piciures Among Them A Corot Or Two, A Good Lsabev, A Sea-Piece By Courbet, And Three Of Tissots Series Of Parisian Scenes, Which Wevre Shown In London Some Years Ago. At Mr. Stephen Goodens Gallery, 57, Pall. Mall, There Is On View For A Short Timne A Verv Charming Little Collection Of Cabinet Pictures L1Y Two Artists, Mir. W. E. Norton And Mr. H. G. Moon, Who Were Settled For The Summer Of 1831 At Gravetye Manor, Sussex, And Have Painted The House, The Garden, And The Neighbourinwoods And Fields In Every Aspect And Under Every Condition Of Sun And Shade. 3Mr. Norton Is An American Trained In Paris, Mr. Moon Is English, But There Is Enough Liieness Between Their Methods And Points Of View To Make Tbe Collection Pleasantly Harmonious. We Will Nrt Attempt To Decide The Prize Of Merit Between The Two Artists Ct Witult. Tt Digntus, Et Mic Both Are Clear-Eyed Observers Of Nature, And Each Paints With The Brush Of A Thoroughly Trained Artist. Mr. Dunthorne, In Vigc-Strcet, Sho-Ws A Number Of Pleasant Water--Eolour Drawings Of The Coast Of Forway, By Mr. Walter W. M.Av, A Well-Known Contributor To The Exhibitions Of The Institute. M. Bernheim, At His Gallery In Piccadillv, Invites The Pablic To Admire The Works Of A New Great Man, Theodule Augustin Ribot, Who Died A Year Ago And Whose Memory Was Honoured In The Spring By An Exhibition At The Ecole Des Beaux-Arts. Ribot Wvas A Very Fino Draughtsman, And, Not To Speak Of His Oil Pictures, He Produced Much In Water-Colour And With The Etching Needle. But His Fondness For Exaggerated Light And Shade Is Fatal To The Permanent Success Of His Pictures, The Blacks Of Which Will Infallibly Become Blacker With Time. The Present Display Is Not Extensive, Nor Aro Any Of Ribots Larger And More Important Works Included In It But His Talent-A Yery Real One-Can Be Judged From The Charming Little Picture Mv Pets A Sort Of Souvenir Do Velasquez J, From The Portrait Ealled Tlho Old Sailor, From A Number Of Very Vigorous Sketches In Oil Or In Charcoal, And From Some Masterly Etchings. The Gallery Contains Other Pictures The Best Is A Fine Landscape By Jules Duprd.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Thie Late Sidney Starr. Sensibly Limited To 36 Pietures In Oil And Water-Eolous There Is, Atthe Goupil Gallery, A Memorial Exhibition Of Works By The Late Mr. Sidney Starr 1857-1925. Mr. Starrs Work Is Of Thekind Which,.For Want Of A Better Word, One Describes As Artistic, Being More Remarkable For Tasto And Tact Than For Depth Of Feeling Or Mastery Of Construction. In His Younger Days He Was Associated With Whistler, And Sympathy With His Aims, If Not Influenced By Them, Is Expressed In The Charming Little Paintings Of The Bathing Machine And On The Shore. A Good Instance Of Pictorial Tact Is The White Skirt, Of Awoman Walking On The Cliffs, In Which The Placing Of The Figure, Th. Turn Of A Faintly Suggested Path And A-Single Star All Contribute To The General Impression. In 1892, Mr. Starr Went To America. Where He Remained And Developed As A Decorative Colourlst. His Oil Paintings Suffer Somewhat From A Treatment Of Form Which Looks Like Evasion Rather Than Simplification, Though A Sky At Sea-Point And Plumis Of The River, September, Achieve What They Set Out To Do. It Is In The Water-Colours, The Lane At Wodelesse And Autumn And The Various Studies Of Peonies, In Particular, That The Delicate Talent Of The Artist Is Best Expressed.

Author: Null
Title: Art In Building Decoration
Full_text: Art In Building Decoration. Royal Academy Exhibition. The President And Council Of The Royal Academy Are Making Arrangements For The Decorative Art Exhibition To Be Held At Burlington House In January And February, 1923, Which Is Primarily Intended To Illustrate And Promote The Application Of The Arts, In Their Several Forms, To The Permanent Decoration Of Buildings. It Is Thouglht That The Time Has Arrived For A Public Review Of The Possibilities In This Field Of Art, And It Is Confidenitly Expected That There Will Be A Large Responise From British Artists, And That They Wvill Show Themselves Fully Calpable Of Carrying On And Developing The Great Traditions Of Such Work In The Past. The Exhibition Will Include Architectural Decorations In Paintinig. Mosaic. Tapestry, Sculpture, Carving Or Metalwork, Designs, Cartoons Or Models For Such Decorations, And Designs For Stained Glass And There Wxill Also Be An Arts And Crafts Section. Arranged In Collaboration Witlh The Arts And Crafts Exhibitioni Society, And Limited To Exhibits By Members Of That Society And Other Craftsmen Who Have Been Asked To Submit Works. Works Will Be Received At The Royal Academy On December 15, 16. And 18. Ally Application For Forms And Labels. And Other Information, Should Be Made Durilig November To The Secretary, Royal Academy, Piccadilly, Wv.I.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Entertainments. Art Exhibitions. .. Collection Of Signed Miniatures. After The Invention Of Photography Miniature Painting Was Bound To Be Different From What It Had Been Before The Similarity Of Scale Alone Exerting An Almost Unavoidable Influence Upon The Artist And Those Whose Attitude To The Art Is Based Exclusively On Contemporary Work Are Likely To Be Agreeably Surprised By The Collection Of Signed Miniatures Which Messrs. Sidney Hand Are Exhibiting Attheirgalleries, 16A, Grafton-Street. The Collection Has Been Formed Mainly With The Object Of Providing Unquestionable Proof Of The Work Of As Many Artists As Possible With One Exception It Has Been Kept To Signed Miniatures, Unsigned Works, Even When Their Authorship Was Known, Having Been Rejected And In Every Case The Attempt Has Been Made To Find Not Only A Signed Work, But A Work Which Apart From The Signature Would Be Immediately Recognized By A Good Judge As A Fine And Representative Miniature By The Artist. The Unsigned Exception Is A Portrait Of Louis Napoleon, President Of The French Republic, Painted In 1851 By Sir William Ross, R.A., On A Single Piece Of Ivory Measuring 17, By 13J, To The Instructions Of Queen Victoria, And Presented By Her To Lady Farquhar. As A Work Of Art It Has No Great Merit, Suggesting That The Baneful Influence Of Photography Had Already Begun, But It Is Wonderfully Precise In Execution, And The Background And Accessories Are Pleasing In Touch And Colour. That The Collection Has Been Made With Caution Is Shown By Mr. Sidney Hands Frank Reference In His Introduction To The Catalogue To The Oil Miniature Attributed To Isaac Oliver And Bearing His Signature. He Confesses To A Slight Tingle Of Doubt, Though He Can Find No Reason For It Except That He Has Never Seen Any Of Olivers Work In Oil. The Wollection Consists Of So Miniatures, Representing 62 Artists, Arranged In Six Cases In Decorative Rather Than Chronological Order. Detailed Description Is Hardly Necessary-Particularly In View Of The Excellent Illustrated Catalogue With Its Biographical Notes On The Artists-But Attention May Be Drawn To The Special Interest Or Beauty Of The Examples By Henry Edridge 69 And F. T. Rochard 19, In Case 1. Cosway 43, In Case Ii. George Place 67 And 68, In Case Iii. - Anne Beale 37, In Case Iv. And Lawrence Crosse 56 And 57, In Case V. There Can Be No Doubt That, For Purposes Of Comparison, The Exhibition Will Be Of Great Service To Collectors. An Austrian Artist. The Paintings And Drawings By Mfr. Ronald Strasser, The Austrian Artist, At The Paterson Gallery, 5, Old Bondstreet, Well Deserved A Wider Publicity Than Thev-Or Some Of Them-Received Last October At The Austrian Legation. Mostly The Fruits Of Wanderings In Tibet And Malaya, They Bear The Unnistakable Stamp Of Work Done From An Artistic Interest In The Subjects, And Not Merely Because The Subjects Were Unfamiliar. If Mr. Strasser Has Drawn And Painted Bali Dancers And Tibetan Lamas, It Was Because The Shapes And Colours Of Them Were More To His Taste Than The Shapes And Colours Of Europeans, And One Pleasing Result Is That Their Human Characters Come Through In A Very Friendly Manner. The Merits Of The Cock Fight, At Bali, Were Commented On When It Was Shown At The Legation, And The Picture Makes An Even Better Impression Here As A Gorgeous Piece Of Designing In Colour. The Chief Interest Of The Exhibition, However, Is In The Tempera Paintings And Drawings Of Native Types. Mir. Strasser Began As A Sculptor, Working Under His Father, And The Sculptors Instinct Is Evident Not So Much In The General Forms As In The Surface Modelling, The Ripple Of Light Over Dark, Polished Skins. The Drawing Is Bold And Free, Suggesting Always An Interest In Tone Rather Than In Line, And Every Advantage Is Taken Of Decorative Opportunities In The Costumes. A Bali Dancer, A Chinese Wood Chopper, A Young Chinese Girl, And A Chinaman Holding A Pipe May Be Named For Special Qualities. But It Is The Effect Of Excited Interest In The Artist Which Makes The Exhibition Remarkable. An Italian Artist. Signor Edoardo Gioja, Who Is Exhibiting Landscapes, Drawings, Portraits And Decorations At 58, Glebe-Place, Chelsea, Is More Akin To The Great Figures Of The I Italian Renaissance Than To Most Artists Of To-Day. A Designer Before Everything, He Is Painter, Carver, Modeller And Worker In Metal And Textiles. In Rome He Has Carried Out Several Important Schemes Of Decoration-Notably At The Palazzo Rava, Now Used As The Czechoslovak Legation-Being Responsible For Both Painting And Reliefs, And An Example Of His Decorative Work Is To Be Seen In London, At The Caf6 Monico, In The Shape Of A Frieze Representing A Vintage Of The Golden Age. Signor Gioja Is Represented In The National Gallery, Rome, And Other Public Galleries By Portraits, And He Has Painted Several Distinguished People In This Country, Including The Late Baron Von Hiugel And The Late Mr. M. D. Jeejeebhoy-The Lst Being Exhibited In The Academy Of 1923. The Greater Part Of His Present Exhibition Consists Of Pastel Studies Of The Roman Campagna And Of Places On The Coast Of Italy And Brittany. Essentially Classical In Feeling, Broad In Style And Delicate In Colour, They May For Convenience Be Compared To The Work Of Giovanni Costa, Whose Influence Was Reflected In The Landscape Work Of Both Lord Leighton And Sir W. B. Richmond. Passing Clouds, Near Tivoli, La Vicomte, Dinard, And Monte Cave, Near Rocca Di Papa, May Be Named As Particularly Good Examples. The Foreshortened Head Of Baby Sleeping And Some Preliminary Studies For Decorations. Bespeak Signor Giojas Power As A Figure Draughtsman There Are Some Delightful Nature Studies Illustrating A Childrens Book, A Voi Bimbi, Wtitten By The Artist And His Versatility Is Further Shown In Some Impressed And Gilded Designs Upon Velvet, In The Venetian 16Th Century Tradition. The Exhibition Is Open Daily From 12 To 6.30 Until May 9. The Faculty Of Being Moved By The Beauty Of A Landscape Or Of A Flower Is Fortunately Not Possessed Only By Artists. Mr. And Mrs. Clhrisue Record In Their Pictures At 22, Old Bond-Street The Fact That They Were Moved By Landseapes And Flow-Ers, Ad They Sometimes Record This Quite Competently Enough For Us To Remember By Their Pictures The Emotion, Partly Unaestletic, Which We Should Feel In Contemplatiiig The Subjects Of These Pictures. But They Are Often Too Much Artists To Abandon Themselves Entirely To Addressing The Uniesthetic Emotions, And Too Little Artists To Raise The Purely Testhetic Emotion Which Might Be Roused By A Painting Of An Old Pair Of Boots, Equally As Wvell As By A Painting Of Flowers. Their Paintings Are Obviously Sincere, And The Sincere Expression Of An Emotion, Even Though It Is Mainly Unesthetic, Is Not To Be Despised. But The Conventions Of Their Fellowartists Conceal The Natural Simplicity Of Their Emotions. It Is Only In A Few Of Their Pictures, Such As No. 57, After The Shower, By Mr. Christie, Tiat These Conventions Are Sufficiently Mastered, And Therefore Hidden, And We Can Consider Only The Subject Of The Picture, Which The Painter Obviously Found Delightful, And Succeeds In Making Us See That It Was So. The Broadcasting Programmes For To-Day Wil Be Found On Page 8.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition Water-Colour And Pencil Drawings The Exhibits At The Sixty-Eighth Annual Show Of Water-Colours And Pencil Drawvings Which Opens To-Day At Messrs. Thomas Agnews Gallery In Bond Street Range From Turners Fine Water-Colour Of The Great Fall Of The Reichenbach In The Valley Of Hasle, Switzerland Which Is Done On An Unusualiv Large Scale To Two Sketches Of A Cottage And A Barn, By Alexander Cozens, Which Are No Bigger Than A Coronation Postage Stamp. The Great Eighteenth- And Nineteenth-Century Water-Colourists Are Well Represented, And Among Modern Artists There Are Excellent Examples Of The Work Of Wilson Steer And Glyn Philpot. The Reichenbach Picture, An Impressive Blend Of Blues, Greens, Browns, And Greys, Which Is Particularly Notable For The Way In Which Turner Has Caught The Play Of Sunlight On The Mist Rising Out Of A Rocky Cauldron, Would Be Outstanding In Any Company But It Has Distinguished Competitors In Peter De Wints Carisbrooke Castle, Thomas Girtins Serene Impression Of A Rainbow Over The River Exe,And Cotmans Sepia Drawing Of Ilarmoltville Church. Other Swiss Sttidies By Turner Include One Of Thc Lurleiberg And Another Of The Wettcrhorn Fromn Rosenlaui, A Thing Of The Most Perfect Delicacy, With A Blue On The Distant Mountain Which Only One Hand Could Have Given It. In The Room Devoted To Modern Artists, Where Again The Work Is Of A High Standard, Mr. Wilson Steer Is Represented By Montreuil-Sur-Mer Dated 1907-In Which He Admirably Catches The Atmosphere Of The Deserted Square Of A French Provincial Town On A Cloudy Day-And By Greenhithe In Summer, A Slight But Charming Sketch Done In 1932. Next In Interest Come Some Firstrate Figure Drawings By Mr. Glyn Philpot, Notably The Graceful Seated Nude No. 95 Done In Red Crayon, While There Are Excellent Portraits Of A Young Negro And Of A Boy Asleep By The Same Artist. Lord Methuen Also Shows An Interesting And Distinctive Study In The Nude No. 98. Hazy Weather, Cromer, Is The Best Of Sir Muirhead Bones Exhibits, Some Of Which Are A Little Disappointing. Mr. Bertram Nicholls Makes Effective Play With Sunlight And Shadow On White And Grey Stone Buildings, And Mr. Anthony Devas Shows Three Pencil Drawings Which Are All Clever Studies Of Mood. - The New Forest, By John Nash, Is A Daring Mixture Of Colour Justified By The Resuit, And, In Their Different Ways And With Varying Surccess, There Are Other Interesting Things From Paul Nash, Ethelbert White, And Claude Rogers. It Is In Fact A Well Chosen, Well Balanced Display, On Which Messrs. Agnew Can Congratulate Themselves. V A Leading Article On Sherlock Holmes On Page 5 Recalls That 50 Years Ago To-Day The Detectives Great Opponent, Professor Moriarty, Was Killed In The Reichenbach Falls.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions, 1 1 A Large Number Of Exhibitions Have Been Opening Their Doors During The Lastsew Days So Many, Indeed. As To Bewilder The Intending Visitor. Unfortunately - - It Cannot Be Said That They Contain Anything Of Groat Interest, If We Are To Except The Short Of The Senefelder Club, Which Teell And Fully Represents The State Of Artistic Lithography At The Presort Day. The Rest, Whether They Are Miscellaneous Or One Man Shows, Are Evidence Rattier Of The Quantity Of Modern Art Production Than Of Its Quality, And For The Wmfain Xsoplr Which It Few Vears Asrst The Most Part Contain Work Which A Few Years Ago Would Have Been Kept For Home Use By The Artists. And Not Put Before The Public. This Is Especially The Case With The Immense Collection Of 563 Works Exhibited By The Sketch Society At The Galleries Of The Royal Institute. The Title Is Not Well Chosen, For At Least Half The, Exhibits Are Not Sketches At All, Bub Small Finished Drawings And Paintings, Not Good Enough For The Normal Exhibitions Held In These Rooms In The Summer And Autumn. In The West Gallery We Rather Liked Mr. E. L. Pattisons The Bridge, Four Small Portraits By Mr. Arthur Garratt, Two Portrait Studies By Mr. Hugh Bunbury, A Group Of Small Landscapes By Mr. Claude Hayes, And A Dutch Interior By Mr. El J. Pearson. The Large South Gallery Shows A Larger Proportion Of Good Work. Mr. J. W. Schofield Has A Talent For Painting Moonlight Mr. Edgar Downs Can Block Out The Forms Of Animals With A Certain Vigorous Truth And Landscape And Other Sketches By Mr. Montague Smyth, Mr. Frank Carter, Mr. Max Ludby, And Mr, Terrick Williams Maintain The - Respectable Level Winch These Artists Reached Long Ago. Doubtless The Same Might Be Said Of A Good Many Others But We Remain In Doubt As To Whether The Sketch Society Has Justified- Its Separate Existence. This Club, Formed To Celebrate The Centenary Of The Invention Of Lithography By Aloys Senefelder, Is Holding Its Second Exhibition At The Goupil Gallery. It Is Strengthened By The Inclusion Of A Few Works By Manet, Renoir, F. Bops, Fantin, And Other Old Masters, But The Great Majority Of The Lithographs Are New Works By The Members Of What Seems To Be A Flourishing Society. The Men Mentioned Above Only Used Lithography Occasionally They Were Exceptions, -Who Saw The Possibilities Of The Art In A Day When It Had Become Discredited. Whistler And Fantin-Latour Were The Men Who Really Revived It And. Now All The Young Artists, And Many Of Their Elders, Are Fond Of Practising It. The Method Presents No Difficulties To Any One Who Can Draw, And Ib Certainly Reproduces Penal Work, Or Chalk Drawings, Far More Accurately Than Any Other Form Of Engraving. It Is, In Fact, As The Preface To The Cata. Logue Says, Autographic, A Lithograph By Whistler, Or By M. Steinlen, Or Such A One As Mr. Albert Sterners Charming Portrait Of A Lady, Is Practically The Same Thing As The Original Drawingso That It Is No Wonder That The Art Has Quickly Become A Favourite Both With The Artists And With The Public. Among The Most Successful Of The Exhibitors We May Mention Mr. C. H. Shannon, Mr. John Copley, Mr. E. A- Hope Who Sends Three Very Vigorous Compositions, Mr. Sterner, And Miss Mary Creighton To Whom May Be Added Such - Well-Known Foreign Artists Hans Thoma, Dfeirs Lucas, Smile- Claus, And C. Lsandre. Sir H. Von Herkomer, Who Has Presented The Club With The Death-Mask Of Senefelderhe Worked, Be It Remembered, In Bavaria, Though Born At Pragueis An Active Member Of The Society, And Sends Some Remarkable Contributions. The Manets, Which Include The Terribly Impressive Guerre Civile And The Rare Colour-Print Called Polichinelle, Are A Very Striking Feature Of The Collection. A Landscape Exhibition. It Is Creditable To The Small Group Of Painters Who Started Their Little January Landscape Exhibition In 1896 That It Has Gone On Without A Break Till Now. The 16Th Exhibition Is Open At The Royal Watercolour Societys Room In Pall-Mall East, And There Messrs. R. W. Allan, J. Aumonier, Austen Brown, J. S. Hill, And Leslie Thomson, With Three Invited Colleagues, Have Prepared A Show Of 68 New Landscapes. The Guests This Year Are Messrs. Moffat Lindner, Coutts Michie, And James Paterson, Two Of Whom Strengthen The Scottish Element In The Show Already Predominant. There Is Nothing To Say About A Display Of This Kind Except That In Its General Level Of Sound Workmanship It Repeats The Achievements Of Former Years. Mr. Austen Brown And Mr. Hill Have Sometimes Been More Successful In Landscape, But Mr. Allans Large Sea-Piece, Sir. Leslie Thomsons Holyhead Mountain, And Mr. Aumoniers Golden Autumn Vision Of Dnlas Valley Are As Good As Anything Ever Done By Them. Mr. Hills Two Little Flower-Pieces Are Exquisite. The Upper Rooms Of The Goupil Gallery Contain A Large Collection Of The Paintings Of The Late Miss Sarah Dodson Transferred From Brighton, Where They Were Shown In The Autumn. This Lady Was An American Artist, Who Worked Chiefly In Paris, Under Luminais And Jules Lefebvre Sho Died Five Years Ago, At The Age Of Ss. Her Work Shows Various Influences, For She Was An Eclectic, Following Now The Tradition Of Couture As In The Fine Picture Of Deborat?, Now That Of The Costume Painters Of The Day, And Now That Of The French Landscapists, Though In Landscape She Was Herself A Careful Student Of Nature. It Seems That The Pictures Are Presently To Be Exhibited In America, Where, Doubtless, Many Of Them Will Find A Home In The Public Galleries. The Other Exhibitions Which Open To-Day Are At The Leicester Galleries, The Fine Art Societys, The Baillie Gallery, And The Carfax Gallery. At The First-Named We Have A Large Collection Of English Water-Colours, Formed Some Years Ago By A Collector Who Died Recentiv These, Though None Is Quite First Rate, Are Interesting Examples Of Our Water-Colour Art From About 1840 To 1890. The Haddon Hall Drawings By David Cox, The Landscapes By Bennett, Mckewan, And Thomas Collier, And A Powerful Study By Cecil Lawson, Are Among The Most Noteworthy. In The Adjoining Room Are A Number Of Water-Colour Landscapes By Mr. Robert Tattle, R.W.S., A Scottish Artist Of Talent. The Fine Art Society Shows Some Extremely Pretty Garden Scenes And Flowery Mountain Landscapes By Miss Rosa Wallis, Not Very Original, But Sure To Be Popular A Large Collection Of Drawings By Mr. Egerton Hine, The Best Of Them Recalling The Down Landscapes Of His Father, Once Vice-President Of The Institute And The Pictures By Mr. Arthur Garratt, From Which The Latest Of The Innumerable Books About Eton Has Been Illustrated. Mr. Garratt Paints Well, Especially Wtien He Has To Deal With Interiors, Such As Upper School And The Hall.At The Baillie Gallery, In Bruton-Street, Are Some Good Oil Pictures, Landscapes, And Portraits, By Mr. W. J. Leech, An Artist Of Much Promise, And Some Agreeable Water-Colour Sketches, Very Slight And Transparent, By Mr. William A. Wildman.Lastly, The Carfax Gallery, In Burystreet, Contains The Recent Drawings Of Mr. Walter Sickert, A Faithful Follower Of Whistler And At The Present Time As Would Appear From A Recent Paper A Votary Of The Post-Impressionists. These Extremely Slight Performances Are Very Clever, But They Take Us Only A Very Little Way. Perhaps This Is As Well, For The Way Is Often Not The Way Of Pleasantness, Except For Those Who Find Their Ideal Of Life In The Music-Hall And Their Ideal Of Form In Beings Like That Called La Belle Hollandaise.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. . . Ar.. Won Jiitdhens. That Mr. Ivon Hitehens Is Not Limited To What The Shops Would Call Pastel Shades In His Colouring Is Shown By His Management Of Deeper Tones In The Exceueent Landscape Called The !Iluer8 Cottage, But Most Of His Oil Paintings At The Mayor Gallery, 37, Sackville-Street, Would, So To Speak, Melt In The Mouth. His Enjoyment Of Pink, Blue, And Pale Grey Is Evident In His Care To Give Them The Mamraum Of Gradation, By Choosing Rounded Forms Like Stuffed Armchairs And Puffy Eiderdown Quilts, Or By Quite Femorselessly Curving That Which A Literal Petou Would Call Straight. The Most Engaging Quality In His Work Is, Indeed, The Combination Of A Perfectly Friendly Feeling Towards Nature With A Cheerful Determination To Bend Her To His Own Uses, Which Are To Make Confections Of Shapes And Colours In The Medium Of Oil Paint. It Is Put That Way Because One Of The Nost Promising Signs In His Work Is A Feeling For The Mnaterial. Something He Owes To Matisse And Something, One Would Say, To Marie Laurencin, But He Is Young Enough To Wear These Influences Gracefully, And He Is Clearly Finding His Own. Way. So Long As He Keeps On Touching Earth His Light-Handed Way With The Facts Is No More To Be Regretted Than Is The Turning Of Blackberries Into Blackberry Jelly. That Nature Does Not Protest Under The Process Is Shown By The Amount Of Homely Feeling Which Survives In The Millers Cottage. It Has A Touch Of Cotmanesque Nobility In The Design, With A Youthful Exclamnation At The Spot Of Sunlit Grass. This, Interior, And ,Spring In Eden -With A Classical Torso For Eiv -Are Mir. Hitchenss Best Pictures. The Macrae Gallery. The Principal Aim Of Mr. E. Yarrow Jones, Who Shows Water-Colours Of Spain, Tangier, And The South Of France, With Some Animals. At The Macrae Gallery, 16, Fulham-Road, Is To Translate What He Sees Into Terms Of Pure Colour, Which He Does By The Careful Relation Of Tones In A Curious Technique Of Square Touches. Every Now And Then He Produces Something Quite Thrilling, Such As The Purple And Gold Orange Terraces, The Brown And, Purple Village Of St. Jeannet, And Some Of The Studies Of Almond Blossom But His Method Does Not Seem To Be Suitable For Al Purposes. .His Architectural Subjects Are Apt To Look Papery Through Some Defect Of Relation Between The Lighted And Shadowed Planes. But For This The Blighty Tower Swims In The Light Well Deserves Its Title You Say Swims, Yes Mighty, No. In Painting Tigers And Leopards Mr. Yarrow Jones Is Preoccupied With The Stripes And Spots, But It Is Remarkable What An Effect Of Solidity He Has Given To The Foreshortened Beast In Tigers. At The Same Galery There Are Water-Colour Impressions Of Australia By Miss Edith Vaizeyhope. These, Grouped According To State, Are Of Hardly More Than Illustrative Interest, Though One Or Two. Such As Bathing Pool, Blac -Wood River, Reach To The Artistic Meaning That The Word- Impression Conveys. The Graham Gallery. Of The Four Ladies Now Showing Watercolours At The Graham Gallery, 72, New Bondstreet, Miss Hilda Walker Is The Only One Who Rises Above The Amateur Level. She Is A Good Colourist, Able To Keep Strong Notes In Relation, And Sbe Has A Nice Firm Touch With The Brush. A Garden In Somerset, Broom And Gorse, And Blue And Gold Are Excellent For What They Set Out To Do. Mlrs. Berrill, In Her Sketches Of Yorkshire, Presents The Unusual Character Of Better Composition Than Drawing, And The Beck At Hutton Suggests That Her Talent Is Worth Cultivating. The Best Of The Brittany Sketches By Miss Noltennis Are The Studies Of Sea Holly, Her Sense Of Colour Being In Advance Of Ber Knowledge Of Form And In Some Rather Heavy-Hauded Water-Colours Of Bruges And Other Places Miss Kate Tizard Shows At Least A Feeling For The Picturesque In Architecture.

Title: Flemish Art Exhibition
Full_text: Flemish Art Exh1Bition. -O. Precautions In Digp-R At. The Pictures And Statues Lent For The Exhibitiorn Of Flemish Art At Burlington House Aie Now Being Sent Back To Their Owners, And The Dispersal Of This Collection, Drawn From Galleries At Home And Abroad, Public Andprivate, Inv6Lves Special Diffioulties. Twelve Workmen, Selected By The Authorities For Their Experience In The Handlinpg Of Art Treasures, Have Been Entrusted With The Task Of Packing. Before The Pictures -Were Taken Down They Weie Serutinized In Order To Make Certain That None Of The 764 Huoig Had Suffered The Slightest Damage, And As.They Are Removed.From The Walls They Are Severai Times Counted And The Results Checked Withh-The Most Scrupulous,Care. Whire The Work Is In Progress Theg4Lleries Are Under.Special Police Protection. During Their Transit From Burlington House To Different Parits Of The. Country. And To America, France, Holluad, And Austria Every Possible Piecaution Will Be Taken. To Guard Them From-Thieves And Aecidental Damage. The Pictures Lent By The King Are Being Sent Back To. Holyrood Uunder A Spopial Escort Many Of The Pictures Will Be Taken Abroaidin Charge Of The Curstbibof The Galleries To Which They Lbgib Esiad None Will Be .Dipatched Except Ui,Der Official Escorte . -.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition An Argentine Painter It. Is As A Vivid Record Of A Picturesque And Disappealing Phase Of Life In A Country To Wlhich We Are Closely Botund By Friendslhip And Material Initerest That The Exhibition At The Tate Gallery Of Paintings Of Scenes Of Gaucho Life In The Province Of Eiutre Rios, By The Argentine Artist Sefior Don Cesareo Bernaido De Quir6S, Will Be Chiefly Welcomed. In View Of The Generous Hospitalit.Y Given To British Arts Aid Iaiiufactuires At The Forthcoming Exhibition At Buenos Aires, The National Gallery Of British Art Was Obviously The Riglht Place For Such An Introduction To Native Life-Particularly Since Senior Quir6S Lhas No Material Interest In The Nmatter, His Pictures Being Destined For A Corpuration In The United States After They Have Betjn Exhibited By Invitation In The Luxembourg Museum, Paris. This Is Not To Say That Senior Quir6S Wonld Not Be Welcome Here On Artistic Grounds It Is Only To Mark The Essential Purpose Of His Art In This Particular Series Ot Paintings-25 In All. Tlhere Is Sufficient Evidence In The Few Landscapes Included Thlat Hie Has Sometlhing Of His Own To Tell Tls Ill Ai Pulely Pictorial Direction, Sometiung That Is Gravely Poetical In Feeling. But The Broad Fact Remains That In These Lays Of Rapid International Comnmuuicaiion, Unless A Foreign Artist Lias Some Strilng Aesthetic Message To Convey, Which Would Hardly Be Claimed For Sefior Quir6S, Lie Is Paying Us A Higher Complirnent By Present Ing Us With His Country Than Witli His Artistic Opinions And, Particularly In The Case Of Comparatively New Countries With Strongly Marked Characteristics, We Could Do Wvith More Exhibitions Of This Kind. The Impression Given By The Paintings Of Sefior Quir6S Is That These Descendants Of Thle Conquistadores Bear Somewhat The Same Relation To Their European Ancestors As The Boers Of South Africa To The Dutch Pioneers. There Is The Samxe Effect Of A Sternly Patriarchal Life, On Guard Against Natural And Human Enemies, But Aiore Concerned To Be Let- Alone Than To Adventure Farther. The Racial Types, However, Are Much More Picturesque And Unconsciously Romantic, And There Is Much More Colour In The Costumes-Red Predoninating To An Extent .Which Gains Eredit For The Artist In Controlling It. The Subjects Of Velazquez At Grass, Having Stoutened And Let Their Beards Grow And Exehanged An Urban For A Pastoral Dignity, -Would Be A Fair Description Of Several Of Tho Figures. The Justice Of The Peace, Holding His Silver-Handled Whip In One Halnd And A Documept In The Othel, Is Typical. His Judgments, One Feels, Would Minglo The Nobility Of Don Quixote With The Shrewvdness Of Sanchlo Panza. The Healer, The Butcher, And The Master Are Other Striking Realizations Of Character, But It Is In The Compositions Of Several Figures, Such As Cakes At The Races, Women In The Shade Of A Reed Thatch, Lances And Guitars, And The Minstrel And The Herdsmen That Seinor Quir6S Excites Our Keenest Interest In Both Subject Matter And Pictorial Arrangement. Three Of The Landscapes Are Nocturnes, And They, Together With The Accomplished Painting Of Flowers And Silver On A Table, S Sun Patches, Suggest Some Affinity With The French Painters Of Coloured Twilight, Such As Le Sidaner. It Was Well To Include These Pictures, Because They Show That-The Artist Can Adapt His Methods To His Materials. The Dance, In Which The Figures Are Reduced To A Flicker In The Moonlight Against The White Wall Of A House, With A Dim Glow In The Windows, Is An Adtnirable Piece Of Pictorial Reticence.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Pictures By Army Officers Intelligent Modesty Of Aim The Army Officers Art Society, Now Holding Its Eighth Exhibition At The Suffolk Street Galleries, Has Long Ceased To Depend-If It Ever Did Depend-For Interest On The Suggestions Of Its Title, Though It Undoubtedly Gains In Distinctive Character From Its Constitution. The Kind Of Watercolour Intended By Mir. Bernard Shaws Colonel Of The Old Water-Colour School Can Be Found In The Present Exhibition, But It Is So Much In The Minority As To Make The Jest A Compliment, As Meaning That A Sense Of Proportion And Order And Skill In The Control Of A Difficult Medium Would Be Presumptive Evidence Of A Good Soldier-By No Means An Extravagant Claim. The Exhibition, Of 300 Works, Is Verv Well Drilled In Open Order, And Every Picture Gets Its Chance. Allowing For Variety, A Rough Division Can Be Made Between Works Which Have What Are Felt To Be The Special Virtues Of The Amateur, And Works Which Follow, More Or Less Successfully, Professional Practice. Typical Of The First Class Ate The Small Bright Oil Paintings By Lieutenant-Colonel F. A. Goddard. For Convenient Description They Are Pre-Raphaelite Paintings, But They Have What The Kind Generally Lacks, A Precision In Tone Registration To Match Their Precision In Drawing. A Pond Is As Good An Example Of Detailed Statement, With Everything Kept In Its Place, As One Could See Anywhere, And It Has, Moreover, Great Charm Of Restrained Colour. Another Excellent Painting By The Same Artist Is Clock Golf, In Which The Relation In Space Between The Two Girls, Dressed Alike, Is Decided As Much Bv Tone Of Blue And White As By Comparative Size. How Rare Is This Combination Of Gifts May Be Seen By Looking At Other Works In A Somewhat Similar Style Such As The Water-Colour Near Srinagar, Kashmir, By Captain H. R. Dixon-Smith. In Both General Plan And Detail The Drawing Is Excellent, But The Relations Ih Colour Do Not Explain The Relations In Space So Perfectly As They Do In The Work Of Colonel Goddard. He Is Cultivating A Small Field, But He Is Cultivating It With The Most Admirable Taste And Skill. In What May Be Called The Sargentesque Way Ot Painting Thc Niost Brilliant Piece Of Work Is- Pigs In Slinlight, By Captain W. L. T. Fisher. Hc Has Observed, But Not Lost His Head Over, The Circumstance That The Shadows On White Objects In Sunlight Are Blue, And The Painting Is Joyously Swung Together. On The Whole, However, Thc Honours In The Mnore Professional Kind Of Painting Must Go To Colonel Wv. S. S. Harvest. Lic Has Seven Landscapes In Oil, All Distinguished By Breadth Of Touchi And Plcasantly Cool Colour. Hrece In Particular May Be Named- A Sunset, Boumemouth, Wistful In Gesture And Tender In Colour-Rather Like A Steer- The Valley Of Thc Auber, In Vhich Elaborate Detail Has Not Weakened The Grasp Of The Main Features, And A Street .Ene, The Markusturm, West Side, Rothenburg. There Is A Quiet Assurance About Thc Landscape Work Of Colonel Harvest Which Is Very Pleasing. What Strikes One Most About The Exhibition As A Whole Is The Prevailing Intelligent. Modesty Of Ainm. There Are Very Few Arnbitious Performances. The Most Obvious Is A Large Figure Subject-A Rembrandt Composition It Might Be Called- Talitha Cumii-I Am The Resurrection And The Lifc, By Lieutenant-Colonel H. Paul Ireeby. The Artist Has Not Quite Known What To Do With The Shape Of The Large Area Of White Formed By Thc Bed, But The Picture Is Good In Feeling, Unconventional In The Physical Types, And Singularly Attractivc In The Colour Scheme Of Green, Whitc, And Mauve. The Exercises In What May Be Callcd Rhythmical Solidity, With Horses For The Subjects, By Lieutenant C. S. Brownlow, Are Interesting. That Thcy Should Break Down In Places Is Not Surprising, For To Keep Up A Continuous Movement In Three Dimensions Is Extremely Difficult. A Genuine Artistic Sensibility Is Expressed In The Water-Colours Of Moorland And Coast Scenery By Major-General Sir Arthur Scott. Carefully, Though Loosely, Drawn, And Carried Out In A Limited Scald Of Tones, With Blue-Grey And Mauve Predominating, They Are Delightful Examples Of Their Kind. Sandsend Bay, Whitby, And Newton Dale, Yorks, May Be Specially Mentioned. Other Pictures To Be Noted In A Necessarily Glancing Record Are From My Window, By Colonel R. J. Strachey, Market Day, Vannes. By Mlajor F. A. Wilkinson, Old Mill, Wickham, By Captain J. B. Slade-Baker. And Cork Trees. Hyeres, By Lieutenant-Colonel W. Howel Jones. All Available Profits From The Sale Of Catalogues Will Be Devoted To The Soldiers, Sailors And Airmens Families Association. Miodern English School At The Galleries Of Messrs. Tooth And Son, 155, New Bond Street, The Contemporary Art Society Is Holding An Exhibition Of About 50 Oil Paintings, Water-Colours, And Draxwings Which It Has Acquired. This Has Every Clairn To Be-Considered A Thoroughly Representative Collection Of Modern English Painting If A Foreigner Wished To Know What The English Had Done Recently He Might Conveniently Be Referred To This Exhibition. The Societys Selection Is Cxtremely Eclectic, As, Of Coursc, It Should Be. There Is Even One Work Which Is Entirely Academic In The Ordinary Sense Of The Word, Though Not In The Technical Sense Which Allows One To Call A Cubist Picture Academic. It Is No Reproach To The Society That It Scems To Have Bought With Extraordinary Impartiality, Now Choosing Works Which Are Almost Entirely Illustrative, And Now The Most Uncompromising Displays Of Pure Painting. And It Is Probably Not So Much An Indication Of The Societys Taste, As Of The Taste Of The Available Painters, That There Is So Large A Proportion Of Works Which Can Only Be Described As Mannered. All The Temptations Of The Mannerist, The Cultivation Of Minor Clegancies And Flourishes, Exaggerations Of Rhythm And Curiosities Of Texture, Together With A Certain Quaintness In Illustration, May Be Studied In This Exhibition. Messrs. Paul And John Nash, Messrs. Stanley And Gilbert Spencer, Mr. Ben Nicholson, Mr. Edward Wadsworth, Mr. Cedric Morris, Mr. Neville Lewis, And Mr. David Jones Are All Represented By Characteristic Works. Often, Of Course, Their Ingenuity Is Very Seductive-If Mannerism Were Quite As Pointless As Historians Of Art Pretend When They Come To The Period Of The Mannerists It Would Never Be Practised-But One Can Hardly Cscape The Conclusion That This Exhibition Is Overloaded With Charm. But There Are A Number Of Most Serious And Eminent Works To Restore The Balance. Two Fine Works By Mr. Sickert A Still-Life By Mr. Duncan Grant, Which Is Perhaps Not An Entirely Representativc Work, Since, Though The Colour Is Equal To His Best, The Flowers Have A Papery Lack Of Solidity Which Is Not At All Characteristic Of This Artist A Large And Imposing Still-Life By Mr. M1Ark Gcrtler- In -Hisi Most Uncompromising Manner A Grave And Intellectual Design, The Top Floor, By Mr. Robert Medley, Which Is Painted With A Robust Mastery Of The Medium Mr Roger Frys Sussex Downland, An Unusually Romantic Work And Several Of Mr. William Roberts Elaborate Designs-These Are Enough To Restore The Gravity Of The Exhibition And To Prove The Scriousness Of The Contemporary Art Societys Taste.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Entertainments Art Exhibitions Mr. Herbert Haseltine Any Feeling Of Uncertainty About Mir. Herbert Haseltines Purely Sculptural Powers-His Capacity For Translating Natural Forms Into Terms Of Bronze Or Stone In A Composition Of Niasses Which Shall Be Satisfying Irrespective Of What It Represents-Is Put Aside In Appreciation Of His Tact, Judgment, And Skill In Tho Application Of Such Powers As He Lundoubtedly Has. Having Observed That The Animals-The Suffolk Punch, The Percheron, And The Champion Bull-Which Predominate In His Present Exhibition At Messrs. Knoedlers, 15, Old Bond-Street, Are Sculptural In Themselves, He Wisely Lets Them Alone, Contenting Himself With A Slight Stylization Of The Forms And A Slight Emphasis Upon Planes, And Devoting Himself To A Decorative Treatment Of Surface Character, Coat And Mane, So That Each Piece Becomes A Work Of Beautiful Craftsmanship. In Principle He Followvs The Example Of The Chinese Artists Of The Tangor, Rather, Wei-Dynasty. Except On Account Of The Beauty Of The Material It Would Not Be Easy To Say Why Mr. Haseltines Work In Stone Gives More Pleasure Than His Work In Bronze But There Is Nothing In His Present Exhibition That Leaves Such A Satisfying Impression As Suffolk Ptmch Stallion Sudbourne Premier And Percheron Stallion Rhum, In Burgundy Stone-Even Though The Bronze Version Of The First Has Mane Ornaments Of Lapis Lazuli And Onyx Eyes. Hereford Bull Twvyford Fairy Boy, In Bronze, Partially Plated With Gold, Shows To Advantage His Way Of Giving Decorative Interest To Surface By A Conventional Treatment Of The Locks Of Lhair. It Is When One Comes To The Slighter Aninials, Such As The Thoroughbred Horse Composite Type And Polo Pony Perfection That One Begins To Wonder If Mr. Haseltines Work Is As Good As It Looks Whether It Does Not Represent A Simplified Anatomy Rather Than A Sculptors Grasp Of The Volumes And, Beautiful As They Are From The Craftsmanship Point Of View, And Wvell Proportioned In General Designthe Beast Being In One Block With The Pedestal-It Is Questionable If His Two State Bullocks, In Burgundy Stone, Do Not Escape From Formal Control. There Is A Slight Effect Of Something Beginning To Knelt. A New Departure For Mr. Haseltine Is Thle Mlodel, In Gilded Bronze, Of An Equestrian Statue Of The Sixteenth-Century Warrior, Jam Rawvalji, For The Present. Maharajah Jmnsalieb Of Nawanagar, To Be Completed On The Heroic Scale. So Far As The Horsealert And Erect, With Iwvard Pricked Ears --Is Concerned, It Looks As If It Would Enlarge Satisfactory, But The Figure Of The Warrior Seems To Need A More Construetive Treatment. It Is Not True In Sculpture Thlat Nature Never Lets You Down. A Mnild Protest May Be Entered Here Against The Increasing Lhabit Of Wvhat May Be Called Freak Catalogues To Art E.Xhibitions-Odd Shapes And Sizes, With Trimmings. Mr. Haseltines Bears On Its Cover A Thin Brass Plate, With An Incised Design In Black Of A Horses Head. This Is Very Pretty And All That, But The Corners Of The Plate Inevitably Detach Themselves, To The Risk Of Scratching The Hand And Making Inconvenient The Preservation Which The Photographic Illustrations Deserve. Apart From Practical Disadvantages, Too, Such Adventitious Aids Are Bolund To Create The Subconscious Impression-Obviously Unjustified In This Case-That The Exhibition Cannot Be Trusted To Stand On Its Own Merits. Lefevre Galleries The Least Mannered Of The Wlorks In Sculptture And. Drawings By Mr. Csaky, A Naturalized Frencli Artist Of Hungarian Extraction, At The .Lefevre Galleries, La, Ksing-Stieet, St. Jamess, Are Laigle, In Black Basalt, And Ly N Endoin I In Bronze. These Are Very Good Compositions, Close To The Materials Of Wvhich They Are Rnade, And Fiumly Simphfliqd In The Treatment Of Form. Together With Soine Vases, In Bronze, And Such Little Statuettes As Fenmme Debout And Femme Au Miains Eroisees, They Leave The Impression That Mdr. Csaky Is Really A Decorative Artist., Somnething Betweern A Sculptor And An Architect In His Instincts. Hiis General Progress-All The Works Are Diated-Appears To Hav-E Beenl Fr Oml Cubistn Under The Influence Of Mi. Josephi Bernard, Wvithl Its Gracefull Mdrierisnis Mnost Evridciit In Thle Figures In Stone. An Arni Throwvn Over The Head, .For Instance, Is A Frequent Theme. But Le R6Pos, In Whito Miarble, Is A Pretty Little Thinlg, And There Is Niueh To Adajire In Torse, In A Spotted Stone. In All Materials Mr. Csaky Is An Exceellent Eraftsman, Finishing His Bronzes Wvitlh A Beautiful Sturface, And His Drawinlgs Help To Support The Belief That His True Province Is In Architectural Applicationl. M Hr J.-R. Monsell The Coloured Drawvings By Mir. J1. R. Mlonsell At The Mlacrae Gallery, 16, Fuliani-Road. Give The Pleasure That Is Felt When The Knowvledge, Taste, And Judgment Of The Atrtist Are Ahead Of Etle Technical Powers. There Is Little Facility In R3Lr.. Monsdlls Work,S-But Everything Is Well Considered And Staited Withl A Tactful Economy. Most Of Thci Drawings Areas Described, With The Fuledtf Basis Tiikicgithe Chief Responsibility, But The Best Of All, The Miole, St. Jean-Def.Uz, Jutting Out Inkto The Sea Is Mnainly In Wvash, Leading To The Conclusion That With Increased Courage Mir. Mionsell Might Develop Into An Excellent Painter In Water-Colour Anotlher Drawing To The Same. Purpose Is On The Front, Alassie, With A Charming Pattern Oe Green Shutters. Msost Of The Subjects Are In The Basque Proviiices, But There Are Some Appreciative Studies Of Classicall Remains, Such As Temple Of Neptune, Paestum And Temple Of Castor And Pollux, Grigente. Delicate Colour Is Onie Of The Attractions In The Work Of Mr. Mionsell.
