Author: Null
Title: Exhibition Of Mogul Art
Full_text: Exhib1Tion Of Mogul Art European Inelt Tf.Ncz.1S The British Museum Has Arranged In The Print Room An Exhibition Of The Mogul Art Of India, Mainly Represented By A Selection From The Museums Unrivalled Collection Of Miniatures, But Also By Gold Coins And Carved Jade. To The Average Amateur Of Art Mogul Painting May Appear Very Much All Of A Piece, But The E,Hibition Is Skilfully Designed To Show The Various Influences That Went To Its Formation This Style Was Compounded Of Four Different Ingredients And Each Of These Is Displayed And Distinguished On Separate Screens. The Most Curious Shows The Influence Of European Art Jesuit Missionaries Brought Samples Of Christian Art, Mainly Flemish And Gerran Engravings But Also Flemish Miniature Paintings, To The Court Of Akbar, And A Little Later Secular Painting Of The European School Became Known When Sir Thomas Roe Showed Miniatures, Probably Of The School Of Hilliard, To Jabangir. This Influence Produced A Number Of Works That Seem More Strange Than Beautiful, And There Are Some Very Singular Examples Of Paintings Done Over European Engravings, But. It Appears That Mogul Painting Did In Fact Owe Some Of Its Atmospheric Effect And Sense Of Space To European Art. Nevertheless It Was The Introduction Of Persian Art By Akbar And Other Rulers Which Had The Most Profound Effect On The Indian Painting Of This Time, And The Most Refined And Exquisite Miniatures Are To Be Found Among Those In Which The Persian Influence Predominates.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exetbit10Ts. We Are Glad To Welcome The New English Art Club Back To The Dudley Gallery In Piccadilly From Their Temporaly Exile At Knightsbridge. There They Had To Be Content With Rooms That Were Never Intended For The Display Of Pictures And, In Spite Of The Praiseworthy Efforts Of The Members To Convince The Public Of The Superiority Of Side Lights To Top Lights, The Exhibition Was A Failure. In Their Old Quarters We Can See Tho Pictures Perfectly And, According To Our Temperament, Enjoy Or Dislike To The Full These Audacious Attempts To Mako The British Public See Nature Through Artists Eyes. People Who Visit Picture Galleries Have By This Time Learned To Know What They Must Expect From The New English Art Club, An Association Of Young Men And Women, Not All Of Them English, Who Paint For The Most Part Under Influences Which Come To Them From Paris Through Mr. Whistler. The Word Impressionism Has Gradually Become More And More Limited In Its Technical Meaning, But, Broadly Speaking, It Is The Word That Best Describes The General Character Of The Art In This Room. The Impressionism, Indeed, Of M. Blanche Is Very Different From That Of Messrs. Henry And Hornel That Of Mr. Paul Maitland Is Far Removed Fiom That Of Mr. Alexander Roche. But Still The Word, For Want Of A Better, Must Serve To Cover Them All. All The Painters Here Are Preoccupied With The Desire To Paint Things As They See Them To Paint Pictures And Not Illustrations Of Literature To Solve Artistic Problems, And To Banish And Utterly Forego Each And All Of The Non-Artistic Qualities Which The English Mind Is Accustomed To Associate With Works Of Art. Their Work, Therefore, Will Only Appeal To A Relatively Small Public, Though An Increasing One. The Present Exhibition Is, On The Whole, An Adequate Measure Both Of The Abilities Of Theso Young Painters And Of The Leading Tendencies In The Art Of The Present Time. Sincerity, Great Labour, And A Strong Desire To Get At Truth Of Impression Are Evident In The Work Of Such Men As Mr. P. W. Steer, Mr. Walter Sickert, Mr. George Thomson, Mr. Edward Stott, Mr. Francis Bate, And Mir. Frod Browrn, To Mention Only A Few Out Of Many And The Same May Be Said Of The Pictures Of Two Accomplished Foreign Members Of The Club-Ndi. Blanche And Roussel. All Of These Show Capital Work, Perhaps The Most Conspicuous Successes Being Mr. George Thomsons The Skating Rink 4, Air. Sickerts Dieppe 42, And M. Blanches The Pink Rose 26. The Last, Howeveri Clever And Interesting As It Is, Might Very Wvell Be Taken To Show That These Artists, In Their Revolt Against Tradition, Are But Flying From One Conventionality To Another. The Childs White Face Is Not Nature It Is M. Blanches Parti Pris. The Dieppe Is Extremely Clever, And Is, Moreover, A Charming Picture While Mr. Thomson Has Succeeded In A Remarkable Degreo In Giving Movement To His Skaters. Of The Landscapes, Those Of Mr. Laidlay, Mr. Bate, And Mir. Bellingham Smithwvill, Perhaps, Attract The Most Attention And, Among The Portraits, Mfr. Steers M Lrs. Cyprian Wvilliams And Her Children And Mr. J. J. Shannons Sketch-Profile Of The Duchess Of Portland Are Noteworthy. A Word Should Be Added Of Lhfr. Paul Maitlands Extremely Careful Pastel, A Lamplight Scene Of The Streets 98, Of Mr. F. A. Jacksons Study Of Geese 71, Of Miss S. C. Harrisons Portrait Head 7I And Of A Clever Sketch By Mir. Jacomb-Ihood, Whose Work Has Littlo In Common With That Of The Majority Of The Members. Lovers Of Japan And Its Art Will Be Interested In A Small Exhibition Of Water-Colour Drawings By Mr. John Varley And Mlr. Charles Fripp, Which Opened Yesterday At Mr. Larkins Gallery, 28, New Bond-Street. These Artists Have Travelled In Japan And Painted What They Saw Mr. Varley Chiefly Landscapes And Mir. Fripp Figure Subjects. The Former Are The More Successfuj, For Mr. Firipp, Though He Can Paint The Details Of A Figured Robe With No Little Skill, Fails On Tho Constructive Side Of His Art.

Title: Flemish And Belgian Art
Full_text: Flemisii And Belgian Art Exhibition In London. The Angfo-Lselglan Union Is Arranging An Exhibition Of Flemish And Belgian Art Dating From 1350 To 1900, To Be Held At The Royal Academy In January. And February Next, By Permission Of The President And Council Of The Royal Academy. 4. An Execttive Committee Has Been Formed, Which Includes Lord Burnham, Sir Frank Dicksee, Sir Lionel Earle, Mr. Lionel Cust, Mr. R. Anning Bell, And Mr. Algernon Maudsley. M. Paul Lambotte, Director Of The Beaux- Arts In Brussels, Is In Charge Of The Arrangements In Belgium, And Was Present At The First Meeting Of The Executive, Which Has Just Been Held. The Exhibition Wviu Comprise Works Of The Most Celebrated Early Flemish Artists, Tapestries, Drafts, Wood-Carving, And Sculpture, And Also A Smal Exhibit Of Belgian Artiats Of The 19Th Century. A Large Collection Of Notable Works Of Art Of The Period In Question Has Been Promised By Collectors In This Country. No Such Exhibition Of Belgian Paintings Has Been Held Since 1805, When There Was A Similar Exhibition At Gifildhau In London.-Reuter.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Miniatures. , , Miniature Painting Seems To Be In A Flourishing Condition, Although The Books Tell Us That It Died When Photography Was Born. It Had, Indeed, A Time Of Eclipse, But It Has Come Forward Again With Votaries More Numerous Than Ever.. Besides The Exhibitors Who Show At The -Academy, Where They Are Not Very Well Treated, There Are In London Two Large Societies, Whereof The One Which Bears The Prefix Royal Has Filled The Gallery Of The Royal Water-Colour Society, In Pall-Mall East, With Some 270 Of Its Productions. Of No Kind Ot Art Is It More Difficult To Give An Account- That Shall Really Distinguish, For In The Painting Of Small Portraits Like Theseand Nine-Tenths Of The Exhibits Are Portraits The Differences Of Style Are Naturally Small. The Late Sir Richard Holmes, Who Was Keeper Of The Royal Collection Of Miniatures, Once Gave A Lecture On The Art, And Illustrated It By Coloured Photographs Of The Size Of Life, Which He Threw Upon The Lanternscreen. Then Indeed It Was Easy Enough To See The Difference Between The Bad And The Good, Between The Careful And The Perfunctory, Between The Artistic And The Conventional. One Could Not Only See The Greatness Of Holbein And Cooper And The Comparative Weakness Of Cosway And Firmer, But One Could Distinguish In A Moment Between These Two Men, And Between Both Of Them And Their Contemporaries Like Engleheart. But The Modern Miniaturist Has Not To Submit To Any Such Cruel Test, Which Is Perhaps Fortunate. A Large Number Of The Exhibitors Produce Portraits Which Are Agreeable And Fairly True, The Goodness Of The Likeness Depending In Many Cases On. The Aid Given By Photography, Which Has Now Been-, Summoned As An Ally, After Having At First Been Regarded As An Enemy. The Large Majority Of The Artists Are Ladies, And Among Them, Though Selection Is. Not. Easy, An Impartial Judge Might Honestly Give High Praise To Quite 15 Or 20. To. Follow, The Order Of The Catalogue, We Admire The Work Of Miss K. W. Walker 11, Miss Myra Luxmoere 13, Miss Hepburn-Edmunds 15, Mrs. Rapley Wood 40, Who Paints Hair Admirably. Miss E. M. Burgess 58, Miss M. E. Broadhead 83, Miss Burrell With Some Royal Portraits 92, 94, Miss Emilio King 142, Miss Inez Buchanan 176, Miss B. J. Johnson 204, And Miss E. G. Thomson,Whose Mrs.Scott 233 Is A Very Complete. Little Picture. The Few Male Members Include Mr. Alyn Williams, The President, Whose Work Is Always Accomplished Mr. O. W. Quinnell, Who Should Not Represent His Young Ladies As If They Had Painted Their Lips Mr. C. Spencelayh 69, And Sir James Linton, Who Sends Some Highly Finished Drawings Of. 16Th Century Historical Scenes, In His Well-Known Manner. A Little Variety Is Imparted To The Exhibition By Some Tiny Sculptured Works In Plaster Or Bronze By Mrs. Stabler, Who Has A Good Deal Of Talent, By The Coloured Wax Heads By Misses E. And N. Casella, And By The Triptych 114 Ot Miss Jessie Bayes. 1 , I . ,

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Entertainments Art Exhibitions Sculpture And Drawings At Stafford Gallery Sculpture And Drawings By Sculptors Are The Present Attraction At The British Art Centre, Stafford Gallery, 13, St. Jamess Place. The Feature Is A Collection Of Works By Mrs. Elsa Fraenkel, Who Has Won Favourable Attention By The Combined Subtlety And Firmness Of Her Portrait Heads. So Far As Can Be Judged She Is A Portrait Rather Than A Monumental Sculptor, And Her Affinities Appear To Be With The East Rather Than With The Mediterranean. A Characteristic, Suggesting A Subjective Approach, Is That Many Of Her Heads Are Represented With Closed.Eyes. It Is, No Doubt, The Accident Of Physical Type That Makes The Very Rev. Haham Dr. M. Gaster Work Out A4Tonishingly Like A Chinese Sage, But There Are Several Other Heads That Recall Khmer Bronzes In Their Firm Simplification Without Loss Of Expression. An Interesting Contrast Is Presented By Mathematician Working And Mathematician Lecturing. In The Former The Eyes Are Closed And The Whole Expression Is Inward, While The Second, With Open Eyes. Gives Out All The Time. Sidney Sabin, Of Which The Subject Happens To Be Familiar, Speaks For Mrs. Fraenkels Power Of Getting A Lileness, And Madeleine And Swiss Pianist Are Other Good Examples Of Her Sensitive Art. Her Drawings Are Of An Infinite Delicacy, Retiring Into The Paper So That Plastic Quality Is Not Lost For All The Slightness Of Delineation. In The Mixed Exhibition Of Sculpture And Drawings 51 Artists Are Represented, Including Mr. Jacob Epstein, Mr. Frank Dobson, Miss Dora Clarke, Miss -Dora Gordine, Miss Barbara Hepworth, Miss Gertrude Hermes. Mr. Maurice Lambert, Mr. Benno Schotz, And Mr. John Skeaping. It Is A Most Interesting Collection In A Great Variety Of Styles. The Nude At The Leger Gallery, 13, Old Bond Street, There Is The Sixth Exhibition Of The Nude In Contemporary Art. In Spite Of The Fact That Works From France, Where They Do This Sort Of Thing Better On The Whole, Are Few And Far Between, It Strikes One As Above, The Average Of The Series. One Reason Is, Undoubtedly, Because The Exhibition Contains Fewer Works Among The 70 Or So Pictures And Drawings In Which The Nude Model Is Not Translated Into The Condition Of Painting. By Far The Most Complete And Consistent Example Of This Translation Is The Broadly Painted Foreshortened Figure By Mr. Matthew Smith. This Has An All-Through Character Which Is Lacking To Some Extent Even In The Excellent Composition By Rodrigo Moynihan, In Which The Figure Is Felt To Be In A Slightly Less Degree Of Translation Than The Surroundings, Which Include Flowers And The Small Reflected Figure Of The Painter. Another Delightfully Consistent Piece Of Work Is The Small Study 6, By Miss Ethel Walker, A.R.A., And The Deeply Recessed Reflected Figure 12 By Mr. Walter Sickert Has Its Own Charm Of Low-Toned Colour. Other Artists Who Bring Distinction Into A Collection In Which There Is Very Little That Is Positively Unpleasant Are Mr. Duncan Grant. Lord Methuen, Mr. Kenneth Rowntree, Mr. Robin Darwin, Mr. Arnold. Mason, A.R.A., Mlrs. Vancssa Bell, And Miss Fairlie Harmar.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. The Leicester Galleries. With Paimtings By Mr. Ernest Procter And Mrs. Dod Procter- In One Room, Paintings By Mr. Leon De Smet In Another, And Drawings And Statuettes By The Late Mr. William Caine In A Third, Thetleicester Galleries May Be Said To Fulfil The Claims Of Solidity, Colour, And Humour. Though They Are Not Sworn To The Place, The Procters Represent An Intersting Develop. Ment Of The Newlyn School. To A Certiiin Extent They Take The Same Subject Matter-The Fisherfolk, The Streets, And The Harbour-But Give To It A Formal As Well As An Illustrative Interest. It Is Their Retention Of A Reasonable Amount Of The Latter Which Distinguishes Them From The Whole-Hoggers For Plastic Design. Of Their Plastic Sense There Can Be No Doubt Whatever, But They Somehow Seem To Be Able To Indulge It Without Distortmg Or Dehumanizing Their Subjeots. Simplification Without Distortion Mnight Be Their Motto. Moreover-And Nar-Ticularlyirgmr. Procter-They .Show More Consistency Than Most In Making Colour And Substance Contribute To Their Plastic Effects. Mir. Proctor Has The More Lively Imagination, The Keener Taste For Colour In The Abstract, And The More Sensitive Feeling For Atmosphere In Landscape. His Biost Inportant Contribution Is, However, A Sculptural Exercise, The Neglectful Shepherd, With The Feminine Reason For His Neglect, In Subsequent Repose. It Is A Long Picture, Remotely Resembling The Botticelli Mars And Venus In Composition, But Much More Complicated In The Relations Between The Two Figures. The Disposition Of The Limbs Working Out As A Horizontal Figure Of Eight. No Praise Can Be Too High For The Combined Logic And Grace With Which The Group Is Treated. The Light Would Appear To Be That Of The Moon, Or Of Early Dawn, Reducing The Colour Scheme To Pale Gold And Purple Grey, So That Nothing Is Allowed To Weaken The Sculpturalunity Of The Whole. Mr. Proeterisalso Represented By Some Excellent Landscapes, Newlyn And Porthsvw8Rra For Choice, Studies For Decorations, A Record Of The Burmese Visit Which Did So Much To Confirm The Powers Of Both Artists, And Some Smaller Pictures Including A Delightful Study Of The Fantastic Movement Of Chairoplanes. Mrs. Procter Has Put All Her Science And Skill Into A Baby, Lying On His Back On A Blue Cushion On A Mound Of Grey Rugs. Apart From All The Other Merits Of This Picture, Happy Placing, Incisive, Drawimg, And Beauty Of Colour, One Cannot Sufficiently Admire The Nice Graduation Of The Handling, Distinguishing Textures But Keeping Everything In The Unity Of Pigment. Almost Equally Good Are The Half-Lengths Of Janey And Girl In Blue -The Latter Made Very Interesting In Design By The Arrangement Of The Arms -Both Combining With Their Formal Qualities A Reserved Appreciation Of Human Character. Somehow The Landscapes And Still Life Subjects By Mrs. Procter Do Not Reach The Same High Level, But They Are All Serious Exercises. There Is A Distinct Affinity Between The Work Of These Two Interesting Young Painters And The Sculptture Of Mr. Frank Dobson, And It Represents A Very Healthy Movement In Contemporary English Art. Mir. Non De Smet Is, Before Everything, A Decorative Colourist, Finding His Most Characteristic Expression In Stilllife Subjects, Including Flowers, And Portraits In Costumes That Allow Him To Idulgehis Enjoyment Of Pattern. Hisaim Is To Provide A Festival For The Eye, And In A Bowl Of Flowers, The Green Tray, And Zinnias He Comes Near To Persuading Us To Give Ourselves Up To It. The Most Attractive Of His Figure Subjects Is A Merry-Go-Round, In Which The Decorations Of The Machine Itself Have Helped His Design. Nobody, So To Speak, Knew That The Late Mr. William Caine Was An Artist As Well As, The Author Of Extravagantly Humorous Novels. His Drawings, Mostli Illustrations To The Gluttons Mirror, Published By Messrs. Fisher Unwin, Have The Same Extravagance The Same Down- A Right Statement In A Reckless Disregard Of Probability. Very Bold And Simple In Style, They Are Exuberant In Imagination And Quite Out Of Bounds In Caricature. You Accept Them As You Accept The Situation In Lady Shebas Last Stunt. Even More Astonishing Are The Fantastic Bronzes By The Same Artist, Representing Types And Accidents In A Sort Of Chinese Baroque, With Plastic Feeling In Every Curve. Mer. Russeill Flint. To A Certain Extent Mr. W. Russell Flint, A.R.A., Suffers From His Own Facility In The Handling Of Water-Colour For The Purposes Of Gradation, And There Ore Signs In The Exhibition Of His Recent Works In That Medium At The Galleries Of The Fine Art Society, 148, New Bondstreet, That He Is Trying To Break Himself Of A Habit Which Limited The Expression Of His Powers As A,Painter. To Put It Crudely, He Is Flattening His Style And Rolying More On The Natural Tendency Of The Wash, While Rightly Preserving The Distinction Between More Or Lass Realistic Studies From Nature And The Decorative Illustra. Tions.Which Represent Another Side Of His Talent. That It Will Cost Him S,Oire Im.Nediate Popularity Is Likely Enough, But Tle Findl Result Is Bound To Be For The Better. . In Certain Landscapes, Such As Headlands Of Morvern, Abendberg, .Grimmnialp, And Vanishing Mistssannox Bay, Arran, He Has Already Gone The Whole Way And Allowed The Pic. Ture To Form Itself Out Of Washes In Just Relations Of Tone And Colour. It Is In The -Relation Of. Figures To Landscape, Par. Ticularly Nude Figures, That The Defect In Mr. Flints Style Has Been Most Apparent, And Here He Has Undoubtedly Gained From Painting In Switzerland, Where Figures Tell Against The Snow In Flat Colour. The Ski Partys Return, With Its Enchanting Design -A La Japanese, Is Actually The Best Of The Swiss Pictutes, But Lthe Rink With Its Unshadowed Relation Of Figures To The Ice, Is A Good One And There Are Several Others Which Give Pleasure. In His Pictures Of Girls Bathing, Mr. Flint Always Gains By The Addition Of Drapery-As In Rthree Models, In Which Deck Chairs Play A Connecting Part Between Bare Flesh And Landscape. The Statue By The Sea, In Which Living And Sculptured Forms Are -Compared, Has Its Own Interest. The Abbey Gallery. The Best Of The Water-Colours Of Xorth Frica, -Italy, 8Icily, And France By Mr. A. B. Prescott At The 4Bbey Gallery, 2, Victortostreet, Are Those In Which Decoiative Colour Has Forced The Hand Of The Artist Out Of A. Too Small Treatmeent Of Nature. Ai. Eastern Market Place, With Its Reds, Oranges,. And Mauves, The Orange Terrace, And Venetiun Fruit And Vegetable Barge Are Examiples. In M Lentone The Picture, As A Picture, Is Saved By- Its Charm Ofgatbern A Light Screen -F -Grolives Framing. The Pink Tolwn. Mr. Prescotts Colour Tezies To Betoo.Pretty But ,It As Itsa,Ppeai, Hnd Blistare And Sklli Representing Det4Ail D,Eser.Ve Recognition. His Eapacity For Detail Finlds Suitable Employment ,In. So,Me. E,Tchings Of Old, Buiildings .Inl,Bristol ,And E,Lsewhere. - -T1Ie- Ada.Iug Ornteo R To Days A8Nd Rcdtlng N6Tes Wil Be

Author: FROM A CORRESPONDENT
Title: Italian Art
Full_text: Entertaininents Italian Art British Museum Exhibition From A Correspondent Thie British Museum Has Arranged To Open Early In January A Special Display Of Italian Art Supplementary To The Burlington House Exhibition. The Department Of Manuscripts Possesses Some Of The Finest Work Of The Italian Miniaturists, And A Selection Of These Illuminations Widl Be Placed On View In The Grenville Library Of The Museum Adjoining The Vestibule On January 6. Ont The Following Day A Larger Exhibition Of The Museums Italian Drawings, Woodeuts, And Engravings Will Be Opened To The Public In That Section Of The King Edward Vii. Galleries Normally Reserved For Select Prints. Of The 41 Maniuscripts Chosen For Exhibition In The Grenville Library The Majority Are Works Of Devotion. The Earliest Of These Is The 12Thcentury Beneventan Esultet Roll Reproduced This Year, In Which The Writing And Illuminations Face In Opposed Directions. The Latest Are A Collection Of Small Florentine Books Of Htours And A Breviary From Santa Croce In Florence, All Of Which Can Be Dated In The Last Years Of The 15Th Century. By Arranging The Manuscripts In A Rough Chronological Order It Will Be Sholn How The Work Of The Miniaturist Changed Between The Interlaced Initials Of A 12Th-Century Psalter And The Splendid Climax Of The Sforza Book Of Rours. The Sforza Book, Iuluminated For Ludovico Sforza-Visconti, Duke Of Milan, About 1490, Is One Of The Principal Treasures Of The Museum, And Is Seldom Placed On View For Fear Of The Brilliant Colours Fading. Its Flemish Mriiatures Were, However, Displayed As An Accompaniment To The Exhibition Of Flemish Art In 1927, Anid Four Pages Of The Milanese Minia. Tures In The Book Will Now Be Seen. Associated With This Are Two Other Works In The Museum Collection. One Is The Contemporary Sforza Deed, Granting Lands From Ludovico To His Duchess, Beatrice Deste. This Contains His Signature Aud A Flnely Painted Border With Medallion Portraits Of Both Ludovico And Beattrice. The Second Is The Sformiada, A Vellum-Printed Life Of Liidovicos Predecessor. Francesco, Illuminated With Portraits Of Both Dukes. The Humanistic Manuscripts Of The I 5Th Century Will Be Well Illustrated In A Volunme Of Livy. A Copy Of Augustines De Civitate Dei, A Plutarch, And A Duns Scotus, While Two Petrarchs Done For Members Of The Medici Family Will Stand As Examples Of The Best Florentine Craftsmanship. The Most Interesting Work To Be Exhibited, However Apart From The Sf-Rza Documents, Is A Treatise On The Vices, Illuminated In The Late 14Th Century By A Genoese Artist. Lthe Painter, Who Is Traditionally Supposed To Have Been The Monk Cvbo Of Hyeres, Was Evidently Familiar With Oriental Miniatlures. His Illustration Of Gluttony, For Istance, Is A Lively Picture Of A Tartar Monarch Feasting Among His Courtiers To The Straims Of Negro Music, And -He Intersperses W Ithin His Text Representations Of Insect Life, W,Hich Show Almost Certain Contact With The W,Ork Of Arab Naturalists. Leonardo Da Vinci The Productions Of The Miniaturists Are Unsigned And Individual Illuminators Can Rarely Be Identified. The 120 Drawings, On The Other Hand, Which Will Be Seen In The King Edward Vii. Gallery, Have Been Chosen As Illustrations Of The Technique Of Various Known Masters, Quite As Nmuch As For Their Beauty In Themselves. Before Fra Filippo Lippi And The 15Th-Century Florentine School Only A Few Of The Museums Italian Drawings Are Of Interest, But They Include A Pisanello And Several Specimens Of The Schools Of Verona And Tuscany, Dating From Just Before 1400. These Will Be Seen In January, And With Them The Botticelli Flgures Of Abundance And Fate, A Wonderful Verrocchio Head, And Three Drawings By Lorenzo Di Credi. Contemporary Are The North Italians Led Byi Mantegna, Of Whose Drawings The British Museum, More Fortunate Than Any Other Gallery, Poswssses Six Examples. Four Will Be Shown, Flanked By A Selection Of Florentine Drawings By Filippino Lippi And Fra Bartolomiieo And By The Umbrians-Luca Signorelli, Pietro Perugino, And Melozzo Da Forli. Nine Drawings Bv Leonardo Da Vinci Wiil Be Idisplatyed Together. The Sketch Of The Virgin And Child Plaving With A Kitten, And Tli Head Of A Warrior Wvearing A Helnct, Are Probably The Best Known Of These, Bu. There Is Also A Drawving By Leonardo Of One Of His Mor L- Dvilish War-Machines Surrounded Bv Scythes. Which Mow Downi The Enemy. The S!Icceediing Group Contains The Milane.,E Nmaster Anibrogio La Predis And A Selectioni Of The Veaietians, Especiallv Gentile And Gio-Ainni Bellini, Cima, Carpaccio, Anid An Eariv Loreuizo Lotto. Two Complete Screens Are To Be Devoted To Raphael And Michelangelo. Fourteen Raphaels Will Appear, Including Specimens Of The Rare Silverpoint Drawings, While The 11 Michelangelos Chlosen Display Both The Early Atd The More Mannered Later Style Of That Artist. Andrea Del Sarto, Pontorimo, And Sebastiano Del Piombo Will Be Seen To Advantage And Amonig-The Later Drawings Chosen Are Excellent Exanmples Of Such Venetiani Masters As Titian, Poidenone, Bassano, And Paolo Veronese. Coriegglo, Parmegiano, And Three Superb Baroccios Will Be Grouped Together. The Latest Draughtsman Represented Will Be The Bolognese, Carracci. Woodcuts And Engravings It Will Be Observed That The Collection Of Drawings Chosen Hardly Touches The 14Th Century, But After A Strong Group Of Early 15Th-Century Masters It Becomes More Abundant Up To The Middle Of The 16Th Century And Then Practically Breaks Off. The Woodcuts Anid Enigravinigs Begin Anid End Later, Rangirng From The Middle Of The 15Th Century Almost To The Enid Of The 18Th. A Primitive Woodeut In Red. Blue, And Brown Of About 1440-1450 Is The Earliest To Be Seen And One Of The Most Remiarkable. It Represents The Virgin Anid Child, And Is Of I Type Fr. Rarer Thani The Con-. Temlporary Gernia, Woodcuts. It Is Followed Chronologically By The Work Of That Very Eclectic 16Th-Century Craftsman Known From Hlis Signature As The Master I.B. With A Bird. Three Examples Of His Woodcuts Will Be Slhown, One Reproducing A Painting Of The Crucitixion, The Others In Entirely Distin.T Styles Copying Pictures Of Classical Legends. More Or Less Contetuporarv- Craftsmen Represented Are Domenico Campagnola, Of Padua, Lucantonio Degli Uberti, And Jacobus, Of Strasburg, A German Who Settled In Italy. In The Later 6Ith Century The Works Of Titian Appear To Have Been Popular Subjects For The Copyist, And A Selection Has Been Made Of Woodcuts Done After This Painter. A Presumed Self-Portrait Of Titian Engraved By Giovanni Britto Is Perhaps The Most Noteworthy. Titians Niephew. Cesare Vecellie, The Authority On Costume, Was Himself A Woodcutter, And Two Naively Delightful Works By Him -Are To Be Shown. Onie Depicts The Doge And Senate Sittinig In Council, The Other A Venetian Weddinig Scene In Which The Bride Is Being Conducted To Her Festal Gondola. Far More Finished Are The Chiaroscuro Woodcots Done From Three Or Four Blocks In Different Tones Of The Same Colour, Which Ugo Da Carpi Introduced Into Italy. Many Of Raphaels Paintings Were Reproduced In This Technique And Among The Work Of Ugo Da Carpi Selected For Exhibition Are An Interestig Dliogentes After Parmegianio, A Correggio, And A Pordonone Taken From A Fresco Now Perished. Lxamples Will Also Be Given Of Rather Shmilai. Work By Andreani. A Little Later In The 16Th Century, And By Zanetti, Who Revived The Methlod About 1720. The Line Engravings To Be Displayed Are Chiefly Florentine. The Earliest Is A Rather Crude Depiction Of The Killing Of St. Peter Miartyr, Anld There Are A Pleasing Hunting Sc,Ine, A Representation Of Florentine Arts And Crafts From The Planets Series, And An Engravinig Of The Cretan Labyrinth, All To Be Dated Before 1460, Belonging To The School Of Finiguerra. The Most Important Of The Early Series Is A Large Triumph Of Bacchus And Antadne, Acquired By The Museum In Two Separate Pieces From Different Collections. This Is A Work Of Great Beauty, Rather Doubtfully Ascribed To Botticelli, But Certainly Inspired By His School. And The Museums Copy Is Unique. A Line Engraving Of The Assumption Of The Virgin, Dated A Little After 1490, Is Certainly After A Design By Botticelli, And It Is Even More Beautiful Than The Bacchus And Ariadne. The Two Large Pollaiuolos The Battle Of Naked Men And Hercules And The Centaur Chosen To Follow The Botticelli Are Well Known,.And A Selection Has Been Made Of Works By Lucantonio Degli Uberti And Robetta, While Of North Italians We Shall See A -Number Frdm The School Of Mantegna-And A Battle O The Sea-Gods Engsved By That Master Himself. Coming To The 16Th Century, Sped - Mens Have Been Chosen Of The Milanese . T Which Include A Girl With Her Head Crowned With Leaves, Engraved By. One Of Leonardos Pupils, And A Lare Original Comnposition By The Same Anonymous Artist Whose Miniatures Will Be Seen In The Sforza Book Of Hours, Among Other Engravings To Be Shown Are A Reproduction By Mocetto Of A Mgntegna From The Uffzi, Now On Loan At Burlington House, And Works By The Brothers Campagnola, Includng A Very Delicate Design Of A Stag Chained To A Tree. Te Latest Of The Line Engravings To Be Shown Include Seven Specimens Of Marcantonio Raimondis Work, One Reproducing A Raphael Design, To Be Seen At Burlington House, Together With Two Examples Of The Work Of Jacopo Francia, Larcantonios Pil. Only Two Cases Of Etchings Will Be Seeu. The 17Th-Centuryexamnples Chosen Begin With A Group By Stefano Dela Bela, Representing The Florentines Castigione And Biscaino, Who Show The Genoese Style And Giulio Campioni. The Mnost Pleasing Are The Queer Biarie Of Braceui, Whose Figures, Made Up Of Geometrical Shapes And Other Fantastic Constituents, Resemble Designs For A Modern Russian Ballet. Etchings Of The 18Th Century Wiu Be Confined To Two Masters, Tiepolo And Diamantini, And The Eight Frames Eleed Ditplay The Various Styles Of These Masters. No Talian Aquatints Or Mezzotints Wil Be Placed On Exhibition. The Illuminated Manuscripts Will Be On View Only For Three Months, But The Italian Prints And Drawings, Like The Dutch Prints Wbich They Are Now To Displace, Will Probably Be Seen For A Considerable Time After The Pralel Burlington House Exhibition Is Closed. A Very Close Working Arrangement Now Exists Between Burlington House And The British Museum, With Some Overlapping Of Staff. Visitors Will Be Directed From The One Exhibition To The Other By Notes In The Burlington House Catalogue And By Posters Both At Burlington House And In The British Museum. The Victoria And Albert Museum Wiul Hold No Special Exhibition Of Italian Art, As The Best Examples Of Italian Work In The Possession Of The Museum Are Either To Be Seen In Special Collections Already On View Or Are In Books, And, Therefore, Inaccessible For Display. One Very Important Drawing And Two Bronzes From This Museum Have, However, Been Specially Lent To Burlington House, And A Series Of Free Lectures On Subjects Connected With The Burlington Hiouse Exhibition Wil Be Given On Trhursday Evenings At 6.30 In The Victoria And Albert Museum By The Director, Mr. E. R. D. Tmaclagan, And Others. The Arst Of These Will Be Delivered On January 16.

Author: Null
Title: Paris Exhibition Of Industrial Art
Full_text: Paris Exhibition Of Industrial Art. Collective British Exhibits, A Meetingof The General Purposes Committee, Appointed In Connexion With British Participation In The International Exhibitio Of Modern Decorative And Industrial Art To Be Held In Paris Next Year, Took Place At The Department Of Overseas Trade On Thursday. Sir William Clark, Comptroller-General Of The Department, Presided, And Among Those Present Were- Sir Charles Aloin. Sir Kenneth Anderson Sir Rtginald H. Ke. Gadart.Ltendel. Ee.Kb.Ua.R Harlgey Ra6Nville- Sir Lawlrence Wea3Vehr.Etnd Lentbet,T.Coiorei H. W. G. Cole Cenlmlssloner.Generali. Maor A. A. Longden General To The Gbritish Comnmnssloer.3Lg Sertr A Number Of Preiiminary Questions Were Discussed, Such As The Possibility Of Providing A British Restaurant On An Adjoining Site On The Quay Of The Seine The Charge For Space To Be Made To Ex4Ibitors And The Formation Of Collective Exhibits Which Would Permit The Display Of A Number Of Objects In Their Proper Surroundings. A Report By Dr. Anning Bell, Who Has Recently Returned From Paris And Had Opportunities Of Inspecting The Various Sites Reserved For The British Section, Vas Read To The Committee, As Well As Some Notes Which He Had Compiled On The Decorative Art Section Of The Salon Dautomne. It Was Agreed That The Group Comraittees Which Are To Be Set Up In Connexion With The Various Industries Falling Within The Scope Of The Exhibition Should Be Called Together As Soon As Possible, So That The Work Of Organization May Proceed Without Delay. The Broadcastihg Programmes For To-Day And To-Morrow Will Be Found On Page 21.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Mr. Williami Roberts. So Far As His Paintings Are Concerned Mr. William Roberts Does Nbt Get The Distance- He Really Needs At The Chenil Galleries Chelsea, But It Is Something To Have Them Brought Together. It Is Little Shoxtzot An Artistic Tragedy That This Young Man Should Be Compelled To Paint Pictures For The Chances Of Exhibition Instead Of In The Security Offered By The Wall Of A Public Building. Properly To Appreciate His Powers The Visitor Should Look First At Such Things As The Portrait Of Miss Tupper-Carey And The Foar Drawizngs Of Soldiers In The Room Above, Not Because They Are The Best Things In The Exhibition, But Because. They .Make. Evident - The.. Fact That, The .Treatnuent. Of Form In Some Of Tho Other Works Is Deliberate, For The Double. Purpose Of Racy Comment And Articulate Design. Dock. Gates, To Nisnie Onlyone Example, Shows That Mr. Roberts Would- Be. The Ideal Decorator Of A Municipal Or Commercial Building, Alrd -It Ds Indeed Remarkable That This Picture-Has Not Been Secured By One Of Onr Shippingcompanies. ........... . -M.R. Roberts Has. Flrstofall .An.Intimate. Knowledge Of The More Characteristic Aspects Of Contemporary Urban Life And He O Has Worked Out. A, Convention Which Enables Him-To.-Present.Them In Aiforciblc Manner- With An Insistence On The Grotesque That Is Calculated To Makethem Stick In The Mind. Love Song In A Bar, Brass .Balls,- And The Dance .Club Are Examples. Only An Artist Who Was Completely-Master Of His Forms I-Could Simplify Them So Boldly, -And -Mr. Robertsb Knows Exactly When, And -When Not, -To Employ Distortion To Give Coherence To His Designs. In His Portraits, And In Such A Picture As .Jewish Elody, He Is Content With,. Simplificationm . . .. Pictutres By Mr. Neville- Lytton.. Originality And Imagination, Rather Than Technical Nastery. Are The Qualities To Be Found In The. Pictures By,Mr.Ne-Ville Lytton, .Atthe Alpine.Cglub Gallery, Mill- Street, C Conduit-Street. . Not That Mr. Lytton Is Lacking In Technical Sympathy, But That His Mental Powers And General Artistic Sensibility Are Ahead Of His Manual Performance. Among The Pictures There Are Some Very Charming Alpine Landscapes, Done In A Combination Of Watercolour And Pastel, So As To Secure The Per-. Manent Ind Fleetjng Aspects Of The Scene. These, Are Remariable For-A -Peculiar Classical Serehit, -Orpaiable, For Convenience, To Th E Spirit Of .J R. Cozens. .Snniset, Lac Dannecy.And The Lake Mimizan Are Good Examples And There Is, The Same Feeling In The Grey Dieppe Harbbour Andin-The Oil Painting Leda And-The Swan -The Scene Here Being A Lalke In The Landes. Diana Salutes The - Das9I Is Another Excellent .Landscape In.Oils, Essentially Poetical, The. Relation Between The Figare And The Cloud Being Particularly Happy From Adesigners Point Of Viewv. I Of The Figuire Paintings In Oils. Le Cabriolet Adds The Greatest Charm- Of Handliiig To The Originality Of Conceptiou Whieh. Is Present In All The Pictures, While Portrait Of Madame Negroponte Compels Attention By Its Gravity. Two Cartoons For Friezes Of Peace And War In True Fresco, At -Balcombe Town Hall, Excite Eagerness To See The Finished Works. . .

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Armong The Numerous Exhibitions Which Open To The Public To-Day, The Most Important And Interesting Is That At Messrs. Agnews Gallery In Old Bond-Street. The 31St Annual Display Of Old And Modern English Drawings Is In One Way Very Much Like Those Which Have Preceded It That Is To Say, It Consists Of A Number Of Very Carefuuy Selected Works By The Best Masters, Deceased Or Still Living, Of The Englisix School Of Water-Colour Painting. Turner, De Wint, David Cox, Wiliam Hunt-These Are Among The Great Men Of The Bygone Generation Who Are Here Represented In Force While Of Living Artists We Have Important Drawings Of Sir E. Burne-Jones, Hir. Alma Tadema, Mr. Carl Haag, Mr. Briton Riviere, Mr. Birket Foster, And Amiss Mary Gow-Who Sends Four Drawings Of Charming Delicacy And Grace. It Would Be Hard To Say Anything New Of The Art Of The Foar First-Named, Nor Need We Attempt It. The Principal Drawings Mado By Turner Have Been So Often Classified And Described That A Collector And A Turner-Lover Knows Them By Name, And It Is Enough That He Should Be Informed That In A Certain Gallery Ho Can See The Zurich, The Richmond, From The England And Wales Series, And So Forth. These Two Drawings Form The Principal Object On One Of Tho Screans At Messrs. Agnews, And We Are Again Abe To Wonder At The Strange 4Nimagination Which Led Turner To Place His English Richmond On A Mountain-Top As Though It Were Fresole Or Some Other Italian Hill-Built City, And To Make Of Zurich A Blaze Of Colour And Sunlight Such As No More Prosaic Eye Than His Could Identify With That Busy And Homely Swiss Town. All The Same, The Quality Of Theso Two Drawings Is Marvellous, While Of Equal Interest, If Of Less High Finish, Are Such Works As The Oberlahnstein And The Neuwied. Both Of Which Form Part Of The Wonderful Collection Which The Artist Brought Back From His Brief Tour On The Rhine, To Enrich The Cabinet Of His Friend, Ir. Fawkes, Of Farnley. Very Beautiful Is Such An Early Work As The Brecon Castle And Bridge, While In A Vaulted Chadel Wo See One Of The Architectural Studies In Which The Young Turner Found Such Useful Training For His Eye And Hand. De Wint Is More Strongly Represented Than David Cox At The Back Of Tha Same Screen We Have Two Beautiful Aud Unusual Drawings By Him- Grouse-Shooting And Partridge-Shooting -Which He Is Said To Have Painted For The Same Amateur, Mr. Fawkes, And Which Are Marvels Of Broad And Noble Treatment. This Screen Is So Rich That It Might Be Taken To Represent In Miniature Not Oal7Y Ihe Gallely, But Old English Water-Colour Art As A Whole For, Besides The Works That We Have Named, We Have Some Masterly Though Very Slight Sketches By Constable, Four Or Five First-Rate Examples Of William Hunt-Noteespecially The .Egro Boy 219 And Flowers In A Jug 227-Instances Of The Grave Landscapeo Art Of John Varley, Of David Coxs Favourite Hayfield, Of Coploy Fieldings Highly Artificial Renderings Of The Sea And Such A Fine Thing As The -Palace Of The Moorish Kings, Cordova,I By David Roberts, One Of The Best Of Draughtsmen, Whose More Ambitious Oil Pictures Were Often Less Painter-Like Than His Rare Water-Colours Such As This. On The Walls Are Larger Works Of The Same And Other Artists Lie Wints K Onilworth Castle The Sunset Of That Eminent Classicist, George Barret The L Lancaster Of Copley Fielding In His Barret Manner So Noble A Piece Of Colour As The Hospital Of The Pieth, Venice, By James Holland, And, Of More Recent Men, The Remarkable Tournay Cathedral Of Louis Fliighe The Cairo Bazaar Of J. F. Lewis, And Some Beautiful Drawings By Thomas Collier, With Whom Died The Best Of The Successors Of David Cox. The Works Of Living Painters That Will Deservedly Attract Most Attention Are The Icupid And Psyche Of Sir Edward Burnejones-Not His Best-Known Treatment Of The Subject,But The Version Painted In 1866-Andtheseries Of Drawings By Miss Mary Gow To Which We Have Already Referred. Scarcely Any Living Painter Uan Rival This Lady In Her Treatment Of White Lhowing Draperies In Water-Colour, But, What Is More Important, Sho Has A Gift Of- Gracious Composition And Of Realizing Tho Lighter Side Of The Tender Maternal Feeling That Is Rare Indeed. A Small Wvindsor Castle, By Sir Edward Poynter, A Tiny Early Millais 3R. Dicksees Small Watercolour Version Of His Paolo And Francesca, And Various Drawings By Mr. Birket Foster, Including One Of His Largest And Most Elaborate Surrey Scenes, May Be Mentioned As Adding To The Varied Interest Of This Exhibition. At The Fine Art Societys Rooms, Where Recently We Saw The. Leighton Sketches, Mr. Wallace Rimington Now Shows 138 Drawings Illustrating Wanderings In Italy. When, A Few Years Ago, This Artist Exhibited A Similar Series Of Spatush Drawings, They Were Welcomed Not Only As Art But As A Charming Guide Through An Almost Unknown Land Ns The Making Real Of A Number Of Places Which Till Then Had Been To Almoit Every Visitor Mere Names In The Book Of History Or Romance. It Is Not The Same With Italy. For One Person Who Has Visited Valladolid Or Oviedo, A Thousand Have Been To Venice And Verona Nay, Even Amalfi And Teano, Modena And Ferrara, Are No New Discoreries. Mir. Rimingtons Italian Plan Has Necessarily Differed From Hisspanish. Heo Has Sought For The Picturesque Wherever It Was To Be Found, And Has Not Intentionally Left The Beaten Track In Pursuit Of The Relatively Unknowvn. We Confess That We Should Have Felt N. Somewhat Greater Interest In His Enhibition If It Had Satisfied Our Curiosity More If, Like H. Paul Bourget, The Artist Had Given Us A Volume Of Sensations Djtalie Gathered Trom The Vast Unvisited Regions Of It-From The Abruzzi, From Ban, From Taranto. Perhaps, However, Thiis Pleasure Is Only Deferred. The Room Contains The Fruit Of Visits Spread Over Three Years Let Us Hope That In Other Years This Painter, Who Combines Tho Gifts Of The Artist And The Traveller In A Remarkable Way, Will Extend His Researches Southward. We Must Not, However, Be Understood To Say That Mr. Rimirgton Paints Hackneyed Subjects On The Contrary, Be Avoids Them, Though He Has Given Us A Good Many Views Of Well-Known Places. San Gimignano, Volterra, Subiaco, The Lake Of Bolsona, The Lake Of Orta-These Are A Few Of The Places Which He Illustrates, And Of Them The Englieh Wirld Knows But Little. In A Word, There Is Great Variety In These Drawings, And Mr. Rimington Not Only Feels The Spell Of The Places-He Comnmunicates It. Lhe Is An Excellent Draftsman, With A Good Sense ,Of Colour And A Broad, Workmanlike Touch. A Few Doors Off, At Messrs. Dowdeswells, Are Some Drawings By M1R. Arumonier, Whose Reputation As A Landscape-Painter, Always Considerable, Has Been Rising Of Late Years. These Sketches Are Of No Great Importance, But They Are Artistic And Theyr Have, At Least, The Econdary Merit Of Actuality. One Group Of Them Immortalizes, Of All Things In The World, The Old Chain Pier At Brighton, Whose Material Existence Came To A Suddlen End In One Of This Winters Storms. In Mlr. Aumoniers Drawings We See The Old Pier In Life A Rather Languid Life And In Death, With The Waves Beating Over Its Wreck, Its Chains Snapped, Its Pillars Falling Or Fallen. It Was A Kindly Idea Of The Artist Thus To Perpetuate The Last Act Itn The Life Of So Historical Asetructure His Clever Drawings Ought To Be Photographed Sud Published In A Memorial Volume. M R C. E. Holloway, A Painter Who Has Distinctly Gone With The Movement And Bas Become More Impressionist As He Has Grown Older, Shows At The Goupil Gallery A Collection Of Water-Colours And A Few Oil-Sketches, Illustratinf Englirh Scenes, Chiefly Of The Shore, And Views Of Renice. They Are Rapid, Summary Notes, Not All Of Them Successful, But All Showing A Certain Powor Of Free Handling. A Small Fulllength Portrait Of The Artist, By Mr. Whistler, Will Be Looked At With Curiosity. Two More General Exhibitions Dewnnd A Word, Bat Only A Word, Of Notice. The Dudley Gallery Art Society Has Its Annual Water-Colour Exhibition, And At The Hanover Gallery Is A Collection Of Milit-Vy Pictures, Mostly By Lirench Followers Of Bfe.Fsonier And De Neuville. A Small Work By Detaife, Illustrating The Campaign Cf 1814, And A Age Sketch Of The Battlo Of Chainign We Presume, A Part, O.The -Lage Panoramapainted By That Artist Are Perlaps T!He Prinpipal Pictures. For The Rest, The Work Of Econdary Masters Predominates, Sucli Asmm Dupray,.-Beauquesne, And Perboyre. Atthe Dudley, Among A Multitude Of Quiet, Ordinary Iandseares, The Visitor Will Single .Ont The Drawings -Of Mesrs. Claude Hayes, D.Vida -Reen, Aad 1Osxtag4Essmyth, And Of Miss E. Jex-Blake, Miss -Rose Barton Accomplished As Alw5Ys Iss Roso- Mead, And Miss Margaret Bernain, Whose C,Ever Drawings Of Ctow,Ds In Picturesque Fcreign Market-Places Are Evidently Inspired Bv Mr. Arthur Melville Or Some Other Painter Of The Spotty School.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Ar.T Exhibitions. The Abbey Gallery. At The Abbeyi Gmijery, 2, Viceoria-Street, An Exhibition Of Colour-Etchings, Drypoints, Painting8, And Water-Colours By Mr. Edgar L. Pattison Has Been Arranged To Inaugurate A Considerable Improvement Of The Premises. The Whole Of The First Floor Has Now Been Taken Over By Messrs. Deighton And Divided Into Three Galleries, Very Weu Suited To The Exhibition Of Small Works Ot Art, And Two Private Offices. A Word Is Due To The Simplicity And Good Taste With Which The Decoration Of The New Rooms Has Been.Carried Out. 3Fr. Pattisons Work Is Particularly Well Seen In Its Present Quarters, Because It Is Essentially Of A Kind To Suit The Small Domestic Interior Carefully Desizned And Intimate In Feeling. The Colour-Etehings Of Eastern And Southern Subjects Made In One Printing Bya Method Of The Artists Own, Suffer Somewhat From The Effect That The Colour-Pattern Is Not So Subtle As The Linear Desgn-An Effect Difficult To Avoid In Etching-Though A Southern Port, A Nocturne, In Venice, And Tangier Are Good Colour Designs In Themselves But The Objection Does. Not Apply To The English Subjects, Such As The Eisherman, N Near Ry,E, Rye, Harbour, And Landsca E, Of A Bridge, Castle, And Cliff. Here Line, Which Mr. Pattison Handles With Grace And -Ertainty, Plays The Principal Part, The Colour Being Reduced To Sober Tinting, And The Effect Is Charming Indeed. Proofs Of Several Of The Etchings, As Of The Aquatint Geese, Have Been Acquired For The British Museum. But The Most Distinguished Things In The Exhibition Are The Small Water-Colours, Such As Trces, After Rain, And The Castle. Perhaps The Best Way-Of Describing Their Appeal Is To. Say That They Are At The Same Time Romantic In Feelig, And Classical Mn Composition. The Most Attractive Of The Oil Paintings Is The Incoming Tide, Zaanber, A Refined Study In Grey And Buff. All Mr. Pattisons Work Is Carefully Considered, And An Exhibition Of Little Pictures So Perfectly Adapted To Modest Requiremexts Promises Well For The Future Success Of The New Galleries. In Another Room There Are A Few Spanish Water-Colours By Mfr. Anthony Gross, A Young Artist Of Considerable Originality And Promise. Washerwomen, Ronda, Is A Good Example Of His Work.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Curtis Moffat Gallery At The Curtis Moffat Gallery, 4, Fitzroysquare, Is An Exhibition Of Modern English Paintings By Various Hands, Which Is Well Worth A Visit, If Only For The Opportunity Of Seeing Pictures Well Hung In An Agreeable Setting Where Their Merit As Ornaments Can Be Adequately Judged. For The Most Part It Consists Of Small But Good Examples Of The Work Of Excellent Artists. In A Small Landscape, Hampstead, Mr. Duncan Grant Has Observed With Unusual Fidelity A Transitory Phase Of Light. Here He Has Not, As So Often, Transposed The Colours Of Nature Into An Entirely Different Key, And The Result Shows That Mr. Grant Would Have Made A Very Sensitive Impressionist. Mr. Richard Sickerts Dieppe -It Is Obviously Not A Very Recent Workis A Most Adroit Conjunction Of Difficult Colours, And Mr-. Keith Baynes, In His Rue De La Republique, Shows Much The Same Kind Of Skill In Conciliating Light And Acid Tints, Though The Actual Quality Of His Paint Still Verges On Brutality. Mr. Matthew Smiths Anemones And Daisies Displays All The Advantages Of A Natural Sense Of Colour, Mr. Adrian Daintreys Greenhouse, Though Painted Witli A Rough Handling, Is Still A Compact Design, And Mr. H. E. Du Plessiss To Be Let Or Sold Is An Engaging Piece Of Realism. By Accepting With No Demur The Oddity Of The Forms Seen From A Casually Chosen View-Point He Has Been Able To Produce A Fantastic Effect With Admirable Ease And Spontaneity. Two Other Works By Mir. Duncan Grant, Mr. Augustus Johns Girl At Mlanorna, And Miiss Eve Kirks Greenwich Beach Also Attract Ones Attention In Their Different Ways.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: . I Airt Fix111Irmons. . - -7 -.- - - . - Indian Paintings. Ii The Prinft And Eijawinis Gallery Of The British Museum There Has Been Arranged An Extensive Exhibition Illustrating The History Of Painting In India, With A Few Supplementary Examples Of Painting Produced Inneighbodring Countries, Such Asturkestan, Tibet,Tand Siam, Under Iiidiauinfluence. Since The1Last Exhibi-I Tion Of A Similarkindwas Held, In 1922, The Collections Have Been Enriched, Notably By Examples Of The Rajput. Schools,And These Give A Special Interest And Charm To The Present Exhibition. -Of Classical Or Monumental Painting In India Few Traces Remain, The Most Important Being The Buddhist Frescoes In The Cave-Temples Of Ajanta And Bagh, Which Are Supposed To Date From The First Tothe Seventh Cebtury,.-Ad. Copies From Both Ajanti And Bagh, Made By An Indian Artist, Are To Be Seen In The.Present Exhibition-Nos. 14, 15, 16, And 145. In Look-, Ing At Thern One Is Struck By The Grandeur! Of The Conceptions, The Rhythmical Move.4 Ment Of The Designs, And The Depth Of The Colouring, The Art Rising To Its Greatgsti E.Qtional Height In -The, Group Of T-He1 Glorified Buddha Appearing To His Wife! And Child. From The Eighth Century To Its Revival In The 16Th Century Under The Moguls Only S6Attered Relics Of Indian Painting Survive. The Earliest Works Of The Mogul School Were Made Under Persian Influence, Examples Being Shown In Floor-Case V. And In Princess Of The .-House Of Tirnur No. 1, Painted In The Persian Stylerby Al Persian Artist, But With Figures Added In The Indian Style By An Indian Artist. In Its Full Development The Mogul School Became Pre-Eminently A School Of Por- Traiture And Of The Representation Of Cere-! Monies And Hunting Scenes And Subjects. There Are Also In It Occasional Adaptations From Westerm Art-As In The Picture Of A Lady With Her Lover No. 26. But The Mogul School Does Not Exhaust The Interest Of Indian Painting, For Already In The 17Th Century The Purely Native Art Was Reviving An Art More Gentle And Subjective, More Musical In Its Expression. Hindu Legends Provide The Subjects, And There Is Also A Special Class Of Works With Musical Motives, Associated With Different Houriof The Day And Differentemotional Moodsto Which The Artists Sought.To Give A Pictorial Counterpart. It Is Among The Exampiles Of Rajput Painting That Somqe Of The Loveliest Things In The Exhibition Are To Be Found, Such As The Unfinished Nada And Darnavanti Hailing The Moonrise No. 97. Several Other Unfinished Works Show Us The Technical Methods Of The Artists. For Many Pieople The Raiput Pait- Ings, With Their Peculiar Innocence Of Feeling And Grace Of Expiession, Will Be The Most Attractive Side Of The Exhibition. The Tradition Continued Through The 19Th Cen- Tury, And There Is Even One Picture No. 130 By A Kangra Artist Who-Is Still Alive.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Bonnard And Vuillard I Not Many Contemporary Works Of Art Lend Themselves To Such Easy Enjoyment As Do The 24 Paintings By Pierre Bonnard And Jean Edouard Vuillard Now On View At The Rosenberg And Helft Galleries, 31, Bruton Street. Both Veterans, Within A Year Or Two Of The Same Age, With About The Same Similarities And Differences In Style As There Are In Their Names, These Two Eminently Satisfying French Painters Might Almost Have Been Invented By Balzac -If He Had Lived A Little Longer. In Artistic Slang They Are Grouped Together As Intimists, And The Name Serves Well Enough To Describe Not Only Their Preoccupation With The Domestic Interior But Also Their Habit Of Dwelling Upon Their Material So As To Extract From It The Last Possibilities In Subtle Colour Relationships. Of The Two Bonnard Has Become The Larger In Style And The More Positive In Colour, Vuillard Renmaining, As They Both Began, An Enthusiast For Subdued Harmonies. It Is Not Easy To Select From This Friendly Demonstration Of The Pleasures Of Painting, But Nature Morte And Le Dejeuner, By Bonnard, And Madame Vuillard Et La Famille Roussel And La Lecture, By Vuillard, Are Among The Happiest Things In The Collection. Mr. Stuart-Hill Between The London Bridges And Portraits In The Exhibition Of 23 Paintings By Mr. A. Stuart-Hill At The Redfern Galleries, 20, Cork Street, There Is, No Hesitation, And The London Bridges Have It Every Time. Substituting Truth For Accuracy In Topographical Matters, Though Without Any Serious Distortion Of The Facts Or Their Relationships, Mr. Stuart-Hill Has, Indeed, Produced A Remarkably Interesting Series Of Portraits Of The London Bridges And Their Immediate Surroundings. They Are Portraits Because They Suggest What May Be Called The Temperaments Of The Localities. In General They Are Birdseye Views, In An Embracing Kind Of Composition, Bringing Everything Into Unity Of Effect, Which Is Sometimes Lyrical, Sometimes Elegiac, And Sometimes Dramatic. Charing Cross Bridge From Shell Mex House And Blackfriars Bridge From South Side May Be Specially Quoted. Of The Portraits Of People The Head Of The Duchess Of Choiseul Makes By Far The Best Impression.

Author: FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT
Title: Art Collecting In West Riding
Full_text: Art Collecting In West Riding Exhibition At Temple Newsam From Our Correspondent Leeds, June 13 An Exhibition Of Works Of Art From The Private Collections Of Subscribers To The Leeds Art Collections Fund Was Opened This Evening By Professor Anthony Blunt At Temple Newsam. This Jacobean Mansion, Which Has Become The Principal Art Centre In Leeds, Forms A Perfect Setting For A Remarkable Exhibition Showing The Variety And Scope Of Art Collecting In The West Riding. Without Drawing Upon The Famous Collections At Harewood House And Farnley Hall, The Friends Of Leeds Art Gallery Have, From Their Homes, Brought Together A Collection Of Distinction. In One Room Set Apart For English Water-Colours There Are Fine Examples Of Gainsborough, Cotman, Girtin, Peter De Wint, Morland, Turner, And Paul Sandby, While Two Water-Colours By Anthony Devis Are From A Set Of 14 Which Were Painted For James Lowther, Afterwards Lord Lonsdale, In 1780. Paintings Include Some Of The Works Of Giorgio De Chirico The Gladiators , Mark Gertler, Jacob Kramer The Sphinx , Picasso, Sickert, And Jack Yeats. Modern Sculpture Is Represented In The Work Of Jacob Epstein, Henry Moore, And Barbara Hepworth. Some Rare Pieces Of Seventeenth- And Eighteenth-Century Furniture Are Exhibited, Including One Of The Earliest Known Examples Of A Walnut Writing Table. The Section Devoted To Ceramics Makes Special Appeal In The Collections Of Chinese Famnille Rase Porcelain And Of Chelsea Red Anchor Porcelain. It An Article By Our Art Critic On The Permanent Collection At Temple Newsam Appears On Page 7.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Mainly For The Benefit Of Those Large Numbers Of People Who Come To London For The Summer Season Only, Messrs. Agnew Have Decided To Exhibit Once More Their Famous Fragonards From Grasse, Which Were Shown For A Short Time In The Winter Of 1898. We Then Described Them At Length, And Told The Story Of This Roman Damour De La Jeunesse And At Present We Need Do No More Than Say That This Extraordinary Series, Perhaps The Masterpiece Of French Decorative Art Of The 18Th Century, May Now Be Seen Once More For A Short Time Before The Pictures Take Their Departure To Their Permanent Home, And That Mr. Claude Phillipss Pamphlet Will Tell The Visitor All That Can Be Learnt About Them. A Special Interest Will Attach To Them Just Now, Because In Little More Than A Week We Shall Be Able To Compare Them With The Treasures Of French Art At Hertford-House, Which Are About To Be Thrown Open To A Nation That Has Waited Long. There We Shall See Two Or Three Of The Most Famous Small Fragonards In The World, While Here In Bond-Street Is The Artists Chief Series Of Decorative Paintings. For Ourselves, We Have Our Doubts Whether The Pale Rose-Colour Against Which They Are Now Set Is Quite The Right Tone To Bring Out The Qualities Of The Pictures. They Would, Look Better Against White Wood Panelling, Or Oak Of The Natural Colour, Picked Out With Gilding. Some Fine French Pictures Are On View At Messrs. Artel Tooths Gallery In Bond-Street, Borrowed From Ind Owners By A Society Calling Itself The French Friends Of England. The Only Name Which Appears In Connexion With This Society Is. That Of An Artist, M. De Laubinjure, But We Believe That He Has Really Induced A Number Of French People Living In England To Declare Themselves, At The Present Crisis, In Favour Of The Country Which Gives Them A Home. It Is Not Surprising That Various Royal And Other Distinguished Persons Should Have Expressed Themselves Well Disposed Towards A Society Which Has So Good An Object. Quite Independently, However, Of The Direct Object Of The Exhibition, The Pictures Are Very Well Worth Seeing. They Are Mostly Of The Barbizon School, And Are Chiefly Lent From Two Or Three Of The Choicest Collections In England And It Is Certain That They Make A Finer Show Than Is Made By The Corot Room In The Paris Exhibition. There Is No Corot There Equal To Le Lac, Or The Smaller Picture Which Is Known As The Bent Tree Nor Is There A Diaz So Poetical As The Splendid Sketch Called Lorage. Half A Dozen Other Pictures By The Former Master Are Only One Degree Less Excellent Moreover, There Is An Excellent Troyan, With Several Very Choice Examples Of Daubigny, The Simplest, Least Mannered, And, To Many People, The Most Attractive Of All This Group Of Painters, Especially From His Preference For Quiet River Views Seen From The Banks Of The Oise. One Good Picture By M. De Laubiniere Is In The Same Room, And Upstairs Are A Few More, With Several By Maurice Lb Vis, A Modem Follower Of The Barbizon Men. Further Up Bond-Street, The Rooms Of The Fine Art Society Are Peculiarly Attractive Just Now. The Chief Strength Of The Display Lies In The Magnificent Ruston Collection Of Turners Watercolour Drawings, Lent By Mr. And Mrs. Arthur Severn, To Whom They Were Bequeatheda Collection Well Known To All Devotees Of Turner, And Well Remembered By The Older Generation From Its Having Been Seen Here In 1878. Against These It Is A Little Difficult For Any Landscape Painter In Water-Colours To Hold His Own, But None The Less One Can Very Well Enjoy Such A Collection As That Which Mr. El. L. Norris Has Brought Together In The Next Room, Representing His Work In Wiltshire, Berkshire, And The Midland Counties. Mr. Norriss Methods Are Not Those Of Turnerbe Uses, For Example, A Great Deal Of Body-Colour But He Could Quote Many Sound Authorities Among Modern Men. Such Drawings As Those Called Ragwort 27A Big Yellow Field Iris 56, The Orchard Gate 60, And The Grave Little River Scene Called Coombe Bissett 28 Are Among The Most Attractive Works In An Exhibition Which Is Generally Noteworthy For The Faithful Study Of Nature Which It Reveals. In The Next Room Are Some Drawings Of An Entirely Different And Much More Exceptional Kindthe Curious Water-Colours And Etchings By Maurice And. Edward Detmold, Who, We Believe, Are Twin Brothers, Boys Of 17. Once Before We Hare Noticed One Or Two Of Their Very Powerful Etchings Of Birds Let Us Add That In Their Drawings Also, Whether Of Birds On The Wing, Of Fish, Or Of Beasts Of Prey, These Young Artists Show A Very Nnngnal Knowledge Of Form, Together With A Gift For Design Which Promises Great Things, If Only They Take No Harm From Being Brought Before Th World Too Early. The Flying Lapwing, The Drawing Called A Duel In The Air, And Various Studies Of Tigers And Jaguars Are Of Surprising Excellence. Two Other Exhibitions In Bond-Street Are Worth A Visit. A New Firm, Messrs. Forbes And Paterson, Have Opened A Pleasant Little Gallery At No. 5, Old Bond-Street, And Have Hung It With A Rather Choice Loan Collection Of Pictures Of Early English Portraits. There Is A Charming Gainsborough Of Two Peasant Boys, Lent By The Duke Of Newcastle, A Good Reynolds, A Romney Of Considerable Charm, Some Excellent Raeburns,, A Picture Of Two Small Boys Painted By Sir Thomas Lawrence In Emulation Of Rubens, And A Very Charming Work Of Opies, Paintedbeforehe Had Become Mannered, And Black In The Shadows. Had The Cornish Genius Continued To Do As Good Things As This Mrs. Arkwright, He Would Have Ranked Very Near His Master, Sir Joshua.Messrs. Dowdeewell Have Brought Together Some Capital Italian And Dutch Pictures, Together With A Fine Portrait From The Peel Sale By Dobson, The English Painter Whose Talent Was Transformed By Vandyck Into An Almost Wholly Flemish Character. The Signed Triptych By The Interesting North Italian Painter Macrino Dalba Is The Most Important Of The Italians Here But There Are A Few Small Pictures Of The Umbrian And Venetian Schools Which Are Worth Study. Among The Dutch A Small Presentation In The Temple, By Eekhout, Shows How Near To Rembrandt The Best Of His Pupils Sometimes Earns.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art. Exieeibitions. Beaux Arts Gallery. A Goou Many Or Tne Modem Flower Paintings By Eminentartists At The Beaux Arts Gallery Are Not More Than Records More Or Jess. Well Composed And Executed Of Intrinsically Beautiful Things, But Every Now And Then You Come Upon Something In Which Flowers, Medium, And Artist Have Eonspired .To Form A New Kind Of Beauty. The Most Striking Instance Is Flowers In A Glass Pickle Jar, By Mrs. Winifred Nicholson, Which Is Like A Startled Cry Of Delight In Humdrum Conversation. At Present The Powers Of Thts. Interesting Artist Do Not Go Farther Than The Deft Placing Of Patches -If Pure Colouir Of Creamy Quality Along The Lines Of Her Feeling, So To Speak, But When She Has Learnt To Subdue Solid Objects To Her Mood She Should Paint Very Good Pictures Indeed. She Is Rather Like A Natural Melodist Who Has Yet To Learn The Rules Of Hatniony. A Special Feature Of The Exhibition Is A Group Of Works In Oil And Pastel By Miss Beatrice How. These Have Charm Of Arrangement, Colour, And Surface Quality, But They Rely On The Whispered Statement Of Natural Beauty Rather Than On Its Transformation. Bat Stocks And Marigolds Is A Choice Effect Of Colour. Fron The Other Pictures-There Are 61 In All Chrysanthemums In White Vase, By Mr. R. Mann Livens, Decoration, By Mr. Baker Clack, Narcissi Daffodils, And Wallflowers In A Glass Jampot, By M4R. James Iiill, And Summer Flowers, By Miss Liatherine Clausen, Nmay Be Picked Out As Best Responding To The Cry Raised By Mrs. Nicholson. At The Same Gallery There Are Paintings And Water-Colours By Mr. J. F. M. Floyd. Hle Presents The Engaging Spectacle Of A Vian Who Has Discoverea That Nature Is Not Art. Hle Has Yet To Leain To Organize His Discovery,.But He Is Followiig The Clue, And In One Picture At Least, A Charm, In Which Blue Interspaces Of Sky Have, As It Were, Taken The Tip From The Gestures Cf .A Flame-Like Yellowv Tree, An Act Of Magic Is Performed. At Ptesent Mr. Floyd, Escited By His Discovery, Tries To Say Too Muchincluding Some Romantic Balderdash-In The Same Picture, But A Charm, Spring Landscape, Backs Axid Shanties, And Rock Garden Establish His Right To Be Called An Artist. Sunny Gardens. The Alternatives For The Artist In Such Pictures As The Water-Colours Of Sunny Gardens, By 31Iss Edith H. Adie, At The Halcyon Club, 13 Cork-Street, Are To Sacrifice The Individual Iliovers To The Landscape Sutroundings Or To Tame The Landscape Into Behaving Like The Flowers-That Is To Say, When The Aim Does Not! Go Farther Than Representation. Miss Adie Has! Closenl The Latter Alternstive And !Ulflued It I With Charm Of Colour And Neatness Of Execution. I Preference Among Such Pictures Will Depend A Great Deal On The Stibject Itself-Which Garden, Or Part Of A Garden, Is Prettiest-But The Blue Border, Wistaria Pergola, Rhododendrons, Orange Trees, Bogliaco, And The Thames At Kewv May Be Quoted As Good Examples. The Exhibition Is Open Until I Mlarch 13, Admission Being By Visiting Card. Walkers Galleries. The Oil And Water-Colour Paintings Of Assisi, Yplies, And Other Subjects By Miss B. E. Lithiby At Walkers Galleries, 118. New Bond-Street, Are Distinguished By A Remarkable Firnmness Of Statement In Subjectsv-Hichlaregenerallytreated In The Melting Mood. Not That Miss Lithibys Vork Is Deficient In Feeling, But That The Feeling Is Expressed On A Steady Note, Instead Of Witli The Treinolo That Many Artists Think Necessary When They. Are In A Plicc Wvitlh Associations, Such As Venice Or Assisi. St. Claras Cboir In San Damiano, Assisi, To Name One Of The Best Of The Water-Cblours, Gains Rather Than Loses In Emotional Effect By Being Ostensibly A Still-Life I Study In The Modern Manner Wvith The Emphasis Put Upon, The Plastics Of A Receding. Choirstall, A Book-Rest, And A Doorway. It Is Not Only A Flne Drawving, But A Flne Piece Of Con- Tained Sentiment, And Mliss Lithiby Has Got So I Much. Out Of The Bare Essentials In This Instance Thlt One Almost Resents The Shadow Of The Tuonk In Interior Of San Danmano, Assisi, Tlohigh It-Happens Quite Naturally, As A Concession To The Weaker Folk Who Must Have Sentiment Underlinled. When Occasion Offers. As In The Wet-Lashed Impression Of A Cross In A Rain Squall, On The Somtne, 1910, Miss Lithiby Is Not At All Afraid To Yield To Itwhich Is Proof Rather Than Otherwise Of Her Freedom From Sentimentalitv. Wood-Engraving8. The Wood-Engravings By Amr. Eric Daglish Anld Mfiss Flare Leighton At Tlle Redferli Gallery, 27. Old Bond-Street, Are Good Extanples Of The Unaffected Practice Of An Art Which, Since Its Revival, Is Not Yet Quite Free Iu Most Hands From Tle Artiness Which Hanigs Round Revivals. Both Artists Are Primarily Illustrators. And Possibly That Saves Theni From The Usual Defects By Keepilg Their Nminds Off Aesthetics. As Designers They Are Both Workmna Like Rather Than Inspired, Mr. Daglish Designing Chiefly In Wlhite On Black And Misc Leigliton In Black On Wvhite. It His Designs Of Birds, Beasts, And Fislhes, Not To Speak Of Insects, Mr. Daglisb Began And Continues With The Interests Of A Naturalist, And His Proglrss As An Artist Consists In The Better Reconciliatiou Of Those Interests With The Claims Of Page Decoration By Skilful Patterning. Castles And Cathedralm. English Cathedrals, By Mr Cecil Aldin, And Castles Of England. By Mr. Herbert J. Finn, Make Ul A Happily Inspired Exhibition At The Abbey Gallery. 2, Victoria-Street, Though It Is Of Topographical Rather Than Artistic Interest. Mr. Aldin. Wtho Works In Coloured Crayon, Has The Slicker Band In Picture Making. Being Adept In Suggesting An Olde Worlde Atmosphere. He Uses Figures Very Happily, And Seldom Fails To Give A Good General Idea Of The Cathedral In Relation To Its Surroundings. Salisbury Cathedral And Canterbury Cathedral Are Good Examples, And The Atmosphete Of Cathedral Towns Is Legitimately Showni In The Nocturnes Of Mlercery Lane, Canterbury And An Old English Inn. Mr. Aldins Share In The Exhibition Is Extended To Include Characteristic Drawvings Of Sporting Subjects. Mr. Finn, Who Is A Watercolourist, Has Tackled His Castles At Closer Quarters, Botli In Fact And In Spiirit, Being Obviously Interested In The Features Of Construction.

Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition Ir. Matthew Smith Colour Unuasliained Niiigitbe The Imotto Of Tlho Exhibitioni Of Recent Paintings By Mr. -Matthew. Sinitl . At The Galleries Of Messrs Arthi-Ui Tootlh And S6Ui, 1T55, Now Bond-Street, Ndcl Whatever Else Iiay Be Said About The Work It. Is Calculated To .Put Heart Ilito People Uvaiting For The Spring. Fortunatelv, Too, There Is A Good Deal Else To Be Said, For Oii Hfis Own Lines, Mr. Simith Is An Extremely Interesting Artist .What Strikes One Nmost Tf All Ill-His Present Work Is The Consistentey Of Style He Ibus Ariived At In Order To Gi E Full And Effective Playlto His Leadifig Intrelt. Hbe Is, Befoie Everything, A Paintei, Enanioiured Of Hle Substance As Well As The Colours -Of Hiispiginent, And Everything.Else, Design And Tlhe Treatillent Of Formll, Is Adaptec4 To Giviiig Pigment Its Chalnce. M.Gr. Smlithi Miay Be Gaid To Have Only Two Subjects, Wormen And Flowers, And, Frorai Tlhe Natuire Of The Case His Coniposi.Tions Are Comparatively Simnple In Tlhe Fornial Sense. The Great Advance To Be Seen In His Present Work Is In Eoi.Mplexity Of Colour.. Formerly He Workod Mainily Ini Oppositions Of Red Amd Inetallic Green, But In The Present Exshibitionl There Is Not Only Greater Ariety Of Posit.Ive Colour In The Schemlles Bult An Increased Subtlety In Thle Intervals Betweeni The Positive .Otes -As In The Passages Of Fleshl Painting. Perhaps The Iuost Thrilling Effect Of Colour Is In Feninie Endormie -Golden-Brown Flesh, Golden-Green Couch, And Light-Blie Drapery-Lent By Mr. Jacob Epstein, But There Are Some Exciting Combinations Elsewhere, In Girl Holding A Yellow Rose And .Dahlias. For Examples. Elvery Artist Has The Defects Of His Qualities, And It Is No Use Going To Mi. Simjuith For The Colour Equivalent Of The String Quartet, He Does Not Always Give Loose To The Brass, But The Constitution Of The Full Drehestra Is Felt In All His Work. Choice Between His Womien And His Flowers Depends A Good Deal On Lvhetlher The Mood Inclines To Swinging Curves Or Rounded M-Asses Of Less Definito Outline. His Physical Types Are . Clearly Chosen Forpaiuiters Reasonus, And They Are Dealt With On Painters Terms, That Is To Say, Eoompletely Translated Intoi Pictorial Conditions. There Is Sufficient Indieation Of The Differences Between Flesh, .Hair, Drapery, And Flower Substance, But .There Is No Imitation Of Surfaces And Textures. All Objects Are Brought Into The Same Category Of Brush Representation And Consistently Held In The Mediun. It Is Surprising How Little Conscious You Are Of The Model In Looking At H-Is Paintinigs Of Women. The Pleasure To Be Derived From. Mlr. Smiths Painting May Be Simple And Limited, But It Is Very Stimnulating.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Pictures By Children At The Vertheim Gallery, 3-5, Burlingtongardens, There Is An Interesting And Entertainiing Exhibition, Arranged By Miss Nan Youngman, Of Pictures By Children-Aimed At Showing That There Is A Kind Of Picture Which Is Characteristic Of Childhood. There Are About 200 Examples, Besides Wvork In Portfolios, Representing A Great Many Schools. The Credit For The Idea Of Giving Children, Not Necessarily Gifted, The Opportunity To Make Pictures In Their Own Way Under Sympathetic Direction Belongs To Miss Marion Richardson, Of The Dudley High School, And A Good Many Pupils Of That Institution Are Among The Exhibitqrs. Wvhat Strikes One More Than Anything In Looking Round The Exhibition Is That, Left To Themselves, Children Produce The Kind Of Picture That Is In The Air. This Does Not Necessarily Mean Tllat They Studv The Avork Of Contemporary Artists It Is Something Much Subtler Than That-A Characteristic Tendency In Surroundings Which Is Reflected In Cqntemporary Art.. A Child Surrounded By Motorcars, Aeroplanes, And Modern Industrial Buildings Is Likely To Drawv More Like Picasso Than Like Burne-Joues-To Whom The Characteristic Pictures Of A Former Generation Of Children Might Be Referred. More Significant And Encouraging Than The Kind Of Composition Produced By Children At The Present Day Is The Direct And Whole-Fisted Manner Of Execution. Wliat The Child Conceives Is, Under The Sympathetic Direction Referred To, Set Down With Complete Conviction In Terms Of The Implement Employed. It Is All Straiglht From The Shoulder, Without Any Of The Cramping Of Style That Drawing Lessons Gf The Conventional Sort, Or Undue Insistence Upon Merely Optical Observation, So Often Produce. The Best Compiment To The Exhibition Is To Say That It Shows The Carrying Fonvard, With Increasing Expression And Essential Truth, To The Age Of 16 Or 17 The Characteristics That Delight Us In Thle Drawings Of Infants. The Children Are Growing Up And Gaining Control, But They Are Not Losing The Synthetic -If The Word Must Be Used-Character With Which They Started. This Is Not An Exhibition For Detailed Description, But Special Attention May Be Called To Jonahl 17, Family In A Tramn 44, Saucy Bill 55, The Arrival 96, Tower Bridge 00, Last Supper 103, Hide And Seek 121, The Flower Seller 134, And Haymakers 155. Quiteproperly There Are Ilo Names Of Artists In The Catalogue, But The Age And Sex Of The Child Are Given. Of This Exhibition It May Be Said Truly That It Must Be Seen To Be Believed.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Claridge Gallery. Miss Frances Hodgkins, Who Exhibits Paintings And Water-Colours At The Claridge Gallery. 52, Brook-Street, Is An Original Artist With What Looks At First Sighit A Tendency To Caricature. Continted Acquaintance Wit-H Her Work, However, Shows That This Is Due To Her Anxiety To Give Pictorial, Form To Signific.Ant Movements, Momentary Expressions, And Paswing Effects Of Light And Colour. In Her Own Way, She, Too, Like Cezanne, Is Engaged Il Trying To Make Of Impressionism Something Like The Old Masters. It Is Eatsy Enough To Set Down A Momentary Impression In Vague Terms, -But To Keep The Impression Lively And At T,He Same Time Make The Picture Enduriur In Its Appeal Needs Consideration And A Good Many Compromises In The Appearance Of Things. Hence The Effect Of Caricature. Miss Hodgkins Is Primarily A Colourist, Shnd Sheshows Intelligence In Looseningand W Hen-Necessary Distorting-Her Drawing. In Order To Give Colour Its Full Expression. Her Oil Paintings Show An Interesting Development From Comparatively Hard Outlines Andl Realistie Modelling Towards A More Exclusive Dependence On Colour Values, With Very Good Results In Fisher Boys, Girl With Guitar, And The Two Still Life Paintinas. These Pictures Are, So To Speak. Odd, -But Their Appeal Grows In-Intensitv When It Is Seen That The Real Concern Of The Artist Is With The Colours And Gestures Found In The Subjects. On The Human Side They Are Extremely Sympathetic-In Spite Of Their Emphasis U1Pon The Vunexpected In Attitude And Expression. Among The Water-Colours -In W.Ich The Colour Inclines To Metallic Reds And Greens-W-E May Pick Out Louise, Cehildren Asleep,. Twvo Fisher Boys. And Shrine Of St. Peter As Best Representing An Art Wlhich Is Full Of Life. At The Same Gallery There Is A Very Exciting Collection Of Drawings And Designs By Children Trained Under Miss Marion Richardson At Dudley High School And By Her Pupils At Other Schools. The General Aim Is To Get Children To Put Down Their Irental Images From Observed Or Suggested Subjects, Irrespective Of Whether They Are Like Nature In The Conventional Sense. Tuition Takes The Form Of An Elastic Control, Limited- To Suggestionis For Unprovement And Hints In Design From The Old Masters. The -Results Are Astonishing. It Is Quite Clear That Most Children Form Conceptions-As Distinct -From Mere Arrangements-Of What They Have Seen, And That If They Can Be Encouraged To Put Them Down On Paper In A Whole-Fisted Way We Get Something Much Better Than Copies Of Nature. - Artistic Talent, Of - Course, Happens Where It Will, But These Drawings Seem To Show That It Might Happen More Frequently If Grown-Ups Did Not Interfere With Wrong Methods. The Shopping Subject From The Dudley High School, Flower Paintings From Benenden School, Snow Scene From Westminster School, Theatre Audiences From Westminster City School, Emotional Landscape From Langford Place, And Diaper Designsprinted From Potato Or Hino Blocks Cut By The Children-From - Hayes Court Are Instances In Support. It Is Interesting To Learn That Some Of The Diaper Designs Have Been Taken By The Calico Printers Association.

Title: Britain To-Day
Full_text: Britain To-Day Art Exhibition At Toynbee Hall Organized By The Artists International Association On The Sound Principles Of Showing What British Artists Make Of The World They Live In And Of Bringing The Results Into The Hands Of The People, There Is At Toynbee Hall A Remarkably Interesting Exhibition Of Graphic Art, Representing, In Lithographs, Wood-Engravings, And Etchings, A Cross-Section Of Britain To-Day. For The Most Part The Artists, Who Include Sir Muirhead Bone And Mr. Eric Ravilious, For Familiar Names, Have Drawn Their Inspiration From The Life And Work Of The People, So That The Exhibition Has General As Well As Artistic Interest. It Is Intended That The Exhibition Should Tour The Country By Arrangement With Local Trade-Union Branches, Cooperative Societies And Settlements, For Showing In Their Halls As Ell As In Galleries. As An Attempt To Put Back The Artist Where He Belongs, In Direct Contact With The Mass Of The People, The Enterprise Deserves Every Encouragement, And The Quality Of The First Exhibition Shows That No Lowering Of Standards Is Contemplated. From The Nature Of The Case Lithographs Are Both Most In Evidence And, On The Whole, Most To The Point Of The General Title. By Sir Muirhead Bone There Is A Series Illustrating Clydeside Industries. Mr. Hubert Cook, Who Is Himself A Welder, Deals With Welding In The Swindon Railway Works In Dramatic Designs Of High Lithographic Quality. Great North Road-Approaching London, By Night, By Mr. James Boswell, Waterlogged, By Mr. James Holland, Sheep Market, By Mr. T. E. La Dell, And After The Pantomime, By Miss Mona Moore, Also Deserve Particular Mention. The Intention In Future Exhibitions Is To Get Artists As Far As Possible To Work To Some General Theme, And The Exhibitions Are To Be Circulated At The Almost Incredibly Low Inclusive Charge Of Los. 6D., Plus Carriage To The Next Address. Mr. Rolf Gerard The Paintings And Drawings By Mr. Roif Gerard At The Calmann Gallery, 42, St. Jamess Place, Show Originality And Versatility And Also Some Uncertainty About The Line Of Advance. It Is Evident, However, That If Mr. Gerard Has Not Yet Decided What He Wants To Do He Is Preparing Himself For All Possibilities. There Is Nothing Desultory About His Work, But Each Subject Is Treated With Careful Regard To The Best Means For Its Realization. Of The Works In Oil African Soldier And The Two Blonde Landscapes, Les Oliviers And En Provence, Make The Best Impression. But It Is Questionable If The Personal Style Df The Artist Is Not More Evident In The Nervous Drawings In Pen And Charcoal, Such As Road Sweeper, Mending Nets, And Spanish Shepherd.
