Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Entertainments Art Exhibitions Auguste Rodin To Be Opened By The French Amubassador At 3 Oclock To-Day, There Is At The Leicester Galleries A Coniprehensive Exhibition, Including Drawings And Etchings, Of Works By The Late Auguste Rodin. By This Time Most Of The Uncertainties About Sculpture Which Confused The Appreciation Of Rodin Have Cleared Away. It Is Recognized That, So Long As They Are Kept Distinct, Both Modelling And Carving Have Their Place In Sculpture, And The General Aims Of The Post-Impressiomist Movement In Art Are Well Enough Understood To Make Evident The Artistic Value Of What Went Before. Rodin, Though Some Of His Works Were Translated Into Marble, Was Definitely A Modeller, Building Up His Figures In Clay For Casting In Bronze, With A Maximum Of Plastic Movement In A Rapid Sequence Of Planes. That He Is To Be Called An Lmnpressionist Might Be Disputed, But It Is Impossible To Look At The Play Of Light On The Bronzes In This Exhibition And Not See That He Was Iiiuch More Interested In Passing Effects Of Movemnent And Surface Expression Than In Form In T-He Abstract. At Any Rate, He Was A Naturalist, In Love With Life, And More Concerned With Character And Expression Than With The Effects We Call Monumental. He Responded To Both Classic And Gothic Influences, But What Strikes One Most Of All Is His Firm Basis In The French Tradition. Of Necessity Most Of The Works In The Exhibition Are Comparatively Small, But, Besides Portrait Busts, There Are Several Statues At Full Scale, Including Eve And L Age D Airain, The Male Figure Against Whicli Was Brought The Idiotic Chargeitself Significant Of Rodins Characteristic Powers-That It Had Been Cast From The Living Model. A Good Many Of The Works Will Be New To The English Public, And Several Have Only Recently Been Cast. In Bronze Firom Plasters Left By The Artist. The Directors Of The Leicester Galleries Are Certainly To Be Congratulated On Their Enterprise And Judgment In Providing Us This Opportunity To Study The Work Of The Man Who, Taking His Range Into Account, Remains The Greatest Sculptor Of Modern Times. Maillol Excels Him In Individual Works, But He Has Not Rodins Variety. As A Rule The Artistic Interest Of Rodins Works Is In Inverse Ratio To The Pretensions Of Their Titles. As Is Now Generally Known, He W-As Quick To Take, Suggestions About The Meaning Of His Work, And, Though He Was Deeply Learned In His Own Craft, He ,Was Not A Great Philosopher. Even The Famous Balzac -Shown Here On Ireduced Scale And In Head Studies, As Well As In An Interesting Preliminary Version 85-About Which Much Transcendental Stuff Has Been Written, Is Not So Much A Mystic Symbol Of Literary Gemius As A Very Ingenious And Skilful Attempt To Concentrate Attention On The Expression Of The Head. It Is Questionable If Rodin Ever Produced Anything More Perfectly Beautiful And Satisfying From A Plastic Point Of View Than The Small Group Of A Girl With A Child On Her Knees, Entitled Frere Et Sceur. It Is Harmonious From Every Point Of View, It Is Tender In Feeling, And It Sparkles Witli Life. Another Very Successful Composition Is The Group Of Two Figures, Le Bon G6Nie -Formerly Called Jeune Fille Confiant Son Secret A Isis -Full Of Movement, But Perfectly Contained Within The General Contour. Une Great Interest Of This Exhibition Is That It Shows Many Of The Works In Different Stages. The Several Studies For L Eternelle Idole May Be Quoted, No. 51 Being Particularly Charming. Rodins First Known Work, A Portrait Head Of His Father, Jean Baptiste Rodin, Made In 1860, Is Here, And Thera Are Portrait Busts Of Georges Clemenceau, Bernard Shaw, And Marcelin Berthelot -Whi Is Regarded As One Of The Finest Of Rodins Men Subjects. Les Bouraeois De Calais, Of Which The Replica Is Familiar At Westininster, Is Shown In Little. There Is An Interesting Collection Of Drawvings-Made Rapidly In Pencil And Wash As The Model Moved About The Studio. At A Time When Carved Sculpture Is In The Ascendant, And The Emphasis Is Tlirown Upon Moniumental Character, It Is Well To Be Reminded That There Is Another Form Of The Art, Deriving Directly From Life, And That It Was Employed By Rodin With A Resource And A Variety Of Expression Which Have Not Since Been Equalled.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Mr. Stanley Squire Mr. Stanley Squire, Whose First Exhibition Is To Be Seen At The Hanover Gallery, 32A. St. George Street, Is An Intensely Serious And Obviously Most Conscientious Painter Of Subjects Which It Is Impossible Not To Think A Little Silly. His Larger Compositions Are Skilfully And Painstakingly Constructed Out Of Distorted And Broadly Simplified Female Figures With Huge Bodies And Very Small Heads, Portentously Grave In Expression And Often Looking As If They Had Some Extremely Disquieting Message To Convey. His Smaller Still Life Paintings Mostly Represent, With The Same Scrupulous Attention To Balance And Breadth Of Design, A Number Of Iron Hooks. His Colour Is Subdued And Tactful And He Usually Achieves A Workmanlike Impasto Of Paint.-- Perbaps The Slght But Distinct Impression Of Undue Solemnity That Is Left By These Works Really Comes From The Effort To Force His Natural Talents Into A Mould Which Does Not Suit Them The More Realistically Drawn Passages In Some Of His Figures, Particularly In The Foremost Figure In Bathers No. 13, Suggest That His Modelling Might Be Far More Sensitive If It Was Closer To Life.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Arl Exhibitions The R.B.A. Founded In 1823, For The Encouragemleat, Of Art, The Ruyal Society Of British Artists, Now Holding Its 176Thi Exhibition At The Suffolk Street Galleries, Has The Double Distinction Of Changing Its Presi- Dents V Ery Often And With Rather Startling I Variations In Choice-As The Namnes Of Whistler, East, Solomon, Mr. Brangwyn, Mr. Sickert, Mr. De Laszlo, And Now Mr. Bertram Nicholls Will Suggest-And Of Itself Remaining Unmoved. It Must Be One Of The Most Highly Resistant Bodies In Existence. When Whistler Led A Secession From The Society He Said That He Had Taken Awvay The Artists And Left The Britislh, And There Really Does Seem To Have Been Somethiinlg In It. Possibly There Is A Spell In Thc Nanle Suffolk Street. At Any Rate The Exhibitions Of Thc R.B.A. Mnay Be Described As Woolly But Not Wild. This Does Not Mean That Each New President Does Not Lhave Some Influence-At Any Rate In The First Exhibition After His Elee- Tion-And By All The Signs We Are Now In For A Brown Period. On The Whole One Is Rather Glad Of This, Because Colour At 1 The Ll.B.A. Is Not Remarkable For Discipline. Nmr. Nicholls May Be Described As A Very Methodical But Rather Dull Painter. He Simplifies Rather Than Abstracts, Drawing Carefully And Reducing Everything To Flat Tones In Schemes That Are Almost Monochrome. Detail Gives Wvay To Texture, Produced By Working On A Coarse Canvas. His Pictures- Steyning Church Is The Best Of The Three In This Exhibition-Ate Carefully Planned, But They Do Not Click, As In Real Composition. With Mir. P. H. Padwick To Back Hir Up In A Sout Lern River, Mr. Nicholls May Be Supposed To Be Reminding The R.B.A. Of The Advantages Of Older, And Sonething Zmay Come Of It. But It Is Very Heavy Going Aiionig Flie Oil Paintings At The R.B.A. It Can Be Snid Tluht Sonic Of The Pictures Are Better Than Others, And Among The Works That Relieved A Rouhd Of The Avalls Are Black Cap -No, No. This Is A Landscape, And Not What The General Atmosphere Might Suggest-By Mliss Ethel L. Rawlins, Flowers And Lustre, By Miss H. Stuart Weir, Near Painswick, Glos, And Flower Piece, By Im1Iss Evelyn Ince, Miss Helen Ritchie, By Mlr. Al. Wickham, Head Of A Girl, By Miiss Rosalie Emslie, The Swing, By Mr. James E. Duggins, Boats Passing, By Miss Mary Mccrossan, The Sculptor, By Mr. R. 0. Dunlop, Nosegay, By Miss Irene N. Bridge, And Flowers In A Window, By Miss Edith Saunders. Thle Water-Colours Are More Lively, And, Since It Is So Britislh, One Cannot Help Feeling That The R.B.A. Would Do Well To Give Special Encouragetnent To This Form Of Art. Mr. W. T. M. Hawksworth, Who, After Years Of Precision, Has Developed A Charmingly Loose And Calligraphic Style, Has Several Good Drawings- St. Magnus, From London Bridge Wharf, For Example-And Hir. Ralph Wilson, Mr. Charles Ince, Mr. Hesketh Hubbard, Miss Mlabel Bruce Low, Mr. Staffoid Leake, Miss Sylvia Gosse, Mr. Claude Flight, And Inr. R. Kirkland Jamieson All Help To Keep Up The Interest.

Title: Fleet Street Artists' Exhibition
Full_text: Fleet Street Artists Exhibition Sir Alfred Munnings, President Of The Royal Academy, In Opening The First Exhibition Of Pictures By Fleet Street Artists In The Offices Of The Daily Express Yesterday, Congratulated The Exhibitors, And Drew Attention To A Number Of Works Of Particular Merit. The Artists Are Men Engaged In Newspaper Work. The 100 Paintings And Drawings Include A Number Of More Than Average Merit. Best, Perhaps, Is Mr. C. F. Pashleys Gouache St. Pauls, A Delicately Toned View Taken From Above The Ruins Of St. Brides. Mr. E. H. Glasbeys A Corner Of Newlyn, Cornwall, Is A Competent And Decorative Oil-Painting, And Mr. Leslie Grimes Shows A Pleasantly Coloured Flower-Piece In The Same Medium. Mr. Harry Riley Has A Clever Wash Drawing Of A Man And Contributions Worth Noting Have Been Sent Also By Messrs. H. Tamblyn-Watts, Stanley Harrop, R. G. Alexander, And Others. The Exhibition Is Open To The Public, Free Of Charge, From 10 A.M. To 6 P.M. Until Lulv 31.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Redfern Gallery In Both Quality And Variety The Present Exhibition Of Miodern Colour Prints At The Redfern Gallery, 27, Old Bond-Street, Is About Tho Best Of The Kind That We Have Seen. Excepting Pririts From Metal All The Varietieslinocut, Noodcut Monotyp6, Lithograph, And Sbllotype-Are Shown, And In Most Cases There Is That Suggestion Of The Particular Method In The Effect Which Is One Of The Charms Of This Kinid Of Work. The . Ivood Types, By Miss V. Patehion, Appear To Be Surface Prinied, Without Engraving, On The Monotype Principle, And They, Particularly Fish- Merchant, Are Very Pleasing In Colour. It Cannot Be Said That All The Exhibitors Have Their Colour Composition Completely Under Control, And Loose Colour Is The Commonest Defect In The Exhibition. Tliero Are Several Excellent Designs Of An Abstract Character,.-Which-Oossibly Because The Limitations Of Cutting Are At The Back Of The Mind-Seems To Come Off Better In Prints Than In Painting. The Vase, Very Much A La Braque, Bv Mr..R. Grierson, Is The Most Distinguished, But In The Circus, By Miiss Lil Tschudi, . Staircase -Dance, By Miss K. Eoberts, Tube Station, By Mr. Cyril E. Power, And Floating, By Mr. Claude Flight, All Have Their Attraction. A More Naturalistic Style Is Reuresented In Vale Of Pewsey,- By Mir Loxtoin Knight, And Resting, Bv Mr. Frankl Wood. Other Prints Of Great Merit In A Thoroughly Entertaining Exhibition Are The Flower Studies By Air. A. Noske, Grey Pariots B Miss A. Bresslern Roth, Rabbits, By Mr. Y. Urushibara, Roebuck, By Mr. Hans Frank, And Ice-Cream Cart, By Miss Eileen Mayo. Brook Street Galleries If Mrs. Ernestine Mills, Who Shows Enamels On Copper And Silver At The Brook Street Art Galleries, Were As Good A Designer As She Is A Craftswoman, Her Work Would Rank Very High Indeed. As It Is She Cannot Fail To Give Pleasure With Her Glowing Colours And The Sheer Beauty Of Her Materials. The Intensity Of Everlastings, A Panel On Copper, Heading A Mirror, Could Hardly Be Got In Any Other Mnedium. When The Powers Of Mrs. Mills As A Designer Are Questioned The Word Must Be Understood Strictly. She Is Inventive And, She Has Imagination, And In Combinations Of Colour She Seldoni Goes Wrong. It Is Her Actual Drawing That Leaves Something To Be Desired, And Her Figure Subjects Easily Degenerate Into Sentimentality.. Formality, As In Case Of Heraldic Enamels On Silver And Copper And A Vision Of St. Hildegarde, Always Improves Her Work, And She Is Particularly Successful In Champlevd Enamel, In Which The. Framing Ridges Of .The Metal Ground Imnpose A Certain Restraint. Mrs. Mills Appears To Practise All The Varieties Of Enamel, And -From A Technical Point Of View Her Work Is Excellent.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Balkan Men And Ways. Quite Apart From The Novelty Of Their Subject-Matter, The Paintings And Woodcuts Of Balkan Men And Ways By Mr. Sidney Gausden,. At The Gieves Art Gallery, 22, Old Bond-Street, Are Wel Worth Attention. Mr. Gansden, Who Was Badly Wounded In The War, Afterwards Volunteered To Go To Bosnia To Assist In Educational Work, And This Brought Him Into Close Contact With The Peasantry Who Form The Subjects Of Many Of His Pictures. His Work Divides Itself Into Two Classes Direct And Forcible Paintings From Nature And Severely Formalized Decorative Compositions. Of The Last Reapers, Four Figures In Line, Identical In Form And Action But Diminishing In Si7E, Is An Admirable Example. The Best Of His Direct Studies Are Small Landscapes, Such As Dying Winter. Mr. Gausdens Woodcuts, The Bridge, Mostar, For Example, Have A Vitality Which Is Too Often Lacking In Work Conceived As A Black-And-White Patterr. The Portraits And Paintings By Contessa Pecorini-Manzonii At The Arlington Gallery, At The Same Address, Are, Lively And Original, But Amateurish In Execution. The Redfern Gallery. Opened With The Special Object Of Giving Facilities To Our Younger Artists- For The Exhibition Of Their. Work, The New Redfern Gallery, 27, Old Bond-Street, Shows Every Sign Of Interpreting Its Duties With Discritnination. No Doubt As A Mark Of Confidence, Several Of Our Leadcng Artists, Such As Sir William Orpen And Professor William Rothenstein, Have Contributed Examples Of Their Work To The Opening Exhibition, But The Future Policy Is To Be Seen In The Paintings, Drawings, And Etchings By Well-Trained Young Men And Women Who Are Just Beginning To Make Their Way With The Public. The Opportunities For The Picture-Fancier With The Courage Of His Convictions Are Obvious. A Friend Of The Family, By Orovida A Grey Day, Terschelling, By Miss Muriel Hope Tonghattan Island, By Xiss Rosa Hope, And The Drawings By Mr. Colin Gill May Be Singled Out For Special Mention. Walkers Galleries. The Water-Colours Of Greece, Spain, And England By Miss Mary Hogarth At Walkers Galleries, 118, New Bond-Street, Are Of The Attractive Type That We Associate With The New English Art Club Primarily Drawings, With The Washes Applied For The Suggestion Rather Than The Full Statement Of Colour. In Several Drawings, The Farm, Jijona, And In The Province Of Alicante, For Examples, Miss Hogarth Shows Her Appreciation Of The Strange Landscape Of Spain A Landscape Of Tawny, Terraced Mud Or Sandstone, With A Green Ribbon Marking The Course Of Water. The Drawings Of Architecture, Notably The Parth6Non, And The Old Cathedral, Athens, Show That Miss Hogarth Has Only To Gain Steadiness To Excel In This Kind Of Work The Delberate Economy Of Her Method Speaks Well For Her Future. Brmsh Game Birds. Mr. J. C. Earrison, Who Shows Drawings In Water-Colour Of British Game Birds At The Galleries Of Messrs. Vicars, 12, Old Bond-Street, Is Distinguished In This Form Of Art By His Masterv Of Characteristic Flight. His Drawings Of Mallards, Foreshortened, Gaining Speed, Partridges At Full Speed, Pheasant Tmrning Back. From The Guns, And Green Plover Tumbling In The Air, Are Really Wonderful In This Respect And There S Intimate Observation In The Tucked-In Tails Of Mallard, Widgeon, And Teal Alighting. In Style Of Execution Mr. Harrison Is Rather Broader Than Is Usual In Work Of The Kind, Though His Markings Are Distinct Enough To Satisfy The Naturalist, His Birds Have Air Round Them, And They Are Generally Well Related To Their Landscapes. Fine Art Society. There Are Welcome Signs That Mr. W. Russell Flint Is Trying To Get Away From The Convention Of Too-Too-Solid Damsels On Too-Too-Untroubled Sands Which Has Made Him Popular. In His Present Exhibition, At The Galleries Of The Fine Art Society, 148, New Bond-Street, There Are Several Drawings, Such As Mid-Morning And Parti-Coloured, Which Run To The Gay Colour-Patterns Of The Instinctive Decorator, And It Is To Be Hoped That Mr. Flint Will Be Encouraged To Follow Bis Bent. Mlechanical Facility In Laying A Wash Is A Poor Substitute For Such Things, Or For What Mr. Flint Has To Give Us In Flickers -Sun, Sand, And Fir Trees, And Caprice, With Its Charming Diaper Of Leaves. Mr. Wv. Eg,Ginton, Who Shows Water-Colours On And Around Dartmoor In The Room Upstairs, Has A Real Gift For Composing Moorland Landscape As-. Distinguished By Light And Shade Under Fullbosomed Clouds In South-Westerly Weather -As Witness A. Clondy Eveningl-Dartmoor And South Henary Tor. -Heeis One Of The Artists Who Can Get More Out Of Broken Country Than Out- Of Such Features As Trees And Bridges. The Paint-N Ings Of Wild Life In Many Lands By Mir. John G. Millais, In The Adjoining Room, Will Be Interesting Chiefly To Naturalists And Sportsmen. To The Layman, Lions Hunting A Koodoo Bull Is The Most Exciting.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: I Art Exhibitions. Liege Engravings At Brighton. At The Public Art Galleries, Brighton, To Which We Are Already Indebted For A Long Series Of Exhibitions Illustrating The Nioderii Art Of Different Continental Countries, There Has Been Arranged A Very Initeresting And Informing Exhibition Of The Work Of Liege Engravers, From The 16Th Century To The Present Tile. In Scope The I Exhibitioni Is Someothing Of A Novelty, And, Iiideed, There Cannot Be Many Towns In The World Wbhich Could Provide The Neces-! Sary Nmaterial In Any Particular Art Over R J Simlilar Period. The Fact That Modern Liege I Is A Steel Towvn Is Not Without Bearing On Thc Past And Present Activities Of Itsinhabitarits In Ai Art Which Began With The Ornamentation Of Mietal, Prints From The Sanme Being Ail Afterthought And, I Indecd, The Exhibitiont, With All Its Changes In Style, Has A Sinigular Efeect Of Consistency. Incidentally, It Provides A Short Survey Of The Developmlenit Of Engravinig, Froni The Severe Woork Witli The Burini Aiid Graver To The Freedom Of The Bitten Linle. Apart Froiii Its Intrinswi Initerest, Tthe Cxhibitioli Is In Arrangenment A Nmodel Of Wlhat A Special Exhibitioni Ought To Be. And The Warmest Thanks Are Due To The Liege Departmlent Of Fiine Arts And To The Brighton Fine Arts Sub-Commiiittee For Trio Opportunliity They Have Given Us To Siudy The Work Of A Definite School. Nvhen Ve Talk About Belgian Art We Arc Apt To Einphasize The Flemnish Element. This May Be Just As Regards Painting, But Thte Work Of The Li,Ge Engravers Is Dislinctivelv Walloon, Andc May Be Looked Upoii As Descended Froin That Of The Ivory Carv Ers And Nietal Craftsmeni Of The District, Nvhose Fame Goes Back To The Tenth Centuiry. Though It Ineludes A Contemrporary Section, The Exhibition At Brighton I3 Mainly Retrospective In Ainm. Transport Difficulties Have Delayed The Arrival Of A Collectioii Of Cngraved Glass, But Examples Of Engraved Mietal Anid Somie Very Fine Miedals By Variii And Dluvivier Are Ineluded. The Earliest Engraver Represented Is Lanibert Suavius, -Who Died About 1567. His Work, Imostly Of Single Figures, Is Remnarkable For Molurmenital Digniity And Firinuess Of Execution. The Rich Designs Of Tlhe De Brys, A Family Flourishing From 1528 To 1611, Incildinig An Alphabet Ornaniented With Fancifuil Arabesques, Are Followed By Delicate Religious Subjects By Jean Valdor, And Xwith The 18Th Century We Begin To See The Application Of Engraving To The Reproduetion Of Paintings Anid Drawings Splendidly Illustrated By The Work, After Watteau, Boucher, Huet, And Other French Artists, Of Gilles Demarteau, 1722-1766, Whose Ilitationis Of Drawings With The Roulette Are Marvellously Close To The Originals. The Contemporary Section, The Figure Subjects By Adrieii De Wvitte And The Landscapes By Franfois Mareehal-Who Designied The Poster For The Exhibition-In Particular, Shows That The Long Tradition Of Engraving In Liege Is Alive And Vigorous To-Day. Finte Art Society. In The Chateatux Of Northern France. Mr. 301On Everett Has Found Almost Ideal Subjects For So Etchiings And Aquatiits Now Being Shovwi At The Galleries Of The Fine Art Society, 148, New Bond-Street. So Far As General Feeling Andl Cowmpositioni Are Concerned Lie May Be Saicl To Have Made The Best Use Of The Subjects The Defects In His Work Being A Certain Crudeness Of Drawinig And A Ceitaii Inicoherenice In The Relation Of Tones. The Impression Giveli Is That Mr. Everett Has Not Yet Mastered The Control Of Biting In Aquatint That The Intervals Of Tone Do Not Come Out Quite As Lie Intemided, But With Sudden Jumps Ironi Light To Dark, Opacity In The Shadows, Anid At Lack Of The Middle Tones And His Most Attractive Proofs Are Generally Those In Wlich Linie Predominates. Such As Clitteau Do. Buit Amboise. Cinion 24. And Fresnay Sinr Sarthe Tare Good And Thoroughl Romantic Studies. At The Same Galleries There Is An Exhibition Of Moderin Japanese Colour Prints, Done In The Traditiontal Mannier. As Might Be Expected Thc Lanlscales Iiherc Are Vastly Superior To The Ligulr Subjects, Partly Because The Treatment In Them Is Less Consciouisly Imitative Of The Cleasics. Twso Artists In Particular, Suizan And Liasii. Staiidl Out, Aind In Both Of Them There Are Signs Of Wvestern Inifluence Wlhieli, Being Uncoliscious, Does Not Spoil The Decorative Charm Of The Native Traditimn. Ilozn Rapids, By Suizali. Aud Rlaii-Okaylina. By Hasui, Are Two Good Examples Of Their Work. Accompanyiig The Prints In The Roost Appropriate Manner There Are Miniature Japanese Gardens Arranged By Professor Suzuki.

Title: South African Art
Full_text: South African Art Exhibition At The Tate Gallery An Exhibition Of South African Art, Which Opeaed Yesterday At The Tate Gallery, Has Obviously Been Carefully Chosen To Give A View Of The More Lively Developments Of Painting And Sculpture In That Country. There Ame A Few Eighteenth And Nineteenth Century Works By Topographical Artists, But Most Of The 150 Paintings, Drawings, And Sculptures Are By Artists Who Have Been Fully Conscious Of Recent Movements In Europe Although Many Artists Have Applied French And Other Styles To African Subects, It Is Admitted That As Yet There Is Nothing Approaching A South African School. A General Impression Of Thc Exhibition Suggests An Adventurous Struggle For Freedom Not Unlike That Of A Nurnber Of English Artists When Postimprcssionism Was First Discovered Here One May Well Believe That To Paint Pictures Which Would Not Be Out Of Place In The London Group Required Great Courage And Tenacity When Art, As Mr. Gcoffrey Long Says In His Preface To The Catalogue, Was Largely Represented By Views Of The Mountains Of Cape Province Lit By The Last Sunset Of Victorian Bad Taste And Funereally Framed In Dcad Black. One Or Two Of The Artists Here Would Normally Be Considered Members Of The English School There Is. For Example, Graham Bells Ithe Cafe, From The Manchester Art Gallery, And Mr. Du Plessis Shows A Number Of Characteristic Landscape And Still-Life Paintings. By Contrast, Mr. Walter Battiss Has Been Very Obviously Influenced By Bushmnan Cave Paintings, And The Sculptor Mr. Moses Kottler Is Extremely Skilful And Suave In His Study Of Bantu Figures. Miss Maud Sumner, An Artist Who Has Worked Much In Paris, Is An Attractive Colourist Mr. Terencb J. Mccaws Spring Landscape Is Freshly Painted And Attractive In Feeling, And His Still Life Has A Rich And Juicy Texture Miss Irma Stern Uses An Expressionist Tcchnique, W.Ith Some Vigour Mr. Robert Broadleys 4 Snowv In Lancashire Has A Good Firm Design, And Sixpcnce A Door, By Mr. Gerard Sekoto, A Sclf-Taught Bantu Artist, Has An Agreeable Simplicity And Candour. V,, Pictur On Page 10.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Francesco Gttardl In Aidof The Ktists General Benevolent Association There Has Been Arranged At Messrs. C6Onaghis, 144, New B13Ond-Street, A Very Captivating Loan Exhibition Of Paintings And Drawings By Francesco Guardi 1712-93. More Free In Style Than His Master Canaletto, More, Atmospheric In His Treatment Of Venice, And A More Varied Colourist, Guardi Sums Up To Perfection The Most Attraetive Qualities Of The Baroque Phase Of Painting. His Pictures Are Set To Music, And One Effect Of This Exhibition Is, To Evoke The Illusion Of Somebody Playing Searlatti. Apart From His Power Of Musical Composition, Eontrasting The Movement Of Shipping And People With The Stability Of Architecture, With A Use Of Accents That Might Be Compared To Trills And Turns, Guardi Was One Of The Liveliest Painters In Aetual Execution That Over Lived, With. A Touch That Wvas At The Same Time Firm Arnd Sensitive. In His Treatment Of The Figure On A Small Scale L He Has Some Affinities With Hogarth, Buti The Grace Of Movement Is All His Own. The Baroque Tendency Of His Art Is Most Pronounced In The Large Composition -Almost Certainly Invented-Entitled Seascape. It Is Full Of Echoes And Responses In Form And Colour, The Themae Being Given Out, So To Speak, By The Swinging Sea Wall Below The Tower, Upon Which Slanting Shadows Carry On The Movemnent Until It Is Caught And Returned By The Lateen Sail Of A Boat. A Red-Cloaked Figure In The Foreground States The Strongest Colour, Which Is Echoed In Pink Flags, And, On The Left, A Blue And A Brown Figure Are Emphatically Relieved Upon The Sunset. But This Is A Full-Blooded Exercise, A Little Garlicky In Flavour, And The Graces And Refinements Of Guardi Are To Be Looked For Elsewhere. Three Pictures, In. Particular, Show His Delicate Mastery Of The Figure-In Each Case On A Different Scale And In Different Relations. The Figures Are Smallest In The Piazzetta, And Presented Singly Or In Little Groups, Forming A Series Of Trills And Runs In A Composition That Is Primarily Arehitectural-Suffering A Little As A Composition From The Duality Ereated By The Two Columns. Pius Vi. Blessing A Crowvd In Front Of The Scuola Di San Marco, Which Is Very Likrely To Be One Of The Four Pictures Commissioned By. An Englishman In 1782, Shows Guardis Power To Niake That Most Difficult Compromise Between A Crowd And A Collection Of Individuals--The Foreground Figures Nmight Be Portraits-And Also The Amount Of Colour He Could Suggest In Nomninl Grev. In The Ridotto. An Interior, He Breaks Into Positive Colour, The Scheme Being Arranged To Celebrate The Glorious Blue Domino Worn By The Central Figure. The Effect Of Slow, Swaving Moventent. In This Picture Is Wonderful. A Continuous Rhythm Runs Through The Whole Group? Of Fliures--Some Paradintg In Conversaton, Others Seated At Refreshment Or Games Of Chance-While Individual Pairs Contribute Minor Rhythms Of Their Own. The Most Elaborate Piece Of Formal Counterpoint Is The Riva, With Buildings P4Tllel To The Spectator And, In Front Of Thern, A Very Intrieate Arrangement Tf Ahippinlg, Witht Raking Masts And Calrving Ropes-A Fugal Composition. The Island Of San Giorgio Mlageiore, The Redentorc, Church Of Santa Maria Della Salute, End Dogana Di Mare Show More Partieularly Guardis Atmospheric Qualities, Airy Perspeetives Of Siffsed Colour, Crossed By Dark Gondolas, With Sparkling Accents Where The Oars Sttike The Water. In The Small Gallery- Downstairs There Is A Collection Of Drawings, Of Which Courtyard Of The Doges Palace, In Pen And Grey Wash, Is Tbe Most Complete Example.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Beaux Arts Galler-Y At The Beaux Arts Gallery, Bruton-Place, Paintings And Drawings By The Late Charles Conder Anid The Late Ambrose Mcevoy, A.R.A., Combine In Creating An Atmosphere Of The Past. Tho Two Artists Differed In Inspiration, And Mcevoy Was Contemporary And A Good Draughtsman, Whereas Conder Died Some Years L Ago And Never Learnt To Draw, But For All That They Had In Common The Preoccupation Lvith The Sensuous Qualities Of Painting To The Disregard Of Construction Which Seems To Have Passed Away. 3Mcevoy Had The Nmore General Sense Of Beauty, And, Though His Drawing Was Loose Enouglh, It Was There By Implication. Though This Exhibition Contains Three Oil Paintings The Artistic Interest Is Rather Vith The Water-Colours, Particularly Those Of A Moderate Size, Such As Lillah, Bmr. Noel Cowvard, Study For In A 31Irror, And Boats In Dieppe Harbour. In Their Vaourish Treatinent, With Sharp Accents Where Required, And Fluent Handling In Subduede Colouts They Have A Great Deal Of Charm--Even If They Seem To Evade Rather Than Master Their Subjects. Conder, Though Lie Paintted Some Landscapes, Was Almost Entirely Erotic In His Inspiration, And His Work, With Its Great Inequality, Is A Very Good Illustration Of Hoiw Far Such Inspiration Is Adequate For A Work Of Art. As A Rule The Quality Of His Work Is In Inverse Ratio To Its Size, And It Is Questionable If The Best. Things In This Exhibitioni Are Not The Very Smlall Watercolours On Silk, Bathing Machine And In The Park. Conder Was Not A Great Artist, But He Was A Very Precious Little One, And Lie Is Historically Interesting As Tho Distiller Inito Colour Of That Queer Phase Of Life Wvhichi Is Conveniently Called The Decadence. At The Same Gallery There Are Paintings And Water-Colours By An American Artist, Mrs. Louise Nvood Wright. These, Again, Atre Artistic By Evasion Rather Than! By Mastery, And The Best Pictures In The Exhibitioni Are The Slighlt Grey Portraits Of Mrs. Herbert Brocknian And Mrs. Low, And The Still Life Painting Of Roses In The Windowv, Which Is Charming Both In Colour And In Play Of Light. With More Positive Colours Mlrs. Wright Seems To Lose Her Taste, Though Autumn Flowers, In Water-Colour, Is A Good Study. Chester Gallery Thouglh The Exhibition Of Embroideries By I Aldy Ada Boyd At The Chester Gallery. 2, Chester-Terrace, Mlay Be Divided Into Original I Worknianship By The Artist And Actual Antiques I It Is All Period In Character, Mtti So It, Is To He Judged By Qualitv Ii Execution And Taste In Application Rather Thaln As A Demonstration In Decorative Lesigoi. On1 These Lhies It Is A Very Attractive Exhibition Indeed, Collsistently Harmonious In Colour And Graceful In Pattern. Spealing Generally, The Work Basedl On The Earlier Periods, Suci As The Bess Bed Hangings Worked In Blue Wools On Linen, From Designs At Hardwick Hall, Is The Mlost Pleasing, But The Charmns Of Colour And Workmanship Persist Down To The I Vic- Torianisms. For Soiie Reason The Most I Nmodern Note In The Exhibition Is Strtek By The Florence Bed Hangings, In Silks On Canvas-An Extremely Vell-Balanced Adapta- I Rion, In Both Form And Colour, Of The Florentine Fiordilice. Samnlers And Patchlwork Quilts, Old And Modern, Are Inchlded In The Exhibitioi. I The Flower Paintings By Mis Marion0 Broom At The Same Gallery Show The Artistic Value Of Excess. On Examination They Are Neitlher Well Drawvn Nor True In Tone Relations, But By Virtue Of Thieir Richness And Intensity They Succeed In Looking Handsome. Phlox And Scabious, Toby Jug, And Zinniiias 23 Are Three Good Examples. Miiss Ethel Sands Of The Many Contemporary Artists Who Would Acknowledge Their Indebtedness To Hlr. Sickert There Is None Wlho Hats Managed To Infuse The Debt With A, More Personal Taste In Colour Than Mliss Ethel Sands, And The Present Exhibition Of 20 Paintings By Lier At The Wlarren Gallery, 39A, Maddox-Street, Has The Attraction Of Sometllinlg Conspicuously Of Its Kindlike A Distinct Variety Ini Flowers. The Art Of Mliss Sands Is Highly Civilized In Its Choice Of Subject Mnatter, Inclining To Elegant Interiors Wvhich Might Very Well Be The Settings Of Stories By Henry James. In These Interiors, Xvhich Are Either Panelled Or Else Prettily Diapered, Sunlight Is Graciously Received And Entertained With A Variety Of Objects-Floxvers, China, Glass, Ribbons, Whhat Not-And There Is A Great Deal Of Unobtrusive Art In Deciding Its Direction For The Benefit Of The Ilesigii. As A Rule Miss Sands Is Most Successfal Wvith Blte, Green, And Pale Gold, Thouglh A Lobster Is Ouie Of Her Best Pictures-Largely Owving To The Fact That The Red Is Centred In -Le Composition. In Ail Open Windowv The Red Table Presented Obvioas Difficulties, Owing To The Absence Of Any Pretext For An Echo In The Landscape Beyond, But There Seemns No Reason Wvhy The Unrelated Red Chair In Interior In Sunlight Should Not Have Been Made Niore At Home By Something On The Wall. But There Is None Of The Paintings That Has Niot Its Charm Of Colour And Touch-Often Recalling Pasew-Ani Tne Siivery Mantelpiece, The Low-Toned Corner Of An Empire Room, And A Flower-Piece Are Very Delightful Paintings Indeed. Students Of Textile Design, As Well As People Who Wanit To Buy Fabrics, Will Find A Serious Opportunity At The Gieves Gallery, 22, Old Bond-Street, Where There Is A Combiniedl Exhibitiou Of Yugoslav Peasant Industries And Hand-Woven Woollens, Cottous, And Silks By Lmfrs. Mairet.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: I Art Exhibitions. The London Group. To Anybody Who Wiu Give Himself A Chance With Pictures, Without Too Much Regard To His Own Prejudices, The Twentyfirst Exhibition Of The London Group At The Hinansard Gallery, 196, Tottenham Court-Road, Cannot Fail To Bring Ultimate Satisfaction.. It Is A Remarkably Consistent Exhibition, Comfortable And Even Cosy In General Atmosphere, Due In Great Part To A Prevailing Fatness Of Pigment And A Warming Up Without An Obvious Brightening Of Colour. There Is A Slight Disturbance At The Further End Of The Gallery, Caused By M. Riaoul Dufys Seascape, Seen Through A Window, Which, With Its Blare Of Light And Dancing Wavelets, Reminds You A Little Of The Concealed Spy In The Sack Who Tried To Pass Himself Off As Broken China By Exclaiming At The Critical Moment, Crash, Crash-Tinkle, Tinkle, Tinkle! And Mr. Matthew Smiths Wild And Whirlingnot To Say Sanguinary-Nudes. These Last Represent, No Doubt, A Genuine Impulse, But The Risk Is That When The Moodhas Passed, And The Bubble Is Pricked, So To Speak, Mr. Smith Wil Find That He Hias Learnt To Do Nothing Else Inside Its Exuberance. Having Paid Homage To These Demonstrations And To The Sailor, Nigger, And Lady Having A High Old Time In Mr. J. W. Powers Dance, We May Pass To Quieter Pleasures. For The Deft Use Of Paint To Enclose A Mood There Is Nothing To Equal Mr. Walter Sickerts Banco. Apart From Its Enchanting Colour Scheme Of Golden-Green, Violet-Blue, And Dull Red, And Discreet Suggestion. Of Conflicting Lights, It Conveys The Impression Of A Breathless Moment In Which The Painter, As Well As The Gamesters, Was Absorbed. It Has An Emotional As Well As A Pictorial Unity Which Raises It Far Above A Thing Seen. Mr. Roger Fry, Who In These Political Days Might Be Said To Play Extreme Left To Mkdr. Sickerts Asquithian Liberalism, Is For Once Non-Committal In A Horizontally Composed Beynac Of Quarry-Face, Trees, And Road. His Increasing Geniality Of Substance Is Carried By Others Of His Party Into A Beefiness Which Suggests That The Prevailing Influence Of The Moment Is That Of Segonzac. If The Play Upon A Respected Name May Be Permitted, Mr. F. J. Porter Has Something Of The Advertised Feeding Properties Of That Beverage. His The Mouth Of The Arun Is An Extraordinarily Good Picture, Holding The Day Like A Cup, But Even It Has Traces Of The Excessive Stoutness Of Pigment, Which Obscures The Very Real Merits Of Arundel And Lilac. In The Matter Of Substance, Something Seems To Be Needed Between Mr. Porters Practice And The Extreme Polish Of Mr. Mark Gertler. In His Ornamental Bird The Preciosity Is Justified, And In Head Of A Young Girl It Roughens To The Occasion But In Roses And Tapestry The Surface Does Not Support The Scale, Though The Picture Has All Mr. Gertlers Peculiar Magic Of Colour. As These Remarks Will Suggest, One Great Merit Of The Exhibition Is That Everything In It Is Contained Within The Province Of Painting. There Is Nothingor Hardly Anything-In Which A Doctrinaire Design Sticks Out Like Scaffolding. In Mr. Duncan Grants Still Life, The Forms-Of White Jug, Red Bowl, Black Bottle, And Green Apples-Hardly Earn Their Support On The Kitehen Table, But They Are Beautifully Placed And Well Notirished By Their Background, And His. Pot Of Flowers Shares With Miss V7Anessa Bells Roses And Apples, Not To Speak Of The Lustre Bowl, The Honours Of The Exhibition In Joy Of Colour. A Welcome Appearance, In This Connexion, Is That Of Miss Anne Estelle Rice With Flowers. Mr. Walter Taylor Breaks New Ground In Several Paintings Of Buildings, Exchanging Line For Pattern, And Mr. Ethelbert White In T Dolce Acqua, With A Thrusting Arch, And Several Of The More Prominent Landscape Painters, Such As Mr. Paul And Mr. John 1Ash And Mr. Elliott Seabrooke, Supply Excellent Drawing8. Drawings And Etchhings. Representing Mostly Sheds, Barns And Other Homely Buildings In Sussex And Kent, The Etchings And Drawings By Mr. Grahamn Sutherland At The Twenty-One Gallery, Durham House.Street, Adelphi, Make A Very Good Impression. Mr. Sutherland Is Clearly To-Be Added To The Now Considerable Body Of Young Artists Who, As If Reaeting From The Shorthand Methods Which Fill Our Galleries With Superficial Attractions, Return To Dwelling Upon Their Subjects And Aim At An Artistic Effect By Co-Ordinating Detail Rather Than By Leaving It Out. Apart From The Enduring Excellence Of The Results, The Movement Is Extremely Interesting Because It Is Paralleled In Other Aspects Of Life-In Social Matters.And In Architecture, For Instance. It Is A Defuiite Sign Of The Times-The Still, Small Voice After Too Much Of The Big Noise. The Most Accomplished Things By ?Mr. Sutherland Are Probably The Twvo Small Etchings, Fetching Wvater And October Landscape, And The Slightly Larger The Sluice Gate, In Which The Commonplace Material Of Posts And Rails Is Used With Admirable Effect In Both Pattern And Tone But Everything He Does Has The Distinction Which Comes Of Feeling Into The Subject. The Old Cow Barn, An Interior, And Niumber Fortynine, An Extremely Careful Drawing Of A Ruined Thatched Cottage, With The Rafters Showing, Are Two Of Several Works Remarkalle For The Way In Which Nominally Still- Ife Subjects Are Made To Suggest Local Atmosphere. The Making Of Colour Prints. At The Gallery Of Messrs. Bromhead, Cutts, And C6., 18, Cork-Street, Biurlington-Gardens There. Is Ai Very Interesting Special Exlhibition, Organized By The Society Of Graver-Printers In Colour, Showing The Various Stages In The Pro. Diietion Of Eolour Rints From Wood And Metal. The Exhibition Consists Of Preliminary Drawings, Trial Proofs, Final Proofs, Variations In Printing, And A Few Wood Blocks, And The Net Result Is To Impress The Observer, Not-Only With The Way In Which The Artistic Imtention Of The Final State Is Kept In View Throughout, But Also With The Pare T4Aken And The Sacrifices Made In The Process. It Is Questionable If The Variations In Printingthat Is To Say, Different Colour Schemes From The Same Set Of Blocks Or Plates- Are Much To The Point, And Some Of The Preliminary Drawings Might Have Been Taken As Read The Particular Interest Of The Show Is In The Detailed Analysis Of The Final Result. From This Point Of View, The Most Infor Exhibit Is The Set, Consisting Of The Final - Proof With Six Preceding States Of Coloured Aquatint- For Sun Through A Yellow Mist, Chel. Sea, By Mr. Raphael Roussel The Special Interest Of The Set For The Wood Engraving Of St. Pauls, By Mr. E. Verpilleux, Is In Showing The Rejectionxs And Alterations Made By The Artist Before He Was Satisfied. Line Blocks For Wood Cuts By Kr. Allen W. Seaby Illustrate A Particular Method 6F Working, And Iroxm The Whole Exhibition There Is Much To Learn. The Broadcasting Programmes For Tod8Y And To-Morrow Will Be Found On Page 19. R

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition. The Leicester Galleries English Landscape Paintings Describes More Than The Subjects Of The Pictures By Mr. Algernon Talmage, A.R.A., At The Leicester Galleries, Because, In Both Outlook And Method, He Is One Of The Most English Painters We Bave. He Takes A Broad, Sane View Of Country Life, With A Special Interest In Cattle And Horses, And A Masculine Sympathy For Human Beings In The Open Air Avoiding Alike The Extremes Of Brutality And Sentimentality. His Remote Ancestor Is Constable, But He Has Learnt Something From French Discipline, And Is Not Insensible To The Poetry Of Corot. Always A Painter In The Strict Sense Of The Word, As One Who Fulfils The Requirements Of Drawing, Colour, Tone, And Quality With Every Stroke Of The Brush, Mr. Talmage Goes On Making Progress In Composition, Unity Of General Tone, And Geniality Of Colour. Not The Least Charm Of His Present Exhibition Is That Of The Colour Of Daysgold, Silver, Blue, Green, Or Grey, As The Ease May Be, With Effective Contrasts. As That Between The Setting Sun, Dedham, And A Breezy Morning. Almost Necessarily Mr. Talmage Is. Happiest In A M6Oderatc Size, When The Picture Grows Under His Brush To The Immediate Conception In His Mind Without Much Calculation. The Planning-Out Of A Large Canvas Still A Little Bothers Him. October Morning, With All. Its Merits In Feeling Anid Workmanship, Is Rather Leggy In Its Framework Of Tree Stems And Branches And Their Cast Shadows-And The Last Perplex Rather Than Aid The Eye In Leading It Through The Picture. The Best, Or, At Any Rate, The Most Unified, Of The Larger Pictures Is The Road To Higham, With A White Cow Lcading Her Darker Companions Towards The Spectator Along A Lane In Cool, Grey Shadow At Sunset. The Movement And The Muffled Tread Of The Beasts In The Dusty Roads Are Wonderfully Well Suggested. Better Still, However, Are The Smaller-Sized A Dedham Landscape, In A Steely Glitter, And The Drinking Pool, In Which The Rails And The Slanting Boughs Play A Valuable Part In Holding The Picture Together. Anmong The Small, Direct -Studies, Each-The Expression Of A Nmood, It Is Vcry Difficult To Choose But Nos. 57, 60, 67, 68, 84, 88, And 94 Deserve Special Attention. Mr. Gerald Aekermaun, Who Has The Next Room With Water-Colours, Is In The Healthy English Tradition, With Special Affinities With Cox And Tom Collier. His Drawing Is Not Substantial Enough For Such A Subject As Cley M.Iill, On That Scale, But Give Himn Open Country In Broken Weather, And He Leaves Little To Be Desired. In Several Drawings, Too, In Blarch, The Sheep Fold In February, A . Sunny Mlorning In Marcli, And All October Morning, For Examples, He Gets The Quality Of A Season. Steyning Clhalk Pit, In Shadow, Shows Him Very Successful In A Subject Out Of His Usual Run.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Examples Of Dutch Printing Everybody Interested In Book Production Ought To See The Selection Of Books, Postage Stamps, And Paper Money Printed At The Office Of Joh. Ensched6 En Zonen, Eaarlem, Now On View At The Premises Of Messrs. Bumpus, 350, Oxford-Street. Holland Has An Old Tradition Of Printing, And What Strikes Ono Most Of All In This Exhibition Is The Effect Of Something That Has Gone On Continuously, Clearing Itself M Response To Modern Requirements, And Not Something That Has Been Recently .Revived. There Is A Blonde Quality About Dutch Printing-Recalling, Indeed, The Quality Of Vermeer-For Which It Is Difficult To Find Another Descriptive Word. A Good Many Of The Books In This Couection Are Printed In The Lutetia Fount, Designed By Mr. Van Krimpen, Very Easy And Pleasant To Read In Both Roman And Italic-Both Employed M The Catalogue Of The Collection. There Is Also, By The Same Designer, A Greek 4 Antigone Type, Which Almost Persuades Us That We Know The Language. Several Of The Books Have Been Printed For English Publishers-For Mr. Peter Davies And The Nonesuch Press, For Examples. To Look At The Postage Stamps And Paper Money Is Rather Humiliating-Though There Is Some Consolation In The Circumstance That The Best Of The Designs For The Java Bank, By Mr. Jongert, Have Not Been Circulated. The Dutch Air Mail Stamps, By The Same Artist, Are First-Rate-Showing The Inestimable Advantage Of A Good Convention. The Catalogue, A Work Of Art In Itself, Has The Benefit Of A Preface By Mr. Stanley Morisoni.

Title: Exhibition Of Nigerian Art And Handicrafts
Full_text: Exhibmiion Of Nigerl Art And Handicrafts An Exhibition Of Nigerian Art And Handicrafts Is Being Arranged Under The Auspices Of The Government Of The We.Stern Region Of Nigeria And Will Be Shown At The Tea Centre, Regent Street, From May 28 To June 29. The Exhibition Was Orignally Assembled During February At Ibadan, In Honour Of The Visit To Western Nigeria Of The Queen And The Duke Of Edinburgh. So Much Interest Was Aroused In The Exhibits That It Was Decided To Bring Them To London. The Exhibits. Come From All Parts Of Nigeria And The Cameroons, But The Majority Are The Work Of The Yoruba Peoples Of Western Nigeria, Who Excel In The Arts Of Woodcarving, Weaving, Beadwork And Leatherwork.

Title: Three London Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Three London Art Exhibitions Series Of Aquatints If Somewhat Portentous In Sound, The Title Vertical Suite In Black Literally Describes The Series Of Monochrome Prints By Mr. Merlyn Evans On Exhibition Until March 5 At The St. Georges Gallery, 7, Cork Street. The Process Used, Sugar Aquatint On Zinc, Gives The Effect Of A Brush Drawing With An Added Granular Quality Of Tone, And Mr. Evans, Inspired By African Masks And Carvings, Shows A Calligraphic Fluency In His Interpretation Of Their Design By This Graphic Means. The Arcade Gallery, 28, Old Bond Street, Has A Minor Trophy From The Little-Known Field Of German Rococo Art In The Form Of 20 Drawings, The Majority Of Which, Signed J. B., Suggest The Hand Cf J. G. Bergmliller, A Painter And Engraver Who Flourished At Augsburg In The First Half Of The Eighteenth Century And Executed Many Frescoes For Churches In Bavaria. The Drawings Are Slight But Quite Charming With A Typically Rococo Flavour Of Chinoiserie. The Desert, Without Oasis, Arabs, And Palm Trees, Does Not, One Would Think. Offer Great Scope To Representational Art, And The Painter Brion Gysin Von Liestal Has Not Avoided Monotony In The Oils And Gouaches Of Sand And Sky, On View At The Arthur Jeffress Gallery, 28, Davies Street. A Feeling For The Saharan Spaces Is Evident, However, And In Iron Wind, For Example, Is Conveyed Attractively With Something Of Surrealist Precision.

Title: Artists' War Relief Exhibition
Full_text: Artists War Relief Exhibition. Princess Louise, Duchess Of Argyll, Yesterday Opened The Artists War Relief Exhibition At The Maddox-Street Galleries. The Exhibition, Which Will Remain Open For Several Weeks, Contains Examples Of The Work Of Mr. Clausen, R.A., Sir Ernest George, A.R.A., Mr. Arthur Hacker, Ra., The Late Mr. Stacey Marks, Mr. David Murray, R.A., Mr. Alfred Parsons, R.A., Mr. Solomon, Ra., And Sir Ernest Waterlow, A.R.A. It Has Been Organized Jointly By Tho Imperial Arts League And The Royal Institute Of British Architects.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Brooh-Street Gallery To Make Tuse Of An Irishism-The Best Of The Flower Paintings By Mrs. Sidney H. Cotton At The Brook-Street Art Galleries Are Paintings Of Fruit, Such As From A Cottage Garden, Auttmn Raspberries. Wvhite Grapes, And Scarlet Berries. Why It Slhould Be So Is Not Easy To Say, But It Is Partly Because Except White Grapes. Wvhich Are Drenched In Light -The Fruit Paintiings Are More Even In Tone Thani The Flower Paintings, To Their Advantage In Colour. Mrs. Cotton Does Not. Arrange Things Very Well, But She Is A Deft Painter, Producing A Pleasihg Surface Quality, And The Scarlet Bowl, Wifii Wvhite Carnati6Ns, Daisy Chrvsatnthemums, And Pom-Pon Dahlias Are Attractive Studies. 3Liss Florence Oheils. Who Shows Drawings And Water-Colours At The Same Galleries, .S At Her Best When She Is Most Of A Draughtsivomr.An. Though They Are Not Without Some Awkwardness In Arraugeilmentt The T.V Interiors, The Long Room, 17, Church-Street, Wv., And Hall At The Vache. Have A Linear Intcrest Which Suggests A Special Turni For This Kind Of Work. 31Orhing After The Storm Is Another Goo,T Drawving, And There Are Some Neatly Humorous Illustrations. 1Mr. Benno Schotz Sculptors, Like Painters, May Be Divided Roughly Into Two Classes Those Who Work From Form Towards Character, And Those Who Work From Character Towards Form. Generally, Thougli Not Always, The Former Incline To Carving And Ithe Latter To Modelling. There Can Be Little Doubt To Which Class Mr. Beino Schotz, Who-Thou6H His Work Is Well Known In Scot-. Land-Is Uowv Holdinig 1His First London Exhibiion At The Lefdvre Galleries, Ia, King-Street, St.. Jamess, Belongs. He Begins With Character And Expressas Iiniself Naturally In Modelling. This Dloes Not Mean That, He Is Indifferent To Forn Or Dislikes C Arving. Octurne, A Crouchlinlg Woman In Stone, Is Evidence To The Contrary On Both Counits It Is Wiell Contained Within An Imagiiary Cuboil Block, Though The Internal Rhythims Are Not Perfectly Satisiying And It Is Well Carved. The Other Carving, Herzl. A Mans Head, Is Executed Rather Than Conceived In Carving Terimts. But When The Merits Of These Wvorks Have Been Observed, And Due Recognition Has Been Given To The Formal Dignity Of The Bronze Torso-The Miarch. It Is As A -Nodeller Of Portrait Busts That Mr. Schotz Makes The Best Impression. Here, Too, He Gains By Pronounced Character In The Subject, And His Head Of Hugh Wal- Pole, Esq., Which Depends Upon General Coii- 1 Tours, Is Zot So Good As His Escelle Rit Bst Of I James L. Caw, Esq., Director Of The Scottish National Gallery, In Which Character And Expression Call The Tune. There Are Several Other Good Portrait Heads In Bronze. Includmig A Charming One Of Little Betty,And Some Lively Statuettes. Stencilled Colour Those Who Are Interested In Book Productioii Should Pay A Visit To The Zwemmer Gallery, 26, Litchfield-Street. Charing Crossroad, Where There Is An Exhibition Of Stencilling In Colour By The Curwen Press. The Process, Hvllich Is Best Suited To Small Editions, Is Not New, But By Intensive Cultivation Mr. Curwven Has Brought It To A High Stage Of Perfection. The Great Advantage Over Printed Colour On The Page Is In What Painters Call Quality -Richness Of Gradation And Broken Texture, With The Suggestion Of Light, At The Same Time Keeping Within The Page Convention. The Greatest Triumph Of The Press So Far Has Been In The Illustrations By Mir. E. Mcenight Kauffer To Elsie And The Child, By M1R. Ariiold Beunett, Published By Cassells, And It Is Interesting To Compare These Results With, Tihe Illustrations, Bv The Same Artist, Lo Herman Melvilles Beuito Cereno, From The Nonesuch Press, Which Were A Fir-T Attempt With The Process. For Freedom Of Style The Most Remarkable Exaample Is Experimental Subject, By M1Rs. Edna Clarke Hall, Taken From One Of Her Illustrations To Wuthering Heiglhts, Whicht No Publisher Has Yet Had The Enterprise To Secure. One Would Have Said That It, Was Just The Moment For A New Edition Of This Novel. Apart From Its Special Object The Exhibition Is Interesting From The Range Of Artists Represented-Mir. Albert Rutherston 3Mr. Paul Nash, Jacquier, M1R. Barnet Freetiman, And Mirs. Milarion Dorn Among Zhem. Incidentally, It Is Easy To See That The Stencil Process Is One To Be Controlled Bv Taste Rather Than By The Limitations Of The Medium. Arlington Gallery Though There Is Not Mucl Outnvard Resemblance, The Landscapes. Flov-Er Pieces, Portraits, And Stili1If6Stixies In Oil By Mr. Gerard Ceunis A Belgian Artist, At The Arlington Gallery, 22, Old Bond-Street- Rehind Ooe A Little Of Vian Gogh. That Is To Say, They Seem To Proceed From A Desire For Intensity Of Realization-Particularly In Colour And Light. In Certain Instances, Too. There Is Something Corresponding To The Writhing Technique Which Van Gogh Employed In His Eagerness For Vitality In The Objects Represented. On What May Be Called The Impressionist Side Mir. Ceunis Is A Good Artist, I His Colour, Though Bright, Is Generally Harmoniious, And His Pictures Are Full Of Light But His Drawinig Is Fussy Rather Than Expressive And His Designs Are Comparatively Commoniplace. By Far The Most Original Is The Cabin, An Amusinig Study Of A Rough Sea Crossing, In Wlichl Distortionis Are Effectively Employed To Intensify The Lurching Movement. . On The Whole, However, We Like Mr. Ceunis Best Iin His Flower Pieces Such As Chrysanthemums, Liiies. Tulips, And Copper Pot. Sun In Room Does Not Lose Any Of Its Effect By A Quieter Treatment Than That In Most Of The Other Paintings. A Spanish Artist Mlr. Santa--Marina, The Spanish Artist. Who Shows Paintings And Drawings At The Gieves Gallery, 22, Old Bond-Street., Wins Approval By The General Sentiment Of His Work Rather Than By His Technical Powers. Something Intimate And Slightly Melancholy In His Pictuies Gives Them An Appeal That Their Actual Designls Might Not Exercise. His Nationality Comes Out In The Fondness For Masses In Siihouette Which Has Distinguished Spanish Painting Since Velazquez, As Also In The Convenition, Used In The Painting Of Mmie. Pia De Diego, Of Setting The Portrait Of A Human Being In Emotional Rather Than Strictly Pictorial Relation To The Portrait Of A Town. The Most Completely Satisfying Paintinig In The Exhiibition Is, However, The Portrait Of Mlle. Sol Santamtarina, A Young Girl Seated Witlh Her Hair Ahout Her Shoulders. In This The Silhouette, With Its Balance And Couniterchange Of Light And Dark, Is Managed With Great Skill Anid Refinement, Reminding One Of Coello. The Turning Of The Hands Iniward On The Lap Contributes To The Enclosed Feeling Of The Whole Coinposition. Two Other Attractive Portraits Are Don Mliguel Ramos And Minme. Rene Pierre, The Last Being Remarkable For Grace Of Line And Subtlety In The Modelling Of The Figure Under The Blue Dress. There Are Some Good Decorative Landscapes Of Bruges, Versailles, And Elsewhere, Aiid Portrait Drawings. The Study In Pencil Of Mlle. Sol Santamarina. 8 Is Charming. .Mr. S. M. Litten Though He Works In Line Mir. S. M. Litten, Who Shows Drawings And Etchings At Messrs. Connells Gallery, 47, Old Bond-Street, Has A Primary Instinct Tor Tone-And Toiie In Its Emnotional Rather Than Its Constructive Function. He May Therefore, As A Matter Of Convenient Classification, Be Said To Belong To The School Of Rembrandt. This Relationship May Be Used To Excuse Him For Getting Tone Effects With Line, Becduse The Effects He Values, With Their Richness Of Texture And Indefiniteness Of Gradation, Would Not Coxie Out Vell In Aquatint, Or Even, In Mezzotint. Though It Is Iiot The Mode Of The Moment, This Kind Of Etching Justifies Itself As, Means To An End. From What Has Been Said It Almost Follows That, In Subject., Mir. Litten Leans To The Picturesque And The Atmospheric-The Rather Ramshackle Buildings Of Lolland And The Romantic Light Aiid Shade Of Venetian Canals, Particularly At Niglht. That In Treatilng The Subjects Bis Emotional Attitude Is Too Often Sentimental Must Be Allowed, But Lie Is Consistent As Betwveen Feeling Arid Method, Anid Lie Is A Sympathetic Interpreter Of The Sbirit Of Vlace. The Giudecea Canal, 2Nd State, The Doorwaav Venice. The Smuggler, Acd The Doorwvay, Ely, Amone The Etchings, And Old Houses On The Rokin, Amsterdam, The Wrater Boatmeni, Mlarken, Aiid Santa Maria Della Salute, Among The Drawings, Nay Be Specially Praised.

Title: Exhibition Of Australian Art
Full_text: Exhibitio-N Of Australian Art. From To-Day Till May 7 The Grafton Galleries Will Contain An Exhibition Of Unusual Interest. It Aims At Giving Au Adequate Representation Of Current Australian Art, And, As It Is Organized By The Trustees Of The National Art Gallery Of New Soutli Wvales, That Object Has Been Fairly Secured. Nearly 400 Pictures And Drawings, With A Few Pieces Of Sculpture, Form A Collection The Like Of Which The Colonies Have Never Sent Home Before For The Best Men Exhibit, And The Galleries Of Sydney And Melbourne Lend Many Of Their Most Characteristic Pictures. One Is Tempted To Assume, In A General Way, That Colonial Art Cannot Be Very Good That The Country Is Too Young, And That The Talents Of Its Sons Generally Find Other Outlets. But In Point Of Fact The Last Twenty Years Have Wrought A Great Change In Australia, And The Practice Of Art Has Thriven There, If Not Quite As Vigorously As In America, At Least As Vigorously As Has The Practice Of Literature. These Galleries Show It, And They Show Also That The Impuise, Or At Least The Mode Of Expression, Has To A Great Extent Come From Paris, Through English And Australian Teachers Who Had First Learned What The Paris Ateliers Had To Teach Them. Mr. Bernard Hall, Mr. Daplyn, And Some Other Teachers Are Instances Of This Their Work, With That Of Their Pupils. Shows The Traces Of It. In This Bright And Pleasant Display There Is Very Little That Recalls Anything English The Broad, Summary Treatment, The Firm And Yet Careful Drawin-, The Manner Of Laying On Paint Are In Origin French, Though They Have Become In A Measure Transformed By Transplantation. If There Is Any British Work To Which The Australian Pictures Bear A Clcse Resemblance, It Is That Produced By The Young Men Of Glasgow And We Know How Strongly French Influence Has Told On Them. Mir. Phillips Fox, For Example, The Painter Of A Charming Portrait Of A Child In A Quaint White Frock And Sun Bonnet 108, Might Almost Have Worked With Mlr. Guthrie, And The Australian Landscapists, In Spite Of The Brightness Of Their Climate, Have Much In Common With Their Cousins On The Banks Of The Clyde. Of The Landscape Painters The Most Noteworthy Are Mr. Arthur Streeton, M.Ir. David Davies, 3Fr. Lister-Lister, And Mr. Daplyn While Among The Painters Of Combined Figure And Landscape Mr. F. Mcubbin, Mir. Tom Roberts, And Mr. A. Lotureiro Attract By Reason Of A Certain Individuality And Force. Mlr. Streeton Claims Our Gratitude For Giving Us Impressions Of Landscape Which Seem To Be Distinctively Australian His 1 Hawkesburv River 62 And His Picture In The Inner Gallery 284, Albeit A Little Too Much Composed, Could Hardly Represent Anything In Any Other Latitude. M.R. Davies, On The Other Hand, In His Tranquil, Featureless Landscapes, Almost Suggests The Barbizon Tradition Filtering Lowvn Through Tho New English Art Club. Mlr. Li.Ister Paints On Too Large A Scale, And Does Not Avoid Some Approach To The Commonplace But Mir. Daplyns Carefull W Ork, If A Little Oldfashioned, Has All The Virtue Of Sincerity. Tlle Large Picture Of M.Rr. Micubbin 7-6 Bears The Quaint Title In The Wallaby Track Let The Unmlearned Note That The Wallaby Is A Small Rodent W,Tho Wvanders From Plaee To Place, With No Fixed Home, And Is Therefore A Kind Of Totem For Tramps, Two Of Whom, With The Usual Baby, Are Painted In This Clever And Rather Touching Picture. This Is Ono Of The Everyday Incidents Of Australian Life A Tragedy Of A More Heroic Cast Is The Death Of Burke, The Explorer 09, A Large, Well-Painted Pictulre By Miir. Loureiro Of Melbourne. Let Us Add Mr. T. Robertss Vivid And Extremely Clever Picture Of Bolting Sheep. 1A Break Away 40, Some Portraits Of Sir Henry Parkes And Other Eminences, By Mr. Julian Ashton And Others Some Heads Of Aborigines 143, By Mlr. B. E. Minns Some Clever Pencil Drawings By Mir. Lambert 238 And One Or Two Excellent Little Pictures By Mir. Charles Conder, Whose Work Is Well Kmown In London, And We Shall Have Said Enough To Show That This Australian Exhibition Is Worth Seeing. Tne Subjects Are Fresh, And In Technique The Average Work Of Chelsea Or Clichy Is Certainly No Better.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. New Forest Group. The Excellent Aims Of The New Forest Group Of Artists, Now Exhibiting At The Mansard Galleries, 196, Tottenham Courtroad, May Be Described As To Bring Together Local Talent And To Improve The General Artistic Amenities Of A Rural District In Which There Are No Regular Art Exhibitions Or Reference Libraries, Few Facilities For Seeing Books Or Reproductions, And Little, If Any, Instruction In Design Or Crafts Available. London Has Been Chosen Because A London Exhibition Focuses Local Interest Most Effectively, And Also Because It Is Easier There To Get Into Touch With Those Interested In General Artistic Welfare. The Present Exhibition Concerns Itself With The Architectural Crafts, With Special Reference To Libraries. Naturally Enough, It Is Tentative Rather Than Explicit, And Naturally, Too,It Is A Little Self-Conscious. As Everybody Familiar With. Country Life .Aust Know, The Right Procedure Is Not To Impose A Culture, But To Find Out The Artistic And Intellectual Possibilities To Which The Neighbourhood Will Respond, And This Mheans Conscious Experiment. The Problem, Nowadays, Is Not So Much To Preserve As To Restore Social Health, So That The Artist, Has To Proceed Like The Doctor Exhibiting A Series Of Remedies. Sorne Will Succeed And Some Will Fail, Because They Do Not Suit The Patient. .As In The Case Of The Patient, Much May Be Learnt From Past Habit, And So The R Records Of Interesting Features Of The New Forest And District By Local Artists, The Maps Of Ancient Earthworks And Pottery Sites, And . The Careful Drawings Of Roman Pottery, At First Sight Irrelevant, Have A Definite Bearing On The Problem. A First Step To Local Culture Is To Recall The Locality In Its Facts And History. The Exhibition Gives Evidence Of Much More Consideration-And Wary Consideration-Than Appears On The Surface. The Backbone Is A Series Of Suggestions For Libraries, Public And Private, Architectural, Musical, Seafaring, School And College, Childrens, Village, And Even Prison. Lists Of Suitable Books, Chosen By An Advisory Council Of New Forest Residents, Are Given, Together With Contributions From The Various Crafts For The Furnishing And Decoration Of Libraries, All Of Local Production. Plans And Drawings Of Library Buildings, By Such Architects As Mr. Sidney Greenslade-The Designer Of The Welsh National Library, Aberysytwyth, Now Engaged Upon New Library Buildings At Exeter-Mr. Paul Phipps, Mrs. Cecil Porter, And Mr. A. L. Roberts, Are Shown, And There Are Stained-Glass Designs By Miss C. M. Lowndes-Including Her Suggestions For The Rearrangement Of 13Th-Century Glass In Salisbury Cathedral. The Exhibition Is More Remarkable For What Is Suggests Than For What It Provides In Detail, But Special Attention May Be Drawn To The Decorative Designs By Mrs. Maxwell Armfield, The Textiles By The Forest Looms, And The N1Etal-Work By The Misses Lisle. During The Exhibition There Will Be A Series Of Half-Hour Conferences, At No Extra Charge, On Subjects Connected With Its General Aims, The Speakers Including Lord Montagu Of Beaulieu, Mr. D. Plunket-Greene, Dame Ethel Sniyth, And Mr. A. S. Cooke, County Librarian, Kent. A Tri-Inational Exhibition. The Tri-National Art Exhibition Which Opens At The New Chenil Galleries, Chelsea, Early In October Promises To Be Interesting-Particularly With Regard To America, Which Divides The Field With England And France. Except For A Privately Organized Cxhibition, Which Reflected The Past Rather Than The Present, At The Grafton Galleries A Few Years Ago, And Occasional One-Man Shows, We Have Laked Opportunities In London Tosee What Is Being Done Across The Atlantic And Now We Are To Be Introduced To The Younger American Artists, Such As Glackens, Tucker, Davies, Sheeler, Weber, And Walt Kuhn. The Constitution Of The French Group Reads More Familiar, But There Will Be A Special Attraction In The Sculpture By Bourdelle, Maillol, And Brancusi. Among The English Exhibitors Will Be Mr. Augustus John, Mr. Ambrose Mcevoy, Mr. Glyn Philpot, Mr. Jacob Epstein, And Mr. Frank Dobson. The Idea Of The Enterprise Is Due To Mrs. F. H. Harriman, Of New York, And It Is Intended To Be An Annual -Event Playing Its Part In Proraoting Amicable Relations. Mr. Roger Fry Will Provide The Introduction To The English Catalogue.

Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition. Book Decorations. Book Decorations Is A Modest Title For The Dranwings By Miss B. Taudia Guerelo Now Being Exhibitedl At. Tht Lmayfair School Of Dancing, 44A, Westbourne-Grove, Because They Include Full And Highilv Imaginative Illustrations. Indeed. What Distingiuishes The Work Of Miss Uercio From That Oif Most Contemporary Book Decorators Is Its Extraordinary Richness Of - Content, Recalling In This Respect. Thoutglh Not In Style, The Mieni Of The Sixties I Who Contributed To The Loxon Tennyson. Thiev. Of Course, Workedt For Woodcut, But Miss Guercio Is Vise Enough, While Remembering The Dignity Of The Page. To Take Full Advantage Of The Facilities Of Process Reproduction, Though Working In Pen And Ink, And Not In Wash. Since Her Last Exhibition She Has Greatly Inproved In Her Figure Drawing, Anm Havingi Rnaide Herself Acquainted At Lirst Hand Wvith Tbe Technical Nietliods Of Reproduction, Shel Is Now Very Nvell Equipped For The Branch Of Art In Which She Specializes. The Present Exhibition Is To Be Looked Upon A.S A Display Of Resources Rathler Than As A Collection Of Original Drawings Wlielt Have Been Reproduned, And Publishers Oil Ilit- Look-Out For Voung Talent Would Bei Well Advised To Pay It A Visit. There Is. For Iinstance, A Set Of Fotu Illustrations. Withi Titlepage, To De Quinceys Opium Eater Which Calls Out For A Hanisome Edlition. As Mtay Be Reininhered, Mliss Uercio, Wlho Is Vtrv Young, Is A Sicilian. And Her Work Reflects The Mingled Eastern Amii Western Strains Of Her Origin, Iparticularly In The Fantastic Elaboration Of Her -Rabesque Borders. In The Adaptation Of Her Work To The Printed Page, In Scale Of Detail And Wveight Of Tone, Sie Has Still Something To Learn. But She Lias Such A Fund Of Iiagination And Invention To Draw Upon, That There Can Be Little Doubt Absout Her Future. For Mr. Cyril Beamonts Ilistorv Of The Harlequin Miss Uuiercio Has Made A Cover Dtesign, And Her Exhibition, Wvhieh Closes To-Day, Iticludes Inilial Letters And Page Headings--Inspiret For Thie Niost Palt, Bv German Fairv-Tales--Of Ecurious Interest. The Imiore Fantastic The Authior The Better Liss Guiercio Succeeds.
