Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: - Ex Tuitio N. .,W,,X Vru Indiann Partins. Lilce .Organ Music .Nigli Well Deseribe Theeffeet Produced By The Copis Of Indian Pintings. Iw On Viqw In The Exhibition Gallery Of Theprints And Lraw. Ings Dephrtuient Of The, British Ifuouni. The Originahn In A- Sort Of Freso6, Ate Iu 8The. Caves Dr Rol Temples Of Bigh, In .Gwahor State, And These,Copies Were Made -By Native Artists To The Order Of The Late Maharajahi Scindbja Of Gwalior, At The Suggestion Of Colonql Luard. They Have Been Iesit Over By The Ge.Lior. State For Reproduction- In England By The India Society, Whioh Will Issue A Special Work On The Qubjeet In- The Near Future, And, By Athe Ate -Maharajah, They Ate At The British Museum For Awbout A Fortnight, These Nobl Relics Of Buddhist Art In India Are Supposed To Date From About The Seventh Entury A.D., Contemporary With The Aatest The He Better-Known Examples At Ajanta, That Is To Say, Just Before The Almort Complete Eessation Of Purely Indian .Art Until Its Revival Iri The 16Th Century In Smaller Forms. Mir. Mukul- Dey, -The Indian Artist Who Visited The Bagh Caves A Few Years Ago Is Of Thbe Opinion That The Paintings There Were Never Completely Finished, The Final Black Touches Used For Sucb Details As Hair And Eyebrows At Aianta Being Absent, And Certainly The Copies Would Seem To Support This. If It Be True, It Only Adds The Interest Of An Art, For Whatever Reaton, Out Off Suddenly To These Nmarvellous Renuain.. There Are Nine Panels At The British Museum, Seven Of Them Seeming To Run In A Continuous Series Like A Frieze. Unlike The Aianta Paintings, Which Are Connected With The Story Of Buddha, They Have For General Subjectt A Rausical Play, With Notables Arriving On Horses And Elephants. This, However, Is Not To Saythat They Arte Not Religious In Intention, The Mood Of Them Being That Of Solem.N Rejoicing. The Players, Or Dancers, To The Number Of About 16, Are In A Flowery Enclosure, And The Other Figures Are In Procession-Something After The Fashion Of Magtegnas Triumph Of Julius Casar. But No Western Paintings-Though The Afinity Here Is Greater Than That Between European And Chinese Art-Can Equial These In Grandeur. The Effect Of Slow, Massive Movements In The Elephants And Horses Is Overwhelihing And The Deep Colouring, Of Different Tones Of Indian Red, Ochre, -Dull Blue, And Green, Relieved With Azure On Pale Yellow In The Garments Of The Women, Makes The Musical Comparison Unavoidable. The Drawing Is Tswi?T Andsure, Reaching An Intoxicating Grace In The Hands Of The Dancers. Two Of The Panels Seem To Detach Themselves From The General Scheme. One Represents A Weeping Woman With A Companion The Other, Four Fguresof A Darker Colour Than The Rest, Chocolate Against A Green-Blaek Background, Seated As If In Discussion. Tbot Suggestion Is That Of Predellas To The Festival.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitioons. There Can Be No Doubt That A Worthy Successor To Meissonier, As A Painter Of Headlong Battlescenes, Has Arisen In The Person Of M. Francois .Lameng, Whose Vive Lempereur ! Now On View At Messrs. Tooths Is Tho Most Brilliant Picture Of The Kind That We Have Seen Since 1807. The Subject Is Neys Final Chargo At Waterloo, When, At The Head Of A Nondescridt Body Of Whatever Cavalry He Could Collectcuirassiers, Lancers, Dragoons, Carabineers, The Survivors Of Ten Cther Ferocious Charges-He Dashed Forward Against The Square Formed By The 71St Highlanders. Such A Scene, Scarcely Possible In Modern War, Where The Magazine Rifle Has Taught Cavalry To Keep Their Distance, Gives A Magnificent Opportunity To The Military Painter. He Can Bring Together On One Canvas Cavalry And Infantry In The Death Grapple On The One Side, A Rushing, Tempestuous Wave Of Horsemen, And On The Other The Foot Soldiers Formed In Square, The Hard Immovable Rock Against Nvhich The Wave Is To Dash, To Break, And To Melt Away. This Is What M. Flameng Has Done In The Picture Before Us, A Work On Which He Has Been Assiduously Engaged For Several Years, And In The Painting Of Which Lie Has Had All The Assistance That The Chief Historical Authorities Of The Day And The Descendauts Of Some Of The Principal Combatants Could Give Him. A Brief Pamphlet By M. Henri Houssaye, The Leading French Writeronthe Waterloo Campaign, Explains The Exact Circumstancesof The Charge Andof The Struggleswhichpreceded It- The Close Of Thefourth Act Of The Epicdrama Of Waterloo. It Reminds Us How, Ufter The Capture Of La Haie Sainte, Ney Endeavoured With Eight Regiments Of Cavalry To Break The English Right Wving How He Delivered Ten Separate Attacks, Without Being Able To Make Any Impression On The Squares. And How At Last, Collecting From All Regiments About A Thousand Survivors, He Made This One Last Desperate Venture, Only To Fail As Before. Al. Flamengs Picture Explains Why, Given That Raoral Steadiness Which Has Always Marked Onr Troops, It Was Impossible That Ney Should Succeed, For The Mere Position Of The Highlanders-Behind A Sunk Road, And Protected By A Battery Of Guns, Svhich, Though Silent, Were None The Less An Obstacle To Cavalry-Was Such As Bo Aive An Enormoas Advantage To The Defenders, Ereshly Mored Up From The- Reserve. Lbut, Waiving All Questions Of History, We May Unre3Ervadfy Admire The Spirit, The Accuracy, The Vigour Of M. Flamengs Work, And The Great Sense -.F Pictorial Effect Which It Displays. We Have Aot Even Discovered Any Blunders In The Dress Or 3Quipment Of The Highlanders, Which Is Of Itself L Great Testimony To The Artist And, As For The Efench Soldiers, It Is Enough To Say That Neys ,Ostume Is Painted From That Which The Marshal Ictually Wore, Lent By His Grandson, The Present Prince De La Moskowa. A Like Attention To Debail Is Shown Throughout The Picture. In Other .Aspects It Closely Resembles Meissoniers Work, Ihough It Is In No Sense An Imitation And While Icarcely Inferior To Him In Draughtsmanship, H. Flameng Is Perhaps Better In Colour. This Is The Only Picture Whicb Is Likely To Xraw People Away From The Academy For None Of The Other Shows That Have Just Opened Are Of Much Importance. Miss Earl, At Messrs. Gravess Galleries In Pall-Mall, Exhibits A Number Of Caretul Likenesses Of Celebrated Dogs, And The Attractiveness Of The Display Is Increased By Four Of The Queens Landseers, Specially Lent From Osborne. A French Ladly, Madame Bries, Shows At The Same P Lace Some Clever Water-Colours But In These Days The People Wsho Can Paint As Well As This Are Legion. Lastly, The Fine Art Society In New Bvnd-Street Startle Their Old Clientrle By An Exhibition Of The Works Of M. Jan Van Beers. These Would Be More In Place At A Gallery Further Down The Street, Which Announces Marvellous Pictures From The Paris Salons.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Walkers Galleries Two Of The Present Exhibitors-Lady Humewilliams And Mrs. W. St. John Mildmay-At Wvalkers Galleries, I 1S, New Bond-Street, Have Covered Tho Same Grounid, In Several Instances Painted Tho Sainr Subjects, So That Their Work Atyords An Interesting Comparison In Temperament And Style. Lady Liume-Wvilliamnis Is The More Atmospheric In Her Interests Andpossibly For Thar, Reason-She Has The Better Sense Of Tho Picturo As A Wlhole, Blending Thinigs Together By Noting Their Relative Values In The Schome. Early Morning-Venice, Storm Elffect-Bellagio, And Clhilteau Gaillard Are Three Of The Most Successful Of Her Drawings. Mtrs. Mildmay Is More Positive In Statement, As Regards Both Form And Colour. Witlh The Result That Her Work Looks More Circumstantial And Less Unified. She Is At Her Best When The Colour Scheme Assists Unity, Its In A Provenq,Al Cafe, But Sunshine And Shadow-St. Paul, Clearing Up After Rlain-Normanidy, And Dent Du Mlidi All Give Pleasure By Their Vigour Of Representationi. In Another Room There Are Landscapes In Silk Needlework, By Mrs. Forrester Wood. Theso Inevitably Raise The Question Of The Relation Of Mieans To End-Wvhether It Is Worth While Spending Weeks, Possibly Montlhs, To Get An Efect Very Sirnilar To What Couild Be Done In Water-Colour In An Lhour Or Two. It Is True That The Effect Is Not Quite Tlhe Same The Sheen Of The Material Gives A Silvery Quality. And Its Linmitations In Range And Variety Of Colour Lend Organization To The Schemes. Certainly Mrs. Wood Is Remarkably Successful In Suggesting Atmiiospheric Planes Of Distance, And She Draws And Com1Poses Well. The Relation Of Means To End Ignored, Her Pictures Ars Very Attractive. Miary Duddys Grocery Shop Is Possibly The Best, But Ploughsussex Anid Keepers College-Invernessshiro Run It Very Close. On Its Own Lines Mrs. Woods Work Is Very Consistent. Claridge Gallery Different As They Are In Other Respects The Two Present Exhibitors At The Claridge Gallery, 52, Brook-Street., Mr. Conrad Ttrench And Mir. Adrian Kobnt Have It In Common That They Seemn To Have Coine To The Practice Of Painting With Minds Wvoll Prepared. Of Mr. Ifrench, In Particular, One Would Say That He Had Cultiva Ted The Habit Of Looking At Things Pictorially, And In Terms Of Whllat Miiust Be Called Moderni Design, Before He Had Mutchi Opportunity For Execution. He Has The Advantage In Novelty Of Subject-Muatter, Mlch Of His Work Haviutg Been Done In Jamaica. His Danger Would Appear To Be The Characteristically Moderni One Of Over-Calculation Of The Picture, And There Are Hints Here And Thern Of The Flilled-Iii Design Instead Of The Composition In Terms Of Painting, But It Is Clear That He Is Temperamentally Considerate, And A More Imipulsive Fusion Should Come With Experience. The Most Completely Uniiied Of Hiis Oil Paintings Is The Stmall Banana Grove Jamiaica, But Negro Boy, Still Life 6, Draughts, And Homnestead Are All Pictures Which Add To A Nice Consideration Of The Desigsn, The Charm Of Colour, And Of Deliberate Handling. Depart Des Cygnes, Though It, Is Not So Deftly Painted As The Others, Has A Special Appeal In Its Emotional Gesture. Movement, Again, Is The Attraction In The Excellent Watercolour Of A White Horse, Mr. Browvns Pride And These Two Pictures Support The Impression That Mr. Ffrench Has Reached A Stage In Painting Whenl He Canl Afford To Lose His Head A Little. Mr. Adrian Kient Leaves More To Chance, Anid Seemns To Get A More Robust Pleasure Out Of The Substanice Of His Pigment-His Actual Colour Being Kept Dowvn. Easily The Most Attractive Of His Pictures Is Elephanit Ballet. It Is A Genuinely Plastic Inveiitioii, Its Humour Being Derived From Bulk In Movement, And Not From Any Suggestion Of Conscious Fun In The Animals. Bears, Half-A-Dozen Of Them In A Wood, Is Not Quite So Good In Composition, But Like The Other Picture It Suggests That Mlr. Kent Has Discovered A New Kind Of Artistic Value In Animal Life. The Beasts Are Nmade To Appear Entirely Independent Of Humiianity And One With Their Surroundings, Distinguished From Trees For Artistic Purposes By The Power Of Movement. In Some Of His Landscapes, In The Front, Rapallo. For Instance, Mr. Kent Adventurec Into Brighter Colours, And It Is Clear From Hia Treatment Of Thie Foreground In The Picture Namiied That Lhe Knows Instinctively How To Keef Thenm In Their Place In The Picture. The Tent 1. The Better Versioni Of The Two, Riva Ogni Santi, Venice, And The Canal, Regents Park Are Other Paintings That Promise Well For The Future. Gam1E Birds In His Present Exhibition Of Water-Colours Of British Game Birds At The Galleries Of Messrs. Vicars Brothers, 12, Old Bond-Street, Mr. J. C. Harrison, Who Is V-Ery Well Known In This Kind Of Work, Seems To Be Adopting A More Forcible Style, Particularly In Landscape Surroundings. There Is A Gain In Support To The Pattern Of Birds Against The Sky-Mnost Of The Subjects Are Shown In Flight-But Some R Isk Of Crudeness In Colour. Mr. Harrison Makes The Necessary Compromises-Between Markings As Knowvn And As Seen, And Between Actual And Pictorial Movement-Very Well Indeed But Above All It Is As A Record Of Characteristic Flight In Diflerent Circumstances That His Work Is Interesting. The First Over. Partridges, A Chance In A Life Time. Geese, And White-Fronted Geese Pitching Strike Us As Three Of His Best Irawings, But No Doubt Sportsmiien Andd Naturalists Might Prefer Others. There Are 55 Drawings In The Exhibition. Illuminated Maunuscripts A First Word Is Duo To The Charming General Effect Of The Exhibition Of Illuminated Manuiscripts, Presentation Addresses, And Heraldic Emblems, Engrossed By Miss Dorothv Hutton, At The Threo Shields Gallery, 8, Holland-Street, Kensington. At Once A. Special Form Of Art Is Proclaimed, With A Vitality And Grace Of Its Own, Ajid Examination Of The Work Leaves No Doubt Thast The Iorm Is Justified At The Present Day. It Is Somethinlg Quite Distinct From Fine Printing, Wvith A Give And Take-A Sort Of Tempo Cubato In The Line-That Belongs To Writing Alone. And, Thougll Miss Hutton Is Evidentlty Learned In The Styles Of The Past, There Is No Effect Of Imitation Itn Either Seript Or Decor-Ations. Art, Thev Say, Is A Criticism Of Life And It Is Certainly True That Fine Writing Is A Criticism Of Literature Even More Severe Than That Of Cold Print. It Is Extremnely Interesting To See How Diffcrent Qualities Of Literature Have Affected Miss Huttons Style Of Writing Compare For Instance The Gravity Of The Beatitudes With The Playfulness Of Sumer Is I Cumen In And The Birds Carol Breaks Into Song. Presentation Adldress To H.1.I-I. Princess Louise Is A Romp Of Children, And In Wedding Service There Are Manty Happy Allusions. Keeping Her Balance In Design, 3Miss Hutton Seems To Respond To Every Suggestion In The Words She Writes And In The Occasion Her Work Commemorates. Beaux Arts Gallery Everything In The Exhibition Of Painting6 Of Spain And Morocco By Mr. James Kerrlawson At The Beaux Arts Gallery, Brutonplace, Bears The Mark Of A Cultivated Mind, Alive To The Implications Of The Subjects, A Reflective Habit, And A Flne Taste In Colour. Before He Puts A Scene Or Subject On Canvas Or Paper Mr. Kerr-Lawson Reduces It To Its Essentials In Form And Colour As They Appeal To H?Im, And If These Esrsentials Are Expressed As Simplified Realism, Rather Tlan Synthtii Cally, His Work Is Not Likely To Suffer In General Esteem On That Account. Almost Inevitably Fromii His Method His Designs, Though They Are Well Patterned, Havo A Certain Slackness, And Occasionally-As In Moorish Street Scene - One Feels That He Put In A Colour Because It Was There And He Liked It Rather Than Because It Was Relevant To The Secheme. The Small Fonda, With A White Inule Against White Walls, Strikes Us As The Best Of The Oil Paintings, But They Are All Well Considered And Refined In Execution, And Arch Of Titus And Study Of Devonshire Fishermen Are Tvo Out Of Several Excellent Water-Colours. The Other Exhibitor Is Mr. Francis William Sargant, Who Carved The Stone Panels For The Oakham School Chapel War Memnorial. Of Hie Works Here The Besti Are Probably The Small Decorative Bronzes, Suci As Girl On Tortoise And Lamia. And The Design, Of Man And Mermaid, In Painted Terra-Cotta.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exlibitioins. The Nejw English Art Club Is Scarcely So Interesting As Usual In Its 22Nd Exhibition, Now Being Held At The Dudley Gallery In Piccadilly. New Men And Women Of Talent Have Been Slow To Come Forward To Take The Place Of Those, Once So Active As Reformers, Who Have Been Adopted. And Silenced, By The Academy. We Miss, Also, Mir. C. E. Shannon, Wvho Has Twice Lately Contributed Portraits So Good As To Excite Much Curiosity Ss To His Nest Step He Sends Nothing, Which Is A Disappointment. Perhaps The Things Which Give Most Pleasure Are The Group Of Smali Drawings, In Chalk Or Water-Colour, Near The Entrance And Among These The Chief Are Three Which Are Not English At All, But An I Vited Cqntribution By The Illustrious German Veteran, Professor Von Mlenzel, To Whom The Catalogue Properly Assig,Ns His Newly-Conferred Title Of Eixcellency. Drawingsby D5Enzel Are So Rarely Seen In England, Or Anyvhere Outside The National Gallery In Berlin, That We Must Welcome The Opportunity Of Studying Even Small Examples Of The Man Who, As Du Maurier Used To Say, Is The Real Founder Of The Modem School Of Book Illustration And Of Black And White Drawing In General. His Three Studies In Blaek Chalk Are A Landscape, A Church Interior, And A Figure, The Laat A Study For The Picture In The Library, Masterly In Conception And In The Thorough Knowledge Of Form Which It Displays. The Best Comphlinent We Can Pay To Mliss E. M. Monsell, The Anthor Of The Little Drawing Called Hair-Brushing - 12, Which Hangs Close By, Is To Say That It Shows Strong Traces Of Menzels Influence, Though This Has Trickled Down Through So Many Channols During The Last.50 Years That The Young Artist Herself Is Doubtless Quite Unconscious Of It. Some Extremely Dexterous Work By Mr. Laurence Housman, A Few Notes By Mr. Brabazon, And A Portrait Group By Miiss L. Stillman Are Noteworthy Among The Oth3R Drawings. Of The Pictures, The Most Striking Is Mr. Tonkss Pastoral Play 65, With Its Clever And Quite Appropriate Suggestionsof Lvatteau. But Wvatteau Would Have Regarded This Not As A Picture, But As The First Rough Indication Of One Before He Sent It Out Into The World He Would Have Finished The Faces, The Hands, The Draperies, With The Most Delicate Accuracy In A Word, He Would Have Painted Like Vatteau, And Not Like A New English Artist, With A Head Full Of The Modern Philosophy Of Short Cuts. Of The Portrait-Painters, Mr. P. W. Steer And Mrw. . W. Russell Send Pictures Before Which One Stands And Says, How -Lever! But Ngt How Charming I Or How Trae! There Are Characteristic Landscapes By Mir. Miark Fisher, Mr. Buxton Knight, And Many Others, Among Which The Two Sent By Mliss Beatrice Bland, Unkindly Skied, Are Among The Most Interesting. But This Lady, Like So Many Of Her Colleagues, Inclines Too Much To The Heresy Of Heavyclouds, Which In Nature Would Infallibly Come Down In Watersponts. For A Few Days, There Are On View At The Goupil Gallery A Nuraber Of Landscapes By The Norwvegian And Parisian Painter Fritz Thaulow, Some Of Whose Pastels We Lately Admired At The Pastel Societys Exhibition. They Are Extremely Clever, And Give A Very True Impression Of The -North In Summer And Wvinter But Their Pattern-High Horizon, Very Little Sky, Compensated By Water With Blue And White Reflexions-Is So Monotonous That After A While One Asks For Something Less Artificial. Close Bv, At Iessrs. P. And D. Colnaghis, In Pall-Mall East, There Is A Small Collection Of The Works Of Mr. D. Y. Cameron, One Of The Chief Members Of The So-Called Glasgow School. As A Painter Mr. Cameron Tries Too Exclusively To Follow Velasauez, Even In His Mannerisms But His Very Aelicate Otchings And Pencil Drawings Show That This Is Not For The Reason Which Prompts So Many Other Followers Of The Ureat Spaniard-Because They Cannot Draw. Lfessrs. Shepherd, At Their Little Gallery In Kingstreet, Have In Their Summer Exhibition A Number Of Old English Pictures, Wvith Some Modern Works. A Portrait Of A Lady By Hoppner Is Brilliant In Painting And Almosttoobrilliantin Colour. There Are Small Works By Constable, Miorland, And J. R. Smith. But The Most Interesting Thing Here Is A Faded Portrait Of James I As A Bov-A Picture With A Genuine Inscription, And In Its Original French Frame With Roy Descosse Faintly Visible Upon It. To Collectors And Students The Most Important Exhibition Of The Week Is That Which Messrs. Aognew Have Arranged In Their Gallery In Old Bond-Street, Containing An Almost, If Not Quits, Complete Collection Of The Old Mezzotint Engravings After Gainshorouh Anld Romney. These, As Is Wvell Knowvn7 Are Much Fewer In The Agtgregate, And Specimens Of Them Are Much Rarer, Than Those After Sir J Oshua. Gainsborough And Romney May Have Been Almost As Fully Employed In Portrait Painting As Reynolds Was-Indeed, No Man Ever Got Through More Work Of This Kind Than Romney Did, Vvho Often Had Five Sitters A Day, And Finished A Portraif In Five Or Sis Sittings-But There Is No Comparison Between The Popularity Of Their Work, As Subjects For Engraving, And That Of Reynolds. There Are Extant Some 700 Prints After Sir Joshua Miessrs. Agnew Can Only Show Us 102 After Romney And 14 After Uainsborough, The Latter Including Many Fancy Subjects. It Is Not Surprising That Sir Joshuas Women Should Ha-Ve Been More Popular Than Those Of Either Of His Rivals, For, Beautiful As Are Romneys Lady Hamilton As Nature, Mrs. Robinson, Miss Woodley, And Others, They Form No Such Unrivalled Gallery As The Lady Bampfylde, The Lady Crosbies, And 20 Or Su More That Might Be Named. And In Translating Gainsboroughs Exquisite Portraits Of Women It Is Undeniable That Tho Engraver Often Found The Task Beyond His Povers. Scarcely One, Except That Of Mr. Elliot And That Of I Madame Baccelli Dancing-The Famous Picture Which Used To Be At Knole-Is Entirely Satisfactory. The Mezzotinter Naturally Preferred The More Generalized Art Of Reynolds And Romney. But In His Rendering Of Gainsboroaughs Men He Often Stucceeded Brilliantly Witness The Sir Harbord Harbord At Norwvich, The Henry Beaufov, The Augustus Etervey, And That Astonishing Pair, The Prince Of Wales And His Friend, Colonel St. Lecger, With Their Horses. With These May Be Compared, Among The Romneys, The Thomas Ord And The Sir Hyde Parker, A Masterpiece By J. Walker, Whose Too Few Mezzotints After Romney Show That He Would Have Ranked With Valentia Green And J. R. Smith If He Had Remained At Work In England. The Engravings After Romney And Gainshorough Seemed To Have Been Taken Off In Very Few I-Npressions At All Events, They Are Now So Rare That, While The Present Craze Endures, Sumas Like 200 Are Quite Commonly Paid For Good Proofs At Auction. This Ought To He Of Good Omen For Our Modem Mezzotinters, The Best Of Whom Are Very Little Inferior To Their Artistic Forefathers.

Author: Null
Title: Swedish Art
Full_text: Swedish Art. Exhibition At Burlington House. The Swedish Art Exhibition, Which Will Open Next Tuesday At Burlington House And Last Till About Febrtuary 15, Will Include More Than 400 Works Of Art 33 Of Which Are Sculptures By About 60 Artists Of The Eighteen-Eighties And Eighteen-Nineties, One Of The Most Brilliant Epochs In The History Of Swedish Art. The Crown Prince Of Sweden Is The Patron Of The Exhibition, And The Swedish Minister In London, Baron Pahnstierna Is Honorary President Of The Committee. Tho Exhibition Bas Been Aranged In Connexion With The Anglo-Swedish Soiety In London, Of Which Lord Burnhamn Is The President. The Organizing Committee, Which Has Directed The Preparations From Stockholmn Is Headed By The Avicee-Pident Of The Swedish Royal Academy Of Arts, Professor Oscar Bjorck, Who Is One Of The Leading Swedish Painters. He Has Been Assisted In The Hanging Of The Pictures By Mr. Sixten Strombom Of The National Museum, Stockholm. The Majority Of The Paintings Have Been Lent From The National Museumnat Stockholm And The Gotlienburg Museum, And Also By Private Collectors, Among Them Prince Eugen, G.R. Thorsten Laurin, And The Thiels Gallery. Among The English Owners Who Have Lent Pictures Are Mrs. Minna Cassel And Mir. Robert Dunthorne. The Exhibition Makes No Claim To Be A Complete Representation Of Swedish Art, And The Limits Of Date Have Not Been Rigidly Observed. Some Of The Exhibitors Are Still In The Forefront Of Living Swedish Art. Not All These Swedish Artists Are Strangers To London. Among Them Is Anders Zorn, Well Known To The British Public As An Eteher Among His Paintings To Be Shown At The Royal Academy Are Some Portraits Of English People. An Arlist Who Will Attract Wide Attention Is The Swedish Painter-Prince Eugen. In The World Of Swedish Painting He Has Struck His Own Note. His Decorative Painting For The New Town Hail In Stockholm Has Received Enthusiastic Praise Both In Sweden And From Forciga Crities Who Have Visited That Building, Which Might Be Described As The Result Of A United Effort Of Leading Aitists In Practically Every Sphere. Fourteen Of Prince Eugens Paintings Will Be Shown At The Exhibition. Other Artists Whose Work Will Be Seen At Burlington House Are Bruno Liljefors, The Animal Painter, And Carl Larsson, The Portrayer Of The Swedish Home And Country Life, And Also Painter Of The Large Frescoes In The Entrance Hall Of The National Museum At Stockholm. An Iulustrated Catalogue Will Be Issued, Containing 32 Reproductions Of Works Exhibted At The Academy. The Catalogue Will Have An Introduction Giving A Short Outline Of The History Of Swedish Art By Dr. Axel Gauffin, Of The National Museum, Stockholm. 31R. Sixten Strombom Has Been Asked To Give One Or Two Lectures At The Royal Academy In Connexion With The Exhibition.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Onexhibtons. Boxing Pictures At The Sporting Gallery. Even To The Person Whose Knowledge Of The History Of The Ring Is Limited To The Names Of Tom Sayers And Daniel Mendoza, The Boxing Exhibition At The Sporting Gallery, 32, King-Street, Covent Garden, Is Interesting To The Enthusiastic Amateur It Should Be A Mine Of Information And Entertainment. Possibly Because The Drama Is In The Sequence Of Events L Rather Than In The Situation At Any Given Moment The Ring Does Not Seem To Have Attracted The Great Artists Of The Pastthough There Is In This Exhibition A Print 28 Of A Sadly Unsporting Bout After Rowlandson At Any Rate, There Is Nothing In Art To Correspond To The References Of Such Writers, As Byron, Borrow, George Meredith, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, Mr. Bernard Shaw, Maurice. Maeterlinck, And Mr. Bohun Lynch-To Run Over Only The First Names That Come To Mind. Between Past And Present In Pictorial Representation The Vexed Question Of Subject Interest In Art Is Very Prettily Illustrated. The Older Artists Concentrated On The Technical Side Of Boxing And The Personalities Of Boxers, Emphasizing Their Points Pretty Much As The Older Artists Of The Turf Emphasized The Points Of Racehorses Modern Artists Go, For The Rnost Part, For The General Impression. Bare Knuckles, By Mr. Alfred Sindall, The Dixie Kid. By Mr. Philip Connard, And A Ringside Impression, By Mr. H. Hope Read, Are All Very Wvell, But It Is Not Until-You Come To The National Sporting Club Series Of Etchings By Mr. George Belcher That You Recover The Peculiar Thrill Of Reality Given By Such Prints As Daniel Mendoza And Richard Humphreys, After C. R. Ryley,.Tom Johnson And Isaac Perrins, After C. Metz, And The Fives Court -Lent By The National Sporting Club-After T. Blake. The Truth Seems To Be-And It Bears Heavily On The Whole Question Of Subject Interest In Art-That If You Plump For Impression You Have To Emphasize The Medium In Order To Make Up For The Corroborative Detail Left Out And It Is This That Gives Bite To The Woodcut A Bout In A Booth, By Mr. Steven Spurrier. L From The Boxiana Point Of View The Centre Of Interest Is Lord Byrons Screen, Covered By The Poet And Gentleman Jackson, Champion Of England, With Portraits And Newspaper Cuttings Relating To Pugilism, Lent By Mr. John Murray. It Bears, Incidentally, An Engraving Of Jackson After The Oil Painting, By B. Marshall, Lent By The National Sporting Club, Hung Beside It And Everything About The Screen Bespeaks A Labour Of Love-The Cuttings Being White-Lined Above And Dark-Lined Below, So That They Appear To Stand Ont In Low Relief Byron Appears Again In A Photograph Of A Print Of Him Boxing With Jackson, Lent By Mr. A. Forbes Sieveking And The Lonsdale Heavy-Weight Belt, Cast Of Tom Sayerss Right Anm, And Gloves Worn By Jimmy Wilde When Boxing Against Pal Moore, 1918, Are Other Objects Of Reverence. Tlhere Is An Interesting Sheet, With Woodcuts In Colour, Of The First Rules Of The Prize Ring, Drawn Up At Broughtons Amphitheatre In 1743, Showing Gloves In Use, Classical Allusions Are Not Neglected, And The Humours Of The Ring Are Pictured By Such Artists As Phil May, Fougasse, Mr. H. M. Bateman, Mr. Bert Thomas, And Mr. Alfred Leete. Nothing, In Short, Is Wanting To Create The Mood Of The Quaker Lady Quoted By Mr. Augustine Birrell. Pity Twas That Ever Corruption Came Amongst Them! She Exclaimed. Amongst Whom ? They Asked Her. The Bruisers Of England, She Firmly Replied. The Greatorex Galleries. Mixed Entertaimnent At The Greatorex Galleries, 14, Gramfto-Street, Begins Vith Etchings Of Winchester, By Mr. Huglh Fisher, Occasionially Jumpy In Values, But Excellenit In Composition And Drawinig, Reachiiig Their Best Hi Tlie Large, Clear, General View Of Wiiichester Cathedral, In Which-As In All Mr. Fishers Work-The Graceful Treatment Of Trees Is To Be Noted. There Lollowv Silver-Points, Mostly Of The Nude Flgure, By Mr. Leonard J. Smith, Owinlg More To The Charm Of The Medium Than To The Style Of Drawing, Which Is Niot More Than Pretty. Thjen There Is A Collection Of Etchings And Dry-Poiits By Various Artists-Wvelcome For Its Emphasis Upon The Comparatively Unfamiliar. Examples Are The Cemetery Wall, By Mr. H. Gordon Warlow Tthe Winding Staircase. Chateau Blois, By Mr. W. Douglas Mlacleod The Falconer, By Mr. H. Harvey And Nant Francon Pass -In Aquatint-By Mr. E. Buckton. La Rochelle, By Mr. Henry Rushbury, And Segovia Bridge, Madrid, By Mr. W. Walcot. Are The Outstanding Things By Acknowledged Masters Of The Art. In Another Room There Are Impressions Of England And Provence, Mostly In Gouache, By Mr. Laurence Bell. These Attract By Their Modest Feeling And Considered Execution, La Lice. Martigues, The Old Sea Wall, Rye, And Sussex Being Three Particularly Good Examples. Picture Frames. The Modern Development Of The Picture Frame Can Be Studied To Advantage At The Galleries Of Mesars. Bourlet, The Fine Art Agents, 17, Nassauistreet, Mortimer-Street, Where There Is On View A Collection Of English, Freneh, And Italian Models. They Are All, Or Nearly All, Reproductions-Though In The Senise Of Free Ihterpretation Rather Than Imitation. The General Principle Followed By Messs. Bourlet Is To Take Hints From Old Examples And Adapt Them To Present-Day Requirements, Keeping The Flavour Of The Original, But Allowing A Wide Margin For Modification In Harmony With The Individual Picture. This Breaking Away From The Victorian Convention, With Its Overelaborate Mouldings And Hard, Bright Gold, Was A Long And Diflcult Business. At First There Were Difficulties With Workmen Over The Substitution Of Freehand Methods Of Decoration For Mechanical Accuracy, And The Toning Of The Gold Leaf By Means Of Applied Colour To Suit The Picture Was Looked Upon As Almost Immoral. Another Difficulty Was Getting The Right Quality Of Gesso For Omamert In Relief A Difficulty Which Was Only Solved By Importiiig Chalk From Bologna Prepared By A Method Which Seems To Have Been In Use Since Thei Days Of Cennino Cennini. This Allows The Detail Of Ornament To Be Applied In Fuu Relief Niith One Stroke Of The Brush, Thus Avoiding The Risk Of Cracking Between Separate Layers. I Altogether, As An Object-Lesson In The Gradual Substitution Of Elasticity For Rigidity In Thel Convention Of The Picture Frame, While Keeping The Flavcur Of Style, The Exlhibition Is Extremely Intercsting. Independent Artists. In The Somewlhat Robust Surroundings Of Messrs. Parsonss Showrooms, 315-317, Oxfordstreet, The Society Of Independent Artists Are Now Holding Their Second Exhibition. What These Artists Arc Independent From-Except In Some Instances From The Humdrum Responsibilities Of The Craft-Is Not Very Clear Since A Society Is A Society, And It Is Difficult To See Why A Member Of This One Is More Independent Than A Member Of, Say, The New English Art Club Or The R.B.A. However, The Collection Of 82 Paintings, Drawings, And Prints Affords Some Entertainment. It Is Most In Aecord With The Commonplace Artistic Virtues In The Market Scencs, Bidingsgate And Stratton Grounds, By Mr. Powys Evans, Who Is Best Known As A Caricaturist And The Circus Scenes.The Jockey Act, In Particular, By Miss Gwen Evans. Landscape, Of A River Under The Rising Moon, By Mr. Chappell The Stylish, Though Rather Over-Modelled, Heads By Miss Clara Klinghoffer, Still Life, By Mr. S. B. Gausden, And The Hotel Biron, Paris,. By Mr. L. Bourgeois-Bourget. Are Other Oil Paintings Which -Admit Dependence Upon The Usual Means-Of Making A Picture, And, For The Vet The Most Profitable Search Will Be Among The Drawings And Eolou-Prints. Geese, By Mr. Urusibara, The Bather, By Mr. Walter J. Phiuips, The Donkey Boy,. By Miss M. A, Royd, Summer Afternoon,. Cataluna, By Mr. Wyndham Tryon, And Roman Wine Warts,, By Miss Mary Hogarth Are Some Lesanlngs, - -

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Illustrations At The Redfern Gallery. Grave And Gay Are Pleasantly Mingled At The Redfern Gallery, 27, Old Bond-Street, Whhere There Are Water-Colours By Four Artists, Including Illustrations To Prosper Merim6Es La Double M6Prise, By Jacquier, The Lady Who Poked Gentle Fun At Shelley In Her Pictures For Ariel. Her Work Recalls The Old Saying That He Laughs Best Who Loves Most, For It Is Quite Evident That These Skits At The Sentimental Atmosphere Of A Period Could Only Have Been Made By Somebody Who Felt Its Charm. They Are Not So Much Illustrations Of Incidents As. Comments Upon The Double Reaction, Sympathetic And Quizzical, To The Story By A Reader Far Enough Removed In Time To Make Use Of Modern Expedients In Design To Enhance The Effect. The Melting Mood Of The House In Descente Dans Une Auberge Is An Instance, And Another Is The Removal Of The Near Side Of The Caleche In Two Of The Pictures, So That You Can Enjoy Its Occupants. True To Their Character Of Embodying The Thoughts Too Deep For Tears, Which Well Up Vith Chuckles From A Perusal Of The Book, These Drawings Are Slightly Indefinite In Execution A Light Pencil Line And Colours Of The Soul As Understood In The Romantic Period Quite Certainly Jacquier Ought To Illustrate Wverther. Of The Other Artists, Mr. A. B. Knappfisher Makes The Strongest Impression With Firmly Designed Illustrations To Oxford Renowned -Rather In The Stvle Of The Old Aquatinters. Mr. A. C. Baileys Watercolours Of Cornwall And Elsewhere Are Somewhat. Erratic, But They Have, Real Originality And Succeed Well In The Suggestion Of Light-Filled Space. Except That They Are A Little Quakerish In Feeling, The Tempera Paintings Of Western Counties By Mfr. H. E. Peart Are Excellent.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions .-M Officers Art Society The Sixth Annual Exhibition Of The Atrmy Officers Art Society, At The Suffolk-Street Galleries-Of Wvhichl The Profits Are Contributed By The Societv To Earl Haigs Fund-Strikes One As Being Imore Professional In The Military Aud Less In The Artistic Sense Than Former Ones Of The Series, And This Is Felt, To Be An Advantage. What We Waant To See Is Not So Mucei The Work Of Artists Who Happen To Be Soldiers, As How Professional Soldiers, Who Happen To Have Artistic Talent, Paint And Drawv-Particularly In The Scenes Of Their Professional Experience. It Is A Large Exhibition, Of A82 Works-20U More Than Last Year-And The Great Majorily Of Them Are Vater-Colours, Which Helps To Explain The General Effect Of Service Conditions, Since Oil Colours Are A Nuisance To Carry About. Possibly Without Reason One Is Struck By The Proportion Of Higher Ranks Among The Exhibitors. Particularly In The First Room The Standard In Water-Colour Is Remarkably Highli Gateway, Purana Kila, Delhi, By Lieutenant R. H. Sams, Old Bridge House, Amibleside. By Major.I. A. Wilkinson, Canal, Hevbridge, By Lieutenant-Colonel C. Connell, Salthouse Marshes, By Major-General Sir A. Scott, And Miarshside, By Captain T. 11. Barnard, Are Only A Few Of The Works That Excite Genuitne Admiration. In The Big Room The Level Is Morc Ordinary, Though The Mountain Landscapes Of Colonel H. R. B. Donne, Alverna. Near Cortina, For A Very Good Examole, Will Always Have Their Romantic Appeal, And Every Now And Then One Comes Upon Eomething Original, Such As The Windrushl, Burford, By Captain J. Knyvett, The Farnm Under The Hlill, Devon. By Brigadier-Genjeral W. R. Ward. Thie Black Mountains, Nvelsh Border, By Brigadier E. M. Jack, St. Martin-In-Tlhefields, By Colonel Sir R. Firth, And Twyford Mill, Essex, By Lieatenant-Colonei F. Tirupp. In Oil The Most Thoroughly Accomplished Work Is . Teddy And The Tiger,, A Child In Blue Sitting On A Skin Rug, By Captain W. L. T. Fisher A Picture As Happy In Design As It Is Articulate In Execution. Of The Excellent Landscapes In Oil By Colonel Sidney Harvest, Skiddavr From Borrowdale Is The Best In Atmospheric Ouality And Entralnce To An Old Fort The Most Stable In Design And Colonel Al. A. Tuite Has Several Good Paintings Of Horses In Landscape-As Captain Adrian Jones Of Big Game. Not The Least Interesting Part Of The Exhibition Is The Collection Of Drawingsincluding Swvift Sketches By General Lord Baden-Powell, And Studies Of Native Types By Colonel J. Gayer Anderson, Lieutenant F. Wilson, And Others. The Old Dudley Though It Is Chiefly On Account Of Its Age That The Old Dudley Art Society, Founded In 1861, Deserves Notice, One Caninot But Admlire Tthe Skill And Tact With Which, Without Loss Of Character, Its 105Th Exhibition At The Alpine Clulb Galleries, Mill-Street, Conduit-Street, Lhas Been Made To Look More Or Less Contemporary. It Is Nmainly A Miatter Of Opein Haniginig Anid A Prevailing Light Key. There Are 136 Works, Of Wbich The Great Muajority Are Water-Colours. Mr. L. Burleiglh Brubl, The President, Seems To Be Getting Over The Too Forcible Tone Contrasts Whichl Marred His Capable Work, And All His Contributions Give Pleasure. The Ebb Tide, Iu Particular, Is A Very Attractive Study Of Iridescent Reflections. Mr. A. Warren Dow Is Another Artist Who Makes The Nmost Of His Talents By Tact In Small Things, And Both St. Albatns, In Violet Silhouette Under T Tsquall, And Sunliglht Behiiid The Curtainis, Witl Flowers In A Lustre Jug, Are Very Charning Watercolours. Etudy Of A Garden Party, Westhill, I. Of W,, By Miss E. M. Lipscomb, Has Light And Movement, Aud The Right Effectof Gaiety, And Other Water-Colours Of Merit Are The Yacht Builders, Ramble, By Mr. J. F. Rendell Sussex Farm, By Mr. John Higgins Bayning Monument, By Miss Beth Amoore Alnd Watermoutlh Harbour, N. Devon, By Miss Catheriie Choamney.. Mr. Clarles Harvey Is The Principal Oil Painter, Happiest In His Decorative Impression Of Nnivu Cove.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition. Mir. Christopher Wood. J The General Impression Made By The I Paintings By Amr. Christopher Wood At Messrs. Arthur Tooths, 155, New Bondstreet, Is That Tfle Artist Goes About The World With A Lively Curiosity And Paints Wvhen He Is Really Stung By The Subject Before Him. One Consequence Is That His I Pictures Contain Rather More Of His Ordinary-And Rather Boyish-Interests Tlha Is Commnor In The Work Of Our Yotunger Artists, Who Are Generally On Guard Against Any Interest That Cannot Be Called Wisthetic, And This Nk-Es For Variety. After All, The World Contains A Number Of Things. 3Ir. Wood, In Short, May Be Called An Ingenuous Artist, With An Attractive Combination Of Originality And Receptiveness, Very Direct In His Methods. His Paintings Of St. Ives, Cornwall, May Surprise Those Who Have Been Brought Up On The Productions Of The Colony There, But There Is More Warrant For Them In The Facts Than Their Oddity Might Suggest. At St. Ives You Have Not Really Come To The Granite, Which Prevails Faither West, And The Rocks Have A Twisty, Gnarled Character, Admirably Brought Out M Clodgy And The Island, St.. Ives. These Physical Facts May Not Seem Relevant To The Discussion Of Painting, But. They Affect The Look Of Things, And Part Of T.He Interest Of Mr. Woods Painting Is Its Unconscious Revehition Of Things That You Happen To Know. Entrance To St. Ives Harbour, With Its Effect Of Bustle, Is Perhaps The Best And Most Concentrated Painting Of The Series, But They All Have The Interest Of Something Seen With A Fresh And Unprejudiced Eye And Set Down With An Eager Hand. The Effect Of Discovery Is Characteristic Of All Mr. Woods Work-The Rather Wicked Colour Of Irises, The Orange And Lemon Of Tiger Lilies, And The Blunt Beauty Of Red Dahlias In Their Brown Pitcher. His Danger, One Would Say, Is Quaintness, But That He Can Rise To Larger Interests Is Shown In The Excellent Painting Of A Woman Alone, In Which Everything Is Subordiniated To The Monumental Impact Of The Shoulders On The Lighted Wall And The Downward Sweep Of The Brown Curtain.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Blake Engravings And Colour Prints. Illiami Blake, Our Greatest Imaginative Artist, And Mi. Tlheodore Roussel, An Artist Of F2Renich Birth, Naturalized And Resident In England, Are The Subjects Of Two Very Interestinig Special Exhibitions In The Exhibition Gallery Of The Departmenit Of Prints Aiid Dlrawinigs At The Britisli Museum. The Works By Blake Include Drawinigs. Engravinggs, And Coljur Prints The Engravings Aniid Prints Have Only Recently Beeni Mlouiited Andc Never Exhibited Before. Tho Engravings Leacloff With What Imuist Have Beell Blakels Earliest Effort. I-E Was Born In 1757 And Ipprenlticed To Basire, The Engraver, In 1771, -Nd Joseph Of Arimathea Among The Rocks F Albion Is Dated 1773. Apart From Its Evidenee Of Precocity, The Engraving Lhas Other Interests. The Figure Of Jcseph Is Takeni Fronm The V Atican Crucifixion, Bv M1Ichelangelo, The Artist Who Xvas To Domninatc Blk3Es Imaginlationl Throughout His Career, Aiicn The Inscriptioni Not Only Suggests That Blake Had Heard Of Thc Coninexion Of ,Josephi With Clastonbury, Biut Also That, At The Age Of 1, Lhe Lhad Vicws About England. Or .Albion, As He Already Called It. Tthis Is One Of The Gothic Artists Who Built The Catliedrals In -What Wc Call The Dark Ages, Wandering About In Sheepskins And Goatskins, Of Wxhom The Wvorld Was Not Worthy, Such Were The Christians In All Ages. Aamong Thc Otlei- Engravings Are The Two Superbl Plates Of Job And Ezekiel, For Wvhich Mr. Craham Robertsoni Has The Sepia Drawings, A Completc Set Of Proofs Of The Illustrations To The Book Of Job, And Suchi Minor Works As Three Illustratioons For Alary Wvollstonecrafts Originial Storics Fronm Real Life, Showviing Blakes Imiaginiationi At Wvork On Everyday Themes, And Eight Proofs Of Woodeuts To Thornltonis Pastorals Of Virgil, Nrhlieh Recall Tllc Association Vith Blake Of Calvert And Pailmier. The Series Of Engravings Ends With Blakes Last Work, Eorge Cunmberlands Miessage Card, Of 1827. A Great Rarity Is Blakes Only Lithograplh. Job In Prosperity, Published In 1807 In A Series Of Polyautography. For Slieer Charnm There Is Nothinig To Cqual The Colour Prints-Illustrations To Thie First Book Of Urizen, The Book Of Thel, The Marriage Of Heaven And Hell, And Vision Of The Daughters Of Albion -Printed In A Monotype Process Of Blakes Own Invention. Six Of The Hundred Dant6 Water-Colours Are Shown, And Proofs Of The Only Seven Which Were Engraved. Mr. Theodore Roussel Is Known To The General Public Only By His Occasional Contributions To The Exhibition Of The Society Of Graver-Printers In Colour, Of Whiclh Lhe Is President. Influenced By Whistler In Hiis Earlier Etchings-Mostly Chelsea Subjects And Portraits-Lie Is Famotus Amionig Contemiiporary Artists For His Researches Inito Engraving And Printing Metlhods And His Fastidious Care For Quality. Most Of Iiis Works Pass Through Niianiy States, And The Final Impression Of One Of Iiis Colour Prints, Such As Davn, Represents More Thani A Dozen Printings. To Quote Hiis Owii Words, The Motive Of The Graver-Printer . . . Is To Realize In A Print An Original Composition In Colour Conecived In Llis Niind As-A Print, And Depending For Its Beauty Exclusively On The Means To Be Used In And For Printing. The Exhibition Gives A Practically Comlplete Representation Of Mr. Roussels Workl Betveen 1888 And 1919. Also Hunig In The Gallery Are Two Piranesi-Like Mezzotints Of Prisons, By The Frereli Engraver Blondel. And Original Etchings By Bouclher And Fragonard, Presented By The National Art-Collections Fund. Wl Himsicalities. Under The General Title Of Desire And Destiny There Are At Walkers Galleries, 118, New Bond-Street. A Number Of Wvatercoloni- Drawings By Mr.V W. H. Walker Whiclh Are In Fact W-Himsicalities. Nobody Else Is Working In Quite The Samre Vein. And T4R. Walker Has A Genuine Turn For The Conceit. His Drawing, Though Not Distinguished, Is Quite Adequate For The Scale On Which He Works, His Colour Is Generally Pretty And Sometimes Charming, He Has A Feeling For Quality And His Invention Never Fails. The Game Of Love, Whicli He Treats Witlh Ironical Tenderness, Provides Him With Most Of His Subjects. The Happiest In Invention-Besides Giving Him An Opportunity For The Delicate Still-Life Paintinig In Whieh He Excelsis The Lost Property Office, With Father Time Restorinig To A Very Modlem Damsel Her Lost Love Over The Counter With A Genial Air Of Dont Be So Careless Again. Round The Shelves Of The Oflice Are Stacked, In Times Keeping, Lost Hopes, Illusions, Hearts, Opportunities, Youth. Sleep, Faith, Consciences, And So On And We Note That Time Keeps Old Flames In Cold Storage, And That He Will Receive No Tips. Some Of The Clrawings, Such As Tihe Apple Harvest And Pink Curtains And Matuve Stockings, Are None The Worse For Being Slightly Luscious It Is All In Tlle Vein And A Miothers Meeting, Of Mice With Embarrassing Litters Who Are Being Advised By A Frog Wise-Woman From A Volume Bearing The Naxne -Of A Competent Authoritv, Is Fair Comment. Whimsical Walker, As He Must Be Called, Does Not Pretend To Play Upon The Larger Enmotions, But He Wins And Merits A Chuckle Or A Sigh. A Versatile Artist. In A Chelsea Studio At 1., Wvellingtonstreet, Flood-Street, Kings-Road, Converted From A Hayloft And Mainly Fuirnished By The Artist Himself, There Are To Be Seen From 3 To 7 Daily Some Paintings, Water-Colours, Pastels And Etchings Which Have At Least The Merits Of Originality And Suggestiveness. The Artist Is Mlr. F. H. Haagensen, English-Born But Evidently Owina Something To Norwegian Extraction In His Capacity For Handling Wood. His Etching-Press, For Example, Which He Built Himself, Wo.Ld Pass For A Professional Construction. Mr. Haagensen Is Clearly The Kind Of Artist Who Puts Mood Before Everything-Mood And A Medium. He Is, On The Whole, Happiest In Water-Colour, Which He Handles Very Broadly, Letting The Design Happen Out Of The Wasti Witlh Excellent Effect In Rain, Two Studies Of Seaweed Gatherers, And Charging Assyrions. The Oil Paintings Lack Somewiat In Organization, But They Are Goodiii Quality And Fuill Of The Emotional- Atmosphere Intended-Particularly The Desert -- And The Etchings Have Imagination And Freedom In Execution. Some Pastel Drawings Of Chelsea Subjects, By Miss A. M. Bussell,. Slhow Promise. Pittsburg Awards. The Twenty-Tlhird International Exhibition Of Modern Paintings At The Carnegie Institute Of Pittsburg, 1U.S.A., Consisting Of About 300 Paintings By The Best Artists Of- Practically A-Il The Countries Of Europe And About 150 Paintings By American Artists, Was Opened On April 24. Previous To The Opening A Jury Of Award, Upoii Which England Was Represented By Mr. Alfred J. Munnings, A.R.A., Disposed Of The Following Honours-First Medal 1,500, Mr. Augustus John, A.R,A. England Second Tnedal 1,000, Mr. Giovanni Romagnoli Italy Third Medal, 500, Mr. Garber America First Hon. Mention, Mr. Othon Friez France Second Bion. Mention, ?Mr, Ambrose Macevoy England Third-Hon.- Mention, Mr. Vincenza Bones Czechoslovakia Fourth Hon. Mention, Mr., Savey Soria Russia.-

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Pictures Of Poland. Different As They Are In Style And Mood, The 1 Paintings In Oil And Water-Colour By The Polish Artist Maurice Minlkowski, And The Crayon Drawings By The Ulster Artist Mt. William Conor, At The Galleries Of 3Lr. Godfrey Phillips 44, Duke-Street, St. Jamness, Have It In Co,Rrion That They Deal With What Is Conveniently Called Life. Both Artists Are Competent, But They Are More Interested In Their Fellowcreaitures -Than In Pictur6-Making As An End In Itself. There, However, The Resetablance Endsfor Minkowski Deals Rather Heavily In Method With The Victimus Of War And Revolution In His Native Country, While Mr. Conor Deals Lightly In Method With The Hard-Bitten But Eminently Cheerful Life Of The Streets Of Belfast. Though They Are Not In The Least Propagandist, The Plctdres Of- Minkowski Are Very Difficult To See As Pictures, Because The Human Element Is So Strong In Them. Representiag Such Subjects As The Refugees, Orphans, The Bread Queue, And, Tramping, They Are Painted Not As By The Detached Observer, Or By One With A Feeling For Drama, But As If The Artist Shared The Experiences, They Are Almbst Too Quiet To Be Called Harrowing, The Prevailing Mooa Being One Of Dazed Hopelessness-As Expressed In The Title Whither P The Most Striking General Effect Is Tbat Of Cotnplete Silence. It Is Pertinent To Say That Alinkowski, Who Was Born At Warsaw In 1881, Is A Deaf Mute, And This, No Doubt-Apart From His Unmistakable Sympathy With The Poor And Suffering-Has Tnfluenced His Attitude, Which Is One Of Acceptaiice Rather Than Protest. There Is Not A Single Hint In Any Of The Pictures Of Anybody To Blame. As An Artist Minkowski Has An Unobtrusive Skill In Grouping, He Draws Well Enough, His Colour, Though Naturally Sober, Is Not Unpleasin8, And Technically He Is Very Accomplished-Particularly In Watercolour. He Is Most Interesting Pictorially When The Character Of Costume Has Dictated An Artangement That Can Be Called Decorative -As In Praying Women He Is A Jew And Otphans. One Concludes Finally That The Freedom Of His Work From Theatrical Or Sentimental Appeal Is Due To Artistic Quatlities-Though They Would Be Difficult To Deflne. Vworking In Coloured Crayons In A Method Of His Own-Producing An Effect Very Much Like Lithography-Mr. Conor Gives The Impression Of Xaving Erioyed Eveiy Moment, Humanly Anatechnically. Hlis Drawings-Of Which The Staple Material Is The Street Corner-Are Full Of Light And Movemnent, And, Except Tbat Occasionally A Head Is Prettifled, They Appear To Be Very True In Aharacter. Mothers With Their Babies, Gossips, . Market Women, Shipyard Workers, And Kelp Gatherers Are Somne Of The Subjects, And Thev Are Drawn With An Attractive Freedom And Slightness.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Mr. P. A. De Lxszl6. Every Kind Of Art Has Its Own Convention, And To Complain That The Portraits By Mr. P. A. De Laszl6 At The French Gallery, 120, Pall Mall, Lack Depth And Subtlety Would Be Like Complaining That You Did Not Get A Heart-To-Heart Talk With Your Hostess At A Social Function. It Is The Public Rather Than The Private Appearance Of His Subjects That Mr. De 1Asz16 Presents, And He Must Be Judged Accord. Ingly. On His Own Lines, As A Fashionable Portrait Painter, He Is Not Without His Defects. He Has A Remarkable Gift For Flling A Canvas Easily, But For Permanent Satisfaction His Pictures Would Gain By A More Architectural I311Ing-Not With Architectural Features But With A More Stable System Of Horizontals And Verticals. Too Mnany Of His Larger Compositions- His Grace The Lord Archibishop Of Canterbury Is The Worst Example, But It Vexes Also In The Marquess Of Reading -Have What May Be Called A Diagonal Drift, As If The Artist Were Detetmined At All Costs To Keep Things Moving. His Colour, Too, Would Lose Nothing In Bravery If It Were Truer In Values. For Lack Of Attention To This Rather Than From Defective Construction The Figure Of His Majesty The King Of Spain Looks Incoherent Under A Well-Painted Head, And There Are Several Instanes In Tne Exhibition In Which The Ribbon Of An Order Jumps Out Of The Context With Disturbing Effect. Time May Do Something To Remedy This, But As Painted Mr. De Laszl6S Work Is More Pleasing When It Depends Upon Relations Of Tone And Not Colour Amadame La Duchesse Dltrsel, For A Good Example. What Really Commends Itself In The Work Of Mr. De Lasz16 Is His Wholehearted Enjoyment Of The Social Scene. There Is No Suggestion That He Comes To It By Anything But Positive Preference, And That In Itself Is Enough To Aecount For His Popularity. He Fulfils On Canvas -With Unfailing Gusto And Chic What People Aim At In Their Public Appearances, And He Gives To It Just The Slight Foreign Acecent Which Pleases A People Naturally Reserved. H.R.H. The Princess Beatrice Is One Of The Best Heads In The Exhibition. Her Grace The Duchess Of Portland Pleases By The Aptness Of The Placing On The Unprimed Canvas, The Accent Of The Head, And The Hang Of The Veil And Pearls And Among The More Successful Of The Other Portraits Are H.R.H. The Duchess Of York, The Marquess Of Reading, H.R.H. The Prince Of Asturias, And Miss Dorothy Carnegie. From The Point Of View Of Distinguished Personalities, The Special Feature Of The Exhibition Is The Series Of Spanish Royal Portraits. Drypoints Of The East. Mr. Charles W. Cains Exhibition Of Drypoints, At The Greatorex Galleries, 14, Graftonstreet, Bond-Street, Consists For The Most Part Of Topographical Etchings, In Which Either The Picturesque And Exotic Scenery Of Burma Or Mesopotamia Or Incidents Of Native Life Are Intended To Be The Most Immediate Concern Of The Spectator. Thus. The Artist Is Working Under Difficulties, For He Has To Subordinate Picturesque Fragments If He Wishes To Make A Self-Centred Design, And He May Not Do This Lest These Fragments Seem No Longer Picturesque But Merely Elements Which Are Cold And Unneaning Except When They Are Combined In A Particular Wav. And, Moreover, To Make A Design Out Of Such Subjects, Mr. Cain Would Have Had To Combine A Series Of Objects Of Which Any Artist Except A Vigorous Romantic Like Delacroix Might Well Have Been Frightened. In Fact, In Any Other Medium But Etching Mr. Cains Problem Would Have Been Insoluble. But Etching Is Particularly Suitable For Such Illustration As This. Mr. Cain Has Mastered His Medium And Can Make It Do For Him A Great Deal Which In Painting Only A Pure Painter Could Have Done. The Picturesque Fragments May Remain Picturesque And Not An Integral Part Of A Design, But The Medium, Neverthieless, Asserts Itself Naturally. As Would Not Happen In Painting, And Thus Mr. Cains Drvpoints Have An Air Of Being Works Of Art, Whiclh, Perhaps, They Do Not Really Deserve. This Self-Assertion Of The Medium Is Particularly Fortunate In Mr. Cains Darker And More Elaborate Pr Ints. Sucl As Indian Silversmith And Daughters Of Israel.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Jankel Adler Mr. Jankel Adler, A Polish Artist Who Has Worked For A Considerable Time Both In Germany And In Paris, Shows His Most Recent Paintings, Executed In London During The Last Three Years, At The Lefevre Gallery. These Are Overwhelmirigly Under The Influence Or Picasso, With Some Reminiscences Of Klee, And It Is Therefore Only In His Colour, And In The Concoction Of Very Elaborate And Varied Surfaces Of Paint That The Painter Is Able To Give Expression To His Own Temperament. He Is Certainly An Interesting And Original Colourist. And His Handling Of Paint Shows Efficient If Occasionally Perverse Craftsmanship. Wi,Liam Etty At The Adams Gallery, 92, New Bond Street, There Is A Good Collection Of Paintings By William Etty, Mostly Highly Characteristic Nudes. There Is Nothing Here To Equal The Very Best Of His Early Work, But As Most Of These Paintings,Are Studies Rather Than Finished Compositions There Is Enough Lo Show What A Great Painter He Might Have Become If He Had Not Been Obliged To Cater For The Overwhelming Sentimentality Into Which The Earlier Romanticism Of The Nineteenth Century Declined.

Author: Null
Title: Art Treasures
Full_text: Art Treasures. E Exhibition Opened In London. An Appeal To English Collectors. The Exhibition Of Art Treasures At. The Grafton Galleries, Grafton-Street, W., Which Has Been Organized By The British Antique Dealers Association, Was Formally Opened Yesterday By Lord Lee Of Farehar. A Notice Of - The Exhibition Appeared In The Times Yesterday. Mr. Raneis Mallett, President Of The Association, Presided At The Opening Ceremony And Said That It Was Fitting That The Giver Of Chequers, A House Of Many Treasures, To The Prime Ministers Of England Should Open Their Exhibition. Loan Lee Of Fameham, Before Declaring The Exhibition Open, Said That In A Few Scattered Quarters He Had Heard Adverse Criticisms Both Of The Objects Of The Exhibition And Of His Action In Opening It. There Were Some Zealous People Who Said That The Result Would Be To Nmunish Still Further The Number Of Our Dwindling National Treasures That Soon There Would Be Nothing Left In The Country That Our Heritage Would Be Dispersed For Vulgar Cash, Usualy In The Form Of Dollars And That They Were Engaged In An Unpatriotic Enterprise. Lhe Truth Was Absolutely The Reverse. If The British Public Really Cared For These Beautiful Things, And If They Would Only Take Advantage Of That Absolutely Unique Opportunity Which Was Now Being Offered To Them, The Best Of The Treasures Would Be, Or Should Be, Retained In This Country. That Was The Object Of The Promoters Of The Exhibition. In Any Case, The Criticism Was Somewbat Futile. Miost Of These Treasures Were Not Private Possessions. Some Were From The Private Collections Of Dealers, And Were Not For Sale, But The Bulk Of Them Probably Were In The Market. They Were Dealers Stock, And As Such They Were Liable To Be Sold To Whoever Came Forward To Purchase Them. With The Possible Exception Of Paintings, Not Represented There, They Represented The Selected Cream Or The Stock In The Trade To-Day. The English Collectors Had Never Had Such An Opportunity Before. Generauy Speaking, They Had Very Littia Ides, As To What Was Actually In The Market. As A Class The English Collectors Were Inclined To Be Unenterprisiig, Timid, Even Shy, In Their Search For The Things They Would Like. He Had Often Suggested To His Picture-Selling Friends That They Should Occasionally-Or Even Pehmanently-Have In Their Own Premises A Smal Exhibition-Of Their Pictures, So That A Purchaser Might Inspect Them Quietly By Himself, Instead Of Having To Be Led Into An Inner Sanctum Where Pictures Were Brought Forward One By One And Could Only Be Seen Under The Watchful Eye Of The Vendor Himself. That Wac Very Embarrasing For The Ordinary Picture Collector. He Congratulated The Promoters Of The Exhibition On The Great Taste And Skiu With Which The Objects Had Been Arranged And Displayed. It Was To Hiin The Niost Exciting Exhibition He Had Ever Attended. With Comparatively Few Eaceptions, There Was Nothing There Which Tfhe Enterprising Collector, With Means And The Necessary Quickness Of Decision, Would Not Like To Add To His Collection. He Had No Doubt That The Best Things Would Go Quickly, And He Trembled To Think What Would Happen If They Got A Message From Mr. Ford, Who Was Now In This Country, Saying That He Would Buy Tie Lot. On The Whole The Prices In England For Such Treasures Were Lower Than On The Continent But There Was The Curious Phenomenon That Englishmen Went Abroad For An Expensive Holiday, Visited Foreign Dealers, And Made The Most Gullible And Unfortunate Purchases At Much Higher Prices, Feeling At The Same Time That They Had Done Rather A Smart Thing. His Advice To Collectors Was To Take Their Courage In Both Hands And Buy What They Liked Themselves-Not What They Were Told To Like-Provided That The Quality Was Right. He Recalled A Visit He Paid To Mr. Pierpont Morgans House In Princes-Gate Many Years Ago. Mr. Pierpont Morgan Pointed To A Little Picture Of A Dutch Girl, And Said That Was The Thing He Liked Best In His Whole Collection, For The Reason That He Had Chosen It Hinself. In A Reference To The Association, He Said It Was A Guild In The Best Sense Of The Word, And It Was Also A Philanthropic Body Concerned With The Care Of Those Of The Trade Whai Might Be In Misfortune. It Was A Great Satisfaction To Know That While One-Half Of The Proceeds Of The. Exhibition Would. Go To The Associations Benevolent Fund The Other Half, Would Be Given To The National Art Collections Fund And Would Thus Be Available For The Purchase Of Further Art Treasures For The, Nation. Cheers. Among Those Present Were - King Manoel. Lord Salisbury. Sir Wisuhm Plender. Sir Charles Allom. Sir William Burrell. Sir Charles Holmes. Sir Montague Barlow. Mr. H. Cuthbertson. Mr. Ciifford Smith. And Mlr. H. Oppenheim. Mr. Henry Ford Visited The Exhibition. He Arrived Immediately After The Opening Ceremony.
