Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. I Englis.H Water-Colours. The Third Annual Exhibition Of Watercolours By Tumer And Other Masters Of The English School At The Cotswold Gallery, 59, Frith-Street. Soho, Represents What May Be Called The More Serious Development Of The Art, With The Emphasis Upon Drawing And A Comparative Limitation Of Colour. There Are 47 Drawings, Including Eight By Turner, And These Last -Though Three Of Them Are Late-Are Of A Kind To Relate Him To, Rather Thanx Distinguish Him From, The School. That Is To Say, The Lovely Colour Of Lake Of Lucerne-Morning, Of 1842. And Geneva From The Wvest, Of 1836, Suggests A Flowering Of The Effort Represented By The Other Works Rather Than An Effort Of A New Kind. The Lucerne Drawing, A Miracle Of Space Delimitation By Slight Means, Made Whon Turner Was Nearly 70, Is Hung Next To Mouth Of The Avon, Near Bristol, Made When He Was 17 And Though There Is A Lifetime Of Technical Accomplishment Between Them. There Is Felt In The Early Drawing That Grasp Of The Conditions As A Whole Which Is So Lightly Held In The Late One. Thev Represent The Student And The Master Of Lthe Problem Involved. Another Very Interesting Turner Is London And Westininster, From The Top Of Air. Walter Fawkess House, 45, Grosvenor-Place Precise And Yet Atmospheric, Kept Quiet In Colour As Becomes Its Topographical Intention. The Collection As A Wvhole Extends Our Knowledge Of The School Rather Than Insists Upon The Familiar. There Are Three Dravings By Alexander Cozens, Including A Massive Composi.Tion Of The Old Oak, Gripping The Rock, And The Harbour. One Of His Very Few Coloured Drawings, In Delicate Hues Of Green. Blue, And Lilac. Entranice To The Tyrol, Representing A Castle On A Wooded Bill, And Exceptionally Full In Tone Through Good Preservation, Is One Of The Drawings Made By John Robert Cozens For William Beckford. Other Drawiings Of Particular Note In A Collection Whichl Is Interesting And Informing Throughout Are A Bealltiflulv Balanceci S.E. Aspect Of The Church At Odell, Bedfordshire, By Thomas Heame. Identified By An Engraving A Solid Interior Of A Church, Unidentified, By An Artist Unknown A Little Masterpiece I Of Simplicity, The. Mill Stream, By V John Varley And Two Classical Compositions Of Girls, Welsh And Scotch, At A Well, By Joshua Cristall. Harry Fijrniss. The Exuberant Art Of The Iste Mr. Harry Furniss Can Be Studied To Advantage In A Memorial Exhibition Of His Drawings At The Galleries Of The Fine Art Society. 148, New Bond-Street. To The Nunmber Of 142, Thev Cover The Full Range Of His Activities, As Political And Puneh Cartoonist, Illustrator Of Dickens, Thackeray, And Lewis Carroll, Csuicaturist And Satirist Of Modern Society. Mr. Furmiss Had A Genius For Getting Things Done, Which Went A Long Wav To Rake Up For His Lack Of Subtlety In Feeling And Refinement In Style. As A Draughtsman He Was Forcible And Fluent Rather Than Expressive Or Precise, And He Always Drew At The Top Of His Voice. His Illustrations To Dickens And Thackeray Cannot Be Said To Adorn Their Pages,- But It Is Quite Likely That His Over-Emphasis Of El-Aracter And Situation Brought The Stories Home To Many People Whose Imagination Did Not Respond To The Vriters Themselves. To The Writers Mr. Furnss Acted As A Sort Of Showman. For Some Reasons This Exhibition Is Almest Disconcertingly Interesting. Thus, If The Contemporary Moralist Wanted Documentary Evidence Of The Spirit That Originated The Word Mnicking He Coald Not Find It Better Than In The Cartoon Entitled Ladysmith. M3Arch, 1900. As A Satirist Of Modern Society Mr. Furniss Was Too Rhetorical To Get Home, And The Drawings With That Intention Suggest The Presentation Of The Seener And Situations By Barnstorming Actors Rather Than Anyting In Tul Life. But Mr. Furniss Was Perfectly Honest In His Point Of View, And Enthusiastic In Its Expression, And, Taking His Range And Fertilty Into Awcount, He Must, Be Regarded As A Formidable Figure In The History Of English Humorous Art.

Author: Null
Title: Exhibition Of The New Watercolour Society
Full_text: Exhibition Of, Thb. Aej Wtveb- Coloub Sooiety. Alike In Prices, Dimensions, And Subjects, The Works Of Our Water-Colour Exhibitors, Whether Of The Od Society Or The New, Are Peculiarly Adapted To The Means, Houses, And Tastes Of That Large Portion Of Our Cultivated Classes Who Have Neither Money To Buy, Room To Accommodate, Nor Power. To Appreciate The Productions Of A More Ambitions Form Of Art. Appealing As They Do To The Most Widespread And Least Exacting Kind Of Taste, We Have No Right To Complain That There Is Little To Be Found In Them Of Ideal A-In, Or Even Highly Elaborated Representation Of Outwardcobjects. Toinsiston Morevariety, Moredepthof Insight,Moreeffort To Grasp The Grander Moods And Rarer Moments Of Earth, Sea, And Sky, More Patient And Loving Labour, Would Be To Forget The Conditions, Under Which These Drawings Are Produced, The Purchasers They Attract, The Prices They Command. The Artists Who Supply These Galleries Are Also The Teachers Of Many Who Frequent Them. There Is A Peculiar Familiarity Among The Visitors With The Style And Subject Of Every Master. They Would Be Disappointed Rather If Bennett Were To Leave His Oaks, Fern-Brakes, And Pantain-Beds Mkewen, His Welsh Rivers, Boulders, And Peatstained Rapids Whymper, His Surrey Commons, And Marl Banks, Or Reedy Reaches Of Upper Thames Cooke, His Cornish Coves, And North Devon River Mouths Vacher, His Sun-Flushed Mountain Ranges, And Purple Levels Of Roman Campagna Or Sicilian Pain Henry Warren, His Arabs And Camels Louis Haghe, His Belgian Guild-Halls And Guard-Rooms Rowbotliam, His Blue Lakes, And White Sails, And Foreground Bits Of Pergola Mrs. Miargetts, Her Fruit, And Mrs. Harrison, Her Flowers, For Fresher Scenes And Subjects Less Hackneyed. In Short, There Are No Exhibitions In London The Contributors To Which Are So Hopelessly In The Iut As Those Of Our Two Water-Colour Societies, And None, Therefore, From Which It Is So Difflcult To Carry Away A New Impression Or Fresh Matter For Annual Criticism Or Comment. What Last Years Exhibition Was This Years Is, And Next Years Is Like To Be. E Se Ino New Talents Growing Up To Push The Old Ones From The Walls-No Daring Pre-Raffaelites Of Water-Colour, Defying Ouitworn Conventionalism-No Aspiring Geniuses, Bent On Throwing Into This Facile And Fascinating Branch Of Design The Elevation Of Earnestness, Or Even The Shock Of Eccentricity. Until Some Man Shall Arise With The Determination To Show That A Water-Colour Drawing May Do Something More Than Please The Eye And Prettily Ornament A Draw-Ing-Room-Some One Who Shall Dare To Attempt To Turn Beauty Of Form, And Depth, And Subtlety Of Expression To The Same Account As W. Hunt Has Turned The Homely Truth Of Everyday Faces, And The Features That Belong To Ignoble Needs Or Ludicrous Incidents -We Must Be Content, Year After Year, To Tell The Public, What The Public Needs Not Be Told, That Its Old Favourites In Pall-Mallare Doing This Year The Same Sort Of Thing They Have Been Doing For The Last 20 Years, With Much The Same Average Of Skill And Mastery. Thjo New Water-Colour Society Has No Painter Of Faces, Fruit, And Flowers Like W. Hunt No Great Master Of Landscape, Within A Certain Range, Like David Cox No Consummate Sovereign Of Manipulation And Technical Composition Like Harding No Patient And Microscopic Delineator Like John Lewis. But It Has Stil Its Lewis Haghe, Unrivalled For Skilful Combination Of The In And Oat Door Burgher Life Of The 17Th Century, With The Civic And Ecclesiastical Architecture In Which It Was Set, And Who This Year Contributes Five Drawings-The Drinking Scng, A Party Of Belgian Burgher Gaardsmen Carousing In Their Guiardroom 64 The Spy, A Villanous-Looking Rascal, Brought In Custody Of A Couple Of Archers Before The Prince-Bishop Of Saltzburg In A Chamber Of His Castle 85 The Drill, Soldiers Amusing Themselves With A Poodle, Planted Gravely, Stick Inpaw, In The Midst Of Them 172 The Transept Of The Church Of St. Mark At Venice, With The Sun Glowing From The Golden Mosaic Ground Of Dome And Waggon-Roof, And On The Marble Of Wall And Pavement, And-To Balance This Upper Splendour-A Presentation By Carmagno7.A Of The Standard Of The Republic To The Doge After The Victory Of Macalo 195, And One Of The Side Screens Of The Same Church 214. In Former Years This Artist Has Exhibited Larger And More Ambitions Works, But These Have His Characteristic Merits Of Skilful Arrangement, Good Colour, Brilliant Daylight, And Correct Drawing Both Of Figures And Architecture. Mr. H. Warren Is, As Usual, True To The East, Which He Has Never, We Believe, Visited, Though He So Continually Resorts To It For Subjects. In Costume And Accessories Those Who Inow The Nile And The Desert Assert That He Is Correct But We Are Not Sure That This Truth Extends To The General Colour And Tone Of His Drawings. His Last Work 157 This Year Seemed To Us The Most Impressive. It Represents An Arab Coming Down To Water His Camel In The Nile By Moonlight. His Large Pictulre, The Song Of The Georgian Mfaiden, From Mioores Lig,Ht Of The Harenm 182 Is A Daring Attempt To Combine The Utmost Splendour Of, Colour With Thle Most Minute Elaboration Of Eastern Tissues And Patterns. Warren Seems In This Work To Beaiming At A Competition With John Lewis But, Painstaking And Gorgeous As His Drawing Is, It Misses The Delicacy And Refinement Of Lewis, And Rather Dazzles Than Satisfies The Eye. Above All, It Is Defective In Aerial Tone, Andthere Is Nothing Inthe Forms Or Composition To Make Up For This Defect. Still It Is The Work At Once Of Greatest Labour And Of Highest Aim, In Its Sensual Way, That We Remember To Liave Seen From Mr. Warrenshand. Mr. E. Warren-The Son Of The President-Is As Determinedly English As His Father Is Eastern, And His Large Drawing Of A Beech In The Forest Of Dean 207 Is By Very Far The Completest Piece Of Work In The Gallery. The Rounded Stem And Arms Of The Noble Tree, Wvith All Its Accidents Of Moss, Stain, And Lichen, Sunfleck And Shadow, The Multitudinous Leafage, With Peeps Of Blue Sky Seen Through, The Thick Carpet Of Last Years Russet Leaves That Strew The Ground. Are Rendered With Marvellously Patient And Successful Labour. Mr. Warren Has Evidentlycalledthe Photographtohisaidas Well Asnature, And With A Result, As It Seems To Us, Difficultto Surpass In Its Accuracy Of Realization. Neither Of His Other Drawings, The Road By The Mill Stream 32 And The Pleasure Party 170, Is At All As Satisfactory As This Noble Study Of A Beech Tree. Yet There Are Parts Of The Former, Especially The Bridge In The Lefthand Corner Of The Foreground, And The Path Winding Upward From It Under The Trees, Which Are So Comapletely Carried Out As To Render Us Very Intolerant Of The Splotch Of Red Spots, Intended, Doubtless, For Poppies, And The Bird, -With A Poppy-Red Breast, On The Hand-Rail Of The Bridge, And The Ill-Drawn Water Of The Stream. Mr. Benmett Is Completely Himself This Year. We Need Say No More To Those Who Know And Love The Russet And Yellowing Greens Of This Painter, Who Seems To Have Stopped At A Point Very Far Short Of What His Earlier Works Promised. His Drawings Seem To Us This Year To Have Even Less Daylight Than Usual, Though There Is A Beautiful Effect Of Breaking Sunshine On The Hills Beyond The Lake In The Middle Distance Of His Glengarifi 10. Of All Of Them, We Should Be Inclined To Select One Of The Least Pretentious As The Most Satisfactory, A View Near Streatham On A Fine Miorning 47, Which Has Most Of That Sunlight Of Which The Painter Is So Muceh Too Sparing. As An Example Of Failure In Rendering Light, And That In A Subject Where Light, Was All In All For The Trnthful Effect Of The Drawing, We May Point To His Glen Nevis 2913, In Which He Has Aimed At Giving The Glory Of Sunset Upon Seotch Firs-Than Which Nothing In Nature Canbe More Magical In The Drawing All Splendour Is Lost From The Laek Of Contrast Between The Busnished Copper Of The Limbs Where The Sunlight Sirikes Them, And The Solemn Green And Bronze Of The Unlighted Leaf-Layers And Lrauceles. Mir. Mlhymper Is One Of The Most Facile And In- I Dustrions Workmen In The Society, And His Ma, I Dia,Wigs Of Urtey Commons And High-Banhl-Ix Lanes, Crowned -With Park-Palings, Have An Uuma. T3Keable Look Of Outdoor Truth, And A Freshness Eoai Hi Speaks My Of Them Actual Studies Madj. On The Spot, And Not Spoilt By Studio Cokin1G. Bpesides, Mwr. Whymper Has This Year Anual1Y Had The Courage To Venture On Aa Familim. Subject, ..And Has Thereby Suceeded In Producing One Of The Most Plosing Dra43,G,Ersin Tbe Roo , The Nmnof.Thb Sea Fowl-D E 1Ass Itoch, Early Su Imersmorning. The Iteoaous Rock Rises In The Very Centre Of The Drawir., From A Saooth Green Sea, Under Soft Wreaths, Of Gray Cloud, Its Base Atill Swathed In Trailrtg Volumes Oa Morning Mist., While Fr9M It Clan- Up Cl Ouds Of Un2Nutnbered Sea Fowl, Here Dark O Gainst The Pearly Sky, There White Against The, 6Rk Bluff Tbat Ri3 Betwiur Coud And Shadow-Inore Care In The Colour And Form Of This Shadow Would Have Majle Of This An Alm13T Perfert Drawing. It Has, In A High Degree, Wlat Mir.Winympers Drawings Are Apt To Want-And Wilat Is, Indeed, One Of The Besetting -Vants Of Watercolour Art At Present-Decacy. For Examples Of T7Is, One Of The Supreme Necessiti-S Of All Tut!Ifal Representation, We Must Still Refer To The Drawing3 Of Tumer. Ra. Vacher Evidently Aims At It, And In Upgn5N Of His Numerous Drawings This Year, Some From Iaaly, Others Fram Algeria, He Has Succeeded In Obtaininm It, In His Dstauces At Least, Though Their Value Is Muich Impaired By The Want Of Force And Truth In His Foregrounds. Mr. Vacher Seems To Have Consecrated Himself To The Service Of The Setting Sun, And To Have Vowed To Represent Nature Only Under The Regal. Purple She Wears At The Close Of Day. This Tends To Give A Monotony And Wearisomeneis To His Rwork, Under The Influence Of Which It Is Difficult To Do, Justice To Its Really Delicate And Refined Qualities. And Vhy Will He Mar The Merit Of An Elaborate Dlrvting Like That Of The M Kadonna Del Sasso 23 By Groups Of Unreal Figures Liko Those Which Disfigure His Foreground, And Which Belong To Southern Italy, And Not Northern, If, Indeed, They Have Any Existence Out Of The Atliers Of Prome ? So In His Capri 117, A Really Important Work For Size And Pains, We Are Apt To Stop In Disgust At The Formless And Lumpish Rockwork Of The Foreground Which First Arrests Our Attention, And Find It Difficult To Pass From It To The Beautyandtiruth Of The Distant Cliffs That Risein Alternations Of Warm, Golden Splendo-Ur, And Cool Purple Shadow, From The Sapphire Sea. Of Nir. Vachers Many Drawings Here We Should Select As The Best 63, Lthe Romaan Wvalls Of Constantine, A Rockperched City, Looking Npon A Stretch Of Purple Plain, And Tie Approach To An Italian Townn 184, A Very Fine Composition, With A Truth Of Local Colour, -Vwich, Perhaps, One Values The More From Its Juxtaposition To The Castel Gandolfo Of Mr. Rowbotham. Mr. Rowbotham Deserves Special Comment, As The Crowvning Professor Of That Fatally Attractive Style Of Drawing Of Which He Is The Incarnation In The New Society As Mr. Richardson Is In The Old. M1Astery Of The Material, Firmness Of Hand In Outline, Precision Of Touch, Command Of The Technical Resources Of Composition, Clearness Of Colour, Prettiness Of Grouping, Skill In The Disposition Of Accessor Es-All These Mr. Rowbotham Possesses In A Ahigh Degree. But You Will Seek In Vain Throughout His Many Drawings, Great And Small, For One Impression Of Truth, One Indication Of Genuine, Uaffected Love Or Reverence For Nature-One Touch That, Coming From The Heart Of The Artist, Goes Straight To The Heart Of The Spectator. We Feel Inclned To Doubt, After Studying His Many Italian Dlrawings In This Exhibition, Wrhether 3Ir. Rowbotham Has Ever Been In Italy, So Utterly, So Curiously Unreal Are They, So Suggestive Now Of The Panoramas And The Theatre, Anon Of Mr.Richardson And Mr. Harding, But Never In The Slightest Degree, Or In Any Point Of Colour, Accessories Or Effects Of The Real Scene. 1R. Rowbothams Art Is The Art Of The Drawing Master, Pur Et Simute In All Of Most Mechanical, Conventional, Meretricious, And Enervating, That The Word Can Be Taken To Convey. It Is Not From Any Desire To Cause Pain That This Harsh Language Is Applied To These Drawings, But Because They Are, From Their Very Faults, So Pleasing To Superficial Eves, So Calculated To Mislead Students To Substitute The Effort After Pleasant Falsity For The Resolute Struggle After Stern Truth, So Emasculate In Themselves And So Emasculating In Their Influence That Either It Is A Daty To Stigmatize The School To Which They Belong Or Criticism Is A Farce Altogether. It Is A Pleasure To Turn From Mr. Rowbothams Achievements In The Way Of Finished Falsehood To The Most Incomplete Efforts Of A Hard-Working, Honest Student, Such As Mir. Sutcliffe Seems To Be. He Has Almost Everything To Learn In His Art, Except The Great Truth That Its Onlyfoundation Must Be Nature. He Appears From His Seven Drawings Here To Be Workingv Under The Influence Of This Truth And Though He Has Failed Egregiously In His Largest Efort 328, Mill At Weusley, Yorkshire, Where His Sunshine And Shadow Are Patchy And Incompatible, His Skv Devoid Of Light, And His Distances, Proportions, And Composition All Curiously Blundered-He Has, In Two. Or Three More Modest Attempts-Particularly One Called Spring 187-Rendered, With A Faithfulness And Respect Which Give Excellent Promise For The Future. The Tender Colour And Delicate Foliage Of The Opening Year. Mr. S. Cook Is No Learner. He Has As Great A Command Over The Technical Means Of His Art As Any Draughtsman In The Society. Bat In His Careful Studies Of The Cornwall And Devonshire Coasts He Displays, Besides The Practised Hand Of The Thoughtful Designer, A Delicate Appreciation Of The Trnths Of Sea And Clihf, The Workings Of Tide And Wind, Which Give To His Drawings Well-Nigh As High A Value As Such Transcripts Of Nature Can Have. We May Mention, As Especiary Good Examples Of This Painter, The Rising Of The Ground Sea, Treburwith, Cornwall Lii, Where The Dance Of The Bottle-Green Inshore Water, Spanned By A Faint Rainbow, Under The Watery Light Of A Sunburst, That Has Brolen Through A Shower, The Tail Of Which Still Veils The Cliff On The Left Hand Of The Foreground, Is Rendered With The Nicest Truth. After This We Should Rank The Serpentine Rocks, Kynance Cove, Cornwall 309, By The Same Painter. Lfr. Philp Ve Should Take, From His Choice Of Subjects And Method Of Working, To Be A Pupil Of Mr. Cook, And Our Worst Objection To Him Is That His Drawings Look Too Much Like Inferior Reproductions Of Hismasters Designs. In Figure-Subjects The Exhibition Is Decidedly Weak. It Has Nothing To Compensate Us For The Absence Of Mr. Absolon, Who Has, We Believe, Dedicated Himself To Oil Painting. But We May Signalize, Not Without Satisfaction, The Appearance Of Mr. Wehnert, Formerly A Contributor Of Figure Subjects Of A Seriousness Of Aim Unusual On These Walls, If Not Always Successful, In A New Character, As The Painter Of Some Very Clear, Careful, And Unexaggerated Little Views Of Florentine Architecture -Two Especialiy, A View Of The Uffizii From The Ponte Vecchio, And A View Of The Ponte Vecchio From The Ufflizwi 299 And 310, Of A Merit Altogether Out Of Proportion With Their Minute Diinensions. Mr. Tidey Does His Best To Replace Lmr. Absolon In A Large Drawing Of A4 Field-Day In The Last Century, In Which,With Considerable Grace And Prettiness Of Colour, There Is A Want Of Completencss Which Shows That The Artist Is Not Quite Up To. The Work He Has Attempted. Le Is Seen To Betteradvantage In A Study Called Idleness 46, Whicht Has Character And Ease. His Wanderer 133 Has Too Comely And Clean A Face For His Tattered Dresa And Title. Mr. Kearney Is Not Up To His Level In. His Scene From Our- Old Friend The Vicar Of Wa!E-- Field 202, And Mlr. E. Corbould Does Less Than Usual To Attract A Crowd In His Scene From The Miiacle Play Of Nioah In- The Streets Of Hiull 218, Whero We Have The Familiar Display Of Antiquarianknowledge In Costume, Of Disregard For Trnth In Light And Shadlowy And Of Absence Of Character In Forms And Fii.Ces, Which Are Characteristic Of The Artist. We Oannot Say Anything- In Praise Of The Figure Subjects Of Mr. Morin, A New Member Of The Society, Thougg.There Is Some Daintiness Ancd Affected Grace In His Poissons Itouges 0, A Group Round One, Of The Basins Of Marly In 1760. In Conclusion Vwe May Enumerate Sev-O Drawings By M.. J. Ss. Ptout, Quite In The Outside Mnanner Of His- Great Uncle, But With No Peculiar Merit To Excuse Orjusteif The Imitation B-Two Pretty Little Drawvings By Miss Lfanny Steers Some Honest, And Unnaffected Views In The Lake Cc5Irbry By Mr James Faahey, The Best Thestyehead Pass Llr Some Unpretending English Landscapes By A Ne Member, I R. Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. A Strong Personal And Pathetic Interest Attaches To Tiro Exhibition Which Opens To-Day At The Grafton Galleries, For Itconsists Of The Nearly Complete Works Of The Late Archibald Stuart Wortley. When He Died Just A Ycar Ago, After A Long And Distressing Illness, A Large Circle Of Friends Mourned A Genial Companion, A Brilliant Sportsman, And Au Eager Artist. As An Artist He Will Here Bo Judged But It Is Well To Remember, As One Studies These 70 Or 80 Pictures, That Ho Was Also Much More. He Was Extremely Versatileperhaps It Would Have Been Better For Him, And For His Fame, Had He Not Been So Had Bo Not Been Bora Of A Distinguished Family,With Early Opportunities Of Making Himself One Of Tho Finest Shots In England. Perhaps He Would Have Been A Better Artist If He Had Never Gone To Eton And Oxford, And If Instead He Had Gone To An Art School At 16 And Plodded His Way Upwards Through The Regular Course Of Classes And Studios. As It Was, Millais Took Him Up When He Was Three Or Fear And Twenty, And Ho Underwent Apparently No Other Artistic Influence. His Master Taught Him A Good Deal, And Now And Then, As In The Portraits Of His Brother And Mother Especially The Latter, Which Is Tho Finest Thing Hero, Ho Painted A Portrait Which Might Almost Pass For A Good Millais. As He Went On, The Modem Tendency To Paint Ugly Pictures As Examples Of Artistic Power Drove Him Into A Kind Of Sharp Antagonism. He Insisted Upon The Need Of Tthikrng Pictures Beautiful And Attractive And This, In The Case Of An Artist Who Fails Short Of First-Rate Power, Is Apt To Lead To The Painting Merely Of Pretty Faces Aud Smooth Surfaces, And To A Neglect Of Atmosphere, Tone, And Other Elements Which Are None The Less Essential To A Fine Picture Because Tho Extremists Cultivate Them To The Exclusion Of All Else. Wortley Shared This Tendency, Aud Thus Came To Be Somewhat Disparaged By The Prevailing School, Both Among His Fellow Artists And Among Tho Critics. He Was Anre Of This Attitude On Their Part, And It Certainly Increased The Sense Of Disappointment Of Winch His Friends Were Conscious During The Latter Part Of His Life. Yet He Was As Zealous As Any Of Them For His Work And His Profession And The Fact That He Founded And Presided Over The Society Of Portrait Painters Must Be Remembered As A Proof Of His Influence And Energy. It Was Chiefly As A Portrait Painter That Ho Was Known In London, Though Scores Of Country Houses Possess Engravings After His Shooting Scenes, Of Which The Originals Aro Bore. They Are Marvellously Accurate Nobody Clso Has Ever Painted Grouse-Drives And Partridge-Drives With Such Fidelity And Such Truth Of Movement. The Portraits Include The Wellknown Full-Length Of The King When Prince Of Wales Lent By The Junior Carlton Dub, Ths Excellent Portrait Of The Latte Lord Devon In Advanced Age, The Pictures Of Mr. James Purdoy, Tho Gunmakor, And Of Dr. W. G. Grace, Which Everybody Remembers, And Some 40 Pictures Of Ladies. Sometimes, As In The Portrait Of That Venerable Lady Ths Late Mrs. James Stuart Wortley, The Artist Rises To A Redly Considerable Height And He Is Always Successful In His Decorative Scheme, While His Drawing Is Never At Fruit. Two- Such Pictures As Those Of Mrs. Gore S3 And Thehon. Mrs. Edward Stuart Worthy 86 Arc Undoubtedly Very Attractive And When Time Has Mellowed Them They Will Be Thought To Have Been Better Worth Doing Than Many Of The Pseudo-Whistlers Now In Fashion. Another Exhibition Of A Memorial Character Is That Of The Works-Of The Late W. Evelyn Osborn, At Mr. Patersons Gallery, 5, Oldbond-Street. This Artist, Who Died Lately In His-Early Prime, Had A Delicate Colour Sense And A Channing Gift Of Composition In Landscape. His Studies Of Ths Thames St Battersea Are Of High Merit. Mr. A. W. Bichs Water-Colours At Tbs Carfax Gallery Are Perhaps Hardly So Satisfactory Ns The Drawings Which He Showed At Tbs Alpin Club A Year Or Two Ago But They Are Masterly Studies, More Or Less In The Manner Of Do Wint, End Their Variety Reflects The Variety Of Nature Herself. Mr. Rich Is In High Fashion At The Moment, Because He Realizes With Apparent Cose Those Tones End Values Which Modern Students Are Taught To Regard Os The One Tiling Needful. But In One Matter, Which Wo Should Regard As Quite Equally Essential, Ho Falls Far Behind His Exemplar. Do Wint Would Never Havo Allowed The Formless And Impossible Trees That Appear In Some Of The Drawings. The Pastels Of Mr. Frank Dean And Mr. T. W. Hammond At The Fino Art Societys The Small Drawings By Mr. Baghot De.Fr Bero At The Bruton Galleries Aud Mrs. Mary Mcevoys Works At The Che Nil Gallery, In The .Kings-Roed, Are Noticeable Among The Minor Exhibitions. There Is Also Aa Interesting Display Of The Works Of The South Kensington Sketch Club The Members Belonging To The Central School Of Art In One Of The Buildings Unnexed To The Museum.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions E - The Pastel Society If Wce Were Pastel Wve Should Be Inclined To Resent The Insistence-Both In Ptactice And In The Note To The Catalogue Of The Thirty-Second Exchibition Of The Pastel Society At The New Burlington Galleriesupon The Hard-Wearing Qualities Of The Medium. It Is As If It Vere Said Of A Plhantom Of Delight That She Was A Very Worthy Wonian. In Ordinary Life There Is Sometlung To Be Said For This Over-Subtle Flattery. As Wlheni A Bishop Is Complimented Uponl His Ping-Pong,-Implying That His Episcopal Merits Leap To The Eye-But In Matters Of Art It Is Better To Vaunt Essentials. Pastel Will Do All Sorts Of Things, And It Will Last, So To Speak, For Ever, But It Undoubtedly Has A Special Turn For Slight And Charming Effects. One Consequence Of A General Insistence Upon Thc Incidental Merits Of Pastel Is That At The Exhibition Of The Pastel Society You Are Torn Between Creditable Works Whieh Reduce The Medium To A Drudge, And Less Good Pictures Whichl Really Dq Give Pastel Its Fling. Mr. J. Mielutr-E Hamiltons Pretty Ladies-Like The Sheeps Conversation In The Poem-Are Not Very Deep, But They Illustrate One Of The Happiest Uses Of Pastel In Their Swvift, Light Handling And Delicate Schemies Of Colour. Thev Make .Nost Of The Other Things Look Laboured. For A Fuller Treatment-Lir. Hamilton Lets The Brown Paper Ground Have A Good Deal To Say In The Effect-We May Turn To Trinkets, By Miss Anna Airy, W.Hicll, Tlhough It Is Rathler Obvious In Colour, Shows The Broad And Vigorous Touch That The Pastel Stick Allows To Perfection. One Oddity To Be Noticed In The Exhibition Is That, When An Artist Does Wake Up To A Special Quality In Pastel, Lie Is Apt To Use It In Foreing Colour In A Meahistic Convention. This Is Noticeable In The Landscapes By Ilir. Leonard Richmond. The Colours Are Not Neeessarily Too Bright In Themselves There Is No Limit To Pitchi Of Colour In A Decorative Effect But They Are Too Bright For That Kind Of Picture-Though Lovemnent, Of Wind And Wvater, Has Its Attractions. As A Whlole, However, The Exhibition Looks Better Than Former Ones Of The Series-Partly Because It Is Better Hung. Nothing Could Be More Estimable Than The Studies Of Tlle Cornish Coast By Mr. A. L. Baldry, But The Medium In Them Is Ruled With A Rod Of Iron. One Thinks Of The Reformed Rake. As A Result One Tuins A Lenient Eye Upon Such Things As Mr. Francis Blacks Gardens, Catherine, Working On The Terrace, By Mrs. Laura Anning Bell, Romance, Bv Mr. Miontague Smyth, Girls Head, By Mrs. P4. A. Eastlake, And A Canal-Venice, By Mr. Terrick Williams. They Are Not Such Estimuable Pictures, But They Sing. With The Pastel Society Is Incorporated The Pencil Society, And This Accounts For The Presence Of Such Lively Drawings As The Group By Mr. Steven Spurrier And The Workroom Subjects Bv Miss Madelinie M4. Mcdonald. Things That Should Not Be Missed On Any Account Are A Study, By Mrs. Helen Bedford, The Group Of Small Studies By Mr. L. D. Luard, Andless For Their Technical Qualities Than For Their Wistful Woetry-The Landscapes By Aliss -Mary Yates. Mir. J. Vaugh1An Philipps, Chief Constable Of Bath, Who Was Appointed In 1902, Tendered His Resignation Yesterday. His Father And His Brother Were Former Chief Constables Of Carniarthenshire.

Author: (FROM OUR VIENNA CORRESPONDENT.)
Title: International Exhibition Of Photography
Full_text: Intdibn Ational Exhibition Of Photogbaphy. Fitom Ou1. Vienna Cornespondent. The International Exhibition Of Artistic Photographs Organized By Tho Vienna Club Of Amateur Photographers Was Opened Recently By The Archduchess Maria Theresa, In The Presence Of Many Distinguished Personages, Including Prince Philip Of Coburg, Sir Augustus Paget, And Several Austrian Cabinet Ministers. As The Official Titlo Of The Exhibition Denotes, The Exhibits Are Without Exception Such As Can Claim Really Artistic Value. How Rigorously The Selection Committee, Which Consisted Of Eminent Painters And Sculptors Of Various Nationalities, Went To Wyork May Be Judged From The Fact That Out Of 4.Oou Impressions Offered For Exhibition Only 600 Have Been Admitted. The Result Is, As Is Admitted On All Sides, An Admirable Collection Of Productions Of Modern Photography In Its Most Artistic Application. The Numerous British Photographers, Both Amateur And Professional, Who Are Nowv Exhibiting In Vienna Have Certainly No Reason To Regret Their Participation In This International Competition. It Is Not Too Much To Say That They Form The Great Attraction Of The Exhibition, And That Their Works Well Sustain The Superiority Of English Photography. The Ioenna Journals Frankly Admit That The Most Valuable Exhibits From An Artistic Point Of View Belong To British Photographers, And This Opinion Was Freely Expressed Auring The Opening Ceremony At The Austrian Museum, Where The Exhibition Is Being Held. Greatly Admired Was The M Ljan In Armour, By Arthur Burchett, Of London, As Well As The Landscapes And Natural Scenes By Robinson, Of Tunbridge Wells, And Harry Tolley, Of Nottingham. The Following Camo In For Much Praise -George Davison, Of London, Robert Dresser, Of Bexley Heath, Horsley Hinton, Of London, And Many Others. The English Colony In Vienna Is Represented By Mr. John Bergheim, Who Contributed A Capital Gipsy Family And A Portrait In Rembrandt Style. Next To The English Photographers A Foremost Rank Is Occupied By An Italian Lady, Countess Loridana, And Wilhelm Dreesen, Of Flensburg. Among The Vienna Amateurs May Be Mentioned The Barons Albert And Nathaniel Rothschild. The Patroness Of The Exhibition, The Archduchess Maria Theresa, As Well As The Princess Of Wales, The Grand Dule Ferdinand Of Toscana, And Count Bardi Have Exhibited Hors Conrcotrs. The Princess Of Wales Has Sent Some Small Instantaneous Photographs Which Are Declared By Experts To Belong To The Best Of Their Kind.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. The Grafton. Galleries Are Again Filled, But Only For A Few Days, With, Pictures And Drawings,- The Work Of The Womens International Art Club. The Name Is Not Very Intelligible, For Nine Out Of Ten Members Appear To Be English, And The Whole Of The Committee Bear English Names. Perhaps It Means That The Chief Exhibitors Have Studied Abroad, And That The Dominant Influence Is French We Wish That We Could See More Signs Of The Best French Training, Especially In Drawtag But It Must Be Confessed That The Qualities Most In Evidence Are Those That Come From A Superficial Imitation Of French Colour And Tone. Y O, The Larger And More Conspicuous Pictures Imply An Ambition Greater Than The Artists Power Of Performance. Miss Camerons Two Large Spanish Scenes, For Example, Are Such As M. Zuloaga Paints But One Requires Tile Karoo And Oll Of A Zuloaga To Make Them Tolerable. So With Miss Molony S Largo Group Of Breton Peasants M. Dagnan-Bouveret Might Have Designed It, But How Different Would Be His Execution ! Things Are Better In Tho Rooms Of Drawings. Here There Are Some Excellent Portraits And Sketches In Chalk, Such As Those Sent By Mi Florence Small 309, Miss E. G. Hill, Missa. E. Spong, And Miss Mary A. Williams 349This Last The Best Of Stags View Of The Downs At Scheveninvea 182 Is Powerful, And There Are Some Dainty Little Landscapes By Miss Hagarty, Miss E. M. Lister, Miss Kirkpatrick, And Miss Noma Labouchoro. The Realistic Bronze Groups Of Horses By A Swedish Artist, Mme. Amgen De Spazre, Ato Notable For Their Vigour. At The Pino Art Societys Rooms, In New Bond-Street, Are The Original Drawings For Tho Book Of Travel In France And Italy Which Has Been Illustrated By Mr. Hallam Murray. These Are Sunny And Delightful Inaspect, And The Architectural Drawing Isquiteexcellent. Caen, Chenonceau,Antibes, Florence, And Many Other Places Have Yielded Their Beauties To The Artist, Whose Progress In His Art During The Last Few Years Has Been Remarkable. Here Also Are Some Very Fine Pencil Drawings By Mr. Romilly Fedden, Especially Some Email Heads That Are Unusually Strong And Delicate In Workmanship.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Ar-T Exhibitions. Mr. Sidney R. Sime. Imagination And Humour Are Both Present In The Exhibition Of Drawings And Caricatures From The Sketch-Books Of Mr. Sidney H. Sime At The St. Georges Gallery, 32A, George-Street, Hanoversquare. Those Who Are Old Enough To Remember Pick-Me-Up With Gratitude Will Not Be Surprised To Learn That Mr. Simes Powers, If They Have Sobered, Have Deepened In Rural Retirement, Beeause It Was Evident Then That His Gift Was More Than Cleverness. The Best Things Here Are Small Imaginative Landscapes In Colour, Almost Always Most Impressive When They Are Unpeopled-Unless By Animals Only. The Blake-Ish Dragonshold, Shorehiam Hill, In A Rain Squall, Wastelands, And Wild Beast Wood, With Its Gliding Wolves, Are Examples. They Are True Interpretations Of Landscape Mood, And Technically They Are Beautiful, Done With Hatching Strqkes With The Point Of The Brush In Sober Schemes Of Colour. The Treatment In These Landscapes Is Comparatively Naturalistic, But Another Series, Including The Forest, Remote Landscape. And Moorland Lake, Shows That Mr. Sime Can Formalize In A Decorative Convention Without Losing Mood, And There Are Some Attractive Schemes In Pure Decorationnos. 77 And 79, For Good Examples. The Caricatures Are Of Village Worthies, And They Will Give More Than Local Joy. They Represent Individuals, But The Types- A Football Captain, Horticulturalist, - The Church Beadle, Sheik, And So On-Will Be Recognizable To Anybody Who Has Lived In The Country. Aieldici Society. At The Galleries Of The Medici Society, 7. Grafton-Street. There Are Some Remarkable Colour-Faesimiles Of Old Master Drawings, Made Unler The Direct Supervision Of Herr Jnllius Meder, Director Of The Albertina Gallery. Vienna-Remarkable Alike In Quality And Iii Modesty Of Price. The Special Feature Is The Series Of Dilrer Drawings In The Albertinm Library, Including Such Delightful Things As Bunchi Of Violets. The Hare, Andl Columbines, As Well As Portrait Heads And Architectural Compositions, Like Castle Courtyard, Innsbruck. Very Few Of The Drawings Are In Monochrome, And The Colour Reproduction Is At Any Rate Very Consistent, However It May Compare In Brilliancy With The Originals. Italian, Freneh, And Duteh Drawings Are Also Shown, Alid There Is A Complete Set Of The Wvindsor Castle Drawings By Holbein And Others, Reproduced Under The Direction Of Sir John Fortescue, When He Was Royal Librarian. At The Same Galleries There Is An Exhibition Of The Forest Toys Mnade In The New Forest By Mr. Wliittington. These, Carved In Wood And Painted, Hit A Happy Mean Between Naturalism And Convention, And The Animals Are All Made In Relative Proportions-A Point Iften Overlooked. The Sets Of F Armyard, Fox Hlunting, Circus, And Timber Wagon Should Be Popular. Mr. Adam Knight. In Their Sober And, So To Speak, Oldfashioned, Way, The Water-Colours Of The South Of France And Elsewhere By Mr. Adam Knight At Walkers Galleries, 118, New Bondstreet, Have Considerable Merit-Particularly When The Subjects Are Mainly Architectural. These Water-Colours, In Fact, Remind One Of The Sort Of Conversation Which Is Found On Consideration To Have More In It Than The Absence Of Contenmporary Smartness Miglht Lead One To Suppose. Mr. Knight Knows How To Compose A Subject, Lifr Execution, Though Slow, Is Sulticiently Broad, And His Colour Has That Truth In The Relations Which Makes For Solidity Of Effect. Place De La Mairie, Cagnes, A Pump In St. Tropez, Etaples, Montreuil, And St. Saulve, Montreuil Are All Good Examples Of Wlhat They Set Out To Be. In Open Landscape Mr. Knight Is Not So Successful, Becoming Duller In Proportion As He Avoids Buildings. Brook-Street Gallerles. Though They Are Too Highly Coloured And Decidedly Weak In Drawing, The Oil And Tempera Paintings By Mrs. Stella Mlynors, At Tho Brook-Street Art Galleries, Show Some Evidenre Of Talent. The Artist Has A Feeling For Composition And Some Power Of Suggesting Movement, And It Is Likely That, Even With The Defects Noted, The Racing Subjects Will Please The Initiated. But From A Pictorial Point Of View The Best Things Are The Two Paintings Of Cornish Coast With Cattle, Nos. 13 And 21, And Such Landscapes As In The Woods And Hillsile Parni, Ospedaletti. A Severe Course Of Drawing And Restraint In Colour Are Indicated. Pictures Of India. The Water-Colour And Tempera Paintings Of Iiilia By Mr. W. S. Bagdatopoulos. A Reek Artist, At The Arlington Gallery, 22, Old Bondstreet, Serve To Show How Competent An Artist May Be In Some Respects While To Seek In Others. A4 Representations Of Actual Scenes, Types, And Incidents They Atre Remarkably Vivid -Producing Almost A Hubbul In The Roonihut They Are Robbed Of Artistic Attractivent3S By The Dark Shadows Used For Relief. Nor Does This Treatment. If So Intended, Produce The Illusion Of Sunlight, For The Sunlight In The Landscapes Is Almost Uniformlv Weak And Cold. Jumma Masjid, Agra Show-S How Vastly The Effect Improves With Colour In The Tlarker Tones. But There Can Be No Question Of The Artists Ability To Make A Realistic Representation Of What Is Before His Eye-. The Most Striking Pictures Are Of Scenes Of Industry, Like Coffee Garbling, Mangalore And Carpet Mlaking In Kashmir, Or Studies Of T Pes, Such As A Tibetan. An Afridi, And Lamnani Gipsies, But Some Of The Architectural Subjects- The 3Man Singh Palace. Gwalior, For A Good Example-Have Remarkable Soliditv.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition In The City
Full_text: Art Exhibition Int The City .. . . Work Of Three Banks Staffs The Lord Mayor Of London Sir George Broadbridge Yesterday Opened The First Three Banks Art Exhibition, Which Is Being Held At Guildhall. The Three Banks Which Are Associated With The Exhibition Are The Bank Of England And The Midland And Westminster Banks. Previously Individual Exhibitions Have Been Held, But This Year A Combined Exhibition Has Been Arranged, And There Are 427 Exhibits. Mr. Montagu Norman, Who Is President Of The Bank Of England Arts Society, With Mr. Stanley Christopherson Deputising For Mr. Mckenna, President Of The Midland Bank, Art Club, Conducted The Lord Mayor Round The Exhibition. Mr. Norman Said That The Midland Bank Had Had An Art Society For The Best Part Of A Dozen Years. The Westminster Bank Art Club Was Only Four Or Five Years Old Yet It Had Met With Great Success. The Bank Of England Society Had Had The Longest Life, But Had Not Had The Continuity Of The Others. It Had Occasionally Taken A Rest Off Duty For A Year Or Two. Laughter. They Valued The Exhibition Because It Stimulated The Life And Interest Of Those Who Worked In The Banks And Who Were Thus Enabled To Have A Hobby To Which They Could Devote Themselves. Through That Devotion They Were. He Was Sure, Able To Do Their Dull Bank Work The Better. The Lord Mayor Said That To The City Man Art Should Be A Great Bulwark Against The Hustle Which Modern Life Demanded. The Exhibition Is Divided Into Several Sections-Oil Colours. Water Colours, Pastel, Black And White, Photography, Miniatures, Sculpture, And Handicrafts. Many Of The Pictures Are For Sale, And Prices Range From Half A Guinea To 21. The Exhibition Is Open To The Public All This Week From 10 A.M. To 5 P.M.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. The Dudley Gallery Art Society Opens To-Day 2N Exhibition Of Water-Colours At The Egyptian Elail, Piccadilly. Since The Change Which Took Place Hero On The Establishment Of The Institute The Exhibitions Have Not Been Quite On The Level Which They Attained In The Old Times, But, As Collections Of Tho Work Of Amateurs Or Of The Younger Professional Artiststhey Have Been Respectable. The Present Display Is No Exception To This Rule. It Is Not Very Large, Containing Little Over 200 Works And, Without Comprising Any Drawing That Is Specially Remarkable, It Is Up To A Fair Standard Of Performance. Perhaps Thebest Work Here Is Tho Off Hastings 143 Of Mr. Francis Powell, Whoso Work At The Royal Water-Colour Society Is Well Known To All Who Care For Drawings Of The Sea. Miss Kate M,Acaulay Sends Three Or Four Drawings Of Fishing-Boats And Scenes Of The River And The Sea The Best Is Old Chelsea And Battersea Bridge 138, Which, Except For Being Somewhat Dull In Colour, May Be Called A Successful Rendering Of One Of The Most Picturesquo Bits Of London, Now, Unfortunately, Changed And Mado Commonplace By The, Necessities Of Time. Mfr. Alfred Easts Bit Of A Berkshire Common 122 And M1R. Claude Hayess Gipsy Life 188 Are Studies Which More Or Less Resemble One Another, And Each Is The Work Of An Artist. Among Views Of London Wo May Notice Tho River Pioces Of Mlr. Hubert Mledlycott, And The Trafalgar-Square 55 Of Miss Robertson And Among Flon-Er Pieces The Orchids 58 Of Miiss Helen Thornycroft Stands Out As An Example Of Delicato Colouring And Careful Painting. At 3Mr. Bassanos Gainsborough Gallery In Old Bond-Street There Is Now To Be Seen A Fiulllength Portrait Which Has Been Purchased By Sir Charles Aitchison For The Punjab Institute, Labore. The Occasion Of The Gift Is, Of Course, The Jubilee,Nd It May Be Admitted That The Picture Makes As Good A Jubilee Memorial As Most Others. Wvithout Having Any Very Great Artistic Pretensions, The Portrait Is Interesting As Showing What Can Be Done From Photographs For, Though Her Miajestyhas Seen The Picture And Suggested Certain Points In Its Composition, We Believe That It Has Heon Almost Entirely Painted From Mr. Bassanos Photographic Likeness. The Queen Is Represented Ceated, In Robes Of State, Wearing The Famous Flounce Of Venetian Lace, The Diamond Imperial Crown, The Koh-I-Noor, The Star Of Indin, C. Altogether It Will Give Her Majestys Indian Eubjects A Very Good Idea Of Her Appearance, And Will Always Remain A Pleasant Memorial Of The Jubilee. At The Hanover Gallery, At The Corner Of Mladdox-Street And New Bond-Street, A Good Many Additions Have Been Made To The Exhibition Since Last We Noticed It. Conspicuous Among These Is Carolus Durans Brilliant Childs Portrait, Called Bepino, A Work Which Shows All His Unquestionable Power -Without The Vulgarity Into Which He Too Often Falls.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition. Early Chinese - Ceramics. Beautiful Thingsg In Some Instances Made Stillmore Beautiful By. Time And. The Chemistry Of Earth, Are. To Be Seen At The Galleries Of Miessrs. Bluett And Sons, 48, Davies-Street, Brook-Street, Where There Is A Collection Of Early Chinese Ceranics, Including Examples Recently Brought From China. There Are About 100 Pieces, Ranging From The Ean To The Early Fing Dynasty, Or From About 200 B.C.F To About 1400 A.D. In Our Reckoning So That The Collection As A Whole Illustrates The Progress Of Chinese Ceramic Art From Unglazed Through Glazed Pottery To True Porcelain In Which The Glaze And The Body Are Fused Into A New Substance. By Firing. Believed To Be Unique Are 12 Unglazed. Pottery Statuettes Of Reddish Clay Representing The Signs Of The Chinese Zodiac. These Are In The Form Of Human Figures With Animal Heads-Of The Rat, Ox, Tiger, Hare, Dragon, Snake, Monkey, And So On. Of The Tang Dynasty 618-906 A., They Are All In The Same Convention The Hands Of The Figures Being Folded At The Breast Under The Robe, Of Which The Lines Curve Downwards To Present The Appearance Of Closed Wings. This Gives To The Little Figures A Curious Dignity, An Effect Which Is Enhanced By The Suavity Of The Modelling-Though The Animal Character Ofthe Heads, Of The Snake, For Instance, Is Un- Cannily Suggested. - Included In The Collection Are A Few Bronzes, From Which The Forms Of The Potteries Were Often Imitated-Or, Rather, Translated. There Is One Small Bronze, Koro 16, Of The Tsing Period 265 Ad., With Handles, Beautifully Decorated, Encrusted With A Blue-Green Patina And Bearing Traces Of Gilt And Between This And A Tripod Incense Burner 90, Of The Sung Period 9601279, About The Same Size, An Interesting Comparison Can Be Made. The Form Is Roughly The Same, But In The Porcelain Version The Sharpness Of The Casting And Engraving Is Soothed Away, So To Speak, By The Fingers Of The Modeller. It Is A Translation, And Not A Soulless Imitation, Of The Bronze Form. This Piece, Found On The Site Of Lung Chuan, Has The Most Exquisite Glaze In The Collection, Of A Quality Impossible To Describe In Words, Though The Unctuous Of One Expert Will Suggest The Way It Reflects The Light And Feels To The Fingers. Compared With It Everything Else, Though There Are Many Excellent Pieces In Celadon, Notably A Figure With Unglazed Face And Hands 77, Slightly Glitters. A Feature Of The Collection Is A Set Of Fine Porcelain With A Delicate Blue Or Ying Ching. Glaze, Found In Northem China, And Belonging To A Ju Type. Among The Pieces Is A Deep Saucer With Radiating Lines In Relief 91, In The Conventionalized Form Of The Expanded Corolla Of A Flower. Though Differing In Colour And In The Number Of Petals, It Has The Effortless Perfection Of An Open Primrose. Otlier Things Of Note Are A Glazed Pottery Model Of A Horses Head, Of The Tang Period, But Startlingly Greek In Effect, And A Pottery Pillow Formed As A Crouching Boar.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitioilts. As One Enters The Rooms Of The Fine Art Society In New Bond-Street One Is Delayed By Something Muh Better Worth Seeing Than Any Show Of Ephemeral Art Is Likely To Le-By A Collection Of Historical Documents And Autographs Of Real Importance. Who Is The Owner Of This Collection Of 244 Pieces Is A Secret, But, Whoever He May Be, He Has Succeeded In Bringing Together What Probably Is, Next To Mr. Alfred Morrisons, The Richest Assemblage Of Autographs In Private Hands In England. We Should Be Going Beyond The Scope Of This Article Were We To Describe These Mss. In Any Detail It Must Suffice To Say That They Includte Signatures, Letters, And The Original Mlanuscripts Of. Printedvworks, From The Hands Of Royal Personages, Great Statesmen, Authors, Painters, Musicians, C., For A Period Of Three Centuries Or More. To Mention But A Very Fewv, There Are Signs-Manual Of Henryvii., Elizabeth, Lfrancis I., Charles V. Letters From Elizabeth, Louis Xi., Henri Iv. Letters Of Burleigh And Of Many Other English Statesmen Down To Recent Times Of Mime. De Maintenon And Mme. De Pompadour, Of Coligny And Bossuet, Of Reynolds And Gainsborough, Of Burns And Cowper, Of Scott And Shelley Theautographmss. Of Endymion And Lamia, Of Southeys C Urse Of Kehama, And Of Mloores Epicurean The Original Drafts Of Many Of Sternes Most Famous Letters And, In A Very Different Field, A Whole Series Of Letters From .Napoleon. From These It Is Not Exactly An Ascent To Pass To The Water-Colours And Designs In The Further Rooms But These Things, Too, Are Interesting In Their Way. Messrs. Rheads Illustrations To The Pilgrims Progress Are Firmly Conceived And Drawn, Though A Little Conventional. Mrfr. H. S. Hopwood Is One Of The Newly-Made Associates Of The Old Water-Colour Society, And He Bids Fair To Do Credit To The Well-Established Reputation Of That Body. His Interiors And Markets In Normandy And Brittany Are Seen With The Eye Of An Artist, And Are Carefully And Intelligently Painted. The Artist Belongs, If To Any School, To That Of Fred Walker, Pinwell, And Professor Herkomer, Which Is As Much As To Say He Is Not An Impressionist. But He Is As Productive As If He Were His Output-Surely Not For A Single Year-Amounts To No Less Than 63 Drawings, Some Of Them Quite Elaborate. One Trembles To Think Of The Future If All The 5,000 Artists Working In England Are To Produce At That Rate. Messrs. Tooth, In The Elaymarket, Keep To Their Accustomed Lines, And Their Winter Exhibition Is One Of Cabinet And Other Works By Such En,Lish Painters A Messrs. Hemny Woods, Leader, Bseymour Lucas, David Farquharson, Blair Leighton, And James Orrock And By Tmm. Muiacsy, Domingo, Auguste Bonheur, Jacquet, Deutsch, C. Many Of These Are, Of Course, Extremely Accomnlished. Nothing Could, In Its Way, Be Better Than Mir. Seymour Lucass 17Th Century Figure, Thinking It Out -Very Brilliantly Painted, In His Buff Jarkin And Scarlet Cloak Or Than The Little Venetian Scenes Of Mr. Woods And Mr. Logsdail Or Than The Beautiful Early Work Of The Lamented Henry Moore, An Estuary, With Its Transparent Water And Threatening Sky. Of The Foreign Pictures, A Conspicuous Place Is Claimed By Mme. Di6Terle Van Mharkes Daughter For Her Cattle On The Coast -Very Clever And Competent, But Hardly Interesting Because Representing Rather What The Artist Has Been Taught Than What Shohaspersonallyobserved And Felt. A Better Painter Is The Neglected Auguste 1Bonheur, Whose Cows Are Really Almost As Brilliant As Troyons, Though He Has A Much Duller Feeling For Landscape. The Work Of Professor Scheurenberg Is New To England, Though The Painter Has A High Reputation In Berlin His Picture Of The Seas Delight Is Very English In Technique, And Is Not Wi.Thout Charm. - Next Door, At Mr. Mleans, The Place Of Honour Is Given To A Large Picture Painted By Nflle. Rosa Bonheur In L876, Uine Compagme De Sangliers -Life-Sized Wild Boars Making Their Way Through A Forest. The Boars Are A Surprisingly Exact Copy Of Nature, And The Landscape Is Something Rather Better. It Is Interesting To See Again Two Such Powerful Little Works Of J. L. Ger6Me As The Gladiatorial Figures, The Retiarivs And The Mnirmillo, Here Exhibitedmarvels Of Modelling And Painting, And Extraordinary Archaeological Creations. These Pictures Belong To The Epoch Of The Ave, Caesar, And Other Famous Pictures, When The Artist Was Finding The Source Of A Grim Inspiration In The Sports Of The Roman Amphitheatre. For The Rest, There Are Two Fine Examples Of Schreyer, Who Always Paints Well An Excellent Small Lhermite Mr. Flerkomers At The Well And Sweet Emma Moreland, One Of The Latest Works Of Millais. At Messrs. Dowdeswells, In New Bond-Street, Mr. F. E. Chardon Exhibits Some Clever Pastels Of Foreign Views, Chiefly Neapolitan. They Are, As The Phrase Goes, C Arried Far -Too Far For The Instrument, We Feel Disposed To Think For Here Pastel Trenches Somewhat Upon The Domain Of Water-Colour, And Attempts What Wat.R.Colour Would Perform Better.

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Fine Art Society. The Water-Colours Of London By Mr. W. Dacres Adams At The Galleries Of The Fine Art Society, 148, New Bond-Street, Are All The Better For Insisting Upon Strutture Rather Than Upon Atmosphere. Londons Atmosphere Is Always With Us, Hut We Never, 60Ow Fromday To.Day Wheri Some Characteristic Building-Such As St. John At Wapping-The Old Charity School -Is-To Come Down. The Work Of Mr. .Dacers Adams Is Erinently Static, Firmly Designed And Simplifed Down To, But Not Beyond, The Character Of The Building. And He Gives You The Intrinsic Colour Of, The Bricks And Stones Rather Than Their Accidental Effepts. His Planning Of-Shadows To Intensify The Look Of Solidity Is Remarkably Good, Waterloo Bridige Steps Beingi Wonderful In This Respect. With This Drawing May Be Namned St. Martins Church From The National. Gallery, And A Bit Of Somerset Eouse-Kings College In Rear.. A Few Oil Paintings Are Included, Silence, The Vaulted Interior Of A Church In Spain, Showing Mr. Dacres Adamss Capacity To Vork Out! The Gradation Of Light In An Alrehiteetural Subject. At Tbhe Same Galleries There Are Humorous Drawings By Mr. W. Heath Robinson. Yariations On The- Theme Of Lambs- Roast Pig Might-Be Said To Be His Favourite Subject, For He Is Never-Tired Of Esploiting, With-Much Mechanical Ingenuity,- The Solemn Futility Of Human Beings In. Using A Steam-Hammer. To Crush A Butterfly. His Style Is Best For The Purpose . Clear, Simple, Nd- Patient, As If He Had Clo Desire But To,Show You How The Thing Nvas Worked. -Mr. Henry Winslow. The Wateicolours And Pastels By 31R. Henrywinslow At The Cotswold Gallery, 59, -Frith-Street, Soho-Square, Introduce Us To An Artist Wvho Combines Simplicity With Subtlety. Mr. Winslow Is A Good Designer, With A Fine Sense Of The Emotional Appeal Of Abstract Forms-Witness The Use Made Of The Arching Davit In The White Ship And Of The Bollard In Ihe Hawser-A Sensitive Draughtsman, And A Very Choice Colourist And His Practice Of Painting On Linen Enables Him To Dispense With Detail And Still Get An Interesting Quality From The Texture Of The Stuff. ,Shipping Provides Him With Some-Of His Best Material, And He Has Evident-Ly Studied It Until He Can Leave Out Everything Which Does Not Count Aesthetically. Blackwall, With Its Remarkable Depth Of -Atmosphere, Is His -Best Watercolour, - But The Aberdonian,- A Cunard- Liner, And A Farm Have Speeial Qiiualitis, And There Is Admnirable Perspective Drawing In The Red Barge. Dealing With More Immediate Effects, The Pastels, Of Now York Do Not Seem So True To. Mr. Winslows Refective Temperamlent, But They Are Full Of Weather And Charmin.G N Colour. Panton Art Club. Twenty-One Gallery. Mliss Elizabeth Drury, Who Shows Landseapes, Still-Life Subjects, And A Few Portraits In Oils At The Twenty-One Galery, Adelphi Has A Turn For Abstraction, But Is Iisely Indulgent To The Moods Of Nature. Her Spring Landscape, For Example, Thougih Roduced To The Simnplest Statement, Is Full Of Thi Gaiety Suggested By The Title Islands L Ilave Romance As Well As Form, And Alexanders Field, Under Snow In Winter Sunlight, Makes You Believe In An Actual Alexander. If At A Glance These Landscapes Appear Rather Clumsy, The Reason Is In Miss Drurys Preference For The Larger Contours Of Earth-As In The Bold Sweep Of Ploughland Against The Green. In A Sutton Veny. 2 -And As A Colourist She Gets Full Value Out Of Sober Schemes. Comparison Between Nude Anid G Girl With Fruit, On The One Hand, And The Comparatively Realistic Dusky Head 1B.N.1, On The Other. Shonvs That Miss Drury Cannot Yet Reduce The Human Figure So Successfully As She Does The Forms Of Landscape And Of Tbe Still-Life Subjects, The Yellow Cloth, Which Keeps Pretty Close To The Facts, Is The Most Pleasing. New Ilond-Street, Is That, From S Tipical Point Of View, It Is Very Well Tinied. But She Is A Good Colourist. Vith A Deal,. Dlirect Niiithodl Ii Handling Lier Medium And Tihere Caljacitie N6T -To Speak Of A Keeni Eye For Tlt,E Chaia.Cteristie Subject And Determination Iiu Seciriuig It,- Have Served Her Wvell In Such Hi Avwirs As Primulas And Aiiemonies On The Gilgit Road At Kamri 14.00Oft.. Jacobs Lildder In The .Khilan Woods, And A Wild Gilrden At Biirdwan. Withouit Being Unduly Botanical, These Drawings Are As Good Fromn A Documentary, Point Of View As They Are Phinsiiig As Pictures. And Orclard-Puddlcdo.!K, Sussex Beinig Particularly Good Exainples And Thete Is Much To Adnmire In Such Water-Colours By M1Rs. Stephens As Aiguilles Rouges From Finhaut And Lac De Bourget, Aix-Les-Baius. Pottery By Mr. Wells. At Tile Beaux Arts Gallery, Bruton-Place, Thie-E Is A Large Collection Of Soon Pottery, Iicdithig Statuettes Of Animals, By Mir. Ireginald F. Vells, The Original Maker Of Coldrum Pottery. Mr. Wells Works Frankly In Imitation Of The Chinese Potters, And This, While It Keeps Him ,Ithin The Bounds Of -Discretion In Form, Also Institutes A Severe Comparison In Quality. His Glazes Are Generally Disappointing To The Touch, And Too Often-. Particularly In The Broxen Colours-They Have A Jammy Or Sticky Appearance And It Is Difficult To Resist The Feeling That They Would Sit More Comfortably On More Robust And. So To Speak, Clumsier Forms. Particularly Nvhen One Observes The Fluency Of Mir. Wells Modelling In His Figures Of Animals-The Horses Aiid Ducks Are The Most Successful-The Suggestion Is Given That Liis Movements As A Potter Are Cramped By Respect For The Oriental Traiditioni. The Forms Are Theoretically Correct, But They Lack The Subtlety And Vitality Whici Come From The Potters Hand Working Freely In Its Own Idiom. Lit Thie Reproduction Of Rare Colour Effects Mr. Wvells Has Beens Remarkably Successful, Thlough1 Evenl Hlere Lie Seems More Pleased At Tlhe Solution Of The Chemical Problemt Than Concerued For Tho Resthetic Quality Of The Results. Oln The Vhole The Simpler Pieces In Grey, Blue, Buff, And Prackled White ,Ive Tlie Niost Satisfaction. Ttie Presence Of Niitural Flowers In One Of The Pots Coniflrms Tlne Belief That The Work Of Mlr. Wells Wvill Give More Pleasure When Turned To Such Uses Than Whieni It Is The Subject Of Undistracted Attention. Seven And Five Society. Tile Fifth Exhibition Of The Seven And Five Society At The Paterson Gallery, 5, Old Bondstreet, Has At Least The Merit In These Overcrowiled Days Of Being Only A Srnall One57 Works To Be Precise. Without Committilng Themrselves To Any Piltform, For Their Title Seems. To Have No Ocrault Signifcaiece, Niost Of Thie Members Are Modern In The Sense Of Prrsuing Sonie Degree Of Abstraction. The Extreme Degree Is Reachedl By Mr. Ben Nicholson In Abstraction. Novemher,Whiclh Looks As 1 Lie Hasd Redueed Londoa Fog To Its Conntituent Elements And Then Employed Them Pigrnents In A Patchwvork -Design. His Ben Ira Must Not Complain If She Is Called Big Bertha. Under The Title Un Rsve Est Moins Trompeur Parfois Quun Document, Mr. Claude Flight Has Produced An Engaging Design Of A Geometrically Composed Nude Lady, -,Curled Up Among Fishes In- A Circular Tank, The Repetition Of The Figure Without Plastic Relief No Doubt Illustrating The Title, But He Is More Consistently Represented In Two Watercolour Designs Of The Trawler And The Waves And A Street In Jerusalemn And Some Woodcuts. Good Landscapes Are Shown By Mr. P. H. Jowett, Mr. Normau Janes, And Others Lime. Luns Pillico Shows Some Of Her Imagindtive Decorations And Among The Works In Sculpture There Are Two Nicely-Simplified Cardings Ot Seated Figure And Sleeping Kittten, By Mir. Alan L. Duin8T, Whose Woodeuts Are-Also Worth- Attention. Thei Redfern Gallery The Special Feature Of The Present Eshibition At The Rtedfern Gallery, 27, -Old. Bond-Street, Is A Set Of- Six Wrater-Colours By Jacquier -W,Hich Is The Painting Name Ot An Gungishi Lady-Lluustrating Ariel, The Study - Of Sheuey. By Andr6 Mhaurois. Judging Only By Qtqotations In Reviews, Jacquier Has Caught The Spirit At The Text, And Her Designs, Affectloviqtely Derisive, Are A 4Elight In- Them, Selves Graceful In Rhythmi, Pleasant In Colour, -And Light-Banded In Execution. Byron And His Circus Welcomed - By Guiccioli And Shelley Explains To Some English -Guests That His Clothes Have Beed Washed Away, Are The Two Most Entertaining. Otherwi9E, With The Exceptiorn Of Two Emrphatie Tapestries - By Miss Jean Orage, Fear, Representing Two Chamois- ? Driven By An Irascible -Russian, Designed By A Child, And The 1Owler, Designed By Miss Mabel Royds, And Some Pretty Statuettes. By Mrs. Phcbe Stabler, The Exhibition. Consists Of Etchings, Woodcuts, And Lithographs By A Number Of The Younger Artists. The Wvest Indiamr Etchings By Mr. George 0. Pop Hart Are Highly Original And Moving In Their Play Of Tone, But A Lithograph, The Lunch Hour, Suggests That The Artist Needs A Broader Implement Than The Needle Or Graver To Get- His- Characteristic Effects. To Pick Here And There Among The Other Works, Woman Standing, By Mrs. Edna Clarke Hall. Man And Beast 9Rst State, By Orovida. Ihead Oi A Canadian Woman And Quirks Yard, By Mr. John B. Souter, And Approachin Stoxm, By Miss Vera Ross, Are Alu Excellent Thungs. - M We Regret That By An Unfortunate Error The Late Mrs. Waiter. Donne Wvas Described As Mirs. Walter Doi-E Inu Our Notice Of Her Pictures At Walkers Galleries In The Times Of November 29. The Exhibition, We Learn, Will Remain Onen Until The End Of The Year.

Title: Summer Art Shows
Full_text: Summer Art Shows English And French Paintincs Most Of The Art Galleries Now Arrange Summer Shows To Run Through August And September, And It May Be Of Interest To Indicate What Is To Be Found In Some Of Them. At The Beaux Arts Gallery, Bruton Place, There Are 41 Works By 25 Contemporary Artists, And Though These Last Include Mr. W. Richard Sickert, Explosive In Fireworks, And Sir William Nicholson, Fastidious In Pewter Jug The Special Interest Is, Perhaps, In Choice Things By Younger People. Grey Cranes In The River, By Miss Mildred Eldridge, Brighton Pier, By Miss Susan Palmer, Italian Restaurant, By Mr. Victor Pasmore, And Chrysanthemums And Michaelmas Daisies, By Miss Irene Wyatt, May Be Quoted. The Redfern Gallery, 20, Cork Street, Is Holding A Summer Salon Of French And English Paintings By 44- Artists The Names Of Bonnard, Vuillard, Max Ernst, Mr. David Jones, Mr. Paul Nash And -Miss Ethel Walker Will Suggest- The General Quality And The Range In Styles. At The Galleries Of The Fine Art Society, 148, New Bond Street, There Is An Exhibition Of 130 Early English Water-Colours By 45 Artists, Ranging In Date From Alexander Cozens To E. M. Wimperis.. A Special Feature Is A Collection Of 36 Landscape Drawings, By Edward Lear, Of The Book Of Nonsense.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions Tfie Royal Institute In The One Hundced Ancd Twenty-Third Exhibition. Of The Royal Lnstitute Of Painters In Water Colours3, At 195, Piceadilly, There Seem To Be Nlore Watereolotus Than Usual-Works, That Is To Sax, Wvhich Aitii At Truttlh To Nature In Teriiis Of Water-Colour Painting. This Truttlh In Terms Of The Imediulml Is Not The Whole Of Art, Whichl, Like Poetry Or Imiusic, Must Be, Judged Finally As Comuposition, But It Is A Good Beginning. It Mlakes Art Possible. Thiere Is. Of Course, Another Kinrd Of Tlutlh To Natture, Literal Or Irmitative Truthl, Regardless Of The Medium, And It Is Prevalent In This Exhibition. But It Lands You In An Awkwaicl Predicament. If It Is Accepted As The Basis Of Art You Have To Agree That Many Of The Vworks In The Exhibition Are Better Than Anything Produced Bv Any Of The Old Masters. Rembrandt, For Instance, Never Painted Anvthing So True To Nature In The Imitative Sense As Mrs. George Sutton, By Mr. P. A. Has-, And There Are Several Landscapes Wlhich, By Tile Same Standard, Leave Constable Out Of The Running. It Is Possible, Of Course, That 3Mr. Hay And The Artists Responsible For The Landscapes Ar E Better Artists Than Rembrandt And Constable, But It Seems More Likely That The Kind Of Trutlh In Which They Excel Is Not The Kind That Rembrandt And Const-Able Were Aimiing At. Which Is The Better Kind Of Truth In The Abstract Need Not Be Argued It Is Enough To Say That Truth In Terms Of The Mediunm, Wlich Allows, If It Does Not Compel, Departures From Literal Or Iritative Truth, Seems To Have Been Historically Preferred For Artistic Purposes. If, Instead Of A Painting, You Think Of A Pen Drawing By Rembrandt, The Difference Between The Two Kinds Of Truth Is All The More Apparent. At Any Rate It Is In The Belief That Trutb In Teirns Of The Mediumt Is The More Suitable For Artistic Purposes That This Notice Is Written, And For That Reason-As Well As For Its Graceftul Movement- Dutch Shrimpers, By Miss Miary Meccrossan, Is Preferred To Anything Else In The Exlhibition-Allowing, Of Course, That In An Exhibition Of Nearly 600 Woorks It Is Easy To Overlook Little Masterpieces. The Kind Of Truth Preferred In Water-Colour Is Not, By The Way, Limited To One Style, For Thele Are Several Excellent Things In The Exhiibition That Are Drawings Rather Than Paintings. To Make A Short List Of Works That, In One Way Or Another, Seem To Take Account Of The Medilum In Their Efforts At Truth To Nature There Are Watergate Street, Chester, By Mr. Leonard Squirrcl, A Cup Of Tea, By Miss M. Grace Mead, Colliers End, Herts, By Mir. Alfred H. Hart, Winter Sunshine, Winchelsea, By Mir. George Graham, Autumn In Ken Wood, By Mrs. Emily Tatlow, The Weald Of Sussex, By The Late Mr. Victor Charles Riches-Whlo Died Recently At The Age Of 20- Roses, By Mr. Ronald Gray, Bex Mlill, Cocking, By Miss Veronica Burleigh, Silence, By Miss R. Thurston, Vase Of Flowers, By Miiss Ethel C. Hatch. And Boleigh, By Mirs. Eleanor Hughes. At The Same Galleries There Is The Exlibition Of The Society Of Miniaturists. Going Back To The Old Masters Again, The Best General Criticism Of The Exhibits Is Contained In Tho Recently Read Remark Of Nicholas Hilliard. The Principal Parts Of Painting Or Drawing After The Life Consisteth In Truth Of Lyne It May Be Observed That There Are No Lynes In Nature The Lyn E Withotit Sbadowe Showveth All To Good Judgment, But The Shadowe Without Lync Showeth Nothinlg

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: . Art Exhibitions. ..--- Dkawingb By Sir. B. I Tb Dratrinrs Of Cat Jtere Were Usuallv Made Cn.K N J1 . 1,C T ,. Cvcnlko Master .Ecenury They Were Imitated -In Drawings Which Wore Made For T Own Sae, And Whichi Iff Spite Of Their Cleveraess, Are Cutiously Uninteresting, No Doubt Because Of The .Artificiality Oh-Their Conception. Thev Have A Frac Mentary Look Whiclrwould Bejustified Dnly If They Had Reckless.Vivacity Of Studies, But That Is Just What Fkpv U,Pi- -4 Woll As Too Finish Nf Onffinioto Ere Z Ific Fashion Now In England For Pro- Tho Very Clever, Dtawmgs Of Mr..R.Ihlec, Now To Be Gejx.At The Carfax Gaflcry, Suffer From Fihe Inevitable Weaknesses Of This Practice. They Arc. At The Same Timc Vcry Stylistic, And Yet Often As Fragmentary As H Th Were Rapid Notes Of Fact. Now Styptic - Duties May He Justified In A Finished Picture, Because A- - -V-Cl In V-Hprn. There Ishut S They A V? Much To Bo Said Against Mr. Ihlees Method But W- I Be Fulfilled In More-Finished Works In Many Of His Drawings There Seems To Be A Real Vividness And Spontaneity Only Partly Obscured By His Eclecticism. D Like A Poet Who Has. Sometime To Say But At Present.Can Say It Only In The Xnanner Of Other Poets. His Best- Drawing, Is His Slightest And Least Mannered. In His Girl Reading 22 Although He Reminds Us - - Of Mr. John, He Seems To Have Surprised His Model And She Interests Us For Her Own Sake, Not As An Exercise In Style. In The Group Of Girls Called Give Rile A Drink 26 There Is An Evident Interest In Character Combined With A Desire To Make A Picture At All Costs.. It Is Too Picturesque, But Not Merely -Pipturesque. In Several Of His Drawings Mr. Iblec Is Evidently Influenced By Egyptian Art. His Sonia 16 Reminds One Sharply Of The Princess Nofri. It Is Drawn As It From Sculpture Rather Than From A Living Human Being. In Fact Many Of His Drawings Look As If They Were Quick Studies Of Other Works Of Art, Or As If There Were Some- Alien Artistic Conception Between Him And The Reanty. He Has Yet To Prove Whether He Can Escape From The Commonplace Without The Help Of Such Alien Conceptions. With That Help He Is Already A, Very Promising Student. The Pencil Society. At The Exhibition Of The Pencil Society, Held At Mr. W. Patersons Gafiery In Bond-Street, There Are Draw- Tags By A Number Of Artists In Different Mediums And Styles. Perhaps The Most Interesting- Are Those Of , C T,Xt. . Mt. 8. Spurrier And M,. Joseph Simpson, Both Of Whom Use The Pencil As If It Were The Brush For The Rapid And Precise Statement Of Fact. Both Also Show Remarkable Skill But Their Drawings Look Like Very Sught Pictures Rather Than Studies. Their Figures Arc As Much Posed As If They Were Elaborately Painted Aud They Lack Both The Spontaneity Of A Study And The Finish Of A Complete- Picture. There Is The Same Defect In The Drawings Of Mr. Ferguson, Which Are Called Studies, Yet In Which Facts Arc As Much Manipulated As In A Mosaic Or A Primitive Fresco. The Animal Drawings Of Mr. J. A. Shepherd Show A Strong Japanese Influence But His Line Is More Emphatic- Than Any Japanese Artists,- And Its Emphasis Is. Often Arbitrary. Mr. George Belchers Illustrations Are Only Vaguely Comic. He Has A Sense Of Character,But It Seems To Have Little Reference T? The.Words Which He Illustrates. Interesting Drawings Are Also Shown By Sir Charles Holro Vd And Mr. James Paterson. Some Other Exhibitions. - Further Up The Street,-! The Fine Artsocietys, Are Mr. Wilfrid Balls Attractive Water-Colours, And. At Walkers Gallery The Charming Works Of An Artist Lees Well Known In London, The Little Pictures Of Italy Of Miss Isabel.. Dacre. We Can Call To Mind Few Modem .Painters Who Cah Tender The Different Phases Of Italian Colour With Greater Accuracy Than This Lady, Who Hasevidently Lived Long In The Country And Learned To Love It In All Its Moods And Tenses.. Perugia, Assist, And- Siena Seem, To Be Her Favourite Places, And Her Pictures Of The Hill-Landscapes Around Thpee Cities Are Singularly Faithful. I I

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: -Art Exhibitions.-- Dutch Tiles. The Victoria And- Albert Museum Opens To The Public To-Day An Exhibition Of The Dutch Tiles From The Vis Collection Which Have Been Presented To The-Natioh By Mr. Henry Van Den Bergh Through The National Art-Collections Fund. The Guide-Catalogue Written By Mr. Bernard Rackham Post Free, 10D. Will Be A Great Help To Many In The Enjoyment Of These Fine Specimens Of A Peculiar, Sometimes Beautiful, Sometimes Amusing, Nearly Always Pleasing Art. The Tiles Are Arranged Pretty Nearly In Chronological Order And With The Help Of The Guide We Can Trace The Development From The Tiles Of The Later 16Th Century, When The Art Frst Came To The Low Countries From Italy, To Be Reinforced Later By Influence From Spain, Down To The Later Part Of The 18Th Century. The Earliest Dutch Tiles Were Not Units Their Geometrical And Arabesque Designs, In Blue, Yellow, Brown, And Occasionally Green, In A White Pattern On A Dark Ground, Cannot Be Seen Until At Least Four Are Put Together. The Story Then Becomes That Of The Shrinking Of The Corner Ornament, Until Each Tile Tended To Become A Unit The Coming Of Naturalism In Design, To Replace The Early Formal Conventional Patterns And Very Beautifully Some Of The 17Th-Century Artists Represented Tulips, Or Fritillaries, Or Ships, Or Animals First The Enlargement Of The Colour Scheme,Then Its Gradual Falling-Back Upon Monotone, Either Blue Or Manganese Purple And Then The Treatment Of Tiles As A Field For The Reproduction Of Painted Pictures Or Engravings, Or As Occasions For Original Pictorial Treatment On A Large Scale. All These Periods Are Well Illustrated In Mr. Van Den Berghs Gift, In Which The Tiles Are Never Shown Separately, But Always In Groups. The Dutch Use Of Tiles For The Decoration Of Walls Rather, Than For Floor-Coverings Encouraged, No Doubt, Delicacy And Variety In Treatment And It Is Of Great Interest To Trace Their Development Here From The Rich Formality Of The Earliest Kind To The Exquisite Grace And Fineness Of The 17Th-Century Naturalistic Designs, Thence To The Individually Pictorial Scenes From The Bible, Marine Studies, Shipping Scenes, And The Like, And So On To The Big Pieces Of Many Tiles, Where The Art Declines Through Forgetting Its Origin And Peculiarity. Vincent Van Gogh. The Leicester Galleries Have Secured For Exhibition A Remarkable Collection Of Paintings And Drawings By One Of The Most Remarkable Artists Of The Last Century, Vincent Van Gogh. The Story Of Van Goghs Unhappy Life And Dreadful Death Is Known To Many People But English Lovers Of Art Have Not Before Had The Chance Of Seeing So Large And So Representative A Show Of His Work As This. It Begins With Drawings I And 4, For Instance Admirably Done In The Old Style In The Early Eighteen-Eighties. It Ends Nith The Strange, Frenzied, Whirling Work Of The Last Days In Provence, And In The Asylum At Saint-Remy See No. 34, And The Last Days Of All, At Auvers-Suroise No. 39. And In Between It Shows All The Stages In The Galloping Development Of An Art That Leaped From Aim To Aim And Covered Half-A-Centurys Effort In A Decade An Art That Was A Forerunner And An Influence Hard To Over-Estimate. Van Gogh Is Wel Described By Sir Miichael Sadler In The Catalogue As Preachingfriar Turned Painter. There Is The Same Missionary Zeal In His Painting As There Was. In His Youthful Preaqhing To. The Belgian Miners Of La Borinrge, One Can Trace His Rapid Course From Clarity And Certainty 15, 18, 31 Through Triumphant But Aspiring Conviction. 21, 24, 26 To Spiritual Regions Where He Cannot Easily Be Followed, Regions Where The Definition Of A Straight Line Has Disappeared 39 And He Sees Even A Cypress Tree-To Most Of Us The Very Symbol Of Quiet Certainty And Resigned Confidence-As A Wild Thing Of Spirals And Whorls And Flames 5. It Is Not To Be Supposed That In These Chamois-Like Leaps From Peak To Peak He Always Came To The Rest Of Full Achievemient Bult In Many Of These Pictures There Are The Triumph And .The Beauty Seldom Lacking Some Sort Of Humour Of The Thing Done. Such Are, Especially, Nos. 21, The Portrait Of His Friend, Roulin, The Arles Postman 24, Berceuse, The Postmans Wife, Painted, As Van Gogh Declared, Like A Shop Chrornolithograph, Because It Was Meant For The Iceland Fishermen, At Once Children And Martyrs 25, His Bedroom At Arles A,D, Most Brilliantly Beautiful Of All, 26, One Of The Paintings Of Sunflowers, That He Meant To Put Together As Decoration For The Studio He Was To Share With Gauguin. It Is A Little Ill-Luck, Perhaps, For Mir. E. M. Or. Dickey That He Has An Exhibition In A Room Adjoining That Given To This Giant. On The Other Hand, It May Help To Bring Out All That Is Individual In The Work Of A Young Painter Who Vcry Distinctly Has Style, A Kind Of Quiet Aristocracy Of Vision, And A Suppleness Of Palette And Touch That Makes Him Always And Variously Interesting. Dlesign And Colour In Mr. Dickeys Wvork Are Appropriate And Authentic And In These Landscapes Of Italy, Sussex, And London He Conspicuously Lets The Painting Do Its Own Work, Only Now And Then As In The Painting Of The Railway Lines At Eentish Town, 25 Attempting To Excite Us By Emphasis On Subject. Tee Society Of Wood Engravers. Mr. Dickcy Is One Of The Many Artists Who Contribute To A Striking Little Exhibition Of Wood-Cuts By The Society Of Wood Engravers At .The St. Georges Gallery, 32A, George-Street, Hanoversquare. The Capital Feature Of The Show Is The 10 Woodcuts By Gauguin, Engraved In His South Seas Period, But Only Recently Printed From Blocks In Possession Of His Son. Polynesian, Mystical, Profound, They Strike One As The Woodeuts Of As Painter But Their Veryz Discovery Is An Ev Ent, And Their Artistic Merit Will Be Hotly Discussed. Next To These In Interest We Should Put The Many Masterly Wood Engravings By Mr. John J. A. Mfurphy, Whose Method Is To Cut In The Block Lines Which In The Print Will Be Whzite, And Who More Than Any Other Of The Exhibitors Here Convinces One That He Was Indeed Engraving With A Tool Upon A Block Of Wood. Mr. Eric Gill, Also A True Woodengraver, Sends Some Beautiful Things And Among Other Exhibitors In A Show That No One Who Cares For These Things Must Miss Are Mr. Gordon Craig, Mr. Paul Nash, Mr. John Nash, Miss Gwendolen Raverat, Mr. Robert Gibbings, Mlr. Ethel. Bert White, Mr. Claughton Pellevo, Mr. Lucien Pissarro, And Miss Elinor Lambert. Among The Passengers By The White Star Liner Majestic, Which Arrived At Southampton From New York Yesterday Afternoon, Were Admiral Sir Montague Browning, Brigadiergeneral A. A. Critchley, The Hon. Esmond Harmsworth, Mr. Walter Leat Chairman Of The Westminster Bank, Andlieutenant-Colonel Ralph Isham. Wills And Bequests Will Be Found On Pate 12..
