Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Chelsea Past And Present. To Make Known The Aims And Purpose Of The Chelsea Society, Forrned About Two Months Ago To Protect And Foster The Amenities Of Chelsea, There Has Been Arranged In The Council Chamber At The Townv Hall A Wonderful Exhibition Of Pictures. China. Books, Manuscripts, Tokens, And Other Objects Illustrating Chelsea Past And Present. Probably No Other Quarter Of London Could Provide A Similar Exhibition In Which Historical And Artistic Interest W-Ould Be So Nicely Balanced And Wvhen We Lemember The Namnes Of Turner, Rossetti, Whistler, Eevmour Haden, And R3Argent In The Past-Though Turner, Rossetti, And Largent Do Not Happen To He Repiesented Here-And Mr. Wilson .Iteer, Mr. Frank Brangwyn, Mr. Walter Greaves, And Mllss Ethel Walker In The Piesent, And Also Recau The Fame Of The Cbelsen Porcelain Factory Under Nicholas Sprimont, The Advantages Of Chelsea In This Respect Are Easily Explained. Even To Touch Llponi The Chelsea Worthies Who In One Way Or Another Are Commemorated Here Would Fill Columns, And For The Moment, And In -Iewv Of The Objects Of The Chelsea Society, We May Concentrate Upon The Pictures, Wvhich, After All, Constituto The Major Portion Of The Exhibition. Taken In Orcier Of Time, They Illustrate- Erv Wvell The Tendency Of Art To Pass From The Mainly Topographical To The Mainly Artistic, Even When Dealing Witlh Similar Material, The Extremes Being Marked By Such Irawings As Chelsea Bridge, From Millbank, 1790, By Joseph Farington. R.A.. And Such Paintings As Nocturnle. By Whistler, And The River At Chelsea, By Mlr. Wilson Steer. Thc Facts Are, So To Speak, Dissolved. But The Atimosplhere Is Retained. Not That The Older Artists Were Purely Topographlical Lllost Of Themit Were Composers. And In Sueh Pictures As Tihe Old Chelsea Biui House Bv Pugin. And Chelsea. 1812, By John Varley, We Have Delightful Works Of Art Irrespective Of Wvhat They Happen To Represent. Nor Do All The Modern Artists Find It Impossible To Combine A Pious Concern For The Facts With An Artistic Aim, And One Of The Most Interesting Feattures Of The Exhibition Is The Collection Of About 70 Water-Colour And Other Drawings Bv Mr. Walter Greaves. In This Connexion We Cannot Forbear Quoting The Words Of Tho Late Tr. Clutton-Brock In The Timncs In His Notice Of The Exhibition Which Startled London In May, 1911- Whbistler Definies Only For The Sake Of His Design. Mr. Greiivai Defines Because He Loves Every Timber In Flhe Bridge An Yet Hlis Design Is Almost As Fine As Vhistlers And Almost As Predoniinant. Lie Is Not A Painter Of Moods, Like Whietler, I Ut A Painter Of Things In W-Hich Lie Is Profoundly Interested, Lik.- De Hoogh. From A Chelsea Point Of View, And As R-Epresenting What, To A Considerable Extent, May Still Be Protected And Fostered, . These Drawings-Which Are For Sale-And The Photographs Of Old Chelsea Taken Between 1860 And 1870, By J. Hedderlev, Are Perhaps The Niost Valuable Part Of The Exhibition. This Is Not To Say That The More Purely Artistic Exercises By Living And Recent Artists Will Not Serve A Similar End By Different Means, And In Looking At Thie Thames, Chelsea, By Cecil Lawson, New Battersea Bridge, By Charles Conder, Evening Chelsea Reach, By Mr. Wv. G. De Clehn, Chicyne Wvalk, By Mr. Randolph Schwabe. And Flood-Street At 4 A.M., By Mr. 0. P. Jaeomb-Hood. To Name Onlv A Few Of The Pict Ures. We Are Persuaded Of Amenities As Well As Of Pictorial Effect. The Chel.Sea Porcelain Faetor-V Is Represented By A Ca-E Of Magnificent Pieces, Illustratinig The Four Suecessive Periods Distinguished Hv Marks, And The Revival Of The Tradition Is Shown In The Charming Little Figures Bv Mliss O3Wendolen. Parnell And Mr. Vayse. Historv, As Distinet From Art, Is Not Neglected. The King Has Lent The Bronze Pass For The Kiings Pirivate Road, Chelsea, Issued By Order Of King George 11. In 1737, Which Was Presented To Him On Hiis Landing At Adogan Pier, August 4, 1919, Andl There Are Iiteresting Relies Of The Carlyles And Other Famous Inhabitants. M. Segon-Zac. Somebody Once Said That 31. Andrei Dunoyer De Segonzac, To Gixve Him His Full Name, Whose Paintings. Drawings. And Etchinigs Fill Both The Alpine Chb Gallery, 3Mill-Street, Conduit-Street. Atnd The 1Idependenit Gallery, Gcrafton-Strect, Paints Like A Lauded Proprietor, And There Is A Considerable Amount Of Truth In The Jesl That Is To Say, M. -Segonzac Paints Landscape With The Extragartistic Understanding Which Is Commoner In England Than In France, As Well As With The Artistic Understanding Which Is, On The Whole, Commoner There Than Here. At The Alpine Club Gallery, Where The Oil Paintings Are Assembled, You Havea Pronounced Feeling Of Tweeds, Thick Boots-Not Without Soil Upon Them-Pipes, And Dogs At Your Heels. At The Same Time It Would Be Straining The Truth To Say That M. Segonzac Paints Like An Englishman He Paints Rather As You Feel An Englishman Ought To Paint If He Combined With His Love Of The Country A French Feeling For Pictorial Order And It Is Not Extravagant To Say That, In His Contentment With Large, Simple Masses And A Limited Range Of Colour, There Is A Certain Atfinity Between M. Segonzac And John Crome. Though He Does Not Disdain Trees, He Is Pre-Eminently A Painter Of Earth. Largeness Of Design And Robustness Of Handling Are The Thiigs That Strike You First In The Oil Paintings. With A Similar Number Of Pictures The Alpine Club Gallery Has Never Looked So Completely Furnished. It Is Likely That M. Segonzacs Handling, Much Of It Done With The Palette Knife, Will Be The Difficulty Wvith People Who Come To Him For The First Time But When It Is Observed That The Paint, Though Thick And Rough, Is Well Organized And Supremely Well Related In Scale Of Handling To The Size Of The Picture, What Was A Barrier May Well Become A Link To Syinpathy. Particularly When There Is Felt The Uncommon Consistency As Between The Colour And The Substance Of Pigment Which Is One Of The Most Characteristic Virtues In The Work Of M. Segonzac. Since Chardin, And Our Own Morland, One Cannot Think Of Any Other Painter Who Puts You On Such Comradely Terms-More Masculine Than The Terms Induced By M. Matisse-With The Actual Materials Of Which Pictures Are Made. The Paintings Are Not All Landscapes, Hut Inclulde Figure And Still-Life Compositions, But It Is Probable That The Landscapes Will Have The Most General Appeal. For One Thing-And It Is By No Means Unimportant In The Actual As Distiiet Froni The Theoretical Appreciation Of Art-.Nost Of Them Induce The Feeling Of Comfortable Weather Mild, Moist Weather, With A South-Westerly Wind, If Any, When Colours Deepen And There Are Earthy Scents In The Air. Like Everybody Else Of His Age-He Was Born In 1884-M. Segonzac Has Responded To The Influence Of Cezanne, But More Than Most He Has Embodied The Influence In His Own System Of Painting. His Designs Are Completely Clothed. The General Development To Be Noted Is That From A Brown Tonality To The More Positive Hues Of Nature, But Always With The Sacrifice Of Minor Variations In Favour Of A Simple Scheme. If Individual Landscapes Nmst Be Named. Wve Should Pick Out La Ferme Dans Les Terres And Paysage Aux Toits Rouges, Among The Earlier, And Le Pont De Joinville, No. I,, La Foret, And Paysage De Provence, Among The Later, As Representing M. Segonzac At His Best. Each Of These Pictures Would Lend Itself To Elaborate Analysis, But It Will Be More To The Point To Give A Few Words To Les Canotiers. A Large Composition Of Landscape With Figures, Because It Seems To Hint A New Development. Strongly Side-Lit, And With A Very Active Movement In The Direction Of Its Lines, It Is Emotional In A New Way-By Direct Attack Rather Than By Conveyance. It Is An Agitating Composition, And Those Xvho Saw The Work Of M. Dutfresne At The Lefevre Galleries Will Feel In It A Certain Affinity With The Work Of That Painter. But With The Weightier Control Peculiar To M. Segonzac. This Picture Also Points The Wisdom Of Not Neglecting The Drawings At The Independent Gallery. Because There Will Be Founid Among Them Several Studies, All More Or Less Different, For The Figures In The Canoe. They Show How Thoroughly M. Segonzac Prepares Himself For His Attack Upon The Canvas, And There Are Other Drawings- Les Tartanes And Le Couple Are Good Examples-Which.Show That He Can Be Graceful As Well As Robust. Owing To Misinformation. In The Notice Of His Exhibit-Ion At The Brook-Street Art Galleriee In The Times Of 3Jay 30 Mr. F. Lenhart Was Described As A Swiss Artist Of Austrian Descent. Mr. Lenhart Wishes It To Be Known That. Of Austrian Birth, He Is By Residence Italian.

Full_text: Art Exhibitions. Messes. Shepherds Gallery. This Little Gallery In King-Street, St. Jamess, Continues To Bo The Home Ok Interesting Old English Painters, While It Also Hospitably Entertains A Few Foreign Guests Of Importance. One Does Not Expect To Find Here The Greatest Works Of The Great Men, But Several Of Them Are None, The Less Represented. , - And Artists Of The Calibre Of Lely, Michael Dahl, And Tilly Kettle Are .To Be Seen In Force. Some Of The Lelys Are Particularly Fine, And Evidently His Own Work And Not That Of His Assistants, While The Sir Thomas Twisden, Attributed To Michael Dahl, Is A Superb Example Of The Portraiture Of Kneuers Time, R Is A Little Difficult To Identify The Sitter, For Sir Thomas, The Judge, Died In 1683, A Little Too Early For This Eture, And His Son And Successor Was Called Bogor, Not Thomas But Perhaps This Is Only Importent To Monographers. Of An Corfier Date Ma. Fine Head Of Cromwell, Apparently By A French Pinter, Msenbed On The Back L Tapitamo Cromvd A 1050 1 And Another Small Portrait Historical Interest Is A Grille Of Garnck, By R-Le. Or Probably. Zoffany. A Pair Of Cabinet Scapes By Richard Wilson Are Unusuauy Bright Examples Ot This First Ot The Great And Afterthem May Be Named A. Woodland Scene By John Creme, And Two Smaff 5 B? Inst And Chief Of Afl Ar0 A E Copy By Gainsborough Of The Senheim Charles I. By Vandyck, Now M Lted Jritlh Probability To J Three Or Four Years Ago There Was Another Very Noble Version Of The Same Charles I. We Thought It Older Than Gainsborough, But About The Present Example Dubs Works, Of Which There Are A Few Downstairs, One Will Interest The Older Generation Is The Fourpanel Picture Of The Parable Of The Sower, Hy A Dose Follower Of The Pre-Raphaelites, Larpent Roberts. Reproductions Of This Careful Piece Ok Interpretative Tion Or More Ago. . --

Title: Art Exhibitions
Full_text: I Art Exhibitions Mural Decorations Both On General Grounds-As A Sensible Emplovment Of Young Artists-And For The Taste And Judgment W Itlh Which The Wvork Has Been Carried Out, A Wvord Is Due To The Miural Paintings By Miss Dorotlhy Cohen Atnd Miss W. Hardinarn In St. Peters Church, Huarlmersnith, Xvhich L Ere Unveiled On May 18 By Sir George Clausen, R.A. Details Of The Gift And Dedication Avere Given In The Timles Of May 19. Like The Regency-Square Named After It St. Peters Is An Interesting Building, Dating From 1829. The Name Of The Architect Is Wvanting, But The Church, With Its Ionic Colonnade At The West Front, Bears A Famiily Resenmblance To St. Peters, Eaton-Square, Designed By Hakewill And Consecrated In 1827, And St. Peters, Wvalvorth-Road, Designed By Soane And Completed About 1825. It Is Planned In The Wren Tradition Of A Sermon Hall, With A Gallery And No Chancel, And It Is Remarkable Architecturally For The Wide Span Of The Panelled Ceiling, Which Is Suspended From The Roof Timbers. Under The Advice Of The Late Sir W. B. Richmond, R.A., The Church Wvas Re-Decorated Some Tinme Ago Iii A Scheme Of Buff And Dull Pink, Running Down The Scale To A Reddish Brown. In All That Concerns Relation To The Building And The Colour Scheme Indicated, And In General Composition, The Wall Paintings Are Excellent. They Are Carried Out For The Most Part In Light Tints, Preserving The Surface Of The Wall But Giving A Sufficient Suggestion Of Depth. The Subjects, The Call Of St. Peter And St. Peter Preaching On The Day Of Pentecost, Are Well Illustrated, Without Being Made Unduly Dramatic. On The Whole The Landscape And Architectural Surroundings Strike One As Being Better Thani The Figures, Wliich Might With Advantage Have Had A More Formal Style Of Drawing-More, For A Rough And Ready Illustratiol, Of The Style Of The Raphael Cartoons. The Desire To Avoicd A Conventional Interpretation Of The Subjects Is Understandable. Butsilnce There Is No Attempt To Translate Them Into Couteinhiorary Terms-The Artistic Convention Suggested By The Classical Character Of The Buildinig Wvould Have Been The Right Onie. It Is For General Conception, Colour Scheme And Relation-With Admirable Modesty And Restraint-To The Effect Of The Interior As A Whole That The Paintings Are To Be Praised. Walkers Galleries Of The Water-Colour Drawings Of Flowers And Landscape By Miss Katharhiie Cameron At Walkers Galleries, 118, New Bond-Street, It Can Be Said That They Show, First Of. All, Complete Sympathy With Their Subjects. Flowers, In -Particular, Are Treated By Miss Cameron With A Tender Humour Which Makes Her Work Immediately Recognizable. In Addition, She Lhas Taste And Judgment In Arrangement-Niaking The Design Suit The Character Of The Flowers-And An Exceedingly Good Style Of Water-Colour Painting. Her Flower Studies In This E-Hibition Divide Themselves Roughly Into Three Classes Coloured Drawvings, Putting The Emphasis Uponi Botainical Structure Anid Decorative Arrangement Paintings Which, Though They Are In Colour, Are Conceived Priinarily As Exercises In Tone And Works In Full Colour, Comisidered For Decorative Effect. Personally We Greatly Prefer The First Class, And The Chief Pleasures For Us In The Exhibition Are In Such Studies As Flowers Of April, Vildflowers Of September, And Bluebells Of Scotland Ii. Next Come The Studies In Toiie, With Their Effect Of Reserve And Mystery, Such As White Roses, Hoiieysuckle Ii., And September Rose. Less To Our Taste Are The Paintings, Mostlv Of Roses, In Full Colour-Not Because The Colours Are Too Bright, In Thenmselves, But Because They Seem To Escape Comparatively From The Control Which Distinguishes The Tone Studies. But Allowrance Must Be Made For Every Kind Of Taste, And Flowers Of February In Mediaeval British Jug Is A Gallant Thing. In Landscape One Is Aware Of Miss Camerons Powers As A Drauglitswomani. Here Again There Is A Tendency-Is It A Scottish Characteristic ?-Of Brighter Colours To Get Out Of Hand, And Preference Goes To Works Like The Old House At Bignor And Moonrise Behind St. Giles, Edinburgh. At Tle Same Galleries There Is An Exhibition Of Paintings By Mr. Tom Van Oss And Conimander Denis Fildes. Hung Together, They Are Strongly Contrasted In Style, Illr. Van Oss Being Broad And Loose In His Methods, Reflecting Continental Inifluences, While Commander Fildes Seems To Niodel Himself On The English Marinie Painters Of The Eighteenth Century. Apart From Anything Else, The Contrasts Aiid Occasional Correspondences In This Exhibition Are Most Amusing. As A Figure Painter Mr. Van Oss Excels In An Informal Kiiid Of Portraiture, And Earl Grey And His Daughters Playing Chess At Howick Is One Of His Best Pictures. But All His Work Has An Attractively Free-And-Easy Manner, With Great Variety Of Subject And A Vivid Realization Of Light. As A Composition Quai Comnbet, Villefranche, Leaves Little To Be Desired. Home Fromi The Indies Is A Typical Painting By Commander Fildes, Careful And Orderly And Full Of Nautical Knowledge. That Lie Is Not Tied To One Class Of Subject Is Showvn By The Excellent Still-Life Painitings Of ,The Gardeners Basket And White Phlox.

Author: Null
Title: Art Exhibition
Full_text: Art Exhibition. Mr. Henry Bishops Work. To Speak Of The Paintings Bv Mir. Henry Bishop At The Galleries Of Messrs. Spink And Son, King-Street. St. Jamess, As Highly Tinished Might Convey A Wrong Impression, Beeause They Are Anything But Laboured. They Are Finished, Rather, In The Sense Of Being Completed, By Extreme Seleetion Beforehand Of What To Paint And A Method Of Execution Which Is At The Same Time Subtle And Deliberate. They Give The Impression That From The First Conception Of The Subject The Artist Knows Exactly Where The Last Touch Is To Be Laid And Touch Is Added To Touch With A Delicate Precision Which Leaves Nothing To Be Smoothed Away. Mr. Bishop, Who Is Best Known By. His Paintings Of The White-Walled Cities And Villages Of North Africa, Has An Exquisitely Fine Sense Of Relations Of Both Forms And Colour Values, And It Is In His Management Of Them That The Charm Of His Pictures Chiefly Resides. A Street In Carrara And Red Palace Are Not The Best Pictures In His Exhibition, But They Have A Special Interest As Showing His Capacity To Make The Most Of Very Simple Material. In The Former.The Picture Is Made By The Nice Relation Of The Pink House To The Grey On One Side And The Buff On The Other, And By The Relation Of The Window Openings And The Angle Of The Kerb To The Oblong Of The Picture Area In The Latter It Is The Exact Width Of The Canal And The Direction Of The Causeways Which Makes The Difference Between A Mere Representation And A Picture. These Fine Adjustments, Though Not So Obviously, Are To Be Traced In All His Work. One Would Be Inclined To Sav That The Most Elaborate Of Mr. Bishops Paintings, Ei Early Morning In Tetuan, Was Also The Best, Because In It The Relations And Adjustments Are Carried Out In A Condition Of Light Which Demands An Almost Breathless Attention Bv The Painter, But Between The Walls, The Ferrv. Rabat, And Mouth Of The Thames Run It Very Close Indeed. Perhaps The Best Tribute To The Work Of Mr. Bishop Is That, At A First Glance, It Makes The Two Portraits By Mir. Augustus John. Miss Iris Tree And Amiss Pettigrew, Which Are Hung With It, Look Rather Coarse And Crude And It Needs A Readjustment Of The Vision To See That The Effect Is Due Only To More Emphatic Statement And A Larger Scale Of Intervals In The Painting.
